                               Messenger-Inquirer

                          November 24, 2005, Thursday

Lighthouse loan application denied

BYLINE: By David Blackburn

LENGTH: 716 words



When Lighthouse Recovery Inc. was denied funds to help build a men's
substance-abuse recovery center in April, it was told a few minor errors on the
online application were to blame.

Lighthouse president J.D. Meyer, after talking to Federal Home Loan Bank of
Cincinnati then, thought approval would be likely in the September application
period, he said Wednesday.

So, Meyer couldn't explain the latest denial for Affordable Housing Program
funds to build a 100-bed, 28,000-square-foot facility at Veach Road and Higdon
Lane.

"I'm disappointed but not discouraged," said Meyer, who plans to re-apply in
April.

The Kentucky Housing Corp. and First Security Bank of Owensboro, the local
Federal Home Loan Bank member through which Lighthouse is applying, are still
supportive of the local effort, he said.

"What this means is instead of starting construction in May or June, it will be
September or October of 2006," Meyer said.

Meyer learned of the denial Tuesday in a Nov. 17 letter from Carol Peterson,
senior vice president of the Federal Home Loan Bank, to him and First Security
president John Edge.

The agency received 109 applications requesting $ 26.6 million and suggested 50
of them for approval to the next step, the letter said.

"Your application for the Owensboro Regional Recovery project met the threshold
and was scored," she wrote. "However, the available funds were exhausted before
your application could be included among those recommended for funding."

"I was surprised when I heard that," said Mike Townsend, Housing Corp.
supportive housing program administrator and Recovery Kentucky program
coordinator, in Frankfort.

"I had the same impression, that they were in good hands," Townsend said. "I
felt they were going to be a good candidate for (funding)."

Recovery Kentucky wants to create six men's and four women's facilities to offer
peer-based help for addicts, he said. Thus far, no community in the state has
moved forward with a facility.

"We're still in need for more men's facilities," he said. "Owensboro would be a
key location for western Kentucky."

The project's application scored a 59.5 out of 100, which was about what it
scored in April, Meyer said.

The application received the maximum number of points for income targeting,
promoting empowerment, providing housing for homeless households and meeting
special needs.

It got nearly all of the maximum points for community stability (5 of 7) and
project sponsorship (4 of 5).

But it got only 2 of 6 possible points for subsidy per unit created, which deals
with how efficiently the money is used.

And it scored only 4.5 of 15 points for member financial partnership, although
First Security "did everything they could to get us as many points as we could,"
Meyer said.

Some bank employees have said they would help landscape the site, he added.

The application received no points since it is not located in Appalachia, isn't
going to be on donated or conveyed land, won't be for first-time home buyers and
qualifies as neither urban nor renewal housing.

Lighthouse has a purchase agreement with board member Corine Hedden for the
facility site, Meyer said.

It is close enough to take advantage of resources, but is in the county so as
not to affect the city's Section 8 voucher availability, Meyer said.

But it doesn't qualify as being rural housing because Daviess County's
population is too large, he said.

Until April, Meyer said, "We're going to work with people at the Federal Home
Loan Bank and Kentucky Housing Corp. to make sure our application is approved."

He plans to work with other communities that have been funded to learn how to
improve the local chances of approval.

The delay "just means the light at the end of the tunnel is still on," Meyer
said. "It's just the hallway got a little longer.

"We've just got to be patient."

                      Coventry Evening Telegraph (England)

                            July 25, 2007 Wednesday
                                Nuneaton Edition

'Affordability' issue highlighted

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 123

LENGTH: 398 words


A WARWICKSHIRE developer has welcomed Gordon Brown's call to build three million
new homes across the country by 2020 - but says a radical look at improving
affordability is vital to ease the housing crisis.

Ken Linfoot, chairman and chief executive of Great Alnebased Linfoot Homes, says
the new Prime Minister's proposals are a step in the right direction.

But he says merely setting targets to increase house building is one thing -
actually achieving that output and ensuring people can afford to buy the new
homes requires drastic action.

Mr Linfoot has drawn up an seven-point plan to help ease the financial burden of
home ownership and help more young people to get a foot on the property ladder.

He suggests the following measures: The stamp duty threshold should be raised to
pounds 200,000.

Mortgage tax relief for first time buyers should be reintroduced.

Lower fixed rate mortgages should be encouraged for first time buyers and for
longer periods of time.

Proposals for the introduction of a planning gain land tax should be dropped.

The development of brownfield sites should be allowed irrespective of location.

Sites should be identified in all small towns and villages for small-scale
development for sale to "local" people - that definition to include those who
live within a reasonable distance of the homes being built and people moving
into the area to work.

Where homes are sold to locals there should not be any insistence that future
sales are restricted only to those in the area, to avoid complications.

Mr Linfoot has been a strong campaigner for releasing additional land to provide
homes for "ordinary" families who want decent, well-designed homes with gardens
and enough space for their children.

He recently issued a plea to planners and parish councils to release small
pockets of land for housing in rural areas - both for social housing and for
people wanting to buy homes in villages and small towns.

His company, which he runs with his wife Helen and daughter Claire Linfoot
McLean, is behind a recent, small "affordable homes" development in Long
Compton, using local materials, on land which would otherwise not have been
released for housing.

The scheme, Knights Court, was the first of its kind to be developed under a
Stratford District Council initiative to enable local people to remain in their
own villages.

For more information visit www.linfoothomes.co.uk

                  The State Journal-Register(Springfield, IL)

                            February 11, 2001 Sunday

SHA banking on $35 million investment ;
 Officials hope neighborhood sparks revitalization

BYLINE: JOHN REYNOLDS STAFF WRITER

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. 5

LENGTH: 401 words


When the John Hay Homes were built a little over 60 years ago, the final cost of
the cramped, barracks-style apartment complex was $2.7 million.

Since then, the cost of affordable housing has gone up. The estimated cost of
the Madison Park Place Development, for example, is $35 million.

Officials at the Springfield Housing Authority say that figure includes more
than just the infrastructure at the 33-acre site and the cost of building the
150 rental units and 44 lease-to-own homes. Madison Park Place, according to
officials, is envisioned as the spark that ignites a flurry of revitalization
throughout the east side neighborhoods.

Jacqueline Richie, project manager for the SHA, said construction of the rental
units cost about $17.8 million. The lease-to-own homes came to about $6.9
million.

The figures include infrastructure costs such as roads, streetlights and sewer
lines.

The other $10 million was spent on architectural, engineering and legal fees.

Funding for the project came from a variety of sources:

* $12.2 million from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's Hope
6 program. The Hope 6 project created a pool of federal money for local housing
authorities to reconfigure troubled apartment complexes. Madison Park Place
apparently is the first Hope 6 project to be completed in Illinois.

* $12.2 million from LR Development, a private company that was brought in to
develop and manage the rental units.

* $7 million from other funds, such as Illinois Housing Development Authority
loans, federal loans and local funds.

* About $3. 2 million is expected to be raised from the eventual sale of the 44
homes.

Even though Madison Park Place has replaced the John Hay Homes, the old housing
project will not be completely forgotten.

Bill Logan, executive director of the Springfield Housing Authority, said the
original, 60-year-old dedication plaque from the Hay Homes will be installed at
Madison Park Place's park.

After all, even though the last years of the old development were less than
ideal, the homes were a part of Springfield's history, and thousands of good,
solid people - including police officers and at least one mayor - came through
the Hay Homes, Logan said.

"The John Hay Homes meant a lot to a many families in Springfield," Logan said.
"We don't want people to forget that."

                              The Washington Post

                   September 8, 1983, Thursday, Final Edition

Occoquan Seeks $350,000 U.S. Loan To Help Build Waterfront Restaurant

SECTION: Virginia Weekly; Cities & Towns; Va. 6

LENGTH: 160 words


The town of Occoquan is applying for a $350,000 federal loan to help develop a
$1.4 million private waterfront restaurant, part of a marina complex being built
on the Occoquan River between I-95 and Rte. 1.

The planned Pier 5 Restaurant, about a half mile downriver from the historic
Prince William County town, would be completed by fall 1984 if the grant money
is approved, Richard Krauss, the project's major developer, said this week.

Krauss, who is developing a $1.1 million marina complex on the site, also owns
the Sea Sea Restaurant and the Prince William Marina, which are located within
the town limits.

The federal loan to finance the new restaurant, proposed to be built in the
Victorian style of Occoquan buildings and seat 300 persons, would come from the
$440 million in Urban Development Action Grants of the U.S. Department of
Housing and Urban Development. HUD has earmarked 25 percent of the grants for
small cities and towns.

                                  The Business

                                August 14, 2005

CHERYL TAYLOR

BYLINE: Cheryl Taylor

LENGTH: 983 words


The cost of cleaning up brownfield sites, coupled with up-front development
costs and increased affordable housing requirements, have taken their toll on
urban land values. Their price growth has been below that of greenfield land for
five years.

Now, with static sale prices and the slump in off-plan sales on new build flats,
urban land values look set to fall by 3% in 2005, according to research from
estate agent Savills.

Driving this drop in land values is declining developer confidence in the face
of sluggish sales and mounting development costs. Such problems do not affect
greenfield sites, where costs are lower, sales rates are higher and there is a
scarcity value, say Savills, who expect continued demand for this type of land
in 2005, resulting in price rises of 5% by the end of the year.

Yolande Barnes, head of Savills research department points out there will be
wide variations around the average fall in urban land values: "Some good sites
will hold their value, but under certain circumstances, we would expect to see
far more significant value falls."

Circumstances that would exacerbate a fall in land values include high levels of
unsold, new build supply, low quality land, site contamination, uncertainty
about planning permission and onerous affordable housing requirements.

"Any one of these factors will have a more negative impact on land values than a
softening of the market alone. A combination of these would mean that we would
expect to see significant value drops way above the -3% forecasted nationally,"
says Barnes.

Good sites in prime locations, where planning permission has been secured and
where demand for new flats remains relatively strong, are expected to hold their
value.


More farm land for sale

THERE is more agricultural land on the market than at any time over the past
three years, as many farmers opt to sell after the end of uncertainty over
Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) reform.

Since the deadline for CAP reform on 16 May, commercial and residential farmland
has become more available, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered
Surveyors (RICS). This raises concerns that this could flood the market and hit
prices in the year ahead, says RICS.

Prices fell for the second consecutive quarter, having reached a record high at
the end of 2004. Prices slipped back 3% from their peak, but are still up by 10%
over the year to the second quarter, compared to a 16% rise in the first
quarter. Bare land prices - land that is not farmed, such as moorland - continue
to rise, seeing an increase of 14% over the past year.

The slowing is most apparent for residential farmland, due to the negative
impact of interest rate rises and a cooling housing market. But overall demand
remains firm, according to the survey.

Non-farming individual buyers' activity rose in the second quarter, although
their purchase levels have dropped significantly over the past 18 months, as the
housing market slows. The share of rural land bought by agricultural businesses
reached 8%, its highest level yet, but purchases by independent farmers fell.

Surveyors still predict price rises over the coming year, though these have
become less optimistic as a sluggish economy is likely to restrain demand.
Commercial farms are expected to see slight price falls. Over the past year,
prices rises have slowed across the county, though the South East and South West
are still showing double digit gains. Prices remain largely unchanged in
Yorkshire & Humberside, North West, Wales and Scotland.

According to RICS rural spokesperson Julian Sayers: "The greater availability of
land indicates a period of increased market activity in the year ahead. However,
the wider economic slowdown and subdued housing market will temper demand.
Nevertheless, it is encouraging that surveyors are yet to report a fall in
demand as interest in the rural lifestyle is still strong."


Student squeeze helps knock £17,000 off house price prediction

The price of an average UK house will be over £335,000 by 2025, compared with
£163,335 in 2005, according to the latest report on Housing Futures from the
Centre for Economics and Business Research (CEBR). This may sound like a strong
performance by property, but this estimate is £17,000 below the CEBR's
prediction made a year ago. The CEBR forecasts average annual house price
inflation between 2005 and 2025 of 3.95%, not 4.15%.

Managing director Mark Pragnell, says the main reason for the change is because
the CEBR has reduced its estimate for the number of households in the UK in
2025, from 29,336,000 to 29,676,000, reflecting a lower forecast for immigration
over the next 20 years. The financial pressure on young adults from student
loans will also have an effect.

According to the latest (2003/3) education department survey, 92% of final year
students had debts, owing an average of more than £9,500: "This will only get
worse as the government strives to achieve its target of 50% participation in
higher education, and ever-tighter finances in the university sector," says
Pragnell.

"We expect the rate of household formation to be held back as young people stay
at the parental home for longer, or share flats. So, we have adjusted our
forecast for the increase in the number of UK households over the next 20 years
to 13.6%, from 14.2%."

Pragnell remains sceptical about the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister's
attempts to ease the planning process for house building, but considers the
degree of under-achievement will be less than reckoned a year ago. The CEBR
forecast average annual house building running at slightly higher levels, at
204,000, rather than 199,000:

"The difference might sound trivial, but over the years to 2025 it will amount
to 100,000 extra homes, altering the supply-demand balance," he says.

                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                             June 20, 2006 Tuesday
                                 State Edition

Ashland, Van Buren receive grants to help fund local projects;
County gets money for labor database

BYLINE: BEURMOND BANVILLE OF THE NEWS STAFF

SECTION: Pg. B3

LENGTH: 427 words

DATELINE: CARIBOU


Ashland, Van Buren and Aroostook County have received grants from the United
States Department of Agriculture and the Department of Housing and Urban
Development to assist with housing programs and to update a survey of employees
and employers in Maine's northernmost county.

The Ashland Housing Corp. has been given a grant of $391,215 for its housing
needs, Van Buren is receiving $346,500 and Aroostook County will get $180,000,
according to Sens. Olympia Snowe and Susan Collins.

The money comes from nearly $4.5 million distributed throughout the state by the
two federal agencies.

The Economic Development Initiative money can only be used in projects where
Section 108 Loan Program money is used.

"This funding will help provide vital opportunities for rural Mainers to enhance
community services and health care facilities and boost economic growth in areas
that need it the most," the two senators wrote in a joint statement. "Many
Americans aspire to own their own home and funding provided by the Department of
Housing and Urban Development can often help make that dream a reality."

Daniel Lapointe, community development director at Van Buren, said the grant is
part of the package for infrastructure work at the town's regional business
park.

The grant is one of three sources of funding. Van Buren also received $499,800
from USDA Rural Development and $150,000 from the state's Municipal Investment
Trust Fund.

The entire project is just shy of $1 million. It will pay for sewer and water
line installation, construction of a road to the site, and the installation of
other needed utilities.

The regional business park, located near the town's Gateway School, will have
five lots for business and industrial use.

Lapointe said the town is now in the design phase and officials hope that
construction will begin in the fall. They are awaiting Maine Department of
Environmental Protection permits for the project.

In Ashland, the money will be used to rehabilitate a 32-year-old housing
project. The 24-unit project, known as Forest View Circle Apartments, according
to Shawn Pelletier of CS Management Inc., is owned by the Ashland Housing Corp.

Officials hope to start the rehabilitation project around Aug. 1.

The work includes roof and siding work, windows, electrical and plumbing
components, heating upgrades, the remodeling of kitchens and some earthwork.

The Aroostook County money will be used to update surveys of the county's labor
force. The data will be integrated into a database maintained by the Maine
Department of Labor and the U.S. Census Bureau.

                              The Herald (Glasgow)

                                January 13, 1995

Plan for green-belt housing approved despite protests

BYLINE: Audrey Gillan

SECTION: Pg. 3

LENGTH: 467 words


A PLAN to build houses on a green-belt site in Monklands was given the go-ahead
last night in spite of protests from locals, environmentalists and Strathclyde
Regional Council.

The application by SL Homes to build on farmland at Bargeddie on the outskirts
of Glasgow was recently at the centre of an investigation by the local authority
accounts commission.

It followed a disclosure under parliamentary privilege that a loan had been made
by the company, run by ex-Celtic director Mr Brian Dempsey, to a family firm
associated with Mr Jim Brooks, the leader of Monklands District Council, but no
further action was taken.

Last night, councillors on the district planning and development committee
followed a recommendation by the director of planning, Mr David Cooper, and
voted unanimously in favour of accepting the application, subject to conditions.

The plans are in breach of Strathclyde Regional Council's green-belt plans and
contravene guidelines to discourage building in the countryside.

The council brushed aside the recommendation from the region's director of
physical planning advising them to refuse the application from the building
company for the 45-acre site.

The decision was met with outrage from the Monklands Green Belt Protection Group
who submitted more than 500 letters of objection and attended the meeting last
night.

Group secretary Miss Maureen Somerville said local people felt they had been
fobbed off by the council. "Bargeddie means settlement in green fields in
Gaelic," said Miss Somerville. "They are just about to pour concrete all over
those green fields."

The group's prime objection was the danger of increased traffic because of the
site's proximity to an accident blackspot which has seen 18 deaths in 20 years.
Other objections included the site's drainage problems -- it is subject to
flooding -- and the threat to the rural environment which is inhabited by a
variety of different wildlife species.

Many of the group's members live on Bargeddie's main road and their views on to
open fields and the Campsies will be obstructed.

The council argued that the SL Homes development would solve the area's
population loss problems which have arisen from low levels of private house
building. Mr Cooper's report said: "In his reply to my letter, the regional
director of physical planning notes clearly that he cannot support any
application for green-belt release on either strategic (green-belt) planning
grounds or in terms of local housing need.

"Irrespective of the views of the regional council in this regard, I am
nonetheless wholly satisfied that a convincing case can be made for a limited
and controlled green-belt release."

The plans now go to the region which can refuse or rubber stamp them.

                          The Journal (Newcastle, UK)

                           November 3, 2011 Thursday

We Need To Build More Homes Now

BYLINE: Angela Upex

SECTION: A; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 975 words


ISN'T it about time the Government sorted out our broken housing market in the
North East?

As your piece on Tuesday clearly showed  (76,950 waiting for social housing
Journal, November 1), there are thousands of families being forced to wait years
for social housing.

Most people simply can't afford a 25% mortgage deposit or to get a mortgage at
all for the very high house prices we see in most areas. Renting from private
landlords is expensive and is predicted to rise between 15% and 20% over the
next five years.

This all means that too many families are suffering the hardship of
overcrowding. Some are even being forced to live apart.

At Isos, one of the region's biggest social landlords, we are doing our best to
make a difference.

We own 12,000 affordable homes in the region and last year we built another 206
desperately-needed new homes.

We build in both urban and rural areas like Cleadon Park in South Shields, and
Newbiggin Hall in Newcastle as well as Hexham, Corbridge and as far afield as
Falstone near Kielder, Lesbury near Alnwick and Beadnell on the north
Northumberland coast.

Yet we, and other housing associations like us, know it's nowhere near enough.

Every day we see the damaging impacts of housing shortage on families and single
people across the region who need an affordable place to live.

So we're supporting the National Housing Federation's call for the Government to
look again at how affordable housing is funded, and help ensure many more new
homes are built for those who need a home to rent or buy.

From struggling inner-city neighbourhoods to families being forced out of the
countryside, we believe this will really help our hard-pressed communities as
well as create more jobs in construction.

KEITH LORAINE, chief executive, Isos Housing.

There's still time to have your say

I MUST challenge the views of JW of Walbottle ( Council must not surrender
countryside,' Journal,  November 2) who misrepresents the council's position on
proposals for the green belt and misunderstands our objectives.

The Government has been rightly criticised for its ill-conceived proposals to
allow unrestrained development of the green belt.

Under these proposals, developers will be able to build houses pretty much where
they like unless councils have a plan in place to protect areas where
housebuilding is inappropriate.

Unlike many councils, we have a plan in place which will protect the green belt
from unrestrained development while allowing enough homes to be built to meet
the urgent needs of our growing population.

Our view is clear: brownfield sites must be prioritised and that there should be
no presumption in favour of development.

The proposals suggest that some green belt could be developed to build the homes
we need, but the public and residents will be central to this decision.

That is what our consultation process is all about     listening to the views of
residents and taking decisions based on those views.

If there are strong and compelling representations against building in certain
areas, those areas may be removed from the list as there are more sites
identified than will go forward.

Because we want to do this properly and give everyone as much time as possible
to make their views known to us, our consultation period has been extended to
December 2 and I am writing to every resident to make sure they can have their
say.

We value the countryside and it is our intention to protect it.

Coun HENRI MURISON, cabinet member for quality of life, Newcastle City Council

Protect animals from fireworks

FIREWORKS may be beautiful and exciting for us, but for animals they can be
terrifying.

Cats and dogs are reduced to fearful, shivering wrecks, sheep can spontaneously
abort, horses gallop into fences and rabbits have been known to die from the
shock.

However, there are steps we can take to minimise their suffering.

Firstly, please consider attending a public fireworks display rather than
setting them off in your back garden.

One central display will scare fewer animals, and is likely to be set further
away from homes and their animal inhabitants.

Keep cats and dogs indoors from the afternoon onwards and bring rabbits and
guinea pigs inside as well (or at least cover their home with a thick blanket to
muffle the noise).

Also, be sure to check that hedgehogs and other wild animals have not made a
home in your bonfire before you light it.

Have a happy, and safe, fireworks night!

ASHLEY OWEN, Animal Aid, The Old Chapel, Kent.

Take a stand on public profligacy

THE letter from Blaydon MP Dave Anderson  castigates many of the bosses in the
region's top 100 companies for giving themselves obscenely huge pay awards,
while public-sector workers suffer cuts to pay and pensions.  (Journal Letters,
October 31).

I have no reason to dispute his claim and would hope those companies, being in
the top 100, will be big local employers, profitable and paying large sums in
taxes.

What I'd be more interested to know is  the names of those companies, in the
region, that have relocated manufacturing or service centres outside the North
East, so I may boycott them,  as I did with Twinings teas.

Mr Anderson is also right to highlight the appalling plight many of our
frontline public-sector workers face as they strive to keep us safe and protect
our health and property.

Their situation is hardly helped though when the public sector is awash with
managers, administrators, executives and supervisors who do precious little
productive work for staggering pay and perks .

It was recently reported that scores of senior NHS executives were being given
severance payments of around £300,000 each and then re-hired at a staggering
£1,000 a day  to  carry on mismanaging the health service.

This type of profligacy is an utter disgrace, Mr Anderson, so what are you going
to do about it?

A CARTER, Kenton, Newcastle.

USDA Rural Development Invests $498 million in Rural Iowa in 2013

BYLINE: Sioux County Index-Reporter staff

LENGTH: 936  words


During the past year a relatively small mission area within the U.S. Department
of Agriculture (USDA) has assisted thousands of rural lowans by helping bring
nearly half a billion dollars to rural Iowa to support community and economic
development projects throughout the state.

USDA Rural Development invested $498 million into rural Iowa in 2013 to develop
homeownership opportunities, as well as wide variety of job-creation and
community-improvement projects and activities.

For instance, USDA Rural Development funds were used to build a road in Warren
County to support an expanding small business, helped the City of Corwith plan
for a new fire station, developed an indoor farmers' market facility in Ot-tumwa
and will assist with the upcoming remodeling and expansion at Floyd Valley
Hospital in Le Mars.

"Our focus is on the viability of rural communities which are so vital to our
state and nation," said Bill Menner, USDA Rural Development State Director in
Iowa. "These are the places that help support American agriculture and foster an
ethic that impacts our workforce, our military and our economy. We are working
with communities to create jobs, expand opportunity, encourage innovation and
build a strong foundation for the future."

In 2013, USDA Rural Development funding, through 40 direct loan, guaranteed loan
and grant programs, helped 2,600 rural Iowa families purchase homes, created or
retained more than 1,000 jobs, and assisted 60 communities with improvements to
facilities, services and infrastructure.

This fail a groundbreaking ceremony was held at the future home of C& L
Companies' new warehouse and distribution and testing facility in rural Warren
County. USDA Rural Development provided a $1 million rural economic development
loan to assist with the expansion project.

Additionally, a $280,000 rural economic development grant helped make upgrades
to the roadway near the warehouse and distribution facility. C&L Companies is a
manufacturer of after-market motorcycle component parts. The project is
estimated to create 14 new jobs.

Access Energy Cooperative used nearly $800,000 in USDA rural economic
development grants and loans (REDLG) in 2013 to create a revolving loan fund
that the Henry County Health Center used to purchase health information
technology (HIT) equipment for the surgical and outpatient departments.

Many recipients of USDA Rural Development's 2013 rural business enterprise
grants (RBEG) are supporting local foods efforts. Cass County used an $11,554
technical assistance grant to help develop sustainable and economically
successful local foods systems that support farm-based businesses and
entrepreneurs in the county.

Ottumwa Progress Inc. received a $62,676 grant to assist with construction
costs, as well as the purchase of equipment for an educational and commercial
kitchen area in an indoor farmers' market facility helping small and emerging
businesses. Winneshiek County Agricultural Extension District received a $48,000
grant to help purchase a refrigerated delivery truck and provide technical
assistance to northeast Iowa food producers and processors through a food hub
delivery and marketing service.

In addition to generating jobs, USDA Rural Development investments are also
creating ongoing economic opportunities in rural America that will pay benefits
for years to come.

The City of Bloomfield received $2 million in loan and grant funds to help
establish an emergency connection to Rathbun Regional Water Association's newly
completed water treatment plant in case the city would need to access additional
water in the future. The plant was supported by $20 million in USDA Rural
Development loan funds and can treat six million gallons of water per day.

"We are very happy to be a partner with all the communities we serve as they
work hard to make investments that will impact many future generations," Menner
added. "We also enjoy working with communities on much smaller projects that
provide an outstanding opportunity for residents to work together and experience
success. Many times, this success leads to bigger community-improvement
initiatives."

This year USDA Rural Development awarded grants of $50,000 or less to 29
communities including the City of Blockton to help purchase a fire truck, the
City of Floris to assist with upgrades at their fire station and to Wayne County
Hospital to purchase a 3-D ultrasound machine and viewing station.

Since 2009, USDA Rural Development has invested nearly $3 billion in rural Iowa
on essential public facilities, small and emerging businesses, water and sewer
systems and housing opportunities for Iowa families.

Further information on programs available through USDA Rural Development is
available by calling (515) 284-4663 or by visiting the agency's web site at
www.rurdev.usda. gov/ia.

USDA Rural Development has 11 offices across the state to serve the 1.7 million
lowans living in rural communities and areas. Office locations include a State
Office in Des Moines, along with Area Offices in Albia, Atlantic, Humboldt,
Indianola, Iowa Falls, Le Mars, Mount Pleasant, Storm Lake, Tipton and Wa-verly.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities. USDA's
investments in rural communities support the rural way of life that stands as
the backbone of our American values.

                            WESTERN NEW YORK EDITION

State funds will boost housing program

BYLINE: By Bill Brown - GENESEE CORRESPONDENT

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 331 words

DATELINE: BATAVIA


The Genesee County Legislature on Wednesday voted to accept $600,000 in funds
from the Governor's Office for Small Cities to provide first-time home ownership
and housing rehabilitation.

The Legislature also approved a contract with Rural Opportunities of Rochester
to administer the home ownership and housing rehab program at a cost of $50,000.
The partnership has been in place for several years with annual grants ranging
from $200,000 to $750,000.

The Community Development Block Grant will provide $495,000 in subsidies for
home purchases and minor rehabilitation, $55,000 for program delivery services,
a Homeownership Assistance Program, and $50,000 to Rural Opportunities.

In a 27-item agenda, the legislators approved an $8,500 contract with Clark
Patterson Associates of Rochester to refinance the county's five-year-old
countywide water supply system.

The project was bonded through the sponsoring Monroe County Water Authority for
35 years.

County Highway Superintendent Timothy J. Hens said refinancing part of the
original $20 million loan through a state environmental facilities agency could
save up to $80,000 a year.

In other business, the lawmakers:

*Voted their support for the attempt by the Batavia Bus Service to secure
$341,300 in federal funds to expand bus routes, install bus stop signs and
provide a downtown transfer site. Known as the B-Line, the mini-buses are
operated by the Rochester-Genesee Regional Transportation Authority and run
regular routes throughout the city and parts of the county.

*Appointed Scott A. Waite, a Pembroke businessman, to a vacant seat on the
county Planning Board for a three-year term.

*Set Nov. 6 for a public hearing on the 2007 county budget now being prepared
for a mid-October release by County Manager Jay A. Gsell.

The current $110 million spending plan included a small property tax decrease.
Gsell said he has told department heads to hold the line on spending so that the
present tax rate can be maintained or possibly lowered.

                    BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                              July 19, 2009 Sunday

China banking regulator urges enhanced management against risks

LENGTH: 595 words


Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News
Agency)

BEIJING, July 19 (Xinhua) - China's banking regulator urged banks to strengthen
risk control and optimize credit structure to prevent possible financial risks
amid a surge of bank loans.

Rapid expansion of bank loans in the first half year boosted the country's
economic growth, but it also increased the possibilities of financial risks, Liu
Mingkang, chairman of the China Banking Regulatory Commission, said in a speech
posted on the regulator's web site on Sunday.

He said Chinese banks had seen imprudent and extensive lending, and should be
cautious about possible risks including inadequate capital for investment
projects, financing risks, concentration of loans, and risks on property market
led by rapid loan growth.

He urged lenders to ensure the minimum requirement of capital adequacy ratio and
lift the provision coverage ratio above 150 per cent this year. As of the end of
June, the provision coverage ratio of commercial banks was 134.3 perent, which
was 10.4 percentage points higher than the end of March.

He also encouraged banks to continue lending to major projects backed by the
government, small-and medium-sized enterprises, rural development, low-income
housing, major scientific research, energy conservation and emission cuts
programmes.

Loans to energy intensive and heavy pollution industries, and to sectors of
overcapacity should be under strict control, he noted.

In addition, he ordered lenders to stick to rules on mortgage for second home
buyers and step up scrutiny over approvals. Down payments on second homes is
currently set at no less than 40 per cent of the price.

Government data showed bank lending hit a record 7.37 trillion yuan (1.08
trillion US dollars) in the first half, as the government looked to a moderately
easy monetary policy to support economic recovery. The figure far exceeded the
full-year target of 5 trillion yuan.

The banking regulator said in early July that current rapid loan growth posed a
risk to the country's lenders and a concentration of loans to some industries
and business may damage the stability of the financial system. The watchdog
suggested syndicated loans as a good tool for banks to share risks.

The central government reiterated the stance of adherence to the current
stimulus policies. Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao said on July 10 that the
government should steadfastly adhere to the pro-active fiscal policy and
relative easy monetary policy.

Wang Qing, Morgan Stanley's chief China economist, said the loan growth should
normalize in the remainder of the year, as the pace in the first half of this
year is not sustainable.

China should stick to the current pro-active fiscal policy and moderately ease
monetary policy in the following months to fuel the economic growth, he said,
adding shift to tightening policy might slow down the current growth.

Wang said it's not a problem for Chinese economy to achieve its goal of eight
per cent growth for this year.

The Chinese economy expanded 7.9 per cent in the second quarter, buoyed by the
government's massive stimulus packages. The first half year recorded a growth of
7.1 per cent year on year.

Liu said China's economy was back on the track for recovery as a result of a
pro-active fiscal policy and moderately easy monetary policy, but the foundation
for recovery was not yet solid and there are still many uncertainties.

Liu Mingkang was speaking at a conference held in Beijing on July 17.

Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1404 gmt 19 Jul 09

USDA chief awards $3.4M in Maine

BYLINE: NOK-NOI HAUGER OF THE NEWS STAFF

SECTION: Pg. B8

LENGTH: 424 words

DATELINE: BREWER


Curtis Anderson was a busy man on Thursday as he toured Maine to see the
progress of U.S. Department of Agriculture projects, awarded millions to rural
community programs and helped with the groundbreaking for a Brewer crisis
stabilization center.

Anderson, deputy administrator of USDA's rural utility service in Washington,
began his tour of Maine on Thursday at Husson College by awarding $3.4 million
to 11 area agencies.

"This morning we awarded several million dollars in loans and grants to various
partnerships here in Maine," Anderson said after the ceremony. "We really do
look at this as an investment. It's not a giveaway."

Michael Aube, state director of USDA-Rural Development, said the grant and loan
money was spread evenly between rural communities to the north, east and central
parts of the state.

Aube, a former Bangor councilor and mayor, said USDA-Rural Development is not
just for farmers anymore.

Rural Development helps communities in Maine by offering housing and business
opportunities, providing sufficient utilities to residents, aiding economic
advancement and working to strengthening communities from the ground up, Aube
said.

While in the area, Anderson stopped by the Muddy Rudder restaurant in Brewer to
see how a $50,000 USDA grant to the city helped with a riverfront stabilization
project.

Brewer recently applied for a $90,000 grant from USDA-Rural Development to help
with redeveloping the defunct Eastern Fine Paper Co. mill site.

After the riverfront meeting, Anderson traveled to Acme Road for the
groundbreaking of a crisis stabilization unit, which the USDA is helping to
finance, for Community Health and Counseling Services.

After the groundbreaking ceremony ended, the deputy administrator then passed a
$2.82 million "business and industry loan" check to Paradigm Developments LLC
and PROTEA Behavioral Health Services LLC.

Rural Development has a long history in Maine and is making significant
investments in rural communities in the state.

The following groups received USDA awards at Husson College: Downeast Heritage
Center, $1.2 million; Pleasant Point Passamaquoddy Reservation, $150,000;
Visiting Nurses of Aroostook County $264,448; Androscoggin Valley Council of
Governments, $220,400; Kennebec Valley Council of Governments, $157,500; Eastern
Maine Development Corp., $40,500; Hancock County Planning Commission, $43,000;
Western Maine Finance, $500,000; Northern Maine Development Commission,
$750,000; Money Management International, $10,000; and Northern Maine
Development Commission, $86,800.

                       The Financial Express (Bangladesh)

                             August 31, 2014 Sunday

Thrust on vertical expansion of rural housing

LENGTH: 1179 words

DATELINE: Bangladesh


Bangladesh, Aug. 31 -- Bangladesh is one of the most land-scarce countries in
the world. Though the National Land Utilisation Policy has laid thrust on
family-based land ceiling for rural housing and rural model house building,
there is virtually no land-use plan for the rural areas that comprise about 85
per cent of the total land area.

The present facilities in respect of physical infrastructure, housing, water
supply, sanitation, etc., are very inadequate in rural areas. A study suggests
that housing shortage in the country is estimated to be 3.1 million units, out
of which 2.15 million units are in the rural areas. In fact, Bangladesh is
losing one per cent of its agricultural land every year due to various reasons
including population boom.

Traditionally, rural people are used to living in a 'bari', a homestead which
normally includes houses to live in, a yard, backyard for women to use. It is
usually dominated by patriarchal system. When the sons of the family reach
adulthood, they get married and build few small rooms adjacent to the rooms
occupied by the parents. Over time, the entire household area gets highly
congested.

Even though space availability for horizontal expansion is limited, people are
forced to go for it considering the high cost associated with vertical
expansion. On the contrary, it is observed that people in urban areas usually
expand their house vertically because the cost of vertical expansion is cheaper
compared to the cost of land required for horizontal expansion.

In Bangladesh, unplanned housing is a major problem for the people living in
rural areas. Although the government has implemented a few sporadic rural
housing projects namely cluster and ideal village projects etc., in the rural
areas; those are very meagre compared to the needs of the vast majority of rural
people. On the other hand, the Grameen Bank and few other non-government
organisations (NGOs) are providing loans for rural house building that has
opened a new horizon in the field of rural housing of Bangladesh.

Nevertheless, such organisations are only able to serve a limited number of the
rural population. Formulation of a proper institutional and legal framework for
actively participating in rural housing, which was included in the National
Housing Policy, is still not being implemented.

In such a backdrop, the government has recently approved a compact township
project for rural people of seven divisions involving Tk 4.24 billion. It is a
new concept of compact housing project, which will include residential
facilities alongside agriculture and forestation.

In fact, the idea had originated from the concept of cluster villages, which
provides urban facilities to villagers and save agricultural land. Experts say,
the project should be implemented in participatory process in consultation with
the local people. The poor and the low-income group are expected to hail such
initiative, while the richer section might stand against it.

The government believes such cooperatives based township project branded as
'Palli Janapad' will save arable land, ensure food security as well as improve
the living standards of rural people. Initially, four-story buildings will be
constructed in seven villages of the seven divisions accommodating some 272
families in each village. The project has been undertaken on a pilot basis and
based on its successes, it might be extended in future. The project sites will
be selected prioritising on the wage-earners' remittance prone areas.

Under the project, there will be flats in four categories for the beneficiaries.
A-type flats would be sized of 915 square feet while B-type flats of 710 square
feet, C-type flats of 460 square feet and D-type flats of 365 square feet with
each square feet areas having a price of Tk 1603. Of the total project cost, the
government is likely to provide 70 per cent, while the remaining 30 per cent
will come from the beneficiaries. The flat owners will repay the loan to the
government in 15 years at a flat rate of 5.0 per cent interest.

The value per square feet has been set at Tk 1,603 for each flat, which will
also have dining, kitchen and bathroom facilities. There will be some common
facilities free of cost as well. The model villages will have shops, dairy or
poultry farms, solar panels, biogas, ATM booths, mobile banking, and
playgrounds. Apart from these, Tk 100 million seed money will be given to each
village for training the villagers in order to create self-employment
opportunities. The government will bear Tk 3.63 billion of the Palli Janapad
project cost while the beneficiaries will contribute Tk 0.61 billion. The
project is expected to complete by June, 2017. Centre for Irrigation and Water
Management (CIWM) and Rural Development Academy (RDA) will jointly implement the
project under the Rural Development and Cooperatives Division.

The main project activities include construction of seven four-storey buildings,
construction of another three-storey seven buildings for animal husbandry and
marketing of agricultural produces, setting up solar panels, ensuring safe water
supply, rain water reservation tank construction as well as lake, construction
of biogas plant, producing high-quality organic fertiliser and its marketing,
operating various income generating training for the beneficiaries and operating
RDA credit operations for entrepreneurship development.

The land at the villages will still be in possession of the owners but will be
cultivated as cooperatives through organic farming. Ferro-cement and sandwich
panels would be used for constructing the proposed buildings, which would save
37 per cent of the cost of traditional building construction.

Each of the model villages is expected to save about 13.05 acres of land needed
for traditional housing. Besides, 16.26 acres of agricultural land will be
saved, as the families will be provided with civic facilities through a single
approach road.

The fact remains that when the number of family members rises, people need to
expand their houses. Since space is not available, they expand their houses
horizontally in rural areas on agricultural land. In such a way, cultivable land
is gradually being decreased. Numerous socio-economic problems are being created
as a consequence.

High growth rate of population in Bangladesh has created enormous pressure on
land. In addition to that, land use patterns are radically changing and
adversely impacting country's agricultural land, forest, water bodies and
wildlife habitat. Making new homes on cultivable land is limiting the use of
land for farm production.

In the circumstances, the government's recent decision to build compact township
project for the rural people in phases is a welcome gesture. This will
definitely go a long way to save shrinking agricultural land and solve their
acute housing problem.

szkhan@dhaka.net

                           The Nikkei Weekly (Japan)

                           September 30, 2013 Monday

Chinese land fetching sky-high prices

LENGTH: 694 words


Chinese land fetching sky-high prices

There's a bubble out there and developers are determined to blow it even bigger

KEN KUWAHARA and KENJI KAWASE

Staff writers

GUANGZHOU/HONG KONG - Developers here are spending big for urban land amid
growing expectations of a continued rise in property prices and an anticipated
long-term population influx from rural areas.

At an auction in Shanghai on Sept. 5, Hong Kong-based Sun Hung Kai Properties
Ltd. won a plot of land in the bustling central Xujiahui district for 21.77
billion yuan ($3.56 billion), one of the highest prices ever registered at a
real estate auction in the country.

The nearly 100,000-sq.-meter site is about 2.6 times larger than Hanshin Koshien
Stadium, Japan's storied baseball park. When Sun Hung Kai Properties finishes
building a massive office-hotel-retail complex on the Xujiahui site, it will
have spent at least 40 billion Hong Kong dollars (US$5.16 billion), including
what it paid at the auction.

The company's purchase in Shanghai, China's financial hub, came a day after
Tianjin-based Sunac China Holdings Ltd. bought a plot of residential land in the
central part of Beijing for 73,000 yuan per square meter, a housing real estate
record for the capital.

There is speculation that the sales price for housing units to be built there
will reach 200,000 yuan per square meter, which means that a relatively modest
100-sq.-meter unit would sell for a cool 320 million yen ($3.23 million).

In July, a consortium involving Guangdong province-based China Vanke Co. won an
auction for a commercial and residential site within Shanghai's Zhangjiang
Hi-Tech Park for 4.87 billion yuan, a year-to-date record price for the city.

Property investors have become more aggressive as more of them adopt the view
that government policy has shifted to accommodate rising property prices.

Government green light

As part of efforts to curb the country's housing bubble, the government had put
restrictions on purchases of second homes, including limiting access to housing
loans.

One sign of the probable policy shift came in August when the government let
average per-square-meter prices for new homes in 100 big cities rise for a 15th
straight month.

Of China's 70 biggest cities, 66 saw month on month prices for new homes rise in
August, according to data released by the country's National Bureau of
Statistics. Nationwide, prices rose an average 0.79% that month.

In Beijing, August prices increased 0.9% on the month and 14.9% on the year.
Prices in Shanghai climbed 1.5% on the month and 15.4% on the year. Shenzhen saw
a 1.4% rise on the month and an 18.1% increase on the year. Guangzhou saw the
largest growth compared with both the previous month and the previous year, with
prices there rising 1.7% versus July, and expanding 18.8% compared with August
2012. The figures exclude low-income housing.

China's economy slowed in real terms for the second consecutive quarter in the
April-June period, although there are now some signs that certain sectors, such
as industrial production, are picking up.

Cai Suisheng, president of the Guangdong Real Estate Association, said the
government likely wants to avoid reining in the property market, which could
jeopardize the economy's chances of attaining this year's 7.5% national growth
target.

Expected influx

Another reason behind major real-estate developers' massive spending on prime
plots is the expectation that housing demand in big cities will remain strong
due to a long-term population inflow from rural areas.

The percentage of city dwellers stood at 52% of China's population in 2012, far
below the 70-90% range seen in developed countries. The percentage of people who
have family registries in urban areas - people who are more likely to buy homes
there - is even lower, at 35%.

Given that low ratio, "China's urbanization is still in its initial stage," said
Tan Huajie, China Vanke's board secretary. "The real estate industry still has
great potential for growth."

The Guangdong Real Estate Association's Cai is optimistic China's urbanization
will continue for at least the next two decades.

(The Nikkei Weekly 09/30/2013 Edition)

                             The Telegraph (India)

                           January 12, 2017 Thursday

Realty boom for buyers

BYLINE: Sandeep Mishra

LENGTH: 480  words


Rush of investors for BDA project

Bhubaneswar, Jan. 12: The hunt for houses at reasonable rates is expected to end
shortly with real estate developers evincing interest in a housing project at
Chandrasekharpur to accommodate mainly lower-middle and middle class people.

Bhubaneswar Development Authority's venture - Greenfield Housing Project - will
be executed in public-private-partnership mode for the first time in the state.

Eleven major real estate developers from across the country yesterday attended a
pre-bid meeting for the project. On December 15, the Bhubaneswar Development
Authority (BDA) invited proposals from private real estate players to build
2,600 affordable houses at Chandrasekharpur over an area of 20.31 acres.

Under the scheme, the site developer will get 65 per cent of land for
construction of the 2,600 affordable houses, while the rest 35 per cent land
will go in favour of the developer.

The houses, which will cost between Rs 10 lakh and Rs 15 lakh, will have a
built-up area of 32.2sqm. The executor will provide common facilities such as
drinking water supply, road network, power supply, street lights, solid waste
management and drainage system. "According to the plan, the government will not
spend a penny in the project. The site developers would fund it and incur the
cost from the given land. The developer can use the rest of the land for
commercial or residential purpose," said an authority official.

It has also decided to bring in major banks and loan providers in the fold to
provide easy housing loan assistance to the people. "We held a meeting with 22
major private and public banks, who have assured us of providing easy housing
loans to the people in the upcoming project," said the authority's vice-chairman
Krishan Kumar.

He said the stakeholders were evincing interest in the project since it was one
of its kinds in the state. "The final tendering process will be over by the end
of February. The selected developer will get 180 days to complete the project.
We are also looking forward to providing the basic civic infrastructure in the
proposed site before beginning the project," said the vice-chairman.

The BDA will also execute two similar projects - another one at Chandrasekharpur
and Satya Nagar. The Chandrasekharpur project, to be known as Nilamadhav Abas,
will accommodate around 5,000 people in 1,250 houses. Another one at Satya Nagar
to be known as Santi Nagar Abas will house around 5,200 people in 1,300
affordable houses.

Chandrasekharpur resident Harish Nayak said it was a good move to build such
affordable houses for the lower-middle class people. "The housing projects will
help the administration provide better houses to the urban poor. It will also
facilitate the middle and upper-middle class people to have high-end houses in
good price, which will be developed by the private player on its land," said
Nayak.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                            August 29, 1999, Sunday

FBI asks questions about management

BYLINE: AMYLIA WIMMER

SECTION: CITRUS TIMES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 480 words

DATELINE: CRYSTAL RIVER



The inquiry follows concerns by residents, officials and former employees about
Jotar Management.

The FBI is investigating how Jotar Management, a Gainesville property management
company that operates two federally subsidized apartment complexes in Crystal
River, does business, according to sources that the FBI has contacted.

Residents of the apartments, along with the Citrus County Sheriff's Office, U.S.
Rep. Karen Thurman's office, members of the neighborhood crime watch group and
former Jotar employees have been inquiring about business practices at Jotar for
several months.

The FBI has contacted officials at the Office of Rural Development, the federal
agency that oversees the complexes.

"We've had a call from an agent in Ocala who asked us what was going on, and we
told him we weren't sure," said Louis Frost, acting state director of Rural
Development.

According to Tim Haines, an attorney for Jotar, the bureau has also visited the
complexes in Crystal River.

During the past few weeks, the Ocala- and Jacksonville-based FBI agents
reportedly investigating Jotar have not returned several phone calls seeking
comment. The bureau has not confirmed that it is investigating the management
company.

Several people have made accusations against Jotar since last fall. The
Sheriff's Office identified Atlantis Arms/Greenleaf Forest apartments as a place
deputies were called so often in 1998 Sheriff Jeff Dawsy wanted to base a
community resource office there.

Jotar refused to allow Dawsy to base the office inside the complex, so a deputy
works from a fire station around the corner.

The most serious claims against Jotar were made in July, when Steven and Jessica
Blamy were fired from their jobs as apartment managers after reporting several
problems to Thurman's office. Those complaints were forwarded to Rural
Development, and the Blamys lost their jobs as on-site managers for the complex.

Among their accusations against Jotar:

They questioned why 29 apartments were vacant at the complex, while Rural
Development officials seemed to only know of nine. Rural Development provided
the complex owner, John Curtis, with low-interest loans to build the complexes
and subsidizes rent for residents.

The Blamys suggested that Rural Development was providing rent payments for
tenants who no longer lived in the complex. Frost said Rural Development,
expected to release a report this week on its investigation of Jotar, found no
such evidence.

The Blamys, who worked as managers for Jotar for just three weeks, said Jotar's
poor record-keeping made it difficult to determine who belonged in the complex
and who didn't.

Another accusation, also made by several tenants, is that Jotar occasionally
forges tenant's signatures on lease agreements and tries to evict residents who
complain about their apartments or the management company.

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                  December 18, 2002 Wednesday Marshall Edition

Bremen could get new hospital in 2005;
Board looks to USDA for $16 million loan to help fund move

BYLINE: By ANITA MUNSON; Tribune Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 634 words


BREMEN -- Community Hospital of Bremen has applied for a $16 million U.S.
Department of Agriculture loan to build a new, 65,000-square-foot facility.

Scott Graybill, hospital administrator, said the loan is administered through
the USDA's Rural Development division and is aimed at hospitals in communities
whose population is fewer than 10,000 residents.

"What we've done at this point is to apply for the loan to underwrite the cost
of a hospital replacement project," he said.

Community's board of directors, which approved application for the loan, are
considering property in the vicinity of U.S. 331 and U.S. 6, although no
particular parcel has yet been selected. The board has a parcel in mind, but
does not want to provide its location because of required surveys to meet state
and federal mandates.

The announcement of the expansion is not the first for Community Hospital, which
has seen patient service numbers quadruple since 1990.

The location at 411 Whitlock St. saw a dedication of its outpatient addition in
early April 1990. That expansion saw a doubling of the emergency room, addition
of a chapel and gift shop, as well as a new physical therapy area more
accessible for patients. The recovery room, too, was given increased capacity.

The expansion was a result of a fund-raising campaign led by Tom Stiles, which
led to $800,000 in donations from more than 150 individuals, including hospital
employees and area businesses.

This time, however, hospital leaders are looking to the government for
assistance because of the scope of the project.

"If this particular loan isn't approved...there is a second federal program,"
Graybill said. The back-up plan would be application to the Federal Housing
Administration.

"We would not attempt to borrow funds locally or to raise funds locally," he
said. "The scope is such ... that you really need someone who will behave like a
bank. There aren't a lot of options out there."

Graybill said hospital leaders should know sometime in April whether they have
been successful in their application process for the loan for the 54-year-old
hospital, one of the five smallest in the state.

The Bremen hospital is the first in Indiana to become a federal- and
state-certified critical access hospital. The facility earned the designation in
1999, Graybill said.

"If you're a small, rural hospital ... with under 25 beds and meet some other
criteria, you are then reimbursed higher for Medicare patients," Graybill said.
"True costs are captured."

The certification, he said, is key to the hospital's willingness to take on the
new building project.

"It's one of the tools that make this loan (viable) for us," Graybill said.
"When we know Medicare reimbursement is at a true cost (in most instances), it's
much less risky."

The proposed new hospital will include a more efficient use of floor space, he
explained. The current hospital, located in the heart of a residential area and
stymied in any further growth because of its location, has seen additions since
the 1950s.

"We have filled our facility with new technologies," Graybill said of the
hospital's acquisition of state-of-the-art equipment, thanks to private
donations and assistance from the auxiliary. "We have no space for new service
offerings... We can't expand without using up our parking lot."

He also said the board has commissioned a study to determine whether the current
45,000-square-foot site will operate in conjunction with the proposed new
hospital. Board members also have toured other small hospitals to glean the
best-use ideas utilized in their expansion or re-build programs.

"If the funding is approved in 2003, construction could start in 2004," Graybill
said. "It's a 12-month (construction) process for this size of facility."

                              Sevenoaks Chronicle

                                October 15, 2009

Award-winning history of village 'fills a gap'

SECTION: Pg. 26

LENGTH: 462 words


Soon after the end of the 1914-18 war, the Government introduced its Homes for
Heroes programme and urged all local councils to build new houses for the
working classes.

Several were built in the Sevenoaks area, including four near the recreation
ground at Seal.

They were finished in 1920 but construction was so shoddy that the ceilings fell
down and they had to be rebuilt.

The subsidies were withdrawn until the (short-lived) Labour Government took over
in 1924.

By this time, the country's housing shortage had become acute and the Sevenoaks
area was no exception.

Charles Ashbee, with support from the Vicar of Seal, the Rev Jones-Davies, and
the Hon Violet Mills, who represented Seal on the Rural District Council,
established the Sevenoaks Public Utility Society, a form of housing association,
using government loans to build low-rental houses.

In the brilliant, recently published History of Seal, the authors Jean Fox,
David Williams and Peter Mountfield explain that at the first public meeting of
the Sevenoaks PUS, the Rev Jones-Davies gave startling figures about the
dreadful housing conditions of many younger couples in Seal - one family in a
caravan, another in a shepherd's hut, a family of six sharing a single room,
another in a fruit-picker's summer hut.

They write: "At the next meeting of the RDC, the sanitary inspector tried to
refute these claims but the vicar stuck to his case and repeated them in the
Sevenoaks Chronicle.

"Eventually the campaign began to work; the council used its compulsory purchase
powers and, in June 1926, a one-acre site was acquired in Childsbridge Lane
followed by another at Stone Street. The PUS also acquired another site in
Childsbridge Lane.

"The Government," say the authors, "also made available a subsidy for small
private houses, either for sale or for rent, and under this scheme a Sevenoaks
builder, called Bentley, built 10 small bungalows in a semi-circle alongside
Childsbridge Lane, three of which still survive."

Until recent years, government had little influence in the history of Seal but
this small story - a tiny scrap in a book of more than 250 pages - helps to
explain how the parish developed in the 20th century and about some of those who
played a leading role.

The book, sponsored by Seal Parish Council and published by Phillimore, has won
the Alan Ball Local History Award, presented by the Library Services Trust to a
local authority which actively promotes its local history.

I am told the judges' verdict said it was a beautifully-produced book,
scrupulously researched, that filled a gap "because this parish near Sevenoaks
has never before had its history fully recorded and disseminated".The plaque was
presented recently to Edward Oately, vice-chairman of the council during the
village fete.

                      Farmington Daily Times (New Mexico)

                            February 13, 2006 Monday

Home ownership possible for many

BYLINE: Lisa Meerts

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 6B

LENGTH: 934 words


Journal Correspondent

DURANGO - Nine years ago, Elizabeth von Tauffkirchen moved to Durango, where she
and her husband, Erik, own a mobile home she described as "divey." They
envisioned becoming homeowners but expected years to pass before it happened.

Instead, they will move into their Forest Lakes home within the next two months
- as soon as they receive the certificate of occupancy.

Both work normal jobs in Durango where the median income for a two-person family
hovers around $43,500. She is employed by Louisa's Movie House and he works for
a drywall company.

For many local residents, homeownership poses either an immense financial burden
or a financial impossibility. In 2005, the Durango Area Association of Realtors
reported in-town home prices routinely costing $355,000. Though cheaper, homes
in La Plata County still hit $290,000.

To increase homeownership, the U.S. government has partnered with non-profit
organizations across the nation, providing loan assistance and thereby opening
doors many residents thought closed to them. The program, called Self Help
Build, is sponsored by the United States Department of Agriculture Rural
Development and in Southwest Colorado has been executed by Colorado Housing Inc.
for more than a decade.

This year, as many as 45 Southwest Colorado residents strapped for cash will
finally call home sweet home their own - so long as they meet low-income
standards and are willing to devote a minimum of 600 hours to building their new
home.

"It's not as easy as one would think to find families that are able to commit to
a self-help program," said Jamie Blechman, family services coordinator for
Colorado Housing Inc., who recruits candidates for the program. To qualify, he
said, a two-person family like the von Tauffkirchen's cannot earn more than
$38,000.

Unfortunately, the very reason many locals need assistance disqualifies them, he
said. Combine some credit card debt and a car payment with a low-paying job and
the government cannot lend the money to build. Perfect credit is not necessary,
he said, but applicants need to qualify for a loan.

Still, his group has helped nearly 200 residents earning less than the median
income own the roof over their heads. Often the people who complete the program
are single parents with two children who work in the service industry. Between
paperwork and construction time, it takes a year before they move into brand-new
homes.

"The paperwork was daunting," recalled von Tauffkirchen. People probably drop
out because it's so overwhelming, she said, noting working the construction site
also requires significant effort.

Since they started building, her husband has worked at either his regular job or
the construction site every day - barring Sundays for Christmas and New Year's.
She takes off Fridays but works alongside him at the house whenever she can. The
program requires a family devote 30 hours each week. Volunteers like friends can
put in half those hours.

Her husband first learned about the Self Help Build because he used to work with
Josh Christner, the La Plata County construction manager for the past three
years. Christner walks people through the building process, showing them how the
hang cabinets or siding, paint or any number of tasks.

On average, five to eight houses are simultaneously built, he said. They are
located together on property originally purchased by Colorado Housing Inc. He
works full time, putting in seven-day weeks during the minimum six-month
construction phase. Christner experiences a slowdown for about three months
between builds, when he prepares for the next project.

He started as a volunteer for Colorado Housing Inc. but accepted a full-time
position, even though he earns less than he could working in the private sector.
The job is fun, Christner noted, and rewarding.

And challenging.

Taking five to eight families and their volunteers for more than half a year and
teaching them to build a house while dealing with so many personalities is no
joke, he said. But then, neither is the day they take ownership of their new
homes.

"The best part of it is when they get to move in. Just the smile on their faces
when they get to own a house," he said.

Most Self Help Build homes average 1,200 square feet in size, with three
bedrooms and two bathrooms. They all have similar footprints, which cuts down on
costs. But Colorado Housing Inc. hopes to develop a smaller home to help single
residents qualify for housing. Blechman said they may offer town homes or
duplexes in the next years.

The government gives Colorado Housing Inc. a two-year grant, which varies in
size depending on how many houses the non-profit plans to build. This year, it
received $400,000.

Homeowners assume a loan for around $125,000 when the home is complete, Blechman
said. Colorado Housing Inc. recently incorporated deed restrictions into the
properties so the houses remain affordable for low-income workers. They require
an owner to sell the house to someone who also falls into the low-income bracket
and the home prices are capped at a four percent increase per year.

Besides allowing more residents to become homeowners, the program fosters good
relationships between neighbors. All families in a build work together on each
other's homes so they are well acquainted when the work is finished and the
boxes unpacked.

"Nothing builds community like building your house together," said von
Tauffkirchen. Everyone supports one another, helps one another and everyone
bonds in the experience.

By Lisa Meerts

                      The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)

                           January 11, 2006 Wednesday
                                 Final Edition

Urban housing starts fall: Limited land and shortages of skilled labour main
reasons; starts rise in rest of province

BYLINE: Fiona Anderson, Vancouver Sun

SECTION: BUSINESSBC; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 622  words


Housing starts in Vancouver and other major urban areas in the province dropped
in 2005, as limited land and a shortage of skilled labour put the brakes on
development. But in the province as a whole, starts were up, albeit slightly,
according to numbers released Tuesday by the Canada Mortgage and Housing
Corporation.

Housing starts in British Columbia, excluding rural areas, increased half a per
cent, from 30,874 to 31,043 units.

But starts in Vancouver fell three per cent -- from 19,430 to 18,840 units --
with drops of almost 13 per cent in Victoria and seven per cent in Abbotsford.
The lower housing starts were offset by a 24-per-cent growth spurt in new houses
in Kelowna, and 11.5-per-cent growth in other urban centres within the province.

The move away from the Lower Mainland into the Interior reflects the growing
difficulty with building in Vancouver and Victoria and other major urban
centres, CMHC senior market analyst Cameron Muir said in an interview.

"The reason for the decline is not waning consumer demand," Muir said. "It's
really a function of [having] in those very active markets increasingly complex
building sites, rising construction costs and competition for skilled labour
[which] is putting a ceiling on the number of units builders can produce each
year."

Constrained land supply, which necessitates high-density housing, takes more
planning and more effort in site preparation, adding to the complexity of
development and slowing down starts, Muir said.

Multiple unit starts kept the province on its upward trend with an increase of
5.6 per cent in 2005 from 18,545 units to 19,589. At the same time, the number
of single starts fell 7.1 per cent, from 12,239 to 11,454.

The number of housing starts in 2005 was the highest B.C. has seen since 1994,
when a struggling Ontario was forcing workers to go West to find jobs, Muir
said.

In that year, B.C. had 40,000 net new residents. In 2006, between 7,000 and
10,000 people are expected to move to B.C. from elsewhere in Canada, Muir said.

CMHC predicts that housing starts will slacken slightly in 2006 in both
Vancouver and the province with Vancouver seeing about 18,000 to 18,500 starts,
and the province -- including rural starts which are not included into Tuesday's
statistics -- down to 31,600 units. The decline would be largely caused by
further constriction in the urban centres, Muir said.

Month over month, housing starts in B.C. were up almost six per cent in December
compared to November, fueled by a 9.4 per cent increase in multiple units and a
slight drop in single detached homes.

Across Canada, residential starts were down 4.1 per cent to 223,900 units, the
CMHC stated in a news release. That downward trend is expected to continue as
mortgage rates rise.

The slight decrease in housing starts in Vancouver in 2005 is "not a big deal,"
Peter Simpson, CEO of the Greater Vancouver Home Builders' Association, said in
an interview.

Simpson attributes much of the slowdown to the builders themselves who are
slowing their pace to ensure tradespeople are available when needed.

Simpson expects housing starts in Vancouver to continue to fall in 2006.

And as the cost of land and the cost of developing that land continue to go up,
so will housing prices, Simpson said.
