                                  The Observer

                                 March 10, 2002

UK housing crisis 'needs 4m homes '

BYLINE: Kamal Ahmed Political Editor

SECTION: Observer News Pages, Pg. 4

LENGTH: 513 words


MORE THAN four million homes will have to be built in Britain over the next 20
years - equivalent to a town the size of Reading every year - if Britain is to
tackle rampant house price inflation.

A major inquiry to be published this month will attack the Government for
failing to tackle a crisis which means many key workers, such as nurses and
teachers, cannot afford new homes.

The report, by the respected Joseph Rowntree Foundation, will come as another
blow for Stephen Byers, the Cabinet Minister with responsibility for housing.

It will say that housebuilding is at its lowest level since 1924 and the
Government has been too slow to put in place affordable housing policies.

Last week it was revealed that house prices in Britain are rising faster than at
any time since the 1980s' boom. First-time buyers are being forced to borrow so
much money that many economists fear another 'housing meltdown' with millions of
people being left with crippling negative equity and homes they can no longer
sell.

New figures reveal that the annual increase in house prices was 16.9 per cent
last month, raising the average price by nearly pounds 15,000 to pounds 101,980,
well out of the reach of many workers, particularly in the public sector. A
deposit of nearly pounds 15,000 is now required to get on the first rung of the
housing ladder.

The International Monetary Fund has also said the amount of debt being carried
by people in the form of mortgages and personal loans was in danger of becoming
unsustainable. Low interest rates meant that people were borrowing beyond their
means.

Lord Best, the Foundation's director, said Britain had to tackle its obsession
with protecting 'greenfield' sites which were often little more than 'drab land
on the edge of cities'. Although brownfield sites in cities could be used to
build some of the houses needed, country locations would also be required.

'The development of suburban England has been tremendously wasteful of land,' he
said. 'People seem to think it is their right to have a 60-foot garden despite
the huge effect this has on the lack of space for affordable housing.

The report highlights the growth of 'Poundbury syndrome', named after the town
backed by the Prince of Wales built on the outskirts of Dorchester in Dorset.

In an effort to get back to what critics say is an idealised version of rural
living, houses in Poundbury were built with large spaces in between and big
gardens. In many rural areas, residents balk at the notion of any more houses
being built near them.

The growth of single-person households, the increase in the number of divorced
couples and separated families and increasing affluence have all been blamed for
the chronic lack of housing in Britain, particularly in areas of rapid economic
growth such as London and the South East.

Housebuilding companies have also been attacked for concentrating their efforts
on constructing low-density executive homes, which can be sold for greater
profit than higher-density flats and maisonettes.

                               The New York Times

                            April 30, 2015 Thursday
                              Late Edition - Final

Saddling Homeowners With Risky Loans

BYLINE: By THE EDITORIAL BOARD

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Editorial Desk; EDITORIAL; Pg. 30

LENGTH: 477 words


House Republicans, with the help of several Democrats, recently passed two bills
to weaken new rules against predatory mortgage lending. Senate Republicans are
now trying to win support for the same measures, arguing that the rules would
impose ''regulatory burdens'' that unduly restrict credit.

That is way off base. The rules, called for in the Dodd-Frank financial reform
law of 2010, require that lenders provide borrowers of complex, high-cost loans
with written disclosure of the loan rate and maximum monthly payment as well as
the consequences of default. They also require lenders to give mortgage
applicants a list of counseling organizations that can educate them on risks,
rights and responsibilities.

The rules seek to curtail the use of the riskiest loan features, like balloon
payments, and to reduce conflicts of interest, like the use by lenders of
affiliates in insurance and other related fields, that can result in borrowers
being steered into overpriced loans.

The rules generally do not apply to loans with straightforward terms or prohibit
risky loans to qualified, well-informed borrowers. Their purpose is to help
prevent lenders from peddling deceptive and high-cost loans to unsuspecting
borrowers.

One such lender, according to a recent article by The Seattle Times and the
Center for Public Integrity, a nonprofit investigative group, is Clayton Homes,
headquartered in Maryville, Tenn. Clayton is the nation's biggest builder and
seller of manufactured homes -- basically mobile homes permanently affixed to
their sites. It is also the biggest lender to buyers of manufactured homes,
having increasingly dominated the industry since 2003, when it was acquired by
Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate led by Warren Buffett. The report, which
Clayton Homes claimed was misleading, said the company uses high-pressure sales
tactics, exorbitant fees and excessive interest rates to bolster profits on
loans that borrowers cannot afford for homes they often cannot sell or
refinance.

One of the two bills approved by the House would effectively exempt loans for
manufactured homes from the new anti-predation rules. The bill's architect was
Representative Stephen Fincher, a Republican from Clayton's home base in
Tennessee. Its potential victims are the kinds of consumers the law is meant to
protect -- the mostly older, lower-income buyers of manufactured homes in rural
areas where affordable housing is scarce.

The White House has said it would veto the bills if need be, though the
Republican tactic of passing piecemeal rollbacks to Dodd-Frank raises the
possibility that the bill could be added to a larger measure.

In the meantime, shareholders who gather this week for Berkshire Hathaway's
shareholder meeting could ask Mr. Buffett what it is about basic consumer
protection that Clayton Homes finds so threatening.

loans.html

                       Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)

                             March 8, 2001 Thursday
                                  Late Edition

Roll out the Bowral;
the market

BYLINE: Harvey Grennan

SECTION: DOMAIN; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 970 words


Get in fast if you want a property in the Southern Highlands.

Property prices are likely to soar in the Southern Highlands under a "low
growth" planning policy up for adoption by Wingecarribee Shire Council. Bowral
and its surrounding centres have been a weekend enclave for Sydney's
better-heeled citizens since the middle of last century. They are likely to
remain so. The current development at East Bowral, where the supply of vacant
land is dwindling, could be the last big tract to be released for residential
development.

The "sustainable low growth" strategic plan is aimed at protecting the
"landscape qualities, natural resources and quality of life" of the shire.
Another factor is the protection of the catchment for Sydney's drinking water,
which suffered giardia and cryptosporidium outbreaks in 1998.

Preservation of the area's rural character is a hot local issue. Five years ago
farmers lost their concession to carve off two-hectare blocks, which are highly
sought after. As supply has dried up, the price of these blocks has doubled.

More recently, the council has resolved to prevent homes being built on the top
of escarpments to preserve the landscape for tourists.

Only limited development is contemplated in the strategic plan, including 400
lots at Renwick near Mittagong and a parcel at Moss Vale. Subdivision potential
at Penrose and Wingello will be reviewed. There will be no extension to rural
small-holding areas and villages will not be permitted to expand into
surrounding rural lands.

Mayor Phil Yeo says the plan "allows room for growth without creating suburban
sprawl, which invariably occurs when town and village boundaries are lost".

The Southern Highlands Business Chamber says the plan will result in rapidly
escalating land values. "Are we to place signage at the entrances to the shire
saying 'house full' or 'no riffraff allowed'?" says president Garry Barnsley.
"It is a plan for the 'haves' at the expense of the 'have nots'. Council may try
to erect the palisades but we can't ignore four million people on our doorstep."

But Helen Chadwick, chair of the Southern Highlands Landcare Network, says the
plan reflects the wishes of the community. "We already have too much traffic
through Bowral due to the enormous growth allowed in the East Bowral
development," she said.

The newly formed Wingecarribee Committee for Managed Growth wants an economic
impact study and more time to study the plan.

AGENTS' RIGHTS - AND RESPONSIBILITES

The conscience of real estate

A real estate agents' guide to the Trade Practices Act, Fair and Square, is
available from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (level 5
Skygarden, 77 Castlereagh Street, 9230 9133) for $10. It spells out agents'
rights and responsibilities and covers the GST, unconscionable conduct,
franchising, agency services, land, pricing and more.

DELAYS IN HOME-LOAN APPROVALS

Long wait for big bucks

Major banks are taking up to two weeks to approve home loans instead of the
usual 48 hours. "The service level at the moment is just terrible," says a
leading mortgage broker, singling out Westpac and ANZ as the slowest. "It's just
not

good enough for people who are wanting to buy at auction."

Meanwhile non-bank lender to use brokers to sell its loans.

Chief executive Charles Weiser says RAMS has the margin to use brokers because,
unlike Aussie Home Loans and Wizard, it raises its own funds rather than
securitising funds from other lenders.

Brokers can access RAMS home loans at a new Internet site developed by Citibank.
The site also accesses loans from Citibank Mortgages and GE Mortgage Solutions.

WEB SITE COMPETITION

Click on this

Domain.com.au came in for a proper pasting from veteran agent Max Horne at Raine
and Horne's annual knees-up. Why did agents keep using it when they have their
own Web site in propertypage.com.au? Perhaps because they want to find
customers. Domain.com is No 2 and propertypage.com No 11 with real estate Web
users, according to Net-use monitor Hitwise. Top of the pops is
realestate.com.au which News Ltd recently rescued from the financial abyss. Now
another leading player, property.com.au, has changed hands with RP Data, a
earlier suitor for realestate.com.au, picking it up from PMP Communications for
$3 million.

MIDDLE-AGED FIRST-HOME BUYERS

Shattered stereotypes

The Government's $7,000 first-home buyers' grant has had an unintended
side-effect. The average age of first-home buyers has risen, particularly in
rural and regional areas, according to the Office of State Revenue and real
estate agents. The first-home buyer stereotype of a young couple is giving way
to people in their 30s, 40s and 50s who, before the grant, had resigned
themselves to renting for the rest of their lives. Leanne Pilkington of Laing +
Simmons attributes the age increase to rising property prices, the costs of
education and the trend for couples to marry later and delay having a family.

DILI DEVELOPMENT CONFERENCE

Brave new world

Three leading eco-architects have returned from East Timor where they attended
the fledgling nation's first sustainable development conference. Gareth Cole,
David Baggs and Tony Edye found urban architecture in Dili "totally
inappropriate" and promised to come up with practical ways to rebuild housing
and improve sustainability and living conditions.

JUST WILD ABOUT HARRY

Born free

Meriton's Harry Triguboff may not have cuddled a koala (Domain, February 22),
but he has found new homes for the odd bell frog and possum. Green and gold bell
frogs sitting in front of the dozers at a Meriton development at Rosebery looked
wistfully at Triguboff and ended up at a Taronga Zoo sex party (Triguboff calls
it a breeding program) before resettling in lovely ponds at Botany. More
recently he found some cosy bushland for possums nesting in an old substation in
St Leonards.

LOAD-DATE: July 24, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

displaced possums. Photo: Quentin Jones Timor team: Aussie architects have big
plans for improving Dili's urban architecture. Photo: Andrew Meares

Agriculture, Rural Housing Service: Loan Specialist (General) STHKY-2015-017

LENGTH: 2719  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of Personnel Management has issued the following job announcement:

Job Title:Loan Specialist (General)

Department:Department Of Agriculture

Agency:Agriculture, Rural Housing Service

Job Announcement Number:STHKY-2015-017
SALARY RANGE:
 $47,923.00 to $75,376.00 / Per Year
OPEN PERIOD:
 Tuesday, December 2, 2014 to Thursday, December 11, 2014
SERIES & GRADE:
 GS-1165-09/11
POSITION INFORMATION:
 Full-Time - Permanent
PROMOTION POTENTIAL:
11
DUTY LOCATIONS:
 1 vacancy - Madisonville, KY View Map
WHO MAY APPLY:
 Current permanent USDA Rural Development employees with competitive status, and
USDA CTAP eligibles within the local commuting area.
SECURITY CLEARANCE:
 Q - Nonsensitive
SUPERVISORY STATUS:
 No
JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This position is being concurrently announced under Delegated Examining
Procedures on announcement number DEU-KY-2015-0128 open to any US Citizen.
Current Federal employees may apply to both announcements, but should be sure to
apply to this announcement STHKY-2015-017 to maximize opportunities for
consideration since different referral criteria apply to each announcement type.

TRAVEL REQUIRED

25% or Greater
    Travel to perform Loan Specialist duties

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

US Citizenship is required.
    Selective Service Registration is required for males born after 12/31/1959.
    No Relocation expenses will be paid.
    Must submit a copy of your most performance appraisal (rating).
    Must submit a copy of your most recent (non-award) SF-50.

DUTIES:
Back to top

This position is located in a Area office in USDA/Rural Development (RD). The
incumbent has responsibility for making and servicing loans/grants for small
residential dwellings, and/or selected multi-family housing (MFH) projects,
and/or selected loans and grants for rural facilities, utilities, and/or
businesses.

The incumbent deals with loans either made or guaranteed by the government and
grants for small residential dwellings (e.g., four units or less), and/or MFH
projects and/or very small commercial loans and grants. Commercial and MFH loans
are prescreened by the supervisor to remove those with more difficult
problems/complexities. Credit and financial analysis are based on well-developed
facts which are readily evaluated under RD guidelines.


QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:
Back to top

For the GS-09 level: Applicants must have 1 year of specialized experience
equivalent to at least the GS-07; or its non-Federal equivalent that
demonstrates: experience in performing loan making and/or loan servicing duties
such as regularly examining loan applications, supporting documents and credit
reports, and maintaining servicing activities of somewhat complex loans and/or
grants; assisting higher level loan specialists by performing assigned portions
of financial credit analysis in connection with more complex loans as a way of
acquiring training and competency for more difficult loan examining and
servicing assignments OR master's or equivalent graduate degree OR 2 full years
of progressively higher level graduate education leading to such a degree or
LL.B. or J.D., if related. Equivalent combination of education and experience
are qualifying for this grade level.

For GS-11: Applicants must have 1 year of specialized experience equivalent to
at least the GS-09; or its non-Federal equivalent that demonstrate thorough
knowledge and understanding of complex mortgage or commercial loan
making/servicing and credit principles and practices in order to assess the
fundamental soundness of business loans and loans to corporate and/or municipal
entities and to independently examine applications and corporate financial
documents, and maintain servicing activities on a variety of commercial loans.
Experience may have been gained in work equivalent to reviewing and passing upon
applications for a variety of commercial loans or by servicing a commercial loan
portfolio of a bank or other loan association; performing financial analysis of
commercial concerns for investment purposes; appraising real estate and business
property to determine property valuation; or similar work; OR Ph.D. or
equivalent doctoral degree OR 3 full years of progressively higher level
graduate education leading to such a degree or LL.M., if related OR a
combination of education as described and specialized experience.


o  Must possess and maintain a valid driver's license
o  Travel will be required.
o  Selectee must be able to obtain and maintain a security clearance. If
selected you may be subject to a National Agency Check and Inquiry (NACI) and a
credit report inquiry.
o  This position requires up to 25% travel.

                                August 24, 1998

Into the Economic Mainstream

BYLINE: BY JOHN D. HAWKE JR.; Under Secretary of the Treasury Mr. Hawke recently
addressed the National Association of Affordable Housing Lenders.  His excerpted
remarks are presented as our Open Forum.

SECTION: OPEN FORUM; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 828 words


A goal that I believe -- and that I know Treasury Secretary Rubin and President
Clinton believe -- is of immense importance to our society and our economy as we
approach the 21st century (is): Giving every American the opportunity to join
and succeed in the economic mainstream.

We can, and we must, do more to ensure that our economy works for all Americans.
The key is to identify strategies and replicate them on a national scale and on
a sustained basis.  Our strategy involves a three pronged approach:

The first is strengthening public safety.  In addition to the human costs, high
crime rates are a significant barrier to economic activity.

Second, is investing in people, through the Earned Income Tax Credit; through
education and training, from preschool to adult; and through improving the "job
readiness" of the least advantaged and connecting them to the workforce.

And third, which I will focus on today, is increasing access to private sector
capital and other measures to restore healthy market forces in the inner cities
and distressed rural areas.

At Treasury, we have been very focused on these problems.  We have enacted new
incentives for investments in the inner cities, from our brownfields tax
incentive to encourage the revitalization of environmentally contaminated
properties in distressed areas, to new rounds of Empowerment Zones, fostering
comprehensive approaches to a community's problems.  We have enacted incentives
to help firms hire low income workers who have a difficult time in the labor
markets.  And we have made permanent the low income housing tax credit, helping
to create 90,000 units of affordable housing every year.  This year, the
President has proposed expanding the credit by 40%, which would mean an
additional 180,000 units of affordable housing over the next five years alone.

I think one of the most significant things we've done is help make our financial
system work better for communities long left behind.  At the core of this
approach, we have strengthened the Community Reinvestment Act and launched the
Community Development Financial Institutions Fund.

Now in its 20th year, CRA, in my view, is working.  In 1996 alone, large
commercial banks made $ 18 billion in community development loans.  In the last
four years, national banks have invested four times as much in community
development as they did in the previous thirty years.

Moreover, Home Mortgage Disclosure Act data for 1996 show that since 1993,
private sector conventional home mortgage lending to African Americans has
increased by 67.2 percent, lending to Hispanics has risen 48.5 percent, and
lending in low and moderate income areas is up 37.9 percent.  All this, in a
period in which the market grew only 18 percent.  This data shows real progress,
but much work still needs to be done.

Going forward, nonprofit groups report that there have now been $ 397 billion in
loan pledges to low income areas since CRA was enacted 20 years ago.  Over the
past five years, loan pledges have totaled $ 355 billion, 89 percent of all loan
pledges made since 1977.

The goal of the CDFI Fund is to build a nationwide network of community
development financial institutions to expand access to credit and financial
services in lower income communities.  Often, CDFIs are the pioneers in their
marketplaces, making the leading edge investments based on superior local
knowledge, providing technical assistance to borrowers, and thereby
demonstrating to traditional lenders that these are viable markets.  Banks, in
turn, are looking for these opportunities, partly as a result of CRA.  Banks
have partnered with CDFIs, and once they become involved, many of these
mainstream institutions are staying at the table as they come to understand
these markets and see the available opportunities.

The CDFI Fund has two main programs: the CDFI program, which is designed to
assist specialized community development financial institutions, and the Bank
Enterprise Award program, which rewards financial institutions that are
increasing their lending and providing more financial services in distressed
communities.  Both programs pursue strategies designed to meet local needs to
help each community deal with its particular circumstances, whether it is
helping people buy a house, or start a business.

The Fund has awarded over $ 75 million to 80 CDFIs and intermediaries around the
country in its first two rounds of awards, and under the BEA program, 92 insured
depository institutions have received over $ 30 million in awards for their
activities.  This year, the third round of the BEA program will provide another
$ 25 million in incentives to banks and thrifts who increase their investments
in distressed communities and in CDFIs; 104 banks have applied, seeking $ 60
million in funding.

As a nation, we can never hope to reach our full economic potential unless we
succeed in bringing all Americans into the economic mainstream.

LOAD-DATE: September 3, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Picture, no caption

                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                            August 4, 2007 Saturday
                                  All Editions

A HOME OF YOUR OWN;
Can you afford it?;
Experts say the area has affordable homes; potential buyers ask, 'Where?'

BYLINE: AIMEE DOLLOFF OF THE NEWS STAFF

SECTION: Pg. A1

LENGTH: 1365 words


Finding an affordable house in Greater Bangor is more difficult than some
prospective buyers originally anticipated, but housing officials say there are
affordable homes out there.

"The vast majority of houses I've seen need substantial work in the first few
years of owning them," Tanya Pereira, 30, of Holden, who is looking to buy a
home, said Thursday. "At this price range, there's very little that's ready to
go without some sort of investment."

A single mom, Pereira's looking for a two- or three-bedroom home in the $100,000
range for her and her 4-year-old daughter, Sophie, whose given name is Sophia.
Pereira said she has been renting a small house in Holden for the last two years
since her divorce, but hopes to purchase a home by the time her daughter starts
kindergarten about a year from now.

"I'm obsessed with having enough space for Sophie's swing set," Pereira said.

But there are some things she's willing to exchange for what's most important,
like a place for Sophie to play, good schools and a safe neighborhood.

"I really had to lower my expectations," Pereira said. "I've really had to look
at what I'm willing to sacrifice."

While there's no concrete definition of an affordable house, the general rule is
that buyers shouldn't spend more than 30 percent of their adjusted gross income
on their mortgage.

"In Greater Bangor or Penobscot County, there are homes available," Michael
Aube, Maine's U.S. Department of Agriculture rural development director, said
Wednesday.

"There seems to be an availability of both new construction as well as existing
homes that are affordable," he said.

That's a good sign for the economy as well, Aube said.

"One of the engines that drives the economy in Maine is not just the housing
industry, but the affordable housing industry," Stephen Mooers, director of
Penquis CAP housing services and housing development, said Wednesday. "People
like Cianbro and Hollywood Slots, they've got to have people to work."

Those people need places to live. While some don't want to make the potential
20- or 30-year commitment to purchase a home, the majority of people like to
own, Mooers said.

When developing new housing projects, Penquis CAP primarily focuses on rental
housing, such as that on Griffin Road in Bangor. But recently it completed a
single-family development in Searsport, and Mooers said he's always looking at
the market and possible housing options.

"The city of Bangor has about 35,000 people," he said. "It has the
infrastructure to sustain a population probably twice that size, but it doesn't
have the housing to accommodate it."

The main reason for that, is the lack and cost of land.

"Where are you going to put it?" Mooers asked.


What's available

The Web site www.Realtor.com is a popular site used by potential buyers. As of
Friday morning, there were 1,193 single family homes listed for Maine's northern
region 2, which runs from Dixmont to Bangor and north to Enfield.

But when the search criteria is set with $150,000 as a maximum, the listings
shrink to 421. For someone looking to spend $125,000 or less, there were 237
listings, and at $100,000 or less there were 130.

When the search is modified again to include properties within the Bangor zip
code, there were 562 available single family properties with 107 listed under
$150,000. That number dropped to 20 listings at $100,000 or less.

Most single family properties under $70,000 were camps or homes that need
extensive work with phrases in their descriptions such as "being sold as is" or
"handyman special." Descriptions of those in the $80,000 to $90,000 range begged
for some tender loving care or the properties were in more rural areas, such as
Dexter or Corinna.

That's not to say homes aren't selling. Based on their observations of the
market, Aube and Mooers noted that the real estate market is beginning to shift
and become a buyer's market.

"It's a buyer's market for the first time in a long time," Mooers said.

Penquis CAP, through its MaineStream Finance program, provided homebuyer
education to more than 300 individuals last year. In addition, the organization
assisted 20 families and individuals in purchasing a single family home,
according to Penquis CAP Community Relations Manager Jennifer Brooks.

Last year, Aube's office assisted about 111 people in finding a home they could
afford in Penobscot County.

"That's probably about an average [year]," he said.

Maine's home ownership rate is more than 76 percent, which is among the highest
in the country, according to Aube. The national ownership rate is about 69
percent.

It has been proven that there's a direct link between economic development and
home ownership, according to Aube and Mooers.


Mainers like to own

Mooers says Maine's home ownership rate also has a lot to do with New England
mentality.

"People in Maine like to own, they don't like to rent," Mooers said Wednesday.
"Poor people don't own anything traditionally, but they do here in Maine."

Many Mainers tend to follow the old adage that if you can't afford to pay cash,
don't buy it. That sometimes makes it difficult to build good credit, which is
what most lending institutions base their decisions on.

Maine residents whose incomes fall below the state's 2006 median income of
$44,488 also run into problems.

"The thing that's missing in the lives of most low-income people is equity,"
Mooers said.

The average family of four with both parents working minimum wage jobs brings in
about $25,000 per year, he said.

"They can't afford a typical home today without some subsidy," Mooers said.

The form of subsidy also has changed in recent years.

"The days of grants have sort of disappeared," Mooers said. "We're in a war
right now."

There are forgivable loans available, which are similar to grants, but most of
the assistance provided to buy comes in the form of low-interest loans and other
funds that have to be paid back.

Pereira said she's fortunate to work for the city of Brewer and have a
good-paying job, but that it's difficult to find something suitable with only
one income.

"Everything adds up so quickly," she said.

A good school system is very important, while Pereira considers a third bedroom
more of a luxury.

"It's not going to be my dream home, but it's going to be a great first step for
Sophie and I," Pereira said.


A home for $100,000?

Pereira's not alone in her search for a home in the $100,000 range.

"We get a lot of calls from people looking in that range," Pereira's realtor,
Tricia Largay of Realty of Maine, said.

Jonathan and Karen Prete of Bangor also are trying to find an affordable two- or
three-bedroom home with more than one bathroom.

"We're not looking for anything very elaborate, just a nice comfortable home,
and it's really hard to find," Karen Prete, 42, said Thursday. "The ones that we
have found, they have something wrong with them that would prevent us from
getting homeowners insurance or that would make us have to spend a fortune to
fix them after we purchase them."

The Pretes have seen rotted support beams, leaky roofs, faulty wiring, and bad
neighborhoods in their search for a home.

"I'm not so concerned with cosmetics or anything, because that's easy," Prete
said. "I just want a basic, sound house."

Pereira is looking for the same thing. The single mom said she's not very handy
when it comes to major repairs and has to consider what could go wrong down the
road when she looks at a house.

"If I get into a house, what's going to go wrong in the first five years?" she
asked. "The vast majority of houses I've seen need substantial work in the first
few years of owning them."

The quest became so frustrating for both families that each stopped looking for
a while and just recently started searching again.

"When we first started to look for a home we were very enthusiastic. The longer
the search continued, the more it seemed like a chore," Karen Prete stated in a
recent e-mail.

She estimates she and her husband have looked at more than 20 homes and still
haven't found anything they want to buy.

"It just got so frustrating. It just made me so angry and frustrated just
looking and looking and looking," Prete said. "Maybe we are just destined to be
in an apartment for the rest of our lives."

                                  Western Mail

                            January 25, 2001, Friday

HALF A HOUSE GUARANTEES A HOME FOR COUNTRY VILLAGERS.

BYLINE: Clive Betts

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 438 words


VILLAGERS were yesterday thrown a life-line to enable them to stay in their own
communities and overcome competition from second-home buyers and commuters.

The National Assembly announced a Wales-only initiative to make it cheaper for
local people to buy homes in rural areas: they would buy only half a house.

Edwina Hart, minister for finance, local government and communities, said, "This
is another little building block in preserving our rural communities,
particularly the smallest villages which are most threatened."

Mortgages will attract increased subsidies under the new scheme. This will be
funded by the Assembly giving housing associations more money from the social
housing grant.

The result is that would-be homeowners will be able to buy only half a house,
with the other half held by the housing association. In addition, the mortgage
would be interest-free.

The scheme is aimed at families who would normally rent social housing. The
scheme currently in operation - originated by the old Tai Cymru quango - demands
that the buyer take out a mortgage for 70pc of the property.

John Bader, appointed yesterday to the new post of director of housing for the
Assembly, said, "The new rules can mean a difference of pounds 80 a month in
repayments for a family."

Mr Bader said the scheme should prove a major help in the smallest communities,
where the problem seems to be worst. The first mortgages will be available from
the new financial year, and officials believe that well over 100 families will
quickly be given help.

Saving villages for the locals is proving a major problem for the Assembly:
officials admit that schemes introduced from Westminster in recent years,
enabling the building of cheap homes on village edges, have proved difficult to
implement because of problems in finding sites, plus local opposition.

Officials can see this scheme enabling a couple of families in each small
community to buy their homes. The subsidy will be high enough, it is hoped, to
overcome the twin problems of low incomes among local people, and high house
prices.

Mrs Hart said, "We are all aware of the problems facing some of our rural
communities, and it is vital that we take all possible steps to assist them.

"As people, and particularly younger people, are priced out of the market, there
is a danger that these communities will lose their futures and will lose what
these people have to offer them."

Mrs Hart's move is made only 24 hours before former Plaid Cymru leader Dafydd
Wigley opens a short debate during today's plenary on housing in rural Wales.

                               December 18, 2013

USDA Rural Development invests $498 million in rural Iowa in 2013

BYLINE: Lyon County Reporter staff

LENGTH: 966  words


Funding helps create or retain 1,000 jobs, assist 2,600 families purchase homes
and support 60 communities with improvements to facilities, services and
infrastructure

DES MOINES, Iowa-During the past year a relatively small mission area within the
U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has assisted thousands of rural lowans by
helping bring nearly half a billion dollars to rural Iowa to support community
and economic development projects throughout the state.

USDA Rural Development invested $498 million into rural Iowa in 2013 to develop
home ownership opportunities, as well as wide variety of job-creation and
community-improvement projects and activities.

For instance, USDA Rural Development funds were used to build a road in Warren
County to support an expanding small business, helped the City of Corwith plan
for a new fire station, developed an indoor farmers' market facility in Ot-tumwa
and will assist with the upcoming remodeling and expansion at Floyd Valley
Hospital in Le Mars.

"Our focus is on the viability of rural communities which are so vital to our
state and nation," said Bill Menner, USDA Rural Development State Director in
Iowa. "These are the places that help support American agriculture and foster an
ethic that impacts our workforce, our military and our economy. We are working
with communities to create jobs, expand opportunity, encourage innovation and
build a strong foundation for the future."

In 2013, USDA Rural Development funding, through 40 direct loan, guaranteed loan
and grant programs, helped 2,600 rural Iowa families purchase homes, created or
retained more than 1,000 jobs, and assisted 60 communities with improvements to
facilities, services and infrastructure.

This fall a groundbreaking ceremony was held at the future home of C& L
Companies' new warehouse and distribution and testing facility in rural Warren
County. USDA Rural Development provided a $1 million rural economic development
loan to assist with the expansion project.

Additionally, a $280,000 rural economic development grant helped make upgrades
to the roadway near the warehouse and distribution facility. C&L Companies is a
manufacturer of after-market motorcycle component parts. The project is
estimated to create 14 new jobs.

Access Energy Cooperative used nearly $800,000 in USDA rural economic
development grants and loans (REDLG) in 2013 to create a revolving loan fund
that the Henry County Health Center used to purchase health information
technology (HIT) equipment for the surgical and outpatient departments.

Many recipients of USDA Rural Development's 2013 rural business enterprise
grants (RBEG) are supporting local foods efforts. Cass County used an $11,554
technical assistance grant to help develop sustainable and economically
successful local foods systems that support farm-based businesses and
entrepreneurs in the county.

Ottumwa Progress Inc. received a $62,676 grant to assist with construction
costs, as well as the purchase of equipment for an educational and commercial
kitchen area in an indoor farmers' market facility helping small and emerging
businesses. Winneshiek County Agricultural Extension District received a $48,000
grant to help purchase a refrigerated delivery truck and provide technical
assistance to northeast Iowa food producers and processors through a food hub
delivery and marketing service.

In addition to generating jobs, USDA Rural Development investments are also
creating ongoing economic opportunities in rural America that will pay benefits
for years to come.

The City of Bloomfield received $2 million in loan and grant funds to help
establish an emergency connection to Rathbun Regional Water Association's newly
completed water treatment plant in case the city would need to access additional
water in the future. The plant was supported by $20 million in USDA Rural
Development loan funds and can treat six million gallons of water per day.

"We are very happy to be a partner with all the communities we serve as they
work hard to make investments thatwill impact many future generations," Menner
added. "We also enjoy working with communities on much smaller projects that
provide an outstanding opportunity for residents to work together and experience
success. Many times, this success leads to bigger community-improvement
initiatives."

This year USDA Rural Development awarded grants of $50,000 or less to 29
communities including the City of Blockton to help purchase a fire truck, the
City of Floris to assist with upgrades at their fire station and to Wayne County
Hospital to purchase a 3-D ultrasound machine and viewing station.

Since 2009, USDA Rural Development has invested nearly $3 billion in rural Iowa
on essential public facilities, small and emerging businesses, water and sewer
systems and housing opportunities for Iowa families.

Further information on programs available through USDA Rural Development is
available by calling (515) 284-4663 or by visiting the agency's web site at
www.rurdev.usda.gov/ia.

USDA Rural Development has 11 offices across the state to serve the 1.7 million
lowans living in rural communities and areas. Office locations include a State
Office in Des Moines, along with Area Offices in Albia, Atlantic, Humboldt,
Indi-anola, Iowa Falls, Le Mars, Mount Pleasant, Storm Lake, Tipton and Waverly.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities. USDA's
investments in rural communities support the rural way of life that stands as
the backbone of our American values.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                           November 09, 1999, Tuesday

Federal program to target area complex

BYLINE: AMYLIA WIMMER

SECTION: CITRUS TIMES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 386 words



The Atlantis Arms-Greenleaf Forest apartments will get an anti-drug program in
the wake of a government review of the complex.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture plans to initiate an anti-drug program at a
troubled low-income apartment complex in Crystal River and may send a team from
its national office to check on the management of the apartments.

U.S. Rep. Karen Thurman, D-Dunnellon, met last week with Jill Long Thompson, the
undersecretary for rural development at the U.S. Department of Agriculture. At
Thurman's request, the Office of Rural Development, an arm of the USDA, recently
completed a review of the Atlantis Arms-Greenleaf Forest apartments.

Although Rural Development's state office found that Jotar Management, the
Gainesville-based management company that runs the complex, does a poor job
maintaining good management at the complex, the office did not support other
allegations made against the company.

Steven and Jessica Taylor, former on-site managers at the apartments, have
accused the company of incorrectly reporting how many tenants it has to the
federal government. They also say that Jotar treats residents at Atlantis
Arms-Greenleaf Forest apartments unfairly by evicting them illegally and using
unfair reasons when refusing to admit tenants.

Residents of the apartments have made similar allegations.

Thurman pushed for the USDA to loan Jotar $ 1.4-million to fix up the apartments
and improve quality of life for the residents there. According to a news
release, Long Thompson told Thurman she will continue to keep an eye on the
complex.

"I'll send down a team from our national office to make sure that things are
being carried out properly because of the concerns raised by Rep. Karen
Thurman," Long Thompson said in a news release. "We'll also explore ways to
initiate an anti-drug program in the complex to reduce crime and other
problems."

Thurman said she was encouraged by the meeting with Long Thompson.

"Undersecretary Long Thompson assured me the inspection team will keep a close
eye on the bookkeeping procedures followed by the management company at the
facility," Thurman said in prepared remarks. "It is my hope that the inspection
and financial review will help to answer questions about the overall financial
management of the facility."

                      Western Morning News (Plymouth, UK)

                            November 4, 2008 Tuesday

Laying the foundations of affordable housing for all;
The overall aim of housing policy can be simply stated as an aspiration "to
provide a decent home for everyone at a price that they can afford", but it is
much harder to achieve in practice.

SECTION: Pg. 22

LENGTH: 951 words


In many ways it is even harder in rural areas due to a combination of high house
prices and low incomes, but even more important if villages are going to
continue as sustainable communities.

Affordable housing does not just mean social rented housing with low rents, but
a wide range of other tenures as well; shared ownership, shared equity, low cost
home ownership, sub-market rent and others. In practice it means close
coordination between the providers of finance, the Housing Corporation, housing
and planning sections of a local authority and providers and managers - mainly
housing associations and local authorities, but not exclusively.

An active local authority, like North Cornwall, uses every avenue to seek to
maximise the number of affordable dwellings that are provided.

In 2006/07 nearly 150 new affordable homes were built in North Cornwall. A
little more than 50 per cent were put up for rent by housing associations with
finance provided either by the Housing Corporation or through second homes
council tax, an extremely important source of funding. The remaining proportions
were dwellings for owner-occupation by three routes.

Firstly outright sale, with the prices fixed by the local authority. The re-sale
price is restricted by covenants to ensure that they remain affordable in
perpetuity, and the providers are private sector developers.

Secondly, shared ownership provided by housing associations, where the initial
occupiers buy a minimum 25 per cent share of the equity (but usually more) and
pay rent on the remaining proportion.

Thirdly - and uniquely - via a Community Land Trust (CLT) where a local
community provides owner occupied housing for local people where again the sale
price is restricted and remains affordable in perpetuity by covenants. CLTs
either need a grant or access to loan finance in the initial stage, in our case
provided by an interest free loan from the local authority to help the community
in St Minver. Another source of affordable housing is where local youngsters get
planning permission to build a dwelling for their own occupation on exception
sites on the edges of villages, usually on land that they or their relatives
own.

This form of provision indicates the importance of close cooperation between the
housing and planning departments of the local authority.

North Cornwall places development boundaries around all of its major villages
and many of its minor ones, giving opportunities for development of affordable
housing on exception sites adjacent to, but outside, the development boundary.
The landowner can expect to receive a price significantly above agricultural
value, but much less than open market value.

Another important source of sites is local authorities where the land is usually
transferred at minimal value, commonly £1, and is effectively donated free to
the affordable housing provider. The local authority has to show in its accounts
the real value of the land transferred and thus the assistance that they have
given.

District councils have become increasingly sophisticated and innovative in the
ways that they assist the provision of more affordable housing and it is very
important that this expertise is transferred to the forthcoming Unitary Council
in Cornwall.

There is an overall shortage of dwellings in the UK, including Cornwall, and we
must not forget that one of the most important ways to access affordable housing
is by the first time buyer. A combination of irresponsible lending by financiers
and a shortage of supply has driven prices to unsustainable levels.

When prices stabilise and the lenders have confidence to lend and the buyers to
buy, first time buyers will again become important. However unless we can
increase the supply, the same scenario is likely to repeat itself.

At a recent meeting of the South West Regional Assembly authorities of all
political colours firmly stuck their heads in the sand and refused to recognise
the importance of increasing supply. This makes it almost inevitable that higher
levels of future residential development will be imposed by the Government.

Although buy-to-let may have provided some additional private rented
accommodation it was, in my view, a largely negative development. Irresponsible
lending seems to have been particularly concentrated in this area, to purchasers
who were often naive, and believed that house prices would rise forever. It had
a particularly negative impact on first time buyers.

As we face responding to the greatest financial cataclysm since 1929, there are
bound to be negative short term impacts on affordable housing. Shared ownership
and low cost housing is proving very difficult to sell, so provision of more
rented housing becomes more important.

The Government has greatly increased the resources available to the Housing
Corporation for new schemes, and close cooperation between local authorities and
housing associations, often very good already, is key, particularly in obtaining
planning approvals for development.

Finally, we must not forget that affordable housing issues are exacerbated by
low average wages. The South West is unique in being the only English region
with above average house prices and below average wages.

The provision of good housing for all is an immensely important social objective
giving foundations to successful families and sustainable communities, and it is
an objective that many of us in public life seek to achieve.

Graham Facks-Martin has specialised in housing issues for more than 40 years. A
retired farmer, he is a member of a number of housing associations and currently
is the chair of Tor Homes, chair of the Cornwall Community Land Trust and chair
of North Cornwall District Council.

                                US Official News

                            October 2, 2014 Thursday

Agriculture, Rural Housing Service: SFH Technician IN-2015-001

LENGTH: 2987  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of Personnel Management has issued the following job announcement:

Job Title:SFH Technician

Department:Department Of Agriculture

Agency:Agriculture, Rural Housing Service

Job Announcement Number:IN-2015-001
SALARY RANGE:
 $35,417.00 to $46,037.00 / Per Year
OPEN PERIOD:
 Thursday, October 2, 2014 to Tuesday, October 14, 2014
SERIES & GRADE:
 GS-1101-06
POSITION INFORMATION:
 Full-Time - Permanent
PROMOTION POTENTIAL:
06
DUTY LOCATIONS:
 2 vacancies in the following location(s):
Columbia City, IN View Map
North Vernon, IN View Map
WHO MAY APPLY:


Current permanent Indiana Rural Development employees with competitive status,
reinstatement eligibles, persons with disabilities, VEOA/VRA eligibles, certain
military spouses, 30% or more disabled veterans, former Peace Corps or VISTA
volunteers, CTAP/ICTAP eligibles, Special Hiring Authorities.
SECURITY CLEARANCE:
 Q - Nonsensitive
SUPERVISORY STATUS:
 No
JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This position is being concurrently announced under Delegated Examining
Procedures on announcement number DEU-IN-2015-5258 which is open to any US
Citizen. Current and former Federal employees may apply to both announcements,
but should be sure to apply to this announcement to maximize opportunities for
consideration since different referral criteria apply to each announcement type.

This announcement will be used to fill one vacancy in each of the following
locations:  Columbia City, IN and North Vernon, IN.

The incumbent of this position is a member of AFGE #622.
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Not Required

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

US Citizenship is required.
    Selective Service Registration is required for males born after 12/31/1959.

DUTIES:
Back to top

The incumbent is responsible for providing a comprehensive range and variety of
technical and administrative loan assistance duties and responsibilities
associated with the Single Family Housing loan and grant functions.

As a technical resources, the incumbent functions in a technical and
administrative support capacity and, as such, is assigned duties that involve
technical and administrative functions associated with the SFH loan portfolio.
In the conduct of these functions, the incumbent may perform one or more of the
following agency regulatory functions, practices and activities as may be
required by the assigned portfolio:

Loan and Grant Processing
    Loan and Grant Servicing
    Outreach and Public Information
    General Office Administration

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:
Back to top

Applicants must meet all qualifications and eligibility requirements by the
closing date of the announcement including the following specialized experience
and/or education, as identified by grade level.

For GS-06: Applicants must have 1 year of specialized experience equivalent to
at least the GS-05; or its non-Federal equivalent that demonstrates: experience
providing assistance in processing loans; providing basic information on loan
programs; accepting, verifying, screening loan applications; preparing
correspondence and memos on routine loan matters; maintaining various program
reports of loan/grant activity; and ensuring current information is included in
the resource data base, etc. There is no substitution of education for
experience at the GS-06 level.

Specialized experience is any experience that equipped the applicant with the
particular competencies to perform successfully the duties of the position, and
that is typically in or related to the work of the position to be filled.

Rural Utility Service: Loan and Grant Technician DC-2014-0043

LENGTH: 3384  words

DATELINE: Washington


The United States Office of Personnel Management has issued the following job
announcement:

Job Title:Loan and Grant Technician

Department:Department Of Agriculture

Agency:Rural Utility Service

Job Announcement Number:DC-2014-0043
SALARY RANGE:
 $42,631.00 to $61,377.00 / Per Year
OPEN PERIOD:
 Wednesday, August 6, 2014 to Friday, August 15, 2014
SERIES & GRADE:
 GS-1101-07/08
POSITION INFORMATION:
 Full-Time - Permanent
PROMOTION POTENTIAL:
08
DUTY LOCATIONS:
 2 vacancies - Washington DC, DC View Map
WHO MAY APPLY:


Current permanent Federal employees with competitive status, reinstatement
eligibles, persons with disabilities, VEOA/VRA eligibles, certain military
spouses, 30% or more disabled veterans, former Peace Corps or VISTA volunteers,
CTAP/ICTAP eligibles, Farm Service Agency permanent county employees and those
eligible for other Special Hiring Authorities.
SECURITY CLEARANCE:
 Q - Nonsensitive
SUPERVISORY STATUS:
 No
JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This position is located in the Northern Engineering Branch, Assistant
Administrator-Telecommunications, Rural Utilities Service (RUS).  You will be
responsible for providing technical support to the processing of loans and
grants administered by the Rural Utilities Service.

This announcement may be used to fill additional or subsequent vacancies that
are identified by the organization.

TRAVEL REQUIRED

Not Required

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

US Citizenship is required.
    Selective Service Registration is required for males born after 12/31/1959.

DUTIES:
Back to top

Participates in coordinating workflow to prevent backlogs in the review and
approval of requests for loan fund advances, approval of contracts, amendments,
and force account proposals.
    Reviews and performs analysis of loan recommendations for special conditions
and provisions, as basis for control of loan funds.
    Reviews, analyzes, and processes claims for advances related to Grant and
Loan Programs.
    Ensures correct allocation of Federal and Grantees' matching shares of
expenditures.
    Identifies problems and prepares recommendations for corrective action, and,
when necessary, contacts borrower or grantee to take corrective action.
    Prepares and processes required documentation authorizing Loan and Grant
fund advances for Branch Chief's signature.
    Reviews, analyzes, and processes financial requirement statements,
closeouts, contracts, amendments, work orders, and statements of force account
construction.
    Reviews audit reports and reports of borrowers' expenditures to reconcile
budgeted amounts, advances, and expenditures with various contract documents,
identifies discrepancies, and recommends corrective action.
    Prepares correspondence to borrowers explaining complex budget adjustments.

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:
Back to top

Applicants must meet all requirements by the closing date of the announcement,
including time-in-grade and demonstrated specialized experience.

Time-in-Grade:  Applicants must meet one year at the next lower grade to be
considered for the next higher grade.  (e.g. one year at the GS-06 grade level
for consideration for the GS-07 grade level and one year at the GS-07 grade
level for consideration for the GS-08 grade level).

SPECIALIZED EXPERIENCE GS-07 level: Applicants must possess one year of
specialized experience at the GS-6 grade level or its non-federal equivalent and
must be directly related to the work of the position to be filled.  Examples of
specialized experience may include:  providing information on loan and/or
grants; accepting and verifying loan and/or grant matters; maintain various
program reports of loan and/or grant activities; loan and/or grant processing
experience such as receiving, screening, reviewing, and verifying documents;
maintaining records; providing readily available information orally or by
written correspondence; furnishing information and responding to general
questions from internal and external customers; experience in the use of various
computer programs to include lending, document, and spreadsheet type programs;
utilization of a variety of communication devices to include email (preferably
outlook), fax, and telephone; creating, reviewing, editing and distributing all
forms of correspondence; establishing, reviewing and closing loan documents and
files.

There is no education substitution for this grade level.

SPECIALIZED EXPERIENCE GS-08 level: Applicants must possess one year of
specialized experience at the GS-7 grade level or its non-federal equivalent and
must be directly related to the work of the position to be filled.  Examples of
specialized experience may include:  providing technical support on loan and/or
grant programs; accepting and verifying loan and/or grant matters; maintain
various program reports of loan and/or grant program activities; reviewing and
performing analysis of loan recommendations for special conditions and
provisions; loan and/or grant processing experience such as receiving,
screening, reviewing, and verifying documents; maintaining records; compiling
information; providing readily available information orally or by written
correspondence; and applying guidelines; furnishing information and responding
to non-routine or technical questions from internal and external customers;
experience in the use of various computer programs to include lending, document,
and spreadsheet type programs; experience creating, reviewing, editing and
distributing all forms of correspondence; establishing, reviewing, and closing
loan and/or grant documents and files.

NOTE: To be considered for this position, you must meet all qualification and
eligibility requirements for the GS-1101 series set forth in the Office of
Personnel Management Qualifications Standards by the closing date of the
announcement. A copy is available at:
http://www.opm.gov/qualifications/index.asp.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                            August 22, 1994, Monday

THE GREAT FLOOD OF '94 Newton feels recovery is 'in slow motion' Code problems
complicate aid

BYLINE: By Ellen Whitford STAFF WRITER

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Section A; Page 6

LENGTH: 758 words


Newton - The stench is gone, but the muck remains, and everywhere in this Flint
River town are muddy houses with blank windows and the forlorn look of
abandonment.

Newton, a town of 900 and the metropolis of rural Baker County in southwest
Georgia, has never had much glamour. But since July's flood engulfed its tiny
business district and swamped hundreds of its homes, sorrow has hung heavy in
the air.

"It's a gloomy feeling, " said Mamie Lenier, who runs one of Newton's two
grocery stores. "People want to be optimistic, but it's awful hard."

People are confused and frustrated by requirements for federal and state aid,
and the city's lax code enforcement has further complicated applications.

Newton's water supply was contaminated, and people still can't drink the tap
water.

And because neither the County Commission nor the City Council was willing to
make a plot of land available, the Federal Emergency Management Agency couldn't
loan mobile homes to flood victims who needed housing. Instead, FEMA gave them
travel trailers - about half the size of mobile homes, small enough to be placed
next to damaged houses.

"I'm telling you, we're in a mess," said Councilman Jack Henderson. "Tempers are
running high. People are pretty disgusted."

About 165 families were displaced by the flood; 40 homes were destroyed. Like
the majority of Newton's residents, most victims are poor or elderly. None has
been able to return home.

Everywhere that people gather here, their worried talk turns to federal aid,
conflicting information, eligibility requirements.

Rumors are rampant, misinformation abundant.

The tangle of rules, many residents say, doesn't live up to the early promises
of help or take into account individual needs.

"I don't want a 30-year loan," said Ann Bush, whose 65-year-old house flooded to
the attic.

"I'm 55. My husband's 70. How can we handle a 30-year loan?"

The confusion and barriers to assistance have been compounded further by the
town's distaste for outside interference and a history of doing things its own
way.

Newton has never enforced state building codes. But without those codes, the
town cannot participate in the federal program that allows residents to buy
flood insurance. Homeowners, in turn, cannot get low- interest disaster loans to
make repairs unless they buy federal flood insurance, according to FEMA
regulations.

Another complication: Federal regulations require that houses be built at least
a foot above the 100-year flood plain. But the city has no map showing elevation
points and the plain.

That map is being drawn by the Army Corps of Engineers, and two weeks ago, an
inspector was hired to issue permits and advise residents about building codes -
which the city has agreed to enforce.

Still, even state officials concede that an already arduous process has been
slowed down.

"It's been a little like a circus," said Deral Duke, a coordinator with the
Georgia Emergency Management Agency who is working in Newton. "Folks are
frustrated. I get cussed out several times a day."

"Everyone feels like we're moving in slow motion," said Bush, who is the county
tax commissioner. "There are a lot of 'ifs' and a lot of questions that nobody
knows the answers to."

One thing, however, is fairly certain: Newton will never be quite the same.

City officials have discussed applying for federal aid to rebuild the downtown
business district - about half a dozen businesses and city and county offices -
on higher ground.

If that happens, the town's old county courthouse, a turn-of-the- century red
brick building and historic landmark, would be abandoned. County commissioners
have said they do not plan to restore it.

In the meantime, residents are battling a lingering sense of disbelief. And
depression.

"I can't eat and I can't sleep," said Lenier, whose 100-year-old home was
flooded to the eaves. She and her husband, Michael, spent 26 years restoring it.

"Twenty-six years of my life just went down the river," she said.

Bush, who lives across the street with her husband, George, knows the feeling.
She wanders through their flood-damaged home every afternoon and cries.

On the land behind their house are vacant apartments. The couple had been
renovating them to rent.

"We were looking to our 'golden years,' " Bush said. "Thinking about retirement
and having a little extra income." She sighs. The apartments, like their home,
were engulfed in the flood.

"I know there are worse situations, and I thank God I've never been in one. This
is bad enough."

                             National Mortgage News

                                December 7, 1998

Sweet Harvest

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1065 words


Franklin, La., 125 miles west of New Orleans, is cane country.  The sugar cane
grows in waving stalks of green, higher than corn rows.  Late fall is harvest
time in cane country, and you can pass the stubble fields where it's been cut
down, see the big trucks bearing it away to be processed, smell the smoke from
where they're burning the leavings.  It's a sweet harvest, sugar cane.  And
there's another crop that's been planted out in cane country, a tender human
one, that's coming to fruition as well.

Franklin, a small town in St. Mary Parish in south central Louisiana, is just
about surrounded by cane.  At this time of year it's even in the highways, as it
blows out the top of the open trucks.  You can't do it any more, but people like
Almetra J. Franklin and Jeffrey Beverly are old enough to remember when you
could eat sugar cane.  It was a special variety, reddish-purple, called Two
Ninety (over the years the name got garbled into "Tu Niney").  Eating cane is
what the people called it, so sweet and tender that you could peel it with a
knife and chew on it right from the stalk.  But Tu Niney didn't process into
refined sugar as well as other varieties, so over the years it has gone out of
cultivation.

Well, maybe not quite.  Mrs. Franklin and Mr. Beverly are cultivating something
sweet in the rural reaches of St. Mary Parish.  Their crop is safe, decent,
affordable houses, and there's a harvest of successful, happier lives coming in
among the sweet fields of sugar cane.

Translate "Tu Niney" into two hundred-ninety dollars and you'll be in the range
that St. Mary Community Action Agency charges the residents of its Sparrow
Gardens project in nearby Centerville.  The 30 neat town houses there represent
the first completed housing development St. Mary CAA has done, although a
15-unit single-family project has been started and several more are on their
way.

Mrs. Franklin, the executive director of St. Mary, said that although the CAA
has been in business for 30 years, it wasn't until Hurricane Andrew blew through
the 58,000 population parish five years ago that the agency got into the housing
business.  The many displaced people made Mrs. Franklin and Mr. Beverly, the
housing development director at St. Mary, realize there was a great need for
affordable housing in the parish.  All around, but especially in the nearby
community of Garden City, they found very substandard housing, places with no
electricity or indoor plumbing.

So they got busy, getting designated the first community housing development
organization (CHDO) in the state (Mrs. Franklin is now state CHDO president) in
order to get funding for low income housing.  Then they put together the usual
multiplicity of funding sources it takes to make a big multifamily project work
in rural America.  A permanent loan of $ 144,000 was obtained from a local
lender, Whitney Bank.  Boston Capital syndicated $ 600,000 in Low Income Housing
Tax Credits.  The Department of Housing and Urban Development's HOME program
came up with another $ 700,000, making the total financing around $ 1.4 million.

The units range from two to four bedrooms, and the tenants pay between $ 245 and
$ 380 a month in rent.  At dusk, the development is quiet and peaceful, and
visits to two of the tenants reinforce the feeling that Sparrow Gardens is a
sweet place to live.

Brenda Cage has lived in her two-bedroom 1,000 square-foot unit for a year, and
she loves it there.  Now an associate at WalMart, she is a graduate of the St.
Mary CAA Head Start program.  Her boys, Aaron, 7, and Gavin, 6, are pleasant
young men who attend Centerville High (a 12-year school) and eagerly rattle off
a list of television programs and movies they like.

One of their neighbors, Anna Hamilton, is a teacher in the Head Start program.
The mother of seven and grandmother of ten, Ms. Hamilton calls the development a
beautiful program.  Her well-kept home is decorated by numerous photos of her
children and grandchildren, including one charming young lady who already is a
beauty queen.

Sparrow Gardens is just the first in a series of developments that have taken
St. Mary CAA forward from its original housing role as provider of housing
education, rehab and weatherization expertise.  Currently underway is Faith
Place, a 15-unit single-family project in Patterson, La.  Three of the units are
under construction now, using construction money from Hibernia Bank.  The
Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas has provided a $ 225,000 Affordable Housing
Program grant, and the Louisiana Housing Finance Agency is down for $ 900,000 in
mortgage money through a revenue bond program.  The USDA Rural Development
program will be involved, as well.

Mortgages will be for approximately $ 47,000, and monthly payments will range
from $ 235, to $ 320.  The units feature lots of 72' by 125' and are being built
in different styles to resemble the range of models that would be found in a
suburban neighborhood.

In development now is Isaiah's House, a project planned to rehab six units in
Franklin for senior citizens.  Funding in the works includes rehab money from
the McAuley Institute, a no-interest loan from the St. Mary parish council, and
a grant from the city of Franklin.  Other possibilities include the Norwest
Foundation and the Whitney Bank Community Development Corp.

A unique project underway is Hope House, a housing lab donated by the city of
Franklin.  The house now sits on the CAA grounds, where the city brought it
after taking it off its foundation, and when it gets fixed up it will serve as a
hands-on homeowner education lab.  Potential owners will be saving up for their
downpayments through Individual Development Accounts, and the CAA will look for
a grant which will allow them to earn matching funds.  In the hopper?  A
self-help building project Mrs. Franklin is in the process of applying for.

Although it had gotten too dark to see anything very clearly, Mrs. Franklin and
Mr.  Beverly wanted to show off Faith Place to a visitor on his way back to New
Orleans.  While there, one of the potential new homeowners drove by the site,
just making sure everything was still okay.  He didn't have to, but he was
checking on the growth, on the day's progress, watching over his new home like a
farmer might eye his fields of sugar cane, thinking about the sweet harvest
about to come in.

local community; Picture 2, Anna Franklin sits surrounded by photos of her
children and grandchildren in her townhome in Sparrow Gardens, Centerville, La.;
Picture 3, Aaron Cage, left, with brother Gavin and mother, Brenda Cage, likes
their unit in Sparrow Gardens.
