                             Daily News (New York)

                             June 24, 2001, Sunday

CUOMO'S ERIE CANAL DREAM IS DRYING UP   $237 million for tourism mecca a bust

BYLINE: BY RUSS BUETTNER DAILY NEWS STAFF WRITER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6 DAILY NEWS INVESTIGATION

LENGTH: 2345 words

HOLLEY, N.Y. - For four years, first as federal housing secretary and now as a
candidate for governor, Andrew Cuomo has promised repeatedly to transform the
modest Erie Canal into "an unparalleled national and international tourism
attraction."

During annual trips to the canal - called The Ditch by some locals - Cuomo has
depicted a future made prosperous by boaters and cyclists filling new hotels,
restaurants and renovated historical sites.

He has talked about the "thousands of jobs" that would be created by his plan to
infuse 32 suffering counties with $237 million in federal housing money.

"You see a barge canal, I see a gold mine," Cuomo once said to a crowd near the
waterway.

But a Daily News examination of his Canal Corridor Initiative in rural Orleans
County suggests that, in this pocket at least, Cuomo's gold mine has gone bust.

The $9 million in grants and loans awarded in the county under Cuomo's plan has
created just two jobs - in a beauty salon.

Some of the spending indicates a haphazard approach far from the original goal
of turning the region into a tourism mecca.

The federal Department of Housing and Urban Development provided $60,000 to help
the owner of Krantz Furniture in Albion renovate the facade of her 166-year-old
building.

It provided a low-interest loan to help new owners buy Double Dips, a
50-year-old ice cream stand a mile from the canal.

And it awarded this tiny village 20 miles west of Rochester nearly $1 million to
build a vast park that includes two polished stone markers bearing the
inscription "Andrew Cuomo Canalway Trail" - a path only slightly longer than 100
yards.

"I know Andrew Cuomo promoted it as creating hundreds and hundreds of jobs,"
said Martin Busch, chairman of the canal task force in the town of Medina. "But
I don't know that the Canal Corridor Initiative was all that successful in
that."

Cuomo, 43, the eldest son of former Gov. Mario Cuomo, has touted the initiative
in courting the conservative canal region voters who soundly rejected his father
in 1994.

"I did more for upstate New York from Washington than the [Pataki]
administration has done from Albany," Cuomo boasted recently.

On his campaign Web site, under the headings Creating Jobs for New Yorkers and
Revitalizing the Erie Canal, the initiative tops the list of claimed Cuomo
achievements.

"As HUD assistant secretary, and then as secretary, Cuomo began and implemented
the Canal Corridor Initiative that resulted in billions of dollars in public and
private investment and created 27,000 jobs," the site says.

The claim is an apparent reference to a Cornell University study, funded by HUD,
that said if tourism in the region climbed by 5%, 27,000 new jobs would follow.
However, the study said such a jump had not yet occurred.

Cuomo, who headed HUD from 1997 until January, has blamed the state in
interviews for slowing the approval of building permits along the canal and has
argued that the plan needs more time. But of the $237 million in federal housing
funds he dedicated to the initiative, $202 million has been spent or will soon
expire.

A spokesman for Gov. Pataki, Cuomo's opponent next year should he win the
Democratic nomination over state Controller Carl McCall, called the initiative
an example of Cuomo's "abject failure" at HUD.

"His penchant for exaggeration and overstatement is remarkable and is actually
becoming legendary," said Mike McKeon, a Pataki spokesman.

A Cuomo spokesman, Peter Ragone, responded to numerous requests for comment with
a single E-mail. He listed nine towns and one county where, he said, the program
has been a success.

"If the project is given the opportunity to work, independent economists agree
that it will bring millions of dollars and tens of thousands of jobs to
depressed areas of the state by helping them build on the human, physical and
natural resources of the region," Ragone said in the message.

REMAINS OF BETTER DAYS

In 1825, the Erie Canal opened the first passage for commerce to the Midwest by
connecting the Hudson River to Lake Erie.

During those early boom years, villages sprouted along the canal's 363-mile
route, serving as ports where local fruits and grains were loaded aboard
mule-pulled barges.

But railroads and big trucks eventually rendered the canal obsolete. The loss of
manufacturing jobs brought more pain.

Today, the canal, roughly the width of a two-lane road in many sections, is
filled with water only six months of the year.

Some villages along its banks retain their 19th-century charm. But many show the
strain of decades without a viable economy.

Talk of turning the tide by luring tourists to the area had long been part of
the landscape when Cuomo announced his plan in 1996.

Beyond Orleans County, communities with economic development plans - but no
money - leaped to action.

In Ithaca, on the southern tip of one of the Finger Lakes, a $350,000 HUD grant
paid to clean up industrially contaminated land. This January, The Boatyard
Grill, a 176-seat waterside restaurant, opened on the site with the help of an
$800,000 loan under the HUD program.

An HUD-subsidized loan of $2.1 million at 2% interest helped persuade Sealright,
a multinational manufacturer of paper containers, not to shutter its facility in
Fulton, 15 miles north of Syracuse.

A few miles north of Fulton, on the shores of Lake Ontario, the town of Oswego
was issued a $650,000 low-interest HUD loan that allowed a new owner to buy a
closed restaurant and reopen it as Coleman's Irish Pub.

But in Orleans County, Cuomo's most ambitious economic development plan has
added up to little more than a costly parks project. The folly is most apparent
here in Holley.

Leaders in this village of 1,900 used $67,684 in federal money to buy 30 acres
of undeveloped land. Then they stuffed it with outdoor goodies.

There's a 300-foot wooden boat dock and a large shower facility. There's a big
jungle gym that cost $32,240, and a charming white-and-red gazebo.

Nearby, a wooden pedestrian bridge will soon arch across a small stream, where
another gazebo is to be built. A large field will have pavilions, picnic benches
and barbecues.

"We wrote a very good grant and got everything we asked for," said Mayor Lewis
Passarell.

Many locals are grateful.

"It's real nice," said retired Kodak worker Chuck Sedita, 76, as he sat under
the gazebo, one of two people in the park on a recent warm Friday afternoon.
"Some weekends we have little bands playing. People pull their boats up and
listen for a while."

But four years after the canal dock opened, the economic benefits are hard to
find.

"We've had some boaters walk over, enough that you notice it," said George
Gitsis, owner of Sam's Diner, Holley's only sit-down restaurant. "But not enough
where you hire more people - just everybody works a little harder."

Susan Schuler, manager of the HSBC branch, the village's only bank, said
deposits from retail businesses have not increased over previous summers. "I
think they've done a beautiful job, but I haven't seen any impact yet," she
said.

Worse, maintenance of the park - along with free electricity and water hookups
to boaters - might strain the village's small tax base.

In its grant proposal to HUD, the village cited one source of income: the
showers.

"They will be coin operated, and at 75 cents per shower will produce an
estimated $250 per season in revenues," the proposal said.

Overall, HUD awarded the village $1.6 million - a $900,000 grant for the park,
the maximum offered, and the remainder in a loan pool to attract new employers.

But the loan concept failed.

"We did not put out one loan," Passarell said. "We had a guy - our dentist - go
through quite a few stages of it. And finally he got so upset with it that he
went out privately and got a loan."

HUD's inspector general issued an audit in March that said the loan program had
stalled the canal initiative's job-creation goals. Following years of attacks on
the office, a Cuomo spokesman dismissed the audit as the work of political
partisans.

But even some of the plan's supporters cite the loan mechanism as problematic.

Susan Christopherson, the Cornell University professor who studied Cuomo's
initiative, said the loan program is not suited to the smaller businesses needed
in the most rural and troubled canal towns.

"The [loan] program is not a great tool to do what they wanted to do with it,
but it was the tool that they had," Christopherson said.

Still, Christopherson believes the program may someday bring the 5% increase in
tourism estimated in her study.

"I'm a passionate believer in this program," she said.

The loans to businesses are guaranteed by the community's future HUD grants. To
limit the risk to towns, HUD sets burdensome rules. Borrowers must put up 25%
more in collateral than the loan amount. And they must show that most who
benefit will be of low or moderate income.

"The [loan] program is too difficult for these small communities that have never
done them before," said Harry Sicherman, a former HUD employee who now works as
a consultant to communities seeking grants, including Holley.

BOOMTOWN? NOT

So far in Orleans County, only two businesses have taken loans under Cuomo's
program - and neither is exactly tailor-made to create a tourism boom.

At Celebrity Day Spa in Medina, a low-interest loan paid for high-tech pedicure
and water-massage equipment. The owner added two employees - the only permanent
hires in the county attributable to Cuomo's initiative. HUD announcements had
predicted the creation of 286 jobs in the county.

The other loan enabled Rich and Denise Albone to buy the Double Dips ice cream
stand. But Rich Albone said that consultant fees and the slow approval process
made the loan less attractive than it first sounded.

"We wouldn't recommend that anybody go through it," he said.

Cuomo's plan also offered help to businesses with matching grants for
improvements.

Only one business in Orleans County got such a grant, Krantz Furniture of
Albion, which is fixing up its facade.

Owner Linda Smith praised the $60,000 gift. "I probably would have done it
anyway, but it certainly made it much less of a burden on me," she said.

Cuomo's spokesman argued that no single county can accurately portray the
initiative's progress.

"Anyone who is serious about understanding the needs of upstate New York knows
that the region cannot be viewed as a series of counties and towns that are not
connected," Ragone wrote in the statement. "This is the kind of shortsighted
thinking that hurt these places in the first place."

In fact, the initiative's sparse job creation in Orleans County may not
necessarily represent its impact statewide. But the county received a
larger-than-average award, and its problems putting the money to good use don't
bode well for scores of other targeted communities.

In terms of money, the initiative is nearing its end - 85% of what Cuomo
committed has been spent or will soon be taken off the table. The remaining
$35.6 million is in the loan program.

In 33 communities, projects originally awarded $34.7 million have stalled and
will lose funding unless complete plans are submitted by Sept. 30, under an
agreement HUD signed last year with New York State.

That deadline came out of negotiations to give New York State control of the
funding streams Cuomo used for the initiative, authority that every other state
except Hawaii already held.

Cuomo's spokesman blamed Pataki for demanding the deadline.

"Unfortunately, any funds taken off the table for local communities will be done
by President Bush and Gov. Pataki just to serve partisan political purposes,"
said spokesman Ragone in the written statement.

Among the endangered canal projects: a $3.1 million loan pool to finance a hotel
in Waterford and a $1.3 million loan to rebuild, as a historical attraction, a
tunnel system in Lockport that once generated mechanical power from the passing
canal water.

LOSING BATTLE

Some question whether Cuomo's majestic vision of tourism could ever rescue the
smaller villages along the canal.

The rural communities face stiff competition from big attractions - such as
Niagara Falls, the Finger Lakes and Lake Ontario.

The canal offers a quaint appeal to boaters, but not without frustration. The
speed limit is 10 mph, and scores of drawbridges slow the going even more.

Also, the short tourism season - a few months between brutal winters - makes it
nearly impossible for businesses to survive on that single strategy.

"As a tourist destination, it would be found wanting," said Frank Mahady of FMX
Associates of Massachusetts, which studied the issue in 1993 for upstate
counties and the state.

Jerome Wilson of Albion is a case in point.

He was to receive a low-interest loan under Cuomo's program to expand his
business, Archer Lumber, into renting bicycles, canoes and paddleboats.

But facing competition from big lumberyards in Buffalo and Rochester, Wilson
closed down last month without expanding.

"I can tell you for sure that nobody here can survive on tourism alone right
now," Wilson said. "It might pay off someday, but it's not there yet."

Cuomo's canal money did create some work here in Holley - for the contractors
who built the park, at least two of whom are related to town leaders.

Roger Passarell, the mayor's cousin, built the gazebo and showers, for which he
was paid $120,069. The son of a village trustee built the dock.

Town leaders said the bidding process was fair and open, but it drew few
responses.

"That bugs me," Ross Gaylord, 64, a former village board member said of the
politically connected hires. "I think it shows favoritism."

Gaylord also thinks the village should stop spending on parks.

"It looks very nice, but I think it's gone far enough," he said. "I don't feel
it really benefits us."

Business Digest

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 363 words


ClearOne wins monetary damages in trade-secret case

Salt Lake City-based ClearOne Communications Inc. said it has received a
multimillion-dollar damage award in a federal trade-secret case.

The company had contended that Biamp Systems Corp., WideBand Solutions Inc. and
several individuals, including a former employee, misappropriated trade secrets
that included algorithms and computer code used in its audio conferencing
equipment.

ClearOne said in a news release that a federal jury awarded it about $3.5
million compensatory damages and $7 million in punitive damages.

- Steven Oberbeck

Nov. 14 forum to focus on issues relevant Utah's economy

The Salt Lake Chamber is collaborating with the Sutherland Institute, a
conservative think tank, to create a forum for discussing issues relevant to
Utah's economy.

The issues will likely be "complex and sometimes controversial," according to
the Utah Prosperity Forum.

The first topic will examine a private economic growth strategy that balances
traditional practices of business recruitment.

The forum will be held at the Sutherland Institute, 307 W. 200 South, suite
5005, from noon to 1:30 p.m., Nov. 14. Cost is $10, which includes lunch.
Register by calling 801-355-1272, visiting www.sutherland

institute.org, or sending an e-mail to si@sutherland

institute.org. Registration closes Nov. 13 at noon.

- Paul Beebe

Low-interest home loans available for rural residents

Low-interest home loans are available for rural residents, with financing up to
100 percent loan-to-value and no down payment.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture Rural Development has announced a decrease in
the home mortgage interest rate for its Section 502 Homeownership Direct Loan
Program. The interest rate has been reduced to 5.375 percent, down from 5.750
percent. Depending on household incomes, mortgage payments may be subsidized to
as low as a 1 percent interest rate.

The loan program is available to eligible very-low and low-income households to
buy an existing home, buy a site and construct a dwelling or purchase a newly
constructed dwelling in rural areas.

For more information, visit http://eligibility.sc.egov.usda.gov or call
801-524-4320.

- Dawn House

Scotiabank Costa Rica SME and Housing Loan

LENGTH: 571  words


Region : Latin America and the Caribbean
Sector : O-AA - Commercial Banking - General
Department : Global Industry, Financial Markets
Environmental category : FI2
Date SPI disclosed : September 2, 2016
Projected board date : October 4, 2016
Project Description : The project consists of a loan of up to US$75 million to
Scotiabank de Costa Rica S.A. (the  Bank ) for on-lending to SMEs and low and
middle income mortgages.


Project Sponsor and Major Shareholders of Project Company :


The Bank is a 100% owned subsidiary of Grupo BNS de Costa Rica SA. Grupo BNS de
Costa Rica SA is in turn 80.2% owned by BNS International SA (Panama) and 19.7%
owned by Corporacion Mercaban de Costa Rica, both of which are wholly owned
subsidiaries of The Bank of Nova Scotia, a publicly listed company in Canada.
Total Project Cost and Amount and Nature of IFC's Investment :


The proposed investment consists of a senior loan of up to US$75 million.
Location of Project and Description of Site : The Bank is headquartered in San
Jose and has 34 branches in the country.
Expected Development Impact :


Financial Inclusion: Costa Rica's private sector credit to GDP ratio is below
the regional average. Funding a leading private sector bank will support
increased banking penetration and access to financial services for businesses
and individuals in Costa Rica.
Employment Generation: Improving access to finance for SMEs that lack sufficient
funding and thereby contributing to increased job creation in the country.
Providing loans to new and underserved SME clients translates into larger
production scales requiring additional workers, especially for the bottom 40
percent among the large pool of unskilled labor force.
Shared Prosperity: Access to housing finance for low and medium income
individuals will help reduce high inequality in the country and improve shared
prosperity. Like many other emerging markets, Costa Rica has an unmet demand for
housing finance driven by growing incomes and rapid urbanization.
IFC's Expected Role and Additionality :


Long term partnership across the region: IFC has partnered with The Bank of Nova
Scotia and its subsidiaries across Latin America and the Caribbean. Most
recently IFC has provided digital financial services workshop to Scotiabank's
LAC operations, is engaged in a rural/agri microcredit advisory project with
CreditScotia in Peru, is discussing a DARP program in the Caribbean as well as
in Latin America and is investigating potential for investments in
infrastructure in Latin America. The Bank of Nova Scotia is also a recurring top
partner on trade, having confirmed more than US$1.8 billion, #4 in the GTFP
league tables for volumes.

Financial Sector Consolidation: By supporting one of the strongest regional
financial groups in Latin America, IFC will enable Scotiabank to play a critical
role in the growth and consolidation of the banking sector in Costa Rica and
enabling the private sector bank

                               Right Vision News

                            March 16, 2011 Wednesday

USA: Officials Join Lt. Gov. Skillman to Celebrate North Vernon's "Stellar
Community"

LENGTH: 428  words

DATELINE: STATE HOUSE


STATE HOUSE, March 16 -- The State Of Indiana has issued following press
release:

Lt. Governor Becky Skillman joined officials from North Vernon and leaders from
Muscatatuck Urban Training Center this afternoon to celebrate the city's
selection as a Hoosier "Stellar Community".

Stellar Communities is a first of its kind collaboration initiated by Lt.
Governor Skillman between INDOT, the Office of Community and Rural Affairs
(OCRA), the Indiana Housing and Community Development Authority (IHCDA), and the
State Revolving Fund to help execute communities' strategic plans.

"The State of Indiana is only as strong as its individual communities," Lt.
Governor Skillman said. "North Vernon is on the verge of being a hub for the
defense industry, and Stellar Communities will go a long way in helping the city
achieve that goal."

North Vernon's Stellar Communities application will make the downtown area more
inviting for business and improve housing options in the city. The community
plans to:

* Redevelop a 3.5 acre Brownfield site, clearing the way for private investment

* Restore the Carnegie Library

* Renovate the Depot Events Center

* Install new sidewalks, curbs, landscaping, lighting, and signage on downtown
streetscapes

* Revitalize the Irish Hill neighborhood by improving streetscapes and creating
low- to moderate-income housing

* Close Short Street to create a pedestrian-friendly plaza space

* Develop Main Street for mixed commercial and residential use

The total proposed cost of all Greencastle's Stellar Community projects is
estimated at $16 million. The State of Indiana expects to contribute at least
$12 million to the projects over three years, including $6 million in grants
from INDOT; $1.5 million in grants from OCRA; and nearly $5 million in loans,
tax credits, or grants from IHCDA. The community will provide approximately $2.4
million in matching funds.

"Our region is not able to take full advantage of Muscatatuck without a vibrant
North Vernon," Mayor Harold "Soup" Campbell said. "Without Stellar Communities,
we would certainly lose out on millions of dollars of economic activity."

Funding for the initiatives comes from multiple existing federal funds. State
agencies will continue to offer grant programs to local units of government not
participating in Stellar Communities.

                          The Daily Telegraph (London)

                           February 4, 2017 Saturday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Empty homes have doubled since 1996;
More development will not lower house prices but simply add to the overall
surplus, experts warn

BYLINE: Christopher Hope

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 537 words


THE number of empty homes in the UK has nearly doubled in 20 years, calling into
question whether new housing developments need to be built in the countryside.

The figures come ahead of a major government initiative to encourage more house
building, which Theresa May will launch next week.

The Housing White Paper will propose that car parks near railway stations be
used for new homes, reserve sites for prefab homes and will force developers to
build homes more quickly on sites that have planning permission.

Analysis of government figures shows that there are more than one million homes
above those which are required for the number of households in the UK.

This "housing surplus" has nearly doubled from 800,000 spare homes in 1996 to
1.4million homes at any one time in 2014.

These "empty homes" are typically second homes, or vacant properties that are
either left empty or are waiting for tenants or homeowners to move in.

Ian Mulheirn, an expert from Oxford Economics, said the figures suggested that
allowing developers to build more homes would not bring down house prices. Three
factors drove house prices - the cost of mortgage debt, household incomes and
the supply of houses.

Mr Mulheirn said prices were only likely to come down when mortgage rates begin
to rise. "The point is there are more dwellings than there are households," he
said.

He added that relatively cheap access to credit, combined with bigger incomes in
some middle-class families, had driven house prices up.

Asked if this could be solved by building more homes, Mr Mulheirn said: "The
answer is no.

The evidence suggests that there are more surplus houses than there were 20
years ago."

Shaun Spiers, the chief executive of the Campaign to Protect Rural England,
said: "There is no quick fix to resolve the housing shortage. But as well as
building more homes, the Government must do more to ensure that the homes we
already have are lived in.

"People will be much less willing to accept the loss of green space for housing
if they see homes lying empty and redundant buildings that could be converted
going to waste."

A report from Oxford Economics two months ago found that between 1996 and 2006
house prices rose by 151 per cent after adjusting for general inflation.

It said that rising earnings and falling interest rates, rather than
insufficient supply, drove the boom in house prices between 1996 and 2006.

Additional supply, or shortfalls in supply, only affects prices if sustained
over long periods, it said. A one per cent increase in the number of houses, or
a one per cent fall in the number of households, would reduce house prices by
1.8 per cent. The review added: "In the context of a stock of over 28 million
dwellings in the UK in 2014, this means that even when new supply outstrips new
household formation, its impact on prices is likely to be small unless sustained
over a long period."

A spokesman for the Department for Communities and Local Government said: "This
is completely misleading as it contains figures on some second homes.

The reality is, empty homes are at their lowest level since records began and
we've made it easier for councils to convert derelict properties into homes,
breathing new life into empty buildings."

                        The Pueblo Chieftain (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            November 6, 2009 Friday

Home starts stay anemic: Pueblo's home starts remain at recession lows.

BYLINE: Dennis Darrow, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 301 words


Nov. 6--Home construction in Pueblo County remained mired in a three-year-long
slump through October.

Countywide, there were 11 home starts in the month, tied with March for the
second-lowest number since the local housing crash started in September 2006,
according to Pueblo Regional Building Department and Horizon Communities Inc.
statistics.

The fewest number of monthly permits was nine in August.

For the year, Pueblo County is on pace for 173 home starts, the lowest annual
total since the early 1980s when Pueblo's jobless rate approached 20 percent due
to massive steel mill layoffs. Pueblo's peak year of home building was 2006 with
1,200 home starts.

The number of starts dropped to 665 two years ago and 394 last year.

The slowdown has hit Pueblo West hardest.

Once the site of most of the area's home construction, Pueblo West has seen its
home starts drop below the city of Pueblo's levels this year. Pueblo reported 65
home starts through October; Pueblo West 55.

Home construction is a key sector of a city's economy, responsible for thousands
of jobs and also a major driver of overall economic growth through the issuance
of home loans.

ddarrow@chieftain.com

4DFriday, November 6, 2009

Rural areas 5

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                    February 8, 2000, Tuesday, Home Edition

Some builders see a modular future;
 Skeptics abound, but supporters cite lower costs and a way to beat labor
shortages.

BYLINE: Susan Harte, Staff

SOURCE: CONSTITUTION

SECTION: Business; Pg. 3D

LENGTH: 609 words

Gene and Robyn Turner spent part of a morning watching their new white cottage
lumber down the highway atop an 18-wheel, flatbed truck.

It rolled into the drive, and cranes gently set it down on its prepared
foundation near Washington, Ga.

A team of a half-dozen craftsmen then secured the house to its foundation,
joined the two halves, raised the roof and put in the stairway to the basement.

By the end of the day, the 2,800-square-foot house with green shutters was ready
to be carpeted.

The Turners' house cost about $ 52 per finished square foot, excluding the
5-acre lot.

Builders who use the modular system can save up to 20 percent on labor costs and
building materials, said Atlantan Ken Parris, president of Persimmon Homes,
which built the Turners' modular home.

He and other proponents of modular housing say it is the wave of the future.

"I think they stand a chance of penetrating 5 percent of the market," said
Heather McKeon, the editor of Professional Builder magazine. "Nobody can find
framers today."

But doubters are less sure.

"I don't think builders will buy this. These houses are vanilla (bland)," said
Roger Festa of LandMark Development. "They are starter homes for rural areas."

"You have to have a buyer ready to move in soon," said Bob Thomas, vice
president of New South Federal Savings Bank. "You have to sell them quickly to
make any money.

"You cannot keep modular houses as speculative homes for more than 30 days,
because, unlike your regular construction loan, the builder has to pay upfront
for the product," he said.

Still, the modular housing industry's annual revenue is around $ 8 billion, a
study by the Freedonia Group reports.

The shortage of construction workers in Georgia also may drive up the demand for
modular housing.

According to the Georgia Department of Labor, job orders during the latter half
of 1999 suggest a shortage of skilled workers in the building trades.

"During the six months, Georgia employers requested 4,135 workers in the
structural categories, which includes the building trades plus assembly lines at
General Motors, Ford and Lockheed," said John Ard, a department spokesman. "We
filled only 1,337."

Parris, who says cheap labor and building materials are disappearing in the
South, is banking on the growth of modular housing. He's investing $ 3 million
to $ 5 million in a 135,000-square-foot plant in Wilkes County. He employs 30
people there. At full capacity, targeted for mid-2001, the facility will employ
200 full-time workers.

Parris says the plant can make up to four modular houses a day, or 1,000 a year.
His full-time computer-aided designers can make flexible floor plans for homes
ranging in price from $ 90,000 to more than $ 1 million.

The one- or two-story structures are deliverable within a 300-mile radius of the
factory, he said.

The Turners noticed only one crack in the interior plaster of their modular
home, a small one that was easily repaired.

"System-built houses are constructed to the same building codes and regulations
that apply to on-site construction," said Jerry Hurd-Smith, program coordinator
for the Georgia Department of Community Affairs.

Elkhart, Ind.-based Coachmen Industries makes and sells modular homes under the
All American Homes brand name. Its 1998 revenue was $ 756 million.

Other builders use pre-manufactured parts.

"We are already using manufactured floors, roof trusses and wall panels," said
Tom Bradbury, president of Colony Homes, whose average home price is $ 120,000.
"It depends on the buyer profile. In some markets, standardization is part of
the affordability."

LOAD-DATE: February 8, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

THE MODULAR HOUSING INDUSTRY
The " industrialized housing industry" includes homes built on-site with
factory- produced materials, and homes built of panels or modules made in a
factory and transported to site.
Production of modular homes increased 16 percent between 1998 and 1999, to
163,000 units, and is expected to increase by another 18 percent in 2000.
The value of expected shipments by 2002 is $ 15 billion.
Modular builders expect to see first-quarter sales up by 18 percent over the
year-ago period.

                     Coffs Coast Advocate (New South Wales)

                            March 14, 2012 Wednesday

INDUSTRY BRIEFS

SECTION: Pg. 73

LENGTH: 375  words

Affordable Aussie dream

HOUSING affordability has hit a two-year high.

A Real Estate Institute of Australia (REIA) report found that in the December
quarter of 2011, the proportion of income needed to meet loan repayments
decreased by 0.7% to 32.9%.

The decline was the third improvement in housing affordability across 2011.

The number of loans to first home buyers over the quarter increased in all
states and territories.

"It is positive that we are seeing small increases in first home buyers
returning to the market but would like to see a more significant change which
will come from improved affordability and greater consumer confidence," REIA
president Pamela Bennett said.

The report found the Australian Capital Territory remained the most affordable
state or territory in which to buy a home.

Prime real estate opportunities

NOW that the Lifehouse Church has settled into its new Orlando St premises, the
land which had been earmarked as its future home is up for sale.

The church initially planned to build on two development sites totalling 4.95ha
at South Coffs Harbour.

The sites, with Pacific Hwy frontage, have been listed for sale by expressions
of interest by First National Real Estate Coffs Harbour.

Principal Barry Booth expects demand for Lot 1 will come from businesses looking
for highway exposure on 9376sq m.

Mr Booth said Lot 2 would appeal to buyers seeking a rural/residential lifestyle
offered by the existing home on 4.2ha.

Coffs real estate ok

THE GRASS may always be greener, but not when it comes to real estate values on
the Mid North Coast.

While 2011 was a roller-coaster for real estate in the region, RPData figures
show Mid North Coast values declined by just 1.5%.

While no-one ever likes to see prices slide, things got a lot worse in other
areas of the country where some suburbs and towns said goodbye to close to half
their homes' value.

The worst case was flood-affected North Booval, west of Brisbane, where the
median house price dropped 46.3% to $154,000.

The median price of units in Mittagong in the NSW Southern Highlands plummeted
45.1% to $225,000.

Premium capital city properties also suffered; St Kilda West was the worst of
the millionaire row performers. Prices in the Melbourne suburb dropped by 41.8%
to $1.455m.

                         The Dispatch, Lexington, N.C.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          December 11, 2013 Wednesday

Few speak at CDBG hearing

BYLINE: Nash Dunn, The Dispatch, Lexington, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 585 words


Dec. 11--Davidson County can possibly seek up to $7 million at 2 percent
interest for an economic development Community Development Block Grant, which
would be funneled through the state department of commerce by the U.S.
Department of Housing and Urban Development.

The money would be used to help develop about 500 acres of land south of Belmont
Road to attract new companies to the area.

Local government watchdog Barney Hill and former commissioner candidate David
Speight argued against the use of the federal funds during an initial public
hearing on the issue Tuesday.

"My main objection to the CDBG program has been that it inverts, subverts and
perverts the founders' vision of federalism," Hill said. "I also have complained
that the bankrupt national government can no longer afford to shower every local
government with blessings."

The Davidson County Economic Development Commission has been the main proponent
of the park for more than 10 years. EDC Executive Director Steve Googe said
CDBGs are an integral part of America's growth, the lifeblood of nonpolitical
growth awarded on need, not politics.

Googe said the grants have accounted for about 4,000 jobs in the county and
benefitted companies like TIMCO Aviation Services, Lolly Wolly Doodle and more
recently SV Plastics and Mill-Chem Manufacturing, among others.

The loan must be repaid within seven years, but only interest payments are
required for the first two years, according to county documents.

Commissioners are also inquiring about a second, $2 million Rural Economic
Development Loan and Grant through the United States Department of Agriculture.
The USDA provides the zero interest loans to local utility companies, which
direct funding to local governments.

The REDLG loan, which would flow through EnergyUnited in this scenario, is
repayable over a 10-year period.

If awarded and approved, the loans would likely be Davidson County government's
stake in a planned limited liability company organizing the industrial park.

In the LLC concept, landowners will pool their properties with other municipal
agencies or private companies that provide infrastructure or other assets for
the development. Each contributor's share will depend on what their asset was
valued, and later, when the land is sold to a company or other entity, the
various members split the profits.

Other potential partners will likely include entities that provide
infrastructure-related assets at the site, including the City of Lexington.

Initial phases of the project include about 500 acres directly south of Belmont
Road near the interstate. Robin Team, president of Davidson Progress, a
nonprofit economic development driver and LLC manager, said in a recent
interview that most of the property is owned by several large-tract landowners,
who have given an oral agreement to commit their parcels to the entity. There
are about 12 total landowners in the initial phases, including several who
possess a group of smaller tracts. Team said he is hopeful those landowners will
also participate.

The initial public hearing allows the county to prepare an application for the
CDBG. While the date of a second, required public hearing was not set Tuesday,
it will likely come during a regular meeting in January.

Nash Dunn can be reached at 249-3981, ext. 227, or at nash.dunn@the-dispatch.com
Follow Nash on Twitter: @LexDispatchNash

                                US Official News

                           September 23, 2014 Tuesday

Notice of Funding Availability: Multi-Family Housing Preservation and
Revitalization Demonstration Program-Section 514, Section 515, and Section 516
for Fiscal Year 2014

LENGTH: 9216  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Federal Register has issued the following notice:


Action

Notice.
Summary

USDA Rural Development, which administers the programs of the Rural Housing
Service (Agency), announces the availability of $20 million in budget authority
and the timeframe to submit applications to participate in a demonstration
program to preserve and revitalize existing Rural Rental Housing (RRH) projects
under Section 515, Section 514, and Section 516 of the Housing Act of 1949, as
amended. Under the demonstration program, existing Section 515 Multi-Family
Housing (MFH) loans and Sections 514/516 Off-Farm Labor Housing (FLH) loans will
be restructured to ensure that sufficient resources are available to preserve
the ability of rental projects to provide safe and affordable housing for very
low-, low-, or moderate-income residents. Projects participating in this program
will be expected to be revitalized to extend their affordable use without
displacing tenants because of increased rents. No additional Agency Rental
Assistance (RA) units will be made available under this program.

Overview Information Back to Top

Federal Agency Name: Rural Housing Service, USDA.

Funding Opportunity Title: Multi-Family Housing Preservation and Revitalization
Demonstration Program--Section 514, Section 515, and Section 516 for Fiscal Year
2014.

Announcement Type: Inviting applications from eligible applicants for Fiscal
Year 2014, Funding.

Catalog of Federal Domestic Assistance Number (CFDA): 10.447.

Dates: Pre-applications in response to this Notice will be accepted until
November 24, 2014, 5:00 p.m., Eastern Time. The pre-application closing deadline
is firm as to date and hour. The Agency will not consider any pre-application
that is received after the closing deadline. Applicants intending to mail
pre-applications must allow sufficient time to permit delivery on or before the
closing deadline. Acceptance by a post office or private mailer does not
constitute delivery. Facsimile (FAX) and postage-due pre-applications will not
be accepted.
I. Funding Opportunities Description Back to Top

The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2014, Public Law 113-76 (January 17, 2014)
authorized the Agency to conduct a demonstration program for the preservation
and revitalization of the Section 515 MFH portfolio and Sections 514/516 Off-FLH
portfolio. Section 514, Section 515 and Section 516 MFH programs are authorized
by the Housing Act of 1949, as amended (42 U.S.C. 1484, 1485, 1486) and provide
Rural Development with the authority to provide financial assistance for
low-income MFH and FLH and related facilities as defined in 7 CFR Part 3560.

A synopsis of this program and the pre-application's universal resource locator
(URL) will be listed by Catalog of Federal Domestic Assistance Number or at
Federal GrantsWire at http://www.federalgrantswire.com.

This Notice solicits pre-applications from eligible borrowers/applicants to
restructure existing MFH projects already participating in the Agency's Section
515 MFH portfolio and Sections 514/516 FLH portfolio for the purpose of
revitalization and preservation. Eligible borrowers are sometimes referred to in
this Notice as "applicants," "borrowers," "applicant/borrowers," or "owners" as
seems most appropriate for the context of the relevant Notice provision. The
demonstration program shall be referred to in this Notice as the Multi-Family
Housing Preservation and Revitalization Demonstration (MPR) Program. Agency
regulations for the Section 515 MFH program and the Sections 514/516 FLH program
are published at 7 CFR Part 3560.

The intent of the MPR is to ensure that existing rental projects will continue
to deliver decent, safe and sanitary affordable rental housing for 20 years, the
remaining term of any Agency loan, or the remaining term of any existing
Restrictive-Use Provisions (RUP) or prohibition, whichever ends later.
Applications will be selected by the Agency by the process described in this
Notice, and the selected applicants will be invited to participate in the MPR
demonstration program. Upon written notification to the Agency from the selected
applicant of their acceptance to participate, an independent third-party Capital
Needs Assessment (CNA) will be conducted to provide a fair and objective review
of projected capital needs. The Agency shall implement any restructuring
proposal that may be offered under this Notice through an MPR Conditional
Commitment (MPRCC) with the eligible borrower/applicant, which will include all
the terms and conditions offered by the Agency.

One of the restructuring tools to be used in this program is debt deferral for
up to 20 years of the existing Section 514 or Section 515 loans obligated prior
to October 1, 1991. The cash flow from the deferred payment will be deposited,
as directed by the Agency, to the reserve account to help meet the future
physical needs of the project or to reduce rents.

Debt deferral is described as follows:

MPR Debt Deferral: A deferral of the existing Section 514 or Section 515 Agency
loan(s), obligated on or before October 1, 1991, for the lesser of either the
remaining term of the existing Section 514 or Section 515 loan, or 20 years. All
terms and conditions of the deferral will be described in the MPR Debt Deferral
Agreement. A balloon payment of principal and accrued interest will be due at
the end of the deferral period. Interest will accrue at the promissory note rate
and, if applicable, the subsidy will be applied as set out in the Agency's
Interest Credit and Rental Assistance Agreement.

Other Agency MPR tools are as follows:

1. MPR Grant: A grant limited to non-profit applicants/borrowers only. The grant
will be limited to the cost of correcting health and safety violations of a
project identified by a CNA accepted by the Agency. The grant administration
will be in accordance with applicable provisions of 7 CFR parts 3015 and 3019.

2. MPR Zero Percent Loan: A loan at zero percent interest. The loan's maximum
term and maximum amortization will be as authorized by the respective program
authority.

(a) For Section 515 RRH projects, the maximum term will be 30 years, and will be
amortized over a maximum term of 50 years.

(b) For Sections 514/516 projects, the loan will be amortized over a maximum
term of 33 years.

3. MPR Soft-Second Loan: A loan with a one percent interest rate that will have
its accrued interest and principal deferred to a balloon payment. The balloon
payment will be due at the same time the latest maturing Section 514 or Section
515 loan already in place at the time of closing, or the maturity date of any
current loan being re-amortized as part of the restructuring, is due.

MPR funds cannot be used to build community rooms, add additional parking areas,
playgrounds, laundry rooms or additional new units, unless the additional
unit(s) are needed for the project to meet the 5 percent fully accessible
requirement as defined by the Uniform Federal Accessibility Standards (UFAS),
and the Agency concurs. However, other funding sources as outlined below in (i)
through (vi) can be used either for such revitalization and/or improvements:

i. Rural Development Section 515 Rehabilitation loan funds;

ii. Rural Development Sections 514/516 Off-Farm rehabilitation loan/grant funds;

iii. Rural Development Section 538 Guaranteed RRH program financing;

iv. Rural Development Multi-Family Housing Preservation Revolving Loan Program
funds;

v. Third-party loans, grants, tax credits and tax-exempt financing; and

vi. Owner-provided capital contributions in the form of a cash infusion. A cash
infusion cannot be a loan.

Transfers, subordinations, and consolidations may be approved as part of a MPR
transaction in accordance with 7 CFR Part 3560. If a transfer is part of the MPR
transaction, and the transfer includes a seller payment and/or increase in the
allowable Return to Owner, the transfer must first be underwritten to meet the
requirements of 7 CFR 3560.406. The transfer underwriting may assume the
deferral of all eligible Section 515 loans. After the transfer has been
underwritten and concurred with by the Multi-Family Housing Preservation and
Revitalization Demonstration (MPR) program, the MPR transaction may be
underwritten.

For the purposes of the MPR, the restructuring transactions will be identified
in three categories:

1. Simple transactions, which involve no change in ownership.

2. Complex transactions, which may consist of a project transfer to a new
ownership, processed in accordance with 7 CFR 3560.406, with or without a
consolidation, or transactions requiring a subordination agreement as a result
of third-party funds. The applicant will submit one pre-application form. If a
consolidation is proposed, all projects to be consolidated must be submitted on
one pre-application form and be located in the same market area.

To be considered in the same market area, projects must be: in a neighborhood or
similar area where the property competes for tenants; managed under one
management plan and one management agreement; and, in sufficiently close
proximity to permit convenient and efficient management of the property.

Applicants should discuss proposed consolidations with the Rural Development
State Office in the State where the projects are located prior to filing their
MPR pre-application to ensure Rural Development concurs with the application's
market area estimation.

If either the Agency or the owner chooses to remove one or more projects from
the proposal, this may be done without affecting the eligibility of the complex
transaction. To be a complex transaction, the Agency assumes only one project
remains at the MPR closing.

3. Portfolio transactions includes two or more projects with one stay-in owner,
or two or more projects with multiple project sale transactions to a common
purchaser all located in one State: a stay-in-owner is defined as an existing
Section 515 or Sections 514/516 borrower who owns two or more properties either
as a single ownership entity or as separate legal entities with at least one
common general partner. Each project included in the transaction will be
submitted on a separate pre-application form unless some projects are located in
the same market area, as defined above, and are being consolidated. Any projects
in the portfolio proposed to be consolidated will be listed on the same
pre-application form. Each pre-application must have the same portfolio name. If
the owner chooses to remove one or more projects from the proposal, at least two
projects must remain in order to be classified as a portfolio transaction. At
the end of the transaction, the Agency assumes there will be two or more
projects. The stay-in owner or common purchaser must have at least one general
partner in common.

A transaction within each category may utilize any or all restructuring tools.
Restructuring tools available through the MPR program will be used to address
preservation and rehabilitation items identified in the Agency-accepted CNA.

Liens against the project, with the exception of Agency-deferred debt, cannot
exceed the Agency-approved security value of the project. All Agency debt,
either in first lien position or a subordinated lien position, must be secured
by the project, except deferred debt, which is not included in the Agency's
total lien position for computation of the Agency's security value. Payment of
any deferred debt will not be required from normal project operations income,
but from excess cash from project operations after all other secured debts are
satisfied or as directed by the Agency.

The general steps of the MPR application process are as follows:

1. Pre-application: Applicants must submit a pre-application as described in
Section VI below. This pre-application process is designed to lessen the cost
burden on all applicants, including those who may not be eligible or whose
proposals may not be feasible.
Note:

If you receive a loan or grant award under this Notice, USDA reserves the right
to post all information submitted as part of the pre-application/application
package, which is not protected under the Privacy Act, on a public Web site with
free and open access to any member of the public.

2. Eligible Projects: Using criteria described below in Section III, the Agency
will conduct an initial screening for eligibility. As described in Section VIII
below, the Agency will conduct an additional eligibility screening later in the
selection process.

3. Scoring and Ranking: All complete, eligible and timely-filed pre-applications
will be scored, ranked and put in potential funding categories as discussed in
Sections VI and VII below.

4. Formal Applications: Top ranked pre-applicants will receive a letter from the
Agency inviting them to submit a formal application. As discussed in Section
VIII paragraph (2) of this Notice, the Agency will require the owner to provide
a CNA completed in accordance with the Agency's published guidance (available at
http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/HMF_MPR.html) to underwrite the proposal to determine
financial feasibility. Applicants will be informed of any proposals that are
determined to be ineligible or financially infeasible. Any proposal denied by
the Agency will be returned to the applicant, and the applicant will be given
appeal rights pursuant to 7 CFR part 11.

5. Financial Feasibility: The Agency will use the results of the CNA to help
identify the need for resources and applicant provided information regarding
anticipated or available third-party financing, in order to determine the
financial feasibility of each potential transaction, using restructuring tools
available either through existing regulatory authorities or specifically
authorized through this demonstration program. A project is financially feasible
when it can provide affordable, decent, safe, and sanitary housing for 20 years
or the remaining term of any Agency loan, whichever ends later, by using the
authorities of this program while minimizing the cost to the Agency, and without
increasing rents for eligible tenants or farm laborers, except when necessary to
meet normal and necessary operating expenses. If the transaction is determined
financially feasible by the Agency, the borrower will be offered a restructuring
proposal, subject to available funding. This will include a requirement that the
borrower execute, for recordation, an Agency-approved restrictive-use covenant
for a period of 20 years, the remaining term of any loans, or the remaining term
of any existing restrictive-use provisions, whichever ends later. The
restructuring proposal will be established in the MPRCC.

6. MPR Agreements: If the offer is accepted by the applicant, the applicant must
sign and return the MPRCC. By accepting the offer, the applicant agrees to the
terms of the MPRCC. Any third-party lender will be required to subordinate to
the Agency's restrictive-use covenant unless the Agency determines, on a
case-by-case basis, that the lender's refusal to subordinate will not compromise
the purpose of the MPR.

7. General Requirements: The MPR transactions may be conducted with a stay-in
owner (simple) or may involve a change in ownership (complex or portfolio). Any
housing or related facilities that are constructed or repaired must meet the
Agency design and construction standards and the development standards contained
in 7 CFR part 1924, subparts A and C, respectively. Once constructed, Section
515 MFH and Sections 514/516 FLH projects must be managed in accordance with 7
CFR part 3560. Tenant eligibility will be limited to persons who qualify as an
eligible household under Agency regulations. Tenant eligibility requirements are
contained in 7 CFR 3560.152.
II. Award Information Back to Top

The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2014, Public Law 113-76 (January 17, 2014),
appropriated $20 million in budget authority to operate the MPR demonstration
program. The budget authority is anticipated to make approximately $37.8 million
available in program funds depending on the funding tools used. This funding
remains available until expended.

All Agency funding of applications selected under this Notice must be approved
no later than September 30, 2016. Any pre-applications selected under this
Notice, not approved by the Agency prior to September 30, 2016, will be
considered withdrawn automatically, however, the applicants may reapply for
funding under future Notices.

Applicants are alerted that the Agency has unfunded applications carried over
from prior Notices that will receive priority based on those Notices. If funds
available for the MPR are fully committed before all eligible pre-applications
selected for further processing under this Notice, or prior Notices, are funded,
the Agency shall suspend further processing of the pre-applications at that
time.
III. Eligibility Information Back to Top

Applicants (and the principals associated with each applicant) must meet the
following requirements:

1. All applicants must meet the eligibility requirements included in 7 CFR
3560.55 and 3560.555. This Notice will require the selected applicants to make
the required equity contribution as outlined in 3560.63(c). Loan applicants will
not be given consideration for any increased equity value the property may have
since the initial loan. Eligibility also includes the continued ability of the
borrower/applicant to provide acceptable management and will include an
evaluation of any current outstanding deficiencies. Any outstanding violations,
recorded in the Agency's Automated MFH Information System (MFIS), will preclude
further processing of any MPR applications associated with the borrower or
Identity of Interest (IOI) management agent unless there is a current, approved
workout plan in place and the plan has been satisfactorily followed for a
minimum of 6 consecutive months, as determined by the Agency.

2. For Section 515 RRH projects, the average physical vacancy rate for the 12
months preceding the NOFA publication date can be no more than 10 percent for
projects consisting of 16 or more revenue units and no more than 15 percent for
projects less than 16 revenue units unless an exception applies under Section VI
paragraph (1)(iii) of this Notice. If a project consolidation is involved, the
consolidation will remain eligible so long as the average vacancy rate for each
individual project meets the occupancy standard noted in this paragraph.
Projects that do not meet the occupancy threshold at the time of filing the
application may be withdrawn by the owner or the Agency without jeopardizing the
application.

3. For Sections 514/516 FLH projects, rather than an average physical vacancy
rate as noted in III(2) above, a positive cash flow for the previous full 3
years of operation is required unless an exception applies under Section VI
paragraph (1)(iii) of this Notice.

4. Ownership of and ability to operate the project after the transaction is
completed. In the event of a transfer, the proposed transferee must submit an
executed purchase agreement or other evidence of site control in the name of the
individual or entity proposing to purchase the property.

5. An Agency-approved CNA (for guidance refer to
http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/HMF_MPR.html) and an Agency financial evaluation must
be conducted to ensure that utilization of the restructuring tools of the MPR
program is financially feasible and necessary for the revitalization and
preservation of the project for affordable housing. Initial eligibility for
processing will be determined as of the date of the pre-application filing
deadline. The Agency reserves the right to discontinue processing any
application due to material changes in the applicant's status occurring at any
time after the initial eligibility determination.

6. Please note that all grant-eligible applicants must obtain a Dun and
Bradstreet Data Universal Numbering System (DUNS) number and register in the
Central Contractor Registration (CCR) prior to submitting a pre-application
pursuant to 2 CFR 25.200(b). In addition, an entity applicant must maintain
registration in the CCR database at all times during which it has an active
Federal award or an application or plan under consideration by the Agency.
Similarly, all recipients of Federal Financial Assistance are required to report
information about first-tier sub-awards and executive compensation, in
accordance with 2 CFR part 170. So long as an entity applicant does not have an
exception under 2 CFR 170.110(b), the applicant must have the necessary
processes and systems in place to comply with the reporting requirements should
the applicant receive funding. See 2 CFR 170.200(b).
