                        Western Morning News (Plymouth)

                            March 13, 2008 Thursday

Chancellor puts focus on affordable housing

BYLINE:  Paul Greaves  and  Louise Vennells

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 686 words


Key workers including teachers, nurses and police officers will be given a
helping hand to buy a new home, the Chancellor announced.

Alistair Darling said there would be no going back on plans to build three
million new homes over the next 20 years.

The emphasis will be on providing enough affordable homes for first-time buyers
and extending shared equity schemes for key workers.

But home buyers looking for a major reform of stamp duty thresholds were left
disappointed as Mr Darling chose only to tinker with the current levels.

A blow was dealt to second homes campaigners, in the form of a tax break which
effectively makes it more lucrative to buy and sell second properties.
Buy-to-let investors and second home owners will only pay 18 per cent on capital
gains if they sell the property after April 2008. They would previously have had
to pay between 24 per cent and 40 per cent.

And the announcement that the Government had identified surplus sites to build
70,000 new homes has left environmentalists worried about the pressure to build
in the countryside.

Thousands of key workers are set to benefit from the new shared equity schemes -
which split the cost of a home between a mortgage and a loan.

Buyers could take a 50 per cent mortgage with the remaining 50 per cent covered
by an equity loan taken out with a Government-sponsored lender.

From April, two new equity loans will be available through the Government's Open
Market HomeBuy.

Stuart Palmer, chairman of the Chartered Institute of Housing South West, said:
"Getting access to more housing for people in the region is critical because we
face particular problems.

"When we consider that the South West has a wider gap between  house prices and
low earnings than anywhere else, these schemes are vital."

Nurses also supported the changes.

Dr Peter Carter, Royal College of Nursing chief executive, said: "We welcome
moves to make it easier for nurses and other key workers to get on the housing
ladder through new measures and tax breaks on shared ownership schemes."

The Chancellor also announced that stamp duty on shared ownership homes will not
be required until people own 80 per cent of their home.

This could help housing association tenants and first-time buyers to get a foot
on the property ladder.

Martin Willey, South West co-ordinator for the South West Housing Initiative,
which advises government on affordable housing issues, said: "We need to look at
the implications carefully, but this could be a quite significant step and one
to be welcomed."

The Chancellor did not reform the stamp duty rates across the board.

The National Association of Estate Agents (NAEA) were among those calling for an
increase in the house price at which people are exempt from stamp duty payment.
The current threshold is £125,001.

Richard Copus, Devon spokesman for the NAEA  welcomed the 80 per cent stamp duty
limit on shared ownership schemes.

"That's very positive," he said. "My personal view is that we need to encourage
shared ownership to help more first-time buyers. But we are very disappointed
the Chancellor didn't take the opportunity to change the stamp duty payments to
make them fairer across the board."

The Budget paved the way for thousands of new affordable homes to be built
across the country.

Courtenay Smale, Cornwall secretary of the Campaign to Protect Rural England,
warned: "It stands to reason that a lot of these identified sites will be on
greenfield land.

"If they are not used for housing development they could be held in abeyance for
industrial use, which could have disastrous consequences for the environment."

But the Chancellor did not heed pleas to withdraw a tax concession on second
property owners from the pre-budget report. Under his plans,  Capital Gains Tax,
which is paid from the profits of a house sale, is down to 18 per cent above
£9,600 - the lowest in years. And a new entrepreneurs' relief, which lowers it
to 10 per cent, will mean it is even more profitable for businessmen.

Andrew George, Lib Dem MP for St Ives, lobbied the chancellor to remove the
clause, saying it would widen the gulf between rich and poor.

eligible, persons with  disabilities, VEOA eligibles, certain military spouses,
30% or more disabled veterans, former Peace Corps or VISTA volunteers,
CTAP/ICTAP eligibles, Farm Service Agency permanent county employees and those
eligibles for other Special Hiring Authorities.
SECURITY CLEARANCE:
 Public Trust - Background Investigation
SUPERVISORY STATUS:
 No
JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.


This position is located in the Program Compliance Branch (PCB), Civil Rights
Staff, Rural Development, Operations and Management. The PCB monitors, reviews,
and evaluates RD's compliance with civil rights/equal opportunity requirements
in federally-assisted and conducted RD programs involving Single Family and
Multi-Family Housing, Business and Cooperative Services, and Electric,
Telecommunications, Water and Waste Water.

This announcement may be used to fill additional vacancies that are identified
by the organization.

This is a virtual position that allows the selectee to remain in their current
post of duty.

Salary will be determined based on current duty location.
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Occasional Travel
    5 to 7 weeks per year.

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

US Citizenship is required.
    Selective Service Registration is required for males born after 12/31/1959.

DUTIES:
Back to top

Develop, analyze, evaluate and recommend policies, plans, regulations, standards
and procedures to assure equal access to all RD programs and services are
consistent with RD civil rights objectives, and suggest modifications where
needed.
    Assess program and compliance review procedures.
    Advise field staff on the proper execution of forms, instructions, and
guidelines.
    Serve as an adviser on program civil rights issues and procedures in the
interpretation of pertinent laws and regulations relating to specific program
problems.
    Develop and conduct program civil rights and compliance training.

                            The Independent (London)

                             July 13, 1997, Sunday

Imagine Ambridge but with half the villagers homeless...; Weekenders, commuters,
retired people - all are nudging house prices beyond the reach of true country
folk. Felicity Cannell searches for a solution

BYLINE: Felicity Cannell

SECTION: PROPERTY; Page  9

LENGTH: 850 words


TWENTY per cent of people in England live in the countryside and many wish to
continue to do so, but some need help to achieve this.  The Rural Development
Commission is urging the Government to remember that countryside dwellers have
the same problems and deprivations as inner cities but with less access to
solutions offered by public transport, affordable housing and telecommunications
infrastructure.

According to the commission, nearly 20 per cent of rural households do not have
access to a car and 71 per cent of parishes do not have a daily bus service. The
Government has said that transport services in rural areas should not be allowed
to deteriorate, but a policy to improve might be more appropriate. Similarly,
other public services need to be improved rather than simply maintained at a
reduced level.

Probably the greatest problem for rural communities is finding somewhere for
their coming-of-age offspring to live. Many young people will leave rural areas
but those who wish to stay face a number of problems in finding a home. In the
more desirable areas they have to compete against commuters, second homeowners
and retired people. Populations of many rural areas have been growing
significantly, adding to the general need for increased housing. Prices tend to
be out of step with local earnings. Although unemployment is below the national
average across all rural development areas, an above average share of employment
is part-time, low paid and seasonal.

"If people on lower incomes are to continue to live in the countryside, a
substantial increase in the supply of social housing is required," says Richard
Butt, chief executive of the commission. But social housing is not always
available to young people. Alternative measures are needed.  Private rented
housing is no solution at present; in rural areas, at the bottom end of the
market, it is often in poor condition.

For these reasons the commission clashed heavily with the last government over
the right-to-buy scheme for council housing. Says the commission's Gillian
Kempster: "We felt strongly that some homes should be kept as rental only
accommodation, as it has been seen time and time again that local authority
stock, once sold, is not replaced in any shape or form."

Planning policy, meanwhile, has restricted the supply of suitable replacement
homes in many areas. Britain has a deep desire to protect green belt land, but
many rural families feel they need houses more than they need green fields.

Careful development with higher design standards could be one solution.  Corfe
Castle in Dorset has, over the years, become popular for second home owners;
consequently there is little affordable housing for local people. Exceptional
permission was granted to develop a derelict allotment in the heart of the
village to provide new housing for them. Abbots Cottages development used local
materials to blend in with the environment, and planning permission was granted
with the proviso that the homes were to be retained as affordable rental
accommodation for local people. Needs are so great that 44 applications were
made for the first six cottages.

Maybe the Government should take a leaf out of the Channel Islands' book
regarding desirable rural spots, particularly those on the tourist trail.
Locals on Alderney are offered cheap loans to buy property at cheap prices.  But
when it comes to selling, properties must be offered back to the government of
Alderney, which rarely refuses to buy, so keeping them for local people.
Outsiders - those resident on the island for less than 15 years - have to buy on
the open market at considerably greater cost.

Economic change has led to the decline of rural market town centres through the
closure of traditional businesses: livestock markets, dairies, mines, breweries
and local manufacturing. Action for Market Towns is encouraging the
redevelopment of these vacant premises, and new-build properties, to provide
homes for the growing populations, which, despite local industry closures, are
beginning to capitalise on their natural asset - the beauty of the countryside.

There are nearly 900 "market" towns in England, each with a population of under
15,000, and some have already secured funds from sources such as Rural Challenge
and the National Lottery for regeneration. The Rural Commission hopes this will
lead not only to increased housing, but also increased employment, particularly
for young single people.

But this is no help to the residents of the many villages, hamlets and pocket
communities elsewhere in the country. "The re-use of urban sites and improving
life in towns can help to relieve the pressure on the countryside but will not
in themselves remove the need for additional housing in rural areas," says Jo
Lavis of the Rural Development Commission. "Developments concentrated in larger
centres to reduce greenfield land take will not necessarily reduce travel or be
more sustainable."

Rural Development Commission 0171 340 2900; Action for Market Towns 01284
756567.

                               The New York Times

                March 24, 1986, Monday, Late City Final Edition

HOUSING PROJECT SETS OFF DISPUTE IN OLD MILL TOWN

BYLINE: By GENE I. MAEROFF, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 946 words

DATELINE: HOLYOKE, Mass., March 20


A land parcel approved by the Federal Government as the site for a
million-dollar housing project for farm workers has become the focus of an
intense controversy in this old mill town.

In an effort to block the project, the Board of Aldermen voted to appropriate
the site by eminent domain. The Mayor, though also opposed to the project,
thwarted the aldermen, fearing the city would be suspected of discrimination and
lose state and Federal revenue. The local newspaper opposed the project even
though its parent company had made it possible by selling the land.

In the crossfire of arguments are issues of ethnic attitudes, the proper role of
subsidized housing and community revitalization.

The project, for which ground is to be broken in April unless the city finds a
way to stop it, has received a commitment from the Federal Farmers Home
Administration for a grant of $836,300 and a loan of $109,000.

Workers Shuttle to Valley

The unlikely dispute over housing for farm workers in the midst of a small
industrial city arose because Holyoke and neighboring Springfield are home to
farm workers who harvest vegetables and tobacco in the nearby Connecticut
Valley.

Holyoke officials argue that the site for the project, near a decrepit downtown
area the city wants to rejuvenate, is inappropriate for the row houses meant to
accommodate 18 families of farm workers.

''It isn't healthy for a community that is trying to revitalize its downtown to
add subsidized housing to the area if it can be avoided,'' said Mayor Ernest E.
Proulx. City officials have not proposed an alternate site for the project.

But advocates maintain that the opposition chiefly comes because of the
families, mostly Hispanic, who will live in the houses.

''The heart of their objection is to the prospective tenants rather than to the
housing itself,'' said Ann Houston, president of the Valley Housing Development
Corporation, the nonprofit agency set up to oversee the project.

Small Size for Site

The site, four-fifths of an acre on a narrow strip that is vacant except for a
playground, is in a quiet residential area. City officials also say the site is
too small for the number of families who would occupy it.

Three blocks east is Holyoke's main downtown thoroughfare, High Street, whose
splendid Victorian buildings attest to the city's faded glory.

Just beyond High Street are the rows of mills along the Connecticut River that,
before World War II, made Holyoke a manufacturing center for woolens, silks and
high-grade writing paper.

As Holyoke's industrial base crumbled, subsidized housing grew for people who
could no longer afford housing at the market rate. Mayor Proulx said that more
than 40 percent of the rental units in Holyoke, which make up most of the
housing stock, are subsidized.

He maintains that improving the downtown area would be aided by keeping
additional subsidized housing in the neighborhood to a minimum.

But Mrs. Houston pointed out that the city was building subsidized housing for
the elderly even closer to the downtown area than the farm workers' housing
would be. Mayor Proulx said the project was an exception because it was in a
historic building that would not have been saved without subsidies.

Neighborhood Attitudes Divided

Those who would be neighbors of the farm workers have mixed feelings.

''There's enough of them in this neighborhood without adding more,'' a nearby
homeowner who refused to give his name said of his prospective neighbors.

But Jesus Rosa, 27 years old, manager of an apartment building across from the
site, thinks the project is necessary. ''Poor individuals don't have enough
housing,'' he said.

The 15-member Board of Aldermen voted unanimously this month to take the site by
eminent domain. But last week Mayor Proulx refused to appropriate money for the
purchase, saying it would ''be considered a sham, designed to deny the property
owners their civil rights.''

He said he feared that such an action would jeopardize government grants,
including state aid that Holyoke is seeking to establish a $2 million volleyball
hall of fame.

Past charges of bias in housing led the state to require Holyoke to develop a
plan for fair housing or face a cutoff of funds.

Caught in the dispute is The Transcript-Telegram, Holyoke's daily newspaper,
whose owner, Newspapers of New England, sold the land to Valley Housing. A home
belonging to the newspaper's founding family once stood on the site.

Value of Site Disputed

Robert V. Unger, the managing editor, said the connection had had ''no impact on
our coverage.'' Editorials and columns in The Transcript-Telegram have asserted
that the project is not in Holyoke's interest.

The site, carrying an assessed valuation of $8,500, was sold by Newspapers of
New England for $75,000, a price some say was too high.

''I don't think you can find other land around here going for about $75,000 an
acre,'' said Richard P. Courchesne, president of Olde Holyoke Development
Corporation, which has worked worked with the city on nonprofit housing
projects. ''The most expensive land in the area, in the industrial park, goes
for $25,000 an acre.''

Kim R. Crossman, district loan specialist of the Farmers Home Administration,
said he was surprised by the controversy. ''Most of our projects are in rural
areas where farms are located and we aren't required by Federal law to get input
from communities,'' he said.

But city officials in Holyoke are angry that the agency never consulted them.
Now they are seeking a meeting with their Congressman, Representative Silvio O.
Conte, to see what avenues are available to block construction.

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                    February 5, 2004 Thursday, York Edition

Homeownership classes offered at three sites

SECTION: YOUR NEIGHBORS; News Briefs; Pg. 10E

LENGTH: 227 words

DATELINE: SANFORD/ELIOT


Tired of renting? Take the first step in owning your own home by attending a
Homeownership Education Class, offered by York County Community Action
Corporation.

Three new sessions will be offered, those dates include: March 18 at the Sanford
YCCAC office; April 1 at Marshwood High School in Eliot; and May 4 at Noble High
School in North Berwick. The cost for these sessions is $30 and attendees need
only attend one session.

Classes are designed to teach about home ownership opportunities available,
including down-payment and closing cost assistance for first-time homebuyers and
low-income families. Potential home buyers will be instructed in a wide range of
topics, from finding a home and working with a realtor, to improving credit
ratings, obtaining financing for a home mortgage and more. Participants will
have the opportunity to meet guest speakers from local banks and realty
agencies. The fee for the class includes a credit report and appointment with
financial housing counselor. Upon completion of the course participants receive
a certificate required for Maine State Housing Authority, HUD, Rural
Development, and other special low-interest loan programs. York County Community
Action Corporation is a private non-profit organization-serving residents since
1967.

To register for classes, call YCCAC at 324-5762, ext. 9040.

                                US Official News

                             July 9, 2016 Saturday

California: USDA Reminds Individuals and Small Businesses Affected by Flooding
in West Virginia that USDA Offers Disaster Assistance Programs to Help

LENGTH: 1361  words

DATELINE: New York



 Sacramento: State Departments of Agriculture, The State of California has
issued the following news release:



   The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) reminds farmers and ranchers,
families and small businesses affected by flooding in West Virginia that USDA
has several programs which provide assistance before, during and after
disasters. USDA staff in regional, State and county offices are ready to help.





 When floods destroy or severely damage residential property, USDA Rural
Development (RD) can assist with providing priority hardship application
processing for single family housing. Under a disaster designation, RD can issue
a priority letter for next available multi-family housing units.



 As of June 28th the USDA Rural Development office in West Virginia reported
that there are 364 apartments in facilities that are part of the RD Multi-Family
Housing program which are available to people who have lost their homes. There
are 178 one bedroom apartments, 182 two bedroom apartments, and 4 three bedroom
apartments. While RD does not "place" people in these properties, the state RD
office can provide the information on how flood victims can contact the owners
and operators of these facilities. If you or a loved one has lost a home due to
the tragic weather of June, please contact West Virginia's USDA Rural
Development State Office at (304) 284-4860 or email Housing Program Director
David L. Cain at David.Cain@wv.usda.gov Finally, while RD's programs do not
normally have disaster assistance authority, many of USDA Rural Development
programs can help provide financial relief to small businesses hit by natural
disasters, including low-interest loans to community facilities, water
environmental programs, businesses and cooperatives and to rural utilities.



 The USDA Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) coordinates with state, local and
voluntary organizations to provide food for shelters and other mass feeding
sites. Under certain circumstances, states also may request to operate a
disaster household distribution program to distribute USDA Foods directly to
households in need. In addition, FNS may approve a state's request to implement
a Disaster Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) when the President
declares a major disaster for individual assistance under the Stafford Act in
areas affected by a disaster. State agencies may also request a number of
disaster-related SNAP waivers to help provide temporary assistance to impacted
households already receiving SNAP benefits at the time of the disaster.
Resources for disaster feeding partners as well as available FNS disaster
nutrition assistance can be found on the FNS Disaster Assistance website.



 For declared natural disasters that lead to imminent threats to life and
property, the USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) can assist
local government sponsors with the cost of implementing recovery efforts like
debris removal and streambank stabilization to address natural resource concerns
and hazards through the Emergency Watershed Protection Program. In the declared
West Virginia counties, NRCS staff is coordinating with state partners to
complete damage assessments in preparation for sponsor assistance requests. NRCS
also can help producers with damaged agricultural lands caused by natural
disasters such as floods. The NRCS Environmental Quality Incentives Program
(EQIP) provides financial assistance to repair and prevent excessive soil
erosion that can result from high rainfall events and flooding. Conservation
practices supported through EQIP protect the land and aid in recovery, can build
the natural resource base, and might help mitigate loss in future events.



 Severe weather forecasts often present the possibility of power outages that
could compromise the safety of stored food. The USDA Food Safety and Inspection
Service (FSIS) recommends that consumers take the necessary steps before,
during, and after a power outage to reduce food waste and minimize the risk of
foodborne illness. FSIS offers tips for keeping frozen and refrigerated food
safe and a brochure that can be downloaded and printed for reference at home.
For additional questions, call the USDA Meat and Poultry Hotline at
1-888-MPHotline (1-888-674-6854) on weekdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. ET or visit
AskKaren.gov to chat live with a food safety specialist, available in English
and Spanish.



 The USDA Farm Service Agency (FSA) administers many safety-net programs to help
producers recover from eligible losses, including the Livestock Indemnity
Program, the Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees, and Farm-Raised Fish
Program, Emergency Forest Restoration Program (EFRP) and the Tree Assistance
Program. The FSA Emergency Conservation Program provides funding and technical
assistance for farmers and ranchers to rehabilitate farmland damaged by natural
disasters. Producers located in counties that received a primary or contiguous
disaster designation are eligible for low-interest emergency loans to help them
recover from production and physical losses. Compensation also is available to
producers who purchased coverage through the Noninsured Crop Disaster Assistance
Program, which protects non-insurable crops against natural disasters that
result in lower yields, crop losses or prevented planting. USDA encourages
farmers and ranchers to contact their local FSA office to learn what documents
can help the local office expedite assistance, such as farm records, receipts
and pictures of damages or losses.



 Producers should use form FSA-576, Notice of Loss, to report prevented planting
and failed acres in order to establish or retain FSA program eligibility.
Prevented planting acreage must be reported no later than 15 calendar days after
the final planting date as established by FSA and USDA Risk Management Agency
(RMA). Producers must file a Notice of Loss for failed acres on all crops
including grasses in a timely fashion, often within 15 days of the occurrence or
when the losses become apparent. Producers of hand-harvested crops must notify
FSA of damage or loss within 72 hours of when the date of damage or loss first
becomes apparent.



 Producers with coverage through the RMA administered federal crop insurance
program should contact their crop insurance agent. Those who purchased crop
insurance will be paid for covered losses. Producers should report crop damage
within 72 hours of damage discovery and follow up in writing within15 days.



 USDA National Institute of Food and Agriculture provides support for disaster
education through the Extension Disaster Education Network (EDEN). EDEN's goal
is to improve the nation's ability to mitigate, prepare for, prevent, respond to
and recover from disasters. Through the land-grant universities and Cooperative
Extension System across the nation, EDEN links Extension educators from various
disciplines to share research-based resources to reduce the impact of disasters.




 For complete details and eligibility requirements regarding USDA's disaster
assistance programs, contact a local USDA Service Center
(http://offices.sc.egov.usda.gov/locator/app). More information about USDA
disaster assistance
(http://www.usda.gov/documents/fact-sheet-usda-programs-assist-individuals-small
-businesses.pdf) as well as other disaster resources is available on the USDA
Disaster Resource Center website. In a continuing effort to better serve the
public, USDA has developed a new and improved central resource for disaster
related materials. In partnership with the Federal Emergency Management Agency
and other disaster-focused organizations, USDA created a Disaster Resource
Center (http://www.usda.gov/wps/portal/usda/usdahome?navid=disaster-help)
website, utilizing a new online searchable knowledgebase. This knowledgebase is
a collection of disaster-related resources that are powered by agents with
subject-matter expertise. The new Disaster Resource Center website and web tool
now provide an easy access point to find USDA disaster information and
assistance.

                    Cape Cod Times (Hyannis, Massachesetts)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          September 17, 2011 Saturday

Tribe gets $12.7M loan for Mashpee community center

BYLINE: Heather Wysocki, Cape Cod Times, Hyannis, Mass.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 466 words


Sept. 17--MASHPEE -- Crammed into a tiny meeting space, members of the Mashpee
Wampanoag tribe couldn't help but smile when thinking of the much larger
quarters they'll soon have.

On Friday, the tribe signed papers closing its $12.7 million loan from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture, setting in motion plans for a massive community
center to be built at the tribal headquarters site.

"We dreamt very big," Mashpee Wampanoag Tribal Council Chairman Cedric Cromwell
said while surrounded by about two dozen tribe members and supporters. "But the
dream came true."

A year ago, the tribe announced its intentions to build the community center
using a USDA grant and expected to break ground this spring, but the plan was
delayed by unexpected paperwork and research, Cromwell said. "When we were
approved, we thought that was that. There was a lot more, but that's OK."

For years, the tribe has operated out of cramped offices and modular trailers on
a dusty lot off Great Neck Road South. Because of a lack of space, tribal events
have been held at other locations the tribe had to rent, Cromwell said.

The new community center will give tribe members a place to gather and hold
events, and the tribal council will meet at the facility. It also will include
areas for the tribe's social programs such as housing, education and job
training.

An area for youth and a lounge for tribal elders will give those two groups a
space they've never had, Cromwell said. "It's so important for them to have a
tribal identity," he said. "To gather with our chief, with our medicine man, and
to really come together."

At 40,000 square feet, the community center will be nearly twice as large as the
new Mashpee Public Library, which opened last year. The library cost nearly $10
million to build and was funded through a combination of grants, donations and a
town debt exclusion.

The tribe's 30-year loan will be repaid to the USDA's rural development office
through federal money the tribe gets for programs such as health care and
housing, according to a USDA spokeswoman.

New buildings larger than 10,000 square feet usually require Cape Cod Commission
review, but the Mashpee Wampanoag community center is exempt from the review
because of the tribe's sovereign status, a spokeswoman for the county agency
said last year.

The tribe hopes to break ground in the spring, and tribal offices will move to
modular trailers during construction, Cromwell said. He was unsure when
construction would be completed. But one thing was already decided before the
Friday ceremony, according to Chief Vernon "Silent Drum" Lopez.

"I'm going to dig the first shovelful," he said.

                             The Gloucester Citizen

                             July 17, 2007 Tuesday

PM's housing promise 'all spin' - councillor

SECTION: Pg. 9

LENGTH: 462 words


The Prime Minister's pledge to create three million extra affordable homes by
2020 to ease the housing crisis has been met with scepticism by councils in
Gloucestershire.

Gordon Brown's plans include raising the annual house-building target from
200,000 to 240,000 new homes a year by 2016 and releasing 550 brownfield sites
on public land for development.

But Gloucester City Council's cabinet member for housing and health, councillor
Andrew Gravells, said he was sceptical about the promise because no money had
been put on the table for the 5,670 people on the council's waiting list for
homes.

"It's been all spin and good intentions," he said.

Coun Gravells said the number of people arriving daily at the housing department
for advice was growing.

But he said the biggest problem for the city is the increasing number of migrant
workers who need housing.

"What he could do quite quickly and easily for Gloucester is to recognise the
enormous pressure we're under here, having to deal with  the hundreds of migrant
workers now arriving in Gloucester," he said.

"They are in addition to the asylum seekers, which his colleagues in the Home
Office have been directing to the city for several years now."

In Stroud, the district council cabinet member for housing Frances Roden, said:
"We are watching with great interest for further details on how many of the
intended three million extra homes would be built locally, how Government
intends to pay for the extra affordable homes - in particular whether it will
increase its funding to the Housing Corporation and the scope for different
models and providers of affordable housing."

"As details emerge I would welcome wider discussion in the county to actively
and fully ensure opportunities and challenges are addressed, to more closely
meet the needs of our local community and also examine environmental and
infrastructure issues."

Meanwhile, Forest of Dean District Council chairman Marion Winship said the fact
that most housing development was planned for urban areas brought problems for
rural areas like the Forest.

"It means that our allocation is much lower than we want," she said.

"The Government needs to allow us to do what local people need.

"We need a mix in the Forest, not just affordable or rented social housing
because people do want to own their own homes."

The Stroud and Swindon Building Society is currently reviewing its mortgage
products to keep up with demand.

A spokeswoman said: "The new products are likely to include first time buyer
mortgages."

Housing Minister Yvette Cooper has called for every new block of flats to
include a mix of private, social and council homes.

She said there should be an end to the "segregation" of different kinds of
properties with new mixed developments being built instead.

                              The Washington Post

                      May 24, 1981, Sunday, Final Edition

Historic Preservation Awards

BYLINE: By Sarah Booth Conroy

SECTION: Living in Style; B1

LENGTH: 543 words


HISTORIC preservation is not just for monuments and mansions, as this year's
National Trust for Historic Preservation awards show.  Big industrial buildings
and small rural villages are worthy of protection and use.  Honors also went to
individuals and groups.

Gordon Gray of Washington received the Louise Du Pont Crowninshield Award, the
Trust's highest recognition, for his "leadership and skillful guidance" in the
passage of the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 and his "vision and
dedication" as chairman of the Trust from 1962-'73.

The Waterford (Va.) Foundation was honored for preserving through protective
facades and open land easements the historical and cultural qualities of
Waterford's early agricultural village.  The village was settled by Quakers in
1733.  The village was also one of the first to encourage the revival of 18th-
and 19th-century handicrafts.  An annual tour helps support preservation.

William A. Whiteside of Washington was honored for developing the Neighborhood
Housing Service, which has "stimulated the revitalization of buildings in
neighborhoods across the country, generated the reinvestment of millions of
dollars and improved the quality of life for thousands of residents." The
Neighborhood Housing Service started as a Pittsburgh plan.

Whiteside, then director of the Urban Reinvestment Task Force, went on to
establish the program in 123 neighborhoods in 97 cities, with 31 under
development.  The program brings together residents who are repairing and
improving their homes, lenders who agree to lend money for such projects and
city services for capital improvements.

NHS administers a revolving fund.  Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation, the
parent group, oversees the independent programs.  Neighborhood Housing Services
of America Inc. sells loans to private investors, and uses doantions to lower
the interest rate on the revolving fund loans.

Other awards:

The Columbus Iron Works Convention and Trade Center on the Chattahoochee River
is an example of industrial architecture, preserved with some of the old
machinery as decorative sculpture by the Columbus Consolidated Government.
Other industrial preservations efforts honorees included Belknap Mill Society in
Laconia, N.H., which restored the Busiel and Belknap Mills; and Mary Ellen
Kramer of Paterson, N.J., for establishing the Great Falls/S.U.M.  Historic
District in Paterson to include its industrial buildings.

Three theaters won awards: the Fifth Avenue Theater Association in Seattle,
Wash., the Paramount Theater of the Arts in Oakland, Calif. and the Ohio Theatre
restoration in Columbus, Ohio, led by Mary L. Bishop.

Alaska Pacific Bank in Anchorage restored and reused the old City Hall as a
banking and cultural center.  Lavonia Jenkins Barnes of Waco saved and restored
Waco houses, and published books on Banks and restoring the fishing village of
Manteo.  Mary Zoghby of Mobile, Ala., a state legislator, supported the
Historical Preservation Authorities Acts.

The Gamble house, designed and built in the arts and crafts manner by Greene and
Greene around the turn of the century, and owned by the City of Pasadena and the
University of Southern California (see story above.).

                                US Official News

                            October 1, 2015 Thursday

New Equipment Contract for Telecommunications and Broadband Borrowers

LENGTH: 1117 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 WASHINGTON, DC:  This Proposed Rule document was issued by the Rural Utilities
Service (RUS)


  Action

  Request for comments.

  Summary

  The Rural Utilities Service (RUS), a Rural Development agency of the United
States Department of Agriculture (USDA), is requesting public comments on
streamlining the Agency's contractual process for equipment procurement by
replacing type-specific Equipment Contracts, RUS Forms 397, 398, 525, 545, and
the associated documents (Forms 231, 396, 396a, 397b, 397c, 397d, 397f, 397g,
397h, 517, 525a, 744, 752a, 754, and addenda) with a new, unified Equipment
Contract, RUS Form 395 and the associated close-out documents (Forms 395a, 395b,
395c and 395d).

  Dates

  Comments, electronic and/or paper, must be received by November 30, 2015 to be
assured consideration. Late comments will not be considered.

  Addresses

  Comments may be submitted by one of the following methods:


   Federal Rulemaking Portal at http://www.regulations.gov. Follow the on-line
instructions for submitting comments on this final rule with request or
comments.

   Postal Mail/Commercial Delivery: Please send your comments addressed to
Thomas P. Dickson, Acting Director, Program Development and Regulatory Analysis,
Rural Utilities Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture, 1400 Independence
Avenue, STOP 1522, Room 5164, Washington, DC 20250-1522.


  All comments submitted in response to this document will be included in the
record and will be made available to the public. RUS will make the comments
publicly available online at: http://www.regulations.gov. Additionalinformation
about Rural Development and its programs is available on the Internet at
http://www.rd.usda.gov.

  How to Obtain a Copy: To obtain a copy of the proposed new RUS Form 395,
Equipment Contract, use one of the following methods:


   Internet at the following Web site:
http://www.rd.usda.gov/files/UTP_form_395.pdf.

   Email/Postal: By contacting the individual listed in theFOR FURTHER
INFORMATION CONTACTsection of this document.


  For Further Information Contact

  Aylene Mafnas, Chief, Engineering Branch, Policy and Outreach Division, Rural
Utilities Service, Telecommunications Program, U.S. Department of Agriculture,
STOP 1599, 1400 Independence Ave. SW., Washington, DC 20250-1550, Telephone
number: (202) 690-4673.

  Supplementary Information

  Background

  Rural Development is a mission area within the U.S. Department of Agriculture
comprising the Rural Utilities Service, Rural Housing Service and Rural
Business/Cooperative Service. Rural Development's mission is to increase
economic opportunity and improve the quality of life for all rural Americans.
Rural Development meets its mission by providing loans, loan guarantees, grants
and technical assistance through more than 40 programs aimed at creating and
improving housing, businesses and infrastructure throughout rural America.

  The Rural Utilities Service (RUS) loan, loan guarantee and grant programs act
as a catalyst for economic and community development. By financing improvements
to rural electric, water and waste, and telecom and broadband infrastructure,
RUS also plays a big role in improving other measures of quality of life in
rural America, including public health and safety, environmental protection,
conservation and cultural and historic preservation.

  In order to continue to facilitate the programmatic interest of the Rural
Electrification Act of 1936 (the &ldquo;RE Act&rdquo;), as amended (7 U.S.C. 901
et seq.), that loans and loans guaranteed by RUS are adequately secured, RUS has
established the use of certain standardized forms for materials, equipment, and
construction of electric and telecommunications systems. The use of standard
forms, construction contracts, and procurement procedures help to assure that
appropriate standards and specifications are maintained by the borrower in order
to not adversely affect RUS's loan security, and ensure that loan and loan
guarantee funds are effectively used for the intended purpose(s).

  RUS may, from time to time, promulgate new contract forms or revise or
eliminate existing contract forms. In so doing, RUS is required by 7 CFR
1755.29, to publish a notice of rulemaking in theFederal Registerannouncing, as
appropriate, a revision in, or a proposal to amend &sect; 1755.30(c) , List of
telecommunications standard contract forms. On February 12, 2014, RUS published
a proposed rule in theFederal Register, (79 FR 8327) to establish a New
Equipment Contract and associated Policies for Telecommunications and Broadband
Borrowers, RUS Form 395 under 7 CFR parts 1753 and 1755. RUS Form 395, reflects
present business and RUS practices, as well as changes in technology, services
and equipment. It has come to the attention of the Agency that the proposed rule
published in theFederal Registerwas not clear on how or where to obtain a copy
of the proposed new Equipment Contract, RUS Form 395. RUS is issuing this
Request for comments to provide an opportunity for interested persons to obtain
a copy of the new RUS Form 395 for their review and comment. The information
collection and recordkeeping requirements associated with the new RUS Form 395
and its associated forms were submitted to OMB on February 12, 2014 and filed
with comment.

  The purpose of this undertaking is to improve the customer service provided by
RUS's rural telecommunications and broadband borrowers. Changes in competition,
legislation, technologies, and regulation have resulted in changes to business
practices in the communications industry. In response to these changes RUS has
undertaken a comprehensive review of its Telecommunications and Broadband
Programs' contracts and contracting procedures.

  The new Equipment Contract, RUS Form 395 and the associated close-out
documents (Forms 395a, 395b, 395c and 395d) will replace the current Equipment
Specific Contracts, RUS Forms 397, 398, 525, 545, and the associated close-out
documents (Forms 231, 396, 396a, 517, 744, 752, 752a, and 754). The contract
terms and obligations included in the new RUS Form 395, Equipment Contract,
reflect current RUS and private sector industry practices, as well as changes in
technology, services and equipment. The intent here is to streamline the
contractual process for RUS borrowers and expedite the process of approving
equipment procurement during RUS funded construction projects.


   Dated: July 29, 2015.

   Brandon McBride,

   Administrator, Rural Utilities Service.

Wyoming: Federal Home Loan Bank of Seattle Awards $5.5 Million for Affordable
Housing

LENGTH: 917  words

DATELINE: Cheyenne


Federal Home Loan Bank of Seattle, The state of Wyoming has issued the following
news release:

Funds Will Help Create 640 Affordable Housing Units in Five States

News Release: December 18, 2013
Contact:

Connie Waks
206.340.2305


Philip Horton
206.340.2375

Seattle - The Federal Home Loan Bank of Seattle (Seattle Bank) is pleased to
announce the award of $5.5 million in Affordable Housing Program (AHP) funds to
support 14 projects providing 640 units of affordable housing in Idaho, Montana,
Oregon, Utah, and Washington.

The Seattle Bank distributes its AHP funding through its member institutions,
which work with for-profit and nonprofit organizations in their communities to
address local housing needs. The Seattle Bank's 2013 AHP awards will benefit
households with special needs, homeless individuals, Native peoples, and
veterans, among others.

"We are very pleased to provide this funding for affordable housing, and we know
it will be put to good use," said Seattle Bank President and CEO Michael L.
Wilson. "We have a large and diverse district, with a broad range of populations
and housing needs. Our members and their community partners live and work in the
communities they serve, and they are keenly aware of local housing needs and how
best to meet them. We look forward to the completion of these projects and the
positive impact they will undoubtedly have on their residents and communities
overall."

Visit the 2013 AHP Awards page on the Seattle Bank's website for a more complete
description of the projects receiving 2013 AHP awards.

AHP funds are awarded on a competitive basis. To receive an AHP award, an
organization must demonstrate its ability to effectively create affordable
housing and promote community stability.

In addition to the AHP, the Seattle Bank supports affordable housing and
community and economic development projects through its Home$tart Program,
Community Investment Program (CIP), and Economic Development Fund (EDF).

Additional information regarding the Seattle Bank's 2013 AHP awards and
community investment programs is available on the Seattle Bank's website at
www.fhlbsea.com.
About the Seattle Bank

The Federal Home Loan Bank of Seattle (Seattle Bank) is a member-owned
cooperative, serving approximately 330 financial institutions. The Seattle Bank
provides its members with access to wholesale funding, which they use to make
home mortgages, small business, and other loans in their communities.

The Seattle Bank also works with its members and their community partners to
promote affordable housing and economic development. Each year, the bank
provides 10 percent of its profits to fund affordable housing--both rental and
homeownership--and provides millions of dollars in reduced-rate loans for
affordable housing and community economic development.

The Seattle Bank's Affordable Housing Program provides subsidy to acquire,
construct, or rehabilitate affordable rental or owner-occupied housing for low-
and moderate-income households. The Home$tart Program provides downpayment
assistance to first-time homebuyers earning up to 80 percent of area median
income. The Community Investment Program / Economic Development Fund offer
reduced-rate loans for affordable housing and community economic development.

One of 12 Federal Home Loan Banks in the United States, the Seattle Bank serves
Alaska, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming, American
Samoa, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands.

                         Deming Headlight (New Mexico)

                              June 21, 2010 Monday

June is National Homeownership Month

BYLINE: By Terry Brunner For the Headlight

SECTION: OPINION

LENGTH: 631 words


USDA Rural Development State Director Terry Brunner announced that June has been
declared National Homeownership Month by the federal government. The celebration
is a commemoration of the 'American Dream of Homeownership' and to open the door
for new homeowners.

During the month of June, USDA Rural Development has planned numerous activities
across New Mexico to bring more attention to homeownership. The events are
designed to educate the public on how to purchase a home.

In making the announcement Brunner said, "USDA Rural Development has always been
committed to helping families reach their dream of homeownership and this year's
theme 'Protecting the American Dream' is particularly important during these
challenging times." Brunner added, "Since the beginning of the fiscal year we
have provided almost 400 families with home loans making this fiscal year one of
the most successful we've ever had in New Mexico."

National Homeownership Month began in 1997 as a challenge to increase the number
of homeowners throughout the United States. Government studies have shown that
homeownership is a key element in the nation's economy with the housing industry
accounting for about 15 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP) in a typical
year. Studies also show that neighborhoods are strengthened when there is a
higher percentage of homeownership. Homeowners are proven to be more active in
their neighborhoods, they contribute more to their communities and a more stable
environment for families is created.

This month, USDA Rural Development will highlight and honor several families who
have successfully achieved homeownership, who have overcome family challenges to
do so and to also honor the many lenders and realtors who have partnered with
USDA Rural Development to ensure that New Mexico families have access to the
housing programs funding sources offered by Rural Development.

USDA Rural Development's mission is to increase economic opportunity and improve
the quality of life for rural residents. Rural Development fosters growth in
homeownership, finances business development, and supports the creation of
critical community and technology infrastructure. Further information on rural
programs is available at any local USDA Rural Development office or by visiting
USDA Rural Development's web site at www.rurdev.usda.gov .

Event Schedule

June 21, Portales, NM (11 a.m.) -- State Director Terry Brunner will present a
U.S. flag to Burl and Jana Dodd to celebrate their successful purchase of a
home. The event will be held at e Frost Mortgage located at 401 West 4th Street
in Portales, NM. The State Director will also present a certificate of
appreciation to Mr. Chris Wood of Frost Mortgage for his efforts in providing
homeownership opportunities in the Portales area.

June 21, Hobbs/Lovington, NM (3 p.m.) -- Housewarming event at the home of David
Valderaz and family located at West Avenue I, Lovington, NM. State Director
Brunner will present a U.S. flag to the family to celebrate their successful
purchase of a home. Brenda Bryant of ENG Lending will be named lender of the
year in the Hobbs/Lovington area.

June 22, Artesia, NM (10 a.m.) -- Housewarming event at the home of Ms. Sherry
Norwood located at 1409 West James in Artesia, NM. State Director Brunner will
present a U.S. flag to Ms. Norwood to celebrate their successful purchase of a
home. State Director Brunner will also make a special presentation to 1st
American Bank for the work the lending institution has done to provide mortgages
in the Artesia area.

June 22, Roswell (1:30 p.m.) -- Housing partners briefing. State Director Terry
Brunner will lead a presentation on the housing programs offered by USDA Rural
Development in conjunction with various partners including RCAC, HAC and MFA.

                               The Times (London)

                             January 9, 2015 Friday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Tens of thousands of homes in brownfield building boom

BYLINE: Jill Sherman

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 589 words


Tens of thousands of new homes are to be fast-tracked across the country, the
government has announced.

A shortlist of 29 new housing zones - including several in the north and
Midlands - has been published, with proposals of up to 2,000 homes per scheme
although larger sites are being considered. Twenty large-scale housing zones
have already been proposed in London by Boris Johnson.

The first ten housing zones outside the capital will be chosen in the coming
weeks. Brandon Lewis, the housing minister, said they would share a £200 million
pot to help with infrastructure. All the schemes - a mix of social and market
housing - will be on brownfield sites. Some of the housing will be on public
land released by the closure of hospitals, schools and military sites.

Councils will ensure that planning permission is fast-tracked so that developers
can start clearing sites.

The builders will be entitled to loans from the fund to clean up the land and
start setting up infrastructure such as roads and utility lines. In some cases
developers may also get funds to build schools and community services.

However, many of the schemes are bound to attract opposition from local
residents who do not want housing estates on their doorsteps. Plans for
largescale eco-towns were heavily resisted under the last Labour government.

George Osborne said that a key part of the government's economic plan was to
build more homes. Housing experts claim that at least 250,000 extra homes are
needed each year to cope with demographic growth. In recent years less than half
that number has been built.

"I'm delighted to announce the areas shortlisted to become the first housing
zones in England, which as part of a wider package of measures will help deliver
up to 200,000 new homes on brownfield land," said the chancellor.

Officials said that most of the housing zones would be between 750 and 2,000
homes each, but larger schemes are not ruled out. Mr Lewis said: "The ten that
are finally chosen will have the chance to build homes for local communities
while continuing to protect the green belt."

Mr Osborne said last year that there was enough brownfield land for 200,000 new
homes by 2020. He has already announced proposals to ensure that 90 per cent of
this land has planning permission by 2020. Councils will be able to use local
development orders to set out the amount and type of housing that can be built
on the sites.

The Campaign to Protect Rural England welcomed the scheme but said that land was
continually being removed from green belt in local plans so that it could be
built upon at a later date. "Worthy brownfield projects should not hide the fact
that the green belt is still under threat in many areas," said Paul Miner, its
campaign manager.

The shortlisted councils are: Thurrock, Hertsmere, Guildford, Babergh and
Mid-Suffolk, West Lindsey, Dudley, Sandwell, Stoke, Derby, Gedling, Bassetlaw,
Wakefield, North East Lincolnshire, York, Barnsley, Gateshead, Sheffield,
Preston, Blackburn with Darwen, Wirral, Bristol, East Hampshire, North Somerset,
Tewkesbury, Sedgemoor, Poole, Bath and North Somerset, and Gloucester.

? The end of 2014 saw the slowest pace of house price growth in a year. The
average price of a home crept up by 7.8 per cent in the 12 months to December to
£188,858, according to the Halifax, whose index is based on its mortgage book.
House price growth peaked at 10.2 per cent in July and December's pace of annual
expansion was the slowest since last January. On a monthly basis it was 0.9 per
cent higher.

                          New Straits Times (Malaysia)

                           February 28, 2017 Tuesday

HOUSING SCHEME FOR SETTLERS' CHILDREN

BYLINE: T.N. Alagesh

SECTION: Pg. 29

LENGTH: 488 words


ROMPIN: SECOND-GENERATION Felda settlers facing housing problems in their
settlements can look forward to building homes under the "Planned Housing Site
for the Second Generation" scheme.

Â Felda chairman Tan Sri Shahrir Abdul Samad said under the scheme, Felda would
work with the Pahang government to identify lands in settlements that would be
developed for housing.

He said second-generation settlers shortlisted for the scheme could apply for
housing loans from Syarikat Perumahan Negara Bhd (SPNB) to build houses.

"The module is convenient and the site owner will have to bear the cost of the
construction (through SPNB loans). Felda will provide the basic facilities and
infrastructure, including roads, drains and playgrounds.

"Government agencies and the Rural and Regional Development Ministry can provide
the infrastructure.

"What is important is the Felda settlement has to provide a piece of land for
the housing scheme," he said after the groundbreaking ceremony for a similar
scheme in Felda Keratong 5 here yesterday.

Â Shahrir said since land in Felda settlements came under the jurisdiction of
the Land Group Settlement Area (GSA) Act 1960, it had to be measured and handed
back to the state government before work could start.Â

Under GSA, land owned by settlers cannot be leased or transferred to another
party, except with the written approval of state authorities.

He said the concept had received the nod from menteri besar of other states and
would be expanded to other settlements nationwide.

"During my meeting with several menteris besar, they agreed with the concept as
we have a similar project in Felda Tenggara in Johor. Felda wants a solution to
problems faced by second-generation settlers and I believe this is a suitable
concept.

"The project in Felda Keratong was discussed three weeks ago when I met the
assemblymen and members of parliament from Pahang in Kuantan. Rompin member of
parliament Datuk Seri Hasan Arifin shared the module and now we have a better
idea on how Felda can help," he said.

Shahrir said it was not easy to find a solution to address second-generation
settlers' housing problems, but with support from all parties, it could help
young settlers own homes.

Pahang Menteri Besar Datuk Seri Adnan Yaakob, who launched the groundbreaking
ceremony, said the project in Felda Keratong 5 displayed the strong commitment
between the state government and Felda to provide homes for second-generation
settlers.

"The state government will study the list of the second-generation settlers,
especially after Felda settlements submit their lists.

"I hope other government agencies will support the project so that it will not
face delays or setbacks," he said.

The project in Felda Keratong 5 involves 125 participants who are each provided
with a 464-sq m site for each house.Â

The scheme is tailored for the children of early settlers living with their
parents and who do not own houses.

                                 Yorkshire Post

                                 March 27, 2004

Prescott goes round the houses

SOURCE: Yorkshire Post

LENGTH: 1090 words


JOHN PRESCOTT'S oft-quoted remark that the green belt is a Labour policy which
he "intends to build upon" may be apocryphal, but it has also become a
remarkably accurate summary of the Deputy Prime Minister's approach to housing
development in the countryside.

John Yates

It was not so long ago that Two-Homes-Two-Jags Prescott, the man who preaches
the importance of environmentally friendly, sustainable development, was talking
about the need to build new homes on so-called brownfield sites - a posh term
for land contaminated by industrial waste and pollution which no one wants to
build on and where no one wants to live.

But not any more. Leaned on by Gordon Brown - the man who writes the cheques for
New Labour - Mr Prescott has been persuaded that the green belt is the place to
put houses. And lots of them.

As many as 240,000 extra homes, over the next five years, if the latest
Government thinking is acted upon. This is double the amount of new houses
currently being built and would be the equivalent of constructing a city larger
than Manchester.

While much of this development will take place in the South-East, the powers
that Mr Prescott is assuming, and the devious methods he is using to by-pass
local objectors, portend ill for any chance of stopping similar schemes in parts
of Yorkshire and the North.

Quietly, almost unnoticed even, planning powers are being given to the shadowy,
unelected regional assemblies, many of which are dominated by New Labour's
placemen. The M11 corridor-city, for instance, has been pushed through by the
East of England Regional Assembly, which seems to jump at Mr Prescott's every
command. So much for devolution.

The Deputy Prime Minister, whose affection for rural England was best expressed
in his acid reaction to what he called the "contorted faces" of the countryside
protesters, is also cleverly trying to abolish the nation's ancient county
structure with the proposed referendums for urban-dominated, regional
parliaments. Already, new legislation is being framed to tie the old system of
county plans to what New Labour's spin doctors in Whitehall inelegantly call
"regional spacial strategies" and to restrict the power of county halls to
decide on key planning matters.

Though most of this development will fuel the already overheated economy of the
South, to the detriment of the brownfield sites in the North, Mr Prescott has
begun to show an alarming interest in what is being called by one fashionable
architect the "global city coast to coast": a rather wordy way of talking about
the M62 corridor from Hull to Liverpool.

Both Mr Prescott and Will Alsop, whose practice has found favour with New
Labour's development agencies, seem to envisage a long ribbon of housing and
commercial development along this corridor, rather than the Randstad
configuration of cities in the Netherlands with its openness and green spaces.
The result could be an urban jungle linked by a tarmac girdle stretching across
the country from east to west: a terrible thought.

For those who follow these things closely - and fortunately for Mr Prescott they
are a rare breed - subtle changes in planning guidance (a euphemism for central
government dictat) are now tilting the balance in favour of the developer and
away from those who would try to preserve something of the local character and
flavour of rural England.

And who can blame the farmer for seeing in this emerging free-for-all the chance
to turn unprofitable agricultural land into a development opportunity?

This Government has made no secret of its utter contempt for those who have
struggled to make a living off the land.

It lectures farmers endlessly on the need for diversity and enterprise; but how
cruel an irony if those who have for centuries been the custodians of the rural
environment were to be seduced by New Labour's misguided loosening of the
planning regulations into destroying the very thing their families, down the
generations, have held so dear.

And for what? Mr Prescott claims there is a dire housing crisis. And yet the
most recent census data shows that the population of England and Wales is some
900,000 lower than previously thought and that there is a surplus of dwellings
over the households.

Indeed, this surplus has actually increased over the last decade and across all
regions of England with the exception of London (where the balance is largely
unchanged).

The Government claims that the rise in house prices is proof of an excess of
demand over supply, but is this really the case?

Rising house prices are a global phenomenon and occur in countries such as the
United States and Australia where there are no restrictions on land supply.

Moreover, as new housing represents less than one per cent of the total housing
stock (or closer to 10 per cent of the traded housing market) it is hard to see
how it can exert a powerful influence on short-term fluctuations in price.

According to research carried out for the Council for the Protection of Rural
England, volatility in the housing market is brought about more by demand
factors (such as people's changing expectations of their future wage or
employment prospects) than supply-side factors.

What Kate Barker's recent Treasury-sponsored report demonstrates is that there
is perhaps a need for affordable housing for certain income groups or for
certain professions (say, teachers and nurses in the South of England).

But these problems are as much about incomes as they are about prices, and the
government (which prides itself on joined-up thinking) has set its face against
regional pay bargaining, thus making it less likely that the gap between pay and
house prices will narrow.

Instead, Mr Prescott has responded to this dilemma by offering certain groups of
workers interest free loans of up to six-figure sums to get them on the housing
ladder, which seems less a case of joined-up thinking than muddled thinking.

Relaxing planning constraints to allow more building on the green belt, as the
Government is suggesting, will do nothing to bring affordable housing to
teachers and nurses in the South- East where wages and price inflation make it
impossible to get on the ladder as first-time buyers.

But what does Mr Prescott care for the contorted faces of the country dwellers?
Whenever he sings Jerusalem at the end of a party conference, what the Deputy
Prime Minister sees is hypermarkets, caravan parks, and housing sprawl across
England's green and pleasant land.

                     High Point Enterprise (North Carolina)

                             April 2, 2013 Tuesday

Council approves revamped loan pool

BYLINE: Pat Kimbrough, The High Point Enterprise, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 488 words


April 02--HIGH POINT -- City officials have found a new use for a federal loan
pool that went untapped a few years ago when it was targeted for small business
development.

The City Council on Monday gave the OK to seek federal approval to allow the
city to use $3.9 million to fund improvements associated with multifamily
affordable housing initiatives.

The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development has committed to loan the
city this amount. The city's initial plan was to combine the funds with $5.8
million put up by local banks for a small business loan initiative, which was
established in 2010.

None of the funds were ever loaned out, because none of the applicants to the
pool qualified.

If HUD approves the city's request, the money will instead be used to fund
infrastructure or acquire land associated with development projects. The first
recipient of a loan is slated to be Wynnefield Properties of Jamestown, which
plans to develop a 58-unit apartment complex off Samet Drive in north High
Point. If it gets the OK from HUD, the city will draw on $1.35 million of the
funds to loan to Wynnefield, which it will use to try to leverage tax credit
financing for the project.

The site is across the street from Admiral Pointe, a similar project the company
developed a few years ago.

The new development, Addington Ridge, would serve older residents and charge
rents of $210 to $650 for those earning 40 to 60 percent of the area median
income.

If the developer receives the loan, it would repay the city over 20 years, and
the city would, in turn use the funds to pay HUD back. The remaining $2.55
million in loan funds will be available for future projects.

Council members discussed whether the loans could be used in support of
restoring the former Kilby Hotel property on Washington Street, which was
designated unsafe and closed a few months ago.

The property's owner or someone on their behalf could be eligible for a loan if
they're deemed to be a qualified borrower and meet other conditions, officials
said.

Also Monday, council approved a resolution in support of maintaining the state
Parks and Recreation Trust Fund, which has provided $161 million in grants to
local governments over the past 19 years.

Gov. Pat McCrory's proposed budget would cut the fund by 44 percent this year
and eliminate the funding source for the program next year. High Point has
received two PARTF grants -- one for the original Washington Terrace Park
community building ($250,000) and the other for the Allen Jay Recreation Center
($500,000).

City officials have plans to apply for a PARTF grant to fund completion of High
Point's greenway trail by constructing a 1.1-mile stretch from University Park
on Deep River Road to the Piedmont Environmental Center on Penny Road.

Enterprise (High Point, N.C.) at www.hpe.com Distributed by MCT Information
Services

JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This position is located in the Southern Division, Engineering Branch,
Telecommunications.  The incumbent participates with the Division Director in
the development and modification of Division practices and procedures, and is
responsible for recommending specific actions in the engineering area which will
maximize program achievement at the lowest possible costs.

This announcement may be used to fill additional vacancies that are identified
by the organization.

and manufacturers engaged in engineering and constructions activities.

technical operation, and maintenance of rural telecommunications systems and
facilities.
    Provides technical policy guidance, necessary direction and coordination to
the Division's General Field Representatives (GFRs) on work pertaining to the
engineering and construction phases of the telecommunications program.
    Directs and coordinates the implementation of the Distance Learning and
