Rural Utility Service: Supervisory Electronics Engineer DC-2014-0088

LENGTH: 2884  words

DATELINE: Washington


The United States Office of Personnel Management has issued the following job
announcement:

Job Title:Supervisory Electronics Engineer

Department:Department Of Agriculture

Agency:Rural Utility Service

Job Announcement Number:DC-2014-0088
SALARY RANGE:
 $106,263.00 to $138,136.00 / Per Year
OPEN PERIOD:
 Tuesday, August 5, 2014 to Thursday, August 14, 2014
SERIES & GRADE:
 GS-0855-14
POSITION INFORMATION:
 Full-Time - Permanent
PROMOTION POTENTIAL:
14
DUTY LOCATIONS:
 1 vacancy - District of Columbia, DC View Map
WHO MAY APPLY:
 Current permanent Rural Utilities Service (RUS) employees with competitive
status, and USDA CTAP eligibles.
SECURITY CLEARANCE:
 Q - Sensitive
SUPERVISORY STATUS:
 Yes
JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This position is located in the Southern Division, Engineering Branch,
Telecommunications.  The incumbent participates with the Division Director in
the development and modification of Division practices and procedures, and is
responsible for recommending specific actions in the engineering area which will
maximize program achievement at the lowest possible costs.

This announcement may be used to fill additional vacancies that are identified
by the organization.
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Not Required

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

US Citizenship is required.
    Selective Service Registration is required for males born after 12/31/1959.
    OGE Form 450 is required.
    One year supervisory probationary period may be required.

DUTIES:
Back to top

Directs and coordinates the engineering functions of the telecommunications
program for an assigned geographic area, involving administration of the
engineering and constructions phases of rural telecommunications systems and
facilities.
    Coordinates the activities of borrowers, borrowers' engineers, contractors
and manufacturers engaged in engineering and constructions activities.
    Provides advice and assistance to borrowers concerning design, construction,
technical operation, and maintenance of rural telecommunications systems and
facilities.
    Provides technical policy guidance, necessary direction and coordination to
the Division's General Field Representatives (GFRs) on work pertaining to the
engineering and construction phases of the telecommunications program.
    Directs and coordinates the implementation of the Distance Learning and
Telemedicine (DLT) program upon release of funds.
    Approves the advance of loan and grant funds to borrowers and grantees;
processing and approving final inventories of completed construction.
    Provides continuing administrative and technical supervision to a
headquarters staff engaged in substantive professional and technical duties and
responsibilities.

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:
Back to top

Applicants must provide documentation (such as a transcript, professional
registration, Engineer-In-Training certificate, etc.) to show they meet the
Basic Requirements, either Option A or Option B for this position. Failure to
provide documentation may result in loss of consideration for this position:

A. Degree: professional engineering. To be acceptable, the curriculum must: (1)
be in a school of engineering with at least one curriculum accredited by the
Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology (ABET) as a professional
engineering curriculum; or (2) include differential and integral calculus and
courses (more advanced than first-year physics and chemistry) in five of the
following seven areas of engineering science or physics: (a) statics, dynamics;
(b) strength of materials (stress-strain relationships); (c) fluid mechanics,
hydraulics; (d) thermodynamics; (e) electrical fields and circuits; (f) nature
and properties of materials (relating particle and aggregate structure to
properties); and (g) any other comparable area of fundamental engineering
science or physics, such as optics, heat transfer, soil mechanics, or
electronics.

OR

B. Combination of education and experience: College-level education and
technical experience. (NOTE: Due to the length of the qualification standard for
this position, the following is a summary of the GS-0800 Qualification
Standards. Although this section is summarized, you must meet all qualification
requirements as stated in the OPM Qualification Standards. To review the entire
qualification standard please click on: All Professional Engineering Positions,
0800 The adequacy of such background must be demonstrated by one of the
following: 1. Professional registration; 2. Written test - Engineer-In-Training
(EIT) examination and have completed degree requirements as stated on website;
3. Specified academic courses (see list at OPM website above); or 4. Related
curriculum with appropriate experience (see OPM website above).

In addition to meeting the basic requirements, applicants must meet the
following:

For the GS-14 level: Applicants must have 1 year of specialized experience
equivalent to at least the GS-13; or its non-Federal equivalent that
demonstrates: providing advice on technical matters related to engineering and
construction functions such as system design, preparation of plans and
specifications, supervision and inspection of construction and technical
operation and maintenance matters including technical audits; experience
examining loan applications developed by borrowers in support of the engineering
and construction functions; experience leading or supervising technical
personnel. There is no education substitution for this grade level. Note: To be
considered for this position, you must meet all qualification and eligibility
requirements for the GS-0855 series set forth in the Office of Personnel
Management Qualifications Standards by the closing date of the announcement. A
copy is available at: http://www.opm.gov/qualifications/index.asp.


To view qualifying education requirements and/or combination of education and
specialized experience click on the following link:
http://www.opm.gov/qualifications/Standards/group-stds/gs-prof.asp

AND
Click on the following link to view occupational requirements for this position:

http://www.opm.gov/qualifications/Standards/IORs/gs0800/0800.htm

o  Applicants must have, or be able to obtain within a reasonable time
consistent with designated state(s)' testing/licensing procedures, registration
as a Professional Engineer. Application must contain sufficient information to
ascertain the possession of such registration or ability to obtain registration
within a reasonable period of time.
o  Subject to satisfactory completion of a one year supervisory/managerial
probationary period
o  CONFIDENTIAL FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE REPORT: If selected, you will be required
to submit Form OGE-450 within 30 days of your initial appointment date, and
annually thereafter. Selectee is subject to financial Disclosure Requirements in
accordance with 5 CFR, Part 2635, Sub part E regarding business or personal
transactions with applicants, borrowers, or business contacts who have or who
are seeking business with this Agency. Selectee must be able to obtain and
maintain a security clearance. If selected you will be subject to a National
Agency Check and Inquiry (NACI) and a credit report.
HOW YOU WILL BE EVALUATED:

You will be evaluated based on your qualifications for this position as
evidenced by the education, experience, and training you described in your
application package, as well as the responses to the Occupational Questionnaire
to determine the degree to which you possess the knowledge, skills, abilities
and competencies listed below:

Telecommunications Systems Design, Installation and/or Construction
        Project Management
        Assess Technical Studies
        Oral Communication
        Written Communication
        Supervision

We will review your application, including the on-line Occupational
Questionnaire, to ensure you meet the job requirements and assess your ability
to perform this job. Before any certificate can be issued to the selecting
official, the resume and supporting documents are reviewed by an HR Specialist
to ensure that (a) minimum qualification requirements are met and (b) the resume
supports the answers provided to the job-specific questions. Your answers will
be verified against information provided in your on-line resume and application.
Be sure that your resume clearly supports your responses to all the questions
addressing experience and education relevant to this position.
    Applicants who meet the basic minimum qualification requirements and are
determined to be among the best qualified candidates will be referred to the
hiring manager for consideration. Non-Competitive candidates need to meet
minimum qualification requirements to be referred.

Note: If, after reviewing your resume and/or supporting documentation, a
determination is made that you have inflated your qualifications and or
experience, your score can/will be lowered to more accurately reflect the
submitted documentation. Please follow all instructions carefully. Errors or
omissions may affect your rating. Deliberate attempts to falsify information may
be grounds for not selecting you.

OTHER INFORMATION:
o  BACKGROUND INVESTIGATION AND FINGERPRINT CHECK:  Selection and retention in
this position is contingent on a successfully adjudicated FBI National Criminal
History Check (fingerprint check) and a background investigation.
o  Career Transition Assistance Plan(CTAP) or Interagency Career Transition
Assistance Plan (ICTAP):   If you are claiming CTAP eligibility, provide proof
of eligibility to include your most recent performance appraisal, SF-50, and
proof of eligibility such as a RIF separation notice or letter from OPM/your
agency.  CTAP eligibles will be considered well-qualified if achieving a rating
of 85 or above.  Information about CTAP/ICTAP eligibility is on OPM's Career
Transition Resources website at http://www.opm.gov/ctap/index.asp.
o  This position is eligible for telework and other flexible work arrangements.
Employee participation is at the discretion of the supervisor.
o  Persons with disabilities who require alternative means for communication of
program information (Braille, large print, audiotape, etc) should contact:
USDA's TARGET Center at 202-720-2600 (voice and TDD).
HOW TO APPLY:
Back to top

Please read the entire announcement and all the instructions before you begin.
The following instructions outline our application process.

You must complete this application process and submit all required documents
electronically by 11:59 p.m. Eastern Time (ET) on the closing date of this
announcement.
    We are available to assist you during business hours normally (8:00 a.m. -
4:00 p.m., Monday - Friday). Applying online is highly encouraged. If applying
online poses a hardship, please contact our office during business hours well
before the closing date for an alternate method. All hardship application
packages with supporting documents must be submitted no later than noon on the
closing date of the announcement in order to be entered into the system prior to
its closing.
    This agency provides reasonable accommodation to applicants with
disabilities on a case-by-case basis; contact us if you are requesting this.

Step 1: Create a USAJOBS account (if you do not have one) at www.usajobs.gov. It
is recommended that as part of your profile you set up automatic email
notification to be informed when the status of your application changes. If you
choose not to set up this automatic notification, then you will have to log into
your USAJOBS account to check on the status of your application.


Step 2: Create a resume with USAJOBS or upload a resume into your USAJOBS
account. Customize your resume to ensure it documents duties and accomplishments
you have gained that are directly related to this position in order to verify
that qualifications are met. Your resume must support your responses to the
online questionnaire (you may preview the online questionnaire by clicking on
the link at the end of the How You Will Be Evaluated section of the job
announcement).

Step 3: Click "Apply Online" and follow the prompts to complete the Occupational
Questionnaire and attach any additional documents that may be required.
You can update your application or documents anytime while the announcement is
open. Log into your USAJOBS account and click on "Application Status." Click on
the position title, and then select "Update Application" to continue.
NOTE: Verify that uploaded documents from USAJOBs transfer into the Agency's
staffing system. Once in the Agency's staffing system you will have the
opportunity to upload additional documents. Uploaded documents must be less than
3MB and in one of the following document formats: GIF, JPG, JPEG, PNG, RTF, PDF,
or Word (DOC or DOCX).


REQUIRED DOCUMENTS:

A complete Application Package must be submitted and received prior to 11:59,
ET, on the closing date. The following documents are required for your
application package to be complete. Our office cannot be responsible for
incompatible software, illegible fax transmissions, delays in the mail service,
your system failure or downtime, etc. Failure to submit required, legible
documents may result in loss of consideration.

Resume that includes the following information: 1) personal information; 2)
education; 3) work experience including the work schedule and hours worked per
week as well as dates of employment; and title, series and grade if applicable;
4) supervisor's phone number and e-mail address for each work period listed and
whether or not we may contact them for reference checks; and, 5) other
qualifications.

Other required documents as applicable:

Current Career/Career-Conditional: Most recent non-award Notification of
Personnel Action (SF-50 or equivalent) showing that you are/were in the
competitive service, highest grade (or promotion potential) held on a permanent
basis, federal status, position title, series and grade AND most recently
completed performance appraisal (dated within 18 months) showing the official
rating of record, signed by the supervisor, or a statement as to why the
performance appraisal is unavailable. Do not submit a performance plan.
    CTAP: Certification of Expected Separation, Reduction-In-Force Separation
Notice, Notice of Proposed Removal, or appropriate OPM/Agency certification; AND
most recent performance evaluation; AND SF-50 demonstrating your separation or
the position from which you will be separated.

WHAT TO EXPECT NEXT:

Occupational Questionnaire and resume was successful,  2) if you were referred
to the selecting official for consideration, and  3) if you were selected or not
selected. If you choose not to set up automatic email notifications, you must
check your USAJOBS account for the latest status of your application. Your
application may be reviewed to verify that you meet the qualifications and
eligibility requirements for the position prior to issuing lists to a selecting
official. If further evaluation or interviews are required, you will be
contacted. Normally, a final job offer to the selected candidate is made within
30-60 days after the issuance of the certificate.

JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This position is located in the Southern Division, Engineering Branch,
Telecommunications.  The incumbent participates with the Division Director in
the development and modification of Division practices and procedures, and is
responsible for recommending specific actions in the engineering area which will
maximize program achievement at the lowest possible costs.

This announcement may be used to fill additional vacancies that are identified
by the organization.

                               Loughborough Echo

                               February 13, 2009
                                  1ST Edition

Buyers register for new homes at 70 per cent of the price

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 66

LENGTH: 604 words


MORE than 270 prospective homebuyers have signed up for a new scheme backed by
Barratt Homes North Midlands and the Government which enables them to move into
a new home in Leicestershire for just 70 per cent of the price.

Pre-registration for the HomeBuy Direct scheme was launched just four weeks ago.
Homebuyers taking advantage of it will receive a 30 per cent equity loan funded
jointly by Barratt Homes and the Government. The buyer finances the remaining 70
per cent of the purchase price either through a mortgage, a deposit or a
combination of the two.

The company is backing the initiative with a total of 3,000 homes nationwide and
45 in Leicestershire.

"We have had a tremendous response in the four weeks since we launched pre
registration for HomeBuy Direct across the North Midlands, which shows that
there is still enormous demand for new homes in this area," said James Poynor,
sales director at Barratt Homes North Midlands.

"People who have been priced out of the housing market for years can see this is
an outstanding opportunity to buy at new, lower 2009 prices - not high 2007
prices. The 30 per cent equity loan from ourselves and the Government means that
in many cases they don't even need to have a deposit."

"The scheme is open to First Time Buyers, Key Workers and others who are
currently renting. People who have previously owned properties but are now
unable to do so - perhaps because they have been in relationships which came to
an end - can also apply."

Under HomeBuy Direct, buyers will be protected against possible falls in
property values up to 30 per cent as the Barratt/Government equity share will
absorb price risk. In addition, there is no interest to pay on the joint
Barratt/Government equity stake for the first five years, although a fee will be
charged from year six onwards.

Buyers can redeem the loan in instalments, purchasing up to 100 per cent of the
equity after their initial purchase by buying additional equity at the market
rate. Alternatively, if they sell their home, the equity loan is repaid by way
of a share of the sale proceeds.

The 45 homes being allocated to the scheme in Leicestershire include plots at
the Stephensons Place development in Coalville and Regents Park in Hamilton.

Stephensons Place is a brand new development with a stunning collection of two
bedroom apartments and three and four bedroom family homes. Situated in rural
Coalville, on the former Stephensons college site, Stephensons Place offers an
excellent selection of properties and local amenities that make it ideal for
first time buyers and families alike.

Meanwhile, the award winning Regents Park development is located in the popular
residential area of Hamilton on the outskirts of the city and offers a selection
of one and two bedroom apartments and three and four bedroom family homes. With
nearby countryside within walking distance it offers the ideal country retreat.

To pre-register for the scheme visit www.barratthomes.co.uk/homebuydirect.

The website contains the full list of sites. Customers who have pre-registered
will be immediately contacted as soon as a property in the Leicestershire area
becomes available. Households eligible to take advantage of the offer will be
earning less than pounds 60,000 and would not normally be able to afford to buy
a suitable property on the open market.

For further information on the developments contact the sales advisors on 01530
812 543 for Stephensons Place and on 0116 246 0317 for Regents Park.
Alternatively you can visit the developments, which are open Thursday to Monday
between 11.00am and 6.00pm.

Planners' objections 'swept aside'

n From Page 1.

-tial number of new houses due to be built in Doncaster between 1986 and 2001
from 14,600 - a figure set by Government guidance - to 20,000.

Mr Wallens said planning officers had listed all their objections to the new
inclusions in the original draft of the UDP but they had been ignored.

He said planners had described the proposal to earmark housing for the Branton
site as being "in conflict with long-standing policies".

He said the final draft version, produced in 1993, had not been written by the
group of officers who had been working on the UDP for four years, but instead by
the then planning director David Ellis. It was approved by the planning
committee in October that year.

Earlier, the court heard that Hughes had sent Lloyds Bank a copy of a letter
from Ellis to his (Hughes's) financial adviser and co-accused Gordon Armitage to
try to stop it taking legal action over a debt of nearly (GBP)350,000.

Mr Farrer said Ellis's letter, written in November 1993, was to the effect that
permission for housing was likely to be granted in the near future on the
Poppyfields site, which was ultimately worth (GBP)2.25m to Hughes.

It has also previously been alleged that Birks pressured Ellis to write "a
comfort letter" to would-be developers David Wilson Homes to suggest the site
was going to be redesignated from countryside to residential.

Hughes owed over (GBP)6m to four financial institutions but deterred recovery
action by three by telling them his financial problems were to be solved by the
money he would receive from the Poppyfields site, the court heard. In addition
to the Lloyds debt he owed (GBP)5.3m in 1992 to Australian bank Westpac after
defaulting on a loan used to buy Woodside Quarry in Horsforth, Leeds. He owed
Skipton Building Society nearly (GBP)160,000 in early 1993 and in mid-1993 he
owed (GBP)281,000 to the UCB Bank.

The court also heard that the decision to grant planning permission for housing
on Poppyfields was a "surprise" to the planning agent Hughes had himself
appointed to put the application to the council.

George Lindley, a retired Doncaster building surveyor and a personal friend of
Hughes, had submitted Hughes's original application in August 1992.

He said it was initially turned down the following month by the planning
committee, who decided it would "cause a serious detriment to the rural
character of the immediate locality".

A second, almost identical, application was quickly submitted, and then amended
to inc-rease the amount of open space.

Mr Lindley's involvement ended soon after but he was still informed later by the
council that permission had been granted.

He said: "I would have thought if the application had any chance it would have
to be by going to the (Government) inspector on an appeal basis.

"I didn't see any reason the application should be approved by purely and simply
increasing the open space area."

                          Australian Financial Review

                           September 28, 1998 Monday
                                  Late Edition

The financial woes of Japan are land-locked;
Tokyo Observed

BYLINE: Tony Boyd

SECTION: NEWS; International News; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 846 words


When Paul Keating correctly picked the top of the Tokyo property market in 1988,
the company on the other side of the transaction would never have dreamed that
10 years later Japan's property prices would be in the seventh straight year of
decline.

Giant trading house Itochu paid $640 million for a third of the Australian
Embassy garden in Tokyo's Mita ward, but for various reasons it never
constructed the huge pencil-thin tower planned for the site.

The price paid for the land could only be justified if the building went ahead,
but it is likely the property remains in the balance sheet of Itochu at the
bubble economy value.

At the time Itochu did the deal, Japan's land prices had been rising every year
since 1945, with the exception of 1979, and bank lenders and investors thought
there was little risk of a fall.

Seven years after the bubble economy burst, property remains at the heart of
Japan's financial system problem because virtually all non-performing loans are
backed by property collateral.

Apart from some isolated transactions by distressed sellers, Japan's property
market is virtually illiquid because of a combination of taxation, regulatory,
criminal and structural issues.

Until the Government removes the barriers to a more liquid market, banks will
continue to resist the disposal of property backing bad loans and economic
stagnation will persist. High capital gains taxes on land are a major
disincentive for owners to sell. Profits on the sale of land are taxed as income
at the highest corporate rate.

A rule change earlier this year allowing loss-making companies to sell property
free of capital gains tax is having a positive impact on supply. Yamato Life
sold its head office in Hibiya to Goldman Sachs and last week Nissan Motor sold
its new head office in Ginza to Mori Building.

There is a drawback, however, to increased supply, according to John Tofflemire,
general manager of CB Richard Ellis in Tokyo.

"Eliminating the corporate gains tax for corporations in the red is making the
supply curve less inelastic and that means that if there is a shift in demand
the price won't rise as much," he said. "Now that you are seeing these
distressed companies bringing property to the market, it means that even if the
demand increases you are not going to see the price increases that the banks are
sitting and hallucinating- it just won't happen."

Regulations are another barrier to greater liquidity in the property market. One
of the most prominent critics is Minoru Mori, president of Mori Building.

Mori, who this month became a member of Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi's Strategic
Economic Council, told The Australian Financial Review that restrictions needed
to be relaxed on floor space ratio.

"In big cities, the land has to be efficiently utilised to double the per capita
space for living and working, which I call a global standard living and working
space," he said.

He said Japan needed to concentrate the small lots of land in big cities into
large scale lots and build tall buildings. "This will reduce the floor area to
plottage ratio and create additional space for the public such as green tracts."

Mori said the present tax system encouraged small scale housing and this should
be revised.

The criminal influence over restricting supply of property is well known but
rarely discussed by government officials or politicians.

The yakuza has built a huge business out of illegally occupying property that is
held as collateral for bad loans. Many Japanese financial institutions are
washing their hands of this problem by selling such properties to US investors
at a 10th of face value.

One of the few Japanese people confronting this issue head-on is Kohei Nakabo,
the head of the Housing Loan Administration Corp, who is in charge of
liquidating billions of yen in non-performing loans written by the failed Jusen
housing co-operatives.

The yakuza involvement in the bad loan problem is said to be so pervasive some
bankers believe only those institutions from the yakuza stronghold of Osaka,
such as Sanwa Bank and Sumitomo Bank, will have the skills to negotiate their
way through the problem.

The main structural barrier to land transactions is tied in with the country's
long-standing subsidisation of its farming population, which in turn explains
why Japan does not have a society based on consumption.

A host of direct and indirect subsidies and property tax breaks for farmers have
served to push up the price of rural land which in turn has spilled over into
the cost of housing in major urban centres.

Although Japan has the highest level of per capita income in the Group of Seven
richest industrial countries, the high price of land and food has meant the
purchasing power of Japanese is 20 to 30 per cent less than in other countries.

Japanese houses, which were once described as "rabbit hutches" by Sir Roy
Denman, can often only be purchased with a mortgage that lasts two generations,
thanks to the rural protectionism.

Housing starts are at the lowest level since 1985 and in August recorded the
19th straight month of decline.

                              The Herald (Harare)

                          September 25, 2010 Saturday

VP Nkomo Commissions 740 Stands

LENGTH: 488  words

DATELINE: Harare


Acting President John Nkomo yesterday commissioned 740 residential stands in
Kwekwe as part of Government efforts to ensure provision of decent accommodation
to low income earners countrywide.

The stands would be developed under the Mbizo 22 Housing Project under the US$25
million National Housing Loan Facility allocated to the Housing Ministry in the
2009 National Budget.

The acting President also took the opportunity to launch the National Housing
Loan Facility that would also see Government providing affordable residential
stands in all provinces.

Due to prohibitive costs of building houses as a result of illegal Western
economic sanctions, acting President Nkomo said Government committed itself to
ensure decent accommodation for all. "Cognisant of the need to ameliorate the
living conditions of the generality of our population, central government has
redoubled its resolve and commitment to ensure provision of decent, affordable
and functional housing to the people on a sustainable basis.

"The launch of the facility and programme and several others to follow soon in
Harare, Bulawayo, Marondera, Mutare and Checheche Growth Point in Chipinge bears
testimony to the unwavering resolve," he said.

The Acting President called for Public Private Partnerships in the housing
sector as support from multi-lateral institutions had declined.

He said it was also imperative to take cognisance of resettled farmers under the
land reform programme to ensure that they also have decent shelter.

The US$25 million Housing Loan Facility, Acting President Nkomo said, was seed
capital from Government to establish a revolving National Housing Loan Facility.

He said the loans would be redeemable after 24 months to allow for quick and
early repayment of the original loan to the fiscus.

"The major objective of the facility is to improve the housing delivery process
hence reducing the national housing backlog and to achieve 100 percent national
coverage in the provision of decent and affordable accommodation in the long
run," he said.

The Mbizo 22 Housing Project is a partnership between Government and the Kwekwe
local authority. The project will also have four low cost flat sites and one
commercial stand.

National Housing and Social Amenities Minister Giles Mutsekwa said his ministry
was in the process of drafting a Land Developers Bill that seeks to regulate
operations of land developers.

This, he said, was necessitated by rampant corruption in the sector.

"This is in response to numerous cases of unscrupulous land developers who have,
and are continuing to swindle unsuspecting potential home seekers of their hard
earned cash," he said.

In terms of the proposed Land Developers Act, Minister Mutsekwa said land
developers would be required to register before they start to practice in the
sector.

The National Housing Loan Facility would go a long way in reducing the national
housing backlog that is now over one million.

                          The Anniston Star (Alabama)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              July 31, 2011 Sunday

Choccolocco welcomes growth, but not loss of serenity

BYLINE: Alison Gene Smith, The Anniston Star, Ala.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 2163 words


July 31--CHOCCOLOCCO -- Van Roberts used to know just about everyone in the
Choccolocco area. Now it's one out of 10.

"It really exploded prior to the housing bust," the volunteer fire chief said.

When Roberts joined the Quad Cities Volunteer Fire Department the year it
started in 1989, the group served about 250 homes throughout Choccolocco, Old
Davis Town, Iron City, Chosea Springs and Pleasant Ridge.

Now, he estimates, 2,500 to 2,600 homes are in its coverage area.

Nestled east of Anniston and Oxford along the banks of Choccolocco Creek, the
four-mile-wide valley that is home to Choccolocco has historically been a tiny
community of just a few hundred. It is one of the oldest communities in the
county, dating back to the 1830s. Most of the land was once held by slave-owning
farmers growing cotton. After the Civil War and emancipation, tenant farmers
worked the land for decades and the area emerged as a sleepy, agriculture-based
community.

In the 1990s, Choccolocco saw a huge boom in population. Farming all but
disappeared as agricultural land made way for new subdivisions.

When the national recession hit, many communities started to slide, with growth
in established suburban areas grinding to a halt. However, rather than move
backward, Choccolocco and surrounding communities have sustained themselves.

Heritage of a community

"We maintain a community because it has always been close-knit here," said
Georgia Calhoun, a lifelong resident of Choccolocco. "Now some communities, the
new communities, have not come in as much."

Although she said she supports prosperity and progress, Calhoun said she is a
little sad to see the familiar landscape changing.

"I have seen cotton fields and soybean fields turned into housing," she said.

Calhoun has acted as a one-woman unofficial mayor, tourism director and
historian, occasionally receiving mail for the Choccolocco "City Hall" at her
home in the heart of town and answering phone calls at all hours from people
asking for information about the area or for directions to Mount Cheaha.

As president of the Choccolocco Heritage Society, Calhoun tries to keep history
alive with bimonthly meetings. The society's next meeting is in August. The
group discusses the history of the area and works to designate new historic
places.

As new families have moved to the area, Calhoun said, she has seen less and less
interest in the history of her hometown. Although she invites new residents to
the meetings, they rarely attend.

"If you want to live in a place, you ought to want to know why it existed," she
said.

One of the draws for young families to Choccolocco is its proximity to White
Plains schools.

Calhoun said she feels like some people moved for the schools and nothing else.

"Schools, churches and homes were the community," Calhoun said of her childhood.
"I don't think the three should be isolated."

Peace of mind

For Nathe Martin, moving to a subdivision near Pine Hill Country Club in the
Choccolocco area was a "no-brainer."

The California bay-area native moved in last January and started active duty
with the 167th Theater Sustainment Command at Fort McClellan, he said. Now he
wants to put down roots.

"I basically decided it was time to buy a home," he said.

Martin chose the Anniston area out of eight possible assignments but didn't want
to live in the city proper, he said, citing a high crime rate and preferring a
more rural setting.

Once he had ruled out Anniston, Martin looked at a few other areas. He
considered the history of where storms had hit in the past and saw fewer in the
eastern part of the county. After looking at houses in White Plains, Piedmont,
Oxford and Jacksonville, he visited his future neighborhood on a whim.

His neighborhood is kid-friendly, and, Martin says, though he's not extremely
close with his neighbors, everyone is a friend.

"You can't find a comparable place," he said. "There's a certain standard of
living."

Pine Hill is less than 10 miles to work with only five stop signs on the way,
Martin said. It's a safe residential neighborhood full of families and
professionals.

"My mortgage is less than you'd pay to rent a comparable place," he said.

He even likes the sounds of the freight trains as they pass through Choccolocco.

There are some drawbacks to living farther outside the city, including the lack
of choice in shopping, with only a few stores dotting the side of the highway.

"You have to plan accordingly," he said. "You have to make an effort."

Although it takes a little more effort and a little more money, Martin said
having peace of mind about where he lives is worth it.

"It's the basis of your sanity," he said.

People in his neighborhood maintain a community, Martin said, even if it is
separate from Choccolocco.

"People here are like-minded," he said.

They put a priority on their peace of mind, and Martin likened the safe feeling
to a gated community.

"But this is all open," he said.

Martin's neighbors are tolerant of his rumbling 1967 Pontiac Tempest -- he works
on it frequently -- and he respects their sleeping hours, as many operate on
Eastern time and commute to the Atlanta area.

Martin said he would prefer to tell people he lives in White Plains, rather than
Anniston, and doesn't really associate his neighborhood with Choccolocco.

"They have the post office and a real small-town sense of community," he said.
"I like it," he said. "I'm doing everything in my power not to move."

A desirable place

Sylvia Bentley has been selling homes in the Choccolocco area for more than 20
years with ERA-King Real Estate in Anniston. Recently, she sold a house to her
son.

"My son just got married, and he just wanted to be in a good area with a good
school system, so when he starts his family, he's there," she said.

Home prices for the area are in the mid-$200,000 range, which is down from a few
years ago, Bentley said, along with prices for the whole country.

"Anyone who says otherwise isn't being honest or didn't do their homework," she
said.

While many areas have stagnated during the recession, Choccolocco still thrives,
although more slowly than before.

"It's maintaining very nicely," Bentley said, though the area isn't seeing as
much construction as just a few years ago.

"There's not anyone who hasn't felt the recession," she said.

Along with the peaceful nature of the area and a good school system, USDA loans
that allow some homebuyers to get their new houses with no money down and 100
percent financing have also helped the area, Bentley said.

Choccolocco is one of many areas in Calhoun County that are considered rural
and, therefore, people who move there can be eligible for the rural development
loans.

The loans are intended to promote opportunities for home ownership, said Ronald
Davis, state director for USDA rural development in Alabama. In recent years,
the USDA has made between 3,500 and 3,600 loans annually, he said, with about
$400 million in housing loans spread out throughout the country in 2011.

It is common throughout the state for farmland to be turned into housing, Davis
said.

Many families who once farmed are no longer interested in it and sell their land
to developers, he said.

Rural areas becoming more developed is due to more than just these loans, Davis
said. Developers' and real estate agents' interest in an area has a lot to do
with it, he said, while the USDA simply helps with financing.

The greater Anniston-Oxford area just happens to be one of those desirable
places where people like to move, Davis said, and its location halfway between
Birmingham and Atlanta and between the Appalachian Mountains and the Gulf Coast
can draw people in.

Hidden costs

Part of the draw to build in rural areas is the open space available, said
Cheryl Morgan, director of Auburn University's Urban Studio, an outreach program
of the College of Architecture, Design and Construction where students work in
an urban setting.

"What tends to happen is that the easiest place to build is what we call
greenfields," she said. "It also usually is the larger parcels because they were
farms or the remnants of larger farms passed on from generation to generation.
What happens is great-granddaddy owns 500 acres and has two sons who get 250
acres each."

Eventually these parcels get broken down into even smaller tracts and eventually
are sold. Although they are much smaller than when they started out, they are
still larger than anything available in the existing infrastructure of an
established city or town, Morgan said. Developers are able to build multiple
houses instead of one at a time. The more they build, the more money they can
potentially make.

Although these developments can seem like good ideas at first, Morgan said they
have many hidden costs. At the top of this list is transportation. In many
cases, the cost of transportation each month for families exceeds the cost of a
home mortgage.

"What you've been taught is, 'Well, I should buy that house. I'm doing the best
for my family,'" Morgan said.

The depreciating cost of a car and the price of gas need to be balanced with
having a large house, she said, not to mention the time given to a commute that
could have been spent with family, taking a class or doing any number of things.

"At what cost in time and real dollars is that bigger house 10 miles out, versus
if we could take that money, the time, all those things in that commute and put
it into a house closer in," she said.

When the bottom fell out of the housing market in 2008, Morgan said, homes that
were closer to jobs, health care and schools retained value while houses farther
away lost value faster. This shift in housing values and the parallel rise in
gasoline prices -- along with an emerging generation of people who are more
protective of their time with friends and family -- has led to a slowdown in
this kind of outward building, Morgan said.

More places are seeing the benefits of building closer to the core of a city
rather than spreading out, but new patterns are difficult to develop, she said.

"So it's not just when you look at a Choccolocco or growth around the Anniston
area. We see the same patterns in Birmingham, in Montgomery, in Mobile and
across the United States," Morgan said. "But it's a scenario that we're having
to come to grips with."

Community identity

Choccolocco still lacks a restaurant, which Georgia Calhoun admits the area
could use, but in the past several years, it has gained a grocery store, Big B
Grocery, managed by Roger Bahtt.

Bahtt lives in Choccolocco and describes the area as peaceful. Business is good,
he said, bragging that since he's not in any city's limits, customers at the
store pay only 7 percent sales tax.

It's the only store for miles, he said, and according to Bahtt it has the best
meat in the Anniston area.

Although she could do without additional subdivisions, Calhoun can see other
ways Choccolocco could grow.

"A lot of history has been kept alive," she said, "and I'd like to see it be one
of the number-one rural tourist areas."

Choccolocco boasts homes from the 1840s, a schoolhouse built in 1876 and a post
office more than 125 years old, she said.

The quiet community even managed to avoid much of the racial strife that
engulfed the South for decades, she said.

"We lived together," Calhoun said of the black and white families in the area.
"We always came to each other's rescue" -- a necessity in the rural setting,
especially before the volunteer fire department started and new roads allowed
easy access by law enforcement.

The historic Caffey Pond, which sits next to an antebellum home, was the site of
baptisms for everyone in the area.

"I can remember being baptized in the pond. We'd come on Sunday and the whites
would watch us being baptized, then we watched them," said Calhoun, who is
black. Revival meetings were also integrated, and she remembers both races
attending each other's churches.

"Right now we do our Thanksgiving services together," she said.

Calhoun hopes in moving forward some community identity can be salvaged.

"We're losing the countryside," she said. "When we lose the cotton fields and
lose the soybean fields and you look and there's houses there, yes, you're just
losing some identity."

The trademark beauty of the area is one thing she is trying to maintain.

"What we've tried is to encourage people to do flower gardens and yards," she
said.

Calhoun understands why people have moved to her quiet, picturesque community,
she'd just like them to remember why they moved there.

"I grew up here and it's such a peaceful community," she said. "The thing that
has attracted people -- the beauty and serenity -- that's what we're losing."

Star staff writer Alison Gene Smith: 256-235-3550

                             National Mortgage News

                               December 21, 1998

Housing Hegira

BYLINE: MARK FOGARTY

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1730 words


The past year has been an especially rewarding one for this editor, as I have
made it a priority to travel around this vast country of ours to look at the
varieties of housing need and the housing solutions that exist in the United
States today.

Besides the frequent flyer miles I earned, I got quite an eyeful.  Armed with a
tape recorder and a disposable camera, I traveled to urban areas, one so close
as to be almost visible from my window here in New York City, and to rural areas
so unfamiliar they seemed to be a part of another country.  I saw single-family
houses and multifamily projects, done by for-profit and non-profit developers.
I came across many heartwarming stories, and I looked at the faces of
disgraceful neglect.  And everywhere I went, I asked, are there any lenders
involved here?

What follows is a review of the things I saw and some conclusions from my
yearlong housing hegira:

* Putting Back the 'D.' At the annual National Housing and Rehabilitation
Lenders Association meeting in La Quinta, Calif., I saw a presentation by a
for-profit developer that fired my interest.  Beacon Residential's Bill Stetson
outlined a rehab on a 276-unit development called the Mandela Homes, in the
inner city neighborhood of South Boston.  The firm thought it could make money
by revamping a Great Society-era red-brick housing project, the exact dreary
type of inner city housing that now seems best rehabbed by dynamite.  And one of
the first things it did was to replace the wind-damaged 'D'in the Mandela Homes
sign on the side of the project, even though its plans were to completely redo
the facade.  This good faith gesture to the African-American residents of the
project seemed to me an augury of success, and I'll be following up on Beacon's
efforts at the next NH&RLA annual.

* Sparks.  Despite having been a housing journalist for the last 15 years, I had
never heard of the colonias, horrible rural slums along the U.S.-Mexico border,
until just recently.  So on a trip to Albuquerque I made a 600-mile detour to
visit some of these grim communities.  I went to three outside El Paso, Texas.
The colonias are fetid illegal subdivisions, where hundreds of thousands of
Hispanic-Americans, (the overwhelming majority are U.S. citizens) drawn by the
prospect of agricultural and manufacturing jobs, live in shacks and trailers in
places that can be without water, roads or sewers.  These neglected places teem
with blasted lives, high unemployment, and Third-World diseases like cholera and
bubonic plague.  Despite all this, the residents of some colonias, like the
Sparks Housing Development Corp., are embarked on the long journey of making
these slums habitable.  And the Ford Foundation and a few nationwide lenders are
providing some financing to the El Paso Cooperative, a non-profit trying to
clean up this Augean mess.

* Two Bridges.  Nestled between the Williamsburgh and Manhattan Bridges on
Manhattan island in New York City is the remarkable housing tower called Two
Bridges, developed by the Two Bridges Settlement Housing Corp.  There, a mix of
Chinese-Americans, African-Americans, European-Americans and formerly homeless
people live in what appears to be considerable harmony, in a graceful, beautiful
setting with awesome views of the Manhattan Bridge.  Although built to
workmanlike specifications, the tower seemed to me a work of human art when I
visited it with officials of the lead private lender, Dime Savings Bank.

* A Place for Courage.  A little girl named Courage lives in a brand new house
all by itself on a windy high prairie in Fort Defiance, Ariz.  Courage was about
to turn one-year old when I went out to the desert to visit her and her family
in one of the first homes mortgaged on the Navajo Nation, the country's largest
reservation.  Not far from her beautiful home, on cracked or dirt roads, people
live in hovels and decrepit houses on a vast tract of land previously off limits
to mortgage lending because of the government trust status of the land.  It took
nearly five years to get mortgage lending started on the Navajo, and it is still
in its infancy.  Officials at Norwest Mortgage went the extra mile, and then
some, to close a few loans for the most underserved housing population in the
nation.

* The Women's House.  In far-off Anchorage, Alaska, a crew of women
home-builders has been working since May on a special project, a Habitat for
Humanity house built only by women to house women and their families.  It's of
special interest to me since the project is also dedicated to a women, my late
sister, Mary Ellen Fogarty.  I traveled to Alaska twice this year, once to meet
the Todd family that will live there and to spend an afternoon watching the
women raise the first walls (and catering them lunch).  I went again last month,
to the dedication.  A work of considerable heart and spirit, this little pink
house exemplifies Habitat's self-help ethic and the get-it-done attitude that
has made it one of the country's top 20 homebuilders, despite being a nonprofit.
The project will also finance two homes built overseas, and there's a little
money in the kitty to go towards the start of another Women's House.

* Rural Renaissance.  The special emphasis the Federal Home Loan Bank of Atlanta
has placed on affordable housing led me to tour two of its projects when I
visited there for a rural development conference.  Although only fifty miles
from the big city, Cartersville, Ga., is a small town in a rural area near the
foothills of the Appalachian Mountains.  A for-profit developer, the Braden
Group, came up with an ingenious idea there.  Jerry Braden rehabbed old motel
cottages into single-occupancy units for the elderly.  The one-floor units have
few steps to be negotiated, are spacious enough to be comfortable for one
person, and were graciously-enough constructed back in the 1930s that they
retain a sturdiness and charm impossible to imagine if today's motel units get
rehabbed fifty years from now!  And the Etowah Village Apartments, built by a
non-profit, the Paces Foundation, near the site of the Etowah Mounds Indian
burial site, provide well-maintained homes for low and very low-income residents
from a mix of ethnicities.

* Turning the Tide.  The south side of Chicago, according to the old song, is
the baddest part of town.  But now, an Episcopal congregation, St. Edmund's, is
in the midst of a concerted effort to take back its formerly genteel
African-American neighborhood from the usual plague of inner city ills.  The
church, through a development corporation spearheaded by the pastor, Rev.
Richard Tolliver, has developed almost 200 units of housing in the Washington
Park neighborhood, and has plans for a similar amount in the future.  Although
there's no primary lender on their most recent project, Fannie Mae has acted in
effect as a lender by buying a tax-exempt bond issued for the purpose.

* A Steady Foundation.  Housing need in rural Lincoln County, WV, is stark.  Up
to half the children there live in substandard homes, the kind where kids fall
through the floor or porches rip right off houses.  Yet there's no bank within
25 miles of little towns like Harts and Ranger, built alongside a single highway
that threads through the hills of coal country Appalachia.  Luckily for them, a
Catholic nun assigned there started up a housing non-profit, Harts Community
Development Inc., which, bit by bit, is making a dent in the problem by building
a few houses each year and rehabbing many others.  The sturdy little houses they
are building, somewhat on the Habitat model, are helping boost pride in the
white families of Lincoln County that have been given a chance at decent
housing.

* Sweet Harvest.  Fields of sugar cane surround Franklin, La., a rural town that
had a lot of housing stock ruined when Hurricane Andrew whipped through a couple
of years ago.  Helping to put things back together is St. Mary Community Action
Agency, which has developed a townhome community and is building a single-family
tract in a nearby town.  Local lenders and foundations are making up the finance
for this community housing development organization, which is cultivating a
housing crop at least as sweet as sugar cane.

My conclusions from my visits to these diverse places?  There is a remarkable
homogeneity to the projects, despite their being scattered all over the nation
and inhabited by people of nearly as many different cultures as this country
has.

The first similarity is the potpourri of financing sources it takes to put such
deals together.  Foundation grants, government subsidies, and non-profit
involvement appear over and over again, especially Low Income Housing Tax
Credits and HOME funds from the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Are mortgage lenders involved?  Generally, the answer is yes, although they
usually are junior partners providing interim construction money or a smallish
permanent mortgage.  But without the state and federal government subsidies,
these deals would never fly.

And, there is a remarkable similarity in the people involved in nurturing these
affordable housing projects around the country.  These housing advocates, like
Gail Stilley of Harts Community Development, Inc. or Almetra Franklin of St.
Mary's CAA, make deals work through their passionate commitment long after other
people would have given up.  And no matter what their cultural backgrounds, it's
clear to me from visiting all these places that all Americans need decent
housing and respond to having it in remarkable ways.  The people I visited were
all the same, despite being European-American, African-American,
Hispanic-American, or American Indian.  Their needs and wants were the same -- a
decent place to provide a foundation for a decent life, a place for their
children to grow.

Most of all I'll remember, from this long journey of mine this year, the faces
of the children I saw and their bright energy, growing up a little better than
they would have otherwise.  Children are the least-protected people in our
society, the most exposed to poverty and misery, and they have the most to lose
by living in circumstances that will blight the contributions they could make to
our society.  Lenders who help house these children well are well entitled to
feel a little special glow this holiday season.

LOAD-DATE: January 5, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              The Washington Post

                   January 30, 1992, Thursday, Final Edition

Tables, Charts, Smoke and Mirrors -- Annual Budget Process Begins;
AGRICULTURE and INTERIOR;
Proposing a Food Stamp Reserve

Tom Kenworthy

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A21; THE FEDERAL PAGE

LENGTH: 261 words


President Bush said in his State of the Union message that the recession "will
not stand," but deep inside the Agriculture Department budget the administration
is hedging its bets with a $ 5.3 billion "benefit reserve" in the Food Stamp
program in case of "unanticipated program growth."

Overall, Agriculture Department outlays for fiscal 1993 would decrease by about
$ 2.4 billion, to $ 59.4 billion. Much of the reduction comes from a continued
shift away from direct farm, rural housing and rural electrification loans to
loan guarantee programs. Small community and rural development funding would
fall from $ 6.6 billion to $ 4.1 billion.

Spending on the Women, Infants and Children (WIC) supplemental food program
would increase from $ 2.6 billion to $ 2.8 billion.

Under Bush's plan, the Interior Department would see an overall decrease in
outlays of $ 394 million, to $ 8.8 billion. Park and wildlife programs would do
generally better while the Bureau of Reclamation would see about a 30 percent
reduction.

Spending on the "Legacy '99" program, designed to improve upkeep of parks,
wildlife refuges and other Interior Department properties, would increase by
about $ 50 million, including a $ 6.5 million expenditure for renovation of the
Kennedy Center's parking garage.

The budget would also increase spending for land acquisition, including
significant Civil War battle sites, and create an "America the Beautiful
Passport," which for $ 30 would admit people to any recreation area managed by
the Interior and Agriculture departments.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS

                                December 5, 2013

Provisions of Bonnieville Tile and Drainage Grant to protect Indiana Bat Habitat

BYLINE: Hart Countys News-Herald staff

LENGTH: 643  words


The Bonnieville City Council met Monday night and discussed updates to their
$393,000 tile and drainage grant. The grant, originally scheduled to be
completed by the end of this month, has been extended because of an ecological
review that was conducted once some of the original drainage sites were changed.
The Council will sign a Memorandum of Agreement with Fish and Wildlife who will
be undertaking a mitigation response to trees in the impacted area which are
potential habitat for Indiana Gray Bats. Staff from Fish and Wildlife will use
up to $1000 of the grant funds for remediation which could include planting
additional trees.

Three locations still require work which will likely be postponed until next
spring. Two of the sites are on Creek Road and the other is at Jefferson Park
just southwest of 31-W at Bacon Creek.

HOUSING ASSISTANCE GRANTS

Tad Long of Kentucky League of Cities told the.Council about potential grant
funds for housing assistance in Bonnieville. Long recommended that the city
apply to become a part of the Kentucky Housing Corporation and participate in
the Gap Financing Pool which offers financial assistance to income eligible
homeowners to bring homes up to code. Long explained that 'forgivable' loans
ranging from $10,000 to $40,000 are available but only for homeowners meeting
income restrictions and willing to sign a deed restriction agreeing that the
home will be their principal residence for at least the next ten years.

The Council voted to authorize Long to prepare the application for the city to
join the Kentucky Housing Corporation and to participate in the Gap Financing
Pool. Long stipulated that KLC would not be charging for preparing and
submitting the application. He suggested that once Bonnieville is enrolled and
participating in the Gap Financing Program that KLC could help administer the
program in Bonnieville for the first six months so that "the program gets up and
running on solid footing and so that citizens who need help can receive that at
minimal cost," Long said.

Long also said, "If you look at your Strategic Plan, now you're down to the
things that are difficult and long range-creating jobs and housing development."

Long said he would have something to present to the council at their January
meeting.

WATER ISSUES

Barry Back from Kenvirons Consultants spoke to council members about the
Bonnieville Water System. Back has worked in Bonnieville as part of a Division
of Water and Rural Community Assistance capacity building grant to assist with
mapping water lines and leak detection.

Back said that water leakage for the Bonnieville system was down to 17% with 15%
being the industry accepted level. "For a 250 customer system, that's about four
to five gallons of water per minute or minimal loss." Back stated.

Council member Sherman Bowman announced that he and Mayor Denis Edwards will be
attending the Water Council meeting at the BRADD office this week. Water and
sewer projects requiring funding will be regionally ranked at that meeting.

Mayor Edwards explained that Bonnieville had two priority projects. "Extending
sewer lines to our annexed areas is our number one priority," Edwards said. The
city also wants to put in new water lines to eliminate the need for the existing
cement-asbestos water lines.

Vaughn Williams, president of Kenvirons, addressed the council about natural
gas. "Atmos is not ready to extend gas lines to Bonnieville at this time,"
Williams said. He explained that industry and business is usually the driver for
gas line extensions rather than residential customers.

CITIZENS' REQUESTS

Melissa Stinson requested a copy of the current financial report. When Stinson
asked if Bonnieville accounts were ever audited, she was told the city received
a biennial audit. The most recent audit was presented in January of 2008 by
Gilbert and Gilbert for 2006-2007.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                              March 3, 2006 Friday

Just needs a little curb appeal

BYLINE: AARON SHAROCKMAN

SECTION: NORTH PINELLAS TIMES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 596 words

DATELINE: CLEARWATER


In front of a rusted-out warehouse, on trampled reeds and soggy soil, Clearwater
officials this week promised something better for this neglected place.

The dirt beneath the old Clearwater Automotive junkyard, along south Martin
Luther King Avenue east of downtown, is contaminated with petroleum and metals,
the result of the industrial work performed there for years.

But the polluted dirt will be dug up, and the corroded buildings will be
removed. And city officials hope that the 3.5 acres will bustle with families in
new homes.

At least that's the dream for what was once a salvage yard, that also had been a
dry cleaners and even a metal foundry.

Soon, the land will be the site of an affordable housing development.

Demolition crews Wednesday opened a 20-foot-wide hole in the old warehouse with
just six strokes from a back hoe Wednesday, marking the first visible step in
the city's transformation of the former junkyard.

"We're changing the fabric of downtown," said Mayor Frank Hibbard at a morning
demolition party attended by more than 50 city, state and federal officials.
"This is a marvelous day. A day we turn the corner on another property."

It's not yet known how many homes will be built on the property, almost a full
city block between Martin Luther King and Washington avenues and Gould and
Pierce streets. Nor is it certain how many homes will be classified as
affordable housing or if the final product will include commercial or retail
space.

City officials acquired the land in 2003 and, in partnership with state and
federal officials, received a $350,000 loan to rehabilitate the site. That work
should be complete in a year.

Then city officials plan to approach developers for ideas to redevelop the
property. It's the hallmark of the state's brownfields program, the success of
which already has been seen throughout Clearwater:

Abandoned gas stations became the Willa Carson Health Resource Center in North
Greenwood. Junkyard banks on Stevenson Creek were turned into the city's
Northwest Fire Station. The site of an old automotive dealership on Fort
Harrison Avenue became a Publix supermarket.

So far, 75 restorations have been completed in the city's 1,100-acre designated
brownfields area. All the sites aren't polluted, but the designation helps
secure state and federal loans and grants for redevelopment.

"It's making something out of nothing. Or something out of the little bit that
you have," said John Sego, brownfields coordinator for the southwest district of
the Florida Department of Environmental Protection.

Clearwater took ownership of the Clearwater Automotive site as part of a land
swap with the developers building the Clearwater Mall. Then, the Downtown
Development Board, which levies a small tax on downtown property owners, loaned
the city $48,000 to purchase a smaller piece of property adjacent to the
junkyard.

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has loaned the city $350,000 to conduct
the cleanup. Both debts are to be paid off when the city sells the rehabilitated
land to a developer, said Geri Campos, Clearwater economic development director.

The site should be cleared within four weeks, and the remediation of the land
could be concluded within a year.

Meanwhile, residential projects are being developed to the north, south and
west.

"When you drive by this site in the very near future, you won't be seeing rusty
buildings and hubcaps," said Miles Ballogg, a consultant with TBE Group and a
former Clearwater brownfields economic development manager. "You'll be seeing
affordable housing. And that's very rewarding."

LOAD-DATE: March 3, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

City, state and federal officials hold a demolition party Wednesday at the
Clearwater Automotive junkyard on south Martin Luther King Avenue.

Just needs a little curb appeal

                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                          September 30, 2004 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Panel keeps waterworks plan afloat;
Railroad balks at crossing construction; coming winter concerns city

BYLINE: ABIGAIL CURTIS OF THE NEWS STAFF

SECTION: Pg. B3

LENGTH: 438 words

DATELINE: BANGOR


Even though the Shaw House's proposed 35-unit affordable housing complex, to be
located at the Bangor Waterworks site, has been temporarily derailed by Maine
Central Railroad, the Bangor City Council is planning to stick with the proposal
for another year.

The Council's Business and Economic Development Committee members voted
unanimously to back the $6 million plan at Wednesday night's workshop held at
the City Council chambers.

Holding up the project is the railroad company's refusal to allow construction
of a railroad crossing.

"The only way onto the site is to cross the railroad tracks," Shaw House
Executive Director Douglas Bouchard said Wednesday. "[The Department of
Transportation] gave us the right to do that, but the railroad sued DOT."

The matter will be considered by the Maine Supreme Judicial Court on Oct. 19.

"The Shaw House hasn't blinked," Bouchard said. "We're here and stable."

He said that the state, city of Bangor, and federal loan money are all staying
with the project - for now.

One concern mentioned is whether the dilapidated Waterworks structure can last
another winter season.

"We are hoping to simply support the structure while this legal farce plays
out," Bouchard said.

Councilors wondered if Guilford Industries, which owns the railroad, has taken
issue with the fact that the proposed housing complex is for low-income
residents.

Bouchard said that three similar railroad crossings have been approved with no
problems by Guilford Industries within the last 10 years or so. To his
knowledge, the Shaw House proposal is the only one to be challenged in the
courts.

No representative of the railroad was present at the meeting. An attempt to
contact the railroad Wednesday evening was unsuccessful.

In other business, councilors heard from Realty Resources, a development group
that has proposed an affordable housing development near Essex Street on
property owned by Bangor International Airport.

The councilors discussed parking and traffic problems potentially generated by
the complex, tax revenue the property would generate, the project's funding, and
investment loans the city may make to the endeavor so that it may be built.

"This plan as prepared would probably meet our requirements for a high-density
development," City Manager Ed Barrett said. "The next best step is to meet as a
group to come up with an alternative plan that addresses density and traffic
issues."

The project is located in an area now zoned for low-density development, Barrett
said.

The project, with an estimated tax valuation of $1,500,000, would generate
$34,000 in property tax its first year under current tax rates.

                               The Times (London)

                             January 9, 2015 Friday
                                   Edition 2;
                                National Edition

Tens of thousands of homes in brownfield building boom

BYLINE: Jill Sherman

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 583 words


Tens of thousands of new homes are to be fast-tracked across the country, the
government has announced.

A shortlist of 29 new housing zones - including several in the north and
Midlands - has been published, with proposals of up to 2,000 homes per scheme
although larger sites are being considered. Twenty large-scale zones have
already been proposed in London by Boris Johnson.

The first ten housing zones outside the capital will be chosen in the coming
weeks. Brandon Lewis, the housing minister, said they would share a £200 million
pot to help with infrastructure. All the schemes - a mix of social and market
housing - will be on brownfield sites. Some will be on public land released by
the closure of hospitals, schools and military sites.

Councils will ensure that planning permission is fast-tracked so that developers
can start clearing sites.

The builders will be entitled to loans from the fund to clean up the land and
start setting up infrastructure such as roads and utility lines. In some cases
developers may also get funds to build schools and community services.

However, many of the schemes are bound to attract opposition from local
residents who do not want housing estates on their doorsteps. Plans for
largescale eco-towns were heavily resisted under the last Labour government.

George Osborne said that a key part of the government's economic plan was to
build more homes. Housing experts claim that at least 250,000 extra homes are
needed each year to cope with demographic growth. In recent years less than half
that number has been built.

"I'm delighted to announce the areas shortlisted to become the first housing
zones in England, which as part of a wider package of measures will help deliver
up to 200,000 new homes on brownfield land," said the chancellor.

Officials said that most of the housing zones would be between 750 and 2,000
homes, but larger schemes are not ruled out. Mr Lewis said: "The ten that are
finally chosen will have the chance to build homes for local communities while
continuing to protect the green belt."

Mr Osborne said last year that there was enough brownfield land for 200,000 new
homes by 2020. He has already announced proposals to ensure that 90 per cent of
this land has planning permission. Councils will be able to use local
development orders to set out the amount and type of housing that can be built
on the sites.

The Campaign to Protect Rural England welcomed the scheme but said that land was
continually being removed from green belt in local plans so that it could be
built upon at a later date. "Worthy brownfield projects should not hide the fact
that the green belt is still under threat in many areas," said Paul Miner, its
campaign manager.

The shortlisted councils are: Thurrock, Hertsmere, Guildford, Babergh and
Mid-Suffolk, West Lindsey, Dudley, Sandwell, Stoke, Derby, Gedling, Bassetlaw,
Wakefield, North East Lincolnshire, York, Barnsley, Gateshead, Sheffield,
Preston, Blackburn with Darwen, Wirral, Bristol, East Hampshire, North Somerset,
Tewkesbury, Sedgemoor, Poole, Bath and North Somerset, and Gloucester.

? The end of 2014 saw the slowest pace of house price growth in a year. The
average price of a home crept up by 7.8 per cent in the 12 months to December to
£188,858, according to the Halifax, whose index is based on its mortgage book.
House price growth peaked at 10.2 per cent in July and December's pace of annual
expansion was the slowest since last January. On a monthly basis it was 0.9 per
cent higher.
