                              The Herald (Harare)

                             June 23, 2011 Thursday

Residents Soak in Tears of Despair

BYLINE: Fortious Nhambura

LENGTH: 1121  words


Entering Chitungwiza along Chitungwiza Road, one is greeted by a stench from
sewage overflowing in parts of Manyame Park.

The stench worsens as you get to Chigovanyika Shopping Centre. Near the shopping
centre, another phenomenon starts.

Motorists are forced to swerve to avoid potholes that have now been nicknamed
"drumholes" because they have grown very big.

Drivers have to thank the heavens that we are in the dry season and they can
avoid the potholes with less difficulty.

Women carrying 20-litre buckets line the streets ferrying water for domestic use
as the area is always without water.

Every street corner has become a dumping site as the municipality seems to have
forgotten it last collected refuse.

It's a sorry sight for residents who have to endure seeing disused diapers,
sanitary pads, rotting food leftovers and rumble cleared from construction
sites.

The problems have persisted in Chitungwiza unabated that it has now become
synonymous with the municipality.

As such, over the years residents have been forced to endure this pungent smell,
erratic water supply and uncollected garbage on a daily basis while complains to
the town authorities have fallen on deaf ears.

Even protests over poor service delivery have failed to yield positive results.

Adamantly, the council has entered into deals that do not benefit ratepayers but
meant to enrich the few in managerial positions.

Recently, the municipality issued loans to senior management amounting to US$45
000 at the expense of the residents' demands for improved services.

Beneficiaries of the loans include town clerk Mr Godfrey Tanyanyiwa, chamber
secretary Omega Mugumbate, director of engineering Engineer Alfonse Tinofa,
director housing Jemina Gumbo and acting finance director Mr Titus Mudzidzi.

Residents say, the municipality well known for parceling residential and
commercial land for peanuts to councillors and management, is taking them for a
ride should be reminded of their duty - provide service to the people.

Chairperson of Chitungwiza Residents Association Mr Wilson Makomba said it was
unfortunate that council was opting to give top management loans when the
workers are still owed millions of dollars in unpaid wages.

He said it was cruel that the management was giving itself massive perks while
the service delivery system is in shambles.

"As an association we have sought audience with the council since 2008 over the
establishment of infill stands and they have not come back to us.

"We feel the council is taking us for ride and needs to be reminded their
mandate. Money collected from rates should be used to improve service delivery
in the municipality and not to enrich a few individuals in managerial positions.

"What do they need that money for when recently they acquired luxury cars. Why
is it important they get money as loans when the council is struggling to secure
enough water from Harare and improving the road network?

"Is this not ironic that the city fathers can advance themselves loans when they
can not raise money to pay for the release of council property attached for
failing to service loans," he said.

Mrs Tariro Shirichena of St Marys said it is such misdirected policies that show
that the town council does not value the wishes of residents and its workers.

They also felt the town council was failing to do justice to the rates it was
charging residents and they would be forced to consider boycotting paying
service fees until a time the town start delivering a service.

"We are tired of this management that has seen the council reduce the town to a
shadow of its former self.

"Roads are littered with potholes, running water is erratic while collection of
garbage has never been consistent but the management wants to be given perks for
such a shoddy job.

"Our councillors have neglected us as they have joined the gravy train. As such
we cannot expect them to whip management into line as they have swallowed the
hook, line and sinker. They are using their time in council to enrich
themselves.

"We therefore are appealing to the Ministry of Local Government, Rural and Urban
Development to exert pressure on the management and ensure that it prioritises
service delivery," she said.

Raw sewage led to multiple diarrhoea outbreaks including the 2008-9 cholera
outbreak that claimed thousands in the town.

The council that is also notorious with corruption has seen a number of mayors
being fired for illegal land deals and abuse of council property.

Councillors and management voted to allow infills in the town suburbs leading to
areas meant as breathing spaces and for recreation being turn into residential
areas.

Another resident of Seke Unit L Ms Salome Matiza said council was on a looting
spree.

"We are aware that the two main political parties are battling for Chitungwiza
and efforts to seek redress have been misconstrued as political.

"Minister of Local Government, Rural and Urban Development, Dr Ignatius Chombo
should move in to restore order," Mrs Matiza said.

She said plans to rebuild lost image that saw top management going to a retreat
in Kariba were meaningless.

Despite the luxuries being provided for the council officials, authority is
battling to pay its workers with salary areas running into millions of dollars.

A beneficiary of the Nyatsime Housing Scheme, that has gone for over three
without meaningful development, said Chitungwiza was eager to make money and not
improve on service delivery.

"I feel the project was a money-spinning venture meant to raise money to pay
workers during the harsh economic era.

"When we acquired these stands we were told that we would commence construction
by end of 2008 but until now positions continue to change like weather.

The municipality has since asked us to top up the payments in US dollars -
because the money was eroded by inflation - when we know that the money was used
to settle council debts and pay worker during that period.

"Other phases in projects have been introduced, with people paying in US dollars
but still there is nothing going on.

"This clearly shows that the council is not taking residents seriously and needs
to be reminded of its duty."

Experts in land development said it would be very difficult for the town to
address service delivery as it has let the situation to slide back this much.

"With such a work ethic where do Chitungwiza Town Council think they will get
serious investors to partner it in development of residential stands.

"It is risk for any financier when he is aware that the finance administration
system municipality's leaks like a sieve."

He said the financially hamstrung institution needed to clean itself of this
face of corruption and starts owning up to its promises before they can think of
courting investors.

                       Sparta News-Plaindealer (Illinois)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            April 16, 2008 Wednesday

Sparta awards water plant bid

BYLINE: Sparta News-Plaindealer, Sparta, Ill.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 787 words


Apr. 16--The Sparta City Council Monday awarded bids for construction of a new
city water plant and the demolition of buildings on North Market.

The council approved the bid of $8,954,000 from Plocher Construction Co. for a
new city water plant, pending approval from the Rural Development Authority.
Rural Development is providing a loan for the project.

Mayor Rob Link also said the city needs a minimum of $500,000 trimmed from the
project, which was over the engineer's estimate of $6.6 million.

City officials have been meeting with Scott Plocher of Plocher Construction and
Brian Buchheit, engineer from Henry, Meisenheimer & Gende, since the bids were
opened Feb. 13.

Link suggested removing from the bid the demolition of the old water plant,
estimated at $100,000. He also suggested trimming another $90,000 for asphalt
and chipping to the entrance and parking area for the plant.

He asked about $48,000 for site work.

Buchheit said the contractor was raising the elevation of the plant 3 feet to
level the site.

Plocher said the work would cause a steeper slope from the road, but the
entrance would be at ground elevation.

Link said the project would include a generator for stand-by electricity.

He said the city had applied for a $900,0000 grant to try to meet the financing
shortfall for the project.

He said the city also hoped to have increases in water usage to generate
revenues. They also hoped current market conditions would allow creative
financing for funding the project.

Buchheit said if the bond issue proceeds on schedule, construction could start
in June or July.

The council also accepted the low bid of $59,000 from Carl Bannister Excavating
for demolition of the DeLyn, Benson's and Andrew's Furniture buildings on the
100 block of South Market.

City Councilman Gary Stephens asked about asbestos abatement.

At the time the bids were prepared, the inspector felt asbestos abatement would
be minimal.

Code Enforcement Officer Rob Soderlund said the inspector has prepared new
figures based on pipe wrap in the Benson's building, joint compounds in Andrew's
and other asbestos.

The asbestos abatement could be $500 to $1,500 at the DeLyn's building, $8,000
to $15,000 at the Benson building and $15,000 to $25,000 at the Andrew's
Furniture building.

The demolition bids do not cover those asbestos abatement figures.

Link asked Soderlund to arrange a meeting with the inspector to go over the
abatement needs.

He said the city should take possession of the Benson building by May 1. The
owners had requested a June 1 turnover to remove some wood floors, copper pipe
and other materials.

Link said the demolition bids were based on the contractor's ability to market
some of those items.

City Attorney Alan Farris said the city was in position to take over the
Andrew's building. It was up to the current owners to obtain a court order to
stop proceedings.

Link asked for utilities on the buildings to be disconnected May 1-3, with
demolition to start May 5.

The demolition costs will be covered by TIF funds.

City Councilwoman Linda Boston said the citywide clean-up for Sparta residents
will be held from 6 a.m.-noon on Saturday, May 17. Items will be brought to the
CWI transfer station in Eden. Anyone bringing items must show proof of
residency.

Volunteers are needed. Senior citizens and persons with disabilities can arrange
for pick-ups by calling city hall.

She said the clean-up committee will be meeting May 13 to finalize plans.

City Councilman Gary Stephens said Citizens Bank has taken over the Briarwood
Inn.

Stephens said bank officials said the motel would continue to operate. He said
it was expected to be full over the next ten days. Stephens also said bank
officials assured the city the hotel-motel tax will be paid on time.

City Attorney Alan Farris reported he has filed for a dismissal of a lawsuit
filed by S & L Concrete Resurfacing LLC for payment on work at the Sparta
Municipal Pool. S & L sued the city and Haier Plumbing & Heating, the general
contractor on the project.

Due to problems with the concrete resurfacing of the pool, it opened late last
year.

Farris said the lien filed by S & L was after the deadline.

Link said he would be meeting with parents of swim team members Wednesday to
discuss fees associated with the YMCA operation of the pool.

                            Blackmore Vale Magazine

                              May 23, 2014 Friday

New moves to address the shortage of affordable housing in the countryside

SECTION: FEATURES:PROPERTY; Pg. 126

LENGTH: 303  words


Historically, the rural estate or farm was a provider of affordable housing for
many, if not all, of its employees.

However, while many farms and estates today employ fewer people there is a real
need for affordable homes in the countryside.

Savills director Simon Peck advocates that landowners should be allowed to
establish themselves as a registered provider of affordable housing.

This allows them to set up small developments on land they own and keep the
affordable housing, rather than selling it on to a traditional housing
association.

That way they retain some control of the development including site management.

An example of this could be an estate that has entered into a contract on one
piece of land for a private development for sale, while using another piece of
land to meet the Section 106 commitment.

The estate could then  be registered as a For Profit Registered Provider and
would retain ownership and management of the rented properties through the
provider.

The rental income would cover the loan costs as well as the management and
maintenance, and could provide additional asset cover for future borrowing and
investment, years down the line.

Social housing, however, is not a straightforward investment.

There are plenty of regulatory requirements and certain behavioural
expectations, but for those ready to take it on, particularly those who already
manage private rented housing stock, it can offer an attractive investment,
albeit a long-term one.

In the past Savills has called for landowners to be incentivised via taxation,
specifically, suggesting that the provision of affordable housing, designated
for 60 years, could be given the advantages of Business Property Relief for
Inheritance Tax and Capital Gains Tax.

This theme is featured in the Savills spring 2014 issue of Aspects of Land.

                      Penrith Press (Tuesday) (Australia)

                           February 17, 2009 Tuesday
                                 1 - MB Edition

Estate no `death trap' Developer hits at safety claims

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 329  words


Developer hits at safety claims

DEVELOPERS have hit back at conservationists' claims that homes to be built in
bushland at St Marys would become a ``death trap'' similar to those devastated
by the Victorian bushfires.

Residents Action Group convenor Geoff Brown has accused developer Delfin Lend
Lease of ``putting lives at risk'' by going ahead with plans to build 1000 homes
in a bush-ringed section of the site known as the central precinct.

``It's an absolute fire trap with one road in and one road out,'' Mr Brown said.
``If the regional park catches alight, there's nowhere to go.''

The residents' group, which has long-opposed plans to clear portions of
the1500ha site for residential development, said it would be ``criminal'' if NSW
planning minister Kristina Keneally allowed the development to proceed.

Mr Brown called on Ms Keneally to urgently re-assess the plans and rule out
access to the housing estate through bushland.

Delfin Lend Lease's Arthur Illias rejected Mr Brown's claims and criticised his
attempt to link the housing development to the bushfire tragedy.

``It's appalling that (they are) using the tragic events of this week to promote
their opposition to the project,'' Mr Illias said.

Mr Illias said in addition to an existing east-west access road running through
the site, a planned bus and pedestrian road could also be used by residents
during an emergency.

Mr Illias said the Rural Fire Service was ``comfortable'' with the developer's
bushfire assessment, which included building standards and a 30m bush clearance
protection zone.

But Mr Brown said the clearance zone would do nothing to protect homes from fire
and ember attack.

A spokesman for Ms Keneally said the department was currently assessing land use
within the site.

Responsibility for approving development at the site fell to Penrith Council,
the spokesman said.

Assessment of any development proposals would need to consider the State
Government's bushfire protection guidelines, he said.

                             650 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                Vanguard (Lagos)

                               February 04, 2014

Lagos Developer Partners TUC to Build 100,000-Unit Workers' Estates

BYLINE: Jude Njoku

LENGTH: 575 words


ROCK of Ages Properties Limited, a subsidiary of Chicason Group, in
collaboration with Trade Union Congress, (the umbrella body for senior public
and private sector workers in the country), will on Thursday in Abuja, flag off
the construction of 20,000 housing units under the United Workers Housing
Scheme. The scheme is targeted at building 100,000 units of affordable housing
in all the 36 states and Abuja.

The flag-off ceremony which is expected to be graced by FCT Minister, Senator
Bala Mohammed and his Labour counterpart, Chief Emeka Nwogu, will hold at Women
Development Centre in the FCT.

Disclosing these facts to newsmen last weekend, the Executive Director of
Chicason Group, Mr Chux Adike explained that the public private partnership, PPP
scheme would provide affordable housing across the country for the benefit of
senior public and private sectors. Adike explained that the two sites selected
to flag off the scheme in Abuja are located along Airport Road, very close to
AMAC estate in Lugbe and Deidei.

The Airport Road site measuring over 600 hectares is about seven minutes drive
to the city gate while the over 300 hectares site at Deidei is about 12 minutes
drive to Maitama. Adike described the estates as a kind of social housing
schemes because the government is providing the land at very subsidised rates
while long-term mortgage loans would be given to the subscribers.

"The interesting thing about the project is that apart from us as the private
developers and the Trade Union Congress which is the umbrella body for senior
staff in both public and private sectors, other agencies in both public and
private sectors like the Federal Mortgage Bank of Nigeria, FMBN, the Nigeria
Mortgage Refinancing Company and the Primary Mortgage firms are queuing into the
project.

The dynamics of the project is that the house types range from two-bedroom
semi-detached bungalows to two-bedroom apartment block, three bedroom detached
bungalows, three bedroom semi-detached bungalows, three bedroom apartment block,
three bedroom terrace houses, four bedroom terrace apartment and four-bedroom
semi-detached houses. The buildings will be tastefully finished. " he said.

Prominent facilities to be provided in the gated estates include centralised
water supply system, tarred roads, walkways and drainage channels, ample parking
spaces, street lights, schools, recreation facilities, power supply and markets.

On what the subscribers stand to gain from the scheme, Mr Adike said the land
has been subsidised by the government hence the value of each house is less than
what obtains in the property market today. "For a contributor to the National
Housing Fund, NFH and who also has a retirement savings account, that is, he is
a pensions fund contributor, all he need to do is to pick up our application
form for N10,000, fulfil the application formalities and we do our verifications
and give him a provisional offer which would require him to pay just between 10
and 20 percent of the cost of the house depending on the house type.

If the cost of the house is 18 million Naira, because land has been subsidised,
the price may come down to N9 million. He (subscriber) will pay 10 percent, that
is 900,000 Naira which is less than the annual rent he pays in a good satellite
town, not even in the city as annual rent, to own an apartment for life. On
subscription, we group them into batches and the mortgage banks will now package
the mortgages.

                             651 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                            Berwickshire Advertiser

                                 July 14, 2005

Housing boost for first time buyers

LENGTH: 523 words


A JOINT project between Berwickshire Housing Association and Communities
Scotland is making four new houses available to first time buyers who would
otherwise be unable to compete in the housing market.

The 2/3 bedroom houses at Erskine Road South, Chirnside, will be available to
local people for sale at cost and the potential buyers will be able to apply for
Rural Home Ownership Grants from Communities Scotland to help them purchase the
properties.

Berwickshire Housing Association's chief executive, Philip Jones said: 'We are
delighted to be working with Communities Scotland to give local people a better
chance to make their first step onto the property ladder in Berwickshire. We
hope that this pilot project with Communities Scotland will help make home
ownership more affordable for people in the area.'

The Rural Home Ownership Grant is calculated by Communities Scotland according
to individual circumstances and is generally around a third of the total house
price (in this case £91,450 for the two bedroom houses and £96,725 for the three
bedroom houses) grants of between £10,000 to £20,000 being typical.

Those who are eligible to apply for the houses and associated grants include
people living locally and in employment. Pensioners and those unfit to work
through ill health may also qualify for a grant to help them buy one of the
houses if they can prove they have lived in the area for at least a year and
have family or local connections. Applicants need to prove they could not afford
to buy a starter home without such a grant but that they can afford to get a
mortgage to cover the remaining cost of the house after the level of grant has
been decided.

The Berwickshire Housing Association houses included in this pilot project will
be ready for spring 2006 giving potential buyers time to apply for the grant.
They have electric and passive solar heating, super-insulation incorporating
breathing wall technology, on-site parking and gardens.

Communities Scotland's director of investment, Caroline Oatway, said: "The
Scottish Executive wants Scotland to be a place where everyone can create a
successful, sustainable and healthy life for themselves, their family and their
community. In support of this aim, Communities Scotland has made approximately
£123,000 available to families from the Chirnside area to enable them to meet
their housing needs or aspirations within their own community.'

The average cost of buying a house in the Borders rose by 20% to £139,000 and
with the average income being around £18,000 many people are excluded from the
property market and have to relocate out of the area to find better paid jobs
and more affordable housing. Schemes like this one at Chirnside are trying to
redress that balance.

More details about Rural Ownership Grants can be obtained by contacing Gordon
Liddle at Communities Scotland (telephone 0131 479 8819 or email
gordon.liddle@communitiesscotland.gsi.gov.uk).

For a property schedule of the Erskine Rod houses contact Berwickshire Housing
Association on 01361 or visit their website at www.b-h-a.org.uk

                             653 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                             National Mortgage News

                                October 6, 1997

Frank David's Rosebush

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 554 words


This week the Mortgage Bankers Association of America meets here in New York for
its annual convention, the biggest industry meeting of the year.  Besides the
many informational sessions and the social activities at the conference, the MBA
annual presents a good opportunity to think about what the industry is all
about.

We recently had the chance to tour some of the public housing constructed and
managed by a housing authority in rural Montana.  And what we came away with was
the image of a rosebush.

We met Frank David, and his wife, Jackie.  Frank and Jackie live in one of the
units managed by the housing authority.  To those of you who think public
housing is inner-city ghetto towers splashed with graffiti, a rural public
community can be a real eye-opener.

The units are low to the ground and nicely maintained.  The grounds are free of
liter, and there's no feeling that gunfire might break out at any moment.

We couldn't spend much time with the Davids, but Frank made it a point to bring
out and show us a rosebush he's germinating.

Frank is the on-site manager of the development as well as a tenant, and he's
growing the rosebush to plant in the common area of the units to make it look
nicer.  And that says something to us.

It says a lot about how Frank feels about the place where he lives.  It says
Frank feels at home and cares about the place where he lives.  It says he
respects the people who live around him.  You don't try to beautify a place that
has no meaning for you.  Frank's action says that as well as a rosebush, there's
a little hope growing in Frank's backyard.

We don't know much about the Davids, or the child that looked down at us from
the second story window.  We know they live in a place that has a chance to be a
good place to live.  We know that from his back porch Frank has a view of the
Mission Range of the Rocky Mountains that a Donald Trump might envy.  We know
that Frank might be a rich man, and Mr. Trump a poor one.

Private mortgage firms traditionally haven't had much to do with public housing,
which has been mainly rental, but that is going to change.  There will be
opportunities in the future for mortgage bankers to partner with public
entities, both urban and rural, as this kind of housing begins to privatize.

The Montana HA that runs Frank's unit, for instance, has gotten finance from a
local bank for student housing at the local college.  Rehab loans,
redevelopment, mortgages on individual units -- there will be opportunities to
make some money here, and perhaps to do a little good at the same time.

But even beyond the realm of affordable housing, Frank's rosebush is a potent
symbol for what this industry can, and ought to achieve.

That's hope, both personally and for society at large.  You don't put down roots
where there's no chance they'll take hold.  And the space between houses is
where a society conducts its business.

That space ought to be a safe place, where people can respect each other and
maybe a rose might bloom someday.

This industry can put people into the kinds of homes where they want the common
areas between them to be safe and beautiful places.  If that's what you do at
your shop, congratulations.  You can feel proud and happy as you gather in New
York for the most important meeting of the year.

                             654 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                The Toronto Star

                           December 16, 2006 Saturday

CMHC recalls housing advances over 60 years

BYLINE: Theresa Boyle, Toronto Star

SECTION: NEW IN HOMES; Pg. N08

LENGTH: 592 words


Sixty years ago, 44 per cent of Canadian homes did not have an indoor flush
toilet.

Some 55 per cent did not have an installed bath or shower, and 27 per cent were
in need of major repairs.

In the six decades since, the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation was formed
to lead the nation's housing programs, the living conditions of Canadians have
come a long way.

Today, "cloze to zero" Canadian homes are without toilets and without baths or
showers. And only 8 per cent are in need of major repairs.

The findings are included in the Canadian Housing Observer, 2006, an annual
overview of the housing industry, released this week by the CMHC. Since this
year is the national housing agency's 60th anniversary, this edition of the
Observer includes a special feature on "60 years of housing progress in Canada."

"Significant progress has been made in improving housing conditions for
Canadians over this period. While we are among the best-housed people in the
world, there is still work to be done to ensure that all Canadians have a safe,
affordable place to call home," says CMHC president Karen Kinsley.

The report revealed that there are 12.5 million households in Canada today, up
from just under 3 million in the early 1940s.

Some 80 per cent of Canadians now live in urban centres, making Canada one of
the most urbanized countries in the world. In comparison, Canada's urban and
rural populations were almost equal at the time of the Second World War.

The increase in urban living has a direct impact on health, the report notes.

"People living in neighbourhoods that have community, employment and retail
amenities within walking distance of their homes are 2.4 times more likely to
meet their 30-minute daily exercise requirement (recommended by the Heart and
Stroke Foundation)," it reads.

The Observer also found that:

39 per cent of homes did not have piped running water in 1941 compared to close
to zero today.

61 per cent of homes were heated by stove or space heater, compared to close to
zero today.

Down payments of 60 per cent were typically required to buy a home compared to 5
per cent today.

Homes are a lot less crowded today, the report states. In 1941, there were an
average of 4.5 persons per dwelling compared to 2.6 today.

Meantime, houses are twice as big, resulting in three times as much space per
person.

While most homes had 30 to 50 amps of electrical capacity back in the 1940s,
they typically have 200 today.

The report also cited many advances in building technology. Where basement
frames, kitchen cabinets and windows used to be built on site, they are now
prefabricated. Pipes that used to be made of cast iron are now made of PVC.
Where concrete used to be mixed on site, it now comes ready mixed. Interior
walls that used to be made of lath and plaster are now made with drywall.

"The backhoe, reassembled formwork and ready-mixed concrete reduced the person
hours for basement work by 65 per cent, and cement that could be used in colder
weather extended the building season into the winter," reads the 110-page
report.

Building homes is physically less taxing than it used to be, according to the
Observer.

For example, in the early 1940s, all heavy lifting was done "on the back,"
whereas today builders use forklifts and cranes.

"Considerable relief in the backbreaking tasks of homebuilding has come from
better tools of the trade.

Power hammers, forklifts, cranes and other advances when coupled with more
stringent safety and training requirements, have had their impact on costs and
construction site injuries," it states.

LOAD-DATE: December 16, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:  Rick Madonik toronto star file photo Housing findings are included in
the Canadian Housing Observer, 2006. The report reveals hat there are 12.5
million households in Canada today, up from just under 3 million in the early
1940s.

BRIEF: Toledo City Council agrees to allow Fiberglas owners to apply for loan

BYLINE: The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 251 words


June 29--Toledo City Council voted Tuesday afternoon to allow the company that
owns the former Fiberglas Tower downtown to apply for a $10 million federal loan
to pursue plans to renovate the building into a mix of apartments, a hotel, and
a restaurant.

Council voted 10-0 to allow the Eyde Co. of Lansing to apply for the 20-year,
Section 108 loan from the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
It also voted 10-0 to alter the project's one-year action plan with HUD, a
necessary step in the loan process.

Councilmen Steven Steel and George Sarantou were not present.

Eyde must apply for the $10 million before a July 6 deadline.

The company is also seeking $2 million from a Brownfield Economic Development
Initiative grant, which can be used to make the interest-only payments on the
Section 108 loan during the first seven years.

Nick Eyde, whose family owns the firm, said the two financing pieces are key,
and would allow the building "to stabilize for seven years" because with the
grant, they would not have to make payments on the loan during that time.

                                 First Edition

Volunteers help 'barnraise' affordable housing project

BYLINE: Record staff

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 246 words


There was a lot of hammering Friday as 20 Mennonite volunteers held a
"barn-raising" to build the second floor of an affordable housing project.

The volunteers were experienced framers and members of the Old Colony Mennonite
Church, a sect of low-German-speaking Mennonites who came to Ontario from Latin
America, said Martin Buhr, president of MennoHomes Inc., which is building the
housing complex.

This story begins in Waterloo where a fourplex residence was donated to
MennoHomes, a Kitchener-based non-profit organization geared to providing
affordable housing.

Owners of the fourplex chose to donate the building rather than create rubble
for the landfill, Buhr said.

The building was taken apart in sections, and two storeys were taken to Elmira
where the group is reconstructing a two-storey duplex on top of a new
foundation.

Another storey was transported to David Street in the Village of Wellesley
where, on Friday, a second storey was built to create two four-bedroom units.
Occupation is slated for July.

The project will provide affordable housing for low-German-speaking Mennonites,
a group that tends to have large families and often lives in substandard housing
in rural areas, Buhr said.

The Region of Waterloo is contributing $240,000 to cover the purchase of the
land and site preparation, Buhr said.

The rest of the money will be raised through fundraising and mortgage financing.

Since 2001, MennoHomes has built 100,000 affordable housing units worth $10
million.

                              June 12, 2009 Friday

June is National Home Ownership month

BYLINE: Marketta Johnson, McAlester News-Capital, Okla.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 363 words


Jun. 12--June is National Home Ownership month. Betty Petty, office manager of
the Pittsburg County Self-Help Housing program, joined Pittsburg County
Commissioners to sign a proclamation recognizing National Home Ownership month
and the work of the Pittsburg County Self- Help Housing program.

The program began in 1980 in Latimer County. Since then the program has grown to
include Haskell, Pittsburg and LeFlore counties. Executive director of the
Latimer County Housing Authority Self-Help Housing program Janice Coplen
estimates that the program has helped more than 500 families achieve the dream
of home ownership in the four counties.

The Self-Help Housing program, funded through a grant by USDA Rural Development,
can help significantly cut the costs for families buy a new three bedroom, two
bath home. Self -Help helps these families save money by allowing the family to
provide some of the labor in building their own home. Self- Help Housing also
provides technical assistance for families participating in the program. They
help families through the process of applying for loan to finding a site to
build.

Families applying for assistance through Self-Help Housing must meet income
guidelines, have excellent credit, and meet income to debt ratio requirements.
According to Coplen, many families worry they may not qualify because they make
too much money. "You'd be surprised at the number of people who do qualify,"
Coplen said. Income guidelines have raised significantly over the past few
years.

The Self- Help Housing program currently has three houses in varying stages of
construction underway in Krebs.

For more information on the Self-Help Housing program call 918-967-3179.

Contact Marketta Johnson at mjohnson@

mcalesternews.com.

                                    Scotland

Grand plans herald market recovery

BYLINE: Heather Rose

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 44

LENGTH: 556 words


CLEAR signs of the housing market's recovery have been evident this month with a
number of housebuilders preparing to expand their development programmes in
Scotland.

Barratt Homes are on course to open 13 new developments, adding 2,100 homes to
the market. In addition, the work on these sites will help safeguard 4,000 jobs.
What makes this especially significant is the fact Barratt mainly employs local
subcontractors and tradespeople. The forthcoming developments will be spread
throughout the country - in the central belt, the east and the north east.

Sites already confirmed to launch in the near future are Newcraighall Village,
Duddingston Gardens, and Alnwickhill, all in Edinburgh; Kings Way, Renfrew;
Highland Gate, Stirling; Silver Bell, Hamilton; Parklands, Coatbridge; Barclay
Grange, Newmachar; Harlaw Gait, Inverurie; and Ocean, Muggiemoss Road and
Muggiemoss Village in Aberdeen.

Douglas McLeod, left, regional director with Barratt Scotland, said: "We have
seen demand for new homes expand very quickly over the year and the new sites we
are opening mean there will be more choice for local buyers. And it's good news
for the local economy as, in addition to supporting existing construction jobs
as well as creating new ones by building new homes, the people who move into the
new housing will also spend their wages locally." The introduction of the Help
to Buy scheme has played a significant part in the housing market's recovery as
Mr McLeod has acknowledged. He explained: "The really great news this year is
the continuation of Help to Buy Equity mortgages, which means first-time buyers
and those moving up the housing ladder can get moving with just a 5 per cent
deposit, a 20 per cent equity loan, and a 75 per cent mortgage."

Merchant Homes are also in the process of expanding their horizons. One of the
country's younger housebuilders, the business was established in 2007 and has
gone from strength to strength.

As a result they have now expanded their headquarters in Glasgow, moving to
Watermark Business Park opposite the city's Pacific Quay media village. Their 14
head office staff are already based there but the additional space will enable
Merchant Homes to take on 24 new recruits. They are leading a major regeneration
project at Whitfield, Dundee, with affordable housing provider Home Scotland.
The first phase is scheduled for springtime next year and development completion
of the 38 homes is expected towards the end of autumn 2016.

Sales success has already come Merchant's way at their Gantocks development in
Gourock. Now they are launching a new phase, adding a further 25 apartments to
the 25 which have already been built.

Merchant's Philipshill Gate development in East Kilbride has been another of
their success stories. It has sold out but the developers are set to create some
luxury properties in partnership with award-winning architects Hypostyle.
Specially designed for the semi-rural location, there will be nine 2-bedroom
apartments with ground floor apartments having private gardens and upper
apartments having balconies.

Managing director Alan Brander said: "Expanding our geography to locations like
Dundee and further developing our offering across Glasgow, Inverclyde and
Lanarkshire ensures the detail and signature style of our homes reaches more
places than ever before."

                             National Mortgage News

                                 March 30, 1998

South of the Border

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 567 words


Understanding the problems presented by the colonias, the ghastly, mostly rural
ghettoes on the U.S. side of our border with Mexico, will be helped greatly by
understanding something about housing conditions in Mexico.

As more Mexicans have emigrated to this country, so too have some of the worst
characteristics of the Mexican "informal" housing sector.  A recent article
detailing some options for expanding housing choices in the Mexican informal
sector may give U.S. lenders and governments some idea on how to deal with our
own colonias.

According to William J. Siembieda and Eduardo Lopez Moreno in Housing Policy
Debate, an astonishing 40 million Mexicans by the year 2000 will live in the
informal sector, much like our colonias in that they are marked by illegal
subdivisions, irregular infrastructures, and shabby, self-built housing.

Like the occupants of the U.S. colonias, most of these Mexican people have paid
for the land they live on, through loans from the illegal subdividers or "rent
to own" arrangements.  But there are differences as well, since much of the land
to be used for informal sector expansion (occasionally occupied in what the
authors colorfully call "invasions") will come from special status land called
ejido or communal land.

Communal land has its counterpart in the U.S. in tribal trust land, but the
ejido land doesn't really.  It's a "system of land use for the community of
peasants that reside on the land," say the authors, "a corporate holding system
in which the defined users (ejidatarios) have shareholder rights."

Differences aside, the authors' recommendations on how to help the informal
sector will probably have a lot to offer for the problems on our side of the Rio
Grande.

Their first recommendation is to encourage small savings plans, to be pooled
into trusts and then hooked into national housing programs.  An important
feature of them is that "interest" on the savings should not be in the form of
cash, but in building materials and the like, to keep people focused on using
the money for housing.

Local employment in construction-related businesses is also key, the authors
said, and more than that, they like the use of on-site "materials banks,"
financing the manufacture of building materials right on site.  And then
technical assistance, construction and finance know-how, must be provided by
outside interests like government, non-profits, or businesses.  How bad is the
need?  Consider that one of the Mexican colonias, Colonia Jalisco, has a
population density of 300 people per hectare.  A hectare is about half an acre.
So imagine 600 people living on an American one-acre plot and you'll get some
idea of the overcrowding.

The article gives examples of two structures that have given some help with the
informal sector.  One is MAP (Plan de Ayuda Mutua), a microsavings fund
dedicated to housing, like a small building and loan.  The Taller de
Arquitectura Popular, an entity in Jalisco, has organized 600 families into MAPs
since 1992.  There are also Mexican mortgage companies called SOFOLEs.  One
SOFOLE, Su Casita, financed a purchase of land for 400 families and then set up
a reserve fund for collateralization.  And, to maintain the (at best fragile)
housing stock in place in the informal sector, the Ford Foundation has funded a
grant operation for micro-finance housing improvement loans.

                                  City Edition

Agriculture agency to fund Kingfisher theater

BYLINE: Bill Kramer, Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO II; Pg. 20A

LENGTH: 383 words

DATELINE: KINGFISHER


An investment group planning to transform a downtown building into a multiscreen
movie theater has been awarded a guaranteed loan by the U.S. Agriculture
Department's Rural Development department.

Michael Sanders, an assistant to the secretary of agriculture for rural
development, said Tuesday that $500,000 is being deposited at First Capital Bank
of Kingfisher. The money is earmarked for renovations of the building in
preparation for a three-screen theater.

Sanders will join city and state officials and at a kickoff and formal
announcement of financial arrangements for the theater at 11:30 a.m. Thursday.
The event will be at the theater site, a 116-year-old building at 304 S Main.

Sanders, a former Kingfisher resident who now works in Washington, said he is
excited to be involved in a project that will benefit his hometown.

"They're expected to add up to seven or eight jobs, and this will be a
tremendous asset," Sanders said.

The loan is courtesy of the business and industry guaranteed loan program
administered by the rural development department.

"There's not a lot of people who know we don't deal with just farmers and
ranchers," Sanders said of the Agriculture Department. "We also help business,
utilities and housing. This program is one of the more flexible and
far-reaching."

Only communities of fewer than 50,000 population qualify for this program.
Sanders said the department has pumped $1 billion into Oklahoma's small towns in
the past four years.

The money will be repaid by the investment group over a period of 20 years at a
variable rate that mirrors the prime lending rate, said Jeff Johnson, a city
councilman and senior vice president of First Capital Bank.

The city has been without a movie theater since March 27, 2004, when a fire
destroyed an 87-year old landmark building that housed the 89er Theater at 113 N
Main.

John Storm, who is part of the investment group, said he expects there will be a
gap between the loan amount and the actual cost of renovations. Storm and seven
other area businessmen recently formed 89er Theater LLC, a financial group
arranging for the transformation of the 7,000-square-foot space.

Seating will be limited to 281 patrons. Theater capacities will range from 83 to
101. Storm hopes construction can be completed and the theater open by late
fall.

                                US Official News

                              June 24, 2016 Friday

Washington: USDA Announces New Assistance to Help Rural Utility Customers
Conserve Energy, Lower Bills

LENGTH: 592  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following
news release:



 Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced a new program that will help
rural residents conserve energy and save money on their utility bills. The new
Rural Energy Savings Program (RESP) will make $52 million in loans available to
energy providers to help rural families and small businesses reduce their energy
use.





 "Investments like the ones we will make through the Rural Energy Savings
Program not only reduce energy costs for consumers, but also build a cleaner and
more sustainable energy future," Vilsack said. "This program is the latest of
many financing options USDA provides to rural communities to expand energy
efficiency efforts and strengthen rural economies."



 RESP will provide loans to rural energy providers who in turn fund projects for
consumers to make energy efficiency improvements in their homes or businesses
that will lower their energy use. Eligible applicants include current and former
Rural Utilities Service (RUS) borrowers, subsidiaries of current or former RUS
borrowers, and entities that provide retail electric service in rural areas.



 RESP borrowers finance loans at zero percent interest for up to 20 years,
making the program an attractive and affordable option to finance energy-saving
measures. Energy customers participating in programs financed through RESP then
repay the loans at an interest rate of up to 3 percent for up to 10 years
through their electric bills.



 RESP builds upon the work that USDA Rural Development has done to help improve
the energy efficiency of single- and multi-family housing, businesses, farms and
utilities. It aligns with the Obama Administration's StrikeForce for Rural
Growth and Opportunity and Promise Zone initiatives to help revitalize
communities and expand economic opportunity through targeted funding, technical
assistance and partnerships. RESP will be used to focus on low-income,
high-energy-cost communities.



 Congress authorized the program in the 2014 Farm Bill. RUS administers RESP as
well as the similar Energy Efficiency and Conservation Loan Program (EECLP).
RESP is open to a broader pool of eligible borrowers, has a zero percent
interest rate, and has a longer loan term than EECLP. To be considered for RESP
funding, applicants should submit a letter of intent by August 5, 2016. E-mail
the letter of intent to RESP@wdc.usda.gov Applications will be processed on a
first-come/first-served basis until funds are expended. For additional
information, see page 40262 of the June 21 Federal Register.



 USDA's Rural Utilities Service also administers infrastructure programs that
bring broadband, safe drinking water and improved wastewater treatment
facilities to rural communities.



 Since 2009, USDA Rural Development (@USDARDThis is an external link or
third-party site outside of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)
website.) has invested $31.3 billion in 963 electric projects that have financed
more than 185,000 miles of transmission and distribution lines serving 4.6
million rural residents. USDA also has invested $11 billion to start or expand
103,000 rural businesses; helped 1.1 million rural residents buy homes; funded
nearly 7,000 community facilities such as schools, public safety and health care
facilities; and helped bring high-speed Internet access to nearly 6 million
rural residents and businesses.

contact:

 editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                              The Pioneer (India)

                          September 25, 2014 Thursday

Shelter of hope

LENGTH: 1443 words

DATELINE: India


India, Sept. 25 -- M Ravi Kanth, chairman of HUDCO, shares how the organisation
is fuelling dreams of millions of people who are looking for new avenues

In your previous works, you have worked a lot for uplift of poor, bridging gap
between rural and urban infrastructure. In your new stint, how do you plan to
give home to one and all?

HUDCO is owned by the Indian government and in terms of support for housing and
infrastructure, it is the largest company in the country. It is my firm view
that HUDCO would continue to intensify its role as the largest facilitator of
housing delivery, with particular reference to the weaker sections of the
society. Towards improving access to housing for all sections of the society,
especially at its lower rungs, HUDCO has introduced two innovative products,
namely, 'Rent-to-Own' Scheme, which is a 'rental-cum-ownership' scheme for
low-income employees of an organisation; and HUDCO Nav Nagar Yojana (HuNNY),
which offers a comprehensive solution to the growing cities/towns from 'Planning
to Financing' sustainable habitats.

In the light of the significant deficit in housing in the country and the need
for massive efforts to achieve the objective of affordable housing for all by
2022, HUDCO is fully geared up to take up the challenge of providing housing
finance, especially for the EWS and LIG segments. HUDCO's Corporate Plan-2020
envisages a major focus and thrust on social housing in order to achieve the
national goal of affordable housing for all. It anticipates an increase in the
social housing operations to a significantly higher level, so as to retain
HUDCO's premier role as the only CPSE of its kind financing EWS and LIG at the
most competitive rates. HUDCO's recent innovative initiatives and expansion of
its activities in addition to its conventional techno-financing business would
give a big push to the housing sector..

How will 'Rent-to-Own' scheme help government employees? Does it include both
central and state employees?

HUDCO has introduced a new scheme called, 'Rent-to-Own' scheme, which is a
'rental-cum-ownership' scheme, designed to facilitate an agency to initially
avail loan from HUDCO on behalf of its identified employees for the scheme and
would allot the houses to its employees initially on rental basis. The employee
would become the 'owner' of the house as and when the full cost of the house is
paid to the Agency. This scheme would benefit the employees at Bottom of Pyramid
(BoP) of the agencies, and open to all Central & State Government organisations,
Police Housing Corporation employees, autonomous bodies, state PSUs et al.

Any plans to encourage innovative projects in housing and urban development?

Last year, we have introduced a new innovative scheme for urban extensions and
integrated townships, which is called 'HuNNY' (Hudco Nav Nagar Yojana). This
scheme offers a comprehensive solution to the growing cities/towns from
'Planning to Financing' the sustainable habitats. Under the scheme, we would
provide technical and financial support for developing potential sites as
planned urban extensions to meet the requirements of the ever growing
population. As the government has a mission to build 100 smart cities, it is
expected that HUDCO's new scheme would provide the necessary 'planning to
financing' option for existing cities as well as green field cities to build
sustainable new urban habitats.

In line with our mission to provide sustainable and inclusive living
environment, we are in the process of devising a new product this year for
senior citizens in the name of 'Senior Citizen Housing' to address senior
citizens' housing needs, in order to provide dignified, safe, socially-enriching
living environment, safeguarding the rights of senior citizens in their sunset
years. This will be implemented in all the cities and the ULBs/State agencies
have freedom to approach us and avail financing under the scheme.

Please elaborate on the recent MoUs signed.

As a step towards further promoting the housing and habitat sector, HUDCO has
entered into memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with several organisations such
as National Culture Fund (NCF) for conservation of heritage sites/buildings;
Construction Industries Development Council (CIDC) for creation of skills
required in the building construction industry; National Commission for Women
(NCW) under CSR for improving the living conditions of widows at Vrindavan,
Mathura; National Building Construction Corporation (NBCC) for joint development
of projects; and School of Planning & Architecture for research related
activities in the habitat sector, Central Government Employees Welfare Housing
Organisation (CGEWHO) for members to avail individual loans from HUDCO Niwas
branches all over the country, India Infrastructure Finance Company Limited
(IIFCL) for investment in Infrastructure Debt Fund created for extending loan to
the infrastructure projects in the country and, Credit Risk Guarantee Fund Trust
for Low Income Housing (CRGFTLIH) for providing effective guarantee for such
housing loans upto '5 lakh extended to EWS/LIG borrowers in urban areas without
collaterals and/or third party guarantees.

What standards do you maintain at your Human Settlement Management Institute?

Human Settlement Management Institute (HSMI), was set up in 1985 to infuse
further professionalism through training and capacity building of its borrowing
agencies in project planning and implementation. As per recent MoU signed
between HUDCO and Ministry HUPA, Govt of India; HSMI has been entrusted with the
responsibility of four activities; to be undertaken during 2014-15:

In order to explore the research studies, HSMI has sanctioned 29 research
studies from the year 2012-13 onwards in the research areas as envisaged under
MoU targets of R&D template. These research studies have been sanctioned to the
prestigious institutions like IITs and IIMs, which have to be completed in a
maximum period of two to three years, depending upon the approved scope of work.
Out of 29 research studies, two study research reports on Municipal
Infrastructure Potential for HUDCO Lending conducted by IIPA and study on
'Primary Collection of Solid Waste Management' in Bangalore conducted by IIM,
Bangalore have been submitted to Ministry of Housing & Urban Poverty
Alleviation.

What are the various measures or steps taken in order to aware the local
population about the various prevailing schemes?

We have the mandate to reach the unreached segment of the society by providing
long-term finance for housing and urban infrastructure projects to benefit this
segment in the country. In fact, every 16th house in the country is financed by
HUDCO. With a pan-India presence, we have emerged as a major player in the arena
of housing and urban infrastructure finance over the last four decades offering
a wide range of financing options and services. For housing, HUDCO finances and
supports a broad spectrum of housing activities such as urban, rural and staff
rental housing, land acquisition schemes undertaken by the State's public
organisations and housing projects under JNNURM for meeting the State/ULB
contribution (Viability Gap Funding) as well as Retail Financing to individuals,
through HUDCO Niwas.

How does 'Micro Finance for Housing' scheme benefit women?

To promote micro-finance in housing, HUDCO is participating in the form of
equity contribution to Sewa Grih Rinn Limited to the tune of '1.8 crore, which
is new Micro Housing Finance Company set up by Self Employed Women's Association
(SEWA). HUDCO would ensure financial inclusion of the women members of SEWA, who
have so far been denied the benefit of home loans through the formal lending
mechanism.

How is bamboo-based building system beneficial?

Bamboo offers one of the best alternatives for a totally 'green', environment
friendly building system option. Referred to as 'natural iron', bamboo has
natural tensile properties which make it an excellent replacement for energy
intensive steel, as well as hardwood. Bamboo as a material has a wide range of
applications from food to craft and is widely used worldwide in construction. In
India too, bamboo is traditionally used in the bamboo growing states which cover
over 70 per cent of the country.

What are the projects HUDCO taken up recently?

HUDCO infrastructure initiative also includes industrial infrastructure
financing and we have financed various industrial infrastructure projects in the
country.

Oklahoma Business Briefs, Feb. 28

Vintage cars added to auto showWith the Oklahoma City International Auto Show
celebrating its 100th anniversary March 10-12 at the new Bennett Event Center at
the Oklahoma State Fair Park in Oklahoma City, those attending the event will be
treated to a re-creation of the event from 1917."The addition of our cars
showcases a nostalgic piece of American automobile history - a vivid contrast to
the modern high technology of today - and common interest has fostered a special
car lovers bond," said Jim Adair, past president of the Sooner Region of the
Horseless Carriage Club of America. "Our commitment to the preservation of
pre-1916 automobiles affords us the unique ability to commemorate, save and
forever preserve the era and the evolution of the American automotive
entrepreneurial spirit."Most of the vehicles are rare pieces of automobile
antiquity that are routinely sequestered away in a garage for viewing by
invitation only. As part of the re-creation, 44 cars from that era will be on
display. Adair said this is a great opportunity for the general public to see
cars that don't often see the light of day.Those interested in purchasing
tickets are encouraged to go to www.okcautoshow.org for additional information.

Discounts are available for tickets purchased online. Buy one get one free
coupons are available at local 7-Eleven stores.WPX Energy to pay pollution fineA
Tulsa-based oil and natural gas exploration company is paying $1.2 million for
polluting groundwater supplying five households in southwestern Pennsylvania in
2012.The state Department of Environmental Protection announced the fine Monday
against WPX Energy, which agreed to it in a December consent agreement.Officials
say a leak from a wastewater pit polluted groundwater below WPX's Kalp well site
in Westmoreland County, about 60 miles southeast of Pittsburgh. WPX says it paid
for bottled water and water-treatment systems at the affected households. The
company still must show that it has cleaned up the groundwater.WPX says no
individual's health was ever at risk. WPX has sold of much of its holdings in
the Marcellus Shale natural gas reservoir, and now operates just a handful of
wells there.Federal loan to expand broadbandA $15.3 million federal loan has
been approved to help expand broadband in a rural portion of Oklahoma.The U.S.
Department of Agriculture loan is to Southern Plains Cable LLC to build a
fiber-optic broadband network in a 55-square-mile area that includes Anadarko,
Verden and Chickasha.Acting Deputy Under Secretary for Rural Development Roger
Glendenning announced the loan Monday and said it will help provide high-speed
internet service to the rural area of south-central Oklahoma.The loan is
provided through USDA's Telecommunications Programs of the Rural Utilities
Service.OKC banker joins federal bank boardOklahoma City's Donald R. Abernathy
Jr., president and CEO of The Bankers Bank since 1993, has been elected to the
board of directors of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Topeka, a wholesale bank
that serves as a source of credit for member financial institutions in Colorado,
Kansas, Nebraska and Oklahoma.Abernathy serves on the Operations and Housing
&amp; Governance committees.He has been active in the banking industry in the
Oklahoma City metro area for the last 38 years. He is a past chairman of the
Oklahoma Bankers Association and serves on the board of directors for the
Community Bankers Association of Oklahoma, First Bankers Banc Securities and
other industry and charity groups. He also is a past board member of the
Independent Community Bankers Association and served on the Government Relations
Committee and Community Bankers Council for the American Bankers
Association.Keating joins Citizens Inc. boardCitizens Inc. has appointed former
Oklahoma Gov. Frank Keating as a director, effective immediately, the Austin,
Texas-based company said."We are thrilled that Gov. Keating is able to join
Citizens' Board," said Dr. Robert Sloan, Chairman of Citizens' Board of
Directors. "In addition to his proven record as a leader and public servant,
Gov. Keating brings valuable experience in life insurance, compliance, law
enforcement and corporate governance."Keating is a partner at the law firm of
Holland &amp; Knight LLP. Keating previously was CEO of the American Bankers
Association and before that president and CEO of the American Council of Life
Insurers.Citizens Inc. is a financial services company listed on the New York
Stock Exchange under the symbol CIA. The company said it seeks growth based on
worldwide sales of U.S. dollar-denominated whole life cash value insurance

                                US Official News

                          September 29, 2016 Thursday

Washington: Agriculture Secretary Vilsack Announces USDA Funding for Ohio
Hospital

LENGTH: 803  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following
news release:



 Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced a $54.6 million Community
Facilities program loan to the Fulton County Health Center in Wauseon, Ohio, to
renovate a critical access hospital that also offers treatment for substance
misuse disorders.





 "USDA's investment in much-needed medical facilities is bringing
state-of-the-art health care to residents in our rural communities," Vilsack
said. "When complete, the hospital and new medical office building will have the
staff and equipment to deliver quality medical services to Fulton County,
including treatment for patients who have opioid and other substance use
disorders."



 Secretary Vilsack is leading an interagency effort to address the rural opioid
crisis, which disproportionately affects rural areas. He made the announcement
here today as part of the White House's efforts this week to bring increased
attention to the opioid crisis in rural areas. On Aug. 31, Vilsack announced an
initiative to provide transitional housing for rural Americans who are seeking
to recover from substance use disorders.



 Vilsack was on the campus of Clinton County's Wilmington College where a
similar $19.7 million USDA Community Facilities loan in 2013 helped to finance
the rehabilitation of Kettering Hall, home of the school's Center for Science
and Agriculture.



 "Standing in the rejuvenated Kettering Hall, we see proof of how USDA's
Community Facilities program can have a massive, positive impact in rural
areas," Vilsack said. "A few short years ago, Wilmington was reeling from the
loss of the region's primary employer, which quadrupled the unemployment rate.
But with steady effort and dedicated public-private partnerships, the tide is
turning and the community is making a comeback."



 Today's tour of the Center for Science and Agriculture included viewing
renovations to the circa 1960s original footprint. These renovations focused on
removing environmental hazards, updating mechanical systems and improving
building accessibility. The 15,000-square-foot building addition provides
much-needed classroom and laboratory space for Wilmington College's growing STEM
program.



 Vilsack said Wauseon and the surrounding region on Ohio's northern border also
stand to benefit from the Fulton County Health Center's Community Facilities
loan, particularly because the Center is the only medical provider in the area.
USDA funds will help construct a 62,220-square-foot medical office building,
easing a space shortage and helping attract additional medical specialists to
the area. About 80 new jobs are anticipated as a result.



 Today's funding builds on USDA's historic investments in rural America over the
past seven years. Since 2009, USDA has worked to strengthen and support rural
communities and American agriculture, an industry that supports one in 11
American jobs, provides American consumers with more than 80 percent of the food
we consume, ensures that Americans spend less of their paychecks at the grocery
store than most people in other countries, and supports markets for homegrown
renewable energy and materials.



 From 2009 to 2015, USDA has invested more than $36.9 billion in Ohio, including
more than $5.1 billion to support affordable housing, ag producers and small
businesses, improved water systems, telecommunications, broadband and other
critical infrastructure. These investments have helped create jobs and promote
economic opportunity for those who live, work and raise their families in rural
Ohio. USDA has also invested $828 million in efforts to conserve and protect
Ohio's land, water and air resources and more than $275 million in Ohio to
support research that will secure and improve our food, agricultural and natural
resources systems.



 Since 2009, USDA Rural Development (@USDARDThis is an external link or
third-party site outside of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)
website.) has helped bring high-speed Internet access to nearly 6 million rural
residents and businesses; invested nearly $13 billion to start or expand nearly
112,000 rural businesses; helped 1.1 million rural residents buy homes; and
funded nearly 9,200 community facilities such as schools, public safety and
health care facilities. USDA also has invested $31.3 billion in 963 electric
projects that have financed more than 185,000 miles of transmission and
distribution lines serving 4.6 million rural residents and more than $13.3
billion to finance rural water and wastewater projects. To read more about
USDA's investments in rural America and its successful turnaround, visit USDA's
latest entry on Medium.

contact:

 editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                               The Ottawa Citizen

                     April 6, 1996, Saturday, FINAL EDITION

Factory-direct houses to go: Despite image problem, sales are increasing

BYLINE: ANGELA MANGIACASALE; THE OTTAWA CITIZEN

SECTION: NEW HOMES; Pg. I1 / Front


In a factory south of Ottawa, half the main floor of a new home works its way
down the assembly line. It doesn't matter to the workers if it's pouring rain or
blowing snow outside. They, their tools, and their materials stay dry.

The Guildcrest Homes plant in Morewood is one of about 50 manufacturers across
Canada that together produce about 8,000 homes a year. These homes are built in
sections, set on flatbed trucks and transported to a site where they are
completed.

It's the ideal factory conditions, manufacturers say, that allow them to produce
some of the highest quality housing in the country. While the rest of the
housing industry has been hit with record low sales in the past few years,
manufactured housing sales have increased.

But manufactured housing faces an image problem. Some consumers still think
factory-built homes are cheap in the worst sense of the word.

There is also confusion. "Manufactured" or "factory-built" housing -- also
called "pre-fabs," but never within the industry -- refers both to modular homes
and to mobile homes.

"Distinguishing between mobile homes and modular housing can be difficult, in
some cases, impossible," says Ken Rauch, senior adviser on housing standards for
Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp.

The key difference is that modular homes are installed on a foundation so they
have a full basement, while mobile homes are installed on "piers," a series of
posts usually made of concrete block or wood, and do not have basements. Also,
mobile homes are single-storey buildings, while modular home designs include
split levels and two-storeys as well as bungalows.

Manufactured housing factories are certified and regularly inspected by the
Canadian Standards Association. But there are different CSA standards for mobile
and modular homes.

Mobile homes are subject to a national standard. Since a mobile home is not set
on a full-height foundation, the structure must meet strict rules for rigidity.

A modular home must be built to the standards for housing in the area in which
it will be completed. For example, in Ontario, these homes must meet the Ontario
Building Code as well as the municipality's bylaws.

All types of home construction have become more industrialized, says David
Poupore, president of Guildcrest Homes.

"All we're doing is pushing the manufacturing end of it to the extreme," he
says. "If you go back 40 years, carpenters built windows, they built cabinets
and put them in the house. Nobody does that any more."

Modular homes aren't necessarily boxy. Some Guildcrest designs feature
bay-shaped rooms. They can also include sweeping staircases and elaborate
kitchens with large islands and breakfast bars. Buyers can work with the
company's designers to customize their homes.

Guildcrest is also Ontario's biggest builder of R-2000 homes, a national
standard with strict criteria for energy efficiency, air tightness and indoor
air quality.

For a buyer who already owns a lot, a 1,010 square-foot three-bedroom bungalow
that is R-2000 certified from Guildcrest costs about $ 74,800. The company is
building a development in Metcalfe where the same bungalow is priced from $
124,900 including the 3/4-acre lot.

The traditional market for modular homes is rural lot owners.

"Their range of choices tends to go from the guy who works out of the back of a
pickup truck to the local small custom home builder through to the modular
manufacturer," says Poupore. "We encourage them to look to us for a degree of
consistency of quality and professionalism and longevity."

Once the last resort of consumers who wanted a single-family house but could
only afford a trailer, mobile homes have come a long way from the aluminum,
horizontal elevator shafts they once resembled.

Most mobile homes are still built in one section that can range in size from 750
to 1,400 square feet. But more are being manufactured in two or more sections
and assembled on site, says Jamie Cooke, executive vice-president of the
Canadian Manufactured Housing Association.

Technically, mobile homes can be moved from one site to another. But association
surveys show that fewer than two per cent are ever moved, Cooke says.

Price is one of the most attractive features of mobile homes. A 750-square-foot
single section mobile home that is 95 per cent complete when it leaves the
factory would start at about $ 35,000.

Often mobile homes are set on leased land in "manufactured home communities" --
the term the industry prefers over "mobile home park."

It's the lack of owned land that used to create a financial paradox for mobile
home owners. While they are one of the most affordable types of homes, mobiles
have been subject to one of the most expensive forms of financing -- a chattel
mortgage. Mobile homes were financed as moveable objects much like cars and
subject to higher rates of interest over a shorter term than mortgages on
conventional homes, where ownership includes the building and the land.

This changed in 1988 when CMHC introduced the Chattel Loan Insurance Program or
CLIP, which insured loans on mobile homes. This allowed purchasers to get from
banks mortgage terms and rates similar to those on conventional homes, says John
Purchase, senior policy officer in CMHC's insurance products division.

Since the program began eight years ago, CMHC has insured loans on 15,200 mobile
homes. Almost half the total -- 6,518 loans -- were insured in 1995.

"That's because in modifications (to the program) in January 1995, we included
existing or resale units," Purchase says.

Modular homes -- because they are traditionally completed on land owned by the
home buyer -- are financed exactly the same way as homes built on site.

Overall, manufactured housing has prospered during a time when the rest of the
housing industry has been in a slump, says association executive vice-president
Cooke.

"Between 1994 and 1995, the site-built (housing) industry on a national level
was down 30 per cent in single family home starts. In the manufactured housing
industry, modular and mobile homes were up 10 per cent."

The reason, Cooke adds, is affordability and value for money.

"Because more than 50 per cent of the people in the marketplace are first time
homebuyers they are looking for this type of product."

THE KEY DIFFERENCE BETWEEN MODULAR AND MOBILE HOMES

IS THAT MODULAR HOMES ARE INSTALLED ON A FOUNDATION SO

THEY HAVE A FULL BASEMENT. MOBILE HOMES ARE INSTALLED

ON "PIERS," A SERIES OF POSTS USUALLY MADE OF CONCRETE

BLOCK OR WOOD, AND DO NOT HAVE BASEMENTS.

here today as part of the White House's efforts this week to bring increased
attention to the opioid crisis in rural areas. On Aug. 31, Vilsack announced an
initiative to provide transitional housing for rural Americans who are seeking
to recover from substance use disorders.



 Vilsack was on the campus of Clinton County's Wilmington College where a
similar $19.7 million USDA Community Facilities loan in 2013 helped to finance
the rehabilitation of Kettering Hall, home of the school's Center for Science
and Agriculture.



 "Standing in the rejuvenated Kettering Hall, we see proof of how USDA's
Community Facilities program can have a massive, positive impact in rural
areas," Vilsack said. "A few short years ago, Wilmington was reeling from the
loss of the region's primary employer, which quadrupled the unemployment rate.
But with steady effort and dedicated public-private partnerships, the tide is
turning and the community is making a comeback."



 Today's tour of the Center for Science and Agriculture included viewing
renovations to the circa 1960s original footprint. These renovations focused on
removing environmental hazards, updating mechanical systems and improving
building accessibility. The 15,000-square-foot building addition provides
much-needed classroom and laboratory space for Wilmington College's growing STEM
program.



 Vilsack said Wauseon and the surrounding region on Ohio's northern border also
stand to benefit from the Fulton County Health Center's Community Facilities
loan, particularly because the Center is the only medical provider in the area.
USDA funds will help construct a 62,220-square-foot medical office building,
easing a space shortage and helping attract additional medical specialists to
the area. About 80 new jobs are anticipated as a result.



 Today's funding builds on USDA's historic investments in rural America over the
past seven years. Since 2009, USDA has worked to strengthen and support rural
communities and American agriculture, an industry that supports one in 11
American jobs, provides American consumers with more than 80 percent of the food
we consume, ensures that Americans spend less of their paychecks at the grocery
store than most people in other countries, and supports markets for homegrown
renewable energy and materials.



 From 2009 to 2015, USDA has invested more than $36.9 billion in Ohio, including
more than $5.1 billion to support affordable housing, ag producers and small
businesses, improved water systems, telecommunications, broadband and other
critical infrastructure. These investments have helped create jobs and promote
economic opportunity for those who live, work and raise their families in rural
Ohio. USDA has also invested $828 million in efforts to conserve and protect
Ohio's land, water and air resources and more than $275 million in Ohio to
support research that will secure and improve our food, agricultural and natural
resources systems.



 Since 2009, USDA Rural Development (@USDARDThis is an external link or
third-party site outside of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA)
website.) has helped bring high-speed Internet access to nearly 6 million rural
residents and businesses; invested nearly $13 billion to start or expand nearly
112,000 rural businesses; helped 1.1 million rural residents buy homes; and
funded nearly 9,200 community facilities such as schools, public safety and
health care facilities. USDA also has invested $31.3 billion in 963 electric
projects that have financed more than 185,000 miles of transmission and
distribution lines serving 4.6 million rural residents and more than $13.3
billion to finance rural water and wastewater projects. To read more about
USDA's investments in rural America and its successful
