                                Ashford Adscene

                               November 29, 2012

Fall in people waiting for borough housing

BYLINE: Kathy Bailes

SECTION: Pg. 3

LENGTH: 528  words


Ashford has bucked the trend to show a fall in the number of people on the
authority's housing waiting list.

In a report by the National Housing Federation (NHF) published this week, the
borough is revealed to be one of only two Kent local authorities to have reduced
the number of people waiting for a home.

Between 2001 and 2011 the number of people waiting for social housing in Ashford
dropped  from 1,691 to 1,449 despite  the 2011 Census noting that the
population has increased by 13 per cent since 2001, with an additional 6,350
households in the borough.

Ashford has expanded with family housing developments at Park Farm, Orchard
Heights, Little Burton Farm, Godinton Park and Repton Park. The council's new
local plan also earmarks  land for future house-building.

In the last three years £6.3 million funding from the Homes and Communities
Agency  has paid for 78 borough homes, with 59 more promised by April 2015.

The council is also working with parish councils to identify suitable sites
where affordable housing can be created. The council  owns 4,692 homes and
there are a further 337 properties managed by Moat Housing at Stanhope.

But, with the introduction of changes to housing benefit and Universal Credit
being introduced from next April, plus incentives announced by the Government to
give discounts to tenants who want the right to buy their council homes,  a
shortfall of more than 400 affordable homes in the borough per year has already
been identified.

To help combat this, the council has launched its own social lettings agency
helping people on benefits and those who cannot raise deposits to find privately
rented homes.

ABC is also introducing five-year fixed tenancies from April 2013 and has opted
to join Kent County Council's No Use Empty loan scheme, which will help to bring
back into use  empty homes that could be used as rented accommodation.

Councillor Aline Hicks, Ashford Borough Council's portfolio holder for housing,
said: "These figures are extremely encouraging. They show that  we are always
striving to find solutions to increase our housing stock, meeting the needs of
rural communities and making the best use of  the homes  we have to offer.

"Innovations such as ABC Lettings will help us to address the demand for rented
accommodation in the borough. Of course, we need to continue to innovate and
adapt to change to meet Ashford's housing need."

Housing report

The NHF report says Kent will need 891,000 new homes by 2033 but states the
South East is only building half the homes needed which will "cause house prices
and rents to rocket in Kent" and "housing waiting lists [to] soar".

NHF says Kent's  waiting lists have risen by 57 per cent in the last decade from
28,666 to 45,102.

The highest rise in Kent waiting lists has been in Gravesham where from 2001 to
2011 it has rocketed by 150 per cent.

Ashford has seen its list drop by more than 14 per cent.

No Use Empty

Kent County Council's  loan scheme  enables  owners to refurbish or convert
their empty property and make it available for sale or rent.  Ashford Borough
Council may also use the scheme for property it has acquired, possibly through
compulsory purchase.

ST. PETERS

Hospital is seeking variety of volunteers

Barnes-Jewish St. Peters Hospital is looking for volunteers in a variety of
areas.

The hospital has volunteer opportunities available in the following areas: gift
shop; Siteman Cancer Center; clerical; Women's Center; surgical services;
patient satisfaction; patient care; and at-home work, such as sewing or
knitting.

The hospital offers flexible schedules, where volunteers can work from as little
as once a month, to various times.

For more information, call Jenn Hanff, volunteer coordinator, at 636-916-9679 or
visit the hospital's Web site at www.bjsph.org.

ST. CHARLES

Children's art class offered at foundry

The Foundry Art Centre will hold a six-week children's art class beginning
tonight.

"Adventures in Art" is designed for children 8 to 12 years old who want to learn
a variety of art media.

Topics include drawing, collage, painting, printmaking, sculpture and fibers.

Sessions will be held on Wednesdays from 6 p.m. to 7:30 p.m. The cost for the
six-week session is $85 for Foundry Art members and $95 for nonmembers. All
supplies are included.

For more information, call 636-255-0270.

ST. CHARLES COUNTY AREA

Home ownership program is planned

The North East Community Action Corp. will host a meeting tonight about a
do-it-yourself home ownership program in Lincoln and Warren counties.

Residents are invited to the meeting about the USDA Rural Development Self-Help
Housing Program, at 6 p.m. It will be held at NECAC's office at 115 West Third
Street, Montgomery City.

Applicants who meet income and credit guidelines are eligible for low-interest
loans through Rural Development.

Instead of making a down payment, the families spend at least 25 hours a week
working as a team under NECAC, to build one another's homes.

For more information, call 573-564-3606.

ST. CHARLES COUNTY

Trailnet bike riders can get just desserts

A slice of pie and other desserts await bicyclists who join the Trailnet Bicycle
Fun Club for a ride on Sunday.

The ride begins with registration from 7:30 to 9 a.m. at the Orchard Farm school
complex, 2165 Highway V in St. Charles County.

Riders can chose routes of 12, 21, 40 or 52 miles that take them across the
Mississippi River and into Madison and Calhoun counties.

The routes are on flat to moderately hilly terrain, with bigger hills on the
longer routes. The short route goes to Grafton and includes a ride on the ferry.
Bicyclists are encouraged to stop in at My Just Desserts in Elsah for food and
drinks, and the restaurant will add a scoop of ice cream to your slice of pie
for free. The cycling routes travel Elsah, Eckert's Orchard in Grafton, and Pere
Marquette State Park.

Ride tickets include two ferry crossings and cost $10 for Trailnet members, $13
for nonmembers, and $7 for children under 13.

For more information, visit www.trailnet.org or call Trailnet at 314-416-9930.

                     The Jones County News (Gray, Georgia)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                               September 27, 2012

Hitchcock Road residents finally have a plan to help with water contamination;
Owner of garage facility to be leased seeks a new P&Z hearing

BYLINE: The Jones County News staff

LENGTH: 1053  words


A long-awaited water project to assist several Jones County homeowners with safe
drinking water moved forward at last week's commissioners meeting.

The Sept. 18 meetingbegan on ahigh note with Housing Committee Chairman Donald
Black thanking board members for their support over the past three years for
Jones County's Georgia Initiative for Community Housing team.

The commissionersjoined Gray's City Council in assisting with the committee's
application and expenses for the group's retreats. The GICH team focused on
affordable housing for Gray and recently received the good news of the receipt
of a $385,000 housing grant.

P&Z

Jones County Zoning officer Tim Pitrowski brought commissioners a request from
Equipment Leasing Enterprises LLC for a rehearing on a rezoning petition that
was heard Aug. 7.

Pitrowski explained that the request may be brought back in six months, but the
company does not want to wait. He said what is required to grant the rehearing
is to find that there is new or additional information not available at the time
of the original hearing or not presented due to excusable neglect.

Michael Williams, who wanted to move his truck repair business to the property
on Cumslo Road, brought the original requests to the board. The request was to
rezone the property from Rural Residential (R-R) to General Industrial (M-2) for
the purpose of operating a heavy equipment repair facility.

A trucking company had been previously located on the property but has been
closed over a year. The neighboring property owners were at the August meeting
objecting to the majority of adjacent land has a rural use and approval of this
request would be a detriment to Jones County.

Board members agreed with those objecting and voted to reject the petition.

Equipment Leasing Inc. is the owner of the property, and their point was one of
terminology in the zoning. Their letter stated the existing zoning is Commercial
Rural, which Pitrowski said does not exist in Jones County.

Commissioner Chap Nelson asked what it would hurt to grant the rehearing.

County Attorney Frank Childs said anyone wanting to file a lawsuit against the
county after being turned down for a zoning request must go through the
rehearing process.

"I think they were caught on a technicality and want to be heard again, why not
let them?" Nelson asked.

Childs said, in order to grant the rehearing, commissioners must find new
information is available.

The petition was denied with a vote of 3-1 with Nelson opposed.

New business

Commissioners renewed their agreement with Central Georgia Technical College for
continuation of the Adult Education Program and unanimously adopted amendments
to the county's code on alcoholic beverages.

Board members approved three documents needed to finalize agreements with the
Water Well Trust Foundation and Georgia Department of Community Affairs to
provide affordable loans to homeowners on Hitchcock Road and one additional site
on Callie Road for new water wells.

Homeowners on Hitchcock Road have been asking for help for approximately 10
years after their wells were determined contaminated. Commissioners worked on
several scenarios, including hooking to the Baldwin County water line.

Jarrell Greene of Greene's Water Wells offered his expertise and informed the
commissioners about the Water Well Trust Foundation. That is when a workable
plan started coming together.

DCA approved a $20,000 CDBG under the Immediate Threat and Danger Program that
will be used to reduce the cost of the wells for the participating homeowners.
The county's involvement is as the administrator of the grant and loans.

County Administrator Mike Underwood said the documents have been reviewed by the
county attorney.

"There have been many revisions and a lot of changes, but I think we are at the
point to be approved with little or no exposure to the county," Childs said.

David Gault, who represented District Two when the contamination was discovered,
began the project, and Nelson has carried it forward.

The commissioner made the motion to approve the signing of the documents, and
the motion was unanimously approved.

"This has been a long time coming. This may not be exactly what they wanted at
first but it will resolve the problem. I thank Jarrell Greene for making this
happen and Mike (Underwood) and Margie (Tyson) for all their hard work," Nelson
said.

The board's last item of new business was the approval of the county's road
paving projects with the GDOT Chairman Preston Hawkins said one of the
improvements will be in front of Jones County High School, which is a
much-needed project.

Department heads

Underwood asked board members when the 1 percent raise for county employees
would take effect. He suggested Oct. 1 to allow time for the changes to be input
into the payroll system.

The administrator also asked for approval for the Jones County Sheriff's
Department to have flexibility in distributing the increase. The board approved
both by consensus.

He spoke to the board next about a situation at the water department. Underwood
said cutoff day is causing a lot of abuse to the employees who answer the phones
at the water department.

The accounts are cut off when they have been unpaid for 60 days. The cutoff date
is posted on the water bills.

"The girls do a great job, but it gets to be too much. I've instructed them when
the verbal abuse begins to hang up the phone," Underwood said.

Water Superintendent Freddie Wiggins said the calls are getting really bad, and
the board agreed with Underwood's suggestion.

Comments

Commissioner Larry Childs asked water rates be included on the next meeting
agenda, and Underwood suggested a meeting of the county's water committee to
discuss water rates and wastewater agreements.

Childs said, based on the information he received from the finance director, the
water department account is a mess and notes are coming due.

Commissioner Tommmy Robinson said he intends to continue investigating
cost-saving measures, but his plan will not include anyone losing their job.

Commissioner Bert Liston said thank you to the public works department for its
quick response to two road problems in his district. He added his appreciation
to the county's constitutional officers for the job they do.

"Together they bring more than 100 years experience to the county," Liston
commented.

                              Gloucestershire Echo

                             April 1, 2010 Thursday

Lib Dems promise to tackle housing crisis

SECTION: Pg. 14

LENGTH: 507  words


By Stephen HACKWELL

TACKLING Cheltenham's housing crisis is at the heart of the Liberal Democrats'
plans for the town.

Members of the ruling political party at the borough council are gearing up for
the local elections on May 6 by promising to focus on protecting the green belt
and building more affordable homes on brownfield land.

Its new manifesto earmarks the Government's controversial Regional Spatial
Strategy  as the greatest challenge facing Cheltenham in the next two years.

It also promotes a light railway link between Gloucester and Cheltenham.

Discussing the housing demand, council leader Stephen Jordan said: "It is about
managing whatever level of growth is forced upon us with the basic need for
affordable housing.

"We want social housing to be built on brown land within the borough boundaries,
not in the open countryside and on green belt."

He added: "That is something  we have always been clear  on and for which we
will continue to fight."

The RSS dictates 13,800 new homes must be built in and around Cheltenham, with
some of the suggested areas  falling within Tewkesbury Borough's jurisdiction,
over the next 16 years.

It has been bitterly opposed by green belt campaigners and councillors, who say
the demands are excessive.

The Conservatives have promised to scrap the scheme within 10 weeks if they win
the General Election. Cheltenham Borough Council has already joined forces with
Tewkesbury Borough Council and Gloucester City Council, all of which are against
the RSS, to produce a regional blueprint for new housing.

This Joint Core Strategy outlines how the councils will cope if the RSS is
implemented or it is scrapped and the local authorities are left to come up with
their own housing plans.

Mr Jordan and Councillor John Webster, cabinet member for finance, said they
wanted to force developers to build on existing brownfield sites rather than
focusing on the town's rural hinterland.

The new regulations would also ensure 40 per cent of all developments of more
than three properties must be affordable housing. The threshold is currently
developments of more than 14 properties.

Mr Webster said: "We have already started to restrict back-garden development
through our planning process and we look to do something similar if we can. We
do need some freedom and support from central government to achieve this."

Also included in the manifesto is a plan to fund the proposed light railway link
between Gloucester and Cheltenham.

The Lib Dems want to use the community infrastructure levy - a new tool which
will be introduced in April - to force developers to cough up cash for the £150
million tram system running from Gloucester Docks to Cheltenham Racecourse.

The new charge will effectively replace Section 106 payments and allow council
bosses to set aside money from an unrelated development.

Mr Webster said: "It is a way of getting sufficient money together to really
consider the scheme. Cheltenham, Gloucester and Tewkesbury could all do this and
then negotiate a prudential loan to fund the remaining costs."

              The Times and Democrat (Orangeburg, South Carolina)

                            September 9, 2012 Sunday

County joining lawsuit against Freddie, Fannie

BYLINE: Gene Zaleski, The Times and Democrat, Orangeburg, S.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 699 words


Sept. 09--Orangeburg County has agreed to join a lawsuit against Fannie Mae and
Freddie Mac, saying it is entitled to unpaid fees from the mortgage companies.

The lawsuit claims the two federally backed companies failed to pay real estate
transfer fees over a three-year period.

Orangeburg County Administrator Harold Young said it will not cost the county
anything to participate in the lawsuit, although he was uncertain how much money
the county may receive if it wins.

"We are still looking into it," Young said.

Richland County sued Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and the Federal Housing Finance
Agency for failing to pay real estate transfer fees.

The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan
Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) are government-backed public corporations
that used to be federal agencies.

The county is represented in the lawsuit by Kyle Michel Law Firm LLC and the
Strom Law Firm LLC.

In a separate matter during Tuesday night's County Council meeting, council
unanimously approved:

A $317,513 bid from Myrtle Beach-based MJL, Inc. to place sewer lines and
manholes in the Orangeburg Country Club and Dove Point areas. As part of the
first phase of the project, the work will include part of Moore Road and Putter
Path and the entire Dove Point subdivision. The project is scheduled to begin in
October.

A $40,019 bid from Columbia-based Bonitz Flooring to replace carpet and tile in
the county's Administrative Centre building. The areas getting new floors
include the basement hallway, first-floor hallway, first-floor County Council
Chambers, second-floor administrative suites and hallway and third floor.

A $244,082 bid from Orangeburg-based Palmetto Site Prep and a $258,915 bid from
Columbia-based GH Smith for on-call water and wastewater construction for
planned county projects.

The companies will provide repairs and maintenance. Actual costs will be based
on the needed repairs.

In other business:

Council requested a presentation from TransformHealthRx Correctional Health
Service. THRX provides inmate medical services including medical, mental and
dental care.

If a contract with the company is approved, the county will pay THRX about
$364,804 in the first year based on a maximum inmate population of 350. The
county would also be responsible for medical supplies and equipment.

Orangeburg County is in the process of assuming management of the
Orangeburg-Calhoun Regional Detention Center.

Currently, two nurses and the Regional Medical Center provide medical services
at the jail. Inmates have to leave the jail to receive services.
TransformHealthRx would provide services in the jail and result in savings of a
couple of thousand dollars, Young said.

The issue was referred to committee.

Council gave first reading to an ordinance accepting a $6.7 million U.S.
Department of Agriculture Rural Development loan to provide interim financing
for the Goodby's Creek Regional Wastewater Treatment plant and Sanders Pointe
Farm Effluent Land Application site.

The wastewater plant will be located behind the John W. Matthews Jr. Industrial
Park near U.S. 301 and U.S. 176. It will serve the park and surrounding
communities.

Council gave first reading to an ordinance authorizing a line transfer and water
delivery agreement between the town of Santee and Orangeburg County. The
ordinance would allow Santee to serve customers along the portion of the U.S.
301 pipeline that extends from the city to a location just west of the
intersection of U.S. 301 and S.C. 47.

Council gave third and final reading to an ordinance postponing property
reassessment for a year. The postponement was deemed necessary to ensure
appraisers have the specific qualifications required due to changes in the law.

Council approved giving $20,000 to Santee Cooper Country and $6,000 to Elloree
from Accommodation Tax funds to promote tourism.

Entered into executive session for an economic development matter and a
contractual agreement. No vote was taken.

                                  The Observer

                                January 4, 1998

Rundown inner cities may be the best places to build five million new homes . .
. but where would YOU rather live?;
Government tries to head off countryside campaigners as it extends housing
target for next 20 years

BYLINE: BY BARRY HUGILL AND ROGER TREDRE

SECTION: The Observer News Page; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 1081 words


THE Government is updating the number of new homes it calculates will be needed
over the next 20 years: it anticipates up to 5.5 million units will be required,
rather than the 4.4 million previously planned.

The new target will only be met by concreting over thousands of acres of rural
England.

The projection of 4.4 million was drawn up by the Department of the Environment
under John Gummer in 1995, and has been criticised by environmentalists who
claim it overestimates demand. But Civil Service sources and housing experts
have confirmed that the Government believes it is an under -estimate. Local
authorities have been busy drawing up strategic plans based on the earlier
figure and will bitterly resist any attempt by Whitehall to force them to allow
more development.

Desperate to avert a battle with the powerful environmental lobby, the
Government is searching for ways of encouraging development in cities rather
than the country. Under consideration by the Treasury is a plan to harmonise VAT
on building.

Current legislation encourages developers to plough up greenfield sites because
they are zero-rated for VAT. But refurbishment of long-empty homes carries full
17.5 per cent VAT. Housing experts believe harmonisation at 5 per cent would not
cut revenue and would significantly boost city development.

A report commissioned by the Government on housing in London, to be published
this week, claims most of the 630,000 new households required in the capital
could be accommodated without building on greenfield sites - but only after
dramatic limits on parking and car use.

The man responsible for the future shape of both the city and the countryside is
John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, who is keen to emphasise his 'green'
credentials. He claims to favour a renaissance of 'urban villages' to slow the
building of new houses in the countryside.

But he is also aware that survey after survey indicates that many people would
prefer to live in country towns and villages.

To meet that aspiration, new homes have to be built, and that means inroads into
the green belt and howls of protest from environmentalists. In one of the most
bizarre political developments of recent years, a coalition of 'shire' Tories
and green activists is taking shape, pledged to resist further development.

Professor Peter Hall of Reading University, chairman of the Town and Country
Planning Association, believes the five million projection is accurate:
'Unpopular decisions have to be taken. We are witnessing self-interest dressed
up as environmentalism. Much of the protest is another example of the not-in
-my-back-yard syndrome. We have to look at the human environment, as well as the
natural one. We tend to care about newts but not humans.'

So far Mr Prescott has upset almost every interest group in his effort to sort
out the mess. Local authorities are required to draw up plans for future growth,
and the more rural are reluctant to allow large-scale housing development. West
Sussex was prepared to grant permission for 30,700 new homes, but just before
Christmas the Deputy Prime Minister ordered 50,700. This pleased the builders
and the building societies, but outraged everyone else, from local Tory and
Liberal Democrat councillors to Friends of the Earth and countryside groups.

Later this month Friends of the Earth is linking up with the anti-roads group,
Alarm UK (new houses mean new roads), to plan a resistance campaign which will
not be confined to West Sussex. Hampshire, Cheshire, Devon, Surrey,
Gloucestershire, Somerset and Wiltshire are on a collision course with Mr
Prescott. The inevitable protest campaign will take its lead from Swampy and
friends, with genteel ladies of the shires sitting down in front of bulldozers.

The most vocal opponent of development is the Council for the Protection of
Rural England. To spearhead its opposition, it has called on the formidable duo
of Prunella Scales, immortalised as Sybil from Fawlty Towers, and Gulf War hero
Sir Peter de la Billiere. Mr Prescott is unlikely to relish a scrap with these
two.

The alternative is to encourage people to stay in the cities, but many experts
do not believe this is viable. Professor Hall has no objection to 'brownfield'
development, but doubts that more than 40 per cent of need could be met in ths
way.

Merron Simpson of the Chartered Institute of Housing is an advocate of city
regeneration, but says there are a lot of 'buts'. She says: 'The difficulty is
that brownfield sites are expensive because the land is often heavily polluted.
Maybe we should be thinking about making companies who have made the mess pay to
clean it up. Yes, we should place more emphasis on refurbishment of empty
property and conversion of unwanted office blocks and industrial buildings, but
in the end it's about what people want. Single people are more likely to stay in
the city, but increasingly they want two-bedroom units. It's the problem of
rising expectations.'

Bob Lawrence, director of the Empty Homes Agency, the Government-funded body
responsible for filling empty houses and flats, is sceptical about the projected
demand, but accepts there will have to be greenfield development.

'With the introduction of student loans, more young people will stay at home.
And cut-backs in housing benefit will probably mean more single mothers staying
with their parents.'

Ammunition for the green lobby will arrive on Tuesday, with publication of a
report commissioned by the London Planning Advisory Committee, the Government
Office for London and the Department of the Environment, Transport and the
Regions.

It claims most of the new homes needed in London could be accommodated without
building on greenfield sites.

Planning consultants Llewelyn-Davies, who wrote the report, recommend an
overhaul of Britain's low housing density guidelines. Densities as high as 500
habitable rooms per hectare could be achieved, they say, if parking spaces were
limited, compared with current densities of 125-250.

Dr Patrick Clark, technical director of Llewelyn-Davies, believes good public
transport and restrictions on car use are the crucial elements: 'Up to now, the
debate has been conducted in wholly negative terms. But the demand for new
housing presents an opportunity for urban Britain to reinvent itself.

'The truth is that Britain's town centres have too few people living in them -
not too many.'

                              Daily the Pak Banker

                           January 13, 2011 Thursday

World Bank: US$40 Million for Social Housing -- 10,000 Low Income Families will
benefit

LENGTH: 601  words

DATELINE: Karachi


Karachi, Jan. 13 -- The World Bank Board of Directors (WB) approved a US$40
million loan today for the Social Macro Projects Program in Colombia, seeking to
facilitate low income populations' access to housing with all basic services and
infrastructure.

This type of initiative is generally implemented by municipalities; however,
this priority social housing program is being promoted and executed by the
national government.

The program will help implement between four and six macro projects in several
cities around the country through a public-private partnership authorizing
construction sites and household construction.

The project will finance public-private partnerships that require the
intervention of the public sector for on-site real state integration, the
establishment of urban regulations for land use and exploitation and the
organization of additional financing schemes. The participation of the private
sector is present in the establishment of the real estate trust fund, in project
financing and the contracting of a private party for its execution.

This public-private co-responsibility model allows builders to assume part of
the project's risks (financial and building, among others) while boosting that
sector's future management capacity through the experience generated by this
program.

"I am extremely pleased for the support of the World Bank that will help
Colombia to address the housing problem facing thousands of Colombian families
who are in need for a place to live.

We are making the greatest effort possible to provide timely solutions to
low-income households, especially those located in areas where risks cannot be
mitigated. Support from this loan will support housing development for six
macroproyects, which account for about 8,000 to 10,000 homes and aims to improve
the living standards for those most in need," said Beatriz Uribe, Minister for
the Environment, Housing and Land Development (MAVDT).

The initiative seeks the following objectives:

*Build priority social housing, with quality and dignity;

* Develop infrastructure (water supply and sanitation, drainage, transportation
and mobility structures, gas and energy networks) for low income social sectors;

* Improve the government's institutional capacity in land management for low
income households; and

* Produce a series of studies to increase the management and executive capacity
of the building sector in Colombia.

"With this project we support the Colombian government's efforts to reduce the
national housing deficit through the development of an innovative public-private
financial management model. We will continue to work for those who need it the
most," said Gloria Grandolini, World Bank Director for Colombia and Mexico.

The Program will be implemented between 2011 and 2014. It involves a mix of
implementation, monitoring and supervisory activities concentrated nationally at
the Ministry for the Environment, Housing and Land Development (MAVDT) and the
National Housing Fund (FONVIVIENDA). The MAVDT will be the recipient and
executor of the loan through FONVIVIENDA, a body attached to the MAVDT.

The total cost of the program is estimated at US$74.7 million, US$40 million of
which will be financed by the World Bank and the remainder by project
developers.

This is a US dollar-denominated loan, with a fixed margin interest rate + LIBOR.
The project is expected to end December 31st, 2014. Published by HT Syndication
with permission from Daily Pak Banker. For any query with respect to this
article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at
htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                           Canberra Times (Australia)

                       January 12, 1999, Tuesday Edition

KICKSTART 'SUCCESSFUL' IN HELPING HOME BUYERS

BYLINE: GRAHAM COOKE

SECTION: Part A; Page 4

LENGTH: 535 words


The ACT Government's Kickstart home-buying program has been wound up - with
Urban Services Minister Brendan Smyth claiming it was a complete success.

He said the program, which ended as scheduled on December 31, had helped 610
people get into homes, and given boosts to the real estate and construction
industries.

It assisted people on low and moderate incomes, and eligible public-housing
tenants, to buy their own homes with a grant of $5000 towards the deposit, and
other concessions relating to stamp duty, legal and mortgage costs.

Mr Smyth said Kickstart had been set up when the housing industry was going
through a slump. Now the economy was improving and the program had clearly
served its purpose.

A spokesman for Mr Smyth's office said the Government had kept a tight grip on
land releases since a big surplus was identified in 1993 and '94.

As a result much of the slack has been taken up, and we are returning to normal
the spokesman said.

Nationally, the Colonial State Bank says activity in the building industry
flattened towards the end of 1998, but does not show signs of entering a
significant slump. To a large extent this reflects a lack of oversupply and the
gentle upswing of the last housing cycle, together with relatively easy monetary
the bank says.

Overall approvals for dwellings rose 0.3 per cent in November after a 2.1 per
cent gain in October. They are down 5.1 per cent on a year ago.

Queensland, with a fall of 19.6 per cent over the past 12 months, is the worst
hit, but state president Ross Wallace predicts these very conditions have
created a buyer's market which should bear fruit during 1999.

Increased consumer confidence became apparent towards the end of 1998 and
although it may take some time, perhaps up to nine months, we should eventually
see sales activity on the he said.  A rates revaluation of Yarrowlumla Shire
indicates a strengthening house-site market on a low base at Captains Flat, but
prices down 10 per cent from 1994 levels at Bungendore and Sutton.

There were also mixed re sults among hobby farms and rural home sites. Prices at
Geary's Gap, Fernleigh Park, Radcliffe and Burra have fallen between 3 and 15
per cent, but those at Hoskingtown are up 10 per cent - again from a low base.
The house at 17 McLachlan Crescent, Weetangera, featured in the Sunday Des Res
column late last year, sold before the scheduled auction for $405,000, a record
price for the suburb, Mike Liddiard, of Raine and Horne (Belconnen), said.

He said the previous owners, who had built the house, were pleased with the
price, and the fact it was going to a family. The buyers are tennis players and
I think the court that comes with the house clinched he said.

Meanwhile, the turn-out at an exhibition of former ANU duplexes on Sunday was
outstanding, Andrew Chamberlain, of Peter Blackshaw Real Estate, said. The
duplex complex was the subject of Sunday's Des Res.

On a normal exhibition day we give out about 10 information he said. For this
one I prepared 40 and they were all gone in the first seven minutes. I had to
send back to the office for another 50.154 He said about 20 of the 70 homes were
now sold.

                               The Daily Yomiuri

                           January 11, 1994, Tuesday

Housing corp. refuses;
bulk of land offerings

BYLINE: Yomiuri Shimbun

SECTION: Pg. 8

LENGTH: 246 words


Only one parcel of land has so far been deemed appropriate for residential use
out of about 500 properties offered for sale by private landowners to the
government-financed Housing and Urban Development Corp. between April and
September 1993, the government agency said Monday.

It blamed the poor showing on the fact that much of the land offered was too
expensive and too small to build condominiums.

Many of the properties offered include real estate held by financial
institutions which collected the land as collateral from bad loans. Other
properties, offered by developers, were originally meant for commercial uses.

Of the 500 applications, the housing corporation has turned down 395. Sixty-four
were rated too expensive and more than 50 were too narrow for a site to build
housing complexes accommodating more than 50 families.

The corporation is now assessing about 80 remaining applications, but it said
only a few application will be accepted.

Observers said the corporation's inability to purchase properties being held as
collateral could result in calls from landowners for the government to use
public funds directly to purchase real estate.

A committee on land reform formed by the Sakigake and the Japan New Party, both
part of the ruling coalition, has proposed that the government disburse public
funds from its fiscal investment and loan program for the purchase of land held
by financial institutions for urban development projects.

                        Las Vegas (Nev.) Review-Journal

                            November 7, 2004, Sunday

Real estate instructor encourages Las Vegas new-home buyers to persevere

BYLINE: By Hubble Smith

LENGTH: 608 words



First-time home buyers who are having a hard time finding affordable housing in
Las Vegas shouldn't throw in the towel, a real estate instructor said.

A number of city, state and federal programs are available to assist those who
meet annual income guidelines set by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban
Development.

Ozzie Boyle, who teaches a free class every Tuesday on first-time home buyer
programs, said the city of Henderson has a program that provides up to 4 percent
of the purchase price plus closing costs, with a deferred payment loan at no
interest.

Buyers must make a minimum investment of $ 750 and have less than $ 10,000 in
assets, not including automobiles and furniture.

The cities of Las Vegas and North Las Vegas have home-buyer assistance programs
with as little as a $ 500 minimum investment. Clark County's program allows $
25,000 in assets.

Nevada Fair Housing Center has "Catch the Dream," a loan program that requires
no minimum credit score and matches buyers' savings at 4-to-1, with a minimum
contribution of $ 25 a month for 12 months.

"The reason I'm doing this is you have all these programs and no one has a forum
to explain all six or seven of these programs," said Boyle, who holds the class
at 6:30 p.m. Tuesdays in the Wells Fargo branch at 2231 N. Green Valley Parkway.

"Part of it is educating these kids that they don't necessarily have to have a
house. You can get a condo. It's almost like a feeding frenzy here in the desert
to get a brand-new home. Kids are still thinking that way."

Annual household income must not exceed $ 31,650 for one person, $ 36,150 for
two people, $ 40,700 for three and $ 45,200 for a family of four or more.

"It's hard to find people with low income and good credit," said Ron Trunk of
Citizens for Affordable Homes in Carson City. "The trick is to find hard-working
people with decent credit. They don't have to have cash."

Citizens for Affordable Homes helps families build homes in rural areas of
Nevada using federal money from the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The group
built 25 homes in Dayton and has 30 acres in Pahrump, where the average home
price will be $ 130,000, Trunk said.

The families are spared the down payment, but must work 35 hours a week split
between the head of household and spouse helping to build the house.

"It's a federal program, it's not free," Trunk said. "These families have to
qualify, they pay interest on the loan, they pay taxes. This is the hardest
program that anybody will ever do other than having a baby."

The Agriculture Department provides money for the first deed on the home and
Affordable Homes uses other money for additional assistance.

For example, if someone qualifies for $ 100,000 and the house costs $ 130,000,
the extra $ 30,000 can be covered as a silent second mortgage with no interest
payments until the home is refinanced or sold, Trunk said.

Boyle's Web site is www.realestatefordummies.net. Trunk's is www.cahinev.org.

Housing Opportunities Programs and Education, a nonprofit organization, is
sponsoring a meeting for prospective home buyers and sellers on at 6:30 p.m.,
Nov. 15 at Cimmaron-Rose Community Center, 5591 N. Cimmaron Road.

Information will be presented on how to obtain grants for down payment
assistance.

Home inspection companies, mortgage lenders, title companies and home repair
experts will attend, along with Realtor Dawn Lane of Century 21 Barrett, founder
of HOPE.

                            December 13, 2010 Monday

WB: US$30 Million for Water and Sanitation in 200 Rural Communities in Peru

LENGTH: 634  words

DATELINE: Karachi


Karachi, Dec. 13 -- The World Bank Board of Directors approved additional
financing worth US$30 million for the National Rural Water and Sanitation
Program (PRONASAR) to expand the coverage and sustainability of water and
sanitation services in rural areas of Peru.

Through this new loan, the World Bank supports the efforts undertaken by
PRONASAR to guarantee that remote communities have access to more and better
water and sanitation services. Moreover, this project will keep promoting the
adoption of good hygiene practices through communications campaigns.

"To date, PRONASAR has managed to build and rehabilitate water and sanitation
systems in 283 rural communities, decisively contributing to an improvement in
the quality of life and health of the most vulnerable populations," said Vanessa
Vereau, General Coordinator of the National Rural Water and Sanitation Program
Management Unit, part of Peru's Ministry of Housing, Construction and
Sanitation.

This additional financing will provide clean water sources to close to 320,000
people in approximately 200 communities, through the expansion and repair of
water supply systems with an emphasis on the creation and training of Management
Committees for Sanitation Services (JASS) to guarantee service sustainability.
New water supplies consist of piping networks with home connections, public
pools, protection of springs, wells or rainwater capture systems, according to
the preferences and possibilities of communities consulted in the process prior
to construction.

"New facilities will be sustainable in the long term through efficient planning
and skilled labor guaranteeing high quality water services, adequate training
for those responsible for operations and expanded education on hygiene. These
investments will contribute to the improvement of quality of life in rural
communities," said Felipe Jaramillo, World Bank Director for Bolivia, Chile,
Ecuador, Peru and Venezuela.

The project is composed of three items:

1. Finance the construction, rehabilitation and expansion of rural water and
sanitation systems; provide on-site sanitation solutions, as well as technical
assistance for the establishment of new Management Committees for Sanitation
Services (JASS) and the reinforcement of existing ones to promote education on
hygiene.

2. Provide pilot technical assistance to establish specialized operators, as
well as private or municipal cooperatives, in order to invest in management,
rehabilitation, improvement and expansion of water supply and sanitation
services.

3. Strengthen the capacity of the Vice-Ministry of Sanitation and National
Sanitation Directorate with regards to policies and regulatory functions related
to rural sanitation, support district municipalities' role in monitoring and
controlling services and personnel training, and selected studies, as well as
the establishment and maintenance of a Sectorial Information System.

This operation forms an integral part of a World Bank package that includes
financing, technical assistance, knowledge, and coordination and notification
services, in order to support the government and provide better solutions to the
problem of water service shortages due to the effects of climate change, in an
integral manner.

The total cost of this project is US$50.9 million, US$30 million of which will
be financed by the World Bank and US$20.9 million by the government counterpart.

This investment loan has a variable interest rate (LIBOR), a short, 12-year
maturity period, and includes an 11-year grace period. The finalization of this
project is programmed for December, 2013. Published by HT Syndication with
permission from Daily Pak Banker. For any query with respect to this article or
any other content requirement, please contact Editor at
htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                             Sunday Times (London)

                            February 8, 2004, Sunday

Landlords reap rewards from farmland

BYLINE: Kathryn Cooper

SECTION: Features; Money; 5

LENGTH: 1288 words


Buy-to-let investors are turning to more unusual properties, such as farms and
new developments in eastern Europe. By Kathryn Cooper.

INVESTORS are moving away from traditional buy-to-let and seeking more exotic
ways to profit from property.

Some have been buying farmland, pushing prices to a record high, according to
the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics).

Firms are cashing in on the appetite for alternative property investments with
new funds. Here, we assess your options.

Buying farmland

About half of all people buying rural land are not farmers. In the southeast,
the proportion is about 65%. These buyers typically look for rural land with a
residential property in which they can live for at least part of the year. The
property might also have outbuildings that could be redeveloped and let out as a
holiday home or as office units. Local farmers might be contracted to manage the
land.

Julian Sayers of Rics said: "Prices are rising as rural land becomes an
appealing investment for those with cash to spend in the property market. We may
well see this trend continue when City bonuses are announced.

"Rural land and conventional residential property are equally attractive long
term investments. In both cases, prices are kept high by a lack of supply. With
land, however, you get the chance to enjoy the countryside for at least part of
the year."

It does not come cheap, however. On average, you might pay between Pounds
500,000 and £1m for a modest 50 or 60-acre farm with a residential property in
England or Wales, according to Rics.

Most of the big banks and building societies have agricultural divisions that
will offer mortgages on farmland, but you must usually have a deposit of between
25% and 50%. Mortgage rates are normally higher than for residential loans; you
might pay between one and five percentage points above the base rate, or up to
9% at a base rate of 4%.

Farmland also enjoys tax breaks. Normally, your heirs pay inheritance tax (IHT)
on the value of your estate above the annual exemption, currently Pounds
255,000. If you own rural land and rent it to a farmer, however, it becomes
exempt from IHT once you have owned it for seven years. Alternatively, if you
set up a business that has a contract with the farmer, the land becomes exempt
from IHT after two years.

Investors also pay a lower rate of capital-gains tax (CGT) on any profits if the
land is let or contracted to a farming business. The rate of CGT for a higher
rate taxpayer would be just 10% if you had owned the farm for two years or more,
compared with between 24% and 40% for most other assets.

Always take specialist advice before buying farmland. Sayers said: "Ask what
your responsibilities might be. Your plot of land might include a site of
special scientific interest, for example, and you would be responsible for its
management.

It is also essential that your surveyor finds out about previous uses that may
have contaminated the land."

Buying off plan

A number of companies have launched investment schemes that purchase property
"off plan", or before they are built. Last week, for example, Urban Exposure, an
investment company, launched its Property Trading Plan. The fund will pool your
money with that of other investors to buy homes before construction starts and
then sell them before completion.

Say a building company has planning permission to construct a property that will
be completed in two years' time. If the home were standing today, it might be
worth £100,000.

An investor could sign a contract with the builder to buy the property in two
years for £100,000. The builder has hedged against the risk that the home will
be worth less in two years' time; the investor gets an opportunity to profit if
it is worth more. You would usually have to put down a deposit of 10%, or
£10,000

Suppose the property is worth £200,000 two years later. The investor agrees to
sell it to another buyer just before completion, so he or she never actually
takes possession.

Out of the £200,000 from the sale, the investor must pay the builder £90,000
(£100,000 minus the deposit of £10,000), leaving a gain of £110,000 for an
initial outlay of £10,000 -a 1,000% profit.

The investor would have to pay CGT on the profit, but would not be liable for
stamp duty because he or she has never completed on the property.

The risks of purchasing off plan are high. David Bitner of the Marketplace at
Bradford & Bingley, an adviser, said:

"People have been lucky over the past few years because prices have soared,
producing huge gains. In the future, however, it might not be so easy.

"As more investors get in on the act there is a greater risk that the market
will be oversupplied with properties when you want to get out of the deal, and
you could struggle to get the right price."

If house prices slide, off-plan investors may find themselves with a contract to
buy property for more than its value.

Imagine that in the above example the value of the £100,000 property falls to
£80,000 over two years. The investor cannot sell and must therefore honour the
contract to buy the home for £90,000.

The investor might be able to get a mortgage of only £68,000 (85% of £80,000)
and would therefore by forced to fork out another £22,000, on top of the
deposit, to buy the home.

Mike Boles of Savills Private Finance, an adviser, said: "Some of these funds
may be jumping on the 'off plan' bandwagon a little late. Investors have made
big money from the strategy in recent years, but it is unlikely to contine
indefinitely.

"Always find out exactly where the fund will invest. There may be limited
opportunities in London and the southeast, but better prospects in the north.

Buying overseas

Landlords are being tempted into property hotspots overseas, particularly
eastern Europe, as fears grow that the market in Britain has peaked. Property
prices in countries such as the Czech Republic are expected to boom over the
next few years as their economies are boosted by entry into the European Union.

Letterstone, a property firm, recently offered investors the chance to buy flats
in a development in Prague. The properties were offered "off plan" at a discount
of up to 17% of their value. Investors put down an initial deposit and will have
to pay the balance on completion, when they can keep the property and let it -or
sell.

But investors in eastern Europe should take care. Boles said: "The property and
mortgage markets are immature. Buying off plan is always a punt, particularly in
a market of which you have little understanding.

"Mortgages may be difficult -although not impossible -to arrange, and the local
rental market could be unproven. I suggest using a British lawyer with a local
affiliate to provide an independent evaluation."

Investors are also being bombarded with "sale and leaseback" deals, where you
buy a property and nominate several weeks a year when you will have sole use.

Then you lease it back to the developer who manages the property and lets it out
for the rest of the year. In return, you get a pre-arranged income.

Schemes often guarantee minimum rental yields of 6% to 7%, but these assume you
buy the property for cash and do not need to use the rental income to cover a
mortgage.

You do not usually have complete freedom over when you sell; the scheme may tie
you in for a number of years.

Experts also warn that some plans are not well-regulated, so there may be no
redress if they collapse. They usually recommend that you employ an independent
solicitor to value your property before signing up to an overseas scheme.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                           December 14, 1997, Sunday

Cell tower placement riles rural residents

BYLINE: TIM GRANT

SECTION: NORTH OF TAMPA; ZONING; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 829 words

DATELINE: ODESSA



   In an area of cypress stands and scenic, rural vistas, a 200-foot
communications tower might stick out like a . . . like a 200-foot tower sticks
out almost anywhere, only more so.

That's why a group of homeowners oppose a rezoning request to locate a  cellular
communications tower at the intersection of Hutchison and Wilcox  roads.

They gave the zoning hearing master a list of 83 signatures from residents  of
Lake Leclare, Country Place, Belle Meade and Belle Glen.

Property owner Natalie Worthington has big plans for the 27-acre site. She
intends to divide the land into four pieces that would include a housing
development, a recreation area, town homes and the communications tower.

But although towers can be unsightly, so are TECO stations, GTE telephone  lines
and government pump stations. All of them are needed by the community  and so
are communications towers, said zoning hearing master Andrew Baker.

Baker has recommended that the communications tower be approved. He tends  to
think it might even be camouflaged by the cypress trees. County  commissioners
will decide the issue on Jan. 13. (Petition No. 97-0371KE)

KEYSTONE: County commissioners remanded the Toll Brothers project back to  the
zoning hearing master to review traffic issues that have been brought up  about
Race Track Road.

Toll Brothers Inc. plans to build a residential project on 322 acres north  of
Race Track Road and east of Nine Eagles Road. The development would include  a
golf course, two clubhouses, an over-water driving range, 167 detached  single
family homes and 258 town homes.

Commissioners are concerned about the impact that traffic would have on  Race
Track Road, a designated scenic corridor, and have asked the zoning  hearing
master to gather more information. (Petition No. 97-0319)

KEYSTONE: One of the largest residential developments proposed in the  Keystone
area is being considered by the zoning hearing master.

Representatives of FL Tampa West Inc. have asked to rezone 210 acres from
planned development research corporate park to planned development.

The company wants to build up to 300 attached and/or detached single family  or
multifamily homes a quarter of a mile north of Race Track Road, on the west
side of Nine Eagles Road.

The zoning hearing master will make his recommendation on Dec. 22. County
commissioners will vote on the proposal Jan. 13. (Petition No. RZ 98-0019)

KEYSTONE: Reptron Electronics wants to reduce the acreage and development
rights of Tri-County Business Park in order to develop up to 300 single or
multifamily homes.

Reptron also wants the 386 acres to be significantly modified to permit  400,000
square feet of industrial use rather than the originally approved  3.7-million
square feet.

While the company is selling 210 acres for a housing development to the  north,
it is retaining 115 acres it doesn't use and is asking the county to  designate
the parcel for a 100,000-square-foot office building and another
150,000-square-foot manufacturing and warehouse facility.

Reptron's current factory has 150,000 square feet. Commissioners also will  vote
on this proposal Jan. 13. (Petition No. MM 98-0041)

NORTHDALE: Landowner Arthur Schaer's proposal to build 19 homes northwest  of
Gaither High School will go before the zoning hearing master on Monday.

Schaer, an Odessa resident, proposes the houses for 9 acres he bought at  the
southern foot of Woodacre Lane. He wants to extend Woodacre to the south  and
east, around a 2 1/2-acre cypress stand.

The land is currently zoned agricultural. Schaer is asking for a planned
development zoning. (Petition No. RZ 98-56 KE)

WESTCHASE: The zoning hearing master on Monday will hear Westchase's
developer's request to remove the office designation from 26 acres in order to
build about 120 "courtyard" homes.

The homes would face a landscaped community walkway with small yards and  low
fences, but no street. The garages would be accessible from rear alleys.  In
case the concept doesn't appeal to buyers, Westchase has also sought  permission
to develop apartments on the property.

Westchase wants to switch 2 acres on Sheldon Road, north of Linebaugh, to a
retail designation instead of offices.

Because Westchase received "entitlements" to a large area of development  in its
original rezoning, such shifts of uses from one parcel to another is  considered
a "major modification," not a rezoning. (Petition No. MM 98-64)

Where and when

Hearings of county zoning hearing masters and land-use hearing officers, and
land-use meetings of the County Commission are held on the second floor of the
County Center, 601 E Kennedy Blvd. Zoning hearings begin at 6 p.m. and
commission meetings begin at 9 a.m. Both are televised live on
government-access channels. The land-use hearings, which are not televised,
begin at 9 a.m. For information, call 272-5920.

                              The Washington Post

                                 Final Edition

Revitalization Corporation Plays It Close to the Vest

BYLINE: Debbi Wilgoren

SECTION: Metro; C05 , OFF THE BEAT: D.C. DEVELOPMENT Debbi Wilgoren

LENGTH: 627 words


The National Capital Revitalization Corporation, the District's publicly
chartered real estate firm, has earmarked more than $20 million to buy a
blighted retail complex in the Hillcrest neighborhood of Southeast Washington
and prepare it for redevelopment as a more upscale shopping center.

Officials are seeking a short-term federal loan, and may borrow D.C. capital
funds, to make some initial land purchases. They are taking steps toward using
tax-increment financing -- which lets retailers or developers borrow money to
launch a project, then pay back the loans using a percentage of the taxes
generated by the project -- as an incentive to draw popular stores to the site.

But officials at the revitalization corporation are reluctant to talk about the
plan.

They say they don't want prices to climb for the 18 parcels that make up the
20-acre Skyland site and are owned by 15 individuals or corporate partnerships,
some of whom have sought to have parts of the 55-year-old shopping center
declared a historic landmark that could not be torn down.

"We don't want to expose ourselves and drive up the costs," said Theodore
Carter, chief executive of the revitalization corporation. "It's an expensive
project."

That's why a news release issued after a board meeting late last month made no
mention of the $28.7 million the corporation will make when it completes sale of
a parcel near Union Station to an office developer late this year. The board
plans to set aside much of the money to purchase and develop the Skyland site,
off Alabama Avenue SE -- a case in which downtown profits would directly benefit
an underserved neighborhood.

Buried near the bottom of the announcement is a vaguely worded paragraph that
refers to, but does not fully explain, what the board actually voted for at its
Jan. 21 meeting: to direct Carter to seek permission from the city to use
eminent domain, if necessary, to buy part of the Skyland site; to ask the D.C.
Council to authorize tax-increment financing for the project; to seek a bridge
loan from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development for land
purchases.

The board was not actually borrowing any money or authorizing any financing or
seizing any property -- it was merely launching the multi-step process required
to make some or all of those things happen.

But Carter and Eric W. Price, the District's deputy mayor for economic
development, acknowledge that the actions are important to the project, which is
strongly supported by Hillcrest residents and civic leaders.

So why not shout it from the hilltops, instead of putting out a public
announcement that opens with lots of old information about the developer chosen
to build the new shopping center?

Peggy Armstrong, the revitalization corporation's communications director, who
came from the mayor's office, took some responsibility, saying she may have
underestimated the importance of the seemingly small first steps in the process.

But she also said the three-year-old corporation, although congressionally
chartered and launched with $25 million in public funding, is still learning to
balance the need for public accountability with its private-sector desire to
keep details of deals quiet until they are done.

Carter stressed that the land acquisition was simply the first obstacle and said
he hoped the public would be patient as the corporation tried to move forward.

"If the private sector could do it, it would be done already," Carter said,
adding that there are years of hard work ahead before residents may be able to
shop at a new center. "If we're clicking on all cylinders, and the city
[government] is moving, we could probably get it done and have a ribbon-cutting
in three years," he said. "But that's a best-case scenario."

                           The Taos News (New Mexico)

                            August 28, 2008 Thursday

ENVIRONMENTAL BRIEFS

SECTION: VALLE VISTA/REGIONAL; Pg. B-9

LENGTH: 474 words


Taos Canyon campgrounds closed

The concessionaire who was overseeing three overnight campgrounds up Taos Canyon
has resigned, forcing Carson National Forest officials to shut the gates for the
rest of the year.

Hikers and anglers can still access the Río Fernando and trails by parking
outside the locked gates at Las Petacas, Capulín and La Sombra campgrounds along
US 64, according to Carson Forest spokesperson Kathy DeLucas.

However, no overnight camping will be allowed for the rest of the season.

Forest officials will put out requests for bids in the fall in order to hire
another concessionaire, who lives at the site and collects overnight fees.

'Green' Habitat streamlines rules

After several meetings, Habitat for Humanity-Taos has developed criteria for an
affordable-housing design competition.

Addressing both a shortage of low-priced housing and a trend toward
energy-efficient construction, Habitat is seeking template designs for two- and
three-bedroom homes, and two- and four-plex apartment buildings.

An ad hoc committee has developed guidelines and requirements for competition
submissions that focus on low energy use and recycled materials.

Cash prizes for the best plans range from $1,000 to $5,000, following judging by
construction and energy experts.

For more information, call Jim O'Donnell at (505) 779-1181.

Water, wastewater funding online

New Mexico Environment Department officials have streamlined the application
process for municipalities and other government entities seeking water and
wastewater funding.

Now, only one form will have to be filled out when applying for state and
federal funding. That form is available at: http://ufa.nmenv.state.nm.us.

Funding agencies on the Web site include state Environment Department,
Department of Finance and Administration, New Mexico Finance Authority, Water
Trust Board, state legislative Capital Outlay Subcommittee, U.S. Department of
Agriculture's Rural Development and U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.

Gov. Bill Richardson created the Water and Wastewater Infrastructure Development
Division in order to ease the burden of applying for grants and loans.

For information, go to the Web site or call (877) 654-8720.

Non-commercial

forest-owners get help

The 2008 Farm Bill includes cost-sharing programs for people who own forest land
but do not produce timber products.

The Environment Quality Incentives Program offers financial assistance for
forest management, such as planting, thinning and slash treatment.

According to the Natural Resources Conservation Service, eight percent of New
Mexico forests are privately owned; 45 percent of American forests are
non-public lands.

The agency also has wildlife habitat, conservation and health forest incentive
programs from private landowners.

For information, go to www.nm.nrcs.usda.gov and click on Programs.

-- Compiled by Andy Dennison

The Journal Record Business Briefs: May 14, 2010

BYLINE: The Journal Record Staff

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 1221  words


TU's Business College receives certificate in knowledge management The
University of Tulsa's Collins College of Business Center for Executive and
Professional Development has been awarded a new certificate in Integrated
Knowledge and Project Management. The three-course certificate for business and
industry offers a platform for taking lessons from projects and incorporating
data and the human process improvements back into the company's organizational
knowledge base. "Many companies are beginning to realize that baby boomer
retirement may mean key operational knowledge literally walks out the door,"
said Linda Adlof, director of the Center for Executive and Professional
Development. "Organizational knowledge may be a company's competitive advantage.
Certificate participants will learn a model for capturing and transferring the
knowledge not just for the next project, but for the long-term sustainability of
the company. " This three-course certificate, presented in partnership with
consultant Chuck Tyron, is comprised of three single-day courses - Project Based
Knowledge Management, Modern Project Management and Creating Quality Plans.
Participants may enroll in individual courses or the three-day certificate. A
single course is $395 and the fee for all three courses is $995. For
information, call (918) 631-2784.

Cole appoints Powell as field representative U.S. Sen. Tom Cole, R-Okla., has
appointed Tyler Powell as field representative in the Lawton region. Powell will
be replacing Keri Dennis, who has accepted a position with Triangle Insurance
Co. Powell recently graduated from Oklahoma State University with a degree in
agribusiness. He served as an intern in the Oklahoma House and Senate
agriculture committees.

U.S. Cellular expands Sapulpa area network U.S. Cellular has completed
construction of an additional cell site in Sapulpa. A new 105-foot site off of
Highway 66 near E. Line Street will increase U.S. Cellular's coverage for the
east side of the city of Sapulpa and will also complement U.S. Cellular's
statewide network of 635 towers.

Frontier Country offers 'Hour with an Expert' Frontier Country Marketing
Association's "Hour With an Expert" marketing meeting is scheduled at 10 a.m.
Thursday at the Cox Media offices, 6301 Waterford Blvd., Suite 305, Oklahoma
City. Topics will include using Cox Media's entertainment networks for
marketing. "It seems like we are all hesitant when it comes to selling our
product on television," said Sherri Rogers, executive director of Frontier
Country Marketing Association. "This is a great opportunity to overcome any
fears and concerns our tourism businesses may have. Additionally, we will learn
more about its affordability, what networks work best for showcasing our
products and the best ways to reach our target markets. " The marketing meeting
is free to all Frontier Country members and $10 for nonmembers. Call (405)
232-6552 by Tuesday for reservations.

USDA seeks applicants for rural housing grant program The U.S. Department of
Agriculture Rural Development is accepting applications for the Housing
Preservation Grant program. June 28 is the deadline for organizations to file
applications, said Ryan McMullen, USDA Rural Development state director. The
program is part of the Obama administration's efforts to improve access to
affordable housing in rural areas, McMullen said. Applicants may include public
agencies, nonprofit organizations and federally recognized tribal governments
that will use the grant money to assist very low- and low-income rural
homeowners repair their homes. The program offers assistance to rental property
owners and cooperative housing complexes in rural areas to rehabilitate units in
exchange for making the units available to very low- and low-income people. Last
year, five Oklahoma organizations shared nearly $250,000 in grant awards to help
about 60 individuals. Last year's projects ranged from providing storm shelters,
to replacing leaking roofs or deteriorated siding, to installing windows, doors,
and insulation. "I am confident that Oklahoma organizations will continue to
submit solid applications to this unique federal program," said McMullen. "The
small taxpayer investment and very modest home improvements can make a very
large impact in the lives of rural Oklahomans. " For information, call (800)
522-3819.

Sandler Training opens in Oklahoma City Sandler Training, a corporate training
organization, has opened an office in Oklahoma City. Mike Crandall is owner and
principal of Sandler Training in Oklahoma City. He has management experience
with DeWalt/Black and Decker, James Hardie Building Products and Propex.
Crandall is a graduate of the University of Nebraska and has a master's of
business administration from Oklahoma Christian University. Founded in 1967,
Sandler Training provides sales, management and leadership training. Sandler's
network includes more than 250 trainers and consultants.

Public meeting set on Drinking Water State Revolving Fund The Water Quality
Division of the Department of Environmental Quality has scheduled a public
hearing on the Drinking Water State Revolving Fund at 1:30 p.m. June 14 at DEQ's
Oklahoma City offices, 707 N. Robinson Ave., Oklahoma City. The meeting was
scheduled to answer questions and receive public input on the state fiscal year
2011 intended use plan, the priority ranking system and the project priority
list for the Drinking Water State Revolving Fund. The intended use plan outlines
uses for federal money allocated to Oklahoma and lists the projects as ranked
for financing by the priority ranking system. The Drinking Water State Revolving
Fund was established by the passage of the Safe Drinking Water Act Amendments of
1996. The act authorized money to be used by states to establish a revolving
loan fund to address drinking water infrastructure needs and correct other water
system deficiencies that might result in violations of drinking water standards.
A copy of the draft plan will be available at www.deq.state.ok.us/WQDnew/dwsrf.

18 Tulsa Shock games to be televised At least 18 of the Tulsa Shock's 34
regular-season WNBA games will be televised. Cox Communications will air 15
Shock basketball games on the Cox Channel, including five games that will also
appear on Fox Sports Oklahoma simultaneously and one exclusively. Two games will
be televised nationally on ESPN2. "This is yet another milestone for our
organization in partnering with two great local media partners in Cox
Communications and Fox Sports Oklahoma," said Steve Swetoha, Tulsa Shock
president. "We appreciate the support and fervor with which this agreement came
about. " The first televised game was the season opener on Saturday against the
Minnesota Lynx. The next televised will be the game Thursday against the San
Antonio Silver Stars at the BOK Center in Tulsa, which will be televised on the
Cox Channel and Fox Sports Oklahoma. Games on May 25 against the Phoenix
Mercury, the defending WNBA champion, and June 13 against the Los Angeles Sparks
will be televised nationally on ESPN2. The Shock, owned by a group of investors
led by Oklahoma businessmen Bill Cameron and David Box, moved to Tulsa from
Detroit in October. Nolan Richardson was named general manager and head coach
shortly thereafter. The WNBA has 12 teams.

                       TELEGRAM & GAZETTE (Massachusetts)

                  April 27, 2005 Wednesday, RT. 9 WEST EDITION

Water districts to get grants, loans for repairs and upgrades

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 537 words


The Leicester Water District, the Oxford/Rochdale Sewer District and the Warren
Water District will receive loan and grant money Friday from Rural Development,
an agency of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The Warren Water District will receive a loan of $1,425,000 and a grant of
$405,000 for the repair and improvement of the water system at 9:30 a.m. Friday
at the town's new water storage tank in the Tyler Park area off Southbridge
Road.

It is the fourth round of federal funding for the Warren Water District since
2002.

Established in 1920, the Warren Water District is made up of many old sections
in need of improvement to meet future water system demands.

The money that will be presented Friday will finance the replacement of transit
pipe throughout the district's water system.

According to water district officials, the AC pipe lining presents possible
health problems because of its potential to leach volatile organic chemicals
into the drinking water.

There are also concerns about the potential for asbestos fibers, which are found
in AC pipes, to contaminate the drinking water.

The Oxford/Rochdale Sewer District will receive a $620,000 loan and $180,000
grant at a ceremony at 10:45 a.m. at the Leicester Water District Building, 124
Pine St.

The money will be used to install a gravity sewer system with a connection to a
nearby treatment plant that has the capacity for additional flow.

According to Rural Development officials, the project will consist of about
3,000 feet of 12-inch sewer pipe, 1,700 feet of 8-inch sewer pipe, and 19
manholes and service tees. The sewer project will connect to an existing sewer
manhole located on Clark Street.

Twenty-three homes and a 72-unit housing project, Laurel Heights, use septic
systems in the area. Many systems have failed or are failing and need repair or
replacement. According to the local Board of Health, the majority of the
existing systems would fail inspection.

The installation of the gravity sewer will eliminate the need to replace failed,
on-site septic systems and will provide additional protection for Greenville
Pond, a nearby water supply, according to Rural Development.

The Leicester Water District will receive a $1,720,620 loan and a $490,000 grant
that will allow the installation of new sewer lines, a wastewater pump station,
and the replacement of additional sewer lines along Route 9 to the Spencer town
line.

District officials said all homes and businesses in this area are served by
septic systems, many of which have failed or are failing.

The Leicester Board of Health has documented numerous complaints regarding
septic system problems.

According to Rural Development, home and business owners in the area will see
substantial savings because this project will be included as part of the
Massachusetts Highway Department's reconstruction of Route 9 from the center of
Leicester to the Spencer town line.

The project will include 15,000 feet of 10- and 15-inch polyvinyl chloride
gravity sewers, 2,300 feet of 8-inch ductile iron force main, 2,600 feet of
6-inch PVC sewer services from the mainline to the property line, about 10
grinder pumps, and other accessories.

REAL ESTATE NOTES

BYLINE: by Margaret Jackson, The Denver Post

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. K-06

New Steamboat gondola on tap

Construction of a new gondola at Steamboat Springs is scheduled to begin next
summer.

Wildhorse Meadows developer Resort Ventures West is spending about $4 million on
the gondola, which will start at the residential community located between
downtown and the base of the mountain. It will take about five minutes for
passengers to reach the base area.

The gondola should be finished for the 2009-2010 ski season.

Gates project in pilot program. A 40-acre mixed-use development on the site of
the former Gates Rubber factory has been selected to participate in the
Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design for Neighborhood Development pilot
program.

The first phase, Metropolitan Gardens, being developed by Joseph Freed and
Associates, will include 1 million square feet of retail space, Robert Redford's
fourth Sundance Cinema, two hotels, 610,000 square feet of office space, 850
apartments and 1,300 condos, as well as parks, pedestrian plazas and a major
transportation hub with access to light rail.

Home-buying classes offered. The Colorado Rural Housing Development Corp. is
offering homebuyer-education courses that offer tips for negotiating the price
of a home, shopping for a loan, and establishing and maintaining good credit.

Research shows that homeowners who receive prepurchase counseling are more than
30 percent less likely to default on a mortgage than homeowners who do not get
counseling. The classes will be offered:

9 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. Oct. 13 at Mountain Terrace, 3650 W. 84th Ave., Westminster.

9 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. Oct. 20 at Colorado Housing Enterprises, 7 E. Bijou St.,
Suite 209, Colorado Springs.

Mortgage brochure updated. A brochure to educate homebuyers and those
refinancing a loan has been updated to include information about adjustable-rate
mortgages.

"Mortgage Loans," first published in 2001 by the American Financial Services
Association and the American Association of Residential Mortgage Regulators,
contains worksheets to help consumers shop for the best mortgage deal and
determine an affordable monthly payment. A glossary defines basic, but
important, loan terms, such as annual percentage rate, finance charge, balloon
payment and arbitration clause.

For a free copy, visit afsaef.org or call 888-400-2233.

Margaret Jackson: 303-954-1473 or mjackson@denverpost.com
