Washington: USDA Announces $59 Million in Loans and Grants to Increase Economic
Opportunity, Support Rural Microenterprise Development

LENGTH: 892  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Department of Agriculture, The Government of USA has issued the following
news release:

USDA Rural Development Acting Under Secretary Doug O'Brien today announced the
selection of 85 utilities and development organizations for loans and grants to
support rural business activities that will boost economic growth in rural
communities.

"These USDA investments capitalize rural small businesses, which allows the
owners to expand operations, enter into new markets and increase hiring,"
O'Brien said. "The investments we are announcing today include financing to
development organizations for microlending to very small rural businesses. Funds
are also being provided to utilities to pass on to local businesses for
development projects. These innovative programs increase economic opportunities
in rural areas - a top priority of Secretary Vilsack and President Obama."

O'Brien announced the rural business investments while in Kentucky with Governor
Steve Beshear, Congressman Hal Rogers, and the executive board of Shaping Our
Appalachian Region (SOAR)This is an external link or third-party site outside of
the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) website. to discuss
investment opportunities in eastern Kentucky, including Promise Zones and
regional SOAR initiatives.

Funds are being provided through the Rural Economic Development Loan and Grant
Program (REDLG) and the Rural Microentrepreneur Assistance Program (RMAP). Under
the REDLG program, USDA provides zero-interest loans to local utilities which
then, in turn, relend the funds to local businesses (ultimate recipients) for
projects that will create and retain employment in rural areas. The program
funds business start-up or expansion, business incubators, education and
training facilities and equipment, community development assistance, health care
and other projects that support rural jobs.

Under RMAP, USDA provides loans to Microenterprise Development Organizations
(MDOs) that, in turn, make microloans for business start-up or development to
eligible microentrepreneurs defined as very small businesses with 10 or fewer
employees. Grants are available for MDOs to provide technical assistance and
training, particularly in rural areas experiencing persistent poverty or
significant outmigration. USDA does not directly provide funds to the ultimate
recipients.

The Rural Microentrepreneur Assistance Program was created under the 2008 Farm
Bill and recently reauthorized through the 2014 Farm Bill.

The Kentucky Highlands Investment Corporation is receiving a $500,000 RMAP loan
to capitalize a revolving loan fund to provide microloans to very small
businesses in 19 counties designated by the Appalachian Regional Commission as
distressed communities. The Kentucky Highlands Investment Corporation is the
lead organization carrying out the state's Promise Zone initiative. Its Promise
Zone work was made possible through the financial support from USDA.

MEDI, Inc., is receiving a $400,000 RMAP loan and $100,000 RMAP grant to serve
as a microlender and technical assistance provider for very small rural
businesses throughout Kentucky.

Since the start of the Obama Administration, Rural Development has invested more
than $4.4 billion in Kentucky. The agency is targeting assistance to persistent
poverty areas in Appalachian Kentucky through the USDA StrikeForce Initiative
for Rural Growth and Opportunity, and will continue its work with Governor
Beshear and his staff, the Kentucky Congressional Delegation, other federal
agencies, SOAR officials and community leaders throughout the region to benefit
rural communities in the impacted areas.

At the national level, the USDA investments are meeting a wide variety of
business and manufacturing needs across rural America. For example, in South
Carolina, the Santee Electric Cooperative is receiving a $1 million Rural
Economic Development loan to support the local "Help My House program," which
makes energy efficiency improvements in the rural areas of Williamsburg,
Georgetown, Clarendon and Florence Counties. The Nodak Electric Cooperative in
North Dakota is receiving a $775,000 Rural Economic Development loan to help S&S
Grain, Inc. purchase and renovate a building in Walhalla, N.D., for grain
drying, handling and storage.

The Rural Economic Development Loan and Grant program directly supports the
Obama Administration's Investing in Manufacturing Communities Partnership (IMCP)
initiative to boost the manufacturing sector and create well-paying
manufacturing jobs, using economic development resources available through
existing Federal programs.

Through today's announcement, USDA is providing over $59 million in loans and
grants to 85 organizations in 31 states, including the District of Columbia, to
strengthen rural businesses and promote economic development. The funding is
contingent upon the recipients meeting the terms of their loan or grant
agreements.

President Obama's historic investments in rural America have made our rural
communities stronger. Under his leadership, these investments in housing,
community facilities, businesses and infrastructure have empowered rural America
to continue leading the way - strengthening America's economy, small towns and
rural communities.

                           Business Times (Singapore)

Property becomes the main earnings engine for SBS

                                 April 1, 1997

Christopher Tan


TRANSPORT-BASED Singapore Bus Service has every reason to be proud of its 1996
performance, in which a maiden contribution from its first property project
yielded close to $ 30 million in pre-tax profit.

The boost, from its King Albert Park homes, was sizeable enough to offset a
one-third plunge in transport earnings to bring the group's bottom line close to
the previous year's level. This was in spite of $ 8 million in additional taxes.

Investors holding SBS shares must be smiling to themselves now. For the
better-than-expected results followed a series of other encouraging news about
the company. Most of these pertained to property and were behind the spikes in
the stock's movement in recent weeks.

Factory units: They included a plan with Technology Parks and Lend Lease Asia to
build and sell terraced and semi-detached factory units on a 130,000 sq m site
it secured in Tuas. Then there is the 30 per cent venture with Jurong Town Corp
and the Lend Lease Group to develop a 240-hectare industrial estate in Java.

More exciting is a deal with Keppel Land to develop an en bloc site in Avenue
Park, located in the prime Sixth Avenue belt. The freehold site can accommodate
about 140 1,500 sq ft apartments.

With these projects lined up, the potential for SBS to become a major property
player is there. But how profitable its ventures will be is another matter. The
fact that the group cut its teeth in the King Albert Park project is not totally
convincing because the site was a former bus depot, and hence had negligible
land cost.

Not so with its Garlick Avenue plot. It forked out $ 141 million for the
99-year-leasehold land, which will have six semi-detached houses and 141
cluster-houses with "full facilities". Based on estimates of development charges
it would have to foot, and an uncertain response to cluster-housing, analysts
are saying SBS would only "break even" on the project.

And the fact that it is a 99-year property means it might face competition from
executive condo projects. Also, conditions on the property market are far from
what they used to be and are unlikely to improve much in the short term.

Nevertheless, SBS, like any other cash-rich group in a similar situation, has
immense holding power. The Avenue Park site, for instance, may not be
redeveloped immediately. In the meantime, it is expected to collect rental from
existing tenants, though.

For the current year, however, SBS will continue to see an enviable flow of
revenue from King Albert Park. Its project in London, Waterdale Manor, is also
likely to contribute. They are expected to yield more than $ 30 million in
pre-tax profit.

New acquisitions: After 1997, a number of newer projects including the ones
mentioned above and a few new acquisitions yet to be announced would be in place
and should sustain property earnings, which SBS has come to rely on.

Bus operations, even with a possible fare adjustment this year, will contribute
only modestly. The rising cost of labour and equipment will continue to eat into
profit. There is also the competition from rail-based systems, but here there is
consolation in that SBS is itself venturing into the competitor's turf as well.

With diminishing returns from bus operations and increasing contributions from
other divisions -including a surprisingly profitable taxi subsidiary -one
wonders whether Singapore Bus Service should undergo a name change. Or even seek
a separate listing for its non-bus businesses.

                                US Official News

North Carolina: Governor McCrory Announces Nearly $2.6 Million in Infrastructure
Funding

LENGTH: 1297 words

DATELINE: New York



 Raleigh: The Department of Commerce, North Carolina has issued the following
news release:



 Governor Pat McCrory announced today that the North Carolina Rural
Infrastructure Authority (RIA) approved 10 grant and loan requests totaling
$2,565,689. The requests include commitments to create a total of 200 new jobs.





 "One of the top priorities of my administration is connecting North Carolinians
to better roads and infrastructure by ensuring that every community has the
building blocks for economic development and job creation," said Governor
McCrory. "These loans and grants will enable our smaller towns and counties to
better focus on business and job growth."



 Authority members review and approve funding requests for grant and loan
programs. The programs are operated by the Rural Economic Development team at
the North Carolina Department of Commerce, which is led by Secretary John E.
Skvarla, III, and Assistant Secretary Dr. Patricia Mitchell. Grants support
infrastructure development, building renovation and site improvements.



 Since its creation by Governor McCrory and the North Carolina General Assembly
in 2013, the Authority has approved nearly $120 million in awards.



 The RIA approved one request under the state's Industrial Development Fund -
Utility Account program.



 City of Claremont (Catawba County): A $28,189 grant to augment an existing
grant of $120,975 that assists businesses in the Claremont Industrial Park with
sewer system improvements for long-term growth. The project opens development
and job-creation opportunities for the entire 22-acre industrial site.



 The Industrial Development Fund - Utility Account provides grants to units of
local government for 80 counties in the state considered Tier 1 or Tier 2. Funds
may be used for publicly-owned infrastructure projects that are reasonably
expected to result in the creation of new jobs. IDF - Utility Account funding is
derived from set-asides of Job Development Investment Grants (JDIG) awarded in
Tier 2 and Tier 3 counties.



 The RIA approved one loan under the state's Community Development Block Grant
(CDBG) - Economic Development program:



 City of Thomasville (Davidson County): A $200,000 loan to support the reuse of
a vacant building accommodating a 10-job expansion by Whitewood Industries. The
Thomasville-based company, a distributor of ready-to-finish furniture, has been
in business for 34 years. The building was constructed in 1970 and has been
vacant for the past year. Funds will be used to improve roofing, lighting and
plumbing, and re-pave the parking lot. The loan will support a total capital
investment of $1.5 million.



 The Community Development Block Grant program is a U.S. Department of Housing
and Urban Development (HUD) program administered in part by North Carolina
Commerce. CDBG's economic development funds provide grants to local governments
for creating and retaining jobs. Project funding is based on the number of jobs
to be created and the level of economic distress of applicant communities.
The RIA approved eight grants under the state's Building Reuse program:



 Existing Business Building Category



 Town of Mocksville (Davie County): A $100,000 building reuse grant that will
facilitate a 10-job expansion at REEB Millwork. The company custom-manufactures
and distributes millwork products such as doors, columns and stairs across the
eastern United States. Renovations include lighting and dock doors among other
items. The building was constructed in 1980. The grant is part of a total
capital investment of $320,451.



 Granville County: A $500,000 grant to support a building addition in Creedmoor
that will facilitate a 50-job expansion by Altec Industries. The company
provides equipment and services to customers in the utility, telecommunications
and other industries. Altec will add 8,000 sq. ft. to the building, which was
constructed in 1984. The grant is part of a total capital investment of $16.7
million.



 Halifax County: A $200,000 grant for renovating three buildings in Weldon to
facilitate a 20-job expansion at Meherrin River Forest Products. The
Virginia-based company manufactures hardwood lumber. The buildings were
constructed in 1950. Renovations include roofing, mechanical systems and
interior configuration. The grant is part of a total capital investment of more
than $2 million.



 Robeson County: A $500,000 building renovation grant in Pembroke that will
facilitate a 50-job expansion by Trinity Frozen Foods. The company manufactures
frozen sweet-potato fries for domestic and foreign markets. The building was
constructed in 1998. Renovations will include electrical, plumbing and concrete
work. The grant is part of a total capital investment of more than $5.5 million.




 Robeson County: A $500,000 grant to support the renovation of a building in St.
Pauls that will facilitate a 50-job expansion by Watts Water Technology. The
company provides plumbing, heating and water quality solutions for residential,
industrial, commercial and governmental customers. The building was constructed
in 1974. Renovations will include flooring, HVAC and interior configuration. The
grant is part of a total capital investment of more than $3.7 million.



 Vacant Building Category



 Montgomery County: A $50,000 grant for the reuse of a vacant building in
Biscoe. Tractor Supply Company will lease the building and create five jobs. The
building was constructed in 1990 and has been vacant for seven months.
Renovations include electrical, plumbing and HVAC. The grant is part of a total
capital investment of $834,951.



 Wilson County: A $462,500 grant to support the reuse of a vacant building in
Wilson by Peak Demand. The company, which designs and manufactures electrical
transmission systems, is adding 37 jobs to its existing workforce. The building
was constructed in 1970 and has been vacant for five months. Renovations include
HVAC, electrical, flooring and fire-protection systems. The grant is part of a
total capital investment of more than $3 million.



 Town of Columbia (Tyrrell County): A $25,000 reuse grant of a vacant building
by Waypoint Oyster Bar. The start-up company, a full-service restaurant and
caterer specializing in local seafood, will create five jobs. The building was
constructed in 1932 and has been vacant four months. Renovations include
flooring, plumbing and HVAC. The grant is part of a total capital investment of
$699,511.



 The Building Reuse Program provides grants to local governments to renovate
vacant buildings, renovate and/or expand buildings occupied by existing North
Carolina companies, and renovate, expand or construct health care facilities
that will lead to the creation of new jobs in Tier 1 and Tier 2 counties and in
rural Census tracts of Tier 3 counties.



 In addition to reviewing and approving funding requests, the N.C. Rural
Infrastructure Authority formulates policies and priorities for grant and loan
programs administered by NC Commerce's Rural Economic Development team. Its 15
voting members are appointed by the Governor, Speaker of the House and Senate
President Pro Tem. The North Carolina Secretary of Commerce serves as a
non-voting member of the Authority. "The availability of modern infrastructure
and ready-to-go buildings is necessary for restoring North Carolina's
white-picket-fence communities," said Commerce Secretary Skvarla."Working
alongside the NC Commerce team, the Rural Infrastructure Authority partners with
the state's less populated communities in creating jobs, growing businesses and
attracting economic investment."

                           October 26, 2016 Wednesday

North Carolina: Governor McCrory Announces Nearly $2.6 Million in Infrastructure
Funding

LENGTH: 1297 words

DATELINE: New York



 Raleigh: The Department of Commerce, North Carolina has issued the following
news release:



 Governor Pat McCrory announced today that the North Carolina Rural
Infrastructure Authority (RIA) approved 10 grant and loan requests totaling
$2,565,689. The requests include commitments to create a total of 200 new jobs.





 "One of the top priorities of my administration is connecting North Carolinians
to better roads and infrastructure by ensuring that every community has the
building blocks for economic development and job creation," said Governor
McCrory. "These loans and grants will enable our smaller towns and counties to
better focus on business and job growth."



 Authority members review and approve funding requests for grant and loan
programs. The programs are operated by the Rural Economic Development team at
the North Carolina Department of Commerce, which is led by Secretary John E.
Skvarla, III, and Assistant Secretary Dr. Patricia Mitchell. Grants support
infrastructure development, building renovation and site improvements.



 Since its creation by Governor McCrory and the North Carolina General Assembly
in 2013, the Authority has approved nearly $120 million in awards.



 The RIA approved one request under the state's Industrial Development Fund -
Utility Account program.



 City of Claremont (Catawba County): A $28,189 grant to augment an existing
grant of $120,975 that assists businesses in the Claremont Industrial Park with
sewer system improvements for long-term growth. The project opens development
and job-creation opportunities for the entire 22-acre industrial site.



 The Industrial Development Fund - Utility Account provides grants to units of
local government for 80 counties in the state considered Tier 1 or Tier 2. Funds
may be used for publicly-owned infrastructure projects that are reasonably
expected to result in the creation of new jobs. IDF - Utility Account funding is
derived from set-asides of Job Development Investment Grants (JDIG) awarded in
Tier 2 and Tier 3 counties.



 The RIA approved one loan under the state's Community Development Block Grant
(CDBG) - Economic Development program:



 City of Thomasville (Davidson County): A $200,000 loan to support the reuse of
a vacant building accommodating a 10-job expansion by Whitewood Industries. The
Thomasville-based company, a distributor of ready-to-finish furniture, has been
in business for 34 years. The building was constructed in 1970 and has been
vacant for the past year. Funds will be used to improve roofing, lighting and
plumbing, and re-pave the parking lot. The loan will support a total capital
investment of $1.5 million.



 The Community Development Block Grant program is a U.S. Department of Housing
and Urban Development (HUD) program administered in part by North Carolina
Commerce. CDBG's economic development funds provide grants to local governments
for creating and retaining jobs. Project funding is based on the number of jobs
to be created and the level of economic distress of applicant communities.
The RIA approved eight grants under the state's Building Reuse program:



 Existing Business Building Category



 Town of Mocksville (Davie County): A $100,000 building reuse grant that will
facilitate a 10-job expansion at REEB Millwork. The company custom-manufactures
and distributes millwork products such as doors, columns and stairs across the
eastern United States. Renovations include lighting and dock doors among other
items. The building was constructed in 1980. The grant is part of a total
capital investment of $320,451.



 Granville County: A $500,000 grant to support a building addition in Creedmoor
that will facilitate a 50-job expansion by Altec Industries. The company
provides equipment and services to customers in the utility, telecommunications
and other industries. Altec will add 8,000 sq. ft. to the building, which was
constructed in 1984. The grant is part of a total capital investment of $16.7
million.



 Halifax County: A $200,000 grant for renovating three buildings in Weldon to
facilitate a 20-job expansion at Meherrin River Forest Products. The
Virginia-based company manufactures hardwood lumber. The buildings were
constructed in 1950. Renovations include roofing, mechanical systems and
interior configuration. The grant is part of a total capital investment of more
than $2 million.



 Robeson County: A $500,000 building renovation grant in Pembroke that will
facilitate a 50-job expansion by Trinity Frozen Foods. The company manufactures
frozen sweet-potato fries for domestic and foreign markets. The building was
constructed in 1998. Renovations will include electrical, plumbing and concrete
work. The grant is part of a total capital investment of more than $5.5 million.




 Robeson County: A $500,000 grant to support the renovation of a building in St.
Pauls that will facilitate a 50-job expansion by Watts Water Technology. The
company provides plumbing, heating and water quality solutions for residential,
industrial, commercial and governmental customers. The building was constructed
in 1974. Renovations will include flooring, HVAC and interior configuration. The
grant is part of a total capital investment of more than $3.7 million.



 Vacant Building Category



 Montgomery County: A $50,000 grant for the reuse of a vacant building in
Biscoe. Tractor Supply Company will lease the building and create five jobs. The
building was constructed in 1990 and has been vacant for seven months.
Renovations include electrical, plumbing and HVAC. The grant is part of a total
capital investment of $834,951.



 Wilson County: A $462,500 grant to support the reuse of a vacant building in
Wilson by Peak Demand. The company, which designs and manufactures electrical
transmission systems, is adding 37 jobs to its existing workforce. The building
was constructed in 1970 and has been vacant for five months. Renovations include
HVAC, electrical, flooring and fire-protection systems. The grant is part of a
total capital investment of more than $3 million.

by Waypoint Oyster Bar. The start-up company, a full-service restaurant and

                     Deseret Morning News (Salt Lake City)

                              July 30, 2007 Monday

Land loan is cross between a mortgage, personal loan

BYLINE: Jeffrey R. Kosnett Kiplinger's Personal Finance

LENGTH: 430 words


When Bill Killmer purchased a tract of land for about $2,700 an acre, he
financed it by making a tax-deferred exchange for other land he owned close to
Atlanta. Buyers of rural property who own other real estate investments often
use such so-called 1031 exchanges to delay paying capital-gains taxes. Other
buyers may pay cash.

If you borrow, know that a land loan is a cross between a mortgage, which is
secured by the property, and a personal loan, which has more stringent terms
than a mortgage. Figure on putting 25 percent to 30 percent down, with a loan
term of 10 to 20 years. Interest rates were recently about 8 percent.

Your best sources of credit are local commercial banks and farmers' cooperative
banks. Even as lenders tighten credit for suburban housing lots and condos,
they're eager to finance recreational properties, especially within three hours
of a major city, because they are gaining value. Steer clear of so-called land-
loan specialists, which are finance companies, not banks, and charge
double-digit interest rates.

If you're buying land for personal use, the interest is not deductible. If
you're buying it as an investment, the interest is considered investment
interest, like the margin interest on stock purchases. That makes it deductible
to the extent that you report taxable investment income, but the deduction does
not shelter capital gains and qualified dividends. To get a more useful
deduction to offset the cost of the land, finance part of the purchase with a
home-equity loan. Interest on up to $100,000 in home-equity debt is deductible.

While you're waiting for your acreage to appreciate, it'll be yours to enjoy.
But there will be expenses. Most rural land for sale lacks accommodations other
than maybe a rude cabin, so you may want to build a house. Figure on paying $700
to $1,000 an acre to clear land for a pasture or a building site. You'll need a
well and a septic system. Roads suitable for vehicles that don't have four-wheel
drive can cost thousands of dollars.

Without a house on the property, taxes should be low. Land is generally taxed
based on its current use, so taxes on timberland may set you back as little as
$2 per acre per year.

The more improvements you make, the more valuable the underlying land will be.
But don't expect to cash out quickly. It takes an average of about six months to
sell 500 acres, and it may take as long as two years. Still, it's comforting to
know that land is one investment that won't crater on news of an unexpected
earnings shortfall or the madness of crowds entering trades on computers.

                    BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                            August 14, 2012 Tuesday

Chinese officials deny report of expensive reconstruction plans for ancient city

LENGTH: 434 words


Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News
Agency)

Zhengzhou, Aug. 14: Officials have denied rumours that extravagant sums are to
be spent on restoring a central Chinese city established over 1,000 years ago.

Controversy has been sparked over claims that the government of Kaifeng, in
Henan province, is planning to spend 100 billion yuan (15.77 billion U.S.
dollars) to rebuild the ancient city.

Kaifeng, with the ancient name of "Bianjing," acted as the capital for several
dynasties.

The so-called "rebuilding Bianjing" project has sparked an outcry at Sina Weibo,
a popular microblogging service in China.

Some bloggers have accused the municipal government of intending to use the work
to build up its own political credentials while disregarding their duty to
conserve and improve locals' living conditions.

Others say reconstruction of the ancient scenic spots is aimed at removing the
shanty towns from the city, and relocation of the residents might be neglected.

The annual financial income of Kaifeng is only about 500 million yuan, the 13th
highest of the province's 18 cities. Should the ancient city be rebuilt, the
government would have to borrow heavily.

However, the Kaifeng government clarified on Monday [13 August] that it only
aims to remold the shanty towns to improve people's living conditions.

Most of the buildings in the areas in question were built in the 1950s and
1960s. Residents there have been suffering from a lack of running water, heating
or sanitation facilities for several decades.

"Shanty towns have been a tough challenge for Kaifeng for a long time. The
government has put in place an office to resolve the problem," said Kong
Xiangcheng, deputy director of the city's Housing and Urban-rural Development
Bureau.

Kong said the shanty town renovation scheme includes the relocation of local
residents and construction of new houses and infrastructure.

About 80,000 families living in the shanty towns would benefit from the
renovation project, according to the official, who added that ancient historic
sites will be preserved during the renovation.

"As a city with multiple historic sites, we will try our best to keep the
original style of the ancient city during our reconstruction," Kong said. "We
have already earmarked 86 sites for protection within the area."

Kong also explained that the Kaifeng government will follow national regulations
concerning shanty town renovation, and raise money through financial aid, bank
loans, self-financing and other means.

Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1223gmt 14 Aug 12

                    Daily Journal of Commerce (Portland, OR)

                            March 28, 2013 Thursday

Apartment projects not always easy in small Oregon cities

BYLINE: Lee Fehrenbacher

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 1041  words


Pendleton, about 210 miles due east of Portland, has grown slowly over the past
125 years. The city of 17,000 or so swells by approximately 70,000 each
September during the weeklong Pendleton Round-up, but it otherwise is sheltered
from booms and busts.

Recently, officials took steps to accelerate growth. But they encountered a
problem.

"A few years back, the city did an urban growth boundary expansion to bring in
industrial properties, and brought some new roads in," said Tim Simmons, the
city's community development director. "Companies though have found that they
don't have a real sizable workforce, and when they looked into that, the people
said we can't find housing. "

Pendleton isn't alone. While multifamily construction is booming in Portland,
rural communities in Oregon are struggling to do likewise. Low rents and
reluctance from investors create significant hurdles for developers, so city
officials are becoming scrappy to entice projects - in Pendleton, they're giving
land away.

"These days, people do different things in the way they dispose of bodies with
cremation being more popular than direct burials," Simmons said, in reference to
a 7-acre property - near a city-owned cemetery - that Pendleton gave to a
developer. "(The cemetery) didn't need the future growth area in terms of this
lot. So they looked at trying to get it back on the tax rolls. "

That developer is planning a three-phase project, beginning with 30 apartments.
The city also gave a 12.4 acre lot - the site of a former police shooting range
- to Walker LLC, which plans to build 20 to 25 units, and as many as 100
depending on the rate of absorption.

Those projects are the result of an Oregon Solutions pilot program. The
state-created community consultant organization was tasked with documenting the
problem.

Pendleton Mayor Phillip Houk said a major finding was that between 30 and 50
percent of people working in his city were commuting because they couldn't find
housing in it. Meanwhile, apartment occupancy was strong.

"(When) someone moved out, there was someone right there lined up to move back
in," Houk said.

Being able to demonstrate that need to developers is key, said former Oregon
Solutions employee Kim Travis, who is now the community engagement manager for
Oregon Housing and Community Services' East and Central regions. Travis helped
Pendleton perform the research and said atypical moves, like giving land, can
aid rural communities with few financial resources.

"Workforce housing is a huge issue in non-metro communities," she said. "It's
not just Pendleton - it's all over the state ... The state has no programs
focused on workforce housing. So it has to be a locally driven initiative, and
it's important to understand what local communities might be able to offer to
incent the local market. "

Along the coast, for instance, she said communities struggle to convince
developers to build long-term rental housing in lieu of weekend vacation spots.
In Boardman, nearly 70 percent of workers commute - and 31 percent drive more
than 25 miles to work. She said Boardman was creating a revolving loan program
to provide gap financing for housing projects.

Those towns, Travis said, have economic development potential, but investors are
leery. David Simon, a developer in Hood River, knows that.

"In Hood River there hasn't been any new apartments built in 20 years," he said.

Simon plans to build 20 two-bedroom units about a mile from downtown. Hood
River, like coastal cities, has a lot of short-term rentals, but few year-round
options. Land prices are high, so his approximately $2.5 million construction
project didn't pencil out easily.

So far, Simon has talked to nine banks. A national one expressed strong
interest, but corporate underwriting standards disqualified him. Community banks
were supportive, but his project was too large for their comfort levels.

"That leaves ... regional banks," he said. "And of those that I spoke with, only
one of the five or six was willing to step up to the plate and finance new
construction in a rural area where there hadn't been construction in a long
time. "

That's not surprising to Tim O'Brien, an HFO Investment Real Estate partner who
recently spoke with a La Grande developer who was trying to find investors for a
40-unit apartment project there.

"Nobody wanted to go over there," O'Brien said. "I probably talked to at least
half a dozen folks. The scale of the projects was too small, getting the lending
out there was going to be more difficult, and physically, location-wise, it's
tougher to access. "

Part of the problem is that rents in rural communities are frequently too low to
support new construction. Oftentimes, developers of market-rate projects find
themselves competing against those subsidized for low-income tenants.

So, a financial edge - like free acreage - can make a difference.

"No developer could pay for the land and construct the project at a cost per
square foot that would have told them that this was a market they should enter,"
said Bob Savage of Walker LLC. "You just couldn't do it. "

Walker LLC is hoping to break ground on its project by fall. The company is
seeking a traditional construction loan, but it's providing the equity itself -
a considerably larger amount than would be required by banks in a market like
Portland, Savage said.

Institutional investors relying on standard checklists probably wouldn't see
opportunities for housing development in Pendleton if they visited, Savage said,
but they exist. An $80 million hospital will open this fall, and several smaller
medical offices have already popped up. Simmons said workers are on their way.

And Savage and Simon said there is one great advantage to building in places
like Pendleton - city officials usually say 'yes. '

"In the world of development, you're used to starting out from 'no,' " Savage
said. " 'You can't do it here, but here are the hoops that you're going to have
to jump through to get there. ' In Pendleton, you're starting from 'Yes, we want
to see you build here. ' And that's refreshing - something I haven't seen in
ages. "

                        Laurel Leader-Call (Mississippi)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 13, 2011 Sunday

Cities of Ellisville, Taylorsville awarded for community projects

BYLINE: Charlotte Graham, Laurel Leader-Call, Miss.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 968 words


March 13--JACKSON -- Two area communities are listed among the 13 recipients of
the 2011 Governor's Community Projects of Excellence Award presented by Governor
Haley Barbour and Gray Swoope, executive director of the Mississippi Development
Authority (MDA), during a ceremony at the Mississippi Department of Education
building in downtown Jackson Wednesday.

The City of Ellisville was recognized as "Best CDBG-Recovery," while the Town of
Taylorsville was honored for "Best Small Municipal and Limited Population County
Grant (SMLPC)."

The awards are presented to community leaders and representatives from
non-profit organizations for their outstanding use of Community Development
Block Grant (CDBG), Emergency Shelter Grant Program (ESG), Capital Improvements
Revolving Loan Program (CAP), Rural Impact Fund Program (RIF), Small Municipal
and Limited Population County Grant Program (SMLPC) and Home Investment
Partnerships Program (HOME) funds over the past year. The state and federal
funding programs, which provide assistance for community improvement projects,
are administered by MDA's Community Services Division.

The CDBG Program helps local units of government realize their potential by
providing the necessary funds to ensure adequate housing, basic community
services, environmental quality and economic opportunities for their residents;
ESG funds are designed to provide assistance to homeless individuals and
families; HOME Program funds are made available to local communities to provide
for affordable housing, whether through homeowner rehabilitation/reconstruction,
new construction, the substantial rehabilitation of multi-family rental units or
through assistance to homebuyers.

"The awards presented today represent the excellent use of state and federal
funding programs in Mississippi communities around the state," Governor Barbour
said. "I thank this year's award recipients for their service to their
communities and their dedication to making them better places in which to live,
work and do business."

Other winners of the Governor's Community Projects of Excellence Awards are:

--Coahoma County -- Best CDBG Economic Development (ED)

--City of Magnolia -- Best CDBG Public Facility

--Town of Braxton -- Best CDBG Self-Help

--Haven House Family Shelter -- Best Emergency Shelter Grant (ESG)

--Monroe County -- Best Capital Improvements Revolving Loan (CAP)

--Calhoun City -- Best Rural Impact Fund (RIF)

--Valley Community Development Corporation -- Best HOME Program Community
Housing Development Organization (CHDO)

--Town of Ethel -- Best HOME Program Homeowner Rehabilitation

--City of Holly Springs -- Best HOME Program Homebuyer Assistance

--City of Gulfport -- Best Katrina CDBG Community Revitalization

--The Lodge -- Best Katrina CDBG Long Term Workforce Housing

In addition, two Gulf Coast municipalities were presented awards for their use
of federal Hurricane Katrina Disaster Recovery CDBG funds, which are
administered by MDA's Disaster Recovery Division. Katrina CDBG funds are
designed to help local units of government in the areas hardest hit by Hurricane
Katrina. These funds can be used by counties and cities to ensure basic
community services, environmental quality and economic opportunities for their
residents. CDBG-Recovery funds were made available to the state through the
American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 as part of the federal
government's efforts to stimulate the economy. These funds can be used for
needed infrastructure projects, basic services to residents and activities that
promote energy efficiency and conservation through the rehabilitation or
retrofitting of existing buildings.

The state offers a number of community development programs, as well. CAP funds
are provided to counties or municipalities to finance capital improvements such
as water, sewer, industrial draining and fire protection improvements,
industrial access roads, construction of multipurpose facilities for tourism
development and recreation improvements. RIF funds are designed to assist and
promote businesses and economic development in rural areas by providing grants
to rural communities. SMLPC funds are used for publicly-owned infrastructure for
community-based projects such as drainage systems, water and sewer systems,
roads and bridges and buildings. Funding from this program can be used by small
municipalities and counties with limited populations.

"The key to economic development success is having vibrant, competitive
communities," said Swoope. "Last year, MDA administered $83 million in state and
federal funds, excluding Hurricane Katrina programs, all of which are aimed at
enhancing our communities.

"Today we recognized those projects that excelled at using these programs to
better the quality of life and economic well being of their citizens."

MDA is Mississippi's lead economic and community development agency, employing
nearly 300 people to engage in providing services to businesses, communities and
workers in the state. While the agency is best known for its efforts to recruit
new businesses to Mississippi, MDA provides services to promote tourism, help
communities improve their quality of place, help existing employers identify and
meet opportunities and challenges and help workers improve their skills -- all
with the goal of improving the quality of life and economic well-being of
Mississippians.

To learn more about the agency and its programs, visit MDA's Web site at
www.mississippi.org.

To see more of the Laurel Leader-Call or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.leadercall.com. Copyright (c) 2011, Laurel Leader-Call, Miss.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more information
about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                                US Official News

                           September 30, 2016 Friday

Washington: Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Announces
Availability of 2015 Data on Mortgage Lending

LENGTH: 1397  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has issued the following news
release:



 The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council (FFIEC) today announced
the availability of data on mortgage lending transactions at 6,913 U.S.
financial institutions covered by the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA).
Covered institutions include banks, savings associations, credit unions, and
mortgage companies. The HMDA data made available today cover 2015 lending
activity and include:





     applications, originations, purchases and sales of loans, denials, and
other actions related to applications

     loan amount

     loan type (conventional, Federal Housing Administration (FHA), Veterans
Administration (VA), Rural Housing Service (RHS) or Farm Service Agency (FSA))

     purpose (home purchase, home improvement, or refinancing)

     property type (1-4 family, multifamily, or manufactured housing)

     owner occupancy

     preapproval (home purchase loans only)

     property location (metropolitan statistical area (MSA), state, county, and
census tract)

     applicant and co-applicant characteristics (race, ethnicity, sex and
income)

     pricing-related data

     type of purchaser

     whether a loan is subject to the Home Ownership and Equity Protection Act
(HOEPA)

     whether a loan is secured by a first or subordinate lien, or is unsecured



 The data released today also include disclosure statements for each financial
institution, aggregate data for each MSA, nationwide summary statistics
regarding lending patterns, and Loan/Application Registers (LARs) for each
financial institution (LARs are modified to protect borrower privacy). The FFIEC
prepares and distributes this information on behalf of its member agencies.

 Understanding the Data



 The 2015 HMDA data use the census tract delineations, population, and housing
characteristic data from the 2010 Census and the combined 2006-2010 American
Community Surveys, as has been the case since 2012, when these delineations and
data were first used . In addition, the data reflect metropolitan statistical
area (MSA) definitions released by the Office of Management and Budget in 2013
that became effective for HMDA purposes in 2014.



 Caution should be used when comparing HMDA data across multiple years for
specific geographic areas due to the changes in MSA and census tract boundaries
and updates to the population and housing characteristics of census tracts.



 The HMDA data are the most comprehensive publicly available information on
mortgage market activity. Among other uses, the data help the public determine
how financial institutions are serving the housing needs of their local
communities, and facilitate fair lending and compliance examinations. When
examiners evaluate an institution's fair lending risk, they analyze HMDA data in
conjunction with other information and risk factors, in accordance with the
Interagency Fair Lending Examination Procedures available at
http://www.ffiec.gov/PDF/fairlend.pdf .



 The current HMDA data alone cannot be used to determine whether a lender is
complying with fair lending laws. The data do not include many potential
determinants of loan application and pricing decisions, such as the applicant's
credit history, debt-to-income ratio, the loan-to-value ratio, and other
considerations. Therefore, when examiners conduct fair lending examinations,
including ones involving loan pricing, they analyze additional information
before reaching a determination about an institution's compliance with fair
lending laws.

 Observations from the 2015 Data



 For 2015, the number of reporting institutions declined about 2.5 percent from
the previous year to 6,913. While there were some new reporters in 2015, this
number was more than offset by the number of institutions that reported in 2014
but did not do so in 2015. In most cases, this is because of mergers and
acquisitions.



 The 2015 data include information on 12.1 million home loan applications, of
which 7.4 million resulted in loan originations, and 2.1 million in purchased
loans, for a total of 14.2 million actions. The data also include information on
approximately 531,000 requests for preapprovals for home purchase loans.[1]



 The total number of originated loans of all types and purposes increased by 1.4
million between 2014 and 2015, or 22 percent. Refinance originations increased
by 36 percent, and home purchase lending increased by 13 percent.[2]



 From 2014 to 2015, the share of 1-4 family home purchase loans made to low- and
moderate-income borrowers (those with income of less than 80 percent of area
median income) rose slightly from approximately 26 percent in 2014 to roughly 27
percent in 2015, while the share of refinance loans to low- and moderate-income
borrowers decreased from 24 percent to 22 percent.[3]



 In terms of borrower race and ethnicity, the share of home purchase loans for
1-4 family properties made to black borrowers rose from 4.9 percent to nearly
5.2 percent, the share made to Hispanic-white borrowers rose from 7.5 percent to
7.9 percent, and those made to Asian borrowers declined slightly from 5.7
percent to 5.5 percent. The share of refinance loans made to black borrowers
decreased from 5.2 percent to 4.9 percent, the share made to Hispanic-white
borrowers rose slightly from 6.0 percent to 6.1 percent, and those made to Asian
borrowers rose from 4.5 percent to 5.1 percent.



 In 2015, black and Hispanic-white applicants experienced higher denial rates
for conventional home purchase loans than non-Hispanic white applicants. The
denial rate for Asian applicants is more comparable to the denial rate for
non-Hispanic white applicants. These relationships are similar to those found in
earlier years and do not take into account potential differences in risk
characteristics across demographic groups.



 In 2015, the FHA-insured share of first-lien home purchase loans for 1-4
family, site-built owner-occupied properties increased to 25 percent from 21
percent in 2014, reversing a downward trend in the FHA's market share since
2009. The VA-guaranteed share of such loans remained at approximately 10 percent
in 2015. The overall government-backed share of such purchase loans, including
FHA, VA, RHS and FSA loans, was 39 percent in 2015, increasing from 37 percent
in 2014, but down from 54 percent in 2009. One reason for the rise in the FHA's
market share may have been that the FHA significantly reduced its annual
mortgage insurance premiums by 0.5 percentage points in January 2015 for loans
with terms greater than 15 years.



 The FHA-insured share of first-lien refinance mortgages for 1-4 family, site
-built owner-occupied properties also increased in 2015, to about 14 percent
from 9 percent in 2014, while the VA-guaranteed share of such refinance loans
decreased by approximately 1 percentage point to 9 percent.



 The 2015 HMDA data also include information on loan pricing for loans
classified as "higher-priced." Higher-priced loans are defined as loans with
annual percentage rates (APRs) that exceed the average prime offer rates (APORs)
by at least 1.5 percentage points for first-lien loans and at least 3.5
percentage points for subordinate lien loans.[4] The data on the incidence of
higher-priced lending shows that nearly 6 percent of first-lien loans originated
in 2015 have APRs that exceed the loan price reporting thresholds, down from
nearly 8 percent in 2014.



 About 22 percent of the FHA's first-lien home purchase loans had APRs above the
reporting threshold for higher-priced loans, significantly down from 45 percent
in 2014.[5] As discussed earlier, the FHA lowered its annual mortgage insurance
premiums in 2015, which had a direct effect on the APRs of FHA loans, because
the APR includes the cost of mortgage insurance.



 As noted above, the HMDA data identify loans that are covered by HOEPA. Under
HOEPA, certain types of mortgage loans that have interest rates or total points
and fees above specified levels are subject to certain requirements, such as
additional disclosures to consumers, and are also subject to various
restrictions on loan terms. For 2015, 1,249 loan originations covered by HOEPA
were reported: 494 home purchase loans; 186 home improvement loans; and 569
refinance loans.

                                US Official News

                           September 30, 2016 Friday

Washington: Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council Announces
Availability of 2015 Data on Mortgage Lending

LENGTH: 1397  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has issued the following news
release:



 The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council (FFIEC) today announced
the availability of data on mortgage lending transactions at 6,913 U.S.
financial institutions covered by the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA).
Covered institutions include banks, savings associations, credit unions, and
mortgage companies. The HMDA data made available today cover 2015 lending
activity and include:





     applications, originations, purchases and sales of loans, denials, and
other actions related to applications

     loan amount

     loan type (conventional, Federal Housing Administration (FHA), Veterans
Administration (VA), Rural Housing Service (RHS) or Farm Service Agency (FSA))

     purpose (home purchase, home improvement, or refinancing)

     property type (1-4 family, multifamily, or manufactured housing)

     owner occupancy

     preapproval (home purchase loans only)

     property location (metropolitan statistical area (MSA), state, county, and
census tract)

     applicant and co-applicant characteristics (race, ethnicity, sex and
income)

     pricing-related data

     type of purchaser

     whether a loan is subject to the Home Ownership and Equity Protection Act
(HOEPA)

     whether a loan is secured by a first or subordinate lien, or is unsecured



 The data released today also include disclosure statements for each financial
institution, aggregate data for each MSA, nationwide summary statistics
regarding lending patterns, and Loan/Application Registers (LARs) for each
financial institution (LARs are modified to protect borrower privacy). The FFIEC
prepares and distributes this information on behalf of its member agencies.

 Understanding the Data



 The 2015 HMDA data use the census tract delineations, population, and housing
characteristic data from the 2010 Census and the combined 2006-2010 American
Community Surveys, as has been the case since 2012, when these delineations and
data were first used . In addition, the data reflect metropolitan statistical
area (MSA) definitions released by the Office of Management and Budget in 2013
that became effective for HMDA purposes in 2014.



 Caution should be used when comparing HMDA data across multiple years for
specific geographic areas due to the changes in MSA and census tract boundaries
and updates to the population and housing characteristics of census tracts.



 The HMDA data are the most comprehensive publicly available information on
mortgage market activity. Among other uses, the data help the public determine
how financial institutions are serving the housing needs of their local
communities, and facilitate fair lending and compliance examinations. When
examiners evaluate an institution's fair lending risk, they analyze HMDA data in
conjunction with other information and risk factors, in accordance with the
Interagency Fair Lending Examination Procedures available at
http://www.ffiec.gov/PDF/fairlend.pdf .



 The current HMDA data alone cannot be used to determine whether a lender is
complying with fair lending laws. The data do not include many potential
determinants of loan application and pricing decisions, such as the applicant's
credit history, debt-to-income ratio, the loan-to-value ratio, and other
considerations. Therefore, when examiners conduct fair lending examinations,
including ones involving loan pricing, they analyze additional information
before reaching a determination about an institution's compliance with fair
lending laws.

 Observations from the 2015 Data



 For 2015, the number of reporting institutions declined about 2.5 percent from
the previous year to 6,913. While there were some new reporters in 2015, this
number was more than offset by the number of institutions that reported in 2014
but did not do so in 2015. In most cases, this is because of mergers and
acquisitions.



 The 2015 data include information on 12.1 million home loan applications, of
which 7.4 million resulted in loan originations, and 2.1 million in purchased
loans, for a total of 14.2 million actions. The data also include information on
approximately 531,000 requests for preapprovals for home purchase loans.[1]



 The total number of originated loans of all types and purposes increased by 1.4
million between 2014 and 2015, or 22 percent. Refinance originations increased
by 36 percent, and home purchase lending increased by 13 percent.[2]



 From 2014 to 2015, the share of 1-4 family home purchase loans made to low- and
moderate-income borrowers (those with income of less than 80 percent of area
median income) rose slightly from approximately 26 percent in 2014 to roughly 27
percent in 2015, while the share of refinance loans to low- and moderate-income
borrowers decreased from 24 percent to 22 percent.[3]



 In terms of borrower race and ethnicity, the share of home purchase loans for
1-4 family properties made to black borrowers rose from 4.9 percent to nearly
5.2 percent, the share made to Hispanic-white borrowers rose from 7.5 percent to
7.9 percent, and those made to Asian borrowers declined slightly from 5.7
percent to 5.5 percent. The share of refinance loans made to black borrowers
decreased from 5.2 percent to 4.9 percent, the share made to Hispanic-white
borrowers rose slightly from 6.0 percent to 6.1 percent, and those made to Asian
borrowers rose from 4.5 percent to 5.1 percent.



 In 2015, black and Hispanic-white applicants experienced higher denial rates
for conventional home purchase loans than non-Hispanic white applicants. The
denial rate for Asian applicants is more comparable to the denial rate for
non-Hispanic white applicants. These relationships are similar to those found in
earlier years and do not take into account potential differences in risk
characteristics across demographic groups.



 In 2015, the FHA-insured share of first-lien home purchase loans for 1-4
family, site-built owner-occupied properties increased to 25 percent from 21
percent in 2014, reversing a downward trend in the FHA's market share since
2009. The VA-guaranteed share of such loans remained at approximately 10 percent
in 2015. The overall government-backed share of such purchase loans, including

in 2014, but down from 54 percent in 2009. One reason for the rise in the FHA's
market share may have been that the FHA significantly reduced its annual
mortgage insurance premiums by 0.5 percentage points in January 2015 for loans
with terms greater than 15 years.



 The FHA-insured share of first-lien refinance mortgages for 1-4 family, site
-built owner-occupied properties also increased in 2015, to about 14 percent

decreased by approximately 1 percentage point to 9 percent.



 The 2015 HMDA data also include information on loan pricing for loans
classified as "higher-priced." Higher-priced loans are defined as loans with
annual percentage rates (APRs) that exceed the average prime offer rates (APORs)
by at least 1.5 percentage points for first-lien loans and at least 3.5

in 2015 have APRs that exceed the loan price reporting thresholds, down from

premiums in 2015, which had a direct effect on the APRs of FHA loans, because

                               The Times (London)

                           August 14, 1999, Saturday

City life with the stress taken out

BYLINE: Joyce Blake

SECTION: Features

LENGTH: 1041 words


Not all villages are rural. Joyce Blake meets the couple with a plan to turn
inner-city London streets into a neighbourly urban community.

Max Comfort loves living in the city. He enjoys going out to theatres,
restaurants and having a choice of jobs.

But there is something missing from his daily routine. Although he couldn't bear
to commute from the country he does dream about living in a more caring
community.

Comfort longs to go home to a village where people have more time for each
other, are concerned about the environment and want their children to enjoy the
freedom of playing safely outside away from traffic. And while many city
dwellers fantasise about such a lifestyle, Comfort and his wife, Jo Rowbotham,
intend to make the dream a reality by founding an "urban village" in London.

Comfort says: "When people hear about co-housing communities it conjures up an
image of rural living with maypoles and thatched cottages. Jo and I have always
been interested in ecology-based building and we would both like to live
somewhere with a sense of community, but initially we couldn't see how we could
combine these ideals with our urban lifestyle and need for privacy."

Comfort and Rowbotham first realised that it might be possible to fulfil their
wishes when, during their honeymoon in America 18 months ago, they went to visit
a thriving co-housing project in California.

"What really struck us about this community was that it was a children's
paradise. Everyone knows each other, the elderly are looked after, the children
have freedom and parents are supported and escape the isolation that many feel
living in a city," said Comfort. "And the residents all agreed they had become
much more tolerant since living in the village."

Since then, Comfort and Rowbotham have progressed a long way with their plans.
They have looked at many other co-housing projects in Denmark and are now
convinced that the urban village can complement city life.

In 1998 they co-founded Loco - the London Co-Housing Project. Comfort is quick
to point out that it also means "mad" in Spanish.

Loco now has seven households (which comprise 16 adults and six children) who
are committed to the project and to contributing financially and socially to the
development of the scheme. They hope to add a further 13 households to the group
which, as far as possible, will reflect the mix and balance of society as a
whole.

The group is very busy. They are working on the business plan, discussing the
finances with banks and building societies, organising the social structure and
looking for a suitable property.

The village will consist of a group of private houses, ideally a mix of family
sized and smaller units which are entirely self-contained with their own
kitchens and bathrooms. The site will be traffic-free, with cars parked only on
the outer edge.

The main difference from other building developments is that there will also be
a common house where people can meet and share cooking and eating in the
evenings, so that most people need to cook only two or three times a month.

There will be a core of communal facilities including a dining/meeting space,
children's play area, a creche and possibly a laundry, workshops, library and a
business centre, depending on the needs of the residents. There is even the
possibility of creating a village school.

For many of the residents, issues such as energy efficiency and conservation are
important and they would like these elements to be included in the design and
construction.

They would like to build on a brownfield site and aim to create as much green
space as possible. Comfort hopes they can build houses which cater for the
elderly or disabled as well as young parents with a double-buggy. "Attention to
this type of detail costs pennies at the building stage, but it would cost
thousands of pounds to make these conversions later," he says.

The group believes it is both economically and socially important to include the
wider community in their plans. "We do not want to be known as the 'weirdos
behind the brick wall' and would like to interact with the local community,"
says Comfort.

"We believe that a lot of our facilities are compatible with commercial
enterprise. If we are going to have an expensive, industrial kitchen in the
village, which is only fully utilised after the children come home from school,
it makes sense to open it to the public as an organic cafe during the day.

"On the same level, we hope to have an organic market and offer our other
facilities to non-residents on a commercial basis."

While there are very few co-housing communities in the UK, the concept is not
new. Co-housing has become increasingly popular in Scandinavia and the States.

In Denmark, the trend began in the late Sixties and 5 per cent of the population
now live in co-housing communities. The Danish Government actively encourages
this type of lifestyle. If a group of people find a site and can raise 20 per
cent of the cost of the land and buildings, the Government will provide an
interest-free, 25-year loan for the balance.

There is good reason for the British Government to be interested in this type of
scheme as it does provide practical solutions for topical problems. By living in
a community with childcare facilities and a business centre it becomes much
easier for a single parent to combine work with looking after the children; jobs
are created in the village, which in turn reduces the level of traffic as fewer
people drive to work.

It also encourages the use of brown-field sites rather than building in our
countryside. Comfort is convinced the timing is right for this enterprise.

"It seems we are all so busy rushing about, yet we don't seem to belong
anywhere. I believe co-housing is the way forward. Perhaps in the new millennium
we can learn from the past and find a less stressful way of living.

"There seems to be little doubt that many of our social problems could be solved
and our practical needs met if people could really feel they were part of a
caring community in a big city."

For further information contact Loco (0181-374 0888) or e-mail:
janedent@hotmail.com

                                 MAIL ON SUNDAY

                                 April 13, 2003

Turkey, the East made easy...;
buying abroad - You'll get more for your money than anywhere else in Europe and
it's only four hours away

BYLINE: Victoria Combe

SECTION: Pg. 31

LENGTH: 956 words


The war in Iraq is almost certain to hit house prices in countries which share a
border. That's what's happened in Turkey where there are bargains to be had for
Britons looking for a home in this warm, friendly country.

The country's western and southern coastlines offer good beaches, unspoilt
countryside, ancient archaeological sites and lively small towns that welcome
foreigners.

Is Turkey safe for foreigners?

Yes. A glance at the map shows that the popular coastal towns are a long way
from any war zone. Turkey is 95 per cent Muslim, but it is a secular state and
people can drink alcohol, smoke and wear what they want. In rural areas it is
common to see women wearing headscarves, but it is not expected.

Turkey wants to join the EU and talks about its application for membership are
scheduled for 2004. The Turks welcome Britons and are happy to have them as
neighbours.

Why is it good to buy now?

The Turkish economy is suffering and the Iraqi conflict has severely hit the
stock market. This means British buyers can get more for their pounds in Turkey
than elsewhere in Europe.

The purchase has to be made in Turkish lire exchanged from foreign currency at a
Turkish bank and there are no building societies to provide loans.

However, for GBP 50,000 you can find a house with a garden and sea views.

Who would want to live in Turkey?

The British are only just realising that Turkey is an easy and cheap place to
buy property. It has been a popular holiday spot for years, but few have taken
the plunge and settled there.

The British are most attracted to Bodrum, the prettiest town on the north Aegean
Coast, which has its own international airport. There is now a population of 600
Britons, about half of whom are retired, and an honorary British Consulate to
look after them and the tourists.

Turkey appeals to those who want to discover another culture, not people who are
seeking Little England in the sun. It is only a four-hour flight from Britain,
but in terms of civilization it is an exotic cocktail of East and West.

The Ottoman cuisine is far more sophisticated than the doner kebabs we see in
Britain and the wines can be as good as those of Spain or Italy.

What are the pitfalls?

The language barrier. Turkish is considered to be one of the world's ten most
difficult languages to learn and by no means do all Turks speak English.

Any prospective buyer would be advised to find an English-speaking lawyer to
nurse them through the purchase.

Although in theory it should be easy for a Briton to buy property in Turkey, in
practice the red tape can be obstructive. According to the British Consulate, no
foreigner is allowed to buy land or property without getting permission from the
military commander in the area. This is to ensure that nothing is bought in
militarily sensitive areas. This process can take several months and the seller
is often reluctant to wait.

Also, a British buyer needs to have a residence permit and must buy within the
municipalities. No foreigner may purchase land or property in the villages or
rural areas, no matter how much money they have to offer.

What are the best areas to buy?

Bodrum, with its white sugar cube houses and pretty harbour, is one of the
loveliest spots and, unlike other resorts, doesn't shut down in the winter.

The town itself is noisy and crowded in the summer and the properties are more
expensive. The surrounding small towns of Gumusluk and Bitez are more tranquil.

In Yalikavak, on the Bodrum peninsular, the Port Bodrum Marina opens in May.

It will have a large number of luxurious villas with gardens for sale. Prices
are likely to start in the region of GBP 300,000.

In Bodrum, prices vary hugely depending on location and size. It is possible to
pick up a rundown studio apartment for GBP 5,000, but a large house close to the
harbour with a pool will go for GBP 100,000.

For sun lovers, there is Marmaris, on the western Mediterranean coast further
south. A British property consultant-who has lived in Turkey for 26 years
describes the city as 'a cleaner and more orderly Blackpool'.

Fethiye has mountains popular with hang-gliders and some of the country's best
beaches. Antalya, with a population of 600,000, is favoured by Germans, who have
set up their own enclave in nearby Alanya.

Istanbul is also cheap for foreigners who crave the bustle of this magical city.
It is laden with history and its winding streets are lined with bazaars and
mosques. A view of the Bosphorous doubles the price of a property.

For a bargain, Britons are looking at the area around the Galata Tower where
two-bedroom flats in Ottoman buildings sell for less than GBP 50,000.

And the weather?

On the south coast it is warm enough to sunbathe from April to November.

But Istanbul can have bad winters, with snow from December to March.

It starts to get warm in May.

What about Turkish workmen?

Turkish workmen do not make appointments and usually, when you call them, they
offer to come round the same or the next day. They are cheap and honest, but
need to be supervised. It is rare to find one who speaks English.

Websites: www.info vartur.com www.britishembassy.org.tr

sea-view balconies. Agent: www.property inturkey. com

                          New Straits Times (Malaysia)

                           March 20, 2002, Wednesday

Federal move on housing welcomed

SECTION: National; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 854 words


KUALA LUMPUR, Tues. - State Governments today welcomed the Federal
Government's move to take over the building of low-cost houses. The move,
they said, would reduce the burden of the State Governments.

In Johor, Menteri Besar Datuk Abdul Ghani Othman said the Federal
Government's move would supplement the State's ongoing efforts to increase
the number of such houses in the State.

He said Johor would continue with its aim of building 200,000 units of
low-cost houses within the next five years, with the co-operation of
private developers.

He said the State Government was supportive of the Cabinet's decision as
it faced some difficulties in financing the public low-cost housing
projects and collecting loan payments from house owners.

"We support the Cabinet's decision as it will lessen our burden to build
low-cost houses but we will continue our current co-operation with the
private developers to build low-cost houses at new housing estates in the
State," he said, adding that Johor Government would give the necessary
help to the Federal Government.

In Seremban, Negri Sembilan Housing and Local Government Committee
chairman Datuk Dr Yeow Chai Thiam hoped that State Governments would be
consulted first prior to the takeover.

He said the State Government had so far built 14,000 low-cost units in
the form of terrace houses and walk-up flats of which 7,000 had not been
sold.

Among new low-cost housing estates which have been completed are the
Springhill project in Seremban and Port Dickson, Nilai new town, Seremban
Selatan and Seremban Two. Another project under construction is located in
Seremban Three.

In Kuching, State Assistant Housing Minister Dr Abang Abdul Rauf Abang
Sen said Sarawak would not be affected by the Cabinet's decision as it had
its own system and authorities for building low cost houses.

"Economic factor is another reason why the decision could not be
extended to Sarawak," he said. He said at the moment the prices of low-
cost houses in the State were also lower than those in peninsula and that
all construction of low-cost houses was undertaken by the Sarawak Housing
Development Commission.

Nevertheless, Abang Abdul Rauf welcomed any assistance from the Federal
Government to help the State to expedite its effort to build more low-cost
houses.

"I hope that the Federal Government can extend the fund allocated under
the revolving fund to help the private sector to participate in the
building of low-cost houses here," he added.

In Kuantan, while welcoming the move, Pahang State Rural Development,
Settlers Affairs and Non-governmental Organisation committee chairman
Datuk Shahiruddin Ab Moin said the Federal Government should focus more on
low-cost housing projects in the rural areas.

He said this was because there was an increasing demand for such houses
among rural folk.

"We hope that more low-cost housing projects would be built in the rural
areas, especially around the Felda schemes."

In Alor Star, the State Government will submit a list of all proposed
low-cost housing projects in Kedah this year to facilitate the Federal
Government in the taking over of the projects.

State Housing and Local Government committee chairman Datuk Ahmad Bashah
Md Hanipah said among the projects were those in Kubang Pasu, Pendang,
Pokok Sena and Semeling near Sungai Petani.

He said the State Government would co-operate with the Government in
terms of site identification and land acquisition.

Ahmad Bashah said the State Housing Division had planned to build low-
cost homes in all districts under the Eighth Malaysia Plan.

Among them were 1,500 units of flats in Paya Nahu, near Sungai Petani
and 600 units in Mergong.

"Since 10 years ago, 10,000 units of low-cost homes have been built and
sold at RM25,000 per unit, but the price was increased to RM30,000 three
years ago."

In Kuala Terengganu, State Exco member Wan Abdul Muttalib Embong said
the Federal Government should complete all the low-cost housing projects
in Terengganu which has been stopped since Pas came to power in 1999.

He said it was not important whether the Pas-led State Government
supported the move by the Federal Government.

"What is most important is that all the 13 projects which they have
stopped should be resumed," said Wan Abdul Muttalib who is in charge of
local government, housing and the environment.

In Penang, State Housing Committee chairman Datuk Abdul Rashid Abdullah
said the Federal Government's move would help resolve the delay in the
construction of about 400 low-cost houses at two villages near Kepala
Batas on Seberang Perai.

He said the State Government had acquired the land in Kampung Besar and
Padang Chempedak but was awaiting additional funds to start construction
work.

"The project could not proceed because it was no longer viable to sell
low-cost units at RM25,000 each. The cost in building the terraced units
is now RM39,000 each.

"As such, the Federal Government's move to take over the construction of
low-cost units from the States is timely," he said.

                            Evening News (Edinburgh)

                              May 1, 2006, Monday
                                   1 Edition

Greenbelt anger at Water of Leith plans

BYLINE: GARETH EDWARDS

SECTION: Pg. 10

LENGTH: 506 words


GREEN belt campaigners have warned that development on the banks of the Water of
Leith has reached saturation point after plans were submitted to build more than
60 townhouses along the river.

More than 200 letters of objection have been sent into the council over outline
plans by Caledonian Heritable and a private landowner to build up to 63
townhouses over the north and south of the river at Baberton Loan.

The development would also include plans for a traffic bridge crossing the Water
of Leith and the relocation of an existing footbridge further down the river.

RPS Consultants, who are acting as agents for the developers, stated that the
plans would be part of the ongoing regeneration process along the Water of
Leith.

But objectors to the plans, including local residents, Scottish Natural
Heritage, the Water of Leith Conservation Trust and the local councillor,
believe future housing developments in the area must be stopped in order to
safeguard the green belt.

They say crisis point has been hit following years of development along the
water, with recent large and small-scale housing projects including Old Mossy
Mill which was redeveloped into 15 houses, as well as Spylaw and Woodhall Mill
at Juniper Green, which has been redeveloped into 50 exclusive homes by
Applecross.

Council planners have recommended that the latest plans be refused permission,
as the development is not suitable for the green belt and would be at risk from
flooding.

And Duncan Campbell, co-ordinator of the Edinburgh Green Belt Network, said that
no more housing developments could be accepted on the Water of Leith.

He said:

"We have now reached a crisis point because there have been so many developments
along the river over the years which have been chipping away at its rural
character and quietly eroding the green belt. We are concerned about the
environmental impact this development would have, particularly the road bridge."

Baberton councillor Alastair Paisley said:

"I was stunned at their plans to build a bridge for traffic over the Water of
Leith to access this site, and I think the local road into the area is single
track. It cannot cope with any more traffic."

And Helen Brown, manager of the Water of Leith Conservation Trust, also objected
to the development and said:

"The rural distinctions between Juniper Green and Colinton are already being
eroded and we need to stop any more housing development in that area otherwise
there will be no difference between them."

In a planning support statement, RPS, the agents representing the private
developer behind the proposal, said: "There is great interest in the
regeneration of the Water of Leith along its banks, as exemplified by the
housing scheme being undertaken by Applecross.

"This type of regeneration initiative not only meets local housing needs, but
new developments can improve the dynamic of the Water of Leith walkway."

No one from Caledonian Heritable was available for comment. A decision on the
application will be made by the council's planning committee on Wednesday.
