                        Santa Cruz Sentinel (California)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          November 26, 2008 Wednesday

County OKs $1.3 million for Felton affordable housing despite community concerns

BYLINE: Shanna McCord, Santa Cruz Sentinel, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 706 words


Nov. 26--FELTON -- Environmentalists squared off with affordable housing
advocates Tuesday as the nonprofit developer South County Housing sought nearly
$1.3 million from county leaders to continue planning a 55-unit project in
Felton.

The county Board of Supervisors -- acting as directors of the Redevelopment
Agency, which has already given $700,000 for the development -- agreed to
provide the additional funds in a 4-1 vote after listening to about 20 San
Lorenzo Valley residents voice opposition and support for the housing.

Supervisor Mark Stone voted against the funding, and favored delaying the
decision until county planners could provide a more detailed breakdown of how
the money would be spent.

Supervisors said there is a great need for affordable housing across Santa Cruz
County, and that the project would help fulfill state mandates that require a
certain amount of land be set aside for affordable housing.

"Redevelopment money has to be used for housing," Supervisor Jan Beautz said.
"It's been used in Watsonville, Aptos, Live Oak and Soquel, but it has not been
used in the San Lorenzo Valley. We haven't built any affordable housing in the
valley."

South County Housing, a Gilroy-based affordable housing developer, has proposed
building 24 apartments for very low-income seniors and 31 for-sale homes for
families with low and moderate incomes on an empty 15-acre meadow next to the

Felton Faire Shopping Center on Graham Hill Road.

About nine acres would be preserved as open space.

The property has been designated as an affordable housing site in the county's
general plan since 1994; South County Housing bought the land in 2005.

South County Housing believes the location next to the Felton Faire Shopping
Center, with access to a grocery store, bank, restaurants, public transportation
and parks, makes it ideal for a residential development.

However, several San Lorenzo Valley residents slammed the project mostly over
concerns with sewage disposal, storm-water runoff, traffic and flooding.

"The proposed on-site sewage disposal system is undersized, not sited correctly,
and is not supported by adequate soil and groundwater testing," said Bonny Doon
resident Steve Homan, an environmental consultant. "Furthermore, the proposed
drain fields are located but 40 feet from proposed new detention pond
excavations that will lead by ditches and a pipeline to Zayante Creek."

Some said they simply don't welcome the affordable housing project in the
valley.

A petition with 4,000 signatures of people opposed to the development was given
to the supervisors.

"We don't want the taxpayers' money spent on this wasteful project," Boulder
Creek resident Gordon Stewart told the supervisors. "Keep your city problems in
the city."

Some San Lorenzo Valley residents at the meeting said the housing would be an
asset for the community by giving more families a chance at homeownership.

Andy Leif of South County Housing said his organization has been studying
environmental issues at the site for the past three years, and plans to have an
environmental impact report conducted by a third party.

County Planning Director Tom Burns said the $1.3 million would help cover
"pre-development costs" such as taxes, loan fees, interest, technical studies,
civil engineering and the community planning process.

Burns said the project's rural location requires more intensive environmental
studies and community involvement, which make the development more costly and
time-consuming.

The $1.3 million is a loan with 3 percent interest that becomes part of the
permanent financing if the project becomes reality. If the project does not
materialize, the Redevelopment Agency would be repaid with proceeds of a sale of
the property to a private party.

                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                              June 29, 2012 Friday

Madawaska family celebrates home ownership through USDA program

BYLINE: Jen Lynds BDN Staff

LENGTH: 514 words


MADAWASKA, Maine -- Christopher and Erica Thibodeau of Madawaska thought often
about owning a home but considered it a far-off dream.


While both are employed at Marden's in the community, they do not earn very much
more than minimum wage and, after paying their living expenses, do not have a
great deal left over.


"Our credit is fine," Erica Thibodeau said Friday. "But we would have never had
the money to put a 10 percent or so down payment on a home. We figured we'd be
renters for much of our lives."


But they figured wrong, thanks to a program offered through the U.S. Department
of Agriculture Rural Development. The couple tapped into the agency's Single
Family Housing 502 Direct Program and in March signed papers to close a deal
that secured a home for themselves and their two children, Cyprian, 7, and
Kristiana, 1.


The family was recognized Friday in a brief ceremony at their home on Pleasant
Street by USDA Rural Development to commemorate National Homeownership Month in
June. After a year of renting the home, they now are paying the mortgage. The
payment is only slightly more than their monthly rent and they are building
equity for their future at the same time.


Section 502 loans are used primarily to help low-income individuals or
households purchase homes in rural areas, according to the USDA Rural
Development website. Funds can be used to build, repair, renovate or relocate a
home or to purchase and prepare sites, including providing water and sewage
facilities.


Loans for the modest homes, which must meet certain criteria and inspection
standards, are up to 33 years, or 38 years in some instances.


"In the past three years, we have moved four times," Thibodeau said Friday.
"This last time, we found a home to rent and after awhile decided that we really
wanted to buy it. We just could not afford to make the down payment and we were
concerned about taxes and things, so we could not find any bank or credit union
programs that we could access. When I was working at Marden's, a customer came
in and told me about the USDA program."


The family found out about the 502 Direct Program and soon learned that they
qualified.


"We met the income guidelines, so we did not have to make a down payment and we
have a fixed rate for the loan," she said. "We were spending $400 to $500 a
month in rent and we had just enough left over to get by. Now we are paying
under $500 and that money is going toward something we'll own. It is a much
better way to do it."


Virginia Manuel, USDA Rural Development state director, presented the family
with a signed, framed photo of the home during the brief ceremony. Other USDA
Rural Development representatives were present, as were officials from U.S.
Sens. Olympia Snowe's and Susan Collins' offices, and from the office of Rep.
Mike Michaud.


While she and her husband are happy, their children seem the most thrilled,
Thibodeau said Friday.


"They are a lot happier," she said. "This is a nice neighborhood and the
children are always out playing. My son is always out in our yard or in a nearby
yard with a friend. It's fantastic."

                  Wisconsin State Journal (Madison, Wisconsin)

                             June 1, 2005 Wednesday
                                  ALL EDITION

AG NEWS

SECTION: CAPITAL REGION BUSINESS JOURNAL; Pg. 36

LENGTH: 636 words


In its first year of operation, the Wisconsin Dairy Business Innovation Center
has helped dozens of businesses seeking to enter niches in their markets.

With support from the state Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer
Protection and $2 million in federal money for its first year, the center helped
87 businesses that have opened or expanded six plants.

"We thought we would get about 30 people the first year, and we had (nearly)
100," said center manager Dan Carter said. "We were very lucky we were at the
right place at the right time."

The center is also helping producers to make better cheeses in the Old World
style. With help from the state Agriculture Department and UW-Madison's Babcock
Institute for international dairy research, the center has sent Wisconsin
cheesemakers to Switzerland, England and France to study techniques such as
aging and finishing cheeses in manmade caves.

Farmers struggling on two fronts

Area farmers are facing a squeeze: rising energy costs and lower prices for the
goods they produce, and that can affect both rural communities and the entire
state. In Dane County, for instance, growers and food processors sent $3.2
billion cycling through the local economy in 2000.

The cost of energy, from the electric bill to the price at the pump, will be a
big factor in determining this year's profits. Nationwide, the U.S. Department
of Agriculture estimated that farmers this year will pay $8.2 billion for fuel
and oil, up almost 21 percent from 2003.

"They're taking it in stride," Landmark energy division manager Mike Bandt said.
"But there's not going to be a lot of extra cash floating around come fall."

One bright spot for dairy farmers is the relatively high price of milk. In
March, the price paid nationwide for milk used to make cheese was $14.08 for
11.6 gallons. But UW-Madison dairy economist Ed Jesse said it's highly unlikely
that this year's milk prices would reach 2004's record levels of more than $20,
or that farm profits in the state would reach last year's mark of $1.8 billion.

New 'Farm Fresh Atlas'

The 2005 "Farm Fresh Atlas" has a new look - an expanded booklet format that
makes it easier to find specific farms and food.

The free guide includes more than 100 farms, farmers' markets and food-related
businesses that pledge to protect the land and water resources, treat animals
with care and respect, and provide safe working conditions for their employees.

The atlas is available at many farmers' markets (including the Saturday but not
Wednesday Dane County Farmers' Market), public libraries, farms, food co-ops and
other area businesses. For a complete list of distribution sites, visit
www.reapfoodgroup.org/atlas/index.htm.

The "Farm Fresh Atlas" is a collaborative project of REAP Food Group, the Dane
County Farmers' Market, the UW-Madison Center for Integrated Agricultural
Systems, and the Friends of the Dane County Farmers' Market.

Federal agency recognizes Eagle Mortgage lender

SPRING GREEN - The U.S. Department of Agriculture Rural Development agency
recently presented a Million Dollar Lender Award to Pat Keppler of Eagle
Mortgage.

The award recognizes lenders who have played a significant role in the success
of Rural Development's Guaranteed Rural Housing program in Wisconsin.

Recipients used more than $1 million from the program in 2004 to finance home
purchases.

Netherlands dairy moving to Sauk County

PRAIRIE DU SAC - A dairy in the Netherlands has received a $262,500 loan from
the state to relocate its operations to Sauk County.

According to a news release from the Department of Commerce, the loan will help
Griesen Dairy with its $2.4 million relocation plan and will help pay for 525
cows. The loan is a part of the state's Milk Volume Production program.

The dairy is buying 40 acres in Prairie du Sac and will create seven jobs.

                              The Herald (Harare)

                               November 28, 2013

Housing - a Basic Human Right

BYLINE: Pardon Gotora

LENGTH: 1751 words


HOUSING shortages have been stalking Zimbabweans for many years now. The harsh
economic situation that dogged the country for almost a decade made the
situation worse as land prices and the cost of building materials were beyond
many locals' reach with only a few Zimbabweans in the Diaspora managing to buy
stands.

Housing is an important issue that keeps many Zimbabweans, especially the
urbanites, awake at night as they ponder what to do to own one.

The general definition of a house is a building or dwelling in which people
live. The United Nations Habitat Agenda defines housing as a basic human right,
which must be accorded to all regardless of gender, colour, race, religion or
any other discriminatory milieu.

Similarly, the Constitution of Zimbabwe Amendment (No. 20) venerates the same
and states that "the State and all agencies of Government at every level must
take reasonable legislative and other measures, within the limits of the
resources available to them, to enable every person to have access to adequate
shelter".

Some questions that are likely to come up would be:

Are the mere walls and the roofs over the head regarded as decent houses for the
people, both in the rural and urban ambiance?

Is the shell enough to be called decent accommodation?

What would be the best way to describe decent accommodation or decent shelter?

It goes without say that housing provision goes beyond just a four-walled
building under asbestos or a round thatched hut in which many people in rural
areas live. There are attendant amenities that create sustainable human
habitation with due regards to the environment.

Some of the amenities include water and sanitation, access roads, schools,
clinics, recreational facilities, churches, power and energy and sources of
employment, to mention but these few. However, the Government is seized with
insurmountable challenges of providing decent housing to the people of Zimbabwe.

Inasmuch as there is demand for housing in the rural areas, the effects manifest
and are much felt in the urban areas. For the former, it is more about the
quality of the houses, access to safe drinking water and sanitation, access to
sources of power and energy.

There is a tendency to cast a blind eye to the rural areas on most of the
projects planned and implemented by institutions in the housing sector. The main
reason for such "neglect" is the economic value that decision- makers attach to
the investments in rural housing.

The conception is that no investor "in their right frame of mind" would want to
put money on rural housing since there will be no returns on such investment.
The property does not attract any value, hence it is not worthy investing in.

Consequently, rural housing comes at the periphery of the planning horizon of
any institution involved in housing development. In various fora that I have
been privileged to attend, there has been a lot of talk about rural housing and
numerous documents have been written about the same, but just good enough for
the library. Little initiatives have been witnessed and the majority of our
rural settlements are unplanned, which render the provision of adequate water
and sanitation and all the other attendant amenities challenging.

For instance, how would you electrify the homesteads in the Gotora village in
Uzumba under Chief Nyajina where it is even difficult to describe the settlement
pattern found there? For lack of a better word, I would rather describe the
settlement as haphazard.

The pattern is often determined by the number of children that the father has.
With the approval of the village head, the father subdivides his portion to
accommodate his sons and on rare occasions daughters. It is often subsumed the
daughter will marry and stay with her husband at her in-laws homestead. It will
be the obligation of her "new" parents to find her where to build her own house
to live.

The few accommodated daughters might be those divorced or widowed and chased
away by their in-laws.

The Government has prioritised housing provision since independence as
vindicated by annual budgetary allocations. They have even attempted to address
the issue of rural housing by creating a stand-alone Ministry of Rural Housing
and Social Amenities in 2005.

Although the ministry endeavoured to make an instant impact their efforts were
like a drop in the ocean compared to the demand for decent rural housing.

This could be attributed to underfunding and the sanctions-induced
hyperinflation obtaining from the year the ministry was created until the
creation of the Government of National Unity in 2009 and the adoption of the
multi-currency system in Zimbabwe.

From 2009 to August 2013, there was yet another ministry responsible for housing
provision known as Ministry of National Housing and Social Amenities.

All these efforts by the Government indicate the magnitude of the challenge at
hand-fighting homelessness and also show the determination by President Mugabe
to address the people's needs.

On the other hand, the demand for housing in the urban areas has far-reaching
consequences than in the rural areas. Urbanisation has taken its toll on all of
the developing countries worldwide, and Zimbabwe is no exception. After
independence in 1980, the Government of Zimbabwe repealed all the laws that
prohibited the free movement of people to areas of their choice.

Hitherto, the black majority were regarded as migrant workers who were only
allowed in towns and cities during the tenure of their employment, after which
they would go back to their reserves (kuruzevha).Therefore, they were not
allowed to own houses in urban areas and there was a cosmetic demand for
housing, which was a prerogative of the white minority.

This ideology even affected the land use planning then, where the planners were
planning for a smaller population in terms of the roads, sewer and water
extraction and treatment facilities and electricity. There was no anticipation
of regime change by the settler government despite all the revolutionary
pointers obtaining then.

At independence, the status quo was upended and the black majority began to
enjoy freedom of movement. Those sitting tenants who were in Government/ council
rented-houses were offered those same houses with a repayment period of up to 25
years.

The urban areas began to witness the influx of people looking for greener
pastures, which magnifies the notion that cities are magnets of hope. But this
rural-urban migration brought with it challenges, which the Government had to
tackle resoundingly. The supply side could not match the enormous demand brought
about by this rural-urban migration.

The existing infrastructure could no longer cope with increasing population in
the cities and towns.

Resultantly, the sewer and water pipes have continued to burst, which makes them
even more expensive to maintain. The local authorities, who are the planning
authorities in their areas of jurisdiction, have failed to fully service and
maintain the infrastructure due to lack of adequate capital.

This has even hampered the opening of new townships in the urban areas due to
lack of off-site and on-site infrastructure. The Government and local
authorities have run short of serviced land or even land that is closer to
existing infrastructure.

Some of the councils have resorted to creating infill stands to maximise on the
existing infrastructure, a situation which has to some extent compromised on the
environment since some of the pieces of land are on wetlands which must be
preserved.

Meanwhile, failure by Government to meet the ballooning housing demand led to
the colossal mushrooming of informal settlements, side-buildings on existing
stands, overcrowding in most high-density suburbs, unsanctioned connections of
water, sewer and electricity among other challenges. The informal settlements
dearth for proper water and sanitation facilities, lacks security of tenure and
pose a greater risk of chronic diseases outbreak, and endanger the environment.

The UN Human Settlement Programme (UN-Habitat in Mozambique), in its
publication,"Slum Upgrading and Vulnerability Reduction in Mozambique",
intimated that the living conditions for the majority of the urban population in
Mozambique are not dissimilar to those found in other rapidly urbanising
countries, particularly in Africa.

The conditions are characterised by unplanned settlements, which house over 70
percent of the population in Mozambique, the vast majority of whom live in
overcrowded conditions and lack access to secure tenure, structurally sound
housing, and improved water and sanitation. In most developing countries,
Zimbabwe included, informal settlements often grow at a rate far surpassing the
rate of investment in urban infrastructure and the requisite services.

In view of the extent of the challenges in providing decent housing to the
people, concerted effort is required from all the stakeholders in the housing
sector.

The Government, the local authorities, professional bodies such as planners,
engineers and architects, research institutions like universities and
polytechnic colleges; land developers, banks and building societies;
community-based organisations, non-governmental organisations; and the community
itself among other stakeholders should join forces to tackle homelessness.

We used to have a slogan "Housing for all by 2020", but this has since gone into
oblivion. Whatever the target the sector has agreed upon, it requires not
individual efforts, but we need to join hands as a nation.

I hope the Ministry of Local Government, Public Works and National Housing will
be instrumental in re-energising the stakeholders and bring a breath of fresh
air. My plea to the ministry would be to re-align their priorities and bring
rural housing on the radar.

The issue goes beyond just the communal areas and the old resettlements. We now
have the new farmers who were resettled under the Government's land reform
programme on the eve of the new millennium and they must be taken care of in
terms of housing provision.

Whether the Government will provide afford-able loans or construct houses
remains to be seen.

Hopefully, the ministry has the prototype designs for a typical homestead like
the ones used to build model homesteads for some of our traditional leaders.

Pardon Gotora is a Housing Officer in the Ministry of Local Government, Public
Works and National Housing. The views and opinions expressed in this article are
personal and do not in any way reflect those of the ministry.

                              The Washington Post

                     July 17, 1980, Thursday, Final Edition

NE Hechinger Mall Site Picketed by 100 Workers

BYLINE: By Courtland Milloy, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A32

LENGTH: 560 words


About 100 demonstrators marched on the site of the Hechinger Mall in Northeast
Washington yesterday, protesting what they said was the failure of mall
contractors to hire neighborhood blacks as construction workers in accordance
with the District of Columbia's residential employment plan.

The mall's owner, John Hechinger Jr., a prominent liberal Democrat who is active
in D.C. politics, said he was "shocked and disappointed" that he had been
targeted for protest.

"We probably have the best affirmative action of any construction site in town,"
Hechinger said.  "I don't know why they are doing this to us."

Hechinger said that 33 percent of the construction work on the $10 million mall
has been assigned to minority firms.  He added that 41 percent of those on the
construction work force are District of Columbia residents.

City and federal regulations stipulate the project, which has received a $3.5
million federal loan through the D.C. Department of Housing and Community
development, must hire, whenever pososible, minority residents from the
riot-scarred H Street NE area.

Although no official hiring goal has been set for the Hechinger site, Mayor
Marion Barry recently set a 51 percent minority hiring goal for the Convention
Center project.  Community activists in turn have adopted that figure for other
construction sites.

"So the Godfather of D.C. is shocked, huh?" said Rev. Stan Barry, director of
the H Street Project Area Committee, which maintains a pool of construction
workers available for work on the Mall project.  "Well, I'm shocked, too.  Only
18 people from our community have been hired.  It doesn't make me feel good to
have to protest against John, but I made commitments too, and my credibility is
on the line."

The demonstrators also criticized the District of Columbia government for
"failure to enforce its own laws," particularly those requiring apprenticeship
programs in the construction field.  Although the Hechinger Mall has an
apprenticeship plan that has been approved by the D.C. Apprenticeship Council,
no apprentices have been indentured so far, according to council staff.  The
project is expected to be completed in April.

After the demonstration yesterday, formal complaints were lodged against the
project with the D.C. Office of Human Rights, the D.C. Department of Employment
Services and the city's Department of Housing and Community Development.

Each of these agencies has contract compliance review offices that can
investigate the complaints.  Although none of them can stop payment of the loan
to the project, they could find it in "noncompliance," and jeopardize future
grant monies for other projects.

"We refuse to tolerate government indifference, incompetence and inaction any
longer," said Charles Richardson, head of the D.C. Jobs Coalition.  "The failure
of the government to conduct adequate reviews, failure of the contractors to
comply with federal payroll guidelines and failure to enforce laws pertaining to
aprenticeship job training through systematic discrimination have led to adverse
impact of the quality of life on minorities and women in our city," she said.

Other participants in the demonstration included the Washington Building Trade
Council, which is upset because only seven of the 30 contractors working on the
Mall are unionized.

                              Western Morning News

                           October 15, 2015 Thursday

SECTION: BUSINESS:CONSUMER; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 811  words


Stop wasting   farm land

The debate about the sell-off of social housing, like the debate about
house-building, seems always to omit the most crucial factor.

The popular equation balances people, houses and money to try and find a
solution to the need, in the Northern hemisphere, to shelter everybody. It
doesn't take Einstein to realise that something's missing!

The factor which is missing   is land. It is important because, even the most
prosperous (or indebted!) of second/third/fourth home owners will gain no
enjoyment  in value if there is nothing in the larder and nothing on the tap to
eat or drink. No amount of pluralist votes in any number of elections will help.
How much land do we need for food, energy, fuel, or for woodland, medicine or
for its own sake? Surely, in planning our use of land, we should be balancing
and managing this most finite of resources.

If we consume too much land by building houses to replace those with which we
over-feed the investment industry, the visitor trade and town centre office
demand, and add to this the town centre obsession with only using the ground
floor, leaving hundreds, if not thousands (in Cornwall alone) of perfectly good
dwellings in semi-dereliction 'over the shop', then the outcome is inevitable -
we will clutch parched throats and aching bellies under luxurious roofs and will
fight each other for scraps.

The imminent sell-off of housing association  stock, built with public money to
meet the needs of those increasingly excluded from the   wasteful housing
so-called 'market', and the blithe assurance that it'll be all right because we
will build more and more, rings hollow.

In a society which has institutionalised the food bank, which is held to annual
ransom by a private sector water companyremains obscurely unaccountable to those
whose resources it controls, and where we pay subsidies to increasing numbers
who can't afford payments on homes which their owners (landlords or banks) have
to levy in turn, to meet the costs of the loans which enable them to own, build
and 'profit', we are risking both peace and financial credibility!

Planning' applications over the past generation  no longer  concern  'brown'
land, or occasional fields - they now consume farms, and are beginning to
consume clusters of farms. The erstwhile Truro Area Local Plan postulated the
removal over 15 years of 17 farms from within a 12-mile radius of this town -
that is, a town put there to serve the concentrated area of high quality
farmland. The whole thing is driven by a system obsessed with servicing a
bureaucratic invention dubbed 'the five year land supply' - as if land is
manufactured somewhere up a Norwegian fjord!

With the Cornwall Local Plan  in the offing, and with globalism, climate change,
austerity, population growth and ageing now directly affecting the resilience of
our society  is it time to re-focus the planning system, the assumptions of the
'market', and the husbandry of public resources. Selling housing association
homes is as  stupid a form of anti-social behaviour as is flogging council
houses or spitting in the street!

Bert Biscoe

Truro

Keith Sharp

                               The New York Times

                July 17, 1984, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

HOUSING, NEVER LIVED IN, BEING RAZED

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. MADDEN

SECTION: Section B; Page 2, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 986 words

DATELINE: NAUGATUCK, Conn., July 16


The Naugatuck Heights Apartments, a cluster of 13 buildings that were to have
been homes for 135 families, are being demolished, after more than a decade of
litigation and controversy.

Built with a Federal loan guarantee in the early 1970's at a cost of about $4
million, the buildings stand on a steep, rocky hill with a sweeping view of the
lush, green valley of the Naugatuck River.



Occupancy Certificate Refused

But nobody ever lived there. Naugatuck officials, citing an array of building
code violations and alterations to the project's original design plans, refused
to grant a certificate of occupancy in 1973.

Over the next 11 years, the buildings, almost 95 percent completed and with the
kitchen appliances already installed, remained vacant and fell victim to
deterioration and vandalism.

Earlier this year, the borough of Naugatuck sold the two-story buildings on the
13.45-acre site for about $1,000 each to salvagers, who are carting off the
plywood, the insulation and the roofing trusses for resale.

Demolition of the 11 remaining buildings is scheduled for completion by
November. Local officials hope to convert the site into a park in this old
factory town, just south of Waterbury, with a population of more than 27,000.



Glaring Example of Failure

As a federally aided housing project for low- to middle-income families, the
Naugatuck Heights Apartments were a glaring example of failure. What went wrong
at Naugatuck Heights is still a matter of dispute between Federal and local
officials.

''What a waste,'' said Chris Billings, 19 years old, as he kicked sheets of
plywood loose from a roof and loaded them into a pickup truck in front of the
building he and a partner bought.

''It was just a nightmare,'' Naugatuck's Mayor, William C. Rado, said today in
an interview. ''I'm sure the Federal Government is happy to get rid of it, and
so are we.''

''I would say it's unique,'' Mary Lou Crane, a special assistant in the Hartford
office of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, said of the
project's failure. ''It's the only one we had.''

Naugatuck officials, such as Mayor Rado, said H.U.D. should never have
guaranteed the loan to build a project on what they said was a rocky, hilly site
unsuitable for that number of buildings. ''There's a multitude of sins up there,
in my opinion,'' Mr. Rado said of the project.

Federal officials said the issuance of the building permits that allowed
construction to start was a local responsibility. ''You don't let a project go
that far and decide you don't like it,'' said Mrs. Crane of the H.U.D. Hartford
office.



Origins Lost in Obscurity

The origins of the project have been lost in obscurity with town and Federal
records in storage and not readily available and the original participants no
longer involved with the project.

According to the files of The Naugatuck Daily News, the project was conceived in
1969, and a private partnership called Naugatuck Associates began construction
in 1971, with the Federal Government guaranteeing a $2.5 million mortgage. The
guarantee was part of a housing program, which is no longer available, under
which the Federal Government subsidized the interest costs of projects to hold
down the rents.

Although a H.U.D. architect warned in 1972 that the building site was extremely
rugged, the nearly completed project was not halted until 1973. Naugatuck
refused to issue a certificate of occupancy, and the Federal Government refused
to increase its loan guarantee to permit the construction of retaining walls and
other design changes.

Wash of Boulders and Water


''I'm the one who put the stopper to it,'' said Mr. Rado, a Democrat who was
first elected Mayor in 1973.

He said the developers had not followed their original design plans that had
been submitted to obtain a building permit. He said that the grade of the road
winding up the hill among the buildings was too steep, that the rocky ledges
should not have been built upon and that boulders and water washed down from the
site onto the property of neighboring homeowners.

''The place wasn't fit for anything,'' Mr. Rado said. ''If you took the wrong
step out the door you were in trouble. I don't know how the hell they got a
building permit in the first place.''

''I'm sure somebody made big bucks,'' he said of the project, but he said he was
never able to establish who or how much.

After the project was stopped in 1973, there was prolonged litigation, according
to Federal officials, and the Federal Government finally foreclosed and took
title to the property in 1981.

Records Not Available

H.U.D. officials said they could not estimate the financial loss to the Federal
Government because the records were not available, but local news accounts have
put the loss at more than $3 million.

In 1982, H.U.D. sold the property to Naugatuck for $40,000, touching off a long
dispute over what the borough's government should do with the property.

Naugatuck residents in a referendum in late 1982 voted by a 3-to-1 margin to
tear down all the remaining buildings instead of trying to retain a few of them
for conversion into condominiums.

''It's a shame the three or four buildings at the bottom of the hill had to
go,'' the Mayor said. ''They could have helped someone out.''

Naugatuck is growing and could use the housing, he said.

Before selling the buildings to salvagers earlier this year, Naugatuck conducted
a raffle and sold the kitchen appliances and plumbing fixtures to local
residents. ''At least some people got some good from it,'' the Mayor said.

Standing on a roofing truss the other day, Mr. Billings looked down through the
skeleton of the building he was demolishing.

''The buildings were well built, I'll say that,'' he said. ''Look at those oak
parquet floors. You don't see that in too many buildings these days.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                            South China Morning Post

                            November 22, 2010 Monday

Rise in spending power is luring major developers

BYLINE: Peggy Sito

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 02

LENGTH: 802 words


Policy risk is driving both developers and foreign investment funds away from
the mainland residential market and towards commercial property, say analysts.

And it is a trend that, once under way, could continue for several years.

In addition to the "push" factor of increased risk caused by the introduction of
measures aimed at curbing the growth in home prices, the shift in focus has
arisen because of the rise in consumer spending  power.

Beginning in April this year, the government in Beijing has announced a series
of measures to take the speculative heat out of the residential market, included
the tightening of residential development loans to developers, increasing
mortgage rates and cutting mortgage loans to individuals.

Norman Krone, president of NK Real Estate Advisors, a Florida-based property
consultant with an office in Shanghai, says this is leading developers and
investors to put greater emphasis on retail real estate.

He believes the trend will last for many years.

A number of big developers are currently raising their investments in retail
properties in Beijing.

China Vanke, the mainland's largest public-listed residential developer in terms
of market capitalisation, is building a 100,000 square metre shopping centre and
Sino-Ocean Land, in a venture with Swire Properties, is constructing an 860,000
square metre mall, also in Beijing.

Hong Kong-based New World China last week said it had teamed up with a local
developer to buy a  residential and commercial site in Beijing for 820 million
yuan (HK$956 million).

The 267,918 square metre site in the Shunyi district could include housing and
offices and provide a total gross floor area of 200,012 square metres.

Also last week, Shui On Construction and Materials last week said it bought a
51,000 square metre space at a commercial project in Shanghai's Pudong financial
district for about one billion yuan.

Grosvenor Fund Management, partly owned by the privately-owned international
property development and fund management group Grosvenor of Britain, recently
acquired a 126,000 square metre retail development in Shanghai for 1.7 billion
yuan.

Stanley Ching, senior managing director and head of real estate at Citic Capital
Holdings, said property investors were exploring what they saw as the next big
sub-markets as policy risks in the housing sector grew.

Citic Capital is developing a shopping centre in Changsha and says it will shift
its focus to the retail sector in the future.

On the back of an expanding residential market, an improvement in domestic
consumption will increase the need for retail properties, investors said.

China's retail sales of consumer goods grew 18.6 per cent in October year on
year as the fastest growth among major economies spurred spending.

Urban consumption hit 1.24 trillion yuan in October, up 18.9 per cent year on
year. Rural residents spent 188.9 billion yuan on consumption goods in October,
up 16.8 per cent year on year, according to the  National Statistics Bureau.

"Many retailers from Asia, including Hong Kong, are entering China in view of
this growing consumption power. It is the right time to build the platform,"
said Ding Hui, managing director of Inter Ikea Centre Group China (IICC).

Tapping into the rising consumption power in the world's most populous nation,
IICC is building shopping centres in Beijing, Wuhan and Wuxi at a total
investment cost of US$1.2 billion. As China's economy expands, domestic
consumption will rise, said Ding, and this process is now well under way, based
on Ikea's own experience since it started operating on the mainland 12 years
ago.

It very quickly saw its Shenzhen and Chengdu outlets topping the list of the
group's 300-plus shops in terms of turnover growth, said Ding.

International retailers have their eyes on this growth potential, with retailers
in Singapore, Hong Kong, Korea and Japan entering the market.

"There is a huge consumption potential in the market. Urbanisation is growing at
a fast pace and the government makes a lot of effort in the development of
infrastructure. That benefits the development of retail properties," said Ding.

Krone said the trend by investors to place greater emphasis on retail properties
was likely to continue.

"The official policy of the central government is to encourage spending of some
of the increased incomes on consumer goods instead of just saving the additional
amounts.

"This indicates the average citizen will increasingly become a shopper or buyers
of consumer goods."

In view of the positive outlook, Ding said IICC was looking at the
possibilities presented by expanding in Shanghai. "Ikea, the home furnishing
retailer, plans to open 18 outlets by 2015. We hope to follow this step," he
said.

Meanwhile, he was not concerned about an oversupply of shopping centres on the
mainland.

LOAD-DATE: November 23, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Booming trade at a Beijing mall. Mainland retail sales in the year to
October rose 18.6 per cent as a growing economy spurred spending. Photo:
Bloomberg

                             National Mortgage News

                               February 24, 1997

Housing Aspects of the Budget

BYLINE: BY ROBERT RUBIN, Secretary of the Treasury

SECTION: OPEN FORUM; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 811 words

HIGHLIGHT: Mr. Rubin recently spoke at a session of the House Ways and Means
Committee, where he discussed President Clinton's budget proposal for fiscal
year 1998.  A section of his statement is presented as our Open Forum.


The Budget expands the availability of deductible individual retirement accounts
(IRAs) by doubling, over time, the current income limits for deductible
contributions.  In 1997 through 1999, eligibility would be phased out for
couples filing joint returns with adjusted gross incomes between $ 70,000 and $
90,000 ($ 45,000 and $ 65,000 for single filers).

Beginning in 2000, eligibility would be phased out for couples filing joint
returns with AGI between $ 80,000 and $ 100,000 ($ 50,000 and $ 70,000 for
single filers).  The income phase out, as well as the $ 2,000 annual
contribution limit, would be indexed for inflation beginning in 2001.  As under
current law, any individual who is not an active participant and whose spouse is
not an active participant in an employer-sponsored plan would be eligible for
deductible IRAs without regard to their income.

In addition, beginning in 1997, taxpayers would have the options of either
deducting the amount deposited in an IRA account, or foregoing an immediate
deduction and be free of tax and penalties when the funds are withdrawn from a
new Special IRA provided the funds remain in the Special IRA for at least five
years.

Finally, penalty-free early withdrawals from either type of IRA would be
expanded to include withdrawals to pay for higher education costs, first-home
purchases, long-term unemployment and catastrophic medical costs of certain
family members not covered under current law.

The Budget provides substantial simplification and tax relief for millions of
Americans by replacing the current-law tax treatment of capital gains on home
sales with an exclusion of up to $ 500,000 of gain for married taxpayers filing
joint returns ($ 250,000 for other taxpayers).  The exclusion is available every
two years, so long as the taxpayer used the house as a principal residence for
at least two of the five years prior to the sale.  The exclusion generally
applies to sales on or after January 1, 1997.

The Budget will spur private-sector participants in revitalizing distressed
communities and generate job opportunities for long-term welfare recipients.

To encourage companies to clean up abandoned, contaminated industrial properties
located in distressed communities, remediation costs incurred in connection with
the abatement or control of certain environmental contaminants would be
immediately deductible if incurred for a qualified site.

Qualified sites include business or income-producing properties located in
specified high-poverty areas where it has been certified that hazardous
substances are present or potentially present in the property.  The deduction
would be subject to recapture as ordinary income upon a subsequent disposition
of the property at a gain.  The proposal would apply to expenses incurred after
the date of enactment.

The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development would be authorized to designate
two urban empowerment zones in addition to the six urban and three rural zones
designated on December 21, 1994.  This would have the effect of extending the
current empowerment zone tax incentives to these additional areas, with
technical modifications.

In addition, 20 additional empowerment zones and 80 additional enterprise
communities, which will be subject to modified eligibility criteria, would be
authorized.  These additional zones would have available a different combination
of tax incentives than those available to existing zones.

Among the 20 zones, 15 would be in urban areas and five would be in rural areas.
The 80 communities would be divided between 50 urban areas and 30 rural areas.
Areas within Indian reservations would be eligible for designation.

The Community Development Banking and Financial Institutions Act of 1994 created
the Community Development Financial Institutions (CDFI) Fund to provide equity
investments, grants, loans and technical assistance to financial institutions
that have community development as their primary mission.

The Budget would make $ 100 million in nonrefundable tax credits available to
the CDFI Fund to allocate among equity investors between 1997 and 2006.  The
allocation of credits is capped at 25% of the amount invested in any project and
would be determined by the CDFI Fund using a competitive process.

The goal of the Welfare Reform Act of 1996 (the Welfare Act) is to move
individuals from welfare to work.  To help achieve this goal, the Budget
includes a new welfare-to-work credit that would enable employers to claim a 50%
credit on the first $ 10,000 of annual wages paid to certain long-term public
assistance recipients for up to two years.

In addition, the Budget would expand the existing Work Opportunity Tax Credit to
include able-bodied adults, ages 18-50, who have met their responsibilities
under the law but are subject to the time limits for food stamps.

                        Dalal Street Investment Journal

                          August 21, 2016 6:30 AM EST

Interview: CFHL Using Technology to Increase its Operational Landscape

LENGTH: 583  words


S K Hota, Managing Director Can Fin Homes Ltd.

Net profits for Q1 FY 17 grew by 55 per cent YoY at Rs 4,972.99 Lakhs. What in
your view has led to such a steady growth?

Our Net Profit for Q1 FY 17 has grown by 55% on YOY basis. It could be
attributed to the sustained loan book growth coupled with improved margins.
Backed by higher earnings and reduced cost of borrowing . Our Net Interest
Income (NII) has improved by 43% year on year, which is the major contributor.
This apart, our operating costs have been contained well as represented by a
reduced cost income ratio of 17.79%.



What is your view on Marginal Cost of Lending rate regime and are you able bring
your cost of borrowing down due to new lending rate regime?

The Marginal Cost of Lending (MCLR) rate regime has enabled us to reduce our
interest expenditure on borrowings from banks. Even though only 1/4th of our
funds requirement is sourced from bank loans, the benefit has accrued in terms
of reduction in overall cost of funds.

What are your expansion plans in near future? Any target set for setting up new
branches in coming quarters?

During the current year, we have opened 10 branches & 20 satellite offices
during April itself. With this, we have reached the milestone of 170 outlets
spread across 19 states. As an ongoing feature of our expansion plan, we propose
to keep expanding our network to potential locations, pan India.

Can you throw some numbers on Non housing loans portfolio and its growth with
specific reference to Loan for commercial properties, Loan Against Property,
Personal Loans, Flexi lap loans and Commercial Home Loans?

Our Non housing loans (NHL) portfolio for 2015-16 was Rs.1262 crore which
constitutes 12% of the loan book; around half of it is under mortgage loans
(LAP/ Flexi LAP) while the remaining half comprises of personal, site & other
non housing loans.

What is the rate at which you expect the housing finance industry to grow for
coming years? Do you see any pick up in prices of real estate soon?

Currently, real estate in our country is one of the major employers after
agriculture and the ensuing decade is expected to witness a decent growth in the
segment. As far as our company is concerned, 80% of our existing customer base
is from salaried class and most of them are first time home buyers. With the
implementation of seventh pay commission recommendations effective Aug 2016, we
expect a rise in demand for housing loans, as higher disposable income to fund
EMIs would encourage salaried class to decide on owning a house or to go for
expansion of old house. This apart, a good monsoon and the recent initiatives of
Government such as Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana and tax incentives for affordable
housing, we expect an uptrend in demand for home loans both in rural/semi-urban
areas and the outskirts of metros.

How is digitisation defining your business strategy and can you explain your
digitisation strategy to improve sales? Also how much is you spend on online
media?

Over the last few years, CFHL has used technology to enhance its operational
landscape. Core banking platform has given us a launch pad to scale up our
digital channel capabilities. Customers are now able to access their accounts
information with the help of our online services apart from mobile alerts &
missed call facilities. Most of our new customer acquisitions is from the youth
and 1st time home buyers, hence we are continuously upgrading our
tech-capabilities to match the taste & expectations of this segment.

                                Cornish Guardian

                           October 10, 2007 Wednesday

Construction starts at pioneering homes site

SECTION: Pg. 7

LENGTH: 403 words


Work has started on a unique affordable housing project in Rock.

It is the first in the country to be developed through a community land trust,
whereby local people have a real input in delivering the scheme.

Work on the 12 self-build bungalows is being undertaken by St Minver Community
Land Trust at Penmayne Farm, Rock.

Supported by a grant of £5,000 and a loan of £544,000 from North Cornwall
District Council, the scheme is aimed at helping local people get onto the
property ladder in one of the highest priced housing areas in England.

The community land trust was formed through an initiative by St Minver Highlands
and Lowlands parish councils and is a new way of delivering affordable housing
and ensuring future local control.

Celebrating the start of building work, chair of the trust, David Wills, said:
"This is the result of a lot of hard work by many people, and particularly the
late Bill Dingle who recognised that some-thing had to be done to help our young
people stay in their traditional community.

"Now that we have set up the community land trust we are hoping  this will be
the first of a number of schemes that will provide much-needed affordable
housing in the two parishes."

North Cornwall District Council chairman Graham Facks-Martin added: "This scheme
is another example of the people of North Cornwall leading the way in tackling
the issue of affordable housing and meeting the challenge to local communities
that it represents. Community land trusts are another part of the joined-up
approach adopted by the council in maintaining sustainable communities. The
scheme is another example of how funding from second homes council tax is
essential in enabling the delivery of new affordable homes."

The St Minver group has been advised and supported by Alan Fox, who is partly
funded by the county council and the Tudor Trust to encourage the formation of
community land trusts throughout Cornwall.

Based with Cornwall Rural Housing Association, he said: "This is the first
scheme to start in Cornwall and the first self-build scheme by a community land
trust anywhere in England. The Government is promoting this model and in North
Cornwall not only do we have a first with St Minver, but a second scheme which
is hoped to start at Blisland early in 2008. The learning curve that the St
Minver group has been through will be invaluable to other groups hoping to set
up trusts throughout the country."

                     Charleston Daily Mail (West Virginia)

                            July 22, 2010, Thursday

Huntington accepts bid for industrial site

BYLINE: BRYAN CHAMBERS, THE HERALD-DISPATCH

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P5D

LENGTH: 415 words


HUNTINGTON - The Huntington Municipal Development Authority has accepted a bid
to sell the Huntington Industrial Center for $3.51 million.

The winning bid was one of two proposals submitted to purchase the old
Owens-Illinois factory property on Huntington's West End. Authority officials
will not divulge specific details on the winning bid until a deal is completed.
The other bid came in at $2.5 million, authority Executive Director Tom Bell
said Tuesday.

Both of the bids came from local business owners, even though the authority has
advertised the property to more than 135,000 commercial real estate brokers
across the country, Bell said.

The winning bidder would add more jobs and industrial equipment to his existing
business if he is able to acquire the Huntington Industrial Center, Bell said.

"Several factors are out of our control," he said. "The bidder is preparing a
loan application to the state Economic Development Authority to purchase the
property and more equipment for his business."

The authority also needs a release on the property from the U.S. Department of
Housing and Urban Development, which placed a lien on it when the authority
received a loan from HUD to build KineticPark.

The authority obtained $4.5 million in state and federal loans and grants to
renovate the Industrial Center property after the Owens-Illinois factory closed
in 1993, taking more than 600 jobs and $18 million in payroll with it.

Much of the sprawling 30-acre complex, which includes 545,000 square feet of
space in six buildings, has been vacant since SNE, a manufacturer of vinyl
windows and patio doors, halted production in May 2008. Robert C. Jones Alloys
is now the only tenant under roof.

The deal would also provide financial stability to the authority, which is in a
cash crunch because of revenue lost from tenants moving out of the Industrial
Center. Revenue from leases at the Industrial Center had gone toward paying down
state and federal loans for KineticPark, another authority-owned facility.

But KineticPark has struggled to attract tenants as well. Huntington has been
forced to use federal funding typically reserved for community-based projects
and its housing demolition program to make a $400,000 payment for KineticPark.

"This would provide an enormous boost to the HMDA directly and city indirectly,"
authority board member Chuck Polan said Tuesday. "We would no longer be
financially dependent on the city and might even be able to give a little back
every now and then."

                              Daily Deal/The Deal

                           December 16, 2008 Tuesday

Hope Mill to seek DIP

BYLINE: by Mike Schoeck

SECTION: BANKRUPTCY

LENGTH: 747 words



HIGHLIGHT: A judge will consider the disclosure statement for the real estate
developer and interim access to a $27.16 million postpetition loan.


Bankrupt Hope Mill Village Associates LLC hopes to begin building its future
free of Chapter 11 in the new year with approval of its disclosure statement.

Judge Arthur N. Votolato of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the District of Rhode
Island in Providence is slated on Jan. 7 to consider the outline for the
reorganization plan of the Rhode Island real estate developer.

According to debtor counsel Kevin McKenna of the McKenna Law Offices in
Providence, the company plans to fund both the completion of its 34-acre
apartment complex and hydroelectric power plant project in Scituate, R.I., and
its reorganization with an interim $3.36 million tranche of a $27.16 million
debtor-in-possession loan.

McKenna said Votolato is scheduled to rule on the interim access to the DIP at
the Jan. 7 hearing. Belmar, N.J., mortgage lender Dougherty Mortgage LLC is
providing the postpetition loan, which must be underwritten by the U.S.
Department of Housing and Urban Development.

According to McKenna, both the DIP and its lender must meet the approval of HUD
because Hope Mill's development is designated as a rehabilitation project under
Section 221(d) of the National Housing Act, which governs affordable housing.

On Oct. 8, Dougherty submitted a $24.44 million loan proposal to Hope Mill for
the first 155-unit phase, plus another DIP proposal of $27.16 million for the
first two phases. Court documents indicated Hope Mill planned to use the larger
funding proposal.

According to the plan, the DIPs take the form of 40-year, first-lien
construction loans and bear interest at 6.5%.

Hope Mill's plans for its 207-unit eco-friendly apartment community call for it
to use hydroelectric power generated from the Pawtuxet River as well as solar
electric panels.

The project's first phase will renovate 155 units situated in the historic Home
Mill. The mill property was built in 1806 by Rhode Island governor Stephen
Hopkins, whose signature appears on the Declaration of Independence, McKenna
said.

The project's second phase will include 52 new riverfront apartments powered
solely by solar electricity. The apartments are adjacent to a six-acre state
park that Hope Mill is also developing.

McKenna said the apartments will average about $1,000 in monthly rent for
families.

The attorney said Hope Mill is currently in the midst of finalizing municipal
permits for the project, including the removal of individual septic tanks strewn
about the rural area and a new sewage system that would connect Hope Mill with
nearby Scituate and Hopkinton, R.I., each of which borders the Scituate
Reservoir and Pawtuxet River, where Hope Mill's property is located.

Under Hope Mill's proposed plan and disclosure statement, filed on Dec. 1,
secured creditors' claims of $5.04 million would be satisfied in full when the
DIP order is signed by HUD.

Allowed secured creditors include investors involved with funding the
residential project: Robert Laferriere ($4.25 million) of West Warwick. R.I.,
Patriots Home Site Inc. ($331,000) of Pawtucket, R.I., Sedona Associates
($234,000) of East Providence, R.I., and Hope Riverfront Condominiums LLC
($225,000) of Providence.

Priority claims to be paid in full under the plan include amounts owed to the
town of Scituate, R.I. ($35,000), utility company National Grid plc ($5,400) of
Northborough, Mass., the Kent County Water Authority ($1,632) of West Warwick,
R.I., and the state of Rhode Island ($1,545).

General unsecured creditors holding $948,031 in claims would see a full recovery
under the plan. These include Robinson Design Inc. ($411,000) of Smithfield,
R.I., Steven Miller Law Office ($102,300) of Providence, Lucille Marinelli
($100,000) of North Providence, R.I., Glen Ahlborg ($55,000) of North Kingstown,
R.I., and Bryant Associates Inc. ($16,425) of Boston.

Hope Mill is disputing the unsecured claims of Carole Thomasian, owed $6,450,
and Public Archeology Laboratory Inc., owed $4,000, both of Providence.

According to the plan, Hope Riverfront forced Hope Mill into receivership
earlier this year after its $225,000 deposit toward its $3.25 million proposed
purchase of Hope Mill's second phase on the project was rescinded and converted
to a promissory note and secondary mortgage lien.

Hope Mill filed for bankruptcy on Aug. 20.

According to McKenna, Hope Riverfront took the receivership action because the
investor thought its treatment became diminished and secondary in stature
following the conversion of its proposed purchase into a mortgage lien.

URL: http://www.TheDeal.com

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             August 9, 1985 Friday

Housing decision angers native groups

BYLINE: BARBARA YAFFE; GAM

LENGTH: 708 words

DATELINE: Ottawa ONT


By  BARBARA YAFFE
                           Globe and Mail Reporter
    OTTAWA  - A federal decision to begin transferring responsibility for a
 major native housing program to the provinces has prompted the Native
 Council of Canada to set up a watchdog committee to make sure the
 Government delivers its promise to provide suitable native housing.

The council, claiming to represent 1.2 million non-status Indians and
 Metis, held a news conference here yesterday to protest against the
 federal Government's intention, then staged a protest march on Parliament
 Hill.

With fiery torches, representatives of various native groups circled a
 cringing beaver - actually a protester dressed in a rented furry outfit.
 The beaver symbolized Operation Beaver, a volunteer group that builds
 native housing and has had its federal financing cut to $200,000 this year
 from $655,000 last year.

But the axing of Operation Beaver's budget is only a part of the native
 peoples' concern. They are more concerned that responsibility for the 11-
 year-old federal rural and native housing program is to be handed over to
 provincial jurisdictions which they do not trust to protect their
 interests.

Louis (Smokey) Bruyere, president of the council, told reporters:
 'What that means is that we are going to be left out in the cold because
 the provinces have already stated they have no responsibility for native
 people. It is a federal responsiblity. So, if the federal Government is
 going to give them the program, where does that leave us? It leaves us
 out.'
    Sam Sinclair, president of the Metis Association of Alberta, said: 'As
 (Prime Minister Brian) Mulroney states it, he supports the self-
 determination (concept) to try to work toward our making decisions on
 behalf of our people.
    'Once this program goes to Alberta, they are taking away the little
 powers we did have and, as you know, at the First Ministers' conference,
 Alberta was the most opposed of any of the provinces on self-government.

If we allow the federal Government to give them more powers to block us, I
don't know where we go from here.'     The council invited representatives of
the native groups to Ottawa for  meetings on the issue, which began on Tuesday,
and were attended by  Gregory Fyffe, chief of staff to William McKnight, who has
Cabinet  responsibility for the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp., and Robert
Warne, CMHC vice- president of programs.

Mr. Warne said in an interview later that he understands native
 concerns. 'Obviously some groups feel the federal Government is more
 sympathetic than the provincial governments. But the federal Government is
 committed (to the program) and if the program is transferred to the
 provinces, one of the criteria would be access by the native groups.'
    Mr. Warne said 'it is a complicated issue' and it may not be clear to
 everyone that jurisdiction for the program is being altered only in some
 provincial jurisdictions.

Mr. Warne said in recent years, because of lack of provincial support,
 the program has not operated in New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island,
 British Columbia or Quebec. Actual transfers of jurisdiction for the
 program for 1985 have been completed only in Newfoundland and
 Saskatchewan. Talks with the other provinces are ongoing.

Currently, CMHC provides funds to native housing councils and other
 contracted organizations to build 'off reserve' housing in rural and
 native communities, homes that are purchased by native and low- income
 people at 25 per cent of their income. Last year, about 3,600 homes were
 built at an average cost of $60,000 each.

Native people worry that if the provinces take over the program, they
 may not use the native housing councils to co-ordinate the home
 construction and they may concentrate on building rural housing for poor
 people rather than homes on sites near reserves which are harder to
 service and costlier to build because of their remoteness.

Spokesmen for the 18 native peoples' groups that gathered here said
 they were not properly consulted about the transfer of responsibility for
 the program.

Mr. Warne said he believed that the agency consulted with the native  groups
but, 'they obviously feel they haven't been adequately consulted,  so I guess
you have to report that.'

                            March 15, 2006 Wednesday

Iranian press reports 12 Mar 06 Majlis session

LENGTH: 2128 words


Text of report by the Iranian newspaper Keyhan and by the Iranian newspaper
Resalat on 13 March

Keyhan, 13 Mar 06

Majlis representatives allocated 430 billion Rials to be spent for the
improvement of housing in rural areas, the construction of infrastructures in
newly established towns and meeting the balance of profits and commissions for
the housing loans that are to be granted to janbazan [war invalids] above 25per
cent [percentage of injury to bodies of war invalids that make them eligible to
receive benefits from the government], families of martyrs and azadegan
[released prisoners of war].

At the yesterday's open session, debates on the parts of the 1385 budget bill on
expenditures continued. Seyedabadi, Majlis representative from Sabzevar,
proposed a return to note 6 of the administration-proposed budget bill that was
approved. According to paragraph A of this note, 430 billion Rials will be
allocated for the payment of a fund to balance the interests and commission at
banking loans that are to be granted to janbazan above 25per cent, the disabled
and families of martyrs, improve housing in rural areas, and the construction of
infrastructures in newly established towns - that have been approved by the
council of ministers, Supreme Urban Development and Architecture Council - and
preparing lands for families of martyrs, azadegan and janbazan.

In this connection, the Ministry of Housing and Urban Development shall endow
20per cent of apartments and houses to families of martyrs, janbazan and
azadegan through hire-purchase agreements.

According to paragraph D of note 6, a sum of 1,250 billion Rials will be
allocated for rural development, including the development of water facilities,
roads and education. Paragraph E' allows 100per cent of funds for rural
developmental projects, including water, roads and education to be allocated at
the proposal of the Deprived Areas Office of the Presidential Institute and
after the approval of the president.

Elsewhere, in order to accelerate the provision of housing for the disabled and
the poor people who are under the umbrella of the Welfare Organization, and
facilitating citizens' cooperation, the State Welfare Organization and welfare
offices in provinces will be allowed to pay 50per cent of the expense of
constructing houses up to fifty million Rials per person provided that 50per
cent of the expense is provided by charities.

30 billion Rials for joint border markets

By approving paragraph A of note 7 of the budget bill, Majlis representatives
furnished border provinces with 300 billion Rials for the execution of
developmental projects to construct joint border markets. These funds will be
spent according to agreements with the Management and Planning Organization.

Additionally, based on the proposal of Hassan Kamran, Majlis representative from
Isfahan, a rider was appended to paragraph B of this note. According to this
rider, for the purpose of protecting domestic products, helping the importation
of goods through customhouses, facilitating authorized commerce and combating
smuggling of goods and foreign currencies in 1385 by the optimization and
improvement of regulations and employing all administrative, judicial and
disciplinary facilities of the country, the exportation and importation of goods
by every natural person and legal entity, including civil and military forces
and non-profit organizations and charities, will be permitted only through
official channels that are supervised by the Customs. The import and export of
goods through channels other than customhouses will be regarded as an instance
of smuggling and the offenders will be treated according to the law.

Furthermore, the administration is obliged to allocate up to 85 billion Rials to
the Central Headquarters for Campaign against Smuggling of Goods and Foreign
Currencies. 80per cent of this sum will be spent to buy equipment and capital
facilities required for the campaign against the smuggling of goods and foreign
currencies and 20per cent will be spend to prepare educational items and
propaganda mostly through the Voice and Vision [Islamic Republic of Iran
Broadcasting] and press and cinema branches of the Ministry of Culture and
Islamic Guidance.

4,000 billion Rials of the government's debts to organizations will be settled

In continuation, based on the proposal of the Majlis Committee of Social Affairs
as a rider to paragraph D of note 8, Majlis representatives required the
administration to pay 4,000 billion Rials of its debts to organizations,
including the State Retirement Organization, Social Security Organization,
Teachers' Reserve Fund, Astan-e Qods-e Razavi [the institute administrating
shrine of Imam Reza and the endowment belonging to it], municipalities, medical
insurance organizations, Basij's Reserve Fund, Social Security Fund of Armed
Forces and other executive organizations through assigning movable and immovable
properties and stocks of state-owned corporations.

During debates on part 2 of paragraph D of note 9, the proposal offered by Ali
Abbaspur, Majlis representative from Tehran, that called for a return to the
administration-proposed bill was approved. According to this decision, funds may
be allocated to universities and higher education institutes and research
centres at the request of the highest executive official of the above-mentioned
institutes or other authorized officials that shall be introduced to the
Ministry of Economic Affairs and Finance. Bank accounts will be opened by the
Treasury or treasuries of provinces in the name of these officials and the funds
will be deposited to these accounts. Withdrawing funds from these accounts will
be possible with joint signatures of at least two authorized signatories
designated by financial and transactional by-laws of the institutes.

According to another decision made by Majlis representatives, the buildings and
properties belonging to governmental executive organizations and
non-governmental public institutes that have been used as schools by education
departments in 1383-1384 will still be at the disposal of the Ministry of
Education and any attempt to compel the Ministry of Education to evacuate them
will be prohibited.

The last decision made by the Maljis at the yesterday morning's open session was
on paragraph M of note 9. This decision authorizes the Organization for Enacting
Radio and Communications Regulations to spend up to 80 billion Rials out of the
surplus income earned by providing telecommunication services and use these
resources to improve the management of the radio wave spectrum and paving the
way for competition between governmental and non-governmental companies. These
funds may be spent after exchanging agreements with the Management and Planning
Organization.

Additionally, Majlis representatives approved the proposal of Abbaspur, Majlis
representative from Tehran, returned to paragraph A of note 9 that had been
eliminated by the combined committee, and permitted the Ministry of Education to
distribute 930 billion Rials among affiliated junior colleges to be spent for
the realization of objectives of the Ministry of Education defined in the Fourth
Development Plan Act.

15 billion Rials for the construction of residencies in sites of the [Iran-Iraq]
battles

At the yesterday afternoon's open session, paragraph A of note 10 was approved
that requires the Cultural Heritage and Tourism Organization to spend 15 billion
Rials for the construction of camp-sites in the areas that were battlegrounds
during the Iran-Iraq war in the south and west of the country, and five billion
Rials for supporting Rahian-e Nur tours that visit former battlegrounds in
southern and western borders in coordination with the Basij Resistance Force.

Furthermore, according to paragraphs B and C of the above-mentioned note, the
Cultural Heritage and Tourism Organization shall spend 20 billion Rials out of
the funds allocated for Iranian museums for supporting and construction of the
holy defence museum in Tehran and 10 million Rials for the protection of relics
and values of the holy defence and the construction of the holy defence
monuments in coordination with the Foundation for the Protection of Relics and
Values of the Holy Defence.

In a rider to note 11, Majlis representatives approved research funds for the
Iranian Atomic Energy Organization as hundred-percent allocated funds.

In considering riders to this note, the proposal offered by Tahmasbi, Majlis
representative from Sarvestan, was approved according to which agricultural
firms will be exempted from paying power charges at industrial rates.

The proposal presented by Elias Naderan, Majlis representative from Tehran, was
also approved. According to this proposal, in order to reduce the consumption of
fuel by automobiles, protect environment, reduce death toll, produce power,
develop new technologies and find substitutes for fossil fuels in rural and
nomadic areas, a subsidy or grant-in-aid will be allocated.

In paragraph H of this note, in order to develop power production capacities and
meeting growing needs of the country, the administration is required to begin
study and location of nuclear power plants for the production of 20,000 MW
power.

Resalat, 13 Mar 06

1385 Budget debate will end today

After ten days of intense works of Majlis representatives on the budget bill of
the next year, sometimes even three rounds per day, examining the budget bill
has accelerated in the last two days.

Some Majlis representatives' persistence in offering their proposals has
lengthened the budget debate but in recent days a number of Majlis
representatives were persuaded to withdraw their proposals. By this decision,
the process has accelerated so that it is expected that the debate will end at
today's sessions.

Reports received from the Council of Guardians show that deep legal examinations
by the combined committee, the Council of Guardians will naturally raise fewer
objections to notes of the budget bill of the next year. The Council of
Guardians is expected to present its correcting advices to the Majlis on
Wednesday, and the Majlis will hold an open session on Tuesday in order to
examine opinions of the Council of Guardians and amend its decision to satisfy
the Council of Guardians. The cases on which the Majlis and the Council of
Guardians may fail to reach an agreement will be referred to Expediency Council
for final decision-making in order to draw the final conclusion on the budget
bill on Saturday, the last day of the current year.

The Ahmadinezhad administration will settle debts of former administrations to
other organizations and institutes

The former administration has left a large amount of debts to organizations that
will be settled in 1385.

The Social Security Organization, State Retirement Fund, Astan-e Qods-e Razavi,
Medical Services Insurance Organization, Social Security Fund of Armed Forces,
Teachers' Reserve Fund, Basij Members' Reserve Fund and municipalities will
receive their 15,000 billion Rials, 10,000 billion Rials, 1,150 billion Rials,
2,000 billion Rials, 2,000 billion Rials, 350 billion Rials, 300 billion Rials,
and 500 billion Rials, respectively.

These debts are mostly settled through assigning stocks of state-owned
corporations.

26 Majlis representatives asked the president to allocate a portion of oil
revenues to oil-rich provinces

Messrs Sudani, K'abi, Daneshyar, Sheikh, Ashuri, Jafari, Movahed, M'oalemipur,
Dirbaz, Shoja, Adel-Azar, Ahmadi, Hedayatkhah, Mohammadsadeqi, Naserinezhad,
Musavi, Hayati, Raza'ipur, Purnateqi, Mohebbi, Ashtiani, Shojapurian, Salehi,
Saedi and Hosseini notified the president of the need for allocating 0.02per
cent of oil revenues to oil-rich provinces in 1385. These Majlis representatives
requested the president to pay attention to this matter in the budget bill.

Amateurish collaboration between two reformist dailies provoked the laugher of
Majlis representatives!

Yesterday, in the restaurant of the Majlis, a Majlis representative from
Lorestan Province showed Sunday issues of Hambastegi and E'temad dailies and
this provoked the laughter of the Majlis representatives.

In the page 3 of E'temad and page 6 of Hambastegi, texts of so-called six
telephone calls had been published. Interestingly, the texts of the messages and
the order of messages in both dailies were identical. The content of all the
messages was against the administration and sought defaming the Ahmadinezhad
administration. This Majlis representative from Lorestan told his colleagues:
"we do know these so-called telephone calls are fabricated by the reformist
dailies themselves but directors of the dailies must be careful not to make such
a big gaffe!"
