                                US Official News

                           October 10, 2015 Saturday

Tennessee: THDA Announces the 2015 Tennessee's Best Award winners

LENGTH: 2846 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Nashville: Tennessee Housing Development Agency issued the following news
release:



 The Tennessee's Best awards honor outstanding individuals and organizations
whose contributions on behalf of affordable housing - whether producing,
designing, developing, financing or promoting housing policy - inspire others to
serve Tennesseans' housing needs.



 The 2015 winners and nominees are:

 Excellence in Partnership



 Winner



 United Housing, Inc.: United Housing, Inc. (UHI), recently partnered with the
Community of St. Therese of Lisieux, a Memphis nonprofit that serves women who
are looking to rebuild their lives after being on the streets. The partnership
can assist up to five women in a two-year program including housing, and has
greatly benefitted from the two organizations' combined abilities to leverage
funds and work across sectors. UHI has 20 years of experience in serving
individuals through homeownership counseling and foreclosure prevention, but
recently added a focus on strengthening nonprofit-to-nonprofit partnerships.



 Nominees



 Ridgeview Apartments: For the first time in its 60+ year history, the Gallatin
Housing Authority partnered with a provide developer, Concord Gallatin, LLC, to
seek Low Income Housing Tax Credit (LIHTC) funding for an affordable housing
development. Securing $322,251 through the LIHTC program and another $2.4
million in the form of a two-year, 0% interest loan from a private bank, the two
organizations launched a joint effort to transform the aging Reese Lackey
Heights building into the new Ridgeview Apartments facility. The project is now
65% complete and serves as a prime model for the GHA and other housing agencies
to form public-private partnerships for future developments.



 Buffalo Valley, Inc.: Although Buffalo Valley, Inc., of Hohenwald began solely
as an alcohol and drug treatment center in 1979, housing became a critical part
of its continuum of care in the mid-1990s. Partnerships on the federal level
include being named the lead agency in 19 rural Tennessee counties for HUD's
&ldquo;Homeless No More&rdquo; initiative and a collaboration with the VA to
produce, design, and develop grant per diem housing for homeless veterans. On
the local level, Buffalo Valley has expanded outside Middle Tennessee to partner
with the City of Chattanooga on its affordable housing efforts. The organization
also has an excellent reputation with contractors, vendors, and public partners
for meeting and exceeding compliance and sustainable requirements.



 Nichole Carter, Patten Towers Service Coordinator: Patten Towers was built in
the heart of Chattanooga in 1908 as the first &ldquo;skyscraper hotel&rdquo; in
the city. Now operated by PK Management, the facility helps residents age in
place while providing them with education and value-added services. As the on-
site social services coordinator, Carter has developed community partnerships
with nonprofits, businesses, universities, government entities and churches to
help generate a variety of programs for residents. She is praised for taking a
person-centered approach and conducting focus groups to meet the residents'
programming wants and needs. Programs include food insecurity, health and
wellness, safety, exercise, spirituality, socialization and education.



 Blount County Habitat for Humanity: Serving a community where nearly 50% of
high school seniors do not have career or education plans post-graduation,
Blount County Habitat for Humanity partnered with Maryville High School--as well
as the Maryville-Alcoa Homebuilders Association, the United Way of Blount
County, and the University of Tennessee--to establish a youth workforce
development initiative at a Habitat construction site. This spring, 279 college
and high school students were each involved in 20+ hours of construction-based
activities and skill development, and 24 high school students participated in a
construction-based experiential classroom to learn real world construction
skills and work ethic, as well as explore the wide range of occupations
available within the construction industry.



 Habitat for Humanity of Greater Nashville and Nashville School of Law: These
two organizations partnered to host no-cost clinics for Habitat homeowners and
families in Habitat's HomeWORKS program, allowing them to meet with law students
and attorneys to develop a will. For the students and professionals, the program
provides valuable experience working with diverse, low-income populations and
encourages them to apply their expertise in charitable ways.



 Tim Dimick: A mortgage loan originator with U.S. Bank, Dimick was nominated for
his generous work in helping homeownership become a reality for participants in
THDA's Housing Choice Voucher (HCV) Homeownership program. Dimick is noted for
his availability, reliability, and the quality of service he provides both his
clients and THDA staff. Colleagues of Dimick praise his efficiency,
professionalism, and ability to relatable to the families he serves. Dimick also
gives helpful feedback to when clients receive loan denials, allowing them to
build better credit profiles so they can try again.

 Outstanding Advocate



 Winner



 Scott County Homeless Shelter: Through its work advocating for homeless
individuals and families, the Scott County Homeless Shelter saw a need for a
greater awareness for homelessness issues in Tennessee. With the help of State
Sen. Ken Yager, SCHS Executive Director Ray Perry successfully led the effort
for the Tennessee Legislature to pass a bill recognizing November as
&ldquo;Homelessness Awareness and Prevention Month.&rdquo; Originally providing
only emergency shelter, the Scott County Homeless Shelter quickly grown over the
past five years to provide safe housing, food, clothing, hygiene, and job search
services, as well as the Access 2 Resources (A2R)&rdquo; transportation service
to combat the lack of public transportation in the area it serves. The Scott
County Homeless Shelter also offers a supportive housing program, which provides
the financial assistance to prevent homelessness or rehouse homeless residents.



 Nominees



 Debbie Hillin: During her 25 years of service at Buffalo Valley, Inc., Hillin
has been instrumental in raising $110 million for affordable housing. Dedicated
to assisting high-risk groups in her community, Hillin's top priority is placing
people in a safe environment. Known for being available 24/7, she routinely
keeps extended hours in order to secure housing or funding for an individual who
has the drive but not the means to help themselves. Hillin serves on the
Governor's Council for Armed Services, Veterans, and Their Families and in 2013
was awarded The Adjutant General's Distinguished Patriot Medal for her
dedication to military families in need. She also chaired TAADAS and continues
to regularly work in conjunction with the Tennessee Legislature to emphasize the
need for affordable housing and address barriers.



 Community Development Council of Greater Memphis: Community Development Council
of Greater Memphis (CD Council) is a membership organization of community
development organizations and proponents that support neighborhood
revitalization efforts. The CD Council works in four areas: capacity building
programs for CDCs, community education and civic engagement, planning and
neighborhood revitalization, and policy and advocacy. As the only cross-sector
advocacy effort of its kind in Memphis, the CD Council publishes an annual set
of policy priorities and works throughout the year toward steady progress. The
CD Council has been an active participant the Tennessee Affordable Housing
Coalition, as well as numerous other local networks and coalitions.

 Remarkable Achievement (Rural)



 Winner



 Grace Crossing, LP: Olympia Construction, Inc., completed work on Grace
Crossing in Paris in 2014. The units feature spacious designs and are equipped
with ENERGY STAR-rated appliances. Additionally, there are several units which
are fully equipped to serve those who have a physical or sensory impairment. The
exterior design of each building focuses on low-maintenance, energy efficient,
and beautiful surfaces. The property offers many amenities such as a playground,
computer room, community building with kitchen, covered gazebo, pavilion with
barbeque grill, private patios, laundry facility, and direct access to public
transportation. Grace Crossing is in a prime location, just steps away from the
conveniences offered in town.



 Nominees



 William Basinger: For 13 years, Basinger has been a senior case manager for
housing for Buffalo Valley, Inc., ensuring the development and management of
affordable housing for those with special needs, the homeless, low-income
individuals, and families living in the targeted 19 rural counties served by the
organization. Basinger worked in construction prior to joining Buffalo Valley,
and his experience and efforts have helped Buffalo Valley foster community
collaboration and increased its ability to work efficiently with contractors and
suppliers. Basinger also helps ensure compliance for more than 650 units of
rural affordable housing provided by Buffalo Valley. These units include
emergency shelter, transitional housing, permanent housing with supportive
services, low-income rental, subsidized housing, and homeownership.



 The Villas of Savannah, LP: The Villas of Savannah, located in the town of
Savannah, was developed to optimize green space and utilizes landscaping design
that provides long-term beauty. The property features a spacious community
building with a gathering area, dining area, sofas, an entertainment center,
game room, and fitness area. The units are equipped with ENERGY STAR-rated
appliances, private patios, and additional outdoor storage. The buildings
features sandstone brick exteriors for low maintenance and durability. The
Villas employ an on-site manager who arranges events from potluck dinners to
holiday parties in an effort to create a warm, welcoming community for
residents. The property is owned by The Villas of Savannah, LP, and managed by
Olympia Management, Inc.



 Marshall Gardens, LP: Marshall Gardens, LP, partnered with developer Olympia
Construction, Inc., and nonprofit Paladin Nonprofit TN, LLC, to complete this
48-unit development in Milan. The community building features a computer center,
kitchen and dining area, laundry facility, and manager's office. Residents also
have access to an outdoor playground and covered picnic area with tables and
barbeque grill. The exteriors are a mixture of durable, energy-efficient
materials, and the landscaping is designed to allow the property to blend with
the surrounding environment. Marshall Gardens is a shining example of energy
efficiency, accessibility, and beautiful affordable housing.

 Remarkable Achievement (Urban)



 Winner



 Keystone Development, Inc.: Keystone Development, Inc., was established in 2013
by the Johnson City Housing Authority to address the plight of homeless youth
and veterans. Alan Court is the newest apartment complex built by Keystone in
Johnson City. With seven one-bedroom apartments completed in August 2015, Alan
Court is specifically veterans in the HUD-VASH program. Many participants have
been or are currently being treated through the James H. Quillen VA Medical
Center in Johnson City. Alan Court includes many components that reflect the
best standards in quality and sustainability for its tenants, including ENERGY
STAR-rated appliances and features. All units will be managed by the Johnson
City Housing Authority.

 Best in Innovation



 Winner



 Urban Housing Solutions, Inc.: Urban Housing Solutions was nominated for its 12
Garden Street development in Nashville. The eight-unit complex was constructed
for low-income residents with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD)
who wish to live independently. Created in partnership with the Nashville
Intellectual and Developmental Disability Housing Group, Trevecca Nazarene
University, and Vanderbilt Divinity School, 12 Garden Street allows individuals
with IDD to live next door to divinity students who have volunteered to provide
assistance as needed. There are nearly 7,000 people with IDD on the state's
waiting list for a Home and Community Based Services (HCBS) waiver--a number
that grows larger every month. By rule, these individuals have no more than
$2,000 in assets. The project is the most extensive and energy-efficient
renovation Urban Housing Solutions has ever completed, and it also had a
positive impact on the local neighborhood by removing a known location of drug
and criminal activity.



 Nominees



 Franklin Housing Authority: Located in one of the wealthiest and fastest
growing counties in the country, the Franklin Housing Authority embarked on a
plan in 2010 to change the face of public housing and at the same time provide
more options by being creative in the development and use of properties. The
master housing plan is designed to replace obsolete public housing with modern
communities serving the city's low and moderate income families. The first phase
included FHA's first-ever public-private venture, The Reddick Senior Residences.
The $8.5 million, three-story building featuers 49 one- and two-bedroom
apartments specially designed for an aging population. The facility includes a
health and wellness center, a business center, a library, a game room, and
laundry facilities. For many residents, some of whom lived in the old public
housing on the site, it is the first time their home has had central heat and
air, a dishwasher, and a place to interact with people their own age. An on-site
manager is available to assist the residents. FHA describes the building as the
first step in a long-awaited plan to improve the lives of low-income families in
the Franklin community.



 John Pointer, Dansen and Associates: As owner of Dansen and Associates, LLC,
and a Sears Hometown Store franchise, Pointer was nominated for his work with
the Tennessee Association of Housing Redevelopment Authorities (TAHRA), a
supportive association that represents the majority of public housing
authorities (PHAs) statewide. As a result of the EPA's effort to replacing aging
appliances with the new ENERGY STAR-rated ones, TAHRA contracted with Pointer to
carry out the work on behalf of the 85 housing authorities. Pointer contacted
vendors while reviewing the TAHRA proposal, itemizing all applicable appliances,
and meeting with PHA staff members throughout the state. As a result of his
efforts, energy use has been reduced 10%. The new specifications will also
establish an optional functionality criteria that allows PHAs to be eligible for
a &ldquo;connected&rdquo; allowance if ever needed. Since signing the contract
with TAHRA, Dansen has made deliveries across the state and has placed orders
with members of the Tennessee Association of Affordable Housing for similar
work.

 Vicki George Award for Excellence in Homebuyer Education



 Winner



 Beverly James: As director of financial education and counseling at Christian
Community Services, Inc, for the past five years, James has tirelessly
researched and studied home loan products and financial coaching techniques so
that CCSI families are equipped with the skills and knowledge they need for
long-term self-sufficiency and asset purchase. Praised for her individual
attention to each client, James has successfully reduced time and transportation
barriers for local families seeking homeownership. She is a regular spokesperson
for both CCSI and Habitat for Humanity. Through the Mentoring Towards
Independence program, James assisted a mother of two out of public housing and
into the home she &ldquo;wanted so much&rdquo; for her children.



 Nominees



 Lisa Booker: A dedicated and experienced educator with Family and Children's
Services in Nashville, Booker was nominated for the &ldquo;top-notch education
experience&rdquo; she provides students who participate in her homebuyer
education classes. Her presentation skills have been described as flawless, and
the number of homebuyers she teaches each year is the highest in the state. One
mortgage broker said clients she referred to Booker always provided positive
feedback of their experience, with many saying it was the best class they had
ever taken.



 Taylor Hayes: Just over a year ago, Hayes began working with the non-profit
HomeSource East Tennessee (former Knox Housing Partnership) as a homebuyer
education counselor. In that short time, average number of students served each
month has jumped from 12 to 32, a boost of 266%. Hayes also championed
HomeSource's pilot program for online classes through eHomeAmerica, a move that
resulted in another increase in course enrollment. His success is credited to
consistent partnership building and successful program marketing.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            June 13, 2012 Wednesday

Banks' appraisal methods tightened in hot house market

BYLINE: TARA PERKINS and GRANT ROBERTSON

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: CANADIAN; REAL ESTATE; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 742 words


Several Canadian banks have been quietly re-evaluating their appraisal
strategies amid increased worries about the accuracy of property values in a
market deemed at risk of overheating.

Lenders use a variety of techniques, including full appraisals, so-called
"drive-by" appraisals based on the exterior of the home, and databases of market
prices, to evaluate homes. The values they arrive at help determine how much
money they should lend to mortgage borrowers. They are also key for measures
such as the loan-to-value ratio that are used to track the health of loan
portfolios and borrowers' debt loads.

Banks are emphasizing on-site visits to value properties, especially those above
a certain price or in rural areas.

They are also paying closer attention to who does the appraisal.

The higher level of diligence aims to get more accurate values amid fears of an
overheated housing market. If standards tighten or appraisals become more
conservative, it could result in a decrease of the amount of mortgages that
banks lend.

Appraisal values become most important to banks when a borrower defaults, and
the bank has to sell the property to recoup money. Their accuracy is especially
important in the current environment, in which home prices are believed to be
inflated and borrowers are taking on record debt levels, increasing the risk of
defaults.

There has been no suggestion of widespread or serious problems in Canada's
appraisal system, and bankers say they are comfortable with the values on their
books. But lenders and regulators have recently been scrutinizing appraisal
systems in an effort to ensure that these values are as accurate as possible.

"We have tightened our process, and make sure that we are getting an accurate
read," David McKay, the head of Canadian banking at Royal Bank of Canada, the
country's largest mortgage lender, told analysts on a recent conference call.
"When you think you have an 80 per cent loan-to-value ratio, you want to make
sure you have an 80 per cent loan-to-value ratio."

Mark Chauvin, Toronto-Dominion Bank's chief risk officer, told analysts that in
some of the hotter markets such as Vancouver and Toronto, appraisal values are
coming in slightly above purchase prices.

"We're really not seeing a lot of it," he said. "But we feel our existing
policies will protect us against that."

TD lends 80 per cent loan-to-value up to $900,000, but after that only lends 50
per cent, to protect itself against inflated values on expensive homes. "So if
you take a $2-million house, you get a loan-to-value of 56 per cent under the
sliding scale," he said.

Some banks began to focus more on this last year, after an American insurance
company reported a significant charge in connection with insurance it was
selling to them. That insurance was covering risks associated with the
possibility that appraisal values were off.

California-based First American Financial Corp. had been selling Canadian banks
a "guaranteed valuation" product that guaranteed the valuation of a property was
accurate on the day a mortgage was issued. If it turned out later that it
wasn't, the bank could make a claim.

But First American posted a first-quarter loss in 2011 as it took a $45-million
reserve strengthening charge relating to this obscure Canadian product.

Policies that were experiencing claims had been written mostly in 2007 and 2008.
Sources say the issue stemmed mainly from Alberta, where the housing market
underwent a correction starting in 2007, and problems became apparent as default
rates increased, leading banks to seize more homes as collateral.

"This is just a case where we mispriced the risk," First American CEO Dennis
Gilmore told analysts. (The firm declined to comment.) The company is no longer
offering that insurance in the same form, bankers said.

Spokespeople at Bank of Montreal and Bank of Nova Scotia said Monday that their
institutions were already focused on in-person appraisals.

The Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions is ushering in new
mortgage underwriting rules that require banks to have clear policies outlining
how they value properties. It is urging them to use a combination of tools, and
to include a comprehensive on-site appraisal unless there's an appropriate
reason to use an alternative method.

Banks "should not use title insurance or valuation insurance as a substitute for
a sound appraisal or valuation process," OSFI stated.

                     The Pantagraph (Bloomington, Illinois)

                             July 8, 2004 Thursday

Farm Briefs

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C2

LENGTH: 172 words


Container recycling

Central Illinois farmers can recycle their empty, rinsed plastic agrichemical
containers this summer at two permanent sites and three special collections.

The Illinois Department of Agriculture sponsors the program. The containers get
ground into plastic chips reused to make shipping pallets, hazardous waste drums
and other products. Only No. 2 plastic containers that are clean and dry will be
accepted. Permanent locations are at UAP Richter in Atlanta and Randolph Ag at
Heyworth.

Collections will be from 8 to 11 a.m. July 27 at DCM Crop Care, Deer Creek; 1 to
4 p.m. July 28 at CPS, Saunemin; and 8 to 11 a.m. July 29 at Weber Fertilizer,
Buckley.

Grants available

Community, faith-based and other nonprofit groups have until Aug. 2 to apply for
$2 million in rural housing assistance grants.

The grants support services like home-ownership counseling, home loan packaging
and delinquency counseling.

About 25 to 30 groups are expected to receive grants. Information is on the
Internet at www.rurdev.usda.gov.

                          Waco Tribune-Herald (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 25, 2010 Thursday

Texas offering additional $2,000 credit for some homebuyers

BYLINE: Mike Copeland, Waco Tribune-Herald, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 743 words


Feb. 25--Uncle Sam and the state of Texas want people to buy homes.

The new weapon in their arsenal is a $2,000 credit that Texas is offering to
people who have not owned a home the past three years and want to buy one.

This is not a one-shot deal. Qualifying Texans can knock up to $2,000 a year off
the interest they pay on their mortgages under the so-called Texas Mortgage
Credit Program.

It is available to McLennan County individuals or families of two who make no
more than $57,400 a year, and to families of three or more members who make no
more than $66,010 a year.

The program, offered through the Texas Department of Housing and Community
Affairs, can be used with the federal government's one-time tax credit of $8,000
for first-time homebuyers.

Individuals taking advantage of the federal program must sign a sales agreement
by April 30, and close on their homes by June 30.

"I was working with a buyer yesterday who is moving here from Austin. We were
talking about that $8,000 credit and she may go for it," Waco Realtor Trammel
Kelly said.

"Information is just getting out about the state program, and it is attracting
attention. It will definitely be a plus for a lot of people."

To qualify for a Mortgage Credit Certificate of up to $2,000, a buyer must: --
Meet income and home purchase requirements; -- Have not owned a home as a
primary residence in the past three years; -- Meet the qualifying requirements
of the mortgage loan; and, -- Use the home as his or her principal residence.

All mortgage loan types are eligible. The loans are available through a network
of lenders and must be underwritten according to FHA, VA, USDA/Rural Housing
Service or conventional loan rules.

The Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs Web site lists only one
lender in Waco taking part in its new program -- TXL Mortgage-Lakeside Lending,
3701 Waco Drive, in the Keller-Williams building.

Senior loan officer Jeffrey Bradburn said Wednesday his office has not yet
processed a mortgage involving the $2,000 credit, but he welcomes inquiries and
homebuyers.

Push in smaller cities Larger cities statewide have dozens of mortgage lenders
participating in the program and the state is trying to recruit others in
smaller communities to get involved, program director Dina Gonzalez said.

In Temple, Cornerstone Mortgage, 3820 W. Adams, and DHI Mortgage, 2305 Birdcreek
Terrace, are participating in the program, along with Killeen's First Community
Mortgage, 2101 W.S. Young Drive.

Anyone who buys a home in one of several areas of Waco does not have to meet the
requirement of not having owned a home as a primary residence within the past
three years.

These census tracts lie within low-income areas in East Waco and near Interstate
35 at Valley Mills Drive, the Texas State Technical College campus, Herring
Avenue at 18th Street, Ninth Street at Colcord Avenue and I-35 across from the
Baylor University campus, said Chris Evilia, director of Waco's Metropolitan
Planning Organization.

Basically, Gonzalez said, homeowners in the program qualify for a tax credit
each year equal to 30 percent of the interest paid on the home.

The credit cannot exceed $2,000.

Texas is receiving federal funding with which it is offering the mortgage
credits.

Program example Here's an example of how the program works: A buyer pays
$121,000 for a house at 6 percent interest on a 30-year fixed-rate note. The
first year, he or she owes $7,260 in interest.

Multiplying that figure by .30, the owner receives a tax credit of $2,178. But
the maximum allowed is $2,000, so the buyer would be obligated to pay $5,260 in
interest.

The credit would save the buyer about $167 a month.

Homebuyers taking part in the program should keep in mind they must complete a
homebuyer-education course before their loan closing.

And at closing, they must pay a Mortgage Credit Certificate issuance fee of 1
percent of the loan amount. This is in addition to other closing costs
associated with buying a house.

The program is available to those who want 15- or 30-year mortgages.

http://www.wacotrib.com. Copyright (c) 2010, Waco Tribune-Herald, Texas

                     The Daily Item (Sunbury, Pennsylvania)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             May 16, 2015 Saturday

$1.8M OK'd for housing project

BYLINE: Evamarie Socha, The Daily Item, Sunbury, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 487 words


May 16--LEWISBURG -- About $1.8 million in loan and tax credit requests was
approved for an affordable multifamily housing development at the Pennsylvania
House Commons complex in East Buffalo Township.

The Pennsylvania Housing Finance Agency announced the so-called Penn Commons
complex will receive a $968,742 PennHOMES loan and $878,726 in tax credits to
construct seven general occupancy buildings: five one-bedroom units, 12
two-bedroom units and eight three-bedroom units.

"We're very happy (with the news) and now we can get to work," said Bruce
Quigley, executive director of the Union County Housing Authority, which is
behind the project, among the only low-income housing centers in the county.

The housing will be adjacent to the forthcoming Penn House Commons complex in
East Buffalo Township on the site of the former Pennsylvania House furniture
factory. The housing authority bought the tract between Route 45 and the Buffalo
Valley Rail Trail. The project is estimated at a total 43,868 square feet.

The project is still in the very early stages, Quigley said, adding that the
design phase now can begin and should take several months. Construction likely
won't happen until 2017 once financing has been set, he said.

This will be a low-income housing complex in which residents will pay a portion
of the rent. Those approved for Section 8 housing could live at Penn Commons,
Quigley said, though it is not intended strictly for such clients.

This complex also is not public housing, which is a specific classification
under the U.S. Housing Act.

Stacey Kifolo, manager for East Buffalo Township, said the municipality had
issued a letter of support for the project to the state on the housing
authority's behalf.

The loan is for construction, Quigley said, while the tax credits are for
investors. The tax incentive is intended to increase the availability of
low-income housing, for which the residents pay a portion of the rent.

According to the state housing agency, the Tax Credit Program offers owners of
affordable rental housing a tax incentive, not a loan or grant, in the form of
an annual tax credit to owners of newly constructed or substantially
rehabilitated low-income rental housing projects.

A developer markets or "syndicates" the credits to investors, whose
contributions are used as equity in the development's financing. This program is
federally funded, and each state administers the money.

PennHOMES offers loans to developers with terms that include a zero percent
interest rate, 30-year term and deferred payment. It combines both federal HOME
and state funding.

Statewide, the housing agency awarded $12.5 million in PennHOMES funding and
$36.9 million in tax credits to build 39 affordable multifamily housing
developments in suburban and rural areas.

                      Times of India (Electronic Edition)

                              March 4, 2016 Friday
                               Bangalore Edition

BUDGET 2016 Push for affordable housing in Budget

BYLINE: Ashish Gupta

SECTION: TIMES PROPERTY

LENGTH: 345 words


The Union Budget for 2016-17 was much awaited with plenty of expectations. The
Budget has a significant rural focus.There are some welcome measures initiated
towards pushing the realty sector.

PUSH FOR BUDGET HOMES

In line with the mission 'Housing for all by 2022', the Budget has provided for
a 100 percent deduction against profits from a housing project with units of up
to 30 sq mts (300 sqft) in the four metro cities and 60 sq mts (600 sqft) in
other cities, that are approved between June 2016 and March 2019, and com

pleted within three years of the approval. This will give a major push to the
affordable housing segment.

HIGHER INTEREST DEDUCTION

There is some good news for first-time homebuyers. The Budget has proposed an
additional Rs 50,000 in deduction against interest paid on a loan for first-time
homebuyers.This tax deduction is for a loan of up to Rs 35 lakhs sanctioned
during the next financial year, provided the value of the house does not exceed
Rs 50 lakhs.

This measure is expected to encourage more prospective buyers to invest in
property.As it will reduce the cost of a loan effectively, it is expected to
boost demand for housing

in the budget and mid-segment categories.

This additional deduction of Rs 50,000 will significantly benefit first-time
homebuyers in Tier II and Tier III cities too.

DUTY EXEMPTION

The Budget also extended an excise duty exemption, currently available to
concrete mix manufactured on site, to ready-mix concrete too.This is expected to
lower the cost of construction for developers.

A service tax exemption has been announced on construction of affordable housing
under State and Central housing schemes. Builders will get 100 percent tax
exemption on profits if they build units of up to 300 sqft in the four

metro cities and up to 600 sqft in the other cities. This will give some
much-needed impetus to develop a greater number of affordable housing projects
across the country.

The tax sops for firsttime homebuyers and incentives on development of
affordable housing projects will push demand in the property market.

                    The Blairsville Dispatch (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              June 12, 2009 Friday

Housing authority to take over Derry senior citizen facility

BYLINE: Jeff Himler, The Blairsville Dispatch, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1104 words


Jun. 12--The Westmoreland County Housing Authority is slated to take over
operation of Derry Senior Housing, a senior-citizen housing facility in the
borough whose current owners say they no longer can keep up with costs at the
18-unit complex.

Derry Senior Housing Corp. Board President Vic Mowry said the organization has
run the senior housing facility at Fifth Avenue and Mentor Street since 1992 but
recently decided to search for a buyer due to mounting expenses.

"We hate to see it go, but there's too much work to get done, and there's no
money," Mowry told Derry Borough Council Monday. "The figures don't balance
anymore." He cited roofing and siding as items that need addressed.

According to Mowry, his board expects to sign an agreement on June 16 that will
transfer the housing property to the county authority.

Terms of the proposed deal weren't released. Mowry said the authority is
financing the purchase with a loan through the U.S. Department of Agriculture's
Rural Development program.

"We tried everything we could to keep it going," Mowry said, noting his board
was turned down for a state loan to help cover costs at the senior facility. He
said the authority will be better positioned to take advantage of government
grants for the complex.

In addition to building maintenance costs, Mowry said the board has been
challenged by high insurance rates. "After 2001, it just skyrocketed," he said.

The senior housing complex, which has been in existence since 1975, contains
seven single-bedroom units and 11 two-bedroom units and is fully occupied by 22
residents age 62 or older, Mowry said. He said the housing authority would
continue to operate the property as a senior facility.

Derry Council, in its own effort to upgrade housing, authorized its president,
Allen Skopp, and Mayor Susan Bortz to send a letter recommending 19 properties
in the borough for possible inclusion in either of two local housing development
programs.

Skopp said there was a consensus among borough officials to nominate a dozen
vacant or dilapidated Derry homes for the development programs -- Westmoreland
Community Action's affordable homes program and Homes Build Hope, an effort to
create affordable rental units that is affiliated with Latrobe's Adelphoi
Village. Skopp said he additionally nominated seven vacant lots for
redevelopment through the programs.

The borough won't be involved beyond recommending the sites, which Bortz
declined to identify.

Skopp said some of the properties involved are homes that have been subject to
foreclosure, forcing borough crews to step in and keep grass trimmed, while
others were severely damaged by fire.

Skopp said the borough has been told there should be sufficient funding
available through the programs to redevelop about seven properties in Derry.

"It's a nice way to get new residents and housing in the borough," he said of
the programs.

In the past, Westmoreland Community Action has renovated or reconstructed homes
in Greensburg, Jeannette, Mt. Pleasant, Claridge, Export and New Kensington.

In other property matters, council accepted the sole bid of $6,000 from Brian
Heiple to purchase a vacant borough-owned lot on South Chestnut Street that
previously housed council chambers. The parcel is located next to the
drive-through lane for AmeriServ Bank.

Heiple, who operates an insurance agency on a nearby property, will complete the
purchase in three equal installments through Dec. 15 of this year.

Council currently holds its monthly meetings in the community room of the Derry
Station senior housing complex at Second Avenue and Y Street.

The panel hopes to eventually construct a new municipal building, with meeting
space, on a downtown property at East Second Avenue and South Chestnut Street
that previously housed the Creative Dreams business. The borough recently
assumed ownership of that vacant structure, which poses a hazard due to bowing
of an exterior wall.

Skopp said the borough wants to have the building razed by the end of the month.
It will be necessary to reroute traffic in the vicinity during the two- to
three-day demolition process.

Meanwhile, at its Monday meeting, council approved exoneration of an estimated
$1,912.95 in back property taxes due on the parcel since 2006.

Borough Solicitor Rachel Riedel said she is awaiting word by week's end from the
state Department of Environmental Protection, which is expected to issue
comments addressing a cleanup plan proposed by owner Marlborough U.S. Realty
Holdings for its Porcelain Park property. That multi-tenant industrial and
warehouse facility has become a longstanding eyesore in the community since
portions of the former ceramics plant were demolished, leaving debris on the
expansive property on West Third Street.

If the DEP acts as anticipated, Riedel said, it will give the owner until Aug. 1
to take action on the cleanup plan.

Council member Kristine Melville said state Sen. Kim Ward of Westmoreland County
has offered the borough help in seeking a resolution to the delayed cleanup.
Skopp said council intends to invite Ward to its Aug. 3 work session.

"At this point, I'll take all the help we can get," Councilman Todd Krehlik said
about borough concerns with the Porcelain Park property. "We're spinning our
wheels."

Riedel indicated the question of taxes due on the Porcelain Park property during
the past few years remains unresolved. At issue are changes in the property's
assessed value and its status as a state Keystone Opportunity Zone, which offers
exemption from many taxes for a set period of time.

In other business, council renewed a lease for four years with Copier
Corporation, which supplies a copy machine for the borough office. The monthly
lease of $139.78 will take effect Aug. 1.

Council also agreed to purchase road salt from North American Salt, at a cost of
$63.45 per ton. The price was obtained through the Indiana-Westmoreland Council
of Governments.

Borough Secretary Lori Latta said the supplier will require Derry to take
delivery of at least 80 percent of the tonnage that was bid, compared to 60
percent in previous purchase agreements.

Typically, the borough purchases 600 tons for the winter season, Latta noted.

Agriculture, Rural Housing Service: Single Family Housing Technician
DEU-KY-2014-4602

LENGTH: 2953  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of Personnel Management has issued the following job announcement:

Job Title:Single Family Housing Technician

Department:Department Of Agriculture

Agency:Agriculture, Rural Housing Service

Job Announcement Number:DEU-KY-2014-4602
SALARY RANGE:
 $31,628.00 to $45,828.00 / Per Year

JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This announcement may be used to fill additional or subsequent vacancies that
are identified by the organization.

                                  July 7, 2011

USDA invites applications for Value Added Producer Grant to assist farmers;
Investing in Rural America Essential to Job Creation and Business Growth

BYLINE: Monroe County Appeal staff

LENGTH: 396  words


Deputy Agriculture Secretary Kathleen Merrigan announced that applications are
being accepted for grants to provide economic assistance to independent
producers, farmer and rancher cooperatives and agricultural producer groups
through the Value-Added Producer Grant Program.

"By creating value-added products, farmers and ranchers can expand economic
opportunities, create jobs and keep wealth in rural communities," Merrigan
said."These funding opportunities will promote business expansion and
entrepreneurship by helping local businesses get access to capital, technical
assistance and new markets for their products and servic-es.

Application deadline is Monday, Aug. 29. For further details about eligibility
rules and application procedures, see the June 28, Federal Register. Value-Added
Producer

Grantsmay be used for feasibility studies or business plans, working capital for
marketing value-added agricultural products and for farm-based renewable energy
projects. Eligible applicants include independent producers, farmer and rancher
cooperatives, and agricultural producer groups. Value-added products are created
when a producer increases the consumer value of an agricultural commodity in the
production or processing stage.

Additional information is available by contacting Nathan Chit-wood with the
Missouri USDA Rural Development State Office at 573-876-0995. An informational
meeting and training on completion of the application packet will be held at the
Missouri USDA Rural Development State Office, 601 Business Loop 70 West, Suite
232 Parkade Center, Columbia, Missouri 65203 on Thursday, July 14, at 10 a.m.
Those interested in obtaining additional information are encouraged to attend
and/or contact Mr. Chitwood.

USDA, through its Rural Development mission area, administers and manages
housing, business and community infrastructure and facility programs through a
national network of state and local offices. Rural Development has an existing
portfolio of more than $150 billion in loans and loan guarantees. These programs
are designed to improve the economic stability of rural communities, businesses,
residents, farmers and ranchers and improve the quality of life in rural
America.

Further information on rural programs is available at a local USDA Rural
Development office or by visiting USDA Rural Development's web site at
http://www.rur-dev.usda.gov.

                                 The Cornishman

                           February 28, 2008 Thursday

Fight for our green spaces

SECTION: Pg. 34

LENGTH: 328 words


Caroline astin Penzance

Instead of building affordable housing on green field sites, as proposed in
Penwith District Council's Action Plan, might it not be a good idea to tackle
issues that have led to the housing shortage, in particular that of second
homes?

The number of second homes in Cornwall has risen from 9,233 in 2000 to 13,221 in
2006, a rise of 40%.  Last year twice as many houses sold in the St Ives
constituency went to second home buyers than to first home buyers. Up to 10% of
all housing in Cornwall is now second homes or let as holiday homes.

In some Cornish villages second home ownership is as high as 80%.  Even in towns
and villages where it is lower than this the effects are still seen on local
services; communities without a viable year round population are far less likely
to have schools, shops and all the services and community groups that make for a
pleasant place to live.

The other effect of this is to artificially inflate prices way beyond the reach
of local people.   House prices in Cornwall have risen by 153.1% since 1999, and
the average house price in Cornwall is now £208,000 compared with £191,000 in
England and Wales, yet our wages are 25% below the national average. Buying a
home in Cornwall now means - if such a thing were possible - taking out a
mortgage close to 10 times the average salary.

An article in the Daily Telegraph  of May 19, 2006 put forward for debate the
suggestion that councils should veto second home ownership.  The proposals were
put forward by the Government's Affordable Rural Housing Commission.

It seems we can have either a free market economy and everything that goes with
it - soaring house prices, 'ghost villages', towns without green spaces - or
government intervention to protect local people's right to a home of their own.
We need to ask ourselves hard questions about what we really want.  There is
still time to send in responses to the council's action plan. Fight for our
green spaces!

                     The Journal Record (Oklahoma City, OK)

                              July 2, 2002 Tuesday

Three historic OK properties added to national register

BYLINE: staff

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 295 words


Three Oklahoma properties have been added to the National Register of Historic
Places, including Tulsa's Yorktown Historic District, Grandfield's Downtown
Historic District and the Bank of Nashville in Nash.

The addition of these three properties brings to 998 the total number of
Oklahoma properties listed in the National Register, said Architectural
Historian Jim Gabbert of the State Historic Preservation Office. The National
Register is a listing of buildings, sites, structures, objects, and districts
that are significant in U.S. history, Gabbert said.

The Yorktown Historic District in Tulsa reflects the growth of the middle class
in the city in the decade of the 1920s, said Gabbert. Roughly bounded by 16th
and 17th streets, Victor and Wheeling avenues, 20th Street and Lewis Avenue, the
Yorktown neighborhood is differentiated from the nearby Gillette and Swan Lake
neighborhoods by the sizes and styles of the house.

The Grandfield Downtown Historic District consists of the heart of the
commercial center of this Tillman County city. The buildings along Second Street
represent the range of commercial and service ventures found in agricultural
towns in western Oklahoma.

The fortunes of Grandfield are reflected in its buildings, and the history of
the area can be read on each facade, Gabbert said. The city and its citizens
sponsored the nomination to the National Register.

The Bank of Nashville is on a prominent corner in the Grant County town of Nash.
It is the only standing two-story commercial building in Nash and had recently
fallen into a state of disrepair. The building has been saved through the
efforts of the New Nashville Historical Preservation Association, who are
continuing to raise funds to rehabilitate the building.

                              The American Banker

The Emerging Role of the Manufactured Home

                             March 26, 1979, Monday

By ROBERT L. BERNER, Vice president, Citicorp, New York, and member of the
board, Manufactured Housing Institute, Chicago


From a shakey start before World War II, the mobile home industry became the
stopgap to fill the void in housing availability during the war and the service
thereafter.  It did that well and many builders and investors were saying mobile
homes would take over a lion's share of the housing market from that time
forward.  If the optimistic predictions of that period had been realized, most
American's would now be living in these structures.

After the boom period of the '40s, manufacturers assumed that what they had to
produce was a unit that looked like, lived like, and met the expectations of the
typical conventional home buyer.

It took some time to discover that the mobile home buyers of the late '40s and
'50s were not looking just for an inexpensive place to live, but had found for
themselves an entirely new way of life.  Manufacturers soon learned that their
innovative efforts to make a unit that looked like a conventional house were not
doing well in the market place.  Rather, the units with the round windows, metal
siding and futuristic appearance were carrying the sales volume.

Not without reason, manufacturers stayed with these designs, looked more closely
at their customers, and discovered two important facts: one, most of their
buyers could afford a conventional house but chose a mobile home instead; and
two, people living in mobile homes had a somewhat different lifestyle.  One of
our board members, who has been in this business for a long time, recently
pointed this out.

He is an engineer, a profession not normally associated with this business many
years ago.  He found that the people working in the plant manufacturing mobile
homes could not afford to buy the product which they produced.  Secondly, he
found that the more they tried to make his product look like a conventional
house, the more sales resistance he encountered.  Because of these factors,
builders of the '50s and early '60s continued to produce units which met the
needs of a special market.  Units became longer, wider and more luxurious.  They
were placed in better mobile home parks, found their way into rural and small
town markets, and increasingly were purchased for retirement homes or second
homes in recreational areas.

The first factor was cost.  In the 1940s it was not difficult to find a
conventional house at a price which was reasonably affordable.  This held true
for many years, until the 1970s when conventional housing rapidly took on the
posture of a sizable, then overbearing investment to a large portion of the home
buying public.

The next factor was size and appearance.  After gaining approval in many states
to transport larger and larger units over the highways, the industry increased
its capability by developing multi-section units -- two or more structures which
could be joined together at the home site to form structures of 1,000-2,000, or
more, square feet of living space.

During this time, the Federal government also got involved, as it does today in
almost everything.  The department of Housing and Urban Development established
a national building code for the industry.  Today the only single family housing
units in America which are required to meet high standards of material,
construction and safety because of Federal regulations are mobile homes.

These factors spelled out two things.  One, the well established market for the
conventional mobile home was firm and the industry has a bright future in
continuing to supply this market.  And two, a new market was emerging that could
offer competition with the conventional home market.

We at the Manufactured Housing Institute watched these trends and decided that
two major factors needed modification if we were to move the industry as rapidly
as the market demanded.

First, we would have to do something about zoning.  We are now producing units
which we believe are the equal of conventional houses.  However, we knew that
zoning boards were still viewing our product as transient housing which should
be grouped closely together on the outskirts of town.  We have gone to the state
legislatures, town counsels, mayor's offices, zoning boards, and sometimes to
the courts.  We are happy to report that much progress has been made.  Today
many of our units are side-by-side with conventional houses in residential
neighborhoods.  As a matter of fact, entire subdivisions classified residential
are being developed exclusively with mobile/manufactured homes.  Although we
have much more to accomplish, zoning changes are taking place which open new
neighborhoods to our product.

The second major area we have worked on is that of financing.  We were faced
with the circumstance where lending institutions were still viewing our product
much as they did the purchase of an automobile -- personal property with a
relatively short life and a decreasing value from the time of purchase.  This is
a false impression.

Not only is the quality and safety of our product assured through government
regulation, but we are finding that our homes are appreciating, not
depreciating.  Our manufacturers and dealers have been working with local
lending institutions with the result that more and more lenders are providing
their customers with loans that are in keeping with the high quality of the
product.

Representing our members, the Manufactured Housing Institute went to Congress to
get fair treatment for our product within the various loan guarantee programs
the government provides.  We can now report that Congress responded and the loan
guarantee market for our product is virtually the same as that for conventional
housing.

What all this means is that it is time for the financial community to take a
good look at our industry.  The high quality factory-built home is no longer a
promise about to be fulfilled.  Our product today meets rigid building codes, is
low in cost, outstanding in design, and deserves longterm financing.

A few financial facts about our product, mobile/manufactured homes, underscore
this point.

The name mobile/manufactured homes is descriptive because our homes are
constructed in well-planned, highly-efficient factories that produce several
homes a day using production methods.  Labor costs are greatly reduced by not
having to depend upon weather conditions and the scheduling of subcontractors,
which slows the process of building conventional homes.  Construction standards,
set by Federal regulations of the Department of Housing and Urban Development,
are quality controlled by experts having constant and immediate contact with the
manufacturing process.  In contrast, the conventional sitebuilt home is
subjected to rain, ice, snow and wind over a period of weeks or months during
its construction.  The building contractor of the site-built home is ultimately
the quality control inspector, but more often than not he is away from the site
during the many critical phases on construction.  Because of the factors of cost
and regulated quality, the manufactured house has become a significant factor in
the new home market, especially at the lower cost levels.

The Manufactured Housing Institute sponsored a survey of financial institutions
covering the year of 1977.  The survey sought to identify trends in loan
practices related to manufactured homes, and, to the extent possible from such a
research instrument, to identify factors which might slow the growth of the
industry due to outdated or restrictive financing practices.

Nearly 80% of the financial institutions responding to the survey reported that
they do provide manufactured home financing.  Respondents to the survey
represented holders of 46% of the retail paper outstanding -- $14.6 billion.
The value of mobile home retail paper outstanding is divided among: Banks $8.9
billion Finance companies $3.1 billion Savings and loans $2.5 billion Credit
unions $0.3 billion

This means that just over 60% of financing was with banks, with the balance
closely divided between finance companies and S&Ls.

The 425 financial institutions who replied to the survey reported doing business
in manufactured housing consumer financing of about $6.6 billion in gross dollar
volume during 1977.  This average out at slightly more than $15.5 million per
institution.  This average was up from $14.1 million per institution in 1976.
The three major sources of mobile home loans reported the following changes in
average loan.

Amount in 1976 and 1977: 1976 1977 Banks $8,963 $10,279 Finance companies 9,245
9,143 S&Ls 13,029 13,975

While the overall average went up slightly, the real gain was among banks.
Finance companies and savings and loans remained about the same.

Over the past ten years, the change in the configurations of manufactured homes
has been reflected in sales and financing.  An innovation in the market, the
multi-section manufactured home has grown from 8.2% of the market in 1968 to 30%
in 1977.

The average minimum down payment on single-section manufactured homes went up
from slightly under 16% in 1976 and slightly over 16% in 1977.  Multisection
manufactured home minimum down payment averages also increased from slightly
under 17% in 1976 to 17.5% in 1977.  However, on the single-and multi-section
homes, finance companies reported an average decrease in down payments to under
11% in 1977 from slightly over 12% in 1976 on single units, and about 13% in
1977 down from 15.5% required in 1976 on multi-section homes.

Delinquencies in monthly payments declined in 1977.  The overall decline was
from 4.0% in December 1976 to 3.4% in December 1957.

Repossession data published by the American Bankers Association shows
substantial improvement from January, 1977, to December 1977.  The rate per
1,000 loans fell from 2.22 to 1.47 during this period.

Average maturity of new loans is another way of measuring trends in manufactured
home financing.  Between 1976 and 1977 average maturity of new loans on
single-section homes from 114.45 months to 115.9 months, and on multisection
homes from 136.0 months to 138.4 months.  In both cases average maturity of new
loans increased for banks and finance companies but declined slightly for S&Ls.

In general, banks and finance companies have been in the manufactured housing
market for a longer period than S&Ls.  On the average, banks report 12 years
experience, finance companies only slightly under 12 years, and savings and
loans, just over 7 years.

As part of our report on manufactured home financing in 1977, The Manufactured
Housing Institute reprinted interviews with leading authorities in this field
that had been conducted by Mobile Home Merchandiser, an industry trade magazine.
Their observations provide insight into problems and trends in the area of home
financing.

From the views expressed, it is clear that a lack of what people view as
affordable housing is developing.While demand for site-built housing is still
high, it has been priced into a market which is not affordable by an
increasingly large segment of the population.  The average cost of a new site
-built home is over $64,000 while the average for a manufactured home is about
$15,200.  Moreover, if the cost of land is removed, the difference in price per
square foot becomes dramatic -- in 1977, $24.75 per square foot for site-built
houses and $13.75 for manufactured homes.  A difference of $11.00 because of
this difference, manufactured housing is taking an increasing share of the
lower-priced housing market.  What keeps this trend from accelerating at a
greater rate is the difference in policy for zoning and financing these two
forms of single-family, owner-occupied homes.

It is agreed that these differences should not occur to the extent they do.
Some financial institutions are still looking at the money market in terms of
short-term loans for manufactured homes.  Given changes in the manufacturing
process and regulation by HUD setting rigid standards for mobile/manufactured
housing, there is less justification for financing manufactured homes
differently than site-built homes.

Congress recognized this fact in 1978, and with the strong encouragement of the
Manufactured Housing Institute greatly expanded Federal policy on loan
guarantees, length of loans and interest rates.  Financial institutions are
likely to follow this lead, making it more possible for lower-to-middle-income
families to own manufactured homes.  This should lead to a bright future for the
manufactured housing industry, and an expanding market for financial
institutions.  It also means that the promise of the '40s -- that the
manufactured home would successfully compete with the conventional house in the
market place -- is at long last being realized!

"This should lead to a bright future for the manufactured housing industry, and
an expanding market for financial institutions."

SECTION: Pg. 12

LENGTH: 2152 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

Gilmer County VFD Approved for Rural Development Funds

BYLINE: The Glenville Democrat staff

LENGTH: 252  words


Acting State Director Dianne Goff Crysler announced that Rural Development
approved a Community Facilities loan in the amount of $90,000 and grant of
$50,000 for the Gilmer County Volunteer Fire Department.

Rural Development funds will be used to assist in purchasing a new tank truck.
Crysler added, "A reliable tanker is needed to shuttle water in areas without
hydrants and for situations that require decontamination of hazardous
materials."

Rural Development serves as the lead Federal entity for rural development needs
and administers program assistance through its housing, business/cooperative,
community and infrastructure programs. The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
prohibits discrimination in all its programs and activities on the basis of
race, color, national origin, age, disability and where applicable, sex, marital
status, familial status, parental status, religion, sexual orientation, genetic
information, political beliefs, reprisal, or because all or part of an or the
fact that an individual's income is derived from any public assistance program.

                    The Orange County Register (California)

                             April 7, 2009 Tuesday
                                   1 Edition

FTC complaint targets loan modification firm;
Irvine company allegedly charged fees for little work.

BYLINE: By MATHEW PADILLA; The Orange County Register

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. BizCover_A

LENGTH: 765 words


The Obama administration said Monday that federal and state agencies are
coordinating efforts to stop swindlers who prey on people in jeopardy of losing
their homes.

As part of the effort, the Federal Trade Commission announced five legal actions
against alleged perpetrators of mortgage-related scams, including
Irvine-basedFederal Loan Modification Law Center. The FTC accused the company of
charging upfront fees of $1,000 to $3,000 for help getting a loan modification
but often failing to get the modification.

The FTC also said: "In radio advertisements, the FTC alleges, (the law center)
induces homeowners to call its toll-free number by misrepresenting that it is
part of or affiliated with the federal government, although it is not. According
to the complaint, (the law center) often fails to answer or return consumers'
calls or provide updates about the status of their loan modifications, and
assures consumers that negotiations with their lenders are proceeding when, in
fact, little or no effort has been made to contact the lender."

Nabile "Bill" Anz, managing attorney for Federal Loan Modification Law Center
and one of three people named in the FTC complaint filed Friday, said his
company may have been aggressive, but it has obeyed the law. He is willing to
work with the FTC to change any practices it condemns, including the company
name, Anz said.

Since getting up and running in December, Anz said, the company has taken on
about 5,000 clients and achieved loan modifications for 1,000.

The company refunds consumer fees if it fails to get a loan modification, Anz
said. So far about 10 percent of his clients have requested a refund or already
received one, he said.

Anz said he is running a law firm, and lawyers have a place in the mortgage
business.

"We are talking about negotiating a contract on behalf of a third party," Anz
said. "Only attorneys are allowed to do that."

However, consumers in trouble can seek help from nonprofit agencies certified by
the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. Help is free, but there
may be a waiting list.

Law firms can collect advance fees for loan modification work. Other companies
in California must first get approval from the state Department of Real Estate
to collect advance fees.

The FTC also has taken action against a local man for creating a Web site
offering loan help that gave the false impression of being government-backed.
The agency has shut down the site, bailout.hud-guv.us, and a related site. A
preliminary injunction against Thomas Ryan lists a Newport Beach address for
him. A call to Ryan was not immediately returned.

And the FTC sent warning letters to 71 companies that are marketing "potentially
deceptive" loan modification or other foreclosure rescue programs.

Despite being targeted, Anz said it is a good thing the government is trying to
clean up the mortgage aid business.

"There are real criminals, real bad people out there," Anz said. "We do need to
get rid of a lot of shady characters."

Fraud watch

Homeowners do not have to pay to participate in the administration's Making Home
Affordable program. Homeowners can locate free housing counselors at
makinghomeaffordable.gov or by calling 888-995-HOPE.

Frauds often involve companies with official-sounding names designed to make
borrowers think they are using the Obama administration's efforts to help modify
or refinance 7 million to 9 million mortgages.

"If you are struggling to make your mortgage payment or if you are facing
foreclosure, stay away from anyone who says that they will save your home for
money upfront,"

Illinois Attorney General Lisa Madigan told reporters in Washington.

Officials say such operations almost always are fraudulent and that help is
available for free from government-approved housing counselors.

"These are predatory schemes designed to rob Americans of their savings and
potentially their homes," Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner said. "We will
shut down fraudulent companies more quickly than before. We will target
companies that otherwise would have gone unnoticed under the radar."

The FBI is investigating about 2,100 mortgage fraud cases, a 400 percent
increase from five years ago, Attorney General Eric Holder said Monday. "If you
prey on vulnerable homeowners with fraudulent mortgage schemes or discriminate
against borrowers, we will find you and we will punish you," Holder said.

Federal Trade Commission Chairman Jon Liebowitz announces a coordinated
government effort to protect homeowners seeking loan assistance from
unscrupulous companies.

714-796-6726 or  mapadilla@ocregister.com

                              The Washington Post

                              April 4, 2004 Sunday
                                 Final Edition

Spotsylvania To Host Reenactment;
Civil War Buffs Hope Event Will Help Stave Off Development

BYLINE: Michelle Boorstein, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: Metro; C01

LENGTH: 790 words


Things have been looking up for preservationists and Civil War buffs in
Spotsylvania County. Last summer, they defeated a proposal to build an entire
new town, with office space and retail shops and 2,000 houses, on the site of
the Battle of Chancellorsville. In the fall, they took a majority on the Board
of Supervisors.

Now they're about to celebrate with a massive reenactment of the Battle of
Spotsylvania.

For the first time since the 1960s, the pivotal 1864 battle will be re-created
next month in the county where it was fought, complete with a pyrotechnical
adviser, 4,000 reenactors and a curved, quarter-mile-long battle trench built to
look just like the real one, known as the "Mule Shoe" or the Bloody Angle.

Many Civil War buffs -- especially in Spotsylvania -- believe that this battle,
in which the war's two titans, Robert E. Lee and Ulysses S. Grant, really
engaged for the first time, has been lost in the shuffle of history and its
importance unfairly dwarfed by Gettysburg and Antietam.

Spotsylvania also marked a radical change in fighting style, with soldiers
digging extensive trenches -- also called earthworks -- and living in them,
extending them 15 to 20 miles over the 14-day battle. The trenches were
typically five feet deep, had alleys and were elaborately reinforced with logs
and other engineering devices. The battle in the Bloody Angle alone included 22
hours of fighting by as many as 30,000 troops, more than one-third of whom were
killed.

"Spotsylvania is where the duel was really fought between Lee and Grant -- two
weeks of fighting as these two great leaders tried to out-general one another,"
said Jim Campi, spokesman for the Civil War Preservation Trust, which has placed
the Spotsylvania and Chancellorsville sites on its list of the 25
most-endangered battlefields in the country.

Mega-builder Toll Brothers Inc. recently purchased part of the Chancellorsville
site, and the land is zoned for 225 houses. Although the company's Web site
already has model houses for sale there, preservationists say they hope they can
negotiate a land purchase or at least a reduction in the number of houses.

The reenactment, May 7-9, and its sponsorship by the county -- at a cost of
$200,000 -- marks a cultural and political change in Spotsylvania, where
preservationists have roared back in the past couple years in response to
high-speed development.

Although the Spotsylvania battlefield does not even have a visitors center,
preservationists helped elect a majority of supervisors who are beginning to
focus on historic tourism. Last spring, the county established a tourism
commission charged with promoting history, and the reenactment is its first real
event. County officials also are talking about putting some of the proceeds from
the reenactment into a fund for acquiring land it wants to preserve from
development.

A rural county 15 years ago, Spotsylvania has lost most of its working farms.
Rural landowners today have to choose between selling to developers or paying
ever-rising property taxes. A case in point is the site of the reenactment,
Belvedere Plantation, a 1,000-acre working farm that now hosts such events as a
corporate team-building program held in a corn maze and a "Punkin Chunkin,"
which involves catapulting pumpkins out of a cannon.

The reenactment will be held at the plantation because the National Park
Service, which owns the preserved part of the actual battlefield, feared that it
could not accommodate a three-day event expected to attract at least 10,000
people a day.

With Spotsylvania rapidly becoming a bedroom community for Washington, the
reenactment is a way to educate new residents about the region's history, said
Doug Barnes, interim deputy county administrator. It also will be the first
major test of the historic tourism strategy that preservationists used to fight
development.

"If [the reenactment] does well, there will be more things like it. If it
doesn't, my guess is they won't do it again," said Robert Lee Hodge, a longtime
Civil War reenactor and preservationist who is organizing the 140th anniversary
reenactment.

Hodge, who was named after Robert E. Lee and wore a Confederate cap in his
first-grade photo, noted that some preservationists question whether
reenactments ultimately help their cause.

"When you look at reenacting, it's something easily made fun of by South Park
and the Comedy Channel. When you break it down to the lowest common denominator,
you're talking about a subculture of people who dress up in clothes from 140
years ago," he said. "But when you go to a battlefield, unless you have a great
imagination, it's just a field. How do you connect, especially with kids, when
you're up against so much stimulation?"

                                The Irish Times

                                November 2, 1999

Eco-village plan gains support

BYLINE: By TIM O'BRIEN, Regional Development Correspondent

SECTION: CITY EDITION; HOME NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 293 words


A number of high-profile architects, academics and building professionals have
lent their support to the development of a 40-house eco-village which
environmentalists plan to build on a 100-acre rural site within an hour's drive
of Dublin's M50.

The Village, as the project is to be called, is intended to be a model for
sustainable development offering homes which are constructed to modern,
environmentally-friendly standards, using renewable resources and utilising
highly active waste-management strategies. The Village will include two
community facilities, and identify possibilities for the development of small
businesses.

Among the directors of the project are the Green Party TD, Mr John Gormley, Mr
Brian O'Brien of the Dublin Co-Housing Group, Ms Caroline Conroy, a solicitor
and chairwoman of the Dublin Food Co-op, and Mr Ross Coakley, a civil engineer.

The project directors have identified a number of suitable sites, one in Meath
and one in east Offaly, where they feel they can buy suitable land for (pounds)
500,000 to (pounds) 600,000. They are organising a fund-raising drive, with a
number of investors to provide loans of up to (pounds) 30,000 each. In all, the
project aims to raise (pounds) 1.2 million.

In return for their loans, investors will receive a site, complete with outline
planning permission, and become part of the Village community. The Village will
be run as a co-operative. Investors may alternatively guarantee loans from the
Tridos Bank, which supports environmentally-friendly ventures. Investors may
withdraw their money at any time and shares may be traded.

The Village may be contacted at Sustainable Projects Ireland Ltd, 15 Ostman
Place, Manor Street, Dublin 7, or through email: thevillage(at)tinet.ie
