Preservationists Celebrate With Civil War Reenactment;
History Buffs Hope Event Will Help Preserve Land From Encroaching Development

BYLINE: Michelle Boorstein, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: Metro; C05

LENGTH: 791 words


Things have been looking up for preservationists and Civil War buffs in
Spotsylvania County. Last summer, they defeated a proposal to build an entire
new town, with office space and retail shops and 2,000 houses, on the site of
the Battle of Chancellorsville. In the fall, they took a majority on the Board
of Supervisors.

Now they're about to celebrate with a massive reenactment of the Battle of
Spotsylvania.

For the first time since the 1960s, the pivotal 1864 battle will be re-created
next month in the county where it was fought, complete with a pyrotechnical
adviser, 4,000 reenactors and a curved, quarter-mile-long battle trench built to
look just like the real one, known as the "Mule Shoe" or the Bloody Angle.

Many Civil War buffs -- especially in Spotsylvania -- believe that this battle,
in which the war's two titans, Robert E. Lee and Ulysses S. Grant, really
engaged for the first time, has been lost in the shuffle of history and its
importance unfairly dwarfed by Gettysburg and Antietam.

Spotsylvania also marked a radical change in fighting style, with soldiers
digging extensive trenches -- also called earthworks -- and living in them,
extending them 15 to 20 miles over the 14-day battle. The trenches were
typically five feet deep, had alleys and were elaborately reinforced with logs
and other engineering devices. The battle in the Bloody Angle alone included 22
hours of fighting by as many as 30,000 troops, more than one-third of whom were
killed.

"Spotsylvania is where the duel was really fought between Lee and Grant -- two
weeks of fighting as these two great leaders tried to out-general one another,"
said Jim Campi, spokesman for the Civil War Preservation Trust, which has placed
the Spotsylvania and Chancellorsville sites on its list of the 25
most-endangered battlefields in the country.

Mega-builder Toll Brothers Inc. recently purchased part of the Chancellorsville
site, and the land is zoned for 225 houses. Although the company's Web site
already has model houses for sale there, preservationists say they hope they can
negotiate a land purchase or at least a reduction in the number of houses.

The reenactment, May 7-9, and its sponsorship by the county -- at a cost of
$200,000 -- marks a cultural and political change in Spotsylvania, where
preservationists have roared back in the past couple of years in response to
high-speed development.

Although the Spotsylvania battlefield does not even have a visitors center,
preservationists helped elect a majority of supervisors who are beginning to
focus on historic tourism. Last spring, the county established a tourism
commission charged with promoting history, and the reenactment is its first real
event. County officials also are talking about putting some of the proceeds from
the reenactment into a fund for acquiring land they want to preserve from
development.

A rural county 15 years ago, Spotsylvania has lost most of its working farms.
Rural landowners today have to choose between selling to developers or paying
ever-rising property taxes. A case in point is the site of the reenactment,
Belvedere Plantation, a 1,000-acre working farm that now hosts such events as a
corporate team-building program held in a corn maze and a "Punkin Chunkin,"
which involves catapulting pumpkins out of a cannon.

The reenactment will be held at the plantation because the National Park
Service, which owns the preserved part of the actual battlefield, feared that it
could not accommodate a three-day event expected to attract at least 10,000
people a day.

With Spotsylvania rapidly becoming a bedroom community for Washington, the
reenactment is a way to educate new residents about the region's history, said
Doug Barnes, interim deputy county administrator. It also will be the first
major test of the historic tourism strategy that preservationists used to fight
development.

"If [the reenactment] does well, there will be more things like it. If it
doesn't, my guess is they won't do it again," said Robert Lee Hodge, a longtime
Civil War reenactor and preservationist who is organizing the 140th anniversary
reenactment.

Hodge, who was named after Robert E. Lee and wore a Confederate cap in his
first-grade photo, noted that some preservationists question whether
reenactments ultimately help their cause.

"When you look at reenacting, it's something easily made fun of by South Park
and the Comedy Channel. When you break it down to the lowest common denominator,
you're talking about a subculture of people who dress up in clothes from 140
years ago," he said. "But when you go to a battlefield, unless you have a great
imagination, it's just a field. How do you connect, especially with kids, when
you're up against so much stimulation?"

Economic Downturn Might Be a Catalyst for Smarter Growth

BYLINE: Roger K. Lewis

SECTION: FINANCIAL; Pg. F04

LENGTH: 664 words


The land use and transportation policies of the 20th century are destined to
change dramatically. They enabled sprawl -- the unbridled expansion of American
cities that has engendered enormous unforeseen economic, social, environmental
and aesthetic costs.

Instead, we are turning to a list of R-words: rethinking, redeveloping,
renewing, revitalizing, retrofitting.

Those words have figured repeatedly in recent articles about major proposed
suburban makeovers in Tysons Corner, Rockville Pike and downtown Columbia.
Private and public entities also are developing plans for other sites in the
Virginia and Maryland suburbs, as well as in the District.

Sprawling American suburbs, developed at very low densities, have been zoned and
subdivided into residential enclaves designed primarily for driving convenience.
Widely dispersed employment, commercial and recreational destinations, coupled
with inadequate road systems, have produced severe traffic congestion and
climate-changing carbon emissions while denying suburbanites the choice of
conveniently walking, biking or using transit.

And does anyone find beauty in sprawl?

Sprawl's emblem is the ugly, ubiquitous commercial strip, dominated by surface
parking lots, garish signs and cheaply built, disposable structures.

Land has long been cheaper and more available on the suburban fringe. For
decades, semi-rural counties willingly promoted growth and enacted
sprawl-inducing zoning laws. Lower costs made exurban homes of all styles and
sizes cheaper than comparable homes closer to cities.

At the same time, states and counties continued building roads ever farther out,
aided by federal funding. Inexpensive gasoline and easy credit spurred sales and
use of cars. Easy credit coupled with the federal tax deduction for mortgage
interest also helped home sales. Given the American dream of owning an
affordable single-family house, sprawl was inevitable.

But this dream has become a nightmare for many. The latest housing bubble burst
as borrowers defaulted on subprime mortgages, home prices fell and foreclosures
soared. Not surprisingly, many distressed loans and foreclosed properties are in
sprawling exurbs, especially in high-growth states including Florida, Texas,
Arizona, Nevada, California and, of course, Virginia.

Today's nightmarish economic crisis does teach a lesson. It at last illuminates
the consequences of policies and practices yielding costly sprawl. It shows that
growth by limitless outward expansion is no longer sustainable, no longer an
option.

What's possible and desirable, if not unavoidable in the future, is growth
characterized by the R-words. We must transform portions of our cities and
suburbs that already enjoy favorable locations and serviceable infrastructure,
but are poorly or insufficiently developed. Properties apt to become
economically and functionally obsolete should be revived.

Shifting demographics make such transformations more feasible. Traditional
families -- parents with children -- may continue to opt for the suburban model.
But traditional families represent less than half of all American households.
Millions of households are made up of singles, couples or housemates who neither
want nor need the traditional suburban home. They tend to embrace a more urban
lifestyle, choosing to live in mixed-use environments where they can go shopping
on foot, commute via transit and get along without a car.

Investments in roads, transit and utilities must be aimed at enhancing
infrastructure quality and performance within metropolitan areas, not at the
fringe. Rather than continuing to suburbanize the agrarian landscape, we should
urbanize more of the existing suburbs. This is the essence of "smart growth."

And recession, unemployment and government budget deficits may be just the
pushes needed to finally motivate smart growth behavior by citizens and
policymakers.

Roger K. Lewis is a practicing architect and a professor emeritus of
architecture at the University of Maryland.

Government's housing-rescue plan contains two main programs

SECTION: REAL ESTATE; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 664 words


Q. I have heard a lot about the federal government's plan to help homeowners who
are struggling to meet their payments. What are the details? How can I find out
if I qualify?

A. There are lots of technicalities in the plan that was recently approved by
Congress and signed into law by President Barack Obama, but it basically boils
down to two types of help: a special refinancing program and a more complete
loan-modification plan.

The government estimates that up to 9 million homeowners qualify for one program
or the other.

To be eligible for the special refinancing program, a homeowner must have at
least a 20 percent equity stake in their property and have not missed a payment
in the past 12 months. For those who qualify, the government will back loans for
banks to refinance the property at today's lower rates. The catch is that the
loan must be owned by the Federal National Mortgage Association (commonly called
"Fannie Mae") or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. (Freddie Mac).

Fannie and Freddie buy about half the loans that banks issue, so either agency
might own your loan even if you write your monthly check to the bank that
originally gave you the mortgage or a loan-service company that processes your
payments. Call the bank's customer-service department to find out if your loan
is owned by Fannie or Freddie. If it is, you're probably eligible for the
refinancing package.

The new loan-modification program works differently. It provides government
incentives to banks to lower the interest rates they charge to borrowers to as
little as 2 percent and stretch their loan-repayment schedule to 40 years,
either of which could save homeowners hundreds or even thousands of dollars each
month. The program is not available to those who owe more than $729,750 to their
bank, and most financially troubled borrowers qualify because they owe less.

Again, contact your lender's customer-service department for details about the
new programs. Also go to the government's Web site,
www.MakingHomeAffordable.gov, which includes a tool that can help you determine
if you qualify for either program.

Q. We are both 65 years old, and have started looking for a retirement home in
different rural communities. Many of the properties have two, three or even four
"for sale" signs from different brokerage firms. Where we currently live, homes
are listed by only one company. What gives?

A. It sounds as if the rural communities that you're visiting use "open
listings" rather than the exclusive-right-to-sell agreements that are common in
most urban areas.

City-dwellers who want to sell their home typically sign an exclusive
right-to-sell agreement, which guarantees the real estate agent a commission
even if the seller finds a buyer on their own. But open listings are common in
many rural areas, especially in parts of the nation where there is no Multiple
Listing Service to widely advertise properties that are for sale.

An open listing allows a seller to list with several different agents or
brokerages, and pay only the broker who is able to produce a buyer who can close
the deal. The commission that's owed by the seller under an open listing is
usually about half that owed under an exclusive-right-to-sell agreement, because
the seller is actually paying the broker to represent the buyer only. However,
if the seller finds the buyer on his or her own, no commission is owed at all.

Q. What does the term "NNN" mean?

A. "NNN" is realty shorthand for a triple-net lease, usually involving a
business property. The NNN stands for "net-net-net," which means the tenant not
only pays the monthly rent, but (unlike many other business leases) also must
pay for all of the store or office's share of most other expenses -- from the
project's utilities and insurance, to janitorial services and other costs. So,
in other words, nearly all of the money that the landlord collects is net profit
that goes straight to the bottom line.

                           February 9, 2008 Saturday

Homes dedicated to families

BYLINE: By NATALIE WILLIS Staff writer

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 613 words


SHIPPENSBURG -- The first two homes of seven currently under construction on
Middle Spring Road in Shippensburg were dedicated to families last week.

Interfaith Housing Alliance and the United States Department of Agriculture
Rural Development dedicated the homes to two families -- the Longs and Ruquets,
who are participating in Rural Development's Self Help program and building
their own home with five other families.

Mary Ann Long and Michelle Ruquet have been working on their future homes since
the week of Thanksgiving and said it hasn't been an easy journey. Both agree
that working in the cold weather and balancing their jobs and sweat equity are
the hardest parts in the construction process so far.

Still, the women are having fun throughout the experience and learning about
their future neighbors in North Middlespring Estates.

"It's a hard job but we all have fun," Ruquet said. "We've gotten to know each
other on an intimate level and you learn about people's personalities and work
ethic."

Ruquet will be living at 212 Pike Court with her three children -- Alex, 13,
Anthony, 9 and Destiny, 7. Long will live at 207 Pike Court and is glad her
daughter Aisha, 5, will be able to grow up with her future neighbor's children.

According to George Klaus, director of USDA Rural Development, the future
homeowners will move into the houses by the end of this summer.

Funding is provided through USDA Rural Development's Self Help Housing program.
Rural Development provides an eligible low-income participant with a 502 direct
mortgage, which Klaus explained as a government subsidized mortgage that can
have an interest rate as low as 1 percent.

"This is a great deal for the family," he said. "By building the house, the
family is absorbing the construction cost themselves."

In the Self Help program, the families help construct their future home, working
on the flooring, siding, framing, roofing and other carpentry-type work.
Interfaith hires a contractor for tasks such as digging the foundation and doing
the electrical and plumbing work and Klaus said there is a construction
supervisor monitoring the site and guiding the homeowners at all times.

"There's been about 50,000 people across the country that take advantage of the
Self Help program," Klaus said. "It's a great way to help a low-income, working
family get a home."

Long and Ruquet were ready to put the hard work into their new home after
applying for the program. Ruquet said the only down payment she has needed to
make was $363 for a homeowner insurance policy.

The "sweat equity" saves on labor costs and the homeowners learn about
construction along the way. Klaus said many program participants have actually
learned the home construction trade from the experience.

Interfaith finds an eligible family and puts it through home ownership, mortgage
and financing education. After buying the land and finding an interested party,
Interfaith hires a construction supervisor, buys tools and guides the family
through the construction process.

"They are literally taught how to build a house," Klaus said.

Currently, the organizations are recruiting a new group of families to start
construction of six homes in Newville. Last fall, four families moved into new
homes in Fayetteville, after a year-long construction process.

----------

Natalie Willis can be reached at 262-4747 or nwillis@publicopinionnews.com .

Eligibility

- Applicant must be in the income range of about 50 to 60 percent of the median
income in the county.

- Applicant must be creditworthy and be able to pay back the mortgage loan.

- The families must complete at least 65 percent of the work, working evenings
and weekends to build the home.

the U.S. Department of Agriculture Rural Development.

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

               July 11, 2000 Tuesday SANTA CRUZ/MONTEREY EDITION

HOUSING ACTIVISTS ADD A NEW SERVICE: HEALTH SALINAS-BASED AGENCY ACQUIRES
$200,000 GRANT TO HELP FARMWORKER LEADERS WITH MEDICAL ISSUES

BYLINE: DALE RODEBAUGH, Mercury News

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 562 words


A Monterey County non-profit agency, which for 10 years has taught farmworkers
how to improve their housing conditions, is expanding its horizons to include
rural health issues.

The Salinas-based Center for Community Advocacy has received a $200,000 grant to
teach farmworker leaders to spot health hazards, provide health education and
refer patients to the right medical or environmental authorities.

"This will allow farmworkers to look after the health of their own
neighborhoods," said center director Juan Uranga, a former attorney with
California Rural Legal Assistance.

The program is based on a similar one established in Mexico 27 years ago that is
known by its Spanish acronym FEMAP.

Helenmarie Zachritz, who will coordinate the outreach effort, expects to get
started in January. Zachritz is a former Peace Corps worker in El Salvador and
former executive director of the U.S. fundraising arm for FEMAP. She is now the
fundraiser for CCA.

But first, a half-dozen farmworker leaders from 42 communities organized by the
CCA in the Salinas Valley will travel to Ciudad Juarez in the Mexican state of
Chihuahua. There, they'll see how a program similar to the one envisioned for
the Salinas Valley operates, Zachritz said.

Enriquez Suarez, a pediatrician and executive director of the Mexican health
care program, will visit Salinas next week.

In Ciudad Juarez, Zachritz said, the visitors will spend a week shadowing FEMAP
health care workers. The program, which operates throughout Mexico, provides
health education, family planning and primary health care through hospitals and
clinics.

"The backbone of the FEMAP is a 10,000-member corps of community workers
throughout Mexico," Zachritz said. "They will be the models for our community
leaders, who will train with the Monterey County health department upon
returning from Mexico."

As part of their training, farmworker leaders will learn the benefits of a sound
diet and vaccinations as well as the need for examinations for high blood
pressure, diabetes and cancer. They also will learn to look for health problems
associated with pesticides and raw sewage.

"Many farmworkers don't know the value of health screenings or can't afford
them," Zachritz said.

Salinas Valley farmworkers knew little about housing rights when the Center for
Community Advocacy opened its doors in October 1990. It was a period marked by
high-profile cases involving the squalid living conditions of field workers.

In 1985, California Rural Legal Assistance attorneys filed a lawsuit against a
Salinas strawberry grower, many of whose workers lived in holes in the ground.
Two years later the same agency moved against two growers who allegedly housed
up to 70 workers in a two-living-room, two-bedroom house near Prunedale. In
early 1990, authorities went after a King City labor camp where workers lived
among rat droppings, raw sewage and bare electrical wires.

Today, farmworkers at 42 labor camps and other housing sites know their rights.
They also have learned to negotiate with landlords and know where to find help.

The Rural Communities Assistance Corp. in Sacramento, whose grant is funding the
health training, also is providing a $1.5 million, low-interest loan for a
housing project in northern Monterey County. The Pajaro Valley Housing Corp.
will administer that program.

                December 21, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

And Now the Mobile-Home Co-op, a First in New York

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1062 words

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, L.I.


In New York City, the word "cooperative" evokes images of rambling West Side
apartments overlooking Central Park or comfortable middle-class dwellings along
Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills.

Here in eastern Long Island, several mobile-home owners have added a new
dimension to the idea of cooperative housing: they are creating the state's
first co-op trailer park.

At first glance, it may sound incongruous. In the popular imagination, mobile
homes are for restless, unrooted souls --people like Rockford, the private
investigator played by James Garner in the 1970's television series, who might
at any moment pull up stakes, hitch a cramped, beat-up trailer to a car and
light out for the territory ahead.

In reality, contemporary mobile homesare anything but mobile. They can cost
$60,000 to $70,000 and up, and they often possess an astonishing array of
amenities, from dishwashers and clothes washers and dryers to air-conditioning
and even saunas. They have become the low-cost, permanent housing of choice for
a growing legion, particularly the retired and young couples.

A Home but No Land

Mobile homes still sit on a chassis, to which wheels are attached to transport
them from the factory. But once the trailers arrive on site, they are usually
placed on semi-permanent foundations, like concrete slabs or blocks. It can cost
severalthousand dollars to move the trailers again.

And while the owners hold sole possession of their trailers, they almost always
rent the land underneath. Therein lies a problem for mobile-home owners in many
parts of New York State.

Unlike tenants in apartment buildings, they have few legal protections. A
dispute with the owner of a trailer park -- called "mobile-home communities" in
contemporary nomenclature -- can easily lead to eviction.

In many parts of New York a mobile-home owner may not be able to find space in
another trailer park. Development pressures in places like eastern Suffolk
County, the Hudson Valley and the Albany area also pose a threat to mobile-home
owners. A trailer park just outside Albany was shut down three years ago after
the land was purchased by a supermarket chain, state housing officials say.

It was just such a threat that led to the co-op arrangement at the Parkview
Community here in Riverhead, a small, pleasant trailer park along the Peconic
River, less than a mile southeast of downtown.

Sale of Site Feared

Many of the park's 47 mobile-home owners feared that developers were about to
buy Parkview's seven acres to build townhouses or a small shopping strip. The
property is in a prime location, on the main road between Riverhead and the
Hamptons.

A few owners began organizing their neighbors to save the trailer park.
"Basically what we told people was, 'You have a home, but you may have nowhere
to put it,' " said Kelley McGivney, now president of the co-op board. "There was
no place else for all of us to go, not on Long Island."

The group heard about a new state program, a $9 million fund created in 1988 to
help mobile-home owners buy the land on which they live. They got in touch with
the state, organized, hired a lawyer and a manager and finally bought the land
last spring for $1.6 million. The monthly $300 rent that the owners now pay for
maintenance will help pay back the state loan.

The owners are awaiting formal approval of their application to the State
Attorney General's office to become a legally constituted cooperative.

Saving 'Our Homes'

"From my point of view, there was no alternative," said Ms. McGivney. "The
motivation was to save our homes."

The owners of a second trailer park, in the town of Brockton in Chatauqua County
also recently used a state loan to buy the park. Two other owner groups will
complete their purchases next month, said Richard B. Norton, director of the
state's mobile-home program. Five other applications are being reviewed by the
state.

Housing officials admit that the $9 million is small compared with the need.
There are 2,110 trailer parks in New York State, with more than 76,000
individuals or families living in mobile homes. While they are primarily in
rural or semi-rural areas, there is even one in New York City, the Meadowpark
community along the Kill Van Kull in the Mariner's Harbor section of Staten
Island.

Not all trailer parks are threatened by development or have serious
landlord-tenant problems. The state loans are intended to help those most in
need.

"It isn't going to put the good parks out of business," W. Bruce Stark,
president of the New York Manufactured Housing Association, a mobile-home
industry group, said of the state program. "But it will help us clean up some of
the slums, some of the smaller parks that are in bad condition."

A 'Middle Ground' Option

For consumers, the chief attraction of mobile homes is still financial. "It
represents a middle ground between an apartment and home ownership," said Angelo
J. Aponte, who was appointed State Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal
last month. "For younger couples starting out, for retired people who don't want
to stay in a house that has become too large, mobile homes have a tremendous
attraction."

Mobile homes are usually less expensive to buy than conventional houses. In many
parts of the state, the combination of a mortgage for the mobile home and rent
to the trailer park can cost about as much each month as the rent for a
comparable apartment. But ownership of the mobile home also carries tax
advantages and the possibility that its value will appreciate.

And unlike the cramped trailers of old, contemporary mobile homes come in a wide
variety of models. The largest are actually made from two trailers, pieced
together after they have been trucked from the factory to the trailer park.
These have two or three bedrooms, sometimes several bathrooms, and large living
and dining rooms. Inside and out, they are virtually indistinguishable from a
small suburban tract house.

At Mr. Stark's two large trailer parks in Riverhead, both retirement
communities, many people have added rooms, porches and other personal touches to
their mobile homes. At Foxwood Village, which Mr. Stark built three years ago,
there is even a recreation hall with an indoor pool.

"This is really like a little Levittown," he said as he toured his domain.

                                The Denver Post

                       May 21, 1997 Wednesday 1ST EDITION

Boom times for Brighton Bromley Park project expected to double city's
population

BYLINE: By Steve Raabe, Denver Post Business Writer

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A-01

LENGTH: 679 words

Thirteen years after it was first proposed, a huge new real estate development
in Brighton is finally under way.

Bromley Park ultimately will more than double the population of Brighton, a
once-rural farming community in Adams County that now is grappling with the
benefits and burdens of encroaching growth. In 1995, Brighton's population was
reported at 18,600.

The 1,500-acre residential and commercial project - three times larger than the
Denver Tech Center - has weathered a real estate crash, the failure of Silverado
Banking savings and loan, and a foreclosure by federal regulators until a new
development team took it over in 1993 and brought it to the starting gate.

Developers said Bromley Park's proximity to Denver International Airport and
E-470 and the growing demand for affordable housing should make the project a
significant part of north metro Denver's growth.

Preconstruction work began on the site last week, and developers and Brighton
officials gathered Tuesday for a ceremonial groundbreaking.

The development will include almost 9,000 units of housing, a 300-acre
industrial park and a town center with offices, shops and the new Adams County
courthouse. The development's completion is expected to take 15 to 20 years.

"Initially it may not affect us that much because it's a phased development,"
said Brighton City Manager John Bramble. "But the long-term development
certainly will have a substantial impact on the city."

Bramble said approving the development symbolizes the tightrope that city
officials walk between accommodating growth and preserving the agricultural
heritage of the area.

Bromley Park is a triangular piece of land just north of Barr Lake, bordered by
Interstate 76 on the east, Baseline Road on the north and Tower Road on the
west.

The property was annexed by Brighton in 1985 in anticipation of immediate
development by its owners, a partnership that included high-profile developer
Bill Walters. But the timing corresponded with the fall of metropolitan Denver's
real estate market.

Further complicating development was a loan on the property held by Silverado
Banking savings and loan. Silverado failed in 1988 under the weight of risky
real estate loans, including Bromley Park. Federal regulators seized the thrift
and later foreclosed on the property.

A development team headed by Denver attorney Robert Lembke bought the parcel out
of foreclosure in 1993. It had hoped to start development in 1995 but was unable
to work out an agreement with Brighton until this year.

"Brighton has been very cooperative," Lembke said. "But when you're dealing with
a property of this size and this many issues to be resolved, it takes a lot of
time."

Richmond Homes and Pridemark Homes will start the project's first residential
construction later this summer. Most of the initial homes will be priced from $
100,000 to $ 150,000.

Lembke said the project will incorporate some elements of the "New Urbanism"
movement such as traditional architecture and rows of trees between sidewalks
and streets. But most of the development won't have alleys and thus won't
incorporate the New Urbanism element of detached garages hidden behind homes.

The development will cater to families with jobs at DIA or other businesses in
north metro Denver, Lembke said, as well as commuters who will use the
relatively uncrowded I-76 toward Denver and Baseline Road into Boulder County.

A few parcels of Bromley Park already have been developed, including a
1.2-million-square-foot warehouse and distribution center operated by Kmart, and
the Adams County courthouse now under construction.

Bramble said an additional 300 acres of industrial development in Bromley Park
is important to Brighton because it will provide jobs to local residents.

He said residents and city officials are hoping to enjoy the increased tax base
brought by development without destroying Brighton's character.

"We've got a nice, rural agrarian feel in this community," Bramble said. "It's
part of our heritage and we want to hang on to it."

Rates will come down further: HDFC's Puri

BYLINE: Mayur Shetty & Shubham Mukherjee

SECTION: TIMES BUSINESS

LENGTH: 369 words


As online retailers gear up for mega sales over the next few weeks, HDFC Bank
-which accounts for 40% of e-commerce transactions nationally -is preparing for
a festival bonanza of its own. The bank is preparing to take on the disruptors
in their own space as part of a larger digital strategy. In an interview to TOI,
HDFC Bank MD Aditya Puri said the new digital strategy would change the face of
banking. Excerpts:

Why have banks not yet transmitted the rate cuts made by the RBI entirely?

We were the first to bring down rates and we will continue to be responsive. I
do see interest rates coming down further. However, oneto-one matching cannot
happen. The rate cut and reduction of deposit rates are for incremental deposits
-the old deposits, which account for 90% of deposits, still carry old interest
rates.

How are you responding to the disruption in the banking space due to

technology and entry of payments banks and small banks?

There is a blurring of competition. If you look at the disruptors, none of them
are talking about a new bank.Whether it is Apple Pay or digital wallets, they
are all talking of using the banks' systems, credit cards and merchant. All they
are doing is using the phone to enable payments in one click. So, we used
technology to offer loans in 10 seconds. We are offering car loans where every
element of the purchase -right from choice of make, dealer and colour -can be
made in our branch and the loan delivered to the dealer through a one-time code
texted to the borrower. Our PayZapp application incorporates a marketplace

which gives a discount to the buyer over and above what is offered by e-commerce
companies. When I put them on my site, I am bringing a 32million customer base.
But instead of charging distribution fees, I'm asking them to pass on the
discounts to my customers.

How do you see the pickup of digital in rural? When do you think we will see the
end of moneylenders?

The mobile commerce pickup in semi urban and rural India is 70% more than urban
India as they do not have the same access to physical outlets. In fact, in
Kashmir, our customers use the branch address to receive delivery of
purchases.For the full interview, log on to http://www.timesofindia.com

                              Chicago Daily Herald

                             April 24, 2009 Friday
                                   C1 Edition

Government's housing-rescue plan boils down to two programs

SECTION: REAL ESTATE; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 736 words


Q. I have heard a lot about the federal government's plan to help homeowners who
are struggling to meet their payments. What are the details? How can I find out
if I qualify?

A. There are lots of technicalities in the plan that was recently approved by
Congress and signed into law by President Barack Obama, but it basically boils
down to two types of help: a special refinancing program and a more complete
loan-modification plan.

The government estimates that up to 9 million homeowners qualify for one program
or the other.

To be eligible for the special refinancing program, a homeowner must have at
least a 20 percent equity stake in their property and have not missed a payment
in the past 12 months. For those who qualify, the government will back loans for
banks to refinance the property at today's lower rates. The catch is that the
loan must be owned by the Federal National Mortgage Association (commonly called
"Fannie Mae") or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. (Freddie Mac).

Fannie and Freddie buy about half the loans that banks issue, so either agency
might own your loan even if you write your monthly check to the bank that
originally gave you the mortgage or a loan-service company that processes your
payments. Call the bank's customer-service department to find out if your loan
is owned by Fannie or Freddie. If it is, you're probably eligible for the
refinancing package.

The new loan-modification program works differently. It provides government
incentives to banks to lower the interest rates they charge to borrowers to as
little as 2 percent and stretch their loan-repayment schedule to 40 years,
either of which could save homeowners hundreds or even thousands of dollars each
month. The program is not available to those who owe more than $729,750 to their
bank, and most financially troubled borrowers qualify because they owe less.

Again, contact your lender's customer-service department for details about the
new programs. Also go to the government's Web site,
www.MakingHomeAffordable.gov, which includes a tool that can help you determine
if you qualify for either program.

Q. We are both 65 years old, and have started looking for a retirement home in
different rural communities. Many of the properties have two, three or even four
"for sale" signs from different brokerage firms. Where we currently live, homes
are listed by only one company. What gives?

A. It sounds as if the rural communities that you're visiting use "open
listings" rather than the exclusive-right-to-sell agreements that are common in
most urban areas.

City-dwellers who want to sell their home typically sign an exclusive
right-to-sell agreement, which guarantees the real estate agent a commission
even if the seller finds a buyer on their own. But open listings are common in
many rural areas, especially in parts of the nation where there is no Multiple
Listing Service to widely advertise properties that are for sale.

An open listing allows a seller to list with several different agents or
brokerages, and pay only the broker who is able to produce a buyer who can close
the deal. The commission that's owed by the seller under an open listing is
usually about half that owed under an exclusive-right-to-sell agreement, because
the seller is actually paying the broker to represent the buyer only. However,
if the seller finds the buyer on his or her own, no commission is owed at all.

Q. What does the term "NNN" mean?

A. "NNN" is realty shorthand for a triple-net lease, usually involving a
business property. The NNN stands for "net-net-net," which means the tenant not
only pays the monthly rent, but (unlike many other business leases) also must
pay for all of the store or office's share of most other expenses -- from the
project's utilities and insurance, to janitorial services and other costs. So,
in other words, nearly all of the money that the landlord collects is net profit
that goes straight to the bottom line.

Q. I was interested in the recent column you wrote about living trusts. My
question is, if I create the type of living trust that you suggest, who would I
name as the trustee?

A. The trustee is the person who will manage and control the trust's home and
other property while you are alive. Assuming that you want to control it as long
as you're capable, you should name yourself as the trustee or both you and your
spouse as co-trustees.

                             National Mortgage News

                               December 15, 1997

Fannie Modifies Reservation Pilot

BYLINE: BY MARK FOGARTY

SECTION: AFFORDABLE HOUSING; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 629 words

DATELINE: Dallas


Fannie Mae has modified its pilot program for conventional reservation mortgages
to make it easier for Navajo applicants to qualify, and hopes to close loans
under the program during the first six months of next year.

Mark Vanderlinden, housing impact specialist for the Fannie Mae office here,
said the program will be modified along Community Home Buyer Program standards
so that a borrower will be able to put up 3% down and have 2% come from a gift,
or loan from a nonprofit.

A reservation nonprofit, the Navajo Partnership for Housing, has been educating
potential homebuyers on the reservation and has downpayment assistance available
for them.  The original terms of the pilot, which has seen no loans close after
18 months of existence, were for a straight 5% downpayment from the borrower.

A second change in the works is the expansion of loan products to include
manufactured housing on a permanent foundation.  Since much of the existing
housing stock on the Navajo Nation consists of trailers, this market may
represent "millions and millions" of dollars in potential loans, Mr.
Vanderlinden said.

Navajos will be able to achieve "significant reductions in interest rates" by
refinancing into mortgage loans on existing stock, Mr. Vanderlinden said.
Interim financing to make trailers permanent can also be refinanced.  A tribal
legal question needs to be cleared up first, but the official is "optimistic"
manufactured homes, new and existing, can be added to the pilot.

The Navajo pilot lenders are Norwest Mortgage, Zions Mortgage of Utah, and
Suburban Mortgage of Albuquerque, N.M., which is working through a
correspondent, First National Bank of Farmington, N.M.  The Navajo is the
nation's largest reservation, sprawling across Arizona, New Mexico and Utah.

The pilot is an historic one since no one has ever closed a private mortgage on
tribal trust land.  In recent years, a Housing and Urban Development section 184
loan has been made on trust land, but that is government-guaranteed.

The HUD 184 has been a success on reservations around the country since it has a
construction facility built into it, and many reservations lack existing housing
stock and must build up from ground zero.

To date, a handful of HUD 184s have been made on the Navajo.  Fannie Mae will
buy those loans as well as any made through the conventional pilot.  According
to Mr. Vanderlinden, Norwest may convert a pending 184 to a conventional
mortgage, if it would benefit the homeowner involved.  The modifications were
hammered out with input from the Navajo Partnership for Housing, which has
raised more than $ 1.25 million to date and has graduated 29 households from its
16-hour program, with 56 more in a pipeline.

Four of those have gotten loan approvals from lenders in the NPH program
(Norwest, Zions, First National, Banc One, and Gallup (NM) Federal Savings), but
no loans have closed, according to Steve Barbier, field service officer at
Neighborhood Reinvestment Corp., Denver.  Five or six more Navajo applicants are
very close to loan approvals, he said.

Mr. Barbier's group has given funding and technical support to the NPH, and he
maintains a close link to the group.

Mr. Vanderlinden, who is on the board of NPH, described the bottleneck to loan
closings as things like home site lease and archaeological review at the tribal
level.

Mr. Barbier described the various sources of NPH's funding.  They include $
150,000 from the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco, $ 225,000 from the
Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas, $ 189,500 from the New Mexico HOME program, $
150,000 from the HUD Self Help Program, $ 50,000 from the NRC, and $ 25,000 from
the Housing Assistance Council to promote the programs of the Rural Housing
Service.

                          September 11, 2013 Wednesday

Developer confidence spurs sales growth

BYLINE: Yvonne Liu yvonne.liu@scmp.com

SECTION: PROPERTY; Pg. 02

LENGTH: 309 words


Aggressive bidding for land by developers buoyed confidence in the mainland
property market and led to strong property sales in major cities in the first
week of September.

Data from the China Index Academy showed more than 60 per cent of the 41 major
cities on the mainland posted growth in weekly property sales for the period
September 2 to 8. The surge was led by Wenzhou, where sales were up by 150 per
cent on the same week last year.

Dickson Wong Hung, chief executive at Centaline (China) for northern and
southwestern China, said September and October were traditionally peak sales
months.

"A number of sites sold at high prices, [which] also encouraged people to buy
flats. Many flat owners in Beijing's urban areas raised their asking prices for
their flats after the land sales."

Alan Chiang Sheung-lai, head of residential at DTZ Greater China, said
developers had bid aggressively. Sun Hung Kai Properties, he noted, bought a
site in Shanghai for 21.77 billion yuan (HK$27.37 billion) last week.

"Including their potential construction costs, the company will have to spend
about 30 billion yuan on this project. That's a large amount, and the confidence
it showed encourages people to buy flats."

Buyers were also tempted back into the market because mortgage rates were still
at a low level, Chiang added.

However, it remained to be seen if the strong property sales would be maintained
with fewer new projects available for release in the next few months.

Ten new projects with more than 1,500 flats were released for sale in Shanghai
at the weekend, according to property website Sina House, and nearly 80 per cent
of the flats were sold.

Data from the Beijing Municipal Commission of Housing and Urban-Rural
Development showed 2,286 secondhand flats changed hands in the first week of
September, up 18 per cent on the same period last month.

                           Lowell Sun (Massachusetts)

                              June 25, 2012 Monday

Voters weigh in on land purchase

BYLINE: By Hiroko Sato, hsato@lowellsun.com

SECTION: TODAY'S HEADLINES

LENGTH: 579 words


DUNSTABLE -- Kenneth Leva calls the intersection of Route 113 and Lowell Street
the gateway to Dunstable.

Marked by the historic McGovern Farm and its pasture with cattle roaming, the
street sets the tone for the town that has taken pride in its rural characters.
And, some residents have long believed the town should acquire the forested
private land across from the farm, if it ever becomes available, to preserve it
for good, said Leva, the chairman of the Board of Selectmen.

The opportunity to do just that has arrived. The family who has owned the land
is ready to sell it. And it could become a town property at half the price it
used to be, thanks to the depressed real-estate market, Leva said.

Now, the town only needs residents' consent. And, they will have the chance to
approve it or reject it at Special Town Meeting scheduled for Tuesday.

Selectmen are proposing to buy 12 acres that expand between Route 113 and Lowell
Street for $649,000. The actual price of the land is $699,999. But some
donations, including $25,000 from the Dunstable Rural Land Trust and the use of
$15,000 from the Town Forest account called the Conservation Timber Fund, are
expected to reduce the cost to $649,000, Leva said.

Selectmen intend to borrow about $200,000 through a state program at an interest
rate of 0.9 percent, while paying for the rest of it with the money in the
town's Community Preservation Act fund. The fund comes from the 3 percent tax
surcharge that all local homeowners pay toward the preservation of open space
and historic buildings, a promotion of affordable housing and recreational
amenities. Dunstable collects about $100,000 annually in the tax surcharge, and
the state has also matched the surcharge at the rate exceeding 60 percent each
year, according to Community Preservation Committee member Susan Psaledakis.

The town CPA account currently has $303,000 in general funds, $62,000 separately
set aside for open-space preservation, $114,000 for historic preservation and
$155,000 for affordable housing and recreation.

Owned by the Best family, the land is comprised of five parcels. Selectmen plan
to preserve the two parcels closer to the intersection of Route 113 and Lowell
Street as open space and "land bank" the other three lots for a potential future
town project that could range from housing to recreational use, Leva said.

The proposal to acquire the land was first presented to the Community
Preservation Committee by Conservation Commissioner Alan Chaney and Bob Kennedy
of the Dunstable Rural Land Trust. The Community Preservation Committee then
recommended the acquisition to the Board of Selectmen, who decided to let
residents make a decision on it at Special Town Meeting.

Chaney said the town's Master Plan call for the town's efforts to preserve the
scenic landscapes along Route 113, and that is based on several community
surveys that have been conducted since 1974.

"The idea (of preserving the land) was something that came from the public over
many years," Chaney said.

Psaledakis also said she hopes the town will be able to preserve the land in the
scenic section of the town.

Leva said selectmen consulted with the town accountant and some departments and
did "homework" to make sure the acquisition that would require a 10-year-loan
would make sense.

The board then concluded that "it was advantageous to move forward to borrow the
money," Leva said.

Special Town Meeting will start at 7 p.m. at the Swallow Union Elementary
School.

                             March 10, 2006 Friday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Taxi fares well with funding

BYLINE: Margaret Jackson Denver Post Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C-02

LENGTH: 249 words


Developer Mickey Zeppelin's $16 million urban-renewal project north of downtown
got a funding boost Thursday.

Taxi, located on 15 acres adjacent to the South Platte River at 3455 Ringsby
Court, received a $2 million federal grant and a $6 million federal loan.

The former Yellow Cab headquarters and dispatch center - which was once a
landfill - is being transformed into a new work-live community. Zeppelin already
has redeveloped the Yellow Cab building into office space. The grant and loan
will be used for a new 100,000-square-foot building that will include housing,
offices and retail space.

"We are creating jobs and taking an area that was, at best, an industrial use
and remediating the environmental condition," Zeppelin said.

Zeppelin's project was one of 11 nationally to receive the funding through the
Brownfields Economic Development Initiative of the U.S. Department of Housing
and Urban Development. It beat out Cherokee Denver LLC's redevelopment of the
former Gates Rubber plant. Cherokee received grants for two other projects
elsewhere.

"This is nice because it's a small project. It's bringing jobs to an area of the
city that's economically had some hard times," said Stacey Eriksen, an
Environmental Protection Agency employee who is on loan to the city of Denver.
"I think it's really going to have a domino effect. The area is poised to have a
lot of really interesting things happen."

Staff writer Margaret Jackson can be reached at 303-820-1473 or mjackson@
denverpost.com.

                                  Guardian.com

                                  May 4, 2005

Is Labour the party of property?

LENGTH: 882 words



HIGHLIGHT: Tony Blair yesterday said that a new Labour government would help a
million more people onto the property ladder. We asked industry experts what
they thought of Labour's plans and what they would like to see the next
government do to increase home ownership.


Tony Blair yesterday said that a new Labour government would help a million more
people onto the property ladder through shared ownership schemes and plans to
build homes on public land. He also unveiled a "mortgage wheel" showing how
mortgage rates had dropped since he came to power.

But has Labour really served the country well on property so far? And, if
elected, would the party's plans help first-time buyers? We asked industry
experts what they thought of Labour's plans and what they would like to see the
next government do to increase home ownership.

Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors

Rics welcomed Labour's announcements on house building, but warned that this had
to happen in areas where homes were most needed, with a well planned
infrastructure.

The organisation is also calling on the next government to address the issue of
homes for key workers such as teachers and nurses, who are currently priced out
of their communities.

"At the moment, we've got Metropolitan police officers travelling in from
Oxford, and as higher house prices have rippled out to market towns and rural
areas, key workers are wondering if they can afford to live in the area in which
they work," said William Tew, Rics' head of property policy.

"Labour plans to clear contaminated land will help to free up sites," he said.
"But they must be where housing is needed. A new Thames Gateway development, for
instance, isn't going to help nurses in Kingston; building homes in Kingston
will."

Mr Tew said that Labour's announcements yesterday made the affordable homes
target more realistic. "We broadly welcome the proposals. The target for £60,000
homes now excludes a number of issues, such as the cost of the land on which
properties will be built, and the infrastructure, which, as I understand it,
will be borne by the public purse."

But he said that any new developments would have to take into account the wider
infrastructure of the areas around them, in terms of hospitals, schools, and
public transport, as well as flood planning management.

The National Association of Estate Agents

Less than one in five estate agents believe that the present government has
helped the housing market over recent years, and 45% believe that Labour
leadership has actually hindered the market, according to the NAEA's research.

Some 78% of estate agents believe that further increases to the stamp duty
threshold (increased to £120,000 in March's budget) would improve the housing
market. There has been more activity from first-time buyers since the stamp duty
threshold rose to £120,000, the NAEA says, and it is widely believed among
agents that further increases are needed across all the thresholds to bring the
tax fully up to date.

Compulsory home sellers' packs - set to be introduced in 2007 - are unpopular
with agents, and both the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats have pledged to
scrap them. The body's research shows that two-thirds of estate agents say that
licensing of the profession is a priority, and the NAEA is campaigning for an
effective regulatory scheme with powers to stop rogue agents from continuing to
practise.

"These results reflect the feelings of some 10,000 estate agents across the
country. The political parties should not ignore the strength of feeling on some
of these aspects, and the extent of change they could bring about to the
thousands of people buying or selling a home each year," said Peter Bolton King,
chief executive of the NAEA.

"Whatever the outcome of the election, the NAEA will continue to lobby the
government on licensing, home information packs, stamp duty and the other issues
which have the potential to seriously affect the housing market and the British
public."

FirstRungNow.com

The property website welcomed Labour's plans to increase shared equity schemes,
and claimed that many visitors to the site were planning to vote Labour, in
spite of Tory plans to abolish the lowest band of stamp duty.

"I've been hearing from aspiring first time buyers over the last few days and
they are definitely giving the Labour party their backing," said Helen Adams,
director of the site's first-time buyer advice centre.

"They believe that the Labour party will do more for them and that Labour is
more likely to maintain a more stable economy and will deliver more in terms of
shared ownership schemes."

Ms Adams said that shared ownership schemes were gaining in popularity, with 79%
of visitors to the site asking about the schemes. "Co-ownership, whether it be
buying with a friend or a housing association has become the way to buy a first
home.

"We get enquiries about shared-ownership from key workers who have access to
government schemes, but we also get lots of enquires from young executives who
don't qualify for key worker schemes."

She said that while plans to allocate more public land for building were
positive, it was important that the land chosen was safe land, and not, for
example, prone to flooding. Ms Adams also said that FirstRungNow.com would like
to see stamp duty abolished for first-time buyers and measures taken to keep
typical first homes on the market for private buyers.

"We would like to see a 'supertax' on landlords who buy one and two-bedroom
properties, as we think they should be discouraged in favour of first-time
buyers," she said.

                        Las Cruces Sun-News (New Mexico)

                             October 5, 2015 Monday
                                   1 Edition

MFA adds to assistance program

BYLINE: By, Gary Sandler

SECTION: Z; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 643 words


"Next HOME allows move-up buyers with annual incomes up to $75,000 to buy a home
with a sales price of up to $350,000..."

Teri Baca

MFA Homeownership Representative

LAS CRUCES - Thanks to some very creative thinking on the part of the New Mexico
Mortgage Finance Authority's (MFA's) leadership team, MFA rolled out on October
1st a new program that expands down payment and closing cost assistance to
include buyers who already own a home.

The program, called Next HOME, is designed to assist current home owners who
want to move up, as well as first-time buyers who don't meet the 3-year
requirement . According to Teri Baca, MFA Homeownership Representative, "Next
HOME allows move-up buyers with annual incomes up to $75,000 to buy a home with
a sales price of up to $350,000 anywhere in New Mexico". Baca goes on to say,
"If a buyer would rather retain the proceeds from the sale of their existing
home rather than using them towards their next purchase, they may, since the
required minimum investment from the borrower's own funds is only $500".

Current home owners who desire to convert their existing homes into rental
properties, rather than sell them, are also eligible to purchase a replacement
property under the Next HOME program. Next HOME is a combination first-mortgage
loan and down payment assistance grant. The grant, equal to 3 percenet of the
loan amount, does not have to be repaid and may be applied to down payment,
closing costs, and reserves for taxes and insurance.

Traditional first-time buyers, defined as buyers who have never before owned a
home or not lived in a home (such as a rental property) that they owned for at
least three years prior to purchase, can receive assistance through MFA's First
HOME program. The program provides a 30-year, fixed rate mortgage in the 4
percent range.

VA and USDA Rural Housing loans both require zero down payment; whereas FHA
requires 3.5 percent down and HFA Preferred (conventional) requires 3 percent
down. MFA's goal is to keep interest rates as competitive as possible in order
to enhance affordability. For buyers who need help with down payment and closing
costs, First HOME may be paired with First DOWN.

First DOWN is a 2nd mortgage loan of up to $8,000 that provides an affordable
way for first-time buyers to cover their down payment and closing cost
requirements. First DOWN offers a 30-year repayment term and a fixed annual
interest rate of 6 percent. The First HOME and First DOWN programs may be used
to finance single-family residences which include detached site-built homes,
townhomes, approved condominiums and permanently attached doublewide
manufactured homes.

Buyers must invest at least $500 of their own funds, none of which can be
derived from a gift or loan. MFA requires a minimum credit score of 620, however
in some cases, a borrower with no credit score may still be able to qualify by
using alternative credit. Household income limits for first-timers purchasing in
the Las Cruces Metropolitan Statistical Area (MSA) are currently set at $58,080
for 1-2 persons and $67,760 for three or more. The total sales price of the home
may not exceed $258,691.

As with all MFA programs, down payment assistance loans and grants can only be
used for the purchase of home which will be owner-occupied. Funds cannot be used
to refinance an existing loan or purchase a rental property. These terrific new
benefits are as real as they come and only accessible through MFA approved
lenders, a list of which is available at
http://www.housingnm.org/homebuyers/find-a-participating-lender.

See you at closing!

Gary Sandler is the owner of Gary Sandler Inc., Realtors in Las Cruces and can
be reached at  Gary@GarySandler.com

"Next HOME allows move-up buyers with annual incomes up to $75,000 to buy a home
with a sales price of up to $350,000..."

Teri Baca

MFA Homeownership Representative

                                US Official News

                           September 23, 2013 Monday

Notice of Intent To Review Online Homeownership Education Courses for Nationwide
Use in the Single Family Housing Section 502 Direct Loan Program

LENGTH: 965  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Federal Register has issued the following notice:


Action

Notice.
Summary

Effective on May 7, 2007, first-time homebuyers financed under the direct loan
program must successfully complete an approved homeownership education course
prior to loan closing. 7 CFR Part 3550.11 outlines the order of preference given
to courses. First preference is given to classroom, one-on-one counseling, or
interactive video conference. These formats are generally extensive and require
a significant time and participation commitment from the Agency applicants.
Second preference is given to interactive home-study or interactive telephone
counseling of at least four hours duration. These formats may only be used if
the formats under the first preference are not reasonably available. Third
preference, which can only be used if all other formats are not reasonably
available, is given to online counseling. It also outlines the requirements an
education provider and their course must meet in order to be approved for use by
Agency applicants.

While approval is generally made by the Agency at the state level, there is
currently one nationally approved online education provider. To expand the
Agency applicants' access to and options of approved education providers, the
Agency will consider approving other online education providers on a national
level. Approval will be subject to meeting course criteria, a recommendation by
the Agency-selected panel of housing partners, and signoff by the Administrator.
Approval will be given as a third preference format unless the education
provider is able to demonstrate and document how their online course along with
a required supplemented service provides the same level of training and
individualized attention as a first or second preference.

A notice of education providers approved through this process will be issued via
a memorandum to the Rural Development (RD) state offices. The memorandum will
list the format preference assigned to each provider. A copy of the memorandum
will be simultaneously emailed to all education providers who applied through
this notice.

Approvals are not subject to expiration. However, an approval may be revoked for
justifiable cause.

DATES:
    FOR FURTHER INFORMATION CONTACT:
    Non-Discrimination Statement
    SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION:

0783, Washington, DC 20250-0783.

                                The Denver Post

                        June 10, 1994 Friday 2D EDITION

Denver vies for mega-bucks Empowerment zone would get tax incentives, federal
grants

BYLINE: Renate Robey, Denver Post Staff Writer

SECTION: DENVER & THE WEST; Pg. B-02

LENGTH: 624 words


DENVER - The city of Denver is in a fierce national competition to get up to $
100 million in tax incentives and grants for social programs and economic
development over the next decade.

Denver is trying become the site of an empowerment zone under a program created
by President Clinton. It would mean the city would get federal tax incentives,
employment credits and "one-stop shopping" for other federal loans and grants.
If designated, the city would get priority for receiving up to $ 100 million
that could be used for programs like drug and alcohol abuse prevention and
treatment, employment training, improvement of public facilities and economic
development.

Nine empowerment zones will be chosen nationally, six in urban areas and three
in rural areas. Hundreds of cities are applying.

"The competition is really fierce," said Tony Hernandez, regional director of
the Department of Housing and Urban Development. He estimated Denver has about a
50-50 chance.

However, Hernandez said Denver has a better chance at being named an enterprise
zone, which could bring up to $ 3 million over 10 years. HUD will select 65
urban enterprise zones, and the Department of Agriculture will pick 30 rural
enterprise zones.

"I think it's a slim chance, but I'm optimistic," said Councilwoman Ramona
Martinez. "I think there's a feeling that Denver isn't quite as critical as some
other cities."

City officials, with the help of neighborhood groups, private nonprofit
organizations and others, are spending about $ 150,000 of grant money and
in-kind donations to complete the application, which is due June 30.

Groups in the San Luis Valley and Lower Arkansas Valley may apply for rural
empowerment zone status, which could bring up to $ 40 million over 10 years.

Some preliminary proposals for the Denver zone include expanding health clinics
at high schools, increasing Head Start programs, installing alley lighting in
high-crime neighborhoods, establishing more job training programs, and helping a
community development corporation in the Globeville area.

To qualify for an empowerment zone, an area can't be larger than 20 square
miles, or have more than 50,000 people. Such areas are supposed to have
"pervasive poverty, unemployment and general distress." Denver's application
targets an area of 13.8 square miles, has 49,900 people, and includes some of
the poorest areas of northeast and northwest Denver.

Denver's application also includes Lowry Air Force Base in the proposed zone,
which is allowed as an exception because the area has a negligible population
but is ripe for economic development. The base closes this fall.

Some neighbors of Lowry have questioned including the base in the zone. "In my
opinion, the best way to redevelop Lowry Air Force Base is not to declare the
area blighted and link it up with other areas that are blighted," said Tom
Hames, president of the Historic Montclair Community Association.

Local officials want to use the money for streets and utility improvements that
will make it easier to redevelop the base, at a cost of $ 60 million. They do
not intend to use any federal money for social programs. But Hames said, "I'm
worried that the federal money will come with strings attached."

Others have applauded the program. "Lord knows we can use the money," said
Claudia Abernethy, president of the Clayton Neighborhood Organization.

Her neighborhood is excited about the program because it would give local groups
a say on how the money will be spent, Abernethy said. "We intend to take our
neighborhood back. We don't want social programs. We don't want charity. We want
recreation programs, how-to programs, job training, and we want economic
development above all else."

                         Brattleboro Reformer (Vermont)

                              May 29, 2009 Friday

Tax credits could help Brattleboro

BYLINE: By BOB AUDETTE, Reformer Staff

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 671 words


BRATTLEBORO -- Tax credits are coming to economically distressed communities in
Vermont to spur economic growth and increase their stocks of affordable housing.

As part of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, $30 million in tax
credits will soon be available for economic development projects in Vermont that
primarily benefit low-income Americans.

"Projects need to be located in areas with economic distress as defined by the
United States Census and verified by the Department of the Treasury," stated
David Carle, spokesman for Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., in an e-mail to the
Reformer.

Economically distressed communities can be found in Windham and Bennington
counties, as well as Grand Isle, Franklin, Orleans, Essex, Caledonia, Chittenden
and Rutland counties.

An economically distressed neighborhood is defined as an area where there is a
poverty rate of at least 20 percent or where the median family income is below
80 percent of the area median family income.

According to Housing Vermont, Brattleboro is the only Windham County town with
an economically distressed neighborhood, which is bounded by its southern town
border, Guilford Street on the west, Western Avenue on the north and the
Connecticut River on the east. Much of downtown is not included in the
economically distressed area.

The $30 million in tax credits will flow through Rural Ventures Vermont, a
partnership of Housing Vermont, the Vermont Economic Development Authority, the
Vermont Housing Finance Agency and the Vermont Community Loan Fund, which will
determine whether applicants are eligible for funds, said Nancy Owens, president
of Housing Vermont.

"The New Market Tax Credit program will give us tremendous new resources to help
communities meet their economic development and related affordable housing
needs," stated Owens, in a press release announcing the funds. "Private equity
raised by the program will help close the affordability gap on critical local
projects."

The New Market Tax Credit Program, created in 2000, offers incentives to private
investors by offering them 39 percent of their investments back as a federal tax
credit, according to a press release from Vermont's federal delegation
announcing the release of the funds.

"As a result, the developer can pay investors below-market interest rates,
resulting in the equivalent of a federal grant to help buy down the developer's
borrowing costs," stated the press release.

Even though the tax credits can be used for mixed-use projects, they can only be
applied to the commercial side of the development and not the housing aspect.

Vermont Rural Ventures had identified projects in its 2008 application as
examples of projects it will complete, but that application was turned down due
to lack of funding.

The stimulus package included $3 billion to meet the needs of unfunded 2008 tax
credit applications and an anticipated high number of 2009 applications.

Leahy worked to ensure that the new ARRA funding would allow funding of the 2008
Vermont application.

"These tax credits will leverage private investment dollars that are sorely
needed by several Vermont communities," stated Leahy in the press release. "The
program will take root immediately, putting Vermonters to work at construction
sites, creating housing for vulnerable Vermonters and laying the groundwork for
long-term economic growth."

Vermont Rural Ventures expects that the tax credits will help pay for six to 12
housing and economic development projects statewide.

Locally, Windham Housing Trust has not been involved in the New Market Tax
Credit program in the past, said Connie Snow, executive director, but it will
research whether any of its ongoing or future projects qualify.

"The tax credits could be used for mixed-use housing projects if they have some
sort of commercial component to them," said Connie Snow, executive director of
the Windham Housing Trust, formerly known as the Brattleboro Area Community Land
Trust.

Bob Audette can be reached at raudette@reformer.com, or 802-254-2311, ext. 273.

                              DAILY MAIL (London)

                            March 28, 2013 Thursday

HOMES THREAT TO GREEN FIELDS AS URBAN SITES ARE NEGLECTED'

BYLINE: BY STEVE DOUGHTY SOCIAL AFFAIRS CORRESPONDENT

LENGTH: 481 words


DEVELOPERS are building homes on green fields rather than on derelict sites in
towns and cities because of new Government planning rules, a report said
yesterday.

It said that the Whitehall push for a construction boom is overriding concerns
that brownfield' sites should be used first.

The report from the National Trust and a local government think-tank said
developers are successfully arguing that they can only build on green fields by
claiming that brownfield projects would lose money.

The claim by the charity and the Local Government Information Unit, a body
largely funded by local councils, adds to the pressure on ministers over the new
planning rules, brought in a year ago amid a wave of criticism.

Opponents say the rules will lead to building over large areas of countryside
against the wishes of those living in the suburban and rural areas.

Ministers are anxious to provide more and cheaper homes for a fast-rising
population have told councils to produce local plans which include room for
large-scale housing projects.

Their rules also say planning decisions should be biased in favour of
sustainable' development, a rule which conservationists say simply means the
planning system will be skewed in favour of builders.

Developers claim the new system led to a 45 per cent increase in the number of
projects given the go-ahead last autumn. Chancellor George Osborne added to the
new homes push in the Budget by offering interest free state loans for five
years to those who buy new houses or flats. The loans will be worth 20 per cent
of the value of homes costing up to £600,000.

Yesterday's report said the National Planning Policy Framework is tipping the
scales against brownfield development because it requires councils to produce
local plans including housebuilding that can be completed inside five years.

This means that 400,000 sites across the country which already have planning
permission for homes are unlikely to be included in development plans because
builders say it will be too expensive to start construction inside five years.

Brownfield sites are more expensive than virgin land because they need to be
cleared and cleaned.

The fact that greenfield sites are more profitable to develop than brownfield
sites, and therefore more viable, is forcing councils to propose development of
these sites,' the report said.

Peter Nixon of the National Trust, said: We are very concerned that the
principal of "brownfield first" is being eroded as the new plans emerge.

Our research suggests a growing number of greenfield sites are being prioritised
for development with developers arguing that brownfield sites - many of which
already have planning permission for construction - are now unprofitable to
build on.'

Communities Secretary Eric Pickles has insisted we are making the most of every
single square inch of brownfield land.'

s.doughty@dailymail.co.uk

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,

                        The Augusta Chronicle (Georgia)

                            November 9, 2004 Tuesday
                                  ALL EDITION

CITY OFFERS LOAN AID TO BUYER

BYLINE: By Sylvia Cooper Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B06

LENGTH: 396 words


A development group planning to buy and renovate the Partridge Inn on Walton Way
with a federal loan through the city's housing and economic development
department received an initial nod from Augusta Commission members Monday.

The city's administrative service committee voted to allow The West Paces Hotel
Group L.L.C. to apply through the city for a guaranteed federal loan for $2.5
million. The loan would be paid back at 2 percent interest over 20 years. The
new owners of the hotel expect to invest $2.23 million in equity in the $13.5
million project.

The commitment to pursue the loan, guaranteed under the city's federal grant
program, will allow the developers to firm up their decision to buy the
property.

The last time Augusta guaranteed such a loan was more than a decade ago with
about 50 Olde Town properties. The consolidated government was forced to pay the
debt service on the loan after it went into default, until the property was sold
to a corporation specializing in low-income properties in 1997.

City officials hope to avoid similar problems with the West Paces loan by making
sure a debt service reserve is in place in case of default, housing department
Director Warren Smith said.

The project would create 53 new permanent jobs and improvements in the
112-year-old Partridge Inn, including larger guest rooms and a potential
conference center. It also would add $140,000 in hotel-motel taxes to the city
each year, project developer Earl Patton said.

After reviewing the proposal, Mr. Smith and his staff concluded that the
developer "has assembled a top-notch project team" in the West Paces Group,
which includes former executives of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Co.

The Earl Patton Co. has developed and owned hotels such as the Marriott
Northwest in Atlanta, the Marriott at Sawgrass and the Green Villas in Ponte
Vedra, Fla.

Renovation of the Partridge Inn, which is listed on the Historic Register and is
a Historic Hotel of America, will preserve and enhance the historic architecture
of the exterior. Plans include decreasing the number of rooms from 156 to 132.

The Partridge Inn will be operated and managed by the West Paces Group.

The department expects to apply for the loan with the U.S. Department of Housing
and Urban Development, which has final say on it, Mr. Smith said.

Reach Sylvia Cooper at (706) 823-3228

or sylvia.cooper@augustachronicle.com.
