                       The Day (New London, Connecticut)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             May 29, 2010 Saturday

Mohegan Tribe's government center plan lands stimulus loans: $54 million in
backing expected to foster 1,279 jobs locally

BYLINE: Lee Howard, The Day, New London, Conn.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 607 words


May 29--Nearly 1,300 local jobs are expected to be created thanks to $54 million
in federal stimulus loans the Mohegan Indians will receive to fund the stalled
construction of a new tribal government center.

The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act funding -- targeting rural areas and
amounting to $167.8 million nationwide -- was announced Thursday by the U.S.
Department of Agriculture. The Mohegan Tribe's loans amounted to nearly a third
of all stimulus money made available nationwide in its latest announcement.

"The tribe is building a community center; an educational center; a health
administration center; an administration building, and a library," the agency
said in a press release. "Once completed, the new center will provide essential
government services and create an estimated 1,279 jobs for this rural
community."

It was unclear how many of the jobs will be permanent and how many are
temporary. The Mohegan Tribe did not respond to requests for more details.

The tribe broke ground on the government center in April 2007, according to
information on its website, but put the $80 million project on hold in January
2009 when the economy soured. The partially completed center, which originally
was to have been finished by December 2009, is located on Crow Hill Road in
Uncasville, near the site of the tribe's current temporary headquarters.

"The new four-story structure will house the various departments of the Tribal
Government and also contain a community center which will include a recreation
and practice center for the Connecticut Sun (WNBA basketball team)," according
to the Mohegans' website.

The government building -- expected to house the Tribal Gaming Commission along
with offices for police, fire, education and housing personnel -- was put on
hold at the same time the tribe stopped a major expansion of its Mohegan Sun
casino. The casino also rolled back salary increases and offered voluntary
buyouts to employees, while the tribal government cut positions.

Both casino and tribal employees had 401(k) retirement fund matches and salary
increases suspended at the same time.

A listing of the federal funding for the project shows four separate loans
amounting to nearly $32 million that will be used to construct a "Tribal
Educational Center." A fifth loan, at more than $22 million, would be used for
the "Tribal Community Center."

It's unclear which of the loans, if any, would be used for the health center,
administration building or library. The USDA did not return calls seeking more
information.

"These Recovery Act projects not only provide needed infrastructure in rural
communities, they contribute to the Obama administration's continued efforts to
turn the economy around and create quality jobs," USDA Secretary Tom Vilsack
said in a statement.

The $167.8 million in Recovery Act projects announced this week are funded
through the USDA Rural Development Community Facilities Program. They will be
matched with $60 million from unspecified "other sources."

The funds for rural communities are made available to "public bodies, nonprofit
organizations and federally recognized Indian tribes," according to the USDA.
The latest round of funding will bring 145 loans to 37 states.

                              DAILY MAIL (London)

                                August 31, 2001

Private buyers go in for bidding war

BYLINE: Liz Phillips

SECTION: Pg. 74

LENGTH: 861 words


BUYING a property at auction used to be the preserve of professionals, but these
days househunters and small-time investors have moved into the auction room in
the hope of hammering home a bargain.

Auction fever started ten years ago, when repossessions were at their height and
firsttime buyers saw it as a chance to get a foot in the door of their first
home.

Nowadays, repossessed properties are not as common and competition from other
keen bidders means that you could pay well over the guide price. On the whole,
bargains are going, going, gone.

Auctioneers boast about how much higher properties sell above the guide price.
Paul Jackson, an auctioneer and estate agent firm in Lymington, Hampshire, sold
two New Forest cottages at the height of the summer for nearly GBP 100,000 over
their guide price of GBP 250,000 each.

They both needed complete renovation.

Bidders were left in no doubt that the cottages required an enormous amount of
work, but their saving grace was that they were in beautiful rural settings.

'The two cottages were ideal for auction. They were on good sites with views
across the forest, and they both had enormous potential,' says Paul Jackson.

PERHAPS if they'd been in perfect order they would not have attracted half as
much interest.

'I don't think there are many bargains to be had at auction round here.

You are paying a fair market price when you buy under the hammer, though some
people do get carried away when there are lots of bidders for a property.'

The South of England and East Anglia have seen the biggest rise in the value of
homes at auction, according to the Focus Auction Guide, which compares the price
of vacant terrace houses sold across the country.

The South of England has seen increases of 35 per cent, while in East Anglia
people paid nearly 28 per cent more than a year ago.

In Lancashire, where repossessed properties still come onto the market, prices
have fallen slightly in the past year and the average price paid is less than
GBP 16,000.

In the more buoyant London market, the average terrace house is knocked down at
nearly GBP 200,000.

Mike Logan Wood of Countrywide Property Auctions, which holds auctions
throughout Britain, puts the increased prices seen at auction down to their
popularity with the public.

'We're seeing more private people wanting to buy and sell their homes at auction
than ever before,' he says.

'A new phenomenon is the private investor looking to buy rented properties to
provide an income in retirement. Others are buying offices with good tenants for
their pension fund.

'In Manchester and Leeds, houses with tenants are worth more than those that are
vacant.' Most properties that are up for auction fall into one of three types.
They may be difficult to get a mortgage on because they have structural problems
or a sitting tenant.

They may be sold by the executors after the owner has died to get a quick sale,
or they may be so unusual that they are difficult to value outside the auction
room.

The whole buying process is far quicker than through an estate agent. From the
time the auction catalogue arrives on your doorstep you have only about three
weeks until the auction.

Once your offer has been accepted, you are deemed to have exchanged contracts
and will usually have only 20 working days until completion, when you can move
in.

When the gavel has dropped, the property is yours and you will have to pay 10
per cent of the price as a deposit before you leave the room.

You need to do your homework before the sale. One good way to value the home you
are interested in is to look at as many comparable properties as possible from
estate agents.

Ask someone who knows about property maintenance to give an opinion as to what
needs to be done to put the place right. You can ask builders for quotes for the
cost of the work and refurbishment.

If you want to go ahead, arrange for a surveyor to do a report on the house,
especially if it is an older property in poor repair.

At the time of the auction, you need to have sorted out your finances. They must
be watertight if you are not a cash buyer because there will be penalties if you
cannot complete the transaction.

You must apply for a mortgage quickly if you are not a cash buyer because it can
take at least two weeks to arrange. If you cannot fix a mortgage before the
auction, do not bid.

YOU NEED to get a legal pack for the home you are interested in from the
auctioneers. They will charge a small fee, typically around GBP 10, for it.

Your solicitors will need to go through the details in the pack, which will
include any special conditions.

Mike Logan Wood advises: 'Do your homework because there is no going back once
your bid's been accepted, even if you find out there are major problems later.
The auctioneer won't point them.

'Know the maximum that you are prepared to pay and don't go any further.

People do get carried away with the excitement of the auction. It's a bit like
gambling.

Often their hand is shaking so much afterwards that they can hardly sign the
documents.'

                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                            March 8, 2017 Wednesday
                                 METRO EDITION

Digi-Key: $200M site is possible

BYLINE: DEE DePASS; STAFF WRITER, STAR TRIBUNE (Mpls.-St. Paul)

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 1D

LENGTH: 725 words



HIGHLIGHT: Company is giving state, Thief River Falls the first chance to make a
pitch.


Digi-Key Electronics is considering adding a $200 million factory and
distribution center to its Thief River Falls headquarters that could add 1,000
jobs over 10 years, officials announced this week.

If selected, the project could add 1 million square feet of manufacturing and
warehouse space in Thief River Falls and $500 million in economic output to
Minnesota's coffers, officials said. It also could increase Digi-Key's current
3,200-employee Minnesota workforce by one-third.

The Digi-Key project might ultimately grow in scope to $300 million.

The international wholesaler, which ships all of its parts for smartphones,
electric cars, LED lights and medical devices from its hub in Thief River

Falls, now generates about $1.5 billion a year in sales.

Although Digi-Key is considering other locations for expansion, Thief River
Falls remains its "preferred location," said Rick Trontvet, Digi-Key's vice
president of administration and human resources. Digi-Key will give the city and
state a chance to put together an incentives package before expanding the search
to other sites.

Trontvet declined to say where else the company is looking.

"We obviously are thrilled with Thief River Falls as the place where we have
grown. And we wanted to give Minnesota and the city the first opportunity or the
first bite of the apple so to speak" in trying to make a deal work, Trontvet
said.

"We told our employees [Monday] and there is a lot of excitement about the scale
of the facility and what it could mean," he said.

But he cautioned that Digi-Key's large size means the decision on where to
expand is "more complex and requires that we review a variety of possibilities.
This review process involves a lot of fact finding."

Infrastructure and hiring needs are just two of many issues that will have to be
addressed if the project is to go forward. It's often difficult to find hundreds
of new workers to hire in northern, rural Minnesota, officials conceded. In the
past, housing has been a concern.

Cities and businesses have teamed up in recent years, though, to improve access
to jobs, apartments and houses.

Thief River Falls Mayor Brian Holmer said that, if chosen, his city will welcome
Digi-Key's project "with open arms. ... We want them to stay here."

The expansion proposal was set to be discussed by City Council members during
meetings Tuesday and Wednesday and by state legislators this week, Holmer said.

The idea that Digi-Key could launch such a massive expansion in rural Minnesota
is "very exciting," Holmer said. If it proceeds, it would "provide hundreds of
millions of dollars to the economy in Minnesota, so it would be good to keep
them here in Minnesota."

If possible, city leaders will consider offering Digi-Key some type of tax
increment financing. At the same time, state legislators are considering
proposals to steer state loans or grants toward the company.

The state's Department of Employment and Economic Development has the ability to
offer expanding businesses certain incentives, such as job creation rebates and
Minnesota Investment Fund loans, to assist with expansion. Most measures require
the grant or loan recipient to first invest significant capital and to create a
set number of new jobs before receiving state money.

"We started working on it in January and have worked with the consultants that
Digi-Key hired," Holmer said. "Now we are at a crossroads and have to see how it
all works out."

The city, state and the regional airport are all willing to help ensure that an
expanded Digi-Key plant and its enhanced cargo demands could be met. "In the
future, if [Digi-Key] needed bigger planes at the airport, the airport is
willing to consider that. If we need to grow, we will grow," Holmer said.

Digi-Key Electronics is a global distributor of electronic components,
prototypes and designs from more than 650 name-brand manufacturers. It stocks
1.3 million electronic components and typically ships parts to customers across
the globe within 48 hours.

That track record must be maintained, Trontvet said.

Digi-Key has enjoyed robust growth in the last 15 years as customers moved from
paper catalogs to internet-based ordering. In addition to Thief River Falls,
Digi-Key has a small facility in Fargo and a customer service center in the
Netherlands, plus sales offices in Munich and Tel Aviv.

                     The Journal Record (Oklahoma City, OK)

                             April 18, 2003 Friday

OKC Real Estate Briefs April 18, 2003

BYLINE: Matt Maile

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 1022 words


Workers have raised walls and are progressing with other work in the first and
second phases of construction of Quad/Graphics' Oklahoma City printing plant on
168 acres near the intersection of Interstate 240 and S. Sunnylane Road.

The Pewaukee, Wis.-based company is scheduled to complete the first phase of the
printing plant -- a 217,000-square-foot building -- this summer. Construction
has already begun on the second phase of the plant that will add another 317,000
square feet to the facility. The second phase of the plant should be completed
by 2004, a year ahead of schedule, company officials said.

The first phase of the development will house Quad/Graphic's offset printing
operations. The second phase will add capabilities for gravure presses.

When completed, the printing plant under construction will begin printing weekly
editions of Newsweek magazine under a five-year contract plant officials
announced in March.

Conferences

Gov. Brad Henry and the Protecting People First Foundation will mark the 8th
anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing with a two-day symposium highlighting
how building owners and managers can make buildings safe from terrorist attacks,
the foundation said.

The two-day event will begin with an awards ceremony at 9 a.m. April 24 at the
Westin Hotel in downtown Oklahoma City. The awards will honor the General
Services Administration for steps taken to protect workers from terrorist attack
in the new Oklahoma City federal campus now under construction.

The Protecting People First Foundation was founded by Aren Almon-Kok, mother of
Oklahoma City bombing victim Baylee Almon.

On April 24 and 25, representatives from the FBI's Terrorism Task Force, the
General Services Administration and other federal, state and regional agencies
will join the governor and First Lady Kim Henry to discuss what steps can be
taken to make sure buildings are safe.

Also attending the symposium will be the lead architects of the new Oklahoma
City federal campus and members of the protective glazing industry, which
crafted the special bomb blast resistant windows in the new federal building.

More information about the event can be found at the Web site
www.protectingpeople.org.

Land sale

More than 1,800 acres of state land in 12 Oklahoma counties will go on the
auction block April 28 through May 2, Ernest Hellwege, the secretary for the
Commissioners of the Land Office, said this week.

The eighth annual sale of lands by the School Land Trust will be held at county
courthouses. Auctions will begin April 28 in Blaine, Caddo, Texas, and Woods
counties. On April 29, Ellis, McClain, Pottawatomie, and Roger Mills counties
will hold auctions. Carter, Garvin and Lincoln counties are scheduled to hold
auctions on April 30. The final auction will be held in Craig County on May 2.

"Money from the sale of state school land increases trust fund revenue for
Oklahoma's education system," Hellege said.

Minimum bids are established for each property. Hellwege said this year's
auctions are expected to generate about $800,000.

Those wanting more information about the auctions can contact the Commissioners
of the Land Office at (888) 355-2637 or (405) 604-8100, or by visiting the Web
site, www.clo.state.ok.us.

Advisory board formed

The Oklahoma Homebuyers Education Association said it has named 17 persons to
serve on its recently created advisory board.

Included as advisers are Brian Alford, manager of corporate communications at
OGE; Roger Beverage, president and CEO of the Oklahoma Bankers Association; Bill
Blalock, president of Southern Plains Indian Housing Council; Gary Carpenter of
the Greater Oklahoma City Hispanic Chamber of Commerce; Cheryl Dorrance,
director of research for the Oklahoma Municipal League; J.D. Foster, president
of the Oklahoma National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials;
Jerry Goodwin, president of the Tulsa Urban League; and Sergio Garcia of the
Greater Tulsa Hispanic Chamber of Commerce.

Other advisers are Jeff Hairston, assistant vice president for the Federal Home
Loan Bank of Topeka, Kan.; Michael E. Jones, executive director of the Oklahoma
Association of Community Action Agencies; Brent Kisling, Oklahoma state director
of the U.S Department of Agriculture/Rural Development; Kevin McNeely, Oklahoma
City director of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development; Jim
Miller, president of the Oklahoma Mortgage Bankers Association; Cris Price,
president of the Oklahoma Mortgage Brokers Association; Dennis Shockley,
executive director of the Oklahoma Housing and Finance Authority; Tom Seth
Smith, executive director of Rural Enterprises of Oklahoma; and Rex Smitherman,
director of the Oklahoma Partnership Office of the Fannie Mae Association.

OHEA is funded by the Federal Home Loan Bank of Topeka, Kan., and a grant from
the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. The Oklahoma Association
of Community Action Agencies administers the program.

The association said its mission is to prepare Oklahomans for home ownership.

Interior design

The Plaza District Association has leased property at 1708 NW 16th St. in
Oklahoma City for the new offices of the association, the group said this week.

Jason Johnston, Plaza District Association board member, has volunteered the
services of his interior design firm, Jason George. In addition to managing and
remodeling the space, Johnston will make what were termed "minor" modifications
to the exterior of the building.

Plans include painting each of the four door fronts along the block-long
structure in primary colors of red, yellow, blue and green.

The association said it would use the space for committee meetings and for
day-to-day operations of the association. Johnston said he expects the office to
be open sometime in May.

Staff additions

Tamra Tresner has joined RE/MAX Associates as a sales associate, the company
said this week.

Tresner formerly served as a training director for Sonic Industries. In her new
position, she will specialize in residential property sales in Edmond and
northwest Oklahoma City.

                                US Official News

                           September 27, 2016 Tuesday

USDA Announces $18.1 Million to Help Rural Businesses Create Jobs

LENGTH: 928  words

DATELINE: New York



 Phoenix: Retirement System, The State of Arizona has issued the following news
release:

  Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced loans and grants for 92
projects worth $18.1 million to help support the start-up or expansion of rural
small businesses. These funds are part of more than 20,000 grants and loans to
more than 85,000 rural businesses USDA's Rural Business-Cooperative Service has
awarded since the start of the Obama administration.





 "I am proud of the work USDA has done to help small businesses grow in rural
America because they are the engine that creates jobs," Vilsack said. "These
funds will allow small and emerging businesses and the organizations that
support them to get the financing they need to strengthen their operations,
create jobs and expand economic opportunities. Thanks to the 2014 Farm Bill, we
can continue this work in a more streamlined and efficient way to benefit small
businesses and the American taxpayer."



 USDA is awarding the funds through the Rural Economic Development Loan and
Grant (REDLG) program, the Intermediary Relending Program (IRP) and the Rural
Business Development Grant (RBDG) program.



 USDA provides grants or zero-interest loans through the REDLG program to
utilities that in turn fund projects to create and retain employment in rural
areas. Vilsack announced $11.7 million in REDLG loans and grants for 18
recipients.



 One of the organizations receiving funds under the REDLG program is the South
Mississippi Electric Power Association, which has been selected for a $2 million
loan. It will lend part of that to the city of Greenwood, which will buy and
renovate a building for the Milwaukee Tools company. This project is expected to
create more than 100 jobs in Lenore County. Lenore is one of many counties
across the nation USDA has targeted for special assistance through the
StrikeForce Initiative for Rural Growth and Opportunity. USDA launched
StrikeForce in 2010 to increase investments in rural communities through
intensive outreach and stronger partnerships with community leaders, businesses,
foundations and other groups that are working to combat poverty.



 In the Intermediary Relending Program (IRP), Vilsack announced $2.5 million for
three IRP recipients. Colorado's First Southwest Bank is receiving a $1 million
loan for business and community development in 11 counties in the southwest part
of the state. The IRP program provides 1 percent loans to non-profit groups,
cooperatives, federally recognized tribes and public agencies.



 USDA is awarding 71 Rural Business Development Grants totaling $4 million.
Congress established the RBDG program in the 2014 Farm Bill by combining the
Rural Business Enterprise Grant program and the Rural Business Opportunity Grant
program. One of the RBDG recipients, the Tennessee College of Applied
Technology-Morristown, will receive a $110,020 grant to buy state-of-the-art
equipment to train students in advanced manufacturing. The Northern Community
Investment Corporation in Vermont is receiving two grants totaling $454,892 to
establish a revolving fund and to provide technical assistance and professional
consulting to help small businesses.



 Past examples of how these awards have helped grow the economy in rural America
include:



     Sisters Kim Brigham Campbell and Terrie Brigham, in Oregon's Hood River
County, used part of an IRP loan awarded to the Mid-Columbia Economic
Development District to open a retail store. They sell salmon, steelhead,
sturgeon and other fish harvested from sites that have been passed down within
this Native American family for generations. The store opened in May 2014.

     USDA's REDLG program is fueling the growth of a firm in Eastern Kentucky.
USDA awarded a $740,000 REDLG loan to the Jackson Energy Cooperative in FY 2011.
The Cooperative, in turn, loaned a portion of those funds to Senture, which
constructed a building where it provides call-center and support services for
private companies and government agencies. Senture is a family-owned business
headquartered in London.

     In FY 2014, USDA Rural Development awarded a $64,990 Rural Business
Enterprise Grant to Sustainable Northwest, a non-profit in Portland, Ore., to
find commercial uses and markets for Western Juniper. It is a widespread and
often problematic species in central and eastern parts of the state. Sustainable
Northwest is using USDA's grant to help create timber and forestry jobs in rural
Oregon and contribute to ecosystem restoration by identifying additional uses
for Western Juniper wood products.



 The funding for today's awardees totals $18.1 million and is contingent upon
the recipients meeting the terms of the loan and grant agreements.



 President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

call (866) 632-9992 (Toll-free Customer Service), (800) 877-8339 (Local or

Washington: USDA Announces $18.1 Million to Help Rural Businesses Create Jobs

LENGTH: 867 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following
news release:



 Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced loans and grants for 92
projects worth $18.1 million to help support the start-up or expansion of rural
small businesses. These funds are part of more than 20,000 grants and loans to
more than 85,000 rural businesses USDA's Rural Business-Cooperative Service has
awarded since the start of the Obama administration.





 "I am proud of the work USDA has done to help small businesses grow in rural
America because they are the engine that creates jobs," Vilsack said. "These
funds will allow small and emerging businesses and the organizations that
support them to get the financing they need to strengthen their operations,
create jobs and expand economic opportunities. Thanks to the 2014 Farm Bill, we
can continue this work in a more streamlined and efficient way to benefit small
businesses and the American taxpayer."



 USDA is awarding the funds through the Rural Economic Development Loan and
Grant (REDLG) program, the Intermediary Relending Program (IRP) and the Rural
Business Development Grant (RBDG) program.



 USDA provides grants or zero-interest loans through the REDLG program to
utilities that in turn fund projects to create and retain employment in rural
areas. Vilsack announced $11.7 million in REDLG loans and grants for 18
recipients.



 One of the organizations receiving funds under the REDLG program is the South
Mississippi Electric Power Association, which has been selected for a $2 million
loan. It will lend part of that to the city of Greenwood, which will buy and
renovate a building for the Milwaukee Tools company. This project is expected to
create more than 100 jobs in Lenore County. Lenore is one of many counties
across the nation USDA has targeted for special assistance through the
StrikeForce Initiative for Rural Growth and Opportunity. USDA launched
StrikeForce in 2010 to increase investments in rural communities through
intensive outreach and stronger partnerships with community leaders, businesses,
foundations and other groups that are working to combat poverty.

three IRP recipients. Colorado's First Southwest Bank is receiving a $1 million

 USDA is awarding 71 Rural Business Development Grants totaling $4 million.

     USDA's REDLG program is fueling the growth of a firm in Eastern Kentucky.
USDA awarded a $740,000 REDLG loan to the Jackson Energy Cooperative in FY 2011.
The Cooperative, in turn, loaned a portion of those funds to Senture, which
constructed a building where it provides call-center and support services for

infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                      AUGUST 6, 1999 Friday CWEST EDITION

A DREAM COME TRUE, THE NEW GARDEN PROJECT MADE PROPERTY OWNERS OF FARMWORKERS. /
MIGRANT WORKERS FORM A NEIGHBORHOOD

BYLINE: Michael Sandler, INQUIRER SUBURBAN STAFF

SECTION: NEIGHBORS CHESTER & BRANDYWINE; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 1176 words

DATELINE: NEW GARDEN


Every month, Dagoberto Guzman pays his bills.

Occasionally, with five growing children, the grocery list varies. This summer,
the electricity bill has been a little higher. But for the most part, the amount
of money he spends has not changed dramatically since his family moved from
Mexico to join him in southern Chester County five years ago.

Something is new in his budget, though. This year, Guzman stopped paying rent.
When he plunks down one week's salary for the roof, that roof is his.

"It is my dream to finish paying for this house," Guzman said in Spanish while
standing in front of the sliding glass doors in his 10-by-16-foot, eat-in
kitchen.

The Guzmans are among 24 families who purchased a townhouse in the Buena Vista
development last year with a reduced mortgage rate set up by the Alliance for
Better Housing. The nonprofit developer assists low-income rural residents, most
of whom work in southern Chester County's mushroom region.

The Alliance for Better Housing was formed five years ago by politicians,
business people and social-service workers in the Kennett area who had gathered
to discuss a growing demand for housing among the area's low-income farmworkers.
Unlike other crops, mushrooms can be grown year-round. As more workers settled
in the area, many moved their families from Mexico.

"We needed to provide a positive environment to make the families feel welcome,"
said Kennett Square Mayor Leon Spencer.

While the alliance has helped more than 70 families purchase homes, Buena Vista
is the first development built specifically to serve a large group of families.
The project received support from several sources, including private donors,
municipalities and the Puerto Rican Coalition.

Toll Bros. built the complex at cost, forgoing the estimated $300,000 profit it
could have made on the project.

The low-interest loans were provided by the Department of Agriculture's rural
development agency under Section 502 of the Housing Act of 1949. With this
program and the additional donations, the alliance sold all 24 units, raising $3
million to construct the development outside Kennett Square.

"If it wasn't for this program, it would be impossible for me to buy a home,"
said Sergio Carmona, who works as a health counselor at Project Salud, a primary
health center for low-income farmworkers in Kennett Square. "They made it
possible for some of us."

Families pay as little as 1 percent and up to 7 percent annual interest on
three- and four-bedroom homes that sold for between $105,000 and $112,000. The
rates are based on household income. Borrowers are required by Department of
Agriculture to recertify income annually. The interest rate on monthly payments
can change as family income changes.

The Guzmans pay $460.04 each month on a 32-year mortgage with an annual 1
percent interst rate for their three-bedroom, 2 1/2-bathroom house. Last year
they paid $400 each month to rent a one-story, two-bedroom house in Kennett.

Dagoberto Guzman earns about $460 each week after taxes, picking mushrooms and
driving a truck. He often leaves the house before dawn for 12 hours of work each
day. His wife, Hilda, takes home about $250 a week packing mushrooms.

"We don't earn much," Dagoberto Guzman said. "But when we are here, we are
fine."

Eligibility was based solely on those household incomes that fell below 80
percent of the average household income in Chester County. Those in the range -
$31,150 for a single occupant to about $55,150 for a family of seven, like the
Guzmans - qualified.

Those numbers are maximum figures. The families living at Buena Vista earn from
$12,000 to $35,000 a year, said Howard Porter, the director of the Alliance for
Better Housing.

"Nobody makes anywhere near $55,000," Porter said.

All the homeowners also had to qualify for a mortgage, which included credit and
debt-ratio checks. Once approved, all buyers needed to produce $3,000 for
closing fees, a portion of the actual $17,000 down payment on each house. The
Housing Partnership of Chester County and First National Bank of West Chester
provided the additional $14,000 as a forgiven grant.

"The only time they would have to pay it back would be if they turned around in
the next five years and tried to sell the house for profit," Porter said.

The families are not just purchasing homes; they are building a community.

On the 7.3-acre site above Old Baltimore Pike, where dilapidated mushroom shacks
and wooded areas once stood, a circle of white townhouses grouped in blocks of
four occupies a newly constructed cul-de-sac.

The first group of families moved into the new homes last December, the last few
this May. Slowly, as the families met, some semblance of a neighborhood began to
take shape. Now, in the evening, families sit outside their houses on stone
porches and talk. Children ride bicycles, organize games of soccer and play tag
on the front lawns.

"It's nice to see all the children playing," said Carmona, who had been renting
a mobile home for himself, his wife and daughter before buying the townhouse.
"My daughter wants to be outside playing all day."

Antero Serrano moved to Chester County from Acapulco in 1988. He picked and
packed mushrooms in Toughkenamon, a few miles from where he lived in Kennett
Square. Since he did not have a car, each morning he walked the three miles
along Old Baltimore Pike to Modern Mushroom Co. When he finished work, he walked
home.

He hardly found peace or quiet in his second-floor apartment.

"I had drunks living above me on the third floor," Serrano said. "I could never
sleep."

These days, he and his family are the only people living under his roof. He
often catches a ride to work with one of his new neighbors.

Guzman's journey toward the status of homeowner began more than two decades ago.
In 1976, he left Guanajuato, Mexico, as a teenager and immigrated alone to the
United States. That year, he went to California and began the first of several
migrant jobs picking grapes and peaches.

Guzman rented a room as a boarder in other people's homes. He returned to Mexico
periodically to see his then-girlfriend. They were married in the early 1980s.
She stayed behind to raise the growing family. He sent them money each month.

When he arrived in Pennsylvania to pick mushrooms, he found stable work and
became a legal resident in 1987. In 1994, he sent for his wife and family, which
now included four children. They had their fifth child in Pennsylvania in 1997.

"We lived in a small house with two rooms," Guzman said. "Two of the children
slept in the living room."

Now the children sleep two to each bedroom in bunk beds. The 2-year-old sleeps
in a crib beside his parents' bed.

"We have more rooms, and we can play in the basement, too," said Jose Luis
Guzman, 11.

"This one has a second floor," said Maria Guadalupe Guzman, 9.

Their father smiled.

"It's nice that we can be together," Dagoberto Guzman said.

LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO;
PHOTO

five-year-old Kennett-area Alliance for Better Housing. (BOB WILLIAMS, Inquirer
Suburban Staff)
Children run across the porches, above, of the development. Carlos Figueroa's
lawn has a shrine to the Virgin Mary, left. Below, Dagoberto Guzman; his wife,
Hilda; Enrique, 2, and Maria Guadelupe, 9, gather at the table. (BOB WILLIAMS,
Inquirer Suburban Staff)

                            October 4, 2016 Tuesday

Washington: USDA Announces $18.1 Million to Help Rural Businesses Create Jobs

LENGTH: 867  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following
news release:



 Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced loans and grants for 92
projects worth $18.1 million to help support the start-up or expansion of rural
small businesses. These funds are part of more than 20,000 grants and loans to
more than 85,000 rural businesses USDA's Rural Business-Cooperative Service has
awarded since the start of the Obama administration.





 "I am proud of the work USDA has done to help small businesses grow in rural
America because they are the engine that creates jobs," Vilsack said. "These
funds will allow small and emerging businesses and the organizations that
support them to get the financing they need to strengthen their operations,
create jobs and expand economic opportunities. Thanks to the 2014 Farm Bill, we
can continue this work in a more streamlined and efficient way to benefit small
businesses and the American taxpayer."



 USDA is awarding the funds through the Rural Economic Development Loan and
Grant (REDLG) program, the Intermediary Relending Program (IRP) and the Rural
Business Development Grant (RBDG) program.



 USDA provides grants or zero-interest loans through the REDLG program to
utilities that in turn fund projects to create and retain employment in rural
areas. Vilsack announced $11.7 million in REDLG loans and grants for 18
recipients.



 One of the organizations receiving funds under the REDLG program is the South
Mississippi Electric Power Association, which has been selected for a $2 million
loan. It will lend part of that to the city of Greenwood, which will buy and
renovate a building for the Milwaukee Tools company. This project is expected to
create more than 100 jobs in Lenore County. Lenore is one of many counties
across the nation USDA has targeted for special assistance through the
StrikeForce Initiative for Rural Growth and Opportunity. USDA launched
StrikeForce in 2010 to increase investments in rural communities through
intensive outreach and stronger partnerships with community leaders, businesses,
foundations and other groups that are working to combat poverty.



 In the Intermediary Relending Program (IRP), Vilsack announced $2.5 million for
three IRP recipients. Colorado's First Southwest Bank is receiving a $1 million
loan for business and community development in 11 counties in the southwest part
of the state. The IRP program provides 1 percent loans to non-profit groups,
cooperatives, federally recognized tribes and public agencies.



 USDA is awarding 71 Rural Business Development Grants totaling $4 million.
Congress established the RBDG program in the 2014 Farm Bill by combining the
Rural Business Enterprise Grant program and the Rural Business Opportunity Grant
program. One of the RBDG recipients, the Tennessee College of Applied
Technology-Morristown, will receive a $110,020 grant to buy state-of-the-art
equipment to train students in advanced manufacturing. The Northern Community
Investment Corporation in Vermont is receiving two grants totaling $454,892 to
establish a revolving fund and to provide technical assistance and professional
consulting to help small businesses.



 Past examples of how these awards have helped grow the economy in rural America
include:



     Sisters Kim Brigham Campbell and Terrie Brigham, in Oregon's Hood River
County, used part of an IRP loan awarded to the Mid-Columbia Economic
Development District to open a retail store. They sell salmon, steelhead,
sturgeon and other fish harvested from sites that have been passed down within
this Native American family for generations. The store opened in May 2014.

     USDA's REDLG program is fueling the growth of a firm in Eastern Kentucky.
USDA awarded a $740,000 REDLG loan to the Jackson Energy Cooperative in FY 2011.
The Cooperative, in turn, loaned a portion of those funds to Senture, which
constructed a building where it provides call-center and support services for
private companies and government agencies. Senture is a family-owned business
headquartered in London.

     In FY 2014, USDA Rural Development awarded a $64,990 Rural Business
Enterprise Grant to Sustainable Northwest, a non-profit in Portland, Ore., to
find commercial uses and markets for Western Juniper. It is a widespread and
often problematic species in central and eastern parts of the state. Sustainable
Northwest is using USDA's grant to help create timber and forestry jobs in rural
Oregon and contribute to ecosystem restoration by identifying additional uses
for Western Juniper wood products.



 The funding for today's awardees totals $18.1 million and is contingent upon
the recipients meeting the terms of the loan and grant agreements.



 President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

Federal relay), (866) 377-8642 (Relay voice users).

                                US Official News

                             July 30, 2016 Saturday

Washington: USDA Announces $18.1 Million to Help Rural Businesses Create Jobs

LENGTH: 867  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following
news release:



 Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced loans and grants for 92
projects worth $18.1 million to help support the start-up or expansion of rural
small businesses. These funds are part of more than 20,000 grants and loans to
more than 85,000 rural businesses USDA's Rural Business-Cooperative Service has
awarded since the start of the Obama administration.





 "I am proud of the work USDA has done to help small businesses grow in rural
America because they are the engine that creates jobs," Vilsack said. "These
funds will allow small and emerging businesses and the organizations that
support them to get the financing they need to strengthen their operations,
create jobs and expand economic opportunities. Thanks to the 2014 Farm Bill, we
can continue this work in a more streamlined and efficient way to benefit small
businesses and the American taxpayer."



 USDA is awarding the funds through the Rural Economic Development Loan and
Grant (REDLG) program, the Intermediary Relending Program (IRP) and the Rural
Business Development Grant (RBDG) program.



 USDA provides grants or zero-interest loans through the REDLG program to
utilities that in turn fund projects to create and retain employment in rural
areas. Vilsack announced $11.7 million in REDLG loans and grants for 18
recipients.



 One of the organizations receiving funds under the REDLG program is the South
Mississippi Electric Power Association, which has been selected for a $2 million
loan. It will lend part of that to the city of Greenwood, which will buy and
renovate a building for the Milwaukee Tools company. This project is expected to
create more than 100 jobs in Lenore County. Lenore is one of many counties
across the nation USDA has targeted for special assistance through the
StrikeForce Initiative for Rural Growth and Opportunity. USDA launched
StrikeForce in 2010 to increase investments in rural communities through
intensive outreach and stronger partnerships with community leaders, businesses,
foundations and other groups that are working to combat poverty.



 In the Intermediary Relending Program (IRP), Vilsack announced $2.5 million for
three IRP recipients. Colorado's First Southwest Bank is receiving a $1 million
loan for business and community development in 11 counties in the southwest part
of the state. The IRP program provides 1 percent loans to non-profit groups,
cooperatives, federally recognized tribes and public agencies.



 USDA is awarding 71 Rural Business Development Grants totaling $4 million.
Congress established the RBDG program in the 2014 Farm Bill by combining the
Rural Business Enterprise Grant program and the Rural Business Opportunity Grant
program. One of the RBDG recipients, the Tennessee College of Applied
Technology-Morristown, will receive a $110,020 grant to buy state-of-the-art
equipment to train students in advanced manufacturing. The Northern Community
Investment Corporation in Vermont is receiving two grants totaling $454,892 to
establish a revolving fund and to provide technical assistance and professional
consulting to help small businesses.



 Past examples of how these awards have helped grow the economy in rural America
include:



     Sisters Kim Brigham Campbell and Terrie Brigham, in Oregon's Hood River
County, used part of an IRP loan awarded to the Mid-Columbia Economic
Development District to open a retail store. They sell salmon, steelhead,
sturgeon and other fish harvested from sites that have been passed down within
this Native American family for generations. The store opened in May 2014.

     USDA's REDLG program is fueling the growth of a firm in Eastern Kentucky.
USDA awarded a $740,000 REDLG loan to the Jackson Energy Cooperative in FY 2011.
The Cooperative, in turn, loaned a portion of those funds to Senture, which
constructed a building where it provides call-center and support services for
private companies and government agencies. Senture is a family-owned business
headquartered in London.

     In FY 2014, USDA Rural Development awarded a $64,990 Rural Business
Enterprise Grant to Sustainable Northwest, a non-profit in Portland, Ore., to
find commercial uses and markets for Western Juniper. It is a widespread and
often problematic species in central and eastern parts of the state. Sustainable
Northwest is using USDA's grant to help create timber and forestry jobs in rural
Oregon and contribute to ecosystem restoration by identifying additional uses
for Western Juniper wood products.



 The funding for today's awardees totals $18.1 million and is contingent upon
the recipients meeting the terms of the loan and grant agreements.



 President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

                          THE JOURNAL (Newcastle, UK)

                       March 14, 1998, Saturday Edition 1

Tax relief warning issued to Brown - Estate agents' pre-Budget plea

BYLINE: By Rik Kendall

SECTION: HOMEMAKER, Pg. 1

LENGTH: 719 words


   SPECULATION over tax hikes in next week's Budget is fuelling concern among
homeowners and property experts.

Whether it's fear of higher mortgage costs, or the implications of a greenfield
tax on house builders, there is plenty of advice for the Chancellor.

The National Association of Estate Agents [NAEA] has warned of financial
hardships for millions of households if Gordon Brown cuts mortgage tax relief.

And if he decides to alter the stamp duty level as well as reduce Mortgage
Interest Relief at Source [Miras], confidence in the housing market would
plummet.

Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy, NAEA chief executive, said: "We would urge the Chancellor
to avoid any further fiscal measures - tax increases - in the housing market at
this time.

"While we recognise that there is an argument for removing Miras, we believe its
further reduction or removal would have serious consequences for the poorer
sections of society - including the retired and those on low incomes."

He added: "We are also concerned about the regional distribution of Miras,
because it remains an important subsidy for more than 50pc of households in many
regions of the North of England and Scotland."

Miras provides tax relief on the first £30,000 of a mortgage - a significant
percentage of the overall mortgage for many low and middle-income families.

Peter Heron, from Peter Heron Estate Agents in Sunderland, agrees. "The average
price of properties on our register is £51,000. If, as looks likely, the
Government continue to erode Miras, it could have drastic effects for much of
the Wearside

housing market." Heading the budget wish list from the Royal Institute of
Chartered Surveyors [RICS], are policies to aid urban regeneration and protect
the countryside.

But before incentives are introduced to encourage urban renewal, or taxes
imposed on greenfield development, they believe the options should be examined
more fully.

RICS president Peter McKendrick, who is also senior partner at a Newcastle-based
chartered surveying company, said: "A long term strategic approach is needed to
underpin the Government's commitment to environmental protection.

"Environmental taxes have a place to play in this but existing Government policy
lacks clarity.

"I therefore strongly endorse a recent proposal from the House of Commons
Environment Audit Committee, that the Government should establish an advisory
body on environmental taxation."

Any greenfield tax should consider whether it is intended to reduce development
on greenfield sites or simply raise money to help regenerate brownfield sites.

The RICS is also concerned with taxes where development is needed but no
greenfield land is available.

Cate Hammond, from the Council of Protection for Rural England [CPRE], based in
Newcastle, commented: "We would like to see the 17.5pc VAT, currently levied on
the development and renovation of existing housing, removed.

"At the same time, introducing VAT on new build will help ease pressure on the
countryside."

Ronnie Baird, chairman of the House Builders Federation [North-East] and
regional director of Wimpey Homes, points out that this could have serious
consequences for employment and lead to a shortages of new houses and higher
prices.

He added: "Since it is acknowledged by the deputy prime minister that a
significant amount of greenfield development is needed to meet growing demand
and prevent town cramming, a greenfield tax conflicts with a clear requirement.

"We do, however, support the case for a reduction in the rate of VAT on
refurbishment of existing housing to 5pc - the minimum rate available under
European Union rules.

"This would help homeowners maintain their own homes and encourage individuals
to purchase run-down properties and renovate them."

Landfill tax is another obstruction to the development of brownfield sites,
particularly with the removal of contaminated material and waste from urban
areas, where there is only limited tax exemption.

Mr Baird concludes: "We would urge Gordon Brown to consider seriously a far
wider exemption in order to reduce the costs of this redevelopment.

"The position at present is that grant aid may be required to offset the effect
of landfill tax. This is clearly a ridiculous outcome."

LOAD-DATE: January 14, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       TELEGRAM & GAZETTE (Massachusetts)

                    August 13, 2003 Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

Hotel TIF gets OK;
 Council votes on other plans

BYLINE: Nick Kotsopoulos; TELEGRAM & GAZETTE STAFF

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 715 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER


- Key development projects in the city were advanced by the City Council last
night when it approved various agreements associated with them.

By a 10-1 vote, the council approved a tax-increment financing deal for the
Hilton Garden Inn hotel project that is planned for downtown.

Under the deal, known as a TIF, Fargo Management LLC, developer of the hotel,
will receive a 50 percent tax exemption on the increase in property value over
the duration of the 20-year agreement.

That means the developer will save about $2.6 million in property taxes during
that period. The city, meanwhile, will realize about $2.7 million in new tax
revenue from the increase in the property's value during that same period.

The TIF will go into effect July 1, 2005.

Upon completion of the TIF, the city will receive more than $300,000 in property
taxes annually from the hotel property.

Councilor-at-Large Konstantina B. Lukes cast the lone vote against the TIF. She
opposed it because she felt the city was ''too generous'' in the incentives it
gave the hotel developer for the project. She also said the $1 million the
developer will pay for the city-owned property where the hotel will be built was
not enough.

The hotel will be built on a 34,224-square-foot site where the Central Street
fire station is situated. To make way for the hotel development, equipment and
personnel in the Central Street station will be redeployed and the station will
be razed.

In another item associated with the hotel project, the council unanimously
approved a $5 million loan guarantee. While the developer has secured financing
from Banknorth of Springfield that will provide up to $17.6 million in
construction financing, it was contingent upon receiving a $5 million federal
Housing and Urban Development Loan Guarantee from the city.

Other development projects advanced by the council were:

Removal of the overhead ramp from the parking garage of the Worcester Common
Outlets mall.

The council unanimously approved a demolition agreement for the ramp that was
negotiated between the city and CIGNA Investments Inc., owner of the downtown
mall.

The demolition of the parking garage ramp, which goes over Worcester Center
Boulevard, is considered key to the redevelopment of the Washington Square --
Union Station area. Peter Pan Bus Lines Inc. intends to construct a bus terminal
for intercity transportation where the ramp is located.

The agreement also calls for the construction of a pedestrian walkway over
Worcester Center Boulevard, connecting the bus terminal to the mall, reopening a
parking garage tunnel on Franklin Street and making Franklin Street, between
Worcester Center Boulevard and Harding Street, two-way to traffic.

Conversion of the School Department maintenance building at 89 Shrewsbury St.
into a restaurant and offices.

The council unanimously authorized City Manager Thomas R. Hoover to sign a deed
conveying the school property to Condron Worcester Realty LLC. The group
includes P. Kevin Condron, president of Central Supply Co,, and Rob Ahlquist,
owner of One Eleven Chop House and Sole Proprietor restaurants.

The group will pay $300,000 for the three-story triangular building, which is on
the west end of Shrewsbury Street, near an off-ramp to Interstate 290.
Restaurant facilities are planned for the first two floors of the building and
offices on the third floor.

Authorized the city manager to solicit requests-for-proposals for G.A.R.
Memorial Hall at 55 Pearl St.

The city holds the property in trust as a memorial to the men of Worcester who
served in the Union Army and Navy during the Civil War. The G.A.R. Hall board of
trustees has custody and control of the building, but it recently voted to
declare the property no longer necessary for the purpose it was acquired and
recommended that it be transferred to the city manager for disposition.

Gave the Worcester Fire Fighters Memorial Committee permission to build a
memorial on city-owned land to the six firefighters who died battling the
Worcester Cold Storage and Warehouse Co. building fire in December 1999. The
memorial park will be on seven acres next to Fire Department headquarters on
Grove Street, bordering Salisbury Pond and across from Institute Park.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                           Free Press Journal (India)

                                 March 1, 2016

Budget snippets: FM puts best foot forward

BYLINE: FPJ Bureau

LENGTH: 707  words


Finance Minister Arun Jaitley specified "nine pillars" for India, which will be
focus areas for the government. The agenda for next year is to undertake
transformative measures based on these nine pillars, Jaitley said in his speech.
The pillars listed by the Finance Minister are - agriculture, rural sector,
social sector, education and job creation, infrastructure investment, financial
sector reforms, governance and ease of doing business, fiscal discipline and tax
reforms.

KISAN CESS: Across-the-board cess of 0.5 percent on services towards farmer
welfare, which will add 50 paise for every Rs.100 one spends on food to mobile
bills. The FM, a lawyer by profession, decided to bring his fellow
practitioners, too, under the service tax net of 14 percent.

CASH SUBSIDY: The direct cash benefit transfers, currently in areas like cooking
gas, will be extended to the fertilizer sector

RECAPTAILISATION: Rs.25000 crore has been earmarked for recapitalisation of
State-run banks that are under financial stress on account of mounting bad
loans. More money will follow as and when warranted, hinted the Finance
Minister. "The budget is not the last word on this," he said, adding he was also
open to consolidation of commercial banks.

GLOBAL INVESTOR: The DFM has sent out signals to the global investor by seeking
to ease the foreign equity norms. Notably, 100 percent such equity will now be
permitted in multi-brand retailing where the produce sold has been processed and
sourced locally.

BOOST TO ENTREPRENEURSHIP: A lower corporate tax rate has been proposed for
small firms with a turnover of below Rs.5 crore, to 29 plus surcharge and cess.

FOR STARTUPS: 100 percent deduction of profits for three out of five years for
start-ups set up between April 2016 and March 2019.

CESS ON CARS: There will be one percent infrastructure cess on small petrol,
LPG, and CNG cars, 2.5 percent on diesel cars of certain capacity and four
percent on higher engine capacity vehicles and sports utility vehicles. Renaming
the Clean Energy Cess as Clean Environment Cess, the FM has proposed to increase
the rate from Rs.200 per ton to Rs.400 per ton.

EASE OF DOING BUSINESS: The FM has also announced a proposal that seeks to amend
the Companies Act for "ease of doing policy;"it will enable registration of a
new company in just one day.

HOUSING LOAN I-T DEDUCTION: The FM has allowed additional income-tax deduction
of Rs 50,000 in interest beyond the current limit of Rs 2 lakh on housing loan
up to Rs 35 lakh to the self-occupied home owners, provided house value doesn't
exceed Rs 50 lakh. Tax payers and industry were expecting Rs 1 lakh to Rs 3 lakh
more, at least in metropolitan cities, as the current limit of Rs 2 lakh is
insignificant.

AFFORDABLE HOUSING: To promote affordable housing and promote real estate
sector, which is facing a huge slowdown, the FM also exempted service tax on
construction of affordable houses up to 30 sq metres in four metros and 60 sq
metres in other cities but only to projects approved between June 2016 and March
2019 and completed within three years. Minimum alternate tax will, however,
apply on these builders. Also extended was the excise duty exemption to ready
mix concretes that is already available to the concrete mix manufactured at site
for construction.

RENT RELIEF: Tax rebate ceiling under Section 87A has been raised from Rs 2,000
to Rs 5,000 for those with annual income up to Rs 5 lakh to benefit 2 crore tax
payers; also, those living on rent will now be allowed deduction of Rs 60,000 a
year instead of Rs 24,000, but that means a rental of Rs 5,000 per month not
available in reality.

TAX DISPUTE RESOLUTION: FM has also come out with a direct tax dispute
resolution scheme to resolve income tax cases pending in courts and tribunals or
before commissioners for want of arbitration and mediation. The defaulters are
now required to pay principal tax, interest, penalty and interest on penalty.
"Now they can simply pay off principal amount and the entire interest and the
penalty can be waived off," said Revenue Secretary Hasmukh.

TAILPIECE

RACE COURSE WINS: As if to encourage horseracing, the threshold limit for tax
deducted at source for winnings from horse race has been increased to Rs.10000.

LOAD-DATE: March 1, 2016

JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

The announcement may be used to fill additional or subsequent vacancies that are
identified by the organization.

This position is being concurrently announced under Merit Promotion procedures
on NY-2014-5237.  Disabled Veterans, candidates with 3 or more years of active
duty military service, and candidates eligible for special hiring authorities
can apply to the Merit Promotion announcement if they meet criteria for the
above and include supporting documents.

DUTIES:

Provides a variety of advance services and technical support assistance to
underwriting staff in order to assist with loan making activities under Rural
Development Single Family Housing loan programs.
    Reviews application documents to insure all required information is properly
completed and obtains supplemental information from external sources to verify
employment, credit, assets and household income.
    Performs a basic financial analysis of SFH applications, identifying obvious
credit risk factors, stability of income, debt to income ratios, property loan
to value, reconciliation and review of a Residential Mortgage Credit Report.
    Furnishes basic information concerning Rural Development's Single Family
Housing loan programs and eligibility requirements.
    Prepares and reviews documentation for loan closing and issues closing
instructions to attorneys.

situation and assist customers with application preparation.

                             June 25, 2015 Thursday

India, China indicate huge aid pledges

LENGTH: 722 words

DATELINE: KATHMANDU


KATHMANDU, June 25 -- Nepal is expected to receive a major boost from India and
China at the International Conference on Nepal's Reconstruction-2015 on
Thursday, with the two immediate neighbours indicating substantive aid pledges
for its reconstruction efforts after the devastating April 25 earthquake and its
aftershocks.

The highest-profile international donor conference ever held in the country has
drawn more than 300 delegates from 60 nations, development partners and donor
community.

Immediately after their arrival, Indian Minister for Foreign Affairs Sushma
Swaraj and Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi held separate meetings with Prime
Minister Sushil Koirala, where they pledged substantive assistance to Nepal.

Sources privy to the development told the Post that India is likely to announce

$1 billion in assistance that includes both grant and soft loan for Nepal's
reconstruction efforts. "Of the total Indian assistance,

Rs 40 billion will come as grant and Rs 60 billion as soft loan," said a senior
official at Prime Minister's Office.

Similarly, China is likely to commit Rs 60 billion in the form of grant and soft
loan. The government has sought Chinese assistance for rebuilding of the roads
connecting Kathmandu to Rasuwagadhi and Tatopani, which were badly damaged by
the earthquake, besides rebuilding houses in rural areas.

The Indian side has yet to indicate its contribution in particular sectors, but
officials said that India is willing to rebuild one of the heritage sites in
Kathmandu.

The US, the EU and Japan are the other major donors likely to announce huge
assistance pledge during the International Conference on Nepal's Reconstruction
on Thursday, according to PMO officials. "The US has promised to provide $130
million and the EU is likely to pledge $100-150 million," said an official. The
Post-Disaster Needs Assessment estimates that

$7 billion will be needed for reconstruction. Ministers and senior government
officials state that they hope to receive pledges of around $3 billion at the
conference.

Although Japan has remained tight lipped about its pledge, sources said Japanese
assistance could be in the range of $300-400 million. These pledges are new
commitments from the donors and development partners for Nepal's reconstruction
bid.

The two multilateral donors-World Bank and Asian Development Bank (ADB)-have
already pledged $500million and $200million for Nepal's reconstruction and
rehabilitation projects. The ADB has expressed interest in the education sector,
reconstruction of government buildings and rural roads, while the World Bank
will be focusing on rural housing and settlements.

Though the donors have shown willingness to help Nepal recover from the
disaster, they are quite apprehensive about the government's ability to use the
pledged money efficiently.

Finance Ministry officials have, however, said the government will assure the
donors that the aid

money would be mobilised transparently through the prime minister-led National
Reconstruction Authority

set up this week through an ordinance.

While the government expects to channelise much of the aid money through the
National Reconstruction Fund, the donors will also be allowed to channelise aid
through I/NGOs as long as they coordinate with the government, the officials
said. "We have adopted one-door policy with multiple windows," said Finance
Secretary Suman Sharma.

Govinda Raj Pokharel, vice-chairman of the National Planning Commission, is more
forthcoming in a bid to clear any mistrust between the government and donors.
"As mentioned in the ordinance, the government will include donors as observers
to monitor the works of Reconstruction Authority," Pokharel said. Bangladeshi
Finance Minister Abdulmaal A Muth, Norwegian Foreign Minister Borge Brende and
Japanese State Minister for Foreign Affairs Hinoru Kiuchi also met PM Koirala on
Wednesday.

Thanking them for the help they extended to Nepal in the immediate aftermath of
the earthquake, Koirala said reconstruction works and

the constitution writing will go ahead simultaneously. "I am confident that we
will be successful on the both fronts," he said.

                        San Bernardino Sun (California)

                            January 22, 2010 Friday

Rialto looks for loan for sports complex

BYLINE: Josh Dulaney, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 270 words


RIALTO - The city might apply for a multimillion-dollar federal loan to pay for
a new sports facility at a shuttered middle school.

A $4.3 million Sec. 108 Loan under the Department of Housing and Urban
Development would fund the project at the old Rialto Middle School at 324 N.
Palm Ave.

Councilman Joe Baca Jr. has pushed for the project for the last three years.

"This would be a landmark park if we could make it happen," Baca said.

The project would include basketball courts, bleachers, ball fields, a track, a
snack stand and new lighting spread over seven acres.

The city is leasing the property from the Rialto Unified School District for 50
years. The site has hosted several sports programs and recreational events.

Sec. 108 is a loan guarantee provision of the Community Development Block Grant
program that provides funding for redevelopment projects in neighborhoods
needing renewal.

"It's in the heart of the city, one of the poorest parts of the city (and would)
provide good opportunities for our youth," Baca said.

The loan would be repaid from the city's annual allocation of CDBG funds.

The city's current allocation is more than $1.3 million each year, according to
a staff report. The city sets aside $252,191 each year to pay off a previous
loan that funded the Senior Center. Officials said that loan will be paid off in
2022.

The estimated annual payment for the new loan is $295,000.

Officials will discuss the issue at a City Council meeting on Feb. 9. The
council meets in open session at 6 p.m. at the Civic Center, 150 S. Palm Ave.

                             June 18, 2015 Thursday

USDA: North Stonington should not use town inspector for EMS building project

BYLINE: Lindsay Boyle, The Day, New London, Conn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 495 words


June 18--NORTH STONINGTON -- When the job opening for the next needed position
for the new $6.36 million emergency services building -- a clerk of the works
for phase two -- closed May 20, there were five applicants.

Members of the Emergency Services Building Committee quickly were able to weed
out three who, Vice Chairman Joe Cassata said, did not meet the position's
requirements.

The remaining two are Lou DiCesare II, the town's building inspector, and Stadia
Engineering Associates Inc., the group performing the clerk of the works duty
for phase one of the project.

Initially, members of the building committee and First Selectman Nick Mullane
were leaning toward choosing DiCesare, whom Stonington recently fired from his
former position as highway manager.

That would mean combining the clerk of the works, who oversees the work site
each day, and the building inspector, who checks that things have been done
properly as needed, into one position.

Mullane repeatedly has said choosing DiCesare would save about $40,000. But
Cassata on Tuesday night said only Stadia sent the committee an official
proposal with expected rates.

DiCesare "did not submit payroll or cost per hour," Cassata said, calling the
$40,000 "speculation."

From the outset, Selectman Bob Testa has asked if combining the two roles would
eliminate a crucial check and balance.

Because the new building likely will be financed by a $6.3 million set interest
rate USDA rural development loan, committee members deferred the question to
USDA area loan specialist Norman St Jean.

But there have been several emails and many questions asked, including whether
it would be a problem to have the town building inspector be the building
inspector for the emergency services project.

"We believe it to be an unacceptable conflict for the inspector to be inspecting
the job he is supervising," St Jean wrote in an email Monday morning without
specifying to which position or positions he was referring. "This Agency
declines the request."

When contacted Wednesday, St Jean, after a lengthy discussion, said the USDA
would see it as a conflict if the town's building inspector was also building
inspector for the project. But he added that he hasn't seen a town lose USDA
loan money for any reason.

St Jean said he had no comment regarding what the USDA thinks about combining
the clerk of the works and the building inspector positions.

"What the town decides to do, we will have to look at it and see if we can
approve it or not," he said.

Cassata asked project manager Peter Springsteel Monday to have a conference call
with the selectmen, USDA representatives and any lawyers involved "to resolve
this once and for all."

Cassata said he wants to make a final decision regarding the clerk of the works
at the committee's Thursday meeting.

                             The Observer (London)

                                January 14, 2007

Cash: A leg-up for locals who need a home: Lisa Bachelor on a innovative way to
keep rural housing affordable for low-income families

BYLINE: Lisa Bachelor

SECTION: OBSERVER CASH PAGES; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 753 words


HOW DO YOU keep affordable housing affordable? While it's possible to control
the cost of a home the first time it goes on sale, as the property is sold on it
reverts to the normal market price.

While this is great for vendors, as it provides them with cash for a deposit for
their next home, it invariably takes the price beyond the pockets of those the
property was originally meant for.

But now councils across Britain are starting to consider a new way to get around
this conundrum - community land trusts. CLTs are not-for-profit organisations
which buy land and capture its value for an indefinite period for the benefit of
the local community. Long-term, affordable property can then be built on it,
with buyers paying only for the house itself, not the land; this still belongs
to the trust.

Local authorities have the power to dispose of land below market value for the
benefit of communities, and several schemes have been kick-started by farm ers
and landowners willing to sell their land at below market price for the benefit
of the community.

The Conservative party, which is to set up a working party to investigate the
expansion of CLTs, believes they could be used to halve the cost of new homes.
Shadow housing minister Michael Gove says: 'There are rural landowners who are
interested in providing an equity stake to people living in their community, and
there is government land, such as MoD and NHS land, that might be suitable but,
for a variety of reasons, has not become available for CLTs. But there are a
number of interlocking problems which have stunted the growth of these trusts.'

Stonesfield Community Trust was registered as a charity in 1983 by Tony Crofts
and two friends in west Oxfordshire in what had been a mining village in the
19th century. They did it in response to rising house prices, which they saw
were threatening the age pro file, social mix and economic range of the local
population. 'As anyone who has recently taken out buildings insurance will know,
the rebuild cost of a house is usually less than half the price paid for the
property,' says Crofts. 'Only by taking the land into some form of public
ownership can you take that out of the value of a transaction.'

Under the Stonesbridge model, all the houses are rented rather than sold to
members of the local community. The revenue from rent pays off loans used to
fund part of the project and the surplus funding services for the community.

Cornwall, meanwhile, has become the first county to set up a project to oversee
the development of CLTs. The two-year project, which began last April, is funded
by the Tudor Trust, the county council, the Cornwall Rural Housing Association
and Defra. It is run by the country's first full-time CLT project manager, Alan
Fox, who says: 'Sites have been identified and landowners found who will sell
their land at a discount, but all projects are still at planning permission
stage.'

Part of the project is being funded through council tax on second homes, and all
the agreements being drawn up specify that those buying through the trust must
have a local connection. The plan is that at least some of these will be sold on
an equity-share basis, with resale prices capped at below market price.

For example, if a property was being sold through the trust for £ 100,000, the
buyer could take out a mortgage on 75 per cent of that, with the rest owned by
the trust. If at resale the open market value had risen to £ 180,000, under a
CLT resale formula the sale would pay off the owner's £ 75,000 mortgage as well
as entitling them to 25 per cent of the increase in value, or £ 20,000. The
remaining equity would stay with the trust and allow the next owner to buy the
property for £ 95,000, the sum of the first buyer's mortgage and their equity
share.

'A CLT resale formula can be designed to provide enough equity - it increases in
line with the open market - for the outgoing household to have a deposit to go
on to full ownership and to subsidise the price for the incoming household,'
says Richard Clarke of the Building and Social Housing Foundation.

'It's a question of "half a loaf or no bread" for families who could not get on
the housing ladder otherwise. They are not going to get rich from a CLT, but
they can get enough equity to help them on their way.'

For more information, contact:

The CLT website, run by Salford University: www.communitylandtrust.org.uk.

Cornwall Rural Housing Association: www.crha.org.uk.

The Building and Social Housing Foundation: www.bshf.org.uk.
