                                US Official News

                            October 27, 2014 Monday

Ecumen, MnSCU form Partnership to Address Rural Senior Care Shortage

LENGTH: 1204  words

DATELINE: Mankato


Minnesota State University has issued the following news release:

Rural Minnesota is acutely impacted by the collision of a rapidly aging
population and a shortage of nurses in senior care. Ecumen, a non-profit senior
housing and services organization, which operates in many rural Minnesota
communities, and Minnesota State Colleges and Universities will collaborate to
help address that problem through a new workforce development initiative called
Ecumen Scholars. The effort is being coordinated by HealthForce Minnesota,
MnSCU's Center of Excellence in healthcare, and is supported by a $1.9 million
grant awarded to Ecumen by the Margaret A. Cargill Foundation.

Over two years, Ecumen Scholars will provide a variety of educational,
vocational and financial opportunities for nursing students at MnSCU colleges
and universities to pursue careers in rural senior health. The U.S. Census
Bureau estimates that 15 percent of rural Minnesota residents are age 65 or
older, and some counties have a population comprised of 20 to 25 percent
seniors. At a time when demand for senior care is increasing, rural Minnesota's
nursing workforce is shrinking as more nurses retire and fewer nurses replace
them.

"The Margaret A. Cargill Foundation's support allows us to take a creative
approach for connecting students and recent graduates in our state with an
extremely rewarding career opportunity and further learn how we can best fill
the rural employment gap in senior services," said Ecumen President and CEO
Kathryn Roberts. "At Ecumen, we find many of our best people were influenced
early on by working with older adults and having a great mentoring experience.
This initiative combines those two important elements to attract our state's
students to this critically important work."

"Our collaboration with Ecumen is a powerful example of how a creative
partnership can help meet an urgent need in Minnesota's workforce," said Steven
Rosenstone, chancellor of Minnesota State Colleges and Universities. "Ecumen
Scholars will have an in-depth clinical experience and the opportunity to live
and work in rural Minnesota. We are very pleased to be partnering with Ecumen to
educate and train more Minnesotans in a field that is critical to the health and
well-being of our seniors."

Ecumen Scholars will work with seniors at a variety of care levels and settings
including transitional care or rehabilitation, assisted living, dementia care
and home care. Key components of the Ecumen Scholar program include:

o Gerontological Clinical Rotations: Beginning with the 2014-2015 school year
clinical rotations will be established at Ecumen sites near MnSCU campuses.
Clinical locations will include Worthington, Mankato, Litchfield, Hutchinson,
Alexandria, Detroit Lakes, Moorhead and Two Harbors.

o Summer Nursing Leadership Fellowships: Beginning in 2015, students in nursing
programs at MnSCU universities will be able to apply for up to eight summer
Ecumen Nursing Leadership Fellowships. Each Fellow will receive a $3,000 summer
living stipend and will work closely with a Director of Nursing at an Ecumen
location for 120 hours, gaining valuable insights into clinical management and
leadership, and education on Ecumen Awakenings, which is Ecumen's integrated
care program to improve Alzheimer's care and life quality by reducing
psychotropic medications.

o School-Work Opportunities: Nursing students at MnSCU colleges and universities
will be notified of open positions at the Ecumen Scholar sites, which will help
them launch careers while attending school and transition to full-time
employment upon graduation.

o Financial Bonus Payments: Ecumen Scholars who graduate from nursing programs
at MnSCU colleges and universities and are hired within one year at rural Ecumen
locations will be eligible for financial bonus payments at the one-year,
three-year, five-year and ten-year anniversaries of their start date. These
bonus payments can be used to repay student loans, and the bonus amounts will
increase with each subsequent anniversary.

o Summer Scrubs Camp: In 2015, Ecumen employees and residents at Ecumen Scholar
sites will have the opportunity to send their high-school age children
free-of-charge to summer Scrubs Camp, which is co-Sponsored by MnSCU and
HealthForce Minnesota. Scrubs Camp is a five-day camp held at Winona State
University, Augsburg College and Saint Paul College dedicated to introducing
high-school students to the health care field. Up to 35 children will have their
$450 tuition covered by an Ecumen Scholars scholarship. This component of Ecumen
Scholars grew out of the fact that children with parents in the health care
field or exposed to the care relatives receive are more likely to enter the
field themselves.

Jody Bloemke, a resident of Mankato and a Minnesota State University, Mankato
alumna, has been hired to manage Ecumen Scholars. She has extensive experience
in communications, marketing, recruitment, rural issues and public outreach. In
her role as Special Program Manager at Ecumen, she will work closely with
HealthForce Minnesota. Bloemke previously served as Healthcare Workforce
Placement Coordinator at South Central College in North Mankato, Minn. She also
served as an administrator for the AgStar Fund for Rural America and managed
AgStar's community involvement program of 600 employee volunteers.

Her vast volunteer experience includes serving on the boards of the Minnesota
Agriculture in the Classroom Foundation, Minnesota Agriculture & Rural
Leadership and the Minnesota Agri-Women Board. Bloemke graduated Magna Cum Laude
from Minnesota State Mankato with a Bachelor of Science in Urban Studies and a
minor in marketing.

Ecumen is one of the nation's top 20 largest non-profit providers of senior
housing and services. Based in Shoreview, Minn., Ecumen operates in 38 cities in
Minnesota, Michigan, North Dakota, Wisconsin, Nebraska, Idaho and Tennessee.
Dedicated to empowering individuals to lead richer, fuller lives, Ecumen prides
itself on innovation and radically changing the way aging is viewed and
understood. Ecumen, founded more than 150 years ago, is a nine-time recipient of
the Minneapolis/St. Paul Business Journal's "Best Places to Work" award. More
information about the Ecumen Scholars program can be found at
ecumenscholars.org.

HealthForce Minnesota is a MnSCU Center of Excellence that works with partners
in education, industry, and communities across the state to increase the number
and expand the diversity of healthcare workers; integrate health science
education practice and research; and build capacity for education and industry
to collaborate to enhance patient care. It is the state's only legislatively
approved Center of Excellence for healthcare. Other MnSCU Centers of Excellence
exist in Energy, Engineering, Manufacturing, and Information Technology.

The Minnesota State Colleges and Universities include 24 two-year community,
technical, and comprehensive colleges and seven state universities serving more
than 430,000 students. It is the fifth-largest higher education system of its
kind in the United States.

                          Australian Financial Review

                           November 20, 2004 Saturday
                                 First Edition

China's property conundrum;
Report

BYLINE: Colleen Ryan SHANGHAI

SECTION: PERSPECTIVE; International News; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 789 words


A debate is raging over whether China's mammoth property boom could turn out to
be a bubble.

China's property bubble has been kicked around like an economic soccer ball
between bureaucrats and analysts in the Middle Kingdom. There is not only
virulent disagreement about whether the bubble is about to burst, but a dispute
about whether it even exists.

And the temperature has only risen since interest rates were increased last
month for the first time in nine years.

The row upon row of high-rise apartment blocks under construction wrapping
around the outskirts of China's larger cities like a cloak and dotting the
skylines of the city centres tend to support the bubble proponents.

From Beijing to Shanghai, from Nanjing to Qingdao, the sheer scale of the
residential construction would leave even the most ambitious Gold Coast
developer speechless. Whole boulevardes are lined on either side with brand new
complexes.

Has the most populous nation in the world launched a property bubble that could
threaten the foundations of its whole economy, as economists such as Andy Xie of
Morgan Stanley have been warning? Or is it merely catering to genuine demand, as
Beijing's Ministry of Construction claims?

Andy Xie states unequivocally that "the bulk of China's property demand today is
not sustainable". A well-known bear on this issue and widely quoted in China's
official media, Xie claims "the development of China's property market is the
determining factor for a hard landing or a soft landing rather than the
government's policies".

A number of vocal analysts in China support Xie's conclusions. Yi Xian Rong of
the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences claims: "The real-estate industry
threatens China's mainland economy and also threatens many regional economies;
it is the banks who will take the responsibility for the bubble popping."

Property values have risen an average of 13.4 per cent over the past year.
Investment in real estate is growing even faster. According to the People's Bank
of China, the country's central bank, loans to the property sector hit 2.1
trillion yuan ($325 billion) at the end of June, up 36 per cent year-on-year.

China's real-estate market can't be compared with that of any other nation.
Until 1998, housing was provided free by the government and/or employers. When
this policy was discarded, residents were mostly offered the opportunity to buy
land-use rights to their residences for a minimal sum. Land-use rights typically
last for 70 years. But any new demand for housing has to be met on the open
market.

In a country where a massive rural urban drift is under way and it is common in
the cities for three generations to share tiny one- or two-bedroom apartments,
the pent-up demand for housing is huge. The Construction Ministry relied on this
argument in a recent controversial report in which it maintains: "It is a
fallacy to say the property market is bubbling. There is no sign suggesting a
possible real-estate financial crisis."

The figures are compelling. Urban residents in China now amount to 490 million.
But this figure is expected to rise to 850 million by 2020, largely due to the
drift from rural areas.

There is also the pent-up demand arising from a desire to increase the living
space available. The average living space for an urban resident is now 23.8
square metres and the ministry expects this to rise to 35 sq m per capita by
2020.

Then there is the passive demand the city dwellers whose houses are being
demolished to make way for office buildings, Olympics sites and the World Expo
site in Shanghai.

The demand may be there but can the average Chinese wage earner afford to buy
many of these new apartments? Ying Yongli, a specialist in real-estate finance
research, says affordability is reaching its limits. In Shanghai, the ratio of
average house prices to average income is 15, compared with an accepted norm of
five.

Ying has also researched the speculative element in Shanghai real-estate
development and concluded, from a study of utility charges, that 16.6 per cent
of recently completed developments are vacant, while a healthier ratio would be
10 per cent.

The Construction Ministry counters the arguments on vacancy rates, saying they
are down 3 per cent year-on-year in absolute terms. And it points to the
mortgage default rates with the major banks, which at 2 per 10,000 are very low.

The central bank does not appear to share the sanguine view, noting in its
latest monthly report: "We must pay a high degree of attention to property
prices."

Misallocation of capital is one of the greatest risks for the economy. With
construction taking up half of fixed-asset investment in Beijing this year,
planners will be praying the return on investment is healthy.

LOAD-DATE: April 5, 2012

                             871 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                Hull Daily Mail

                              May 11, 2009 Monday

'I have never seen a road like it before'

SECTION: Pg. 16

LENGTH: 312 words


When a man from the ministry called at the sea of muck  which was Chesswick
Avenue, Keadby, in January 1953, he took one look at what was dubbed "The Worst
Road in Lincolnshire", went back and returned later with two more senior
colleagues.

The avenue was inches deep in oily, black mud, and dotted all over with deep
puddles.

Although just passable on foot, anyone who used it ended up covered in mud.

The Scunthorpe Telegraph columnist Wayfarer broke the story in his district
diary and commented: "I myself have never seen anything like it in the form of a
road before, and the people who have to live there and daily traverse this
glorified quagmire have all my sympathy.

"The paradox is that the Isle of Axholme Rural District Council want to make up
this road, yet it cannot - for the moment, at any rate. For it has not the
statutory powers to carry out this work on what is a private road.

"The inspectors who have just examined it are making their report to the
Ministry of Housing and Local Government, which will consider the legal position
to find out if it can authorise the Isle council to go ahead.

"If this proves to be the case, the RDC will borrow the money through the Public
Works Loan Board, make up the road and hand it over for maintenance to Lindsey
County Council's highways department."

The terrible state of Chesswick Avenue resulted from the development of the area
by the council and the Keadby Housing Association.

Lorries and other vehicles, heavily laden with material on their way to and from
building sites, were churning up the road.

Local people were very unhappy, prompting Coun GF Stones to tell his colleagues:
"I get insults right and left - and I have no answer to them."

Coun George Cheeseman added: "The people's complaints are absolutely justified,
and if the ministry says we can go ahead, we shall make a new road and it will
be a good job."

LOAD-DATE: May 12, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Daily Times (Pryor, Oklahoma)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          September 13, 2008 Saturday

Adair approves water purchase

BYLINE: Kathy Parker, Daily Times, Pryor, Okla.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 540 words


Sep. 13--Rural Water District 6 has approved selling water to the town of Adair
and Adair trustees want to buy it.

There is a Department of Environmental Quality mandate that will force the town
to spend around $400,000 for filtration to bring the water quality up to
standard at the current plant.

The problem, Water Superintendent Scott Martin said, is there is "no room for
growth. We're maxed out." The water plant is functioning at capacity and it is
not possible to add more customers. There are two developers waiting for water
to build housing additions.

If the town runs three miles of 12-inch water line from RWD 6, the town will
have an unlimited water supply. Engineer Dwayne Henderson said he thinks it will
be possible to run the water line for less money than implementing the
filtration system.

Trustees asked Henderson to complete a time and cost estimate on running the new
water line.

The sewer plant upgrade has been in the works since 1998. The project, estimated
at $327,700 at that time, is now estimated at $1.2 million. Trustees now must
decide where to get the money for the project.

Since borrowing government money has a cheaper interest rate and longer payback
option that other means, trustees will likely get the money from that source.
Government money requires environmental information documents, which include a
study to guarantee there are no American Burying Beetles on the construction
site. The beetles are on the endangered species list and have been found in
northeast Oklahoma. Trustees approved a $2,500 expenditure to complete the
beetle survey.

Henderson said federal funding will take six to nine months to complete the
application.

Adair currently has a loan from Rural Development that was made in 1991. The
40-year note has a $172,000 pay off. Options for financing include paying off
that loan before starting another. That will take most of the town's liquid
funds, but it will take away that payment.

After looking at all the options, trustees will try to get the loan from the
Oklahoma Water Resources Board. Water and sewer rates will have to be increased.
As one of the conditions of the loan, the town must make 25 percent more than
expenses each month to assure the OWRB it can repay the loan. The loan also
requires the town to have 10 percent of the amount of the loan in the bank.
Trustees voted to raise the rates. Raising the rates is one requirement of the
loan. The amount will not be definite until OWRB looks at the proposed rate
schedule and determines whether it will be sufficient.

"We're pretty much in the hole every month on the water side of it," Town Clerk
Melissa Crawford told trustees.

The OWRB loan, if approved, will have a 30 year pay off. Technically, OWRB
cannot make a 30-year loan until April, so the note will likely first be
approved as a 20-year note.

To see more of the Daily Times or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.pryordailytimes.com. Copyright (c) 2008, Daily Times, Pryor, Okla.

to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                            South China Morning Post

                             April 30, 2013 Tuesday

The HK$1 million first-home question;
Would selling discounted flats to young buyers undermine subsidised housing for
others?

BYLINE: Paggie Leung

SECTION: BUSINESS; Bricks & Mortar; Pg. 02

LENGTH: 490 words


When Lee Shau-kee, the chairman of Henderson Land Development, said in January
he would consider building homes and selling them for HK$1 million each to young
buyers, my friends were ecstatic and thought hard about how they could qualify
to buy one of them.

"Just HK$1 million for a 300-square-foot flat - although it may be in a rural
area in the New Territories - is a good deal for poor people like me," a
27-year-old friend, who earns about HK$15,000 a month but is still repaying
government loans for his university degree, said then.

As Hong Kong's home prices have soared to a level where one can barely find a
20-year-old flat for HK$2 million, a brand new private flat at HK$1 million is
really attractive.

But the proposal seems to have changed as discussions between Henderson, or Lee,
and the government continue.

At first, Lee suggested he would sell the flats at their construction price,
about HK$1 million per unit, as long as the government would exempt the
developer from the land premium. The government countered suggesting that Lee
donate his farmland, on which the government would build the flats. It
reportedly selected seven sites, most in the northeastern New Territories, where
it could build 10,000 homes for first-time buyers.

Last week, Lee reportedly told a Chinese-language magazine the government
believed selling the flats only to young people would be unfair to others.

The report said that although Lee wanted to charge the buyers just for the
construction costs, the government thought that was not feasible and might
challenge its subsidised housing policies.

It would prefer to sell those flats at 60 per cent to 70 per cent of the market
price, the report said.

Although the concrete details are yet to be finalised and announced, those of my
friends who were interested in the original scheme said that the new proposals
were a blow to them.

"I think they are moving away from the original idea," the friend I mentioned
earlier said. "The scheme may no longer be just for young people like us.

"New flats in the New Territories are selling at about HK$2.5 million, so after
discounts, it will be more than HK$1.5 million to HK$1.75 million. HK$500,000
may sound a small amount to some people, but it will take me more than a decade
to save that amount," he said in despair.

Another friend said: "I knew it was too good to be true! I bet there will be
more stringent requirements on buyers in future, and it may even be more
difficult to apply for it than other schemes subsidised by the government."

Of course, the Hong Kong government must ensure that the public resources be
used fairly and properly. At the same time, I advised my friends to adjust their
expectations, although they may have done so already.

So how do you think the scheme should be structured so that Lee's idea of
helping young first-time buyers and the government's wish to keep its policies
fair to all can be fulfilled at the same time?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              The Washington Post

                 July 10, 1999, Saturday, Monday, Final Edition

Board Passes Golf Course Development; Plan for High-Priced Housing Draws
Supervisors' Support

Libby Copeland, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: PRINCE WILLIAM EXTRA; Pg. V01

LENGTH: 804 words


A 2,073-acre upscale golf course community near Haymarket got the blessing of
the Prince William Board of County Supervisors on Tuesday, over the objections
of neighbors who fear the development will mar the county's rural western end.

By a vote of 7 to 1, the board approved a series of zoning changes to the design
for Dominion Golf and County Club, which will consist of 2,800 high-priced
detached homes and town houses, a golf course, swimming pools and tennis courts,
and 250,000 square feet of office and retail space, all on the one-time site of
Disney's controversial theme park.

The developer, Pennsylvania-based Toll Brothers Inc., said it recently has made
substantial accommodations to appease area residents. They worry that ground
water irrigation for the golf course will suck their well dry and that the
influx of families will swell traffic on nearby Route 15 and overburden schools
and taxpayers. The developer has the right to build as many as 2,800 homes on
the property.

John Elcano, a Toll Brothers vice president, said the recent proffers will
enhance the company's ability to "build an upscale community that we think is
necessary to attract the upper-level executives and, in turn, attract their
businesses."

But neighbors at Tuesday's meeting urged the board to delay its decision,
complaining that the company's measures were inadequate and might even worsen
the situation by stealing open space for a larger golf course and moving the
locations of several public facilities.

"Simply let the full [zoning] process unfold," entreated Fred Potter, 41, an
adjacent land owner. "Time's our friend. Two thousand acres in its entirety
essentially transforms the western end."

Only Ruth T. Griggs (R-Occoquan) voted against approving the changes. Supervisor
Edgar S. Wilbourn III (R-Gainesville), in whose district the project is planned,
praised the project's high-end housing, as well as proffers mandating
transportation improvements and an extensive water study to test the effects of
the development on the ground water supply. He said these additional measures
constitute a step up from what would have been built under the bare minimum
zoning requirements.

The developers "addressed a lot of the concerns to maintain the rural atmosphere
in the community," Wilbourn said Thursday.

Development has not come easy to this tract of land, perched just north of
Interstate 66 and west of Route 15. A subsidiary of Exxon sparked intense
opposition in 1991 when it obtained a rezoning of the land--then known as
Waverly--and tried to build a housing development of similar size to the current
plan. That effort was put on hold because of a slump in the real estate market.
In 1994, Disney sought to transform the parcel into a historical theme park,
Disney's America, but abandoned the idea after county activists and
preservationists rallied against it.

Last year, Toll Brothers purchased the bulk of the original 2,500-acre Exxon
property and announced its plans for a luxury housing development amid protest
from residents hesitant to accept the trappings of more growth.

But because of the existing zoning, houses on this land are inevitable, and Toll
Brothers says a recent amendment setting aside 250 age-restricted homes should
sweeten the deal by reducing the number of possible children who will live
there. Supporters of the $ 700 million project also point out that the houses
will be high-end, selling for an average of more than $ 275,000 and topping out
at $ 500,000, according to a lawyer for the developer.

Changes approved Tuesday included adding land for nine holes to what will become
a 27-hole golf course, possibly moving the locations of a fire station, library
and recreational spaces, and making transportation and buffer improvements.

The public debate Tuesday shed light on long-running questions over water in
western Prince William, where all the older communities depend on wells. Several
area developments under construction, such as gated retired community Heritage
Hunt and gated golf community Bellwood, will have water and sewer lines, as will
the Dominion property.

Neighbors of the proposed development voiced concern over the accuracy of the
pending hydrology study, even after the public outcry prompted an eleventh-hour
agreement Tuesday night expanding the developer's responsibility for residents'
well-water supplies.

"If our wells do have a problem, that's going to be our problem to pay to
connect to city water when it comes," said Diana Nicholls, 54, of Gainesville.

Elcano said Toll Brothers plans to start basic infrastructural improvements next
month and to have some houses finished and for sale in spring 2000. Well
irrigation for the golf course will not begin until the hydrology study is
completed, he said.

                    February 6, 2002 Wednesday Final Edition

Rising house prices hit record high in January: Increases average 13.8% in year,
30% over 5 years: HOUSING

SOURCE: The Edmonton Journal

BYLINE: Paul Marck, Journal Business Writer

SECTION: Business; Pg. H3

LENGTH: 480 words

DATELINE: Edmonton

The city's hot real estate market continued to sizzle in January, as the average
selling price of a single detached home leaped to a record $162,780, up 13.8 per
cent from a year ago.

Sales for the month reached a new high of 1,054, a 26.2 per cent jump over
January 2001.

Figures released by the Edmonton

Real Estate Board show market activity in 2002 continues a trend.

Home prices made moderate annual gains of four to five per cent from 1997-2000,
and 7.8 per cent in 2001 before striking double digits in the new year.

The total of all those increases adds up to 30 per cent, or $37,545, over the
last five years.

The median, or middle, price for all homes sold in January was $152,500.

The trend is likely to continue, as banks lowered long-term mortgage rates
Tuesday by a third of a percentage point.

Low interest rates are credited with driving Edmonton's strong housing markets
over the past year, said Ken Shearer, president of the real estate board.

"It can only be a positive thing," Shearer said.

Other factors continue to influence the housing market as well.

"We continue to have an influx of job seekers, with low interest rates and taxes
... (making for) a very affordable housing market in the area," Shearer said.

There were also marked gains in other forms of housing. Condo prices rose 17.6
per cent over the year, reaching a record high of $98,554, while duplex and
rowhouse properties fetched an average $141,376, a 25.5 per cent gain.

The average residential price for all kinds of housing reached $142,188 -- 12.4
per cent over a year ago.

Momentum of higher-priced home sales also continued to move upwards. In January,
48 per cent of all home sales were above $140,000, compared with 17 per cent
above that figure in 1997.

Total sales through Multiple Listing Service for January reached a new benchmark
of 1,211 for residential, rural and commercial properties.

January dollar volume of $178.6 million was a whopping 49 per cent higher than a
year ago.

CHECK OUT WEB SITE FOR DEALS

Homeowners befuddled by a grocery list of mortgage options have a new Web site
to turn to for help.

QuickenMortgage.ca is a Web site started by Intuit Canada allowing homeowners to
search for the best mortgage deal, even beyond their home city or province.

The tool is offered through an agreement with the Mortgage Alliance Co. of
Canada, the largest independent mortgage broker in the country.

First-time buyers can use the service to decide how big a mortgage they can
afford, and they can apply online. Within 24 hours a mortgage consultant will
contact them, explaining options offered by 30 major lenders.

People with an existing mortgage can analyse it, look for something better, and
be alerted when there's an opportunity to get ahead by breaking or locking in
their mortgage.

Market plan 'on minister's map'

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 256 words


Jon Walkerjwalker@c-dm.co.uk

A BID for a £3 million bridging loan to build a new livestock market in
Holsworthy has been given greater clout by a ministerial visit.

Secretary of State for rural affairs Caroline Spelman was briefed about the
importance of the new cattle market on her trip to Holsworthy.

She said: "I've seen the existing market in Underlane and heard how the new one
is crucially important for the whole area.

"It will safeguard jobs and create new ones for young people.

"It's an ambitious and interesting example of regeneration benefiting a wide
community. Holsworthy is definitely on my map now."

group, said: "We can't sell the Underlane market to pay for the new one, as
while it was being built there would be nowhere local to sell livestock.

"Until the new one opens we can't sell the existing one. So a bridging loan is
needed."

The loan application is due to be decided in a few weeks.

Mr Quincey said: "Of course we hope the minister will support the bid.

"The new market will safeguard 112 jobs and when the new business park alongside
it opens 250 or so jobs will be created."

He also said to attract the loan, sale of the old site had to be virtually
guaranteed to ensure repayment.

He said that a deal with Tesco for part of it was almost agreed.

No housing developer has  yet emerged as a contender for the remaining land.

                           Cape Argus (South Africa)

                            July 16, 2014 Wednesday
                                   E1 Edition

Minister launches 'mega' housing projects

BYLINE:  Marianne Merten and Sapa

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 458 words


FIFTY "mega" housing projects of no fewer than 10 000 homes will kick-start the
delivery of 1.5 million homes over the next five years, says Human Settlements
Minister Lindiwe Sisulu.

The projects, which brought all three spheres of government together, would get
under way in the next 100 days, as part of an effort to tackle the housing
backlog of 2.3 million homes, said Sisulu before her R29 billion budget vote in
Parliament yesterday.

The "housing opportunities" in the projects would be a mix of state-subsidised
homes, rental accommodation, serviced sites and so-called "gap homes" for those
earning too little to qualify for a bond and too much for a state-subsidised
house. The national government would unlock land, and provinces would provide
services.

Local government would provide land, if available, and manage the housing
waiting lists. In addition, youth brigades would be established for each project
to boost work opportunities and skills training.

"The waiting list requires us to do nothing less than that... We can't go into
30 years of our freedom with a huge backlog..." said Sisulu.

Delivering her budget vote in Parliament, Sisulu said there had been a drastic
drop in the delivery of houses - an average drop of 25 percent over the past
five years.

"We have huge shortages of land for housing, which is a primary need |for our
purpose. We particularly require well-located land close to work opportunities."

She also said alongside housing delivery pledges, there would be a housing
database to prevent fraud and queue jumping. It would also reprioritise state
housing for the indigent, vulnerable and elderly, rather than the large numbers
of 18-year-olds currently on the waiting lists.

"There has been a lot of abuse, making it difficult to understand if the backlog
of 2.3 million households... is actually correct," Sisulu said.

The minister also announced the N2 Gateway project would be taken over as a
national project to fast-track completion.

Other initiatives over the next year included a new programme for youth and
women empowerment in construction, with its own deputy director-general, the
merging of the rural housing loan fund into the National Housing Finance
Corporation to streamline housing financing, and a housing summit.

There would be consultations with the private sector to restart social
partnerships. Sisulu said big employers would be encouraged to provide assisted
housing opportunities for their workers.

With some 2 200 informal settlements across South Africa, Sisulu was upbeat
about meeting the target of 1.5 million housing opportunities by 2019.

"We believe this is within our range of possibility," she said, adding |that
between 2004 and 2009 the |state provided 1.2 million housing opportunities.

                    Berwickshire News & East Lothian Herald

                                 July 15, 2009

Demand for affordable housing is growing;
7,000 people currently looking for homes in the Borders

BYLINE: Janice Gillie

LENGTH: 865 words



HIGHLIGHT: DEMAND for affordable housing in the Borders continues to grow
despite Scottish Government protestations that they are supporting the building
of new homes in the region to the tune of £7.2 million this year.


Borders Choice Homes, the agency which advertises housing association homes
available for rent, has 7000 people registered looking for homes and for every
Berwickshire Housing Association house or flat that becomes available there can
be around 100 people applying.

Family circumstances such as overcrowding, the break down of family units which
means that two not one house is needed, and young people moving out of the
family home, all add to the pressure.

Allocation of homes that become available is causing frustration and during a
recent Scottish Housing Regulator inspection of Berwickshire Housing
Association, inspectors highlighted inconsistencies within the letting system
being used across the region, particularly with the use of medical priority
passes.

Politicians are also growing increasingly concerned about social housing
allocation policies across Scotland in general and during a debate in the
Scottish Parliament last week, Housing Minister, Alex Neil, said: "We are
currently reviewing the allocations guidance that we issue to local authorities
jointly with the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities. We hope to consult on
that guidance later this year."

Roxburgh and Berwickshire MSP John Lamont wants to see the Scottish Government
do more to improve the system of allocating affordable housing in rural areas.
And in particular he wants to see social landlords, including councils, given
more powers to take into account local connections when deciding on housing
applications and transfer requests.

Speaking after questioning the Housing Minister in the Scottish Parliament, Mr
Lamont said: "One of the issues raised with me time and again is the
difficulties people in rural communities face when wanting to transfer to a
house within their own community, only to find that they are so far down the
housing list that this is impossible.

"While this is obviously a difficult problem to deal with and increasing the
overall supply of affordable housing to meet the needs of rural communities and
small towns must be the best way forward, we need to look at other ways of
making sure that local people get access to local housing."

John added: "I am strongly of the view that if the government were to allow
social landlords more scope to take into consideration local connections when
deciding on housing applications and transfer requests, then this would be a
very welcome step. It would help ensure that local people get access to local
houses."

Berwickshire Housing Association chief executive Helen Forsyth sympathises with
this view and would like to see more help given to people wanting to move from
one part of the region to another because of their work commitments.

Adding to the difficult housing situation is the fact that Berwickshire Housing
Association's housing stock continues to reduce as former Berwickshire District
Council tenants exercise their right to buy, while at the same time the housing
association cannot get the grants or loans to build new affordable homes.

Housing stock levels have gone down by 50 over the past five years - 3% of its
stock - while over the past financial year the recession has put the brakes on
building new homes - £200,000 was spent on new builds, considerably less than
the previous two years when BHA spent £1.5 million and £2.7 million building new
houses.

Responding to the current financial situation BHA is currently applying for
charitable status which may assist in accessing grants unavailable to them at
the moment, and they are also looking at working together with other social
housing providers in the region, including housing associations such as Eildon,
Waverley and Scottish Borders Housing Association, plus Scottish Borders
Council, to see if a joint approach to funding would benefit the area.

Helen Forsyth explained the problem: "100 people apply for every house that
comes up for rent. Local people can't get a house with us and I would love to
build them houses but can't get grant or borrowing at the moment.

"We still wish to build new homes but I have to be very careful and because of
the economic climate we have had to slow down. We are talking to all our
partners in the Borders to see if there is a mechanism for building more homes.

"There is growth in the demand from local people needing local homes and
statistics show that people want to stay here."

The association owns land for affordable houses, and plans to buy another  large
site during this financial year, but cannot finance the building at the moment.

Neighbouring East Lothian has similar problems and Shelter Scotland is asking
local residents to support the campaign for more social housing at an event in
Haddington on Friday, July 17, 2009.

The charity will be asking members of the public to draw their ideal home as
they urge Scottish Ministers to fund the construction of 30,000 affordable homes
to rent by 2012.

Graeme Brown, director of Shelter Scotland, said: "We urge everyone to come and
visit the Shelter Scotland Living Room in Haddington and show their support for
the campaign. Their drawing and support will hopefully help us persuade the
Scottish Government to pledge more money through this year's budget."

                        SUNDAY TELEGRAM (Massachusetts)

                       May 23, 2004 Sunday, ALL EDITIONS

First-time home not such a stretch;
 Program helps buyers get in the door

BYLINE: Karen Nugent; TELEGRAM & GAZETTE STAFF

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 837 words

DATELINE: CLINTON


- Below-market mortgages for first-time home buyers are available in
participating cites and towns through a new program offered by the Massachusetts
Housing Partnership, a quasi-public state agency.

The mortgages, which target low- and moderate-income buyers, can increase a
buyer's purchasing power by 20 percent using a two-mortgage system; the second
mortgage is subsidized by the state.

About a dozen area bankers and real estate agents attended a seminar last week
at Town Hall on the ''SoftSecond'' loan program offered by the housing
partnership.

Locally, the program is administered through the Clinton Office of Community and
Economic Development, which recently received a $10,000 grant to get the program
started in town. Grants were also awarded to Fitchburg, Leominster, Framingham,
Hudson, Marlboro, Worcester, and the Rural Community Assistance Program, which
serves several towns in Central Massachusetts, from Auburn to Westminster.

Donald A. Lowe, director of the economic development office, said the seed money
will likely be enough for two families to buy homes. But partnership officials
at the seminar said that if enthusiasm is shown in a community, more money is
available from a pool of funds.

''I think this is a great program,'' Mr. Lowe said. ''I think we can help a lot
of people here, but it is incumbent on the community to demonstrate the need.''

Heather Hennessey Whelehan, home ownership director at the partnership, told the
group the SoftSecond program began in Boston in 1991 to curtail racial
disparities (so-called ''red-lining'') in mortgage lending practices.

Now the program is used to assist first-time home buyers by splitting the
mortgage in two, Ms. Hennessey Whelehan said.

By offering below-market-rate mortgages, she said, a buyer's purchasing power
goes up by 20 percent. For example, a buyer could jump from being able to afford
a $169,000 house or condo to a $215,000 home.

Buyers are required to make a 3 percent down payment, and to pay the principal
and interest on a first mortgage, usually 77 percent of the purchase price, with
a conventional 30-year fixed-rate mortgage. Buyers do not have to pay points or
for mortgage insurance.

On the SoftSecond mortgage, usually about 20 percent of the house price, the
interest payment is subsidized by the state for the first nine years. The
borrower pays interest after 10 years, but no principal until the eleventh year.
The partnership provides the subsidy for the second mortgage payments to the
bank up front, Ms. Hennessey Whelehan said.

For a monthly first mortgage payment of $517.33, a buyer would pay $30.08 a
month on the second mortgage for the first five years and the state would pay
$90.23 a month. The buyer's second mortgage payments gradually increase in years
six through 10. At year 10, the subsidy would be zero, and the buyer would pay
$161.24 for the second mortgage.

Most of the state's major banks, she said, are offering the program -- 42 banks
in all. Representatives of Clinton Savings Bank and Hudson Savings Bank were at
the seminar. Mr. Lowe said Sovereign Bank is already participating.

Under the program, the home must be lived in by the buyer, and be in a
participating community.

''It helps people get in. It helps people get their feet in, and then they pay
at the end. It's not a freebie,'' Ms. Hennessey Whelehan said.

To qualify, a prospective buyer must meet household income guidelines defined by
the federal Housing and Urban Development Department as 80 percent of the area's
median income. In Clinton, a one-person household would have to earn $43,500 or
less per year; and a four-person household $55,450, according to the
partnership's Web site.

Another requirement is that buyers attend approved home-buyer training courses,
which prompted several questions from the audience. Some real estate agents
questioned whether not attending the classes could kill a deal just before
closing.

The classes, according to Gina Govoni, the partnership's program operation
manager, are given at various sites for a small fee and are usually held in four
sessions. Area classes are available in Worcester, Fitchburg, Gardner and
Winchendon.

''We consider them very important,'' Ms. Govoni said of the classes. ''They
can't just get out of it.''

Since 1991, Ms. Hennessey Whelehan said, the SoftSecond program has helped more
than 7,100 families buy their first homes, and it has had only 25 foreclosures.

The Housing Partnership was established by the Legislature in 1985 to help
develop affordable housing. It is governed by a seven-member board appointed by
the governor.

Home buyer classes

WORCESTER -- NeighborWorks Home Ownership Center of Worcester, 674 Main St.,
offers monthly first-time home-buyer classes, down payment assistance,
rehabilitation loans, post-purchase counseling, credit counseling and
foreclosure prevention services. For more information, call Kelly Filock or
Maritza Morales at (508) 791-2170.

                               The Times (London)

                           December 6, 2005, Tuesday

First-time buyers get help with 500,000 new homes

BYLINE: Jill Sherman and Jenny Davey

SECTION: HOME NEWS; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 633 words


John Prescott yesterday announced ambitious plans to build an extra 500,000
homes in the next decade in order to help first-time buyers.

The Deputy Prime Minister also proposed an overhaul of planning laws, including
a windfall tax for landowners and incentives for local councils to put more
brownfield sites up for development.

New measures to help first-time buyers were also detailed. Homebuyers would only
have to find 75 per cent of the property's asking price, with the Government and
mortgage lenders splitting the remainder equally between them.

Halifax, Britain's biggest mortgage lender, the Nationwide Building Society and
the Yorkshire Building Society have already signed up to the scheme, which
should be available from next October.

The scheme will be open to key workers, social tenants, those on the housing
register and other first-time buyers identified as priorities by regional
housing boards in England and Wales.

In the Government's response to the Barker report on housing, Mr Prescott
announced a new target of 50,000 extra homes a year till 2016 -a 33 per cent
increase on current levels.

Although less than the number proposed by Ms Barker, the plan was welcomed by
housebuilders and organisations representing the homeless. But Mr Prescott faces
intense opposition in the South and East of England, where the public is
resisting plans for new developments in densely populated areas.

Rural campaigners said that it would inevitably result in more greenfield sites
being developed. Mr Prescott also launched a number of pilot schemes to
encourage local councils to bring derelict sites back into use and to identify
disused hospital and military land.

Property developers and landowners complained about Gordon Brown's plans to levy
a windfall tax on the profits gained after selling land with planning permission
last night.

The move, which was disclosed in The Times last week, is expected to raise about
£ 500 million, which would be recouped by the Treasury. Most would be
redistributed back to councils, probably in proportion to land sales. The tax is
expected to be between 20 to 25 per cent of profits and would be invested
locally in infrastructure, such as new roads, hospitals and schools.

Critics claimed that the tax, which would be introduced after consultation in
2008, would stifle new development and hit farmers badly.

Stuart Robinson, the head of planning at CB Richard Ellis, said: "The whole
concept of the planning gain supplement is utter madness. The problem with the
housing market, as we were told by Kate Barker and the Chancellor, is that there
is insufficient supply and the prices are unaffordable. So why introduce a
measure that will act as a deterrent to developers and which will increase the
costs of production?"

Mike Harrison, a partner in the landed-estates group at accountants Saffery
Champness, said: "This land tax will be another nail in the coffin for farmers.

Poor profitability and the delay in single-farm payments until next spring has
put many farmers under severe cash-flow pressure this year, but diversification
has offered an alternative income stream."

Mr Brown also announced a new scheme to allow savers to invest in houses, office
blocks and shopping centres, by approving the introduction of new tax efficient
property investment vehicles. The new real estate investment trusts are intended
to boost investment in the private, rented residential and affordable housing
sectors, and to increase the quality and supply of commercial buildings for
businesses. The trusts will also offer savers a way to invest in property free
from the dangers associated with buy-to-let investments. Liz Peace, chief
executive of the British Property Federation, said: "We are extremely pleased
with the news, but the devil will be in the detail."

                                 Sacramento Bee

                          September 1, 2004, Wednesday

Factory-built homes appear in California in record numbers

BYLINE: By Andrew LePage

LENGTH: 1313 words



With California home prices marching higher, a growing number of people are
dismissing past concerns about the structural integrity and design of
manufactured housing.

Shipments of factory-built residences to California home sites are on pace to be
the highest in 14 years -- demand that outstrips what state manufacturers can
satisfy, according to the California Manufactured Housing Institute.

Put on permanent foundations and on land owned by the home buyer, factory-built
homes can be 10 percent to 25 percent less expensive than constructing
comparable stick-built houses, experts say. From some consumer reactions,
neighbors may not even know the difference.

"Is this a real house?" asked many of the hundreds of looky-loos who traipsed
daily through two factory-built homes on display at the California State Fair.

"They think it's going to be the trailer that Grandma lived in," explains
Michelle Hammerbach of Sacramento's Karsten Homes, which is modeling a
1,500-square-foot manufactured house at the fair featuring alder cabinets, a
9-foot-high flat ceiling and Berber carpet.

The price: $ 95,827 with delivery and installation.

Sales of the homes -- built in sections on an assembly line and then trucked to
the home site -- totaled 5,055 through the first half of this year, up 24
percent from 2003.

The homes are coming not only from 11 factories in California -- including
Karsten in Sacramento and Silvercrest, Fleetwood and Skyline in Woodland -- but
also from plants in states such as Arizona and Oregon.

Shipments from out-of-state factories are on the rise because demand in those
states is weaker than here and California manufacturers can't keep up with the
state's demand. Most Golden State factories have four- to 12-week backlogs and
have been reluctant to expand their facilities because of the considerable
investment required and the cyclical nature of the business.

California factories are on pace to produce about 7,500 manufactured homes this
year, which would be up 8 percent from last year.

While impressive for the industry, that would represent less than 4 percent of
the 200,000-plus new housing units -- single-family and attached -- that the
state Building Industry Association predicts will be constructed this year.

Today, most higher-end factory-built homes are placed on private property rather
than in a mobile home park, where the homeowner leases the land. Of those put on
private land, most are in rural or semirural areas, often in foothill locations
such as Grass Valley.

Placing the homes on urban lots and in suburban subdivisions is less common, but
those uses are viewed by some in the industry as having huge growth potential.
State law ensures that manufactured homes can be used in residential
neighborhoods, though local governments can require them to blend in
architecturally with surrounding homes.

Locally, the Sacramento Housing and Redevelopment Agency staff has proposed
developing a subdivision of about 65 factory-built homes on seven acres the
agency owns in unincorporated Sacramento County.

The goal is to offer 20 to 40 percent of the houses at relatively affordable
prices for families earning up to 80 percent of the area median income. For
example, currently a family of four would have to earn $ 51,280 or less to
qualify.

Detached three- and four-bedroom homes, if installed today, would range from
about $ 156,000 to $ 270,000 at the site, according to a consultant's report
commissioned by SHRA. The median price of an existing home is $ 299,000 in
Sacramento County, while it's $ 400,000 for new homes.

In addition to buying the home and the land, the buyer of a new manufactured
home typically faces an additional $ 50,000 to $ 70,000 in expenses for such
things as a perimeter foundation, site preparation, utilities, a site-built
garage, driveway and, in rural areas, a well and septic tank. For particularly
steep sites, as well as those requiring specialized septic systems, the costs
can be much higher.

Still, the savings can amount to tens of thousands of dollars, compared with the
cost of site-built homes. The price of the latter has roughly doubled in the
Sacramento region over the past five years, while wages have grown significantly
less.

Although low mortgage rates and innovative financing have so far kept the market
humming, the California Association of Realtors estimates that the percentage of
households that can afford a median-priced home has declined to 26 percent from
41 percent over the past year.

The price of a factory-built home is kept down by a combination of factors --
for instance, the relatively low pay of the factory workers, who reportedly
average about $ 12 to $ 15 an hour with incentives. Many are hired without
previous experience and are trained in specific tasks.

In addition, the indoor assembly-line construction process ensures minimal
delays no matter what the season and the ordering of home-building materials en
masse helps keep costs relatively low.

Some manufactured housing dealers report that about one-third of all buyers are
paying cash, often because they've sold a house in a coastal market for far
more.

Despite the growing demand for prefabricated homes, the industry faces a host of
challenges. They include more restrictive and sometimes more costly consumer
financing compared with loans for site-built homes, difficulties meeting some
lenders' appraisal requirements, and the swelling cost and thin inventory of
available home sites.

Some would-be manufactured home buyers are overwhelmed by everything that goes
along with buying the house, such as finding a parcel they can afford, lining up
contractors and addressing potential issues such as the need for wells and
septic systems.

Typically the entire process -- from securing the land to having the home built
and installed -- takes from four to six months, said Neal Hocker, general
manager of the Kasco Homes dealership in West Sacramento.

"Some (sales) reps will tell you two to three months and it's just not
realistic," Hocker said.

Still, those in the manufactured housing industry are quick to note that
building a comparable site-built house could take two or three times longer.

Manufactured housing dealers say that with many buyers the time savings is
nearly as important as, or even more so than, the money they expect to save.

But for Gunnar Reiersen, a Rosemont resident who toured the two factory-built
homes on display at the State Fair one recent afternoon, the savings is key.

"Probably the price would be the most appealing thing," said Reiersen, 60. "And
the overall quality seemed pretty nice."

Government building officials, consumer groups and housing industry experts say
quality varies by manufacturer, but factory-built homes can rival stick-built
homes in structural quality.

The factory-built homes at the fair serve two purposes: Help generate sales for
the manufacturers and dealers involved, and expose thousands of people to a new
generation of factory-built homes. Fair officials pegged the 2003 fair
attendance at just over a million.

"If our industry is honest with itself, most people don't know diddly-squat
about our product yet," said Bob West, president of the California Manufactured
Housing Institute. "For a guy with a (dealership), it would take 10 years to get
100,000 people on his lot. At the fair he could do it in two weeks."

Sharon Wagner, a Los Angeles-area resident visiting the fair with three children
in tow, said she was surprised to find a manufactured home "this lovely inside."

"I don't think you can tell (it's factory-built), and for a lot of people it
would be affordable," she said.

                          Australian Financial Review

                             June 15, 1989 Thursday
                                  Late Edition

BANK TIPS CONTINUED STRONG ECONOMIC CONDITIONS FOR SA

BYLINE: COLIN McLACHLAN

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 607 words


The South Australian economy is set for a prosperous entry into the 1990s,
according to a report from the State Bank of South Australia.

The bank said the State's economy had shown marked growth in the March quarter,
with increased levels of employment, housing construction and manufacturing
activity, and economic conditions would remain strong until some time next year.

Meanwhile, the Centre for South Australian Economic Studies predicts that while
the Federal Government is trying to rein-in the economy, South Australia will
probably not slow as quickly as other States.

The centre's research manager, Mr Barry Burgan, said a slowdown was expected,
but South Australia's economy would remain buoyant into next year.

And the State's largest building society, the Co-operative Building Society,
reports that demand for commercial loans for investment is at record levels.

The State Bank's report said South Australia, which has the highest jobless
rates in the country, dramatically improved its employment level in the March
quarter.

On a seasonally adjusted basis, the number of employed grew 7,800, or 1.2 per
cent, over the previous corresponding quarter.

In the year to March, employment increased by 4.9 per cent. This compared with
3.8 per cent across Australia in the same period.

Despite concern over the long-term impact of high interest rates, the State's
economy had outperformed the national economy.

"The fact that newspaper employment advertisements remain near their
pre-Christmas highs, and the likelihood of continued levels of activity in both
the residential and non-residential building industries, suggest continued
employment growth over the remainder of 1988-89 and into 1989-90,"it said.

Stronger retail sales, higher residential building activity and sustained
non-residential building levels were other indicators of the robust state of the
economy.

Demand for new homes was holding up despite the high cost of finance, the bank
said.

However, both residential and non-residential building activity was likely to
slow by 1990 as interest rates took hold.

But the high cost of finance does not seem to have deterred commercial
borrowers.

Co-operative Building Society figures show Adelaide is experiencing unusually
high levels of commercial investment.

The Co-op has recorded more than $37 million in commercial loan approvals in the
past three months.

For the 1987-88 financial year, it recorded only $39 million in commercial loan
approvals.

The Co-op has approved more than $88 million in commercial loans in the past 11
months.

The building society's general manager, consumer and corporate finance, Mr
George Vosvotekas, said: "Levels of demand for commercial loans have never been
stronger, and even the dramatic increases in interest have failed to temper that
demand.

"Uncertainty surrounding interest rates has seen speculators and small investors
leave the market.

"However, this has been more than offset by demand for finance by the large
developers and professional investors who are in the market for the long haul."

The strong level of manufacturing activity in the State is also expected to be
maintained well into the next financial year.

The State Bank report said increased manufacturing activity reflected a high and
unsatisfied demand for new motor vehicles.

For example, General Motors Holden had a backlog of orders for the new Commodore
in March equal to almost four months' production.

A good year is also tipped for the State's rural and agricultural sector
following recent rains.

Apart from wool, rural commodity prices have maintained the rises seen through
1987-88 and are expected to remain firm through 1989.

                              The Nation (AsiaNet)

                             March 30, 2015 Monday

Land inequality inflicts poverty on small farmers

BYLINE: Salman Abduhu

SECTION: Vol. XXIX No. 29

LENGTH: 951  words


The land inequality in provinces of Pakistan is reflected in glaring income
inequality, as large landowner income is 31 times higher than the average
income.

The inequality has also imposed a state of chronic poverty for the landless,
tenants and even the small farmers.

The feudal-tribal order has ensured the continuation of patriarchy, which rules
with an iron hand in rural Pakistan.

Women have almost no freedom to make independent choices about socialization,
health care, childrens education and marriage, voting and voting choice, and
even cell phone use.

However, the level of conservatism varies with land size and pattern of tenure."

This was stated in a report issued by the Pakistan Institute of Labour Education
and Research (PILER).

The report "Profiles of Land Tenure System in Pakistan" has been authored by Dr
Kaiser Bengali, senior economist and Advisor to Chief Minister Balochistan.

The study, first in many years, attempts to document the land tenure patterns as
they currently exist in three provinces of Pakistan.

Covering 1,200 respondents (with equal representation of male and female), the
study records the disparity in incomes, food consumption, housing quality,
impact of floods, indebtedness, and treatment of women in different categories
of landowning and non-landowning classes.

The conclusions are intended to guide the political debate regarding land issues
towards more nuanced directions.

The analysis of land tenure patterns in the provinces of Pakistan shows
considerable variation.

Rural Sindh and Nasirabad Division of Balochistan are highly feudal, with 70-85%
of the rural labour force working as tenants on sharecropping basis on lands
belonging to large landlords.

By contrast, south Punjab has under- gone radical changes, with sharecropping
largely replaced by large- scale self-cultivation or leasing -a la corporate
farming, report says.

Irrespective of the difference in land tenure patterns, there are some
constants.

Asset (land) inequality is stark.

While a handful of large farmer families own thousands of acres of land,
thousands of small farmer families own less than 5 acres each and thousands of
tenants (in Sindh and Balochistan) farm plots of less than 5 acres each.

The inequality is indicated by the fact that, for 6 districts in 3 provinces,
88% of small farmers (holding less than 12.5% of land) own 49% of land and 1.5%
of large farmers (holding more than 150 acres of land) own 8% of land.

Land holding and control over land by large farmers is said to be actually
larger with many de jure small and medium landowners being de facto tenants.

"The centuries old sociopolitical structure of rural society in Sindh and
Balochistan has remained more or less unchanged.

The lack of employment and educational opportunities in secondary urban areas
and the substandard quality of civic services has failed to create the pull
effect for the rural population to break out of the feudal-tribal stranglehold."

According to report, the peasantry is locked in villages that are characterized
by derelict infrastructure, mud and straw housing, mud roads, unhygienic water
supply, garbage dumps and sewage pools (in the absence of waste disposal
facilities), and sub-standard educational and health facilities.

The 2010 floods had washed away most of the villages and villagers who returned
faced difficulty locating the site of their village and of their houses.

The situation presented opportunities to re-build planned villages on high
ground and with drainage to protect villages from future river and rain
flooding.

However, the feudal-tribal leadership opposed relocating the villages as they
would lose control over their workforce and their vote banks -and, most of all,
their debts.

The floods of 2010 affected large farmers and small farmers and tenants
differentially.

Generally large farmer houses are on higher ground and remained protected from
the ravages of the floods.

They also managed to move their livestock to higher ground.

Small farmer and tenant abodes were located on low-lying land and were submerged
and washed away along with their meager belongings.

They remain vulnerable to flood damage in future as well.

An indication of the differential losses is provided by the fact that large
farmer losses accounted for less than one-fifth of the annual income, compared
to 123% for the sample as a whole.

The debt situation throws interesting light on differential vulnerability, with
the debt to income ratio ranging from xx for large farmers to xx for the sample
as a whole.

Access to formal credit decreases with declining land size.

Large and medium farmers and lessees have access to formal sources of financing
for most of their credit needs and tenants have no access at all.

The money lender and the shopkeeper -in that order -are major sources of
financing for small farmers, while the landlord, shop- keeper and money lender
-in that order -are major sources of credit for tenants.

The purpose for which a loan is taken also reflects vulnerability.

All large farmers have obtained loans for productive purposes: agricultural
operations and purchase of land, livestock or supplies.

However, two-thirds of small farmers and over 80% of tenants have obtained a
loan for consumptive purposes: flood losses, medical expenses, etc.

Loans for consumptive purposes do not lead to creation of new assets and has to
be repaid from current income or from new loans.

That small farmers and tenants have to incur debt for meeting household expenses
is indicative to economic stress.

And that they have to incur debt for meeting police and court related costs is
indicative of involvement in criminal cases which they cannot manage through
connections a la the landed classes.

                                Birmingham Post

                              May 7, 2009 Thursday
                                  1ST Edition

Councils and eco groups rail at new homes target;
Office of National Statistics figures ridiculed at inquiry

BYLINE: PAUL DALE

SECTION: Pg. 15

LENGTH: 770 words


Government estimates for the number of new households likely to be formed in the
West Midlands over the next 17 years came under severe attack yesterday as
councils and environmental groups combined to oppose plans to build up to
440,000 new homes across the region.

Figures published by the Office for National Statistics, predicting a 20 per
cent increase in the number people looking to move into their own homes by 2026,
were openly ridiculed at a public inquiry into revisions to the Regional Spatial
Strategy..

The West Midlands Regional Assembly, representing 38 local authorities, said the
figure was "simplistic" and simply assumed that past levels of growth would
continue despite the impact of the worst economic recession in living memory.

If the highest level of new build being considered is finally approved, the
number of dwellings in the West Midlands will increase by a fifth.

That would be an 88 per cent increase on the figure approved by the government
and councils only five years ago and would involve building on the green belt.

Regional assembly housing spokeswoman Ada Wells said projected growth in
population assumed that the number of economic migrants from eastern Europe
arriving in the West Midlands would continue at a high level.

But this was unlikely given the weakness of the pound, which meant that EU
citizens would be able to earn more by being employed in their own countries.

The impact of the recession, which was likely to be felt more keenly in the West
Midlands than other UK regions, would drive down mortgage approvals and result
in far fewer households being formed than the government imagined, she added.

"The point I want to make is the total uncertainty associated with these
projections," Ms Wells said.

Council leaders said they fear they will be forced to release too much land for
house building, resulting in a rush by developers to "cherry pick" greenfield
sites.

In a written submission, the assembly said: "If the government is serious about
ensuring that everyone has the opportunity to live in a decent home which they
can afford, then a range of interventions are required including a substantial
injection of public resources into both brownfield land assembly and building
affordable houses, creating a sustainable mortgage market and addressing income
inequalities." The Campaign to Protect Rural England described household
projections as "wishful thinking", adding that no account had been taken by the
government of the collapse in the housing market.

Estimates for the number of new homes were defended by Jane Hinton, from the
Department for Communities and Local Government.

She told the inquiry that a rapidlyageing population and further increases in
life expectancy meant that just over half of all households in the region would
be headed by someone aged over 55 by 2026.

Such people were likely to remain in the homes they had lived in for years,
resulting in a severe shortage of vacant properties coming on the market.

It was "crucially important" that the region planned for an appropriate level of
housing growth, she added..

Planning inspector Alan Richardson, who is chairing a public inquiry into
revisions to the West Midlands Spatial Strategy, has no shortage of advice on
the appropriate number of new homes to be built by 2026.

Every participant has a view, and they are all different. At the top end are
representatives from construction. The House Builders' Federation thinks the
West Midlands requires 514,000 homes in order to meet demand. That would be
about twice the number councils are planning for.

Easily at the bottom end is the Campaign to Protect Rural England. The group
suggests 285,000, which it says could be adjusted as circumstances dictate.

The most important figure is the 445,600 proposed by consultants Nathaniel
Lichfield.

Their projection is being put forward by the Government Office for the West
Midlands as an alternative to the Regional Assembly's proposal for 365,500.

GOWM was told to produce an independent consultants report by Housing Minister
Baroness Andrews, who said she feared the region's councils were seriously
underestimating the new homes required.

The purpose of this inquiry is to test the validity of the housing figures,
which the region's councils suggest are being massaged by the government which
is intent on forcing through massive growth in new dwellings in order to address
what it says is a serious housing shortage. Mr Richardson will make a
recommendation to government after the seven-week inquiry but the final say will
be with ministers.
