                    Daily Journal of Commerce (Portland, OR)

                           September 20, 2010 Monday

DJC Archives: Greyhound arrived near train station in 1985

BYLINE: Theresa McKinlay

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 1415  words


This month we look back at events of September 1985, when Greyhound's new bus
terminal on Sixth Avenue was dedicated and BOLI's commissioner trumpeted a
ruling in a key court case.

Sept. 6, 1985

Home sales on the rise in metro area

Sales of Portland-area single-family homes and condominiums continued to rise
during August.

Residential real estate representatives say sales are being spurred by continued
low interest rates coupled with the depreciation of Portland's housing stock.

The 1,113 units sold in August was 1 percent more than during July and an
11-percent increase over August 1984, according to statistics released this week
by the Oregon Multiple Listing Service.

The active sales pace was accompanied by falling home prices. The average sales
price in August was 4 percent lower than the previous month and 6 percent lower
than during August 1984.

The average home sold in the Portland area during August cost $69,651 compared
with $72,580 in July.

Sept. 9, 1985

Fred Meyer store site draws ire of residents

Fred Meyer Inc. and nine northeast Portland neighborhood associations are locked
in combat over the siting of a proposed "superstore" in the middle of a
residential area.

The neighborhood group says the giant store has no place in their area, violates
the city's comprehensive plans and would clog streets with an increase in
traffic.

Fred Meyer, which has more than 25 stores in the Portland area, wants to build a
153,000-square-foot outlet on the Hyster Co. site at Northeast Halsey Street and
29th Avenue - a site enhanced by its proximity to the Banfield light-rail
project.

But to do so, Fred Meyer must first win a zoning variance from the city, and the
neighborhood groups are determined to stop that from happening.

Sept. 10, 1985

Agreement with IBM expected to give software firm a boost

Timberline Systems Inc. has signed a second distribution agreement with
International Business Machines, making Timberline the first company to have its
vertical-market software remarketed by IBM.

The agreement makes the Portland-based business software developer and marketer
IBM's sole construction software supplier to its network of about 2,400
authorized dealers. The pact follows an agreement signed in June that made
Timberline construction and architecture/engineer software programs available to
IBM stores and sales representatives.

Timberline considers the agreement a monumental endorsement because it marks the
first time IBM has remarketed such a software program that is written by another
company and sold under that company's name, said Larry Briggs, assistant to the
president at Timberline.

Sept. 11, 1985

Greyhound dedicates new bus terminal near train station

Greyhound Lines Inc. left the driving to Portland city officials Tuesday as
Commissioner Margaret Strachan snipped the red, white and blue ribbon to open
the company's new bus terminal at 550 N.W. Sixth Ave.

Commissioner Mildred Schwab looked on during ceremonies to dedicate the new
terminal, located next to the Union Railroad Station. The red brick bus terminal
is designed to harmonize with the brick and stucco finish of the train station.

The building already has won a citation from the American Institute of
Architects' Portland chapter for its distinctive design. The building features
two 15,000-square-foot areas that are free of columns thanks to the roof being
affixed by thick cables to eight paired steel pylons.

The architect for the project was Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. The Portland
Development Commission helped arrange purchase funding for the new site.

The building occupies two full blocks from Glisan to Irving between Fifth and
Sixth avenues.

The modern terminal, a stark contrast to Greyhound's former home at 509 S.W.
Taylor St., includes about 55,000 square feet of enclosed space.

Skidmore, Owings & Merrill also served as mechanical, electrical and interior
consultant. Robert Perron Associates was hired as landscape consultant.

Emerick Construction Co. was general contractor for the building. Markman Inc.
of Portland was mechanical subcontractor and Cherry City Electric of Salem was
electrical subcontractor.

Sept. 17, 1985

150 workers affected by hospital merger

As many as 150 employees at Holladay Park Hospital and Physicians & Surgeons
Hospital will have been laid off permanently by the time the two hospitals merge
Oct. 1.

In addition, 70 to 100 employees will be shifted from Physicians & Surgeons to
Holladay Park, Hans G. Wiik, administrator of the new hospital - to be called
Holladay Park Medical Center - told reporters at a Monday news conference.

Metropolitan Hospitals Inc., the parent company of six nonprofit Portland
hospitals including Holladay Park Medical Center, said the consolidation will
save money simply by improving efficiency.

Sept. 18, 1985

Port unveils plans for business parks

The Port of Portland made official Tuesday its plans to launch two separate
business parks in the Columbia Corridor, linking both projects into a single
package and starting its search for a developer to build the parks.

Dubbed the Columbia International Business Centers, the parks will include 45
acres near Portland International Airport and 24 acres in the North Rivergate
Industrial District.

The project, which could mean a $20 million investment by its developer, will be
marketed internationally as a Pacific Rim trade hub. The venture is the port's
first business park and is what the port calls the largest multiple-tenant
project in the Columbia Corridor.

The airport site is located east of Northeast 82nd Drive and north of the
Columbia Slough. The Rivergate site is located along North Marine Drive across
from Terminal 6.

The airport property has a proposed building area of 600,000 square feet; the
Rivergate property has 400,000 square feet. Both sites will need improvements
that will be financed by the developer.

Sept. 20, 1985

Discrimination case hailed as landmark

A Roseburg woman has won a $16,000 award from the city of Roseburg in what
Bureau of Labor and Industries Commissioner Mary Wendy Roberts hails as a
"landmark" sex discrimination case in Oregon.

The Oregon Court of Appeals ruled Wednesday that Debra Mobley, an administrative
supervisor of the city transit system, was entitled to back pay, interest and
retirement contributions because her job was substantially similar to jobs held
by three men in her department whose annual salaries were $6,000 to $8,000
higher.

"The court realized that there is a sex-based discriminatory system operating,"
Roberts said at a Thursday morning news conference in Portland. "Besides Deb, I
think there are important benefits to women in the state of Oregon. "

Roberts said the ruling may encourage more women - and perhaps men - to file sex
discrimination suits because the Mobley case introduced the term "substantially
similar work. " Mobley handled the same administrative tasks as her male
coworkers within the city's transportation department, but received pay more
similar to a groundskeeper.

"That substantially similar work standard is more strict than a comparable worth
standard," Roberts said.

Comparable worth standards require employers to allot points for skill,
responsibility, danger and other job factors.

Sept. 30, 1985

New mortgage guidelines require higher incomes

Lending institutions are tightening their mortgage loan guidelines to combat an
increasing number of loan defaults.

The stricter guidelines affect borrowers unable to pay at least 10 percent down
on a home. Those borrowers now must have a higher income to qualify for loans
than necessary previously.

The trend has occurred during the past six or seven months, Portland-area
lenders say. It follows similar restrictions imposed by secondary lenders,
including The Federal National Mortgage Agency, or Fannie Mae.

A Fannie Mae change requiring higher combined household income to buy a dwelling
with less than a 10 percent down payment becomes effective Tuesday (Oct. 1,
1985).

Guidelines now allow only 25 percent of a household's gross monthly income to be
used for housing payments on a mortgage loan with 5 percent down payment. The
former Fannie Mae regulations allowed 28 percent of gross income to be used for
housing.

"DJC Archives" is a collection of excerpts from past issues of the DJC that runs
the third Tuesday of each month. Article excerpts are reprinted exactly as they
appeared at the time of publication. Share your own memories of Portland's built
history by contacting Theresa McKinlay at djcspecialprojects@verizon.net

                           September 11, 2006 Monday

Kazakh leader pleased with western region economy

LENGTH: 613 words


Excerpt from report by Kazakh TV on 7 September

[Presenter] President Nursultan Nazarbayev's working visit to three regions of
the country is now over. The president visited several facilities in (western)
Aktobe Region today. [sentence inaudible]. In all, 16m tonnes of wheat will be
harvested and hundreds of factories will be opened in the country this year.

[Correspondent] The president started the second day of his working visit to
Aktobe Region by attending the opening ceremony of a new office of Otan
[pro-presidential] party's [regional] branch. [sentence inaudible]. Afterwards,
the president addressed the party members. He said that opening such offices in
every region of the country proves that the Otan party is not a mere public
association, but an influential political organization. Nazarbayev urged members
of the party to take an active part in future political campaigns.

[Nazarbayev, in Kazakh] Political parties in every civilized and democratic
country have a heavy workload. Political campaigns are coming up in our country.
The election to the Majlis [lower chamber] will be held in 2009, elections to
the Maslikhats [local representative bodies of power] will be held next year,
elections of heads of districts and rural communities are going to be held this
year as well. Members of the Otan party will have to win all of these elections.

[Correspondent] [sentence inaudible] Members of the Otan party must cherish the
integrity of various ethnicities in our country.

[Bakhytzhan Zhumagulov, acting chairman of the party, captioned] We must learn
from the experience of Japan, Singapore and Malaysia. There is stability and
economic development in these countries thanks to large and mature parties which
have been ruling the country for many years. We must turn the Otan party into
such a mature party.

[Correspondent] After this, the president stopped by a construction site of a
residential cottage settlement on the fringes of the city. The course of
implementation of the national housing programme in Aktobe Region is one of the
fast in the country. [break in reception] President visited one of these
cottages. [Video shows the president in a private house of a local family] The
Shyntasovs bought on mortgage their two-storey house with five rooms and a
garage. The price of the house is cheaper than in Almaty or Astana. One square
meters of the house costs 400 dollars. The president said more such houses will
be built in our country instead of multi-storey apartment blocks.

[Nazarbayev, in Kazakh] The owner of this house is a doctor, his wife is a
teacher. The income of this family allows them to get a mortgage for such house.
There are lots of people building houses themselves. In all, 200,000 people in
Kazakhstan are queuing up to build such houses.

[Correspondent] The president, having visited three regions and got acquainted
with the harvest and the pace of implementation of industrial and innovative
programme, assessed highly the economic and social development in these three
regions. The wheat production area is developing fast in North Kazakhstan
Region. Factories that meet international standards are being opened in Kostanay
and Aktobe regions. For example, 40 enterprises have been opened in Aktobe
Region alone last year, another 60 will be opened this year.

[Nazarbayev, in Kazakh] A 3bn-dollar plant is being built in [western] Atyrau
Region, a large plant with 4,500 new jobs was commissioned yesterday beside a
railway in the steppes of Aktobe, all of these construction sites around Aktobe.
There is no unemployment in Aktobe Region at all.

                       Charleston Gazette (West Virginia)

                            October 2, 2007, Tuesday

Housing boom seen as possible for state

BYLINE: Peeks

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P1D

LENGTH: 538 words


Never mind the home mortgage crunch and the housing slowdown, consultant Ken
Auvil touts anew the prospect of a billion-dollar homebuilding industry in West
Virginia, coupled with "green" or energy-conserving and environmentally friendly
new homes.

Auvil, a former West Virginia legislator and builder for 45 years, issued an
updated brochure on homebuilding in the middle of the hot summer burning with
housing news.

A flurry of national reports came on the drop in the housing market. They told
of foreclosures blamed mainly on the collapse of the subprime mortgage market.

West Virginia, however, stands among states affected less by the collapse and
the impact of subprime mortgages. They are adjustable rate mortgages, which cost
borrowers more when market interest rates rise. An increase hurts working-class
mortgage holders.

Auvil indicates that there's a better way, including do-it-yourself housing,
which he has advocated through the years. It also means "sweat equity" whereby
one can save on building a new home by doing some of the work oneself. Painting,
for instance, might save $1,000 or more.

"According to the 2000 U.S. Census, over 100,000 West Virginians are living in
obsolete trailers, dilapidated shacks and depreciation-prone homes," Auvil says.
"The report basically says West Virginia is leading the nation in shacks and
rural sprawl."

Yet at the same time, Census data puts West Virginia's rate of homeownership
above the national average of 67 percent. In other words, poor housing blotches
the state and yet it abounds with sites for a rebuilding jubilee.

Auvil sees need for public and private efforts to make mortgage money available
for owners to replace shacks and dilapidated housing. Replacements and other new
housing generate jobs, business and taxes for city, county and state.

The construction of 1,000 single-family homes generates 2,448 jobs in
construction and related industries, $79.4 million in wages and more than $42.5
million in federal, state and local tax revenues, according to the National
Association of Home Builders.

From such sources and his own, Auvil's vision grows for a $1 billion
homebuilding industry in the Mountain State.

Apparently, the West Virginia delegation in Congress shares the goal. They
joined other House members in voting for the Extending American Homeownership
Act of 2007.

It calls for lower or no down payment on government-backed loans for borrowers
who can afford mortgage payments but lack cash for upfront payments. It extends
the maximum life of a loan to 40 years from 35. It also doubles the loan cap up
to $829,750.

The bill awaits Senate approval. It's designed to broaden the authority of the
Federal Housing Administration, which was created during the Great Depression.

The update serves "green" building advocates. Projects by Auvil and his crew
include schools and other public buildings in West Virginia and surrounding
states, all built with green design to use a minimum of energy for cooling in
summer and for warming in winter.

Auvil keeps an office at the WV Homes Team & Builders Network, Belington, WV
26250-0846; e-mail: wastenotwantnot@ meet.net, or he can be reached at (304)
823-2533.

Peeks is former business/labor editor of the Gazette.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                  March 21, 1997, Friday, 2 Late Tampa Edition

Council gives cool reception to mayor's downtown plan

BYLINE: RICHARD DANIELSON

SECTION: TAMPA & STATE; Pg. 3B

LENGTH: 450 words

DATELINE: TAMPA



Charlie Miranda says he would like to see the northern end of downtown Tampa
come back to life as much as the next guy, but not at taxpayer expense.

With that in mind, Miranda and several City Council members gave a  skeptical
reception Thursday to Mayor Dick Greco's proposed use of federal  funds to help
finance the redevelopment of the Kress block on N Franklin  Street and the
construction of a parking garage.

The problem is that if the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
ever foreclosed on the $ 10.5-million loan, the city would have to repay it
using federal community development grants.

The city gets about $ 5-million a year in community development funds and  uses
the grants for sidewalks, park improvements, economic development and a  variety
of projects.

"We are truly putting at risk some of our (Community Development Block  Grant)
dollars," council member Bob Buckhorn said. "If these things go  belly-up, we
run the risk of a lot of good projects out there taking a hit."

The Kress block sits across Florida Avenue from the new federal courthouse  and
is now home to three historic but mostly vacant stores - the 68-year-old  Kress,
which is on the National Register of Historic Places, as well as the  Woolworth
and the Newberry buildings.

As proposed, the Doran Jason Group of Tampa would renovate all three  buildings
into up to 70 apartment lofts, plus office space, stores,  restaurants or bars,
or a health club.

The city would use $ 4.5-million of the HUD loan to secure a second mortgage
for the project, which would encompass 147,900 square feet. The Doran Jason
group would get a $ 2.873-million conventional loan for the rest of the
project.

City officials also hope to use up to $ 6.47-million from the federal loan  to
help the Doran Jason Group build a parking garage with up to 1,500 spaces.

The key question is how much of their own money will developers be willing  to
put at risk.

City director of business and community services Fernando Noriega said
developers have discussed having $ 3.5-million in equity in the Kress project,
but he conceded that no formal development agreement will be negotiated until
after the city applies for the HUD loan.

Miranda and council member Rudy Fernandez said they will need evidence that
developers stand to lose their own money before they can sign off on the
project.

"If it's not there, then I can't look at it favorably," Miranda said. "I  don't
want to stop development, but on the other hand, I don't want to put the
citizens of the city of Tampa at risk even for one cent."

A second public hearing is scheduled for 10 a.m. March 27.

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                       May 28, 2001 Monday, Home Edition

Heralded project may yet get rolling

BYLINE: MELISSA TURNER

SOURCE: AJC

SECTION: News; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 1637 words


The 15 acres of grass and weeds are nearly waist-high now. The billboard with
the artist's rendering of a Buckhead-quality mixed-used development has faded.
Trash has accumulated inside the 6-foot-high, padlocked chain-link fence.

This is the dubious site of the $139 million Historic Westside Village, the
highly touted model for "New Urbanism" in the inner city.

Originally conceived a quarter-century ago and unveiled in its most recent
incarnation in the late 1990s, the ambitious project at Martin Luther King Jr.
Drive and Ashby Street was supposed to launch the revitalization of a blighted
area that was once an African-American commercial hub.

The undertaking would include a Publix supermarket, housing, offices, movie
theaters and as many as 1,500 jobs. Buildings were demolished and bulldozers
cleared the property two years ago. A job fair was held in December 1999. Little
has happened since, although city officials say they're within weeks of revving
up the project again.

"Historic Westside Village is a model of how complicated and difficult intown
mixed-use developments can be," says Kevin Hanna, president of the Atlanta
Development Authority, the project's master developer. "Especially when the
developments are in African-American neighbohoods which have suffered
disinvestment for the better part of 30 years."

The project --- a cornerstone of the ADA's vision for redeveloping the inner
city --- is a partnership of the authority, Harold A. Dawson Co. and the
Integral Group.

Like many big public works efforts in poor neighborhoods, it will be financed by
a combination of conventional loans, private equity, bonds and federal loans and
grants. But while the financial framework has been in place since at least 1999,
the money has hardly flowed freely.

Hanna says, "This is really par for the course."

The course has had pitfalls at every turn, from federal funding snarls to
cautious banks and skeptical retailers. The result: The development is nearly
two years behind schedule. The supermarket, townhouses and an office building
were to open at the end of last year. Construction was to be well under way now
on a hotel and movie theaters.

But workers have yet to pour cement for the first phase. Developers are just now
negotiating a construction loan. Only Publix has signed a lease, albeit with
strings attached, while Pizza Hut, a video store and one other retailer have
offered letters of intent. Preleasing on the apartments or offices has not
begun.

"The community is feeling discourged and rejected again," says Byron Amos, head
of the area's Neighborhood Planning Unit L and chairman of the influential Vine
City Civic Association.

There are some signs of progress.

A shiny metal flagpole has been installed in fresh cement in front of one
billboard of historic photos depicting a bustling neighborhood in a bygone era.
A ceremonial groundbreaking and another job fair are set for June.

Most importantly, the developers earlier this month jumped a hurdle that could
have broken the back of the entire project.

The ADA board of directors took the unprecedented step of agreeing to provide a
guaranty for a $4 million construction loan to get the project rolling. The loan
will be repaid by tenant leases. Publix, for example, is expected to pay
$344,644 in rent plus a percentage of sales each year on its 20-year lease.

"As a board we have to really show we believe in what we are doing," says Barney
Sims, an ADA board member and civic activist on the Southside. "The quicker we
can bring Publix out of the ground and make this a reality, the quicker the rest
of the project will come together."

With the ADA backing the project, the bank apparently agrees. "We are confident
that the major hurdles have been cleared, and we anticipate that retail and
office tenant signing, as well as residential development, will now proceed at a
faster pace," says Gwendolyn P. Adams, a First Union senior vice president.

The slow pace --- at least until now --- can be tied directly to the location, a
once-vibrant black neighborhood near the Atlanta University Center and the
Georgia Dome that has fallen on hard times. Within a mile radius of Historic
Westside Village, half the residents live in households with annual incomes of
less than $15,000.

Yet, winning the support of the community, not wooing national retailers, was
the biggest hurdle developers had to cross, they say.

"The key breakpoint to advance this project was to have a community-driven
component to it," says Michael Dobbins, the city planning commissioner. "Once
you do that, however, it does make it harder and it takes more time."

In earlier efforts, outsiders plotted suburban-style shopping centers without
regard for what residents wanted. When the ADA took on the project, community
leaders were brought to the table. They asked for a major grocery, affordable
housing, spots for locally owned shops and restaurants in the center, upscale
aesthetics and jobs for neighborhood residents.

Most of the wish list was met in the planning stages. But to many in the
community the project appears to be at a standstill.

Skepticism is replacing hope. "This sits in a zone in which every economic
initiative the city can offer to developers is available, and for some reason it
is not happening," says Amos.

A look at the Publix deal reveals some of the reasons why.

Negotiations with the Lakeland, Fla.-based grocer took more than a year.
Conflicts over parking spaces and minority hiring requirements were eventually
resolved. But the cautious chain demanded ADA provide contractural assurances
the rest of the project would be completed within a reasonable time frame, or
Publix could change the terms of the deal.

"Publix's concern was they wouldn't be an island unto themselves," Hanna says.

Those assurances were given in December. But without an airtight lease from the
anchor tenant, First Union National Bank demanded its own contractural guaranty
from the ADA board that it would build out the center.

"The supermarket wanted assurances they probably wouldn't require in other areas
of the city, and as a result the bank needed more assurance than it would
typically require in other national supermarket chain-anchored developments,"
Hanna says.

"Woven through all of that are the requirements that come part and parcel with
federal, state and local funds. And overhanging all of that are the community's
needs, which often are diametrically opposed to any one of those."

The requirements for federal funding almost tripped up the project, as well.
Some $6.8 million in funds from U.S. Housing and Urban Development were used to
acquire the property. And $9.2 million in Atlanta Empowerment Zone funding was
to go for demolition and site clearing.

Meanwhile, ADA borrowed $3.3 million from First Union in a bridge loan. That
loan was to be repaid with the Empowerment Zone funds next month.

However, the development authority didn't follow federal procurement guidelines
when it hired Thrasher Trucking to handle excavating work last year, failing to
advertise the contract properly. Hanna says it was an oversight.

Because of that irregularity, the state Department of Community Affairs, which
oversees Empowerment Zone funding, wouldn't sign off on the grant.

With the First Union loan due in June, Hanna had to scramble. He would create a
separate for-profit company, Inner City Development Corp., to build the project
and receive the federal money as a loan.

After a review, the state attorney general last week ruled that the manuever was
legal because for-profit entities getting loans don't have to follow the same
federal procurement standards.

State and city redevelopment officials remain high on the project. Dobbins says
the village, even only in its blueprint stage, has been a catalyst for
revitalization.

Since Westside was announced, the Atlanta Housing Authority has redeveloped a
public housing project into the Magnolia Park mixed-income community across the
street. A short walk up Ashby Street, a new 45-home subdvision, Savannah at
Washington Park, is under construction.

And the ADA and Clark Atlanta University broke ground in March for Heritage
Commons, a $21 million residential complex across MLK from the village. All
these new residents and the thousands of students at the Atlanta University
Center are expected to provide business to Publix and the additional shops and
restaurants.

"We've got the people to support it," says Drewnell Thomas, head of Neighborhood
Planning Unit K across Ashby Street. She has lived in the neighborhood for 30
years and was involved in the early planning. "But now I get discouraged when I
see other developments going on all over town and I don't see anything happening
at Historic Westside Village. We've got to put aside some of the barriers and
move forward."

"Anytime you are mixing public and private dollars, especially public dollars
that have the various strings attached that they tend to have, it is pretty
difficult to marry it all together in a conventional timeline," says Integral
Group's Egbert Perry, who developed the Centennial Place mixed-income apartment
complex that replaced the Techwood Homes/Clark Howell public housing community.

That project has been six years in the making; groundbreaking on its
Kroger-anchored retail center only happened this month.

Perry expects a similar timeframe on Historic Westside Village.

"When you build a project in the city you are constantly in discovery with
respect to market factors and the conditions of the site and availability of the
necessary funds to abate some of the problems," Perry says. "Rest assured this
project will take seven to 10 years."

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                            February 11, 2001 Sunday

SHA banking on $35 million investment  ;
 Officials hope neighborhood sparks revitalization

BYLINE: JOHN REYNOLDS STAFF WRITER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 388 words


When the John Hay Homes were built a little over 60 years ago, the final cost of
the cramped, barracks-style apartment complex was $2.7 million.

Since then, the cost of affordable housing has gone up. The estimated cost of
the Madison Park Place Development, for example, is $35 million.

Officials at the Springfield Housing Authority say that figure includes more
than just the infrastructure at the 33-acre site and the cost of building the
150 rental units and 44 lease-to-own homes. Madison Park Place, according to
officials, is envisioned as the spark that ignites a flurry of revitalization
throughout the east side neighborhoods.

Jacqueline Richie, project manager for the SHA, said construction of the rental
units cost about $17.8 million. The lease-to-own homes came to about $6.9
million.

The figures include infrastructure costs such as roads, streetlights and sewer
lines.

The other $10 million was spent on architectural, engineering and legal fees.

Funding for the project came from a variety of sources:

* $12.2 million from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's Hope
6 program. The Hope 6 project created a pool of federal money for local housing
authorities to reconfigure troubled apartment complexes. Madison Park Place
apparently is the first Hope 6 project to be completed in Illinois.

* $12.2 million from LR Development, a private company that was brought in to
develop and manage the rental units.

* $7 million from other funds, such as Illinois Housing Development Authority
loans, federal loans and local funds.

* About $3.2 million is expected to be raised from the eventual sale of the 44
homes.

Even though Madison Park Place has replaced the John Hay Homes, the old housing
project will not be completely forgotten.

Bill Logan, executive director of the Springfield Housing Authority, said the
original, 60-year-old dedication plaque from the Hay Homes will be installed at
Madison Park Place's park.

After all, even though the last years of the old development were less than
ideal, the homes were a part of Springfield's history, and thousands of good,
solid people  - including police officers and at least one mayor - came through
the Hay Homes, Logan said.

"The John Hay Homes meant a lot to a many families in Springfield," Logan said.
"We don't want people to forget that."

                 The Mountaineer (Waynesville, North Carolina)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             August 19, 2016 Friday

County loses out on bid for low-income apartment project

BYLINE: Vicki Hyatt, The Mountaineer, Waynesville, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1169 words


Aug. 19--Haywood County learned this week a proposal that would have allowed the
original county hospital to be turned into low-income housing wasn't among those
receiving coveted tax credits, something necessary for the project to go
forward.

The county and town had been working with Landmark Developers, a Winston-Salem
company that specialized in restoring historic buildings through the use of tax
credits, to submit the redevelopment plan that would have created 54 one- and
two-bedroom units that could be used as affordable housing.

Landmark assumed the $8,000 cost of putting the county building that houses the
central administrative offices for Haywood County Schools, on the National
Register of Historic Places.

In the first round of competition for the tax credit dollars, the Haywood
project received a perfect score. But by the time the August were announced
Landmark's application on behalf of Haywood was not among those receiving the
credits.

The 2016 housing credit awards were given to 46 projects in 36 counties to
create 3, 243 units, according to a news release from the county. Awards were
also made to 13 tax exempt bond projects totaling 2, 163 units.

"This is certainly a disappointment to the county," said Commission Chairman
Mark Swanger. ""We believed we had the best chance to receive an award with the
new criteria for 2016. We will be looking at our options for the building, but
for now we don't have any immediate plans. The county will continue to make
affordable housing a priority."

As part of the tax-credit application process, the county agreed to sell the
building to Landmark for $200,000 and to loan Landmark $450,000 at 0 percent
interest over the next 30 years to finance the project.

Without receiving the tax credits, however, the plan cannot move forward.

In 2010, the county was poised to sell the building for $1.27 million, again to
be used for low-income apartments, but the project never materialized when tax
credits for both historic preservation and low-income tax credits.

Before the Landmark agreement, the county was unsuccessful in finding a buyer
for the building, despite a fleeting interest in the site as a regional mental
health administrative services building and a 2013 study in partnership with the
town of Waynesville and the UNC-Chapel Hill School of Government to identify
financial incentives and potential investors.

Early on in the application process, Swanger said the project had been
previously unsuccessful because of the way the rules were structured requiring
housing projects to be within a half-mile of medical facilities, grocery stores
or pharmacies. That put rural areas at a disadvantage, and the 2016 process
eased that portion of the application requirements.

Patsy Davis, executive director of Mountain Projects, said she has closely
observed the tax credit award process for more than 15 years.

"It has become more and more obvious as other counties in North Carolina
struggle with affordable housing, the awards for tax credits are harder to
obtain, especially for Western North Carolina. I am greatly disappointed that
this project was not funded. Our community is in desperate need of more
affordable rentals. I felt that after two other times of submitting this
project, the third time would be a winner."

Davis said she has already started reviewing the qualified allocation plan for
next year in hopes that if this project is not resubmitted, there will be
another potential project for Haywood.

"We haven't received an allocation since Smokey Meadows was funded following the
floods of 2004," she said. "I have a lot of hope that our newly formed Housing
Task Force will be successful in finding some local solutions since tax credit
awards seem like a long shot."

The county successfully lobbied to have the rules changed in a way that rural
communities would not be penalized.

I have a lot of hope that our newly formed Housing Task Force will be successful
in finding some local solutions since Tax Credit awards seem like a long shot.

Waynesville partnered in the application process.

"On behalf of the town, I thank the county and Landmark Developers for their
tireless efforts," said Mayor Gavin Brown. "I remain optimistic and see a
continuing opportunity, not a failure."

The original portion of the building on North Main Street in Waynesville was
constructed in 1927 and housed the first public hospital in the state of North
Carolina. It is still in used by the school system.

There were two additions as the hospital grew, but space constraints led to a
new facility being built in Clyde, which opened in 1977. The hospital additions
were eventually converted into county office space, where were used by the
social services department until 2012.

County Manager Ira Dove said the application to place the historic hospital on
the National Register of Historic Places, which was one of the key points in the
Landmark application process, has not gone through as of now.

Other than staff time, Dove said the county had no costs wrapped up in the
applications. The costs for maintenance and utilities, however, are a different
matter. The county has estimated it will cost at $328,000 to maintain the
building between for 2016-18.

"We are exploring options as to the future of the building," he said.

Short-term respite

Haywood County School Superintendent Anne Garrett said the news in, in part, a
relief for the school system because it means there is no immediate need to
move.

"We never knew when we would need to pack up because of the timeline," she said.
"Now we have longer to make a plan."

There are building issues which should be addressed, she said, and now that
there is no sale in the near future, the board will ask the maintenance
department to look into the most pressing repairs.

"We've got four years left on our lease," explained Francis, "so now we can
spend a small amount on maintenance."

There are structural issues with the building, however, that dictate that
remaining in the 1927 building may not be the best choice in the long-term.

County Tax Administrator David Francis, who worked extensively with Landmark on
the tax-credit issue, said an engineering report showed the newer section of the
building, which is tied to the historic structure, is leaning. Demolishing the
newer hospital additions, which have been vacant for nearly five years, would
destabilize the school administrative offices.

Garrett confirmed that a tilting staircase to the upper floors led to extensive
repairs years ago.

The office quarters are suitable for the school administrative functions, said
Associate Superintendent Bill Nolte, especially after enrollment losses and
budget cuts that have led to a reduced staff.

"We have more space here than we need, really," said Nolte. "Five years ago when
we were looking at space, we would have needed something larger."

consumer credit in the form of personal loans, purchase-specific loans or
revolving credit.

                         Business Mirror (Philippines)

                            November 24, 2014 Monday

Biggest agri trading center to open in Benguet

BYLINE: Marvyn N. Benaning

LENGTH: 411  words


THE country's biggest agricultural trading center is set to open in La Trinidad,
Benguet, in the first quarter of 2015, the Department of Agriculture (DA) said
on Monday.

Built at a cost of P655 million, the DA said in a statement that the Benguet
AgriPinoy Trading Complex (BAPTC) is a model of valuechain approach for the
agribusiness sector in the Philippines."

The complex will showcase a holistic approach in stimulating growth in the
sector through valuechain analysisthat is, we do not stop at production, but we
assist farmers in processing, valueadding and marketing,"Alcala said.

Situated on a 4hectare land owned by the Benguet State University (BSU), BAPTC
has three buildings housing trading spaces and processing facilities for
highland vegetables such as carrots, lettuce and broccoli.

It also has dry and cold storage facilities and a dormitory for farmers and
traders who come from other provinces.

Alcala said he visited the project site on Friday to see the progress of the
work and met with the project steering committee to firm up the details of the
management contract for the facility.

Comprised of representatives from the municipal and provincial government, DA,
BSU and farmers' organizations, the committee provides policy directions for the
BAPTC.

The committee replaced the project consortium following the abolition of the
National Agribusiness Corp. in March.

Alcala said he assured the committee members that the complex will be
administered by professional managers who will be guided by the operations
manual being crafted by the Development Academy of the Philippines.

The center needs good management to efficiently handle the both the prospects
and challenges of the project to maximize its potential as catalyst of improving
the lives of vegetable farmers in the Cordilleras, and as a prototype for
replication in other agribusiness hubs in the country," he said. To ensure the
success and sustainable operations of the complex, Alcala proposed the inclusion
of the project in the DAimplemented Philippine Rural Development Project (PRDP).

PRDP is a World Bankassisted initiative that includes a loan and grantfinancing
package for rural infrastructure, as well as small business and livelihood
projects for farmers and fishermen in the Philippines.

Alcala said the DA will also help in the redevelopment of La Trinidad's old
trading post for other agricultural purposes, like the cutflower business, which
is a lucrative industry in Benguet.

                              Late Edition - Final

Monroe Township Journal;
By the Road an Old Oak Stands. That's the Rub.

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS

SECTION: Section 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 36

LENGTH: 880 words

DATELINE: MONROE TOWNSHIP, N.J., March 12


Keeping sprawl in check has become a New Jersey mantra lately. Gov. James E.
McGreevey is traveling the state, promoting clean water proposals in the west
and land reclamation efforts in the east to ease the tension between development
and protecting green space.

But here in the state's rural midsection, that clash is playing out at its most
basic level.

Monroe Township, along with Middlesex County, which has ultimate authority, must
decide whether to spare a majestically crowned 300-year-old white oak that is
standing in the way of a road-widening project that the county planned to
accommodate traffic expected from an 800-unit subdivision that is rising nearby.

Still, the elementary nature of the struggle masks its complications. For one
thing, Monroe is a tree-friendly town -- the home, too, of the Monroe Oak, a
mammoth specimen of Quercus alba that was here when the town was founded in
1838. It was included in the town's official seal as a symbol of endurance and
rootedness.

The other oak --the one now in jeopardy, some three miles away along Route 522
-- is nearly as large; its girth is just a half-inch less than that of the
town's namesake tree. But does the town have room in its heart for yet another,
less celebrated oak?

The question tests the resolve that the town demonstrated five years ago, when
it passed an ordinance requiring developers to get a permit before removing
trees over a certain size. The permit is usually accompanied by a requirement
that the developer do an approved amount of replacement planting and pay a fee
determined by the town into a "Tree Trust" that finances other tree replacement
programs. In the last year, the trust has raised $500,000.

When the New Jersey Builders Association went to court to complain that the law
discriminated against developers, it was seen as a move that dared town
officials to extend the requirement to all the homeowners they face at election
time.

"We called their bluff," said the town engineer, Ernest Feist. In 1999, Monroe
broadened the law to cover anyone who would cut down such a tree.

So it is a bit odd that few paid attention when plans were made to take down the
oak alongside Route 522, two miles southeast of the village of Jamesburg. On
March 5, town officials said, the developer of the subdivision, Toll Brothers
Inc., proposed taking it down. but put it off because of bad weather. Toll
Brothers needed a permit, Mr. Feist said, but had not applied for one.

But one man took notice: David Cohn, a state-certified tree specialist at the
firm the state asked to cut down the tree.

Struck by descriptions of the tree's size, he went to see it and immediately
concluded that it would be a mistake to take on the job, for both preservation
and public relations reasons. Mr. Cohn then called Mayor Richard Pucci of Monroe
Township and the office of the Middlesex County engineer, which was to supervise
the road widening, asking them to save the tree. The mayor has directed town
officials to work with the county engineer's office and the developer to
consider ways to spare the tree.

Mr. Cohn left his job late last month for unrelated reasons, but took with him a
passion for saving the tree, which he estimates is 300 to 400 years old.

"This is the kind of tree that the British used to build the world's greatest
fleet of ships back in the 17th and 18th century," Mr. Cohn said, as he climbed
the tree, waxing grandiloquent about the denseness of its wood and its
resistance to disease.

"Few of these trees live to be this old," he said. "But this one has defied all
probability without lightning-strike damage and never having been struck by a
car even though it's so close to the road."

While not a "perfect specimen," he said, it is nevertheless a "perfect system,
growing vigorously and healthily" to its crown, which measures about 90 feet
across. About six feet from the ground, the tree splits, V-like, into two
"co-dominant" trunks.

"In fact, if it were perfect, it would probably be a ship now," he said.

Roy Etsch, the farmer who sold the land where the tree stands to Toll Brothers,
said that when he subdivided the plot, he tried to lay out a plan that would
keep the tree out of harm's way. But he said that county engineers insisted they
needed the right of way for the road widening, which would run the edge of the
expanded road right down the middle of what is now the tree's trunk.

"They said that they want to put a sidewalk here," Mr. Etsch said, quizzically
staring at what is now a stretch of country road. "It would be a sidewalk in the
middle of nowhere. I think the tree should stay."

Mr. Feist, who must report to the mayor about alternatives in two weeks, said
that now the only option appeared to be shifting the road south, a move that
would require the county to condemn land owned by people who are not involved in
or the subdivision's construction and would not benefit from it. Not only would
this be costly, but it would create two curves in what is now a straight stretch
of road -- all to avoid the tree.

"The threshold issue is whether the value of the tree outweighs the cost of this
kind of shift," Mr. Feist said. "But as an engineer I have to say that before
you get to that issue, you are creating a less-safe road by introducing these
curves."

                                  The Journal

                            February 22, 2013 Friday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Building on new homes success

SECTION: COMMUNITY REGENERATION;NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 799 words


THE last few months have seen many changes in the Government funding for local
regeneration and affordable homes throughout England with some particularly good
news for the North East.

As part of the second round of the Get Britain Building programme over £9.4m has
already been contracted this year to provide more than 200 new homes at schemes
in Newcastle, Durham and the Tees Valley with more identified for later in the
year. This builds on the success of the first round where 298 homes are being
built through an investment of £13.8m.

The HCA is required by Government to make the best use of public land that is no
longer needed and we have been able to put surplus land to good use in the North
East. Our first success is that Galliford Try has just been appointed to build
300 homes on derelict land at the former St George's hospital site in Morpeth at
the same time as preserving the historic Victorian buildings. In Prudhoe,
Sunderland-based Gentoo Developments have been chosen as preferred developer and
will soon start to work with the local community to provide homes on disused
public land while finding a way to preserve the Grade II-Listed, but empty,
Prudhoe Hall.

It is not simply enough to build new houses we also have to ensure that people
can afford to buy new homes if they want to.

The Firstbuy scheme is, as the name suggests, helping first time buyers own the
home they want at a price they can afford through a shared equity scheme which
means that purchasers only have to find a mortgage for 80% of their property.

This scheme has been so popular that in the last year in the North East we have
provided support to allow 500 new homes to be bought.

Not everyone wants or can afford to buy their own homes and our support for
providers of social housing is therefore vital.

The new Affordable Homes Programme which provides funding up until 2015 has
allocated over £66 million for the North East to help provide at least 3,700
affordable homes.

We work to ensure that the homes meet the needs of everyone in the community,
for example over 580 homes will be designed specifically for older people or
people who need support to enable them to live an independent life.

Large housing developments in bigger towns and cities are the easiest way to
ensure that we provide the homes that people want but it is also important to
ensure that rural communities remain viable, so we will be providing almost 300
affordable homes in smaller and more remote communities.

The HCA also acts in a number of specialised ways to ensure that we provide
homes that meet the needs of everyone and that we make best use of our existing
houses.

We have worked with a number of local community groups to help provide funding
for Community Land Trusts which are local charities that provide homes for local
people in areas of specific need, such as Holy Island. A new initiative this
year is the Custom Build Loan fund where we will provide loans to groups of
people who want to build their own homes rather than simply buy an existing one.

The Agency has provided local authorities and other organisations with
additional funding to bring empty homes back in to use where this is seen
locally as a better option than demolition, in the current financial year we
have provided £2.7m to 22 partners to help bring 200 homes back into use.

Looking forward there are a number of Government programmes that will benefit
the North East by increasing the supply of new homes, the Build to Rent fund is
a £200m recoverable loan scheme to allow private sector developers to provide
new homes to rent and will allow the HCA to provide funding to ensure schemes
will be built out, managed and let. The investment can be used to cover
development costs such as land, construction or management costs. Once the
scheme is fully let the developer will sell on its interest or re-finance the
scheme and repay the investment which we will then reinvest in yet more new
homes.

The Department of Health has become involved in helping meet housing needs, over
five years from 2013/14, it is providing us with a £160m capital fund to invest
outside of London. The fund is specifically to allow specialist housing
providers to bring forward development of housing to meet the specific needs of
older people or adults with disabilities.

The Homes and Communities Agency is working with local authorities, housing
providers and developers across the region to help provide much needed homes
that meet the needs of everyone in the North East, wherever they want to live
and whatever their needs might be.

David Curtis is the executive director for the North East, Yorkshire and The
Humber at the Homes and Communities Agency

It is not simply enough to build new houses we also have to ensure that people
can afford to buy new homes

                             Herts & Essex Observer

                                 August 3, 2006

Plan to stop town exodus

LENGTH: 346 words


A SCHEME to stop sky-high property prices forcing families - and young people -
out of Thaxted is on the way.

The proposal has its foundations in what residents say they want and a report
highlights that young people are already having to move away from their
childhood community.

Ten affordable or shared ownership houses and two flats are earmarked for
agricultural land between Newbiggen Street and Walden Road, next to Clare Court.

A demand for at least 30 low-cost homes is revealed by the Thaxted Housing Needs
Survey, conducted by the Rural Community Council of Essex last year.

It concluded: "First time buyers will have little chance of purchasing locally
in present market conditions.

"It will not be possible for most young people to stay in Thaxted."

The lowest price in the town in 2005 for a two-bedroom dwelling was 170,000 - an
individual would need an annual income of 46,140

to get a mortgage, while a couple would need to earn 58,730.

"Some people who said they wanted to purchase on the open market will almost
certainly have difficulty in finding a property at a price they could afford.
This may mean that the overall need is higher than the survey indicates," the
survey said.

"There is a definite housing need in Thaxted to cater for existing residents and
those with close connections to the village."

Of those who responded, 38 stated that family members had moved away in the past
five years because they could not find or finance a home in the town.

The data suggested that 15 households would need a new home within two years,
with a further 15 requiring accommodation within two to five years. Of those, 12
are already registered on Uttlesford District Council's waiting list.

When asked whether they would support a small amount of residential development
in the parish to help meet local needs for affordable housing, 89 per cent of
residents said they would be in favour.

The application from Little Chesterford's Hastoe Housing Association to build on
the 0.793 acre site will be determined by the district council in October.

                       Charleston Gazette (West Virginia)

Sneaky;
Success with bureaucrats

BYLINE: Gzedit

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. P4A

LENGTH: 328 words


Q: How can a clever housing developer induce state bureaucrats to give him
millions of federal taxpayer dollars? A: By naming apartment complexes for the
bureaucrats, their children, their in-laws and even their dogs.

That's the implication of peculiar disclosures by Statehouse reporter Eric Eyre.
Over several weeks, Eyre has revealed:

-Former state housing official Douglas Pauley quit to enter the private rental
business - and his old colleagues at the West Virginia Housing Development Fund
awarded him more than $30 million in federal grants, loans and tax credits.
Since Pauley's firms are allowed to keep apartment complexes built with U.S.
money, he evidently became wealthy from taxpayers.

-Pauley paid state Treasurer John Perdue and his wife $215,000 for a Mason
County site for a complex named Milton Place, after Perdue's late father-in-law.
Mason County commissioners opposed the complex, making it ineligible for U.S.
funds - but a Perdue aide helped change state rules to restore eligibility, and
Milton Place was given $3.7 million in stimulus money.

-With a $2.8 million federal loan granted by state officials, Pauley built Elle
Bella Villa Apartments in Dunbar - named for state housing official Sherry
Bossie's Yorkshire terrier, Elle Bella.

-Pauley built Wilshere Landing in Greenbrier County - evidently named for state
housing official Michelle Wilshere.

-He built Perkins Parke Apartments in Cross Lanes - apparently named for housing
official Nancy Perkins.

-He built Lindsey Terrace Apartments in Martinsburg - evidently named for
Perkins's daughter Lindsey.

Amid all these disclosures, longtime state housing development director Joe
Hatfield abruptly resigned.

An FBI raid seized Pauley's records from his Charleston office, but they were
returned and he was told he isn't a target for prosecution.

Many questions and suspicions hang over this complicated mess. West Virginians
deserve answers. We hope the ongoing federal investigation provides them.

                           September 14, 2009 Monday

September 14th, 1987: Cancer of 'bungalow blight' infecting every part of the
country

BYLINE: JOE JOYCE

SECTION: OPINION; Opinion; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 662 words


BACK PAGES:Along with widespread emigration, another feature of the 1980s was
what became known as  bungalow blight , a play on the title of a book of simple
house designs, Bungalow Bliss, which some blamed for the spread of one-off
housing in rural areas. In a series of articles, Environment Correspondent Frank
McDonald characterised the development as a cancer which was infecting every
part of the country.

THROUGHOUT THE length and breath of the country, rural areas are being destroyed
relentlessly by this structural litter on the landscape   litter than can never
be removed. And this cancer is so pervasive that for every private house built
on a suburban housing estate, at least one other house is built in the middle of
the countryside.

If this was Éamon de Valera s dream of a country  bright with cosy homesteads ,
it has turned into a nightmare.

Because what is happening, in effect, is that we are abandoning our towns and
villages in favour of colonising the countryside. And this is still going on,
almost day-in, day-out, in a year which has been designated by the Council of
Europe for its European Campaign for the Countryside.

Figures compiled by Foras Forbartha illustrate the frightening spread of
bungalow blight. They show that the output of  one-off  houses in rural areas
doubled, from 5,530 to 11,050, between 1976 and 1983, and they now account for
more than 53 per cent of all newly-built private houses compared to just 35 per
cent 10 years ago.

It must be emphasised that these are national figures; if the major urban
centres are excluded, the share of the total attributable to one-off houses
would be much higher.

For example, in Monaghan, which would be a fairly typical rural county, one-offs
now account for a staggering 80 per cent of all private house completions.

And the evidence is that much of this housing is, in fact,  urban-generated
built for people who have no functional connection with agriculture. Most of
them work in the nearest city or town, but they choose to live in a rural
environment for status reasons or because they simply like the fresh air. In
short, they are in the countryside, but not of the countryside.

The doctor, the solicitor, even the butcher and the dancehall owner, used to be
quite happy with homes in town; now they have fantasies about Southfork-style
ranch-houses. Indeed, one of the phenomena of modern Ireland is the
proliferation of vast mansions faking Dallas or Dynasty on the outskirts of so
many provincial towns   the palazzi gombeeni, as one Dublin architect has
scathingly described them.

But if the countryside was populated only by those who depended on it for a
living, many of the one-off houses   large or small   would not be there today.
Indeed, Foras Forbartha reckons that more than half of the State s rural
population, or over 177,000 households, are not engaged in agricultural
occupations. In other words, they are part of the uniquely Irish version of
suburbanisation . . .

The loss of land, often some of the best in the country, can only be estimated.
At an average of half-an-acre per house site, the 11,050 one-off bungalows built
in 1983 alone would have consumed over 5,500 acres of land   the equivalent of
one or two of the great estates which the Land Commission used to break up with
such fervour for redistribution to needy smallholders.

At the same rate over a decade, more than 55,000 acres would be lost to
agriculture. Yet the Department of Agriculture doled out more than £130 million
over the past 10 years in grants to farmers for the reclamation of marginal
land.

Farmers in financial difficulties are often put under pressure by the banks to
seek planning permission for bungalows on their land, to strengthen the
collateral for outstanding loans. But, one way or another, they make as much as
£100 million a year in windfall gains through the sale of land for development,
according to the 1985 Joint Oireachtas Committee on Building Land.

                             The Observer (London)

                     November 27, 2016 Sunday 12:05 AM GMT

The big issue: the affordable housing crisis can be solved by thinking
radically;
Abandon the green belts and set up government-backed housing corporations

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 621 words


Your business leader identified the acute lack of affordable housing as a
serious issue doing great damage to the fabric of our society and requiring
urgent action ( "No more tinkering", (Business).

Finance and a dearth of building land were highlighted as key issues. With
regard to funding, we should look at the Danish model, by setting up a
government-backed corporation able to borrow market funds (currently at
historically low rates) from savers keen to obtain any interest at all and
pension funds, private or public, seeking long-term security, at modest interest
rates.

A second new corporation would vet potential property buyers and their proposed
dwellings, as building societies and banks do now, before recommending them to
the first corporation for mortgages that could be for 25 years, or longer to
allow for buying in more expensive areas.

However, affordable housing relies on the supply of available and cheaper
building sites and, for most towns and cities, that means building on the
outskirts, mainly on farmland, as in my city, Oxford, some of it in the green
belt, some on sites of special scientific interest or of particular landscape
value. Under my plan, farmers would be offered twice the current agricultural
value by selling to local authorities and schemes would avoid SSSIs or scenic
sites, but certainly include some green belt.

Green belts were proposed in 1948 to meet the then current need to prevent towns
expanding into the countryside before brownfield sites were utilised. But
21st-century needs are different and thousands of cheaper dwellings, close to
centres of employment to minimise commuting, are urgently needed.

We should also be using scarce land resources better - three-, four- and
five-storey dwellings and at higher densities to the hectare. We should revisit
the 1950s and 1960s' Parker Morris standards  of space and quality, which would
encourage the use of factory-built dwellings with much higher standards of
construction and energy efficiency. They would be much faster to build, while
creating thousands of skilled jobs (including apprenticeships) in areas that
need such employment.

Only by such broad, radical thinking do we stand a chance of providing enough
affordable housing, but is anyone in government listening? Mike Gotch

Oxford

We grieve for the seaside towns hollowed out by second homes ( "The new
frontline of Cornish war on second homes", News). But they are not alone. In
pretty well every university town, the ivory tower casts a shadow over the local
community, where landlords buy up family homes for use as second homes for
students (in even greater proportions than in Cornwall). The impacts are the
reverse of seaside towns - overwhelmed in term time, deserted in the holidays.
Dr Richard Tyler National HMO Lobby Leeds

Today, 1.2 million people are on housing waiting lists in England and Wales and
more than 6 million face tenure insecurity. The situation in my home city of
Bath is a microcosm of what has been happening in the country. The buy-to-let
sector has mushroomed, the crisis in social housing has become acute, families
live on boats on the canal, homelessness and overcrowding have increased. Yet
Bath is now a richer and more prosperous place than at any time in its history.

In 1945, Bath had been badly bombed and many people, like my parents, were
living in dingy rooms in decaying buildings. But, thanks to the determination of
the governments of both Clement Attlee and Harold Macmillan, the city's postwar
housing crisis was eradicated. The difference between the Bath of today and the
Bath of 1945 is that a sense of common national purpose and concern for those at
the bottom seem to be going down the plughole. Ivor MorganLincoln

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                          Kitsap Sun, Bremerton, Wash

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            December 14, 2009 Monday

BUSINESS SPOTLIGHT: Will It be Kitsap or King for Westbury Inc.?

BYLINE: Rachel Pritchett, Kitsap Sun, Bremerton, Wash.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 744 words


Dec. 14--POULSBO -- Westbury Inc. is edging closer to production of a new
sophisticated outdoor tarmac system to herd passengers safely from airport to
plane.

But will production take place in Kitsap County or in Seattle?

There is no answer yet.

Andrew Butler, chief executive officer of the Seattle-based company, is now busy
interviewing and recruiting senior sales executives around the nation, he said
in an e-mail Friday to the Kitsap Sun. The people his company hires will head 20
nationwide sales offices starting mid-January, according to Westbury's ads on
the Internet.

The next step would be production.

Local leaders have worked tirelessly in the past nine months to convince Butler
to locate a production facility in Kitsap, rather than King County, where
Westbury executives live.

That effort has been led by Bill Stewart, executive director of the Kitsap
Economic Development Alliance, who said his understanding is that Westbury will
choose Kitsap only if it is given a $2 million county-backed federal loan to
help with startups costs.

The Kitsap County commissioners voted in September to support the loan
application to the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. HUD
apparently had no hang-ups with the plan, and now the commissioners are
performing due diligence before committing the county to being on the hook to
back the loan.

Kitsap Commissioner Josh Brown said he still has reservations about going ahead
with the loan. Commissioner Steve Bauer has said the same in the past.

Westbury so far has put up its patent as collateral, and if Westbury were to
default, "I have some concerns about how enforceable that would be," Brown said.

Brown said county staff is studying the issue.

He also said that because of how the loan is set up, a Westbury default could
hurt future funding for local programs that help the needy. "And that's
unacceptable," he said.

The county would be responsible for paying back the loan if the company defaults
and must pledge current and future Community Development Block Grant allocations
as security.

If the loan is not granted, Westbury is planning to immediately set up
production in King County, Stewart said.

That would be a disappointment to local job-seekers anxious for $16-an-hour
positions, with benefits and training. Many of the position would be in
assembly, since parts would be brought in.

The company plans to gradually hire for up to 105 positions in two years,
according to Stewart.

Erin Mundinger, area director for WorkSource, the employment office, said she's
"very disappointed that (the loan) hasn't come through."

Job-seekers are asking about jobs with Westbury.

"We really do have people coming in every day," she said.

Westbury and WorkSource have made a "first-source" agreement. That means
WorkSource would screen and recruit applicants to work at the assembly plant,
which would be at the Twelve Trees Industrial Park outside of Poulsbo.

Mundinger suggested that job-seekers watch the employment office's Web site,
www.go2worksource.com, where any Westbury jobs will pop up.

Stewart estimates a Westbury plant would add $30 million annually to the local
economy.

Westbury's product, called the Vallo Passenger Inhibitor Guide, allows for safer
and less confusing ushering of people from airports to planes on tarmacs. It
features pyramid-shaped standards with webbing stretched between them, and
safety and directional features can be added like lights, cameras and sound,
according to promotional materials.

Westbury leaders were given a tour of other industrial sites in Kitsap, and
liked a new building at the Port of Bremerton very much, Stewart said. But they
chose lease space at Twelve Trees, because the ferry ride to Seattle is shorter.

"It really came down to accessibility," Stewart said.

Stewart and Mundinger remain hopeful Westbury will get the loan and bring new
private-sector jobs to Kitsap.

"I think it will happen," Mundinger said.

Stewart said, "We all wished it was an easier one to put together, but that's
not the reality of the opportunities that are out there."

                                Mail & Guardian

                                 August 1, 2014

State to tackle housing title deed mess

BYLINE: Lynley Donnelly

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 1029 words



HIGHLIGHT: On the cards is the building of 1.5-million homes for the elderly,
poor and child-headed households.


 The government has set itself the ambitious target of trying to eradicate the
state's 2.3-million housing backlog in the coming years, after which it may end
the provision of free state housing. Alongside this herculean task, it also
plans to eradicate the backlog in issuing title deeds to existing housing
beneficiaries, to realise what Human Settlements Minister Lindiwe Sisulu called
"the dead assets" in people's hands. Research shows that more than one million
RDP homeowners don't have title deeds for their properties. The government aims
to complete 1.5-million houses in the next five years, Sisulu said before her
recent budget vote speech.

The provision of homes to the elderly, the indigent and child-headed households
will be prioritised and the practice of having 18-year-olds on the list will be
ended. This will allow the government to set a cut-off date and address the
question of the sustainability of providing free housing, she said. According to
Ndivhuwo Mabaya, the spokesperson for human settlements, the state believes that
the 2.1-million housing backlog in 1994 may already have been cleared and that
the current 2.3-million backlog is made up of new entrants. He said the younger,
economically active people on the list could be assisted with alternative forms
of social housing, such as subsidised rental accommodation, subsidised stands on
which they could build, and employer-supported housing. Housing 'opportunities'
According to state statistics, more than 3.7-million housing "opportunities"
have been delivered since 1994, which includes more than 903 000 serviced sites
and more than 2.8-million housing units. There is a substantial amount of wealth
potentially available to existing housing beneficiaries but without title deeds
they cannot access it. Research done by the FinMark Trust and Urban LandMark in
2011 showed that, at that time, more than one million owners of subsidised homes
had no title deeds. Mark Napier, the former programme director of Urban
LandMark, who is now at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research's
built environment unit, said there were a number of key factors that contribute
to the delays in registration. A primary cause was the failure of developers to
complete the process of township establishment, which delayed the creation of a
register needed for each new neighbourhood or housing area.  The problem was
aggravated by changes made to payment processes for developers. Before 2004, the
bulk of subsidy payments to developers could only be made once the title deeds
for beneficiaries had been registered. But this was changed, resulting in
developers simply forfeiting the final, smaller payment tranches to avoid having
to complete the registration of title deeds. This fell to the municipalities and
provinces, which did not have the capacity to do it once a backlog built up,
Napier said. Transfers
Although an RDP house cannot be sold for eight years, where sales have taken
place informally without title deeds there is no record of the transfer or of
the new owner. There is a similar problem when housing beneficiaries die and
their homes are left to family members. But, according to earlier research, the
number of subsidised houses that are sold is very low - about 11% every five
years. Of this, informal sales make up only 5%. Yet the problems go beyond the
registration of title deeds, Napier said. The cost of surveying, conveyancing
and transfer of homes is often too expensive for poor people. Similarly, the
cost of building planning requirements when occupants extend their homes can be
too high, leading to lapses in compliance. This makes banks reluctant to issue
loans against these homes and, in the short term, many people cannot unlock the
financial gains that come with formally owning a home. Higher real figure
Mabaya confirmed that more than one million homeowners, including recipients of
houses before 1994, did not have title deeds, but added that the real figure
could be much higher because it excluded rural areas. He said the reason for
changing the requirement that developers finalise title deed registration was
that it had delayed final payments being made to small contractors and to the
occupation of the houses by beneficiaries. The department is setting up a
dedicated unit to fast-track the issuing of title deeds, which will be led by
the Estate Agency Affairs Board. The department has also approaching the
Congress of Traditional Leaders of South Africa to reach rural communities. "We
have noted some progress where municipalities are working with chiefs to zone
land and then give people title deeds," Mabaya said. Big strides
Meanwhile, projects such as the Ngwathe Land Reform Project, run by the Free
Market Foundation in conjunction with several private sector partners, such as
First National Bank, has already made big strides in transferring the titles of
former council homes in the Ngwathe municipality in the Free State to some of
its 33 000 residents. According to Leon Marincowitz, the project manager of the
foundation, there were many pre-1994 provisions, such as various forms of lease
agreements, that barred black people from owning homes. Similarly, home
ownership has been undermined by the restrictions on recipients of RDP houses
from selling them and by the many cases in which recipients of RDP houses had no
title deeds, which sat "at municipalities, in drawers somewhere". At a cost of
about R1 850 each, the project provides owners with full title to their homes
and with no restrictions. Marius Marais, the chief executive officer of FNB Home
Loans, said it was difficult to calculate the amount of capital lying dormant in
cases like these. But he estimated that, in the Ngwathe municipality, a 60m2
house was conservatively valued at R300 000, which meant that, in total, about
R10-billion could be accessed. But, he said, homeowners still faced many
challenges to unlock the value of their homes. Key to this was educating them
about both the importance of their title deeds and how much they could afford to
borrow, and preferably for long-term reinvestment in their homes rather than
short-term consumption.

JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This position is being concurrently announced under Merit Promotion procedures
on IN-2014-013. Disabled Veterans, candidates with 3 or more years of active
duty military service, and candidates eligible for special hiring authorities
can apply to the Merit Promotion announcement if they meet criteria for the
above and include supporting documents.

This announcement may be used to fill additional or subsequent vacancies that
are identified by the organization.
