                      Western Morning News (Plymouth, UK)

                             August 18, 2008 Monday

Changes needed in planning terms;
Do Section 106 Agreements, which are used by local authority planning
departments to ensure a dwelling being built in a rural area is restricted to
someone from that locality, result in those local people being treated as
second-class citizens?

SECTION: Pg. 21

LENGTH: 836 words


The reason I ask follows a real-life situation with which  I have just been
involved.

My clients are a young farming family who have grown up in a rural parish near
Launceston and whose parents and grandparents have farmed in the locality all
their lives.

The parents of my client own land on the edge of the village and gave a corner
of the field (that adjoins an established residential cul-de-sac of some five or
six properties) to them.  My clients applied to the local authority for planning
permission to build a dwelling there.

The local authority would only grant planning permission if a Section 106
Agreement was entered into, which ties the occupiers of the dwelling to being
from the parish in which the dwelling was built or the immediately adjoining
parishes.  My clients had no difficulty with that restriction.

The Section 106 Agreement also restricts the value of the property that may be
built.  My clients were not very happy about this, particularly as the
cul-de-sac immediately adjoining has, of course, no such price restriction on
it.  But they were prepared to proceed with that price restriction in place,
fully understanding that it was designed to try to ensure that the property
always remained affordable for local people.

There is a clause within the Section 106 Agreement known as the "mortgagee in
possession clause".  This provides that, if the owners of the property get into
difficulties with their mortgage repayments and the mortgage company repossesses
the property, the mortgage company has to offer the property to a registered
social landlord, such as Devon & Cornwall Housing Association or West Devon
Homes, for 30 days.

If the registered social landlord does not wish to buy the property, the
mortgage company then has to try to sell the property to someone from the parish
or the adjoining parishes, for a further 60 days.

Only after those 90 days have elapsed, and without anyone coming forward to buy
the property fitting the criteria, is  the mortgage company then free of all
restrictions and able to sell the property on the open market.

My clients' mortgage broker, who has many years of experience in the industry,
tried to obtain a mortgage over the property with more than 20 different lenders
- but none of them would provide a mortgage.  They all said they had to be able
to sell the property on the open market free of any restrictions immediately
following repossession, rather than having to wait the 90 days.

Consequently, the property given to my clients by their parents to enable them
to have a home in the place where they grew up and worked is unmortgageable and
unsaleable.

Anyone with any experience of Section 106 Agreements will know there are very
many agreements relating to local-needs dwellings that have a far more
restrictive mortgagee-in-possession clause than the 90-day time lapse.

Many have a six-month period, and many more have no time period at all and the
property can only be occupied by someone who satisfies the local-needs criteria.

Potentially, there is a time bomb ticking away for owners of these local-needs
dwellings.  If the owners need to sell, perhaps when moving jobs, or they have
to remortgage as their fixed-rate deal comes to an end, they are going to find
they cannot sell and they cannot remortgage.

I invited a response to this problem from the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML),
which replied: "As a trade association the CML cannot comment on, or give
guidance to, individual cases or schemes. It will be for individual lenders to
decide whether to lend on a particular scheme."

A clear case of passing the buck, if there ever was one.

Matthew Taylor published his review of the rural economy and affordable housing
last month, and under his chapter dealing with "living, working villages" he
recommended: "To assist local planning authorities in drawing up planning
obligations, the Government should review and update its model for Section 106
Agreements, with particular reference to the delivery of affordable housing on
exception sites and local connection/affordability requirements, so that the
standard terms set out in the model can be used wherever possible to minimise
the need to draft new clauses."

The Government has, on numerous occasions, shown it is  out of touch with rural
communities - and so will have no understanding at all of the fact that local
needs dwellings with a Section 106 Agreement are currently unmortgageable and
unsaleable, and that consequently the owners of these properties are
second-class citizens.

I invite anyone with a property subject to a Section 106 Agreement restricting
the mortgagee in possession from selling on the open market immediately it
repossesses to contact me, so that I may compile a report and submit it to the
Government Department for Communities and Local Government, local MPs and local
district councils to campaign for changes as soon as possible.

Pam Johns is a partner with Coodes Solicitors and may be contacted at
pam.johns@coodes.co.uk or on 01409 253425.

LOAD-DATE: June 11, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: 83


                 Copyright 2008 Western Morning News (Plymouth)
                              All Rights Reserved

service. Rural Development promotes economic development by providing loans to
businesses through banks and community-managed lending pools, while also
assisting communities to participate in community empowerment programs. Join the
Rural Development team and make a commitment to America's rural communities.

                          New Straits Times (Malaysia)

                          February 19, 2004, Thursday

Dream kampung houses for the lower-income families

BYLINE: By Alina Simon

SECTION: Nation; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 813 words


"FOR sale. Double-storey traditional kampung house in Kedah!

"Three-bedroom, two-bathroom with a large plot of land complete with
fruit trees like durian, duku, coconut, mango, ciku and mangosteen. No
fencing. Located in a newly-built village self-contained development with
plenty of modern amenities. Just completed.

"Flexible loan repayment scheme. Price between RM39,000 and RM43,000."

An advertisement like this would reasonably receive a deluge of
inquiries but, alas, houses like this will never be sold on the open
market.

These houses were in fact built for the lower-income families in Kubang
Pasu district, who earn a monthly income of under RM2,000.

Known as Kampung Tradisi, the project is a glimpse into what future low-
cost housing projects for the rural poor can be.

Instead of the usual single-storey link houses or high-rise flats in
cramped communities, Kampung Tradisi allows residents to enjoy modern
amenities in a true kampung setting.

Residents get to enjoy the best of both worlds.

The Kampung Tradisi programme is jointly undertaken by the Prime
Minister's Department and the Kedah Government.

Two pilot projects have been completed involving the construction of 352
houses in Temin and Binjal in Kubang Pasu district, north of Alor Star.

Kampung Tradisi Lembah Keriang in Jalan Sintok, Temin, has 191 units on
a 26.6ha site.

Another 161 units are at Kampung Tradisi Paya Pahlawan in Binjal on
31.2ha of land.

The houses are two-storey units.

On the ground floor is a bedroom, kitchen, dining area and toilet.
Another two bedrooms, a toilet and a living room are on the second floor.

Two sets of staircases link the upper and lower storeys. One is inside
the house; the other outside.

The project was started in Oct 2002. The houses are now ready for
occupation and residents are expected to move in soon.

Project developer Pedoman Semarak Sdn Bhd's company secretary and
finance manager Mohamad Hatar Ismail said the project was the first of its
kind in the country, and might be used as a blueprint for modern rural
villages in the future.

He said several States, including Johor, Perak, Malacca and Negeri
Sembilan, had expressed interest in starting similar villages to address
the housing needs of lower-income families in rural areas.

Mohamad Hatar said the idea of a well-planned modern village was mooted
by former Prime Minister Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad several years ago, when
he cited examples of how small hamlets in England grew to become towns.

He said the former premier specifically wanted the traditional concept
of community living to be maintained while incorporating modern features.

"The idea of kampung living is idyllic, with wooden houses and enough
land around them to rear poultry and plant trees," Mohamad Hatar said.

He said the houses are linked to a central sewage treatment plant, and
other amenities such as a mosque for the village in Temin and a surau in
Binjal.

Each Kampung Tradisi community will also have a police station, a
clinic, a community resource centre, offices for the village head, a post
office, a market, a kindergarten and shops.

The design also incorporates culde-sac roads to minimise traffic and
make the roads safe for children.

Each unit will have a floor area of between 727 and 743 square feet,
while the land area is between 10,000 and 12,000 square feet.

Flood mitigation measures were also included, with a pond built to store
excess water run-off during rainy seasons. It will also serve as a
recreational spot for the neighbourhood.

"The buyers are actually getting a bargain because the project is
heavily subsidised, with the State Government providing the land while the
construction cost is borne by the Federal Government," said Mohamad Hatar.

"The total cost for the project is about RM90 million and the buyers are
getting the house at a bargain price since it is valued at RM80,000 per
unit if sold in the open market.

"The beauty of it is that the houses are already completed with the
Certificate of Fitness issued for Kampung Temin and a temporary CF for
Binjal."

Five types of fruit trees and herbal plants like serai wangi and pandan
are already planted to help demarcate property boundaries.

"The prospective buyers need only to wash their feet and go in because
the houses are already completed and ready for occupation."

Houseowners are also allowed to make renovations or to build additional
houses on their land, on pre-approved guidelines and designs, by applying
to the local authority.

"But they must maintain the facade and the spirit of the traditional
village and this rules out tearing the house down to build a bungalow," he
said.

The houses may even become the latest tourist attraction as there are
plans by the State Government to promote it as a model village.

                       Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)

                            June 11, 2003 Wednesday
                                  Late Edition

Global gloom leaves bank with rates dilemma

BYLINE: Matt Wade

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 504 words


Home borrowing has surged to a monthly record, despite Reserve Bank warnings
that the debt binge poses the greatest single domestic threat to the economy.

Lending for owner-occupied houses reached an all-time high of $9.4 billion in
April, with the average loan jumping to $177,000. In NSW the average home loan
was $220,000.

The stronger than expected home borrowing figures underscored an interest rate
dilemma facing the Reserve as it balances runaway household debt with a
threatening global economic slump.

The number of loans for new construction rose 2.3 per cent in the month,
although the total of new lending commitments was down a little.

A record 28 per cent of new loans were for refinancing existing loans.

The governor of the Reserve Bank, Ian Macfarlane, indicated on Friday that the
weak world economy made a cut in interest rates more likely, but did not hide
his concern that low rates were fuelling growth in borrowing and home prices.

Mr Macfarlane said credit to the household sector for housing purposes had grown
by an unsustainable 21 per cent in the past year, while home investment
borrowing had grown even more about 28 per cent.

"We have a situation where credit is growing a good deal faster than appears
necessary to satisfy the needs of the economy," he said.

Paul Brennan, an economist with Citigroup, said yesterday's housing figures
would do little to ease the Reserve's concerns.

"The housing data probably adds to any dilemma the RBA may have about lowering
interest rates," he said. "Growth in credit to owner occupiers is accelerating,
and new construction approvals continue to strengthen."

Two separate surveys published yesterday added weight to the view that the
broader economy is slowing down.

The ANZ job advertisement survey showed an 8 per cent rise in job listings,
failing to make up for a 12 per cent plunge the previous month. That left
newspaper job advertisements down 5.5 per cent compared with last year. The
trend in job advertisements in NSW is down markedly, despite a rise last month.

The ANZ's chief economist, Saul Eslake, said the results pointed to slower
employment growth in the months ahead.

"An easing in the pace of growth in domestic demand, the impact of weak global
growth on Australia's export sector, the SARS-related fall in international
tourism and the ongoing effects of the drought in rural and regional Australia
are all likely to have adversely affected hiring intentions in recent months,"
he said. "Weaker jobs growth could see the unemployment rate drift up towards
6.5 per cent in the next few months."

National Australia Bank's monthly business survey showed economic conditions
remained strong last month, but a number of forward-looking indicators were
weaker and business confidence fell.

It showed firms with a significant exposure to the world economy especially
exporters were being affected by deteriorating conditions overseas.

"The survey suggests that fundamentally the economy remains robust, but is in
the process of slowing," the report said.

                       Florida Times-Union (Jacksonville)

                            October 16, 2009 Friday

Factory to make fuel from waste;
It will create 70 jobs in Brantley County

BYLINE: MIKE MORRISON

SECTION: Pg. A-1

LENGTH: 649 words


WAYNESVILLE - A new company announced plans Thursday for a $130 million factory
in Brantley County that will turn waste forest products into fuel pellets and
electricity.

Magnolia BioPower LLC will be on an 80-acre site off U.S. 82 about halfway
between the Waynesville and Atkinson communities in eastern Brantley County and
should be up and running by spring 2012, officials said.

The plant ultimately will employ about 70 workers at about $30,000 a year,
Executive Director John Swaan said, although some skilled workers will earn
more.

Daniel Dukes, a real estate developer who owns about 10,000 acres in Brantley
and surrounding counties, will build the plant with loans and equity financing.
He is Magnolia's president and chief financial officer.

Mainly a developer of residential property, he looked to diversify when the
housing boom burst.

"We've been working on this project for a couple of years," Dukes said. "It
arose out of having a bunch of land with trees on it."

The plant will be built in three phases: the first, a $50 million project
possibly beginning by the end of the year, and two others at $40 million each
following quickly, said Ron Ham, the company's project manager and vice
president of operations.

When all phases are operating, the plant will turn out a million tons of wood
pellets a year and generate 30 megawatts of electricity, officials said.

Ham wore two hats during Thursday's ceremony because he also serves as chairman
of the Brantley County Commission. Speaking as chairman, he said the
announcement is very good news for the rural county with little industry.

"This is a truly perfect industry for Brantley County," he said. "All of those
people who have been down-sized, right-sized or early-retired during the
economic recession will be able to go back to work."

The plant's wood pellets have the energy-producing potential of coal and will be
shipped to Europe, where they are in widespread use as a coal alternative.

"We hope to see interest grow for domestic use," Swaan said. "This is a green
fuel made from a renewable resource."

A Canadian who pioneered the wood pellet industry in that country before being
lured south to join Magnolia, Swaan said the new company won't compete with
paper mills and sawmills for forest products, but will use what those industries
cast off.

"We don't want to take a saw log that has a higher value, a higher calling," he
said. "That doesn't make sense. We'll use what the paper companies and sawmills
don't want. There's so much that's wasted right now."

When the first phase opens, it will require 100 truckloads of forest product a
day, Swaan said, increasing to 300 when all three phases are completed.

Material not used in the pellet-manufacturing process, including bark, will be
used to fuel the electricity generators. The plant will use 15 megawatts in its
operations. The remaining 15 megawatts will be sold back into the power grid.
One megawatt can power up to 900 homes.

Swaan said the finished product will be trucked to the Port of Brunswick for
shipment overseas. Should a domestic demand arise, there are nearby railroad
lines.

"Locations don't come any better," he said. "All the ducks line up."

The company touted the emerging industry's "greenness," or environmental
friendliness. And even Satilla Riverkeeper Gordon Rogers gave a qualified nod to
it.

"Generally speaking, we're in favor of burning wood rather than coal to generate
electricity," he said. "But I have not had an opportunity to be briefed on this
particular plan.

"Seventy jobs for Brantley County is wonderful, but I do have a few questions,
such as what the water consumption would be, and what the air effluents and
water effluents are."

Ham said the plant would not be a major guzzler of water.

"Our feasibility study, economic impact study and environmental impact study are
under way," he said. "Everything should be in place in 30 to 40 days."

pellets from wood that would otherwise go to waste.

                             National Mortgage News

                                October 24, 1994

Manufactured Housing Activity Strong in Oregon Market This Year

BYLINE: By DONALD SORENSEN, NMN Correspondent

SECTION: REAL ESTATE; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 350 words

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.


Housing activity is showing strong gains in Oregon, with one of the often
overlooked segments of the industry sharing in the growth and becoming more
popular.

The manufactured housing business, which last year accounted for one-fourth of
all single-family homes purchased in the state of Oregon, is registering
impressive gains.

The percentage is even greater in rural areas of the state.

In two counties -- Jefferson and Malheur -- virtually 100% of new homes sold
last year came from factories, industry observers say.

The growing popularity of factory-built homes has attracted the attention of
financial institutions.

Washington Mutual Savings Bank is one of the prominent lenders.

"With manufactured housing onefourth of the market, you can't turn your back on
that," observes Robert Schoos, vice president of credit marketing for the bank.

Last year, Washington Mutual financed more than 6,200 loans for manufactured
homes in Oregon and Washington and this year it expects to top 7,000, Mr. Schoos
adds.

The popularity of these homes prompts the industry to stage the Portland
Manufactured Homes Show, an annual event that draws large crowds and allows
manufacturers to display the latest in their creations.

This year, the event drew an unusual number of people because of lower interest
rates.

More than 20 new homes were displayed with at least 12 manufacturers
represented.

These homes generally sell for less than on-site homes and the price tags at the
show ranged from $ 23,000 to $ 80,000.

The sizes ranged up to 2,700 square feet.

Financial institutions were well represented with at least eight of them having
staff on hand to explain financing terms.

Oregon is a major producer of manufactured houses and a number of the major
builders have plants in the state.  Oregon with 10 housing factories is the
largest producer of these homes west of the Mississippi River and ninth largest
in the nation.  Last year, it produced 10.576 units, the highest total since
1980.

Figures for this year are not available, but are expected to show increases.

                           January 27, 2010 Wednesday

China's banking regulator urges lenders to keep even pace of credit growth

LENGTH: 288 words


Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News
Agency)

[Xinhua: "China's Banking Regulator Urges Lenders To Keep Even Pace of Credit
Growth"]

BEIJING, Jan. 27 (Xinhua) - China's banking regulator asked lenders to keep
credit growth at reasonable pace in 2010 and vowed to tighten supervision on
property loans amid increasing risk of asset bubbles.

"Banks should reasonably control new loans, better manage the pace and try to
achieve balanced issuance and steady growth of credit quarter by quarter, " Liu
Mingkang, chairman of the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) at a
meeting on Tuesday.

Despite regulator's repeated warnings on risks hidden from the record 9.6
trillion yuan of new loans last year, banks rushed to lend more than 1 trillion
yuan in the first month of this year in fear of the expected tighter loan policy
in 2010 after the credit binge last year as media reported.

An official with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China told Xinhua the
credit growth in the first ten days of January was a little bit fast, and turned
smooth in the last days of the month.

According to the statement posted on CBRC's Web site on Wednesday, Liu said the
regulator will pay special attention to the changes in the property market,
strictly enforce relevant policy, and beef up the "window guidance" over credit
to the real estate sector.

But he restated banks should continue to support first-time home buyers.

Liu also told banks to continue lending to fund rural development, small
business, consumer spending and environmental protection.

He said banks should keep adequate capital and heed of resurgence of bad loans.

Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1423 gmt 27 Jan 10

                       Telegram & Gazette (Massachusetts)

                    January 22, 2002 Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Wiring is key to let in tenants;
 Union Station hearing process

BYLINE: Nick Kotsopoulos; TELEGRAM & GAZETTE STAFF

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 510 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER



- The City Council's Commerce and Development Committee will meet Monday to
establish a public hearing process and hearing dates for the Union
Station/Washington Square development plan.

Councilor-at-Large Dennis L. Irish, committee chairman, said the panel also will
review City Manager Thomas R. Hoover's recommendation to borrow $2.8 million so
that utilities and other infrastructure needs can be provided for potential
tenants in the 26,565 square feet of space at Union Station.

The City Council last week gave preliminary approval to the loan order, but the
three-member Commerce and Development Committee will review that proposal in
detail before it goes back to the council for final action in a few weeks.

In a report to the City Council, Philip J. Niddrie, the city's chief development
officer, said the $2.8 million loan order was based on the need to move as
quickly as possible on ''building out'' Union Station. He said the amount of the
loan order was based on estimates by the city's consultant, Wallace Floyd Design
Group.

''It is, obviously, not our intention to spend these funds until we have a
design and engineering firm confirm our initial figures,'' Mr. Niddrie wrote in
the report. ''The bottom line is that we must do the build out to move the
station along and to prepare for the tax credit deadline of November 2003.''

The Commerce and Development Committee meeting is scheduled for 5 p.m. Monday.
Mr. Irish said he encourages anyone interested in the hearing process to attend.

In a related matter, the recent unveiling of the Union Station/Washington Square
development proposal has sparked renewed interest among private developers,
according to officials.

Mr. Niddrie said after the plans were formally presented to the City Council
Jan. 15, his office received an inquiry from an individual with ''significant
interest in a good amount of space'' in Union Station.

He said the portion of the station they are interested in is the eastern end of
the building, abutting Grafton Street. There is about 6,800 square feet of space
in that part of Union Station. That space, however, needs utilities and other
infrastructure improvements, such as water and sewer connections.

''We had previously received many inquiries about Union Station, but this
particular party contacted us after we had made our presentation to the City
Council,'' Mr. Niddrie said. ''It appears the word is getting out about this
project.''

Mr. Niddrie said there are other developers interested in the housing and bus
station/hotel components of the development plan.

He said there is interest in the housing site, and Peter Pan Bus Lines owner
Peter Picknelly Sr. has expressed interest in developing the hotel/bus station.

''But everybody is pretty much waiting to see what the final configuration of
the roadway in Washington Square will be,'' Mr. Niddrie said. ''That will be key
to determining where the development parcels will be and how they can be
accessed. There's a lot going on, but there's still a lot to do.''

                              The Herald (Harare)

                                October 10, 2013

Property Sector Poised for Boom

BYLINE: Blessing Bonga

LENGTH: 904 words


The property sector is set to boom as building societies and insurance companies
are responding to the demand for housing through different initiatives in the
country.The building societies and insurance companies have come up with housing
schemes that are tailor-made to suit the different economic classes of the
Zimbabwean society with terms that make it easier to own a home especially at a
time the economy is grappling with liquidity challenges.

Schemes range from those that extend loans in order to finance construction of a
house to mortgages for purchasing completed housing units.

FBC Building Society is embarking on a 72 cluster medium-density housing project
in Waterfalls, Harare, that is expected to be complete by the end of the year.

The Masotsha Ndhlovu housing scheme, whose construction started last month, will
see potential home owners forking out US$130 000 cash for a house while there
are also terms for those that cannot afford cash.

The terms will include a payment of US$36 500 initial deposit while the balance
will be payable in a 10-year mortgage bond with clients expected to pay monthly
instalments of US$1 800 for the next 10 years.

The scheme is open to anyone including those that are not FBC clients on
condition that they pay the stipulated deposit. An official from the building
society said in the event that one fails to continue with the scheme, "the
institution will repossess the house, calculate how much the client had paid in
instalments before charging interests and a penalty while the balance will be
paid back to the client".

The initial phase of 18 fully completed housing units will have three bedrooms
(main en-suite), an open plan lounge and kitchen, single lock-up garage, private
garden, landscaping, security wall with electric fence and gate, intercom and
guard house. FBC is also undertaking an almost similar project in Greendale

Another financial institution, CBZ Bank, through its mortgage and finance
department has also unveiled a housing facility that is, however, only open to
the bank's account holders.

The scheme is only for residential stands and beneficiaries would be expected to
build their own houses. According to the bank, a credit facility is extended by
the bank for purposes of acquiring a stand that is a registered bond payable
over 10 years and in the event that one fails to continue with the scheme, the
bank will calculate the total amount contributed by the client then charge
interest plus penalty and pay out the remainder.

The stands on sale are low-density stands in Gweru located along the Shurugwi
highway averaging between 1 800 square metres and 3 500 square metres while the
Mt Pleasant Heights scheme in Harare is yet to go onto the market.

Cash prices are pegged at between US$21 000 and US$34 500 for the smallest and
largest Gweru stands respectively. For the smallest, a deposit of US$9 000 is
required while thereafter one will have to pay US$300 in monthly instalments
while for the largest stands customers will have to pay US$16 000 as deposit,
while about US$700 would be due every month.

For the 10-year balance payment period there is an interest rate of 18,5 percent
per annum that is charged. Fidelity Life Assurance Company is also developing
its South View Park high-density project located along the Harare-Masvingo
highway.

The scheme is open to anyone as long as they pay the required deposit of US$2
500. An environmental impact assessment is being carried out on the site as
permission has already been granted by the local authority while prospective
buyers are already free to approach the company.

Fidelity will provide all the basic infrastructural services on the construction
site which includes roads, sewer system and provision of water while customers
will be expected to develop the stands on their own.

The balance is expected to be paid over five years or 10 years. For the
five-year payment period, customers will be required to pay monthly instalments
of US$89, while for the 10-year scheme customers will be required to pay US$143
per month.

According to a Bard Real Estate property market report, the country continues to
experience a huge demand for serviced residential stands in most towns, while
the lack of key infrastructure has hindered the supply side of new stands, a
recent property market report has revealed.

The report, which was released last year, noted that the lack of infrastructure
such as good road networks, consistent water and electricity supply have
contributed to an increase in the number of properties, especially in Harare's
low-density areas that cannot be let or sold.

The report pegs the average prices for serviced high-, medium- and low-density
land in Harare at US$25, US$18 and US$15 per square metre, while in Bulawayo
they average US$12, US$10 and US$6 respectively.

Completed housing units in the two major cities were also pegged at an average
of US$30 000 for the high-density, US$80 000 low-density and US$150 000 for
Harare while in Bulawayo prices averaged US$12 000, US$50 000 and US$120 000 for
the high-, medium- and low-density units respectively.

The report also noted that in terms of residential rentals per month in prime
locations, Zimbabwe remains among the cheapest in the region with an average of
about US$2 000 while Angola charges the highest average of US$20 000 per month.

Malawi charges the least average that is pegged at around US$1 000 per month.

                                  My Republica

                             April 22, 2016 Friday

Survivors still living in tents

LENGTH: 1051 words

DATELINE: Nepal


Nepal, April 22 -- Seven members of two families became homeless when earthquake
of April 25 floored their three-storied building in the ancient town of Sankhu.
Though it has already been a year since the earthquake, families of Panchalaxmi
Manandhar and her brother-in-law still live in makeshift tents. They have no
idea how they will build two homes in a plot measuring less than one ana (342 sq
ft) as their income is sufficient to meet only their basic needs.

"We can't afford to buy land; it's too expensive. The land, where our houses
stood before the quake, is too small for two houses,"

Panchalaxmi, who works as a seamstress, said. "We shared flats when my
brother-in-law got separated. Now, we don't have money to build our homes."

Her husband works as a laborer in construction sector.

Panchalaxmi is not the only one. Most of the 900 families in Sankhu, which was
devastated by the earthquake, have the same problem. In fact, it is a common
story of poor people in urban and semi urban centers.

Panchalaxmi has received only Rs 15,000 as immediate relief from the government.
"We are desperately waiting for the housing grant announced by the government.
However, we don't know when the government will come to help us," Panchalaxmi
said, adding that she doesn't know whether the government will provide separate
housing grant to her brother-in-law.

National Reconstruction Authority, last week, decided to provide housing grants
to separate families if they are living in the same house. But the grant will be
provided only after conducting public hearing and verification by the local
authority.

Though the government announced to provide housing grant of Rs 200,000 to each
household in mid-July, it started distribution only recently from Dolakha
district. Many say the amount is too little to build their homes.

Officials of National Reconstruction Authority (NRA) do not have any idea when
exactly quake survivors like Panchalaxmi will receive the amount as a survey of
beneficiary households in Kathmandu Valley is yet to be done.

Chandra Bahadur Shrestha, a member of NRA and also a housing expert, said that
it might take at least another two months to begin distribution of housing
grants in Kathmandu, Lalitpur and Bhaktapur district.

Not only the poor families, people, who are capable of building their house, are
also confused as banks and financial institutions have turned down their loan
proposals. Panchalaxmi's neighbor Rameshwor Shrestha has already completed
concrete structure of his new home. But construction work has been halted after
he ran out of money. "I applied for loan at the Agricultural Development Bank
Ltd to complete construction of my house. But bank officials rejected my
application, stating that they have not got received direction from higher
authority regarding financing for quake-damaged houses," Rameshwor said.

Shrestha has reinstated his hardware shop which was buried when his
three-storied house collapsed. He lost goods worth Rs 100,000.

Only 641 households have received Rs 50,000 as the first tranche of housing
grant so far. NRA's Chandra Bahadur Shrestha said it might take three to four
months to finalize the list of beneficiary households.

This means quake-survivors will have to brave yet another rainy season in
make-shift tents.

NRA officials, who are clearly oblivious of the plight of earthquake survivors,
simply say the work pace is slow but is ready to take momentum.

At least three mega events have been organized to kick-start reconstruction. But
it has not moved ahead an inch except distributing grants to few hundred
households. NRA has to distribute housing grant to as many as 600,000
households.

The delay in distribution of housing grants has affected reconstruction work by
people. It has thrown cold water on hopes that our economy will rebound one
reconstruction work kick-starts. Development partners like the Asian Development
Bank (ADB) and the World Bank (WB) have projected less than two percent growth
in the current fiscal year.

NRA got its chief executive on December 25 - seven months after the earthquake -
because of political wrangling over its formation, jurisdiction and choice of
leadership and its key members as well as staffers.

NRA officials are now scrambling to give an impression that rebuilding work has
started in one way or the other. "We want to make sure that works in all sectors
will start by the earthquake anniversary," Ram Prasad Thapaliya, spokesperson of
NRA, said.

President Bidhya Devi Bhandari kick-started reconstruction amid gala event held
at Ranipokhari on January 16. Similar event was also organized in Pilachhe of
Lalitpur on the same day. In February, KP Sharma Oli kick-started a campaign to
rebuild Dharahara. But these events were clearly for publicity only.

"Preparation of legal frameworks and documents together with delay in
identification and verification of beneficiary households took time," said
Thapaliya.

NRA so far has released Rs 5 billion to different ministries for rebuilding
schools, health posts and historical sites and cultural sites. The authority has
received Rs 65 billion from the Ministry of Finance which has already signed
project agreements with different development partners for the assistance worth
approximately Rs 136 billion (US $ 1.28 billion). This amount is a part of total
commitments of $4.1 billion received during International Conference on Nepal's
Reconstruction held on June 25 last year.

To meet resources gap for rebuilding and reconstruction, NRA has now opened door
for NGOs and INGOs to distribute housing grants.

Officials expect this will cover around 30,000 households with housing grants of
Rs 6 billion.

"This will help us to meet resources gap," Baikuntha Aryal, who heads Foreign
Aid Division of the finance ministry, said.

NGOs and INGOs can also distribute additional grants of Rs 50,000 to needy
households. NGOs can provide assistance to 50 households, while the threshold
for INGOs has been set at 250 households.

Gopal Lamsal, president of NGO Federation, said housing grant of Rs 200,000 is
insufficient to build houses even in rural areas.

at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                                US Official News

                           October 2, 2013 Wednesday

Republican Led House of Representatives Shuts Down Federal Government

LENGTH: 1294  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the House of Representative Corrine Brown, U.S Government has issued
the following news release:

Congresswoman Corrine Brown made the following statement:

"By shutting down the United States government, House Republicans have proven
that they are willing to follow through on their threats to the prosperity and
security of our nation - and cause hundreds of thousands of middle-class workers
to be furloughed immediately - all in the name of a pointless attempt to undo
the Affordable Care Act.  Given that the Affordable Care Act passed both
chambers of the United States Congress, was signed into law by the President of
the United States, upheld by the United States Supreme Court, and received a
stamp of approval by the American public when they voted to re-elect President
Obama, it is now time for House Republicans to accept the ACA, discontinue their
obstructionist tactics, and assist their constituents to receive the numerous
heath care benefits that Obamacare offers.

Ironically, even though House Republicans have shut down the government, the
Affordable Care Act is still being implemented today, October 1st, since the
health insurance exchanges are opening regardless of discretionary funding
levels or passage of the CR.  After 42 failed attempts to repeal and defund the
Affordable Care Act, the House majority has chosen to shut down our government
rather than work with President Obama and House Democrats to implement the law,
ignoring the fact that Americans have already begun receiving benefits of the
Affordable Care Act.

By not passing a Continuing Resolution, the House majority has once again placed
partisanship over doing what is best for the American people. The salaries of
more than 800,000 federal employees are at risk, causing them and their families
to face uncertainty with respect to their financial obligations. Additionally,
housing loans to low and middle income families in rural communities, small
businesses and farmers will be put on hold; and job creation will likely slow
considerably because of market uncertainty, endangering our fragile economic
recovery.

While the military would continue working, roughly 400,000 civilian employees --
half of the Pentagon's civilian workforce -- are facing furloughs in a
government shutdown. That comes on top of the civilian furloughs that hit the
Pentagon this year as a result of the sequestration budget cuts. In addition to
civilian furloughs, the Pentagon will curtail day-to-day military operations and
bring new contracts to a halt.  While at the Department of Veterans' Affairs,
roughly 14,000 members of the VA's workforce face furloughs; while compensation,
pension and other benefits that the VA pays out could be disrupted if a shutdown
lasts one month or longer.

The American people have seen enough, and the time has come for Republicans to
abandon their reckless and irresponsible agenda and join Democrats to honor
America's commitments to provide vital services to our citizens which they have
paid for with their hard earned tax dollars. I urge Speaker Boehner, Leader
Cantor, and the Republican Party to end its shutdown by working with Democrats
to pass a clean funding bill and end this charade immediately."

According to the Obama Administration:

·       Hundreds of thousands of Federal employees are being immediately and
indefinitely furloughed, and many Federal employees and contractors that
continue to work will not be paid during the shutdown.

·       Housing loans to low and middle income families in rural communities
will be put on hold, as will start-up business loans for farmers and ranchers.

·       SBA will stop approving applications for small businesses to obtain
loans and loan guarantees.  In a typical month, SBA approves over $1 billion in
loan assistance to small businesses.

·       All facilities and services in our national parks will be closed, as
will the Smithsonian, impacting the hundreds of thousands of people that visit
these sites daily, which will have severely negative impacts on the surrounding
local communities that rely on the revenue generated by travel and tourism to
these destinations.

·       Important government research into life-threatening diseases,
environmental protection, and other areas will be halted.

·       The government will stop issuing permits to conduct drilling operations
on Federal lands, and will stop or delay environmental reviews of planned
transportation and energy-related projects, keeping companies from working on
these projects.

Fact Sheet: A Republican Shutdown Hurts Florida's Economy and Middle Class

A shutdown could delay financial support for Florida's small businesses. In
FY2012, the SBA's flagship 7(a) and 504 loans programs approved 53,847
applications and supported 571,383 jobs, for an average of just over 1,000
applications per week. A shut down would put a stop to this critical source of
small business credit until the government resumes operation. According to the
SBA, Florida is home to 396,515 small businesses. [Small Business Administration
FY14 Budget Justification; SBA]

A shutdown could delay military pay and hurt military families in Florida. The
Department of Defense estimates that during a shutdown nearly half of the
civilian workforce would be sent home without pay, while the rest would continue
to work for delayed pay, impacting the 31,149 civilian workers in Florida.
94,304 service members in Florida would remain on duty, but would see their pay
delayed if the shutdown extends for more than 10 days. Military members,
veterans, retirees, and their families are on pace to redeem more than $100
million in Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefits this year and many
service members, especially the most junior, live paycheck to paycheck.
[Military.com, 9/20/13; Huffington Post, 6/19/13; DoD]

A shutdown could put 89,000 federal employees in Florida out of work. Federal
employees around the country would potentially be furloughed during a government
shutdown. These workers may see reductions in their pay from the time they were
forced to stay home because the government was shuttered. [Census; Washington
Post, 9/23/13]

Possible Additional Consequences of a Government Shutdown

Many federal agencies are still attempting to determine exactly how a shutdown
would impact their programs and operations. The following are consequences of
previous government shutdowns that may or may not come to pass in a future
shutdown.

Social Security checks for new seniors. Although checks for current Social
Security benefits would still go out during a shutdown, applications for new
benefits would be delayed and services for seniors could be significantly
curtailed. As a result of furloughs and service cuts during the last shutdown,
112,000 claims for Social Security and disability benefits were not be taken,
212,000 applications for Social Security Numbers were not taken, and 800,000
callers were denied service on the Social Security Administration's 800 number.
In 2012, 4,004,631 people received Social Security benefits in Florida. [SSA
History; SAA, 2012]

Veterans' benefits. New veterans' educational, compensation and pension benefits
processing could be delayed. During the 1995-96 shutdowns, more than 400,000
veterans saw their disability benefits and pension claims delayed, while
educational benefits were delayed for 170,000 veterans. Florida has 1,520,563
veterans. [Army Times, 2/3/11; CNN, 1/4/96; VA]

School readiness. A government shutdown could force Head Start centers around
the country to close. During FY12, an estimated 1,600 Head Start agencies served
over 950,000 children, including 38,304 children in Florida. [CAP, 4/11; HHS;
CRS, 1/9/13]

For further information please visit: http://corrinebrown.house.gov

                             March 26, 2006 Sunday

Northwest Berks group pursues preservation: The first project is an effort to
preserve a dozen buildings and about 6 acres in Jefferson Township.

BYLINE: Holly Herman, Reading Eagle, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 512 words


Mar. 26--More than two dozen residents met Saturday to learn ways to prevent
developers from destroying historical buildings and farmland in northwestern
Berks County.

Developers will press to build in rural areas, said Sandra R. Kauffman,
president of the Andulhea Heritage Center, a Rehrersburg-based preservationist
group.

"I grew up in this area and I want to preserve the land," Kauffman said to the
group in the Bernville Grange, Jefferson Township. "We want to save our
historical structures. There are a lot of things that we can do to help."

Kauffman said the group's first project is to preserve a dozen buildings on the
former Forry Potteiger farm off Route 183 near New Schaefferstown.

She said that the Potteiger farm was sold in 2003 and that Pottstown developer
Manley Partners LLC has proposed a 30-home development for the 66-acre tract.

Robin Harper, a Jefferson Township supervisor, said the township has been
successful in working with the developer on historic preservation.

"We took the developers on a tour of the township on Thursday," Harper told the
group. "You must sit down and work with them. It's a win-win situation. We want
to save the farm, and they are working with us on it."

Harper said the goal is not to stop development of the site, but to preserve
about 6 acres of farmland and the farm buildings.

Preservationists hope to transform the farmhouse into a museum.

Kauffman said the residents would like to see housing developments built closer
to towns and rural areas preserve their character.

The group is focusing its efforts on Jefferson, Penn, Tulpehocken, Upper Bern,
Upper Tulpehocken and Bethel townships, and Bernville and Strausstown boroughs.

Berks County Commissioner Judith L. Schwank informed the group that the county
has obtained a $36 million loan to preserve farmland and historical
preservation.

Schwank, chairwoman of the commissioners, said the county's special treasures
must be preserved.

"The wave of the future is growth," Schwank said. "We will be facing the issues
of preserving the farmsteads and the historical buildings."

Schwank said the county is working on a plan to identify historical landmarks,

George M. Meiser IX, a Berks County historian, suggested that municipalities
prioritize what sites are of historic significance.

"You can't save everything," he said. "It's a tough battle to preserve."

Michel R. Lefevre, chief preservation planner for the state Historical and
Museum Commission, said development is eating up the county's beauty.

"This is the last of the beautiful farmland that is left," Lefevre said of
Berks. "People come here because they think it is beautiful and wonderful."

Lefevre said he will work with municipalities to develop ordinances that protect
historical buildings.

Contact reporter Holly Herman at 610-478-6291 or hherman@readingeagle.com.

                  Times Colonist (Victoria, British Columbia)

                             March 7, 2009 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

CMHC projects for sustainability; Corporation has several EQuilibrium
demonstration projects on the go

BYLINE: Canwest News Service

SECTION: HOMES; Pg. E8

LENGTH: 916  words


The Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation launched its EQuilibrium initiative
in 2006, bringing together the private and public sectors to develop model homes
designed for sustainable living. Twelve winning projects were announced in
February 2007, of which six have been built. The houses will be open to public
and professional tours for a minimum of six months. After the demonstration
period, the houses will be sold and monitored for performance for a minimum of
one year.

Winners each receive $60,000 from the CMHC but most of the building costs are
borne by the builder.

The EQuilibrium initiative has since been expanded, and a further three projects
were announced a couple of weeks ago. They are:

- The Green Dream Home in Kamloops: a partnership between the Canadian Home
Builders' Association (CHBA) Central Interior Chapter and Thompson Rivers
University (TRU);

- The Harmony House in Burnaby: a project by Habitat Design + Consulting Ltd.
and Insightful Healthy Homes Ltd.; and,

- The Moncton VISION Home in Moncton, N.B.: a project by AlternaHome Solutions
Inc. in partnership with Vision Land Development Inc..

In addition to the Alstonvale Net Zero Energy House under construction in
Hudson, Que., 11 other EQuilibrium demonstration homes have been built or are
under construction:

- Abondance le Soleil -- Verdun, Que.

Montreal-area urban infill housing for three Quebec families designed to produce
more energy than it consumes each year.

The triplex will get its energy from several sources, including a geothermal
heat pump system, solar thermal panels and photovoltaic array. It also has
toilets that use captured rainwater, which will reduce the demand on city sewers
by 75 per cent.

- EcoTerra -- Eastman, Que.

A rural single-family home east of Montreal oriented to maximize solar exposure
and designed to produce as much energy as it consumes. Other features include
reduced CO2 emissions, sustainable use of materials through recycling and waste
reduction, and off-site manufacturing to reduce environmental impact.

Open for tours.

- Avalon Discovery 3 -- Red Deer, Alta.

A single-family home with integrated renewable solar and space heating, and a
highly insulated building envelope. Additional features include greywater
recycling system for laundry, bathroom and irrigation, and no- or low-pollutant
emitting finishings.

Open for tours.

- EchoHaven -- Calgary, Alta.

Designed to be part of a community of healthy, low-impact homes laid out to
maximize solar exposure. The homes will share a variety of on-site renewable
energy systems, including a grid-tied photovoltaic array, and solar hot water
heating. Other features include 100-per-cent storm water retention on-site, and
greywater and balanced water strategies.

- Inspiration: the Minto ecohome -- Manotick, Ont.

An Ottawa-area home in a mixed-use, master-planned suburban development. Solar
thermal and photovoltaic power sources produce more energy than the house
consumes each year. Other features include double-wall construction with
strategically located triple pane windows, and an "all-off" switch to turn off
not only lights, but computers, cable boxes, amplifiers and other phantom-load
power consumption.

Open for tours.

- Now House -- Toronto, Ont.

A 60-year-old wartime house in an established neighbourhood in Toronto
retrofitted with the latest healthy, energy-efficient and sustainable features.
Improvements include insulation upgrades, new windows, solar hot-water panels, a
photovoltaic array, Energy Star-certified appliances, and a waste-water heat
recovery system.

Open for tours.

- Riverdale NetZero Project -- Edmonton, Alta.

A duplex designed to produce as much energy as it uses through photovoltaic
array and solar hot-water heating systems. Features include: air-tight
construction; 60 per cent reduction in indoor potable water use; regional,
recycled or abundant construction materials.

Open for tours.

- The Laebon Canadian Housing Energy Sustainable Solutions (CHESS) Project --
Red Deer, Alta.

A resource- and energy-efficient bungalow tailored to the climate extremes of
central Alberta with a highly efficient building envelope and geothermal, solar
thermal and solar photovoltaic renewable energy sources. It's designed to
accommodate the full life cycle of the occupants, improve indoor air quality,
and re-use building materials.

Open for tours.

- Top of the Annex TownHomes -- Toronto, Ont.

Three energy efficient infill town houses in a downtown area featuring a highly
insulated building envelope, energy-efficient glazing and ground-source heating
powered by solar PV panels. The downtown site also takes advantage of public
transit, allowing occupants to reduce or eliminate dependence on cars.

- Urban Ecology -- Winnipeg, Man.

The Winnipeg Housing Rehabilitation Corporation project will be a semi-detached,
environmentally friendly development in an inner-city Winnipeg neighbourhood.
The two units will be adapted to Winnipeg's climate: the units will have pitched
roofs so the photovoltaic energy system can remain free of snow in winter.

- YIPI! Net Zero Footprint Housing -- Prince Albert, Sask.

A rural home designed to take advantage of Saskatchewan's sunny climate through
the use of site-specific design. Ready-to-move (RTM) construction methods and
materials that can be ordered online make this house more affordable. Solar
power will provide energy while efficient appliances will keep energy
consumption to a minimum. It uses low-toxicity materials and an advanced
ventilation system.

                              The Herald (Glasgow)

                               February 18, 1992

£3.3m aid to tackle problem of homeless

BYLINE: Frances Horsburgh, Local Government Correspondent

SECTION: Pg. 11

LENGTH: 652 words


A FURTHER £3.3m grant for Scottish Homes announced yesterday by the Government
is to go towards initiatives designed to bring empty properties back into use to
help the homeless.

Scottish Environment Minister Lord James Douglas-Hamilton, told a conference in
Edinburgh that he believed more could and should be done.

"Every empty house is a wasted opportunity," he said. "It could be someone's
home and could reduce the need to build new houses."

He emphasised that it would be wrong to regard vacant housing as an easy
solution to the homeless problem, but it would also be wrong to underestimate
the contribution the better use of such properties could make,

especially in rural areas.

Scottish Homes chief executive Peter McKinlay said that because of the extra
funding for 1992-93 the agency could step up its efforts with organisations like
the Forestry Commission and the Scottish Landowners' Federation to develop a
flexible range of options for the owners of such private properties.

Mr McKinlay said Scottish Homes also planned to develop the findings of a recent
research project into the future potential of empty properties above shops in
many town centres.

It was also working on a scheme to allow a housing association to act as
management agent for a private landlord

with empty, or under-used properties.

It is estimated that about 10% of the 25,000 properties owned by members of the
Scottish Landowners' Federation in rural areas are vacant, but not all are
likely to be habitable. The Forestry Commission has about 400 surplus houses,
but few are empty, and most are in remote locations.

Lord James told the conference, organised by the Glasgow-based Planning
Exchange, that the commission and Scottish Homes had agreed to give local
housing associations preference to acquire surplus houses and sites for new
dwellings, and some sales had already taken place at Glentrool in Galloway.

The Minister said he was glad to report that few houses in Scotland were empty
through repossessions, because of mortgage defaulting.

Scottish Homes and the Council of Mortgage Lenders had concluded that no special
schemes involving the lease of repossessed properties to housing

associations like those in the South-east of England, were so far necessary in
Scotland.

With regard to the public sector, he said that last year there were just under
26,00O empty houses owned by councils, Scottish Homes, and the five new towns.
This was about 3% of their total housing stock.

He did not accept that the number reported as void was necessary, and in 1992
-93 councils which lost more than 2.5% of their rent income because of empty
houses, would face a reduction in housing support grant.

Later, Glasgow housing director David Comley said Glasgow would lose £1.6m in
grants as a result, and had been forced to increase rents by 24p. The Government
ruling was based on nearly 6% lost rent from the number of empty council
properties, but if the lower figure for what the council regarded as lettable
vacant homes was used, it would be below the Government's 2.5%.

Glasgow had recently made great strides in letting such properties, and if the
Government removed from the calculations the empty houses earmarked for area
renewal and awaiting disposal, for example to community ownership and housing
associatons, it would prove a further £912 of housing grant per unit.

Mr Comley said he was glad to hear Lord James had also raised the issue of
Scottish Homes's own vacant properties. The housing director pointed to the
3l,000 Government-owned empty properties, many of which came under the control
of the Ministry of Defence.

* On Friday, Lord James will unveil a plaque to mark the completion by Whiteinch
and Scotstoun Housing Association of the 50,000th house to be improved by the
Housing Association Movement in Scotland.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                      May 23, 1992, Saturday, City Edition

New loans approved for Key Center

BYLINE: KEN MORITSUGU

SECTION: CITRUS TIMES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 401 words

DATELINE: CRYSTAL RIVER



The Key Training Center has been approved for $ 600,000 in loans through the
Farmers Home Administration to build a thrift shop and employment training
center for its mentally retarded clients.

    The center plans to build an 8,000-square-foot building on 3 acres next to
its retail plant nursery on State Road 44, said Chet Cole, executive director of
Key Training Center.

    The front half of the building will house a thrift shop, similar to the
center's other three thrift shops around the county. The shops raise money for
its programs.

    In the rear, about 30 clients will work on crafts and process goods coming
into the thrift shop for sale. The building also will have a job service office
to help handicapped people find jobs.

    "It's going to enable our folks to have jobs in the community," Cole said at
a news conference Friday at the nursery. He said he hopes to have the new
building open by early next year.

    Farmers Home approved a $ 550,000 loan with a 5.75-percent interest rate for
the project about a month ago. The money comes from a program that helps develop
facilities to provide essential services in rural communities.

    On Friday, Farmers Home presented a letter of commitment to guarantee a $
50,000, 9-percent loan to Key Training Center from SunBank & Trust Co. The money
will be used to purchase equipment for the employment training center.

    The second loan is the first in Florida under a 3-year-old program in which
a private financial institution makes the loan, and Farmers Home commits to
reimburse up to 90 percent of the loan amount if the borrower defaults.

    The federal guarantee helps financial institutions make loans to needy
organizations that otherwise might not get them, said Jim Cherry, state director
for Farmers Home.     "By SunBank coming in and being willing to do this, that
allows us to use that $ 50,000 somewhere else in the state," he said.

    Farmers Home has introduced a similar guaranteed loan program for housing
for moderate-income people. The first home built in Florida under the program,
completed in March, was in Citrus County, too.

    Crystal River Bank made the 9-percent mortgage loan for the $ 48,000 home on
N Conant Avenue, which, coincidentally, is close to the planned site of the new
Key Training Center building.

                             950 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              Western Daily Press

                            January 7, 2006 Saturday

Make village pub the hub of rural life

SECTION: Pg. 12

LENGTH: 244 words


Villagers living in Dymock, Gloucestershire, have reason to raise their glasses
to the future of the local pub - they own it.

Rural communities have faced huge difficulties over the past few years as
populations, social habits and lifestyles have changed beyond recognition.

Whereas every village used to have a pub, a school, a church, a shop, a village
hall and a garage, some now struggle to tick even one checkbox on the list.

But make no mistake, with the loss of such facilities goes the loss of the
community, and the very fabric of rural life.

All are important to the way country communities function, but perhaps the most
important are village pubs.

Far more than simple watering holes, they have the potential to fulfil a
business and a community role.

Perhaps they have to, if only to prevent simple economics turning pubs into
high-value housing sites.

The Beauchamp Arms in Dymock is now a community centre which the whole village
has a stake in, thanks to a loan from the 'Pub is the Hub' scheme.

But other rural pubs could assume the mantle of the village post office, shop,
arts centre, takeaway or tearoom.

If they run restaurants, maybe they could source food ingredients from local
bakers, butchers and cheesemakers.

Finding ways the local pub can work with the community and benefit everyone
could be quite a challenge.

But it could also be a most enjoyable task, with the bonus of retaining a vital
rural service and bolstering village life at the same time.

JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This position is being concurrently announced under Delegated Examining
Procedures on announcement number DEU-IN-2014-5097 which is open to any US
Citizen. Current and former Federal employees may apply to both announcements,
but should be sure to apply to this announcement to maximize opportunities for
consideration since different referral criteria apply to each announcement type.

The incumbent of this position will be a bargaining unit member of AFGE #622.

a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

                              The Washington Post

                                 Final Edition

Pipe Dreams Are Becoming a Reality;
Water Finally Running In 4 Willisville Homes

BYLINE: Arianne Aryanpur, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: Loudoun Extra; T03

LENGTH: 549 words


Like most residents in the rural hamlet of Willisville, near Middleburg, Lottie
Payne-Smith, 49, had grown accustomed to life without indoor plumbing. No
washing machine meant weekly runs to the laundromat. And without a proper
kitchen, dinner often came from the microwave or electric skillet.

But that all changed Jan. 4, when Payne-Smith's home and three others in
Willisville  finally got running water. The project was managed and
subcontracted by the Windy Hill Development Co., a subsidiary of the Windy Hill
Foundation, a nonprofit housing agency based in Middleburg.

"It was a wonderful day," said Payne-Smith, an accounting specialist for the
Loudoun Golf and Country Club. Payne-Smith now has a bathroom, a kitchen with
running water and a laundry room. Her parents and next-door neighbors, Ethel and
Nathan Smith, also now have  a bathroom, after having used an outhouse their
entire lives.

"It was my mom and dad's 50th wedding anniversary, which made it even more
special," Payne-Smith said. "I'm just happy that the elderly people in town are
still here to enjoy this."

Willisville was founded just after the Civil War, when a freed slave bought a
cabin  on three acres for $100. Many of the community's  older residents have
never  had any type of indoor plumbing. The community consists of 11 properties,
seven of which already had running water but lacked a good septic system.

The county received a state loan in 1999 to build a sewage treatment plant in
Willisville, but the project became snagged in red tape. In 2005, County
Administrator Kirby M. Bowers appointed a senior assistant, Paul L. Brown, to
oversee delivering water and sewer service to the 11 properties. The county has
covered most of the cost of connecting homes to the system, drilling new wells
or adding bathrooms, kitchen sinks and washing-machine hookups. The remainder
has been raised by the Windy Hill Foundation.

"It was our goal, before winter got here, to get them serviced," Brown said of
the four homes that received indoor plumbing Jan. 4. Those homes were given
priority because they were in the poorest condition, said Kim Hart, president of
the Windy Hill Foundation.

For now, the four homes are running off a temporary pump-and-haul system, a tank
that collects wastewater on-site and is emptied every other day, Hart said.
Eventually, all the homes in Willisville will be serviced by three on-site tanks
that collect and treat wastewater.

The last two of those tanks were delivered Friday, and it is expected to  take
about three weeks for the system to be connected, said Liz Sitter, a project
engineer with the Loudoun County Sanitation Authority.

Brown said he was hopeful.

"We've had a good combination of warm weather, lack of rock and tremendous
contractors," he said.

The results so far have been very worthwhile, he added.

"The best feeling was when I heard the ladies talking about taking showers for
the first time and flushing for the first time," Brown said.

Emma Howard, a 50-year resident of Willisville, is another of the homeowners who
no longer needs to rely on an outhouse. She got her first bathroom this month
and is  counting down the days until she gets her first washing machine.

"I already picked it out," she said. "I went to the store in November."

                                 The Bond Buyer

Trends in the Region: EZs Offer Financial Hope for Virginia, West Virginia
Cities

                           January 21, 1999, Thursday

By Daniel Meisler



Blighted urban areas in Virginia and West Virginia expect to get boosts in
economic development, thanks to the federal government's recent empowerment zone
assignments.

The Department of Housing and Urban Development last week designated 20 cities
and counties empowerment zones, making the areas eligible for grants and
low-cost loans as well as bond financing.

Now it's up to the localities such as Huntington, W. Va., and Norfolk, Va., to
take advantage of these incentives, including authorization to issue $130
million each year in tax-free bonds in each urban zone, and $60 million annually
for rural zones. Each zone is also awarded a grant - $3 million if it is an
urban area, and $2 million if it is a rural area.

Officials in the zones, which are part of the second group designated by the
federal government, are hopeful bond authority will be put to good use. Each
already has a host of sites poised for development. But many difficult tasks
remain, including administration of the zones, attracting employers, and even
finding bond counsel.

"We view the bonding capacity as just as exciting, if not more exciting, than
the monies," said Cathy Burns, Huntington's director of development and
planning. "Definitely we envision we will be doing some bonds."

A major development that is slated for Huntington's ten-square-mile zone, which
includes part of Ironton, Ohio, will be a "business and technology park,"
incorporating space for large employers as well as retail shops, Burns said.

The city has identified $3 million of state and federal funds to go towards the
$8 million necessary to prepare the site for construction, Burns said. She said
the city hopes to break ground on the project this year, making up for the $5
million in remaining costs by selling tax-free bonds.

"Two things have to happen" before bonds are sold, she predicted. "We have to
finalize the construction drawings, and issue a series of permits." She said
that may take eight months to complete.

"Then we have to bid for the construction. Simultaneously, we will be putting
the financing particulars together," she added.

The bonds will be backed either by the expected sale of the developed land, or a
pledge of lease revenue from the buildings.

Despite what Burns called a prime location - the intersection of Interstate 64
and state Route 10 - only one company, a telemarketing firm currently located in
downtown Huntington, has expressed interest in moving to the proposed
development.

Burns said the city has approached Marshall University as well, which is in the
process of building a new medical center.

In addition to difficulties in finding tenants, Huntington could have a hard
time retaining local bond counsel for debt sold to fund the site's development.
Burns said the city would like to have local counsel, but she lamented that no
law firms in Huntington have expertise in public finance. However, one local
firm did come to her office to pick up the IRS rules for tax-exempt bonds in
empowerment zones, she said.

The city won't have to create a new bond-issuing authority, because it plans to
use the Huntington Municipal Development Authority, which has sold bonds in the
past.

In the neighboring state of Virginia, David Rice, executive director of the
Norfolk Redevelopment and Housing Authority, said any bond issuance for
Norfolk's zone, which also includes part of Portsmouth, will not hit the market
for at least a year.

The first task is to create an administrative framework, Rice explained.

"What we have to go through now is to set up a governing body, get it staffed,
and schedule its priorities," he said. "It will probably be a year before we get
anything going."

Any bonds for development within the zone will be issued by his authority, Rice
said, but debt sales did not top his list of concerns.

The major obstacle is to get companies to commit to the area. In addition to the
possibility of tax-exempt financing for new buildings, the cities are offering a
voucher of $500 for each employee living in the zone hired by a firm. The
voucher can be used for education and job training at "Empowerment Centers" in
the zone.

"The challenge is to attract people," he said. "The question is, Will these
incentives cause that to change."

Some of the developable sites in the Norfolk-Portsmouth zone also have to be
purchased from the companies that own them now. A 600-acre lot near the harbor
currently owned by a cable company, for example, still has to be acquired.

Like Norfolk, the zone in Miami is several months away from issuing bonds,
according to city economic planner Bob Schwarzreich. He said several firms
already doing business in the zones are likely to want to take advantage of the
tax-exempt financing, and that kind of activity will probably account for more
debt issuance than any big-ticket items.

Other urban empowerment zones established in the Southeast are in Knoxville,
Tenn., and Columbia, S.C.
