                               The New York Times

                  April 11, 1993, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Focus; Seattle;
Developers Turning to Farms and Forests

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING

SECTION: Section 10; Page 3; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1391 words

DATELINE: SEATTLE


HOME builders are turning to virgin forests and farmland far from this city's
job markets because closer sites are locked up in land-use disputes.

Longtime developers like William Conner are rethinking strategies and focusing
on rural towns because, they say, the state's 1989 Growth Management Act
requires cities to designate certain areas as rural, closing thousands of acres
to development.

The act was a response to the alarm of residents who saw a 1980's-type housing
boom, spurred by a job spurt at Boeing, creating urban sprawl, chaotic traffic
and soaring home prices in the suburbs.

Seattle sprawls for about 20 miles along Puget Sound and for two decades
developers have followed the Interstate 5 corridor to the north toward Everett
and south to Kent and Tacoma, turning the area into a congested, 100-mile-long
megacity. Since the early 80's the Kent Valley's lush farmlands have given way
to homes, strip malls and warehouses.

With Interstate 90, on which work began in the early 80's, nearing completion,
Mr. Conner and other builders now are looking 30 miles east of Seattle in towns
like North Bend, Snoqualmie and Carnation. I-90 stretches eastward through the
Snoqualmie Valley into the rugged Cascade Mountains.

"We shouldn't be in these towns," said Mr. Conner. "They're a long way out." He
said that he would rather be on I-90 some 15 miles closer to Seattle on the
Sammamish Plateau, but that zoning there prevented development.

Some Seattle workers also don't want to be in these towns or on the east side of
Lake Washington because they must cross it on one of the two bridges, where rush
hour traffic often is snarled. One bridge section, damaged in a 1990 storm, is
still being replaced.

Snoqualmie Valley towns also can be snowy, making commuting difficult. Farther
east, at Snoqualmie Pass, winter avalanches often close I-90 for hours or days
and big-rig trucks line up for miles waiting for roads to reopen.

Mr. Conner has watched the growth patterns change since he formed Conner
Development in 1957. He will build about 140 homes this year, the same as in
1992, compared to 180 homes a year when the market was strong.

Near North Bend, he sold 50 speculative homes in his Riverpoint project in 1992
at prices of $224,000 to $285,000. The appeal there is one-acre lots with
stunning views of the Cascades. To lure buyers a year ago, Mr. Conner urged each
visitor to cut a Christmas tree on the forested lots that had to be cleared.

This winter, because of the poor economy, he didn't have a bite on the last
seven Riverpoint homes until mid-February, when he sold three in one week. An
offer on a fourth was canceled because the hopeful buyer's company lost an
important contract when Boeing pared production.

Uncertainties at Boeing contributed to sluggish home sales in the last half of
1992 and the market has not yet snapped back. The aerospace company has been
cutting jobs for more than a year and announced in February it would give pink
slips to 15,000 more Seattle-area workers this year and 4,000 next year.
Builders are concerned over how this will affect future sales but say a bright
spot is that companies such as Microsoft are healthy.

MOST of the Riverpoint buyers were from Seattle or its suburbs and are
professionals working for Boeing or Microsoft, both of which are based in
Redmond, an east-side suburb.

The North Bend City Council has been besieged with development proposals and
annexation requests. In Washington, a large land owner or group of owners in an
unincorporated area outside a city's limits can ask the city for annexation.
Some developers have sought this because North Bend allows a 15,000-square-foot
minimum lot size compared to mostly five-acre lots in King County.

The influx of "outsiders" angers many residents who are fighting development. At
council hearings, they have protested development, angry that soaring home
prices are causing property taxes to double, and concerned that runoff from
mountain ridges cleared for houses will flood their homes. They say their
children will not be able to afford homes there and they fear gridlock in towns
like North Bend, which now only has one stoplight, or in Snoqualmie, which has
none. Opposition initially halted one of Mr. Conner's projects, Tannerwood, near
North Bend. Last fall, King County denied his application to build 109 homes,
saying it would threaten the rural character of the area. He won an appeal taken
to the King County Zoning and Subdivision Office and expects to get his
approvals within several weeks.

"IN our eyes, Tannerwood is one of the last pieces of land left for development
near Interstate 90," Mr. Conner said. "Most of the area has been downzoned to
5-acre lots."

His land costs, he said, have soared by $7,000 an acre since he first optioned
the property in 1992 and record high lumber prices will add $5,000 to the price
of a home.

"I've got $12,000 per lot I've got to get rid of to appeal to the same market
segment," he said. "I will have to trim about 200 square feet from the size of
the house."

To test market strength and preference, he will at first build a half dozen
speculative houses of 2,400 to 2,600 square feet using several designs.

Gordon and Karen Byrd, who sold their home in Chicago eight months ago and left
the advertising field, would like to buy in Tannerwood. "You can get more for
your money," Mr. Byrd said. "Friends say their kids thrive in the school system
here. And there is no busing, the reason we won't buy in Seattle."

Banks, including Seafirst, Mr. Conner's banker of 30 years, have stiffened rules
on lending and require him to invest 10 to 40 percent of his costs up front
before they will provide loans. Until about 1991 banks lent 100 percent, with
few questions asked -- a major factor in the savings-and-loan debacle.

Nearly five years ago Mr. Conner and a fellow Bellevue builder, Fred Burnstead,
spent $1 million, or $20,000 an acre, for 50 acres in Snoqualmie. The property
is next to the site of Snoqualmie Ridge, a 2,000-home, billion-dollar
residential development proposed in 1989 by the Weyerhaeuser Real Estate
Company. It has been held up by financing problems and a long approval process.
Nothing has been built yet. And last fall the Snoqualmie Indian tribe opposed
access road plans, saying Wyerhaeuser had not adequately considered the tribe's
culture and heritage.

The two partners cannot get their project under way until Weyerhaeuser builds
roads and utilities. When Weyerhaeuser does move forward, Mr. Conner and Mr.
Burnstead could be among those building the Snoqualmie Ridge homes.

Paul Wozniak, manager of the real estate and land department of John L. Scott's,
a large Seattle broker, said he believed that by 1995 land for new housing would
reach "a critically low level." He just made a study that indicates the shortage
will most greatly affect affordable housing in the Puget Sound area. Causing the
shortage are increasingly complex development regulations on several government
levels, unwillingness by banks to lend money to developers and rising mitigation
fees for roads and schools.

MR. WOZNIAK said that in Redmond, two developers with adjacent land, Quadrant
and Blackhawk Port Blakely Communities, had spent $10 million on development
fees since 1990 but recently refused to invest more until major hurdles were
cleared.

Seattle, which supplies water to most of King County, is embroiled in regional
water issues and says it will no longer commit to providing water. The state
also has yet to build access to Route 18, which links up to I-90, from the
Snoqualmie Ridge project.

Mr. Conner started building homes along I-90 in 1985 at a development called
Klahanie, in Issaquah, 15 miles from Seattle. When he began there, he said, even
Issaquah "seemed like it was too far out," but "now I consider it close in."

Mr. Conner paid $19,000 for 50- by 100-foot lots for $85,000 Klahanie homes. The
homes have sold well because they were marketed as affordable in an attractive
foothills setting with good freeway access.

In recent months, as the last few land parcels available there rose in price to
$65,000 a lot, Mr. Conner decided against even bidding because the homes would
sell for $200,000. Now he wishes he had bid because of the scarcity of available
land.

LOAD-DATE: April 11, 1993

Seattle. (Doug Wilson for The New York Times)

                            Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

                              July 19, 2015 Sunday
                                TWO STAR EDITION

PENN PLAZA LANDLORD PAUSES EVICTION PROCESS AFTER OUTCRY;
AT EAST LIBERTY COMPLEX, CITY BROKERS A 60-DAY STAY

BYLINE: Sean D. Hamill, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B-1

LENGTH: 848 words


A landlord under fire for telling some residents of two East Liberty apartment
buildings that they had 90 days to leave to make way for redevelopment of the
site has agreed to rescind those notices and put a stay on issuing any more.

That agreement between the city of Pittsburgh and owners of Penn Plaza
Apartments was reached just hours after a heated and emotional meeting Saturday
morning between about 200 tenants and city and county leaders.

"We've agreed to the 60-day stay and we're hopeful we can come to a broader
agreement" on the issues surrounding redevelopment of the site, Jonathan Kamin,
attorney for the owners, said in an interview after the meeting. He did not
attend the meeting but was negotiating with city officials by phone much of the
day Saturday.

Pennley Park South Inc., the corporation that owns the buildings, is owned by
the Gumberg family. The family owns LG Realty, which manages Penn Plaza.

Pittsburgh Mayor Bill Peduto told tenants Saturday that in meetings since the
city first found out about the 90-day notices that went out 10 days ago, city
officials told the Gumbergs the city wanted them to rescind the notices, to
include some affordable housing in their plans for the site and to create a fund
that would provide financial assistance to help residents move.

Moreover, the mayor told the tenants: "We've got to make sure this is the stand
that is taken so other developers in the city know this is not how we do
business in the city" by abruptly kicking poorer residents out of a building to
make way for wealthier tenants, without offering them help.

The broader discussions of the development itself will also include trying to
figure out how to "phase in" the development and prevent anyone from being
displaced without a new, affordable home in the neighborhood, said Kevin Acklin,
Mr. Peduto's chief of staff.

It was Mr. Acklin who negotiated with Mr. Kamin on the 60-day stay agreement, a
process that was ongoing even as Saturday morning's meeting was taking place.

Mr. Peduto, city Councilman Ricky Burgess, state Rep. Ed Gainey,
D-Lincoln-Lemington, and county Executive Rich Fitzgerald met for about 90
minutes Saturday morning in the East Liberty Lutheran Church.

The church is located across Penn Avenue from the two, red brick Penn Plaza
apartment buildings which were opened in 1968 by the late developer Pat Navarro
Sr. using about $5 million in Federal Housing Authority low-interest loans.
Sometime later the Gumbergs bought the site.

The original federal loans, authorized in 1964, came with covenants that
prevented redevelopment of the site for 40 years. The covenants expired in 2004,
freeing the way for the Gumbergs to redevelop the site, Mr. Kamin said.

About six years later the Gumbergs began preparing for redevelopment by not
renewing annual leases, he said, and instead went to month-to-month leases. At
the same time they also stopped leasing out about 70 of the apartments that
needed renovation.

With about 230 apartments still being leased out of about 320 total, there are
still more than 500 people, according to tenants, many of them working class,
poor and elderly who are concerned that they won't be able to find affordable
replacement housing anywhere near their current homes.

Efficiency apartments at Penn Plaza rent for about $470 a month, residents say,
and two-bedroom apartments go for about $850. That's less than the $1,200-and-up
rental rates on the new apartments that many residents have found opening in the
neighborhood.

"I'm a working person but I could never afford $1,300 a month," said Pamela
Robinson, 51, a security guard for Pittsburgh Public Schools who has lived at
Penn Plaza for seven years. "That would be about one-third of my salary."

Mr. Kamin said that the company "recognizes that the affordable housing issue is
a citywide problem and we believe that developers should take the lead in
addressing the issue."

Mr. Peduto and other community leaders asked residents of the building to form a
tenant council so that a few representatives could be at the table to negotiate
in future meetings with the city and the Gumbergs.

"We need to be part of this process so that the owners know that what they've
done is unjust," said resident Gail Williams, 66, a retired UPMC housekeeper who
has lived in Penn Plaza for three years and worries she'll have to move out of
the neighborhood.

Mr. Peduto said he hopes no one will have to move out of the neighborhood if
they don't want to and the city intends to use all of its leverage to prod the
Gumbergs to help prevent that.

The company has told city officials it is considering a mixed-use development
combining both residential and retail on the 7-acre site that surrounds a
2-acre, city-owned park, Enright Parklet, in between the two buildings.

That city-owned park may be small, but it could have a big impact on how the
site is developed, Mr. Peduto said.

In addition to zoning and possible government financial support for the
development, the park "is our leverage," he said. "If they tried to develop it
without [the park] they'd have a doughnut."

                     The Press Democrat, Santa Rosa, Calif.

                              April 1, 2016 Friday

Cloverdale drafts plan for long-vacant property downtown

BYLINE: Clark Mason, The Press Democrat, Santa Rosa, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 673 words


April 01--Cloverdale is looking to jump-start development on a prominent piece
of downtown property that has sat barren for years.

The city bought the 5.3-acre site seven years ago from a struggling developer
whose plans for a supermarket, retail space and housing fell through. But the
Thyme Square site has continued to languish.

The bare land, located next to the Citrus Fair, is one of the first things
motorists see as they take the central Cloverdale exit off Highway 101.

"It is one of the entrances to Cloverdale. Whatever goes in there should look
good," Mayor Mary Ann Brigham said Monday.

"We're going to have something there that really makes an impact and directs
people further into the downtown and says, 'OK, you've arrived at a beautiful
city,'" Councilwoman Carol Russell agreed.

City Council members last week agreed on a conceptual plan with a variety of
uses for the site. It calls for affordable housing, retail space and buildings
that would house the Police Department and Alexander Valley Healthcare. To top
it off, there would be a youth skate park and a couple of sculpture plazas.

But the ambitious plan must be approved by the California Department of Finance,
since the city bought the property with $3.1 million in redevelopment funds set
aside for low- and moderate-income housing projects.

The proceeds of any land sold to a developer and not used for affordable housing
may have to be returned to the state, City Manager Paul Cayler said. But it's
possible the funds could be applied to develop affordable housing on another
city-owned site near Cherry Creek.

"We don't know exactly how this is going to go with the state of California,"
Cayler said.

With a conceptual plan now in place, he said the city attorney will be able to
take the next steps of a more detailed analysis.

"There will be some limitations on what can be done, given that site was
purchased for affordable housing," City Attorney Jose Sanchez said. "Our office
is looking at different options on how to move forward."

The city last year agreed to support Alexander Valley Healthcare's plans to
build a three-floor, 38,000-square-foot wellness center on the Thyme Square
property to replace the rural clinic's aging, cramped facility and add dental
and mental health services.

"They're anxious to get going as soon as possible," Cayler said. "They're
bursting at the seams."

The Cloverdale Police Department, which has long sought to relocate from its
obsolete, seismically deficient building, is also looking to build a new,
two-story 16,000-square-foot headquarters on the Thyme Square site.

Some redevelopment funds previously were set aside for a new police building.
"We still have a few million (dollars) stashed away for the Police Department,
but not enough to do it," Brigham said.

Police Chief Stephen Cramer said his department is pursuing another option to
cover the whole cost -- funding from the U.S. Department of Agriculture -- with
slightly more than half in the form of a grant and the rest in form of a loan.

The conceptual plan for the Thyme Square property that was approved by the City
Council last week was developed by Collaborative Design Architects under a
$23,800 contract with the city.

During the council discussion, one real estate agent said there should be more
than 16,500 square feet of retail, since an anchor tenant would require even
more space.

There were also questions about the 34 one-bedroom or studio units of affordable
housing suggested in the plan. Councilwoman Russell said there should be more
bedrooms to accommodate families.

Mayor Brigham said the conceptual plan is intended to start a discussion on what
the community would like to see built.

"The conversation is beginning and everyone knows now how seriously we want to
do something with this," she said.

You can reach Staff Writer Clark Mason at 521-5214 or
clark.mason@pressdemocrat.com

(Santa Rosa, Calif.) at www.pressdemocrat.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.

JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This position is being announced to USDA, Rural Development Wisconsin employees
only.

This position will be located in either the Menomonie or Spooner Area Offices,
WI.  The Area Director will supervisor and be responsible for both Area Offices
within Wisconsin Rural Development.  One position will be selected from either
location.
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Occasional Travel
    Occasional Travel will be required

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

    Selective Service Registration is required for males born after 12/31/1959.

DUTIES:
Back to top

This position is a managerial position and is assigned to an Area Office with
USDA, Rural Development.  This position reports to the State Director.  The
incumbent serves as a key member of the State Director's staff and participates
fully in the planning, development, and implementation of rural development and
assistance programs.  The Area Director is fully responsible for the single
family housing and multi-family housing programs (loans and grants) throughout
the area, supervising employees, as well as analyzing program requirements,
providing training, and oversight of program compliance, community development,
and marketing.  Provides leadership for a comprehensive Rural Development
program to process, service, and supervise loan and grant programs throughout
the jurisdictional area and furnishes professional advice and credit ,
financial, and management guidance to rural communities and Agency customers as
appropriate.  Plans, implements, directs, and evaluates operations within the
jurisdiction, assuring that employees are receiving adequate training, loan
operations are being effectively carried out, and that customers adhere to and
receive adequate financial guidance.  Performs systematic program review and
spot-checks of individual cases to identify trends and problems.  The incumbent
is expected to work closely with other federal agencies, state legislative
bodies, state agencies and organizations, and the private sector in developing
and implementing comprehensive rural development strategies and programs to
market RD programs and service, assure optimum economic development and
opportunities in rural communities.

JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This position is being announced to USDA, Rural Development Wisconsin employees
only.

This position will be located in either the Menomonie or Spooner Area Offices,
WI.  The Area Director will supervisor and be responsible for both Area Offices
within Wisconsin Rural Development.  One position will be selected from either
location.

DUTIES:
Back to top

This position is a managerial position and is assigned to an Area Office with
USDA, Rural Development.  This position reports to the State Director.  The
incumbent serves as a key member of the State Director's staff and participates
fully in the planning, development, and implementation of rural development and
assistance programs.  The Area Director is fully responsible for the single
family housing and multi-family housing programs (loans and grants) throughout
the area, supervising employees, as well as analyzing program requirements,
providing training, and oversight of program compliance, community development,
and marketing.  Provides leadership for a comprehensive Rural Development
program to process, service, and supervise loan and grant programs throughout
the jurisdictional area and furnishes professional advice and credit ,
financial, and management guidance to rural communities and Agency customers as
appropriate.  Plans, implements, directs, and evaluates operations within the
jurisdiction, assuring that employees are receiving adequate training, loan
operations are being effectively carried out, and that customers adhere to and
receive adequate financial guidance.  Performs systematic program review and
spot-checks of individual cases to identify trends and problems.  The incumbent
is expected to work closely with other federal agencies, state legislative
bodies, state agencies and organizations, and the private sector in developing
and implementing comprehensive rural development strategies and programs to
market RD programs and service, assure optimum economic development and
opportunities in rural communities.

                          China Daily European Edition

                            December 13, 2013 Friday

Chinese farmers expect reform to ease land rights worries

SECTION: INDUSTRIES

LENGTH: 535 words


HEFEI -- City people barely glance at migrant workers like Li Jinlong, an
electric welder, who lives with his wife in makeshift dwellings near plants or
construction sites.

Li has spent the past 20 years living a humble life in Chinese cities. He seldom
has time to go back to his rural home, a two-story private abode that would be
envied by urbanites who want to escape from city life.

Li has never dreamed of buying an apartment in the city, as property prices,
even in China's second-tier cities, are skyrocketing.

What really makes the former farmer from  province anxious is that his rural
house and land have been left unattended, yielding no crops nor revenue all
these years.

There are more than 200 million farmers like Li toiling in cities without a
decent dwelling place. Their farmland and houses in rural areas have never been
their own property because they can neither trade them for cash nor mortgage
them for bank loans under the country's land laws.

Although China's urban property market has flourished since the 1990s, and has
been a major engine of economic growth, the collective ownership rules for rural
land have not changed, which has constricted rural development.

The reason lies in the fact that farmers who are entitled to property use rights
don't have property certificates to trade these rights.

In order to unleash the vitality of the rural sector, China's leaders have
decided to tackle the rural land issue by putting forward a number of reforms at
the Third Plenary Session of the 18th Communist Party of China (CPC) Central
Committee held in November. A reform master plan approved at the session
promises to give the country's 650 million rural residents more property rights.

Li feels he is lucky, as his hometown has been listed as one of 20 counties in
Anhui to pilot a new round of rural property transfer reform.

The pilot program was announced by the provincial government on the final day of
the plenary session. The reform plan is designed to pilot the mortg and transfer
of farmers' homesteads, as well as the sale, lease and demutualization of rural
construction land.

Anhui is the first Chinese province to announce it will launch the new rural
land reform. Details of the reform, however, have not yet been announced.

An official with the provincial bureau of land resources, who declined to be
named, said the reform is expected to ease the financing bottleneck to encourage
large-scale farming and invigorate the rural economy.

He said the key to tackling reform is to transform the land use rights of rural
property from their current state as collective land resources to private
property.

Li, the migrant worker, hopes that once transaction is allowed, his property can
be sold for a good price, as he has already planned for his retirement.

He wants to sell the house and go live with his son, who is currently working in
Anhui's provincial capital of Hefei.

Lu Pengfei, president of the Pengfei Modern Farming Co-operative in Anhui, said
he has already bought 5,000 mu (333 hectares) of land, which was transferred by
individual farmers through earlier rural land reforms. However, he cannot
mortgage the land to apply for bank loans for large-scale farming activities.

                              The Washington Post

                    March 26, 1994, Saturday, Final Edition

Disney Plan Called Threat To Farmland

Compiled from news services and staff reports

SECTION: REAL ESTATE; PAGE F6; REAL ESTATE NOTES

LENGTH: 754 words


The proposed Disney America theme park in Prince William County will result in
sprawling development that will threaten thousands of acres of rural Virginia
land, jeopardizing 50 percent of the state's orchards and 15 percent of its
farmland, a national farm conservation group said.

Ralph Grossi, president of the American Farmland Trust (AFT), said this week
Walt Disney Co.'s plan should not be given government approval without some
preservation measures in place.

Those measures should include the designation of special agricultural reserves
in master plans and "right-to-farm" protection for agricultural operations,
Grossi said.

"This is just one of the most flagrant examples of the threat of unplanned
growth that we see all over the country," Grossi said.

He compared rural Virginia to California's Central Valley and South Florida's
sugar cane fields, where sprawling suburbs have gobbled up thousands of acres.
"Development often causes local leaders to act in too much of a hurry to get
these jobs," Grossi said. "They don't realize what they are giving up."

Edward Thompson Jr., director of public policy for the AFT, said thousands of
acres of productive farmland will be turned into urban sprawl unless specific
plans are developed to prevent it.

"The Disney theme park is a national test case of our ability to recognize the
significance of our fast-disappearing farmland and take the steps necessary to
protect it," Thompson said.

Mary Anne Reynolds, a Disney spokeswoman, said the company has "already
identified a number of environmental initiatives for Disney's America that will
benefit adjacent farmlands." For example, she said, "we're restoring some forest
areas and reconstructing 28 acres of wetlands destroyed by agriculture years
ago."

Rick Lawson, Prince William County development services manager, said the AFT's
concerns are being addressed by the county and by a citizens task force.

He said that 2,100 acres of the 3,000 controlled by Disney already had been
zoned for a residential planned community.

The farmland preservation group issued a report examining the potential impact
on the agricultural resources and production of 12 Northern Virginia counties
within about an hour's commute of Haymarket, site of the proposed park.

The report said the area's 6,000 farms contain more than 1.2 million acres of
agricultural land, or 14 percent of the state's farmland, and account for 15
percent, or $ 236 million, of the state's total farm production.

Fifty-seven percent of the state's orchard land is found in the region, the
study said. The counties included Prince William, Fairfax, Fauquier, Loudoun,
Warren, Rappahanock, Culpeper, Clarke, Page, Frederick, Shenandoah and Madison.
The study was based on the 1987 census of agriculture, the last available.

The D.C. Housing Finance Agency (DCHFA) said it has $ 35 million in
single-family mortgage money available at its lowest interest rate ever, 6.5
percent for a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage.

Under the agency's rules, first-time buyers, with a household income of no more
than $ 69,690, may buy homes anywhere in the District; current homeowners must
purchase homes in certain "target areas" of the District undergoing
revitalization with a household income limit of $ 84,840.

"Our concern is the economic revitalization of the District's neighborhoods,"
Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly said in a statement. "We want those citizens who moved
to surrounding jurisdictions to return to the District. DCHFA's competitive
financing will help us strengthen the District's tax base and bring some native
Washingtonians home."

The agency finances FHA-insured and VA-guaranteed mortgage loans. The loan limit
in the District is $ 151,725 for FHA financing and $ 184,000 for VA financing.


IN THE NEWS ... The Northern Virginia Association of Realtors reported that 831
single-family homes, condominiums and co-ops were sold during February 1994, up
5.32 percent from the same month last year.


CALENDAR ... The Northern Virginia Association of Realtors is sponsoring a
seminar on the "Essentials of International Real Estate," April 18-19 at the
Dewberry & Davis Training Center, 8403 Arlington Blvd. in Fairfax County. For
information, call 703-207-3210 ... The Washington Metropolitan Chapter of the
Community Associations Institute is sponsoring a seminar for leaders and board
members of condominium and homeowner associations April 9 at the Ramada Inn in
Old Town Alexandria. For information, call 703-750-3644.

                            Birmingham Evening Mail

                           November 18, 2005, Friday
                                 Worcs Edition

Sailing into battle!;
PROTEST: Edgbaston vows to save reservoir oasis from 'fortress flats'
development

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 287 words


PRECIOUS green space around Edgbaston Reservoir would become "like Benidorm" if
two monolothic blocks of flats gare built, objectors claim.

The controversial scheme to build 40 family homes and 50 apartments on the site
of the Tower Ballroom on the shores of the reservoir has sparked outrage from
local people.

At a packed public meeting scores of residents spoke out against what they
claimed would be a "fortress" development which would damage forever the
priceless rural appeal of the reservoir.

The Friends of Edgbaston Reservoir, backed by residents, believe the proposals
for two four-storey apartment blocks would set a precedent and encourage other
developers to build directly on to the reservoir, destroying its ecological
balance.

Developers Countrywide Homes, who have been consulting city council officials
and the local community, say the proposals would create a waterside village and
kick-start the wider regeneration of the area.

More than 80 acres of land surrounding the reservoir and the Icknield Port canal
loop are to be redeveloped with new bars, restaurants and homes.

The reservoir is already designated as a Site of Importance for Nature
Conservation and is home to a sailing and a rowing club and the Sea Cadet Corps
of Training Ship Vernon.

It also has a lodge at its main entrance which is a Grade II Listed building.
The reservoir site is currently designated for leisure use, not housing, and
that is how local people want it to stay.

Rather than building more homes in an already densely populated area, they want
to see a leisure centre or a swimming pool.

Led by Friends of Edgbaston Reservoir chairman Chris Vaughan, residents now aim
to bombard city planners with letters and a protest petition.

                                US Official News

                             June 19, 2014 Thursday

Agriculture, Rural Housing Service: Loan Specialist (Commercial) TN-MP2014-4886

LENGTH: 3311  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of Personnel Management has issued the following job announcement:

Job Title:Loan Specialist (Commercial)

Department:Department Of Agriculture

Agency:Agriculture, Rural Housing Service

SALARY RANGE:

OPEN PERIOD:

SERIES & GRADE:

POSITION INFORMATION:
 Full-Time - Permanent
PROMOTION POTENTIAL:

 1 vacancy - Nashville, TN View Map
WHO MAY APPLY:
 Current permanent Rural Development employees government-wide with competitive
status, and USDA CTAP eligibles.
SECURITY CLEARANCE:
 Not Applicable
SUPERVISORY STATUS:

JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

This position is part of the Community Programs Staff of the Rural Development
(RD) Tennessee State Office. The incumbent develops and recommends standards,
guides, procedures and forms, informational releases and training materials for
use of personnel regarding loans and/or grants, as appropriate, comprising the
specialized Community Programs (CP) area of agency program work; and
participates fully in planning and executing statewide training programs.
Ascertains the effectiveness of services provided by Area Offices, their
adherence to program objectives and the level of technical and management skills
applied to loan planning and servicing.
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Occasional Travel
    Occasional travel from 1-5 days a month

DUTIES:
Back to top

Provides technical advice and assistance to Area Office Personnel on such
matters as sound loan making and servicing methods, organization of
associations, land use and development practices, distribution and use of water,
installation of facilities, analysis of borrowers' records and operations, rural
development, holding borrowers' meetings, and the handling of legal and problem
cases, security servicing, collection and related program matters. Assists them
in making effective contacts to keep the public informed of RD programs, resolve
difficult problems of program acceptance, and to utilize available outside
services for program purposes.

Advises Area Personnel of the latest trends and developments in rural property
management and credit fields; sees that they are provided with adequate
materials and guidance for practical application; and that they receive adequate
engineering and other technical assistance from within and outside the
organization to fulfill CP operating requirements.

Reviews and evaluates overall CP activity, including loan making, loan
servicing, technical services, credit counseling and the progress and transfer
of borrowers to private or cooperative credit, to determine operating efficiency
and the degree of understanding and correctness of application of program
policies and procedures. Makes recommendations for improving total CP
operations, giving particular attention to those areas having unusually complex
operating problems and conditions.

Reviews grants and recommends approval or disapproval of loan and grant cases
channeled through the State Office; develops the necessary actions and solutions
to problems associated with the highly complex types of loans; and exercises
delegated loan approval authority. Processes legal and problem cases submitted
to the State Office; with responsibility for seeing that they are competently
planned and negotiated with all interested parties.

Corresponds with the National Office, Office of the General Counsel and others
thereon and advises initiating office on case disposition. Reviews and
recommends action on cases pertaining to the compromise, adjustment or
cancellation of debts and those involved in litigation or bankruptcy actions.

Analyzes field program activity reports to determine trends or detect weaknesses
and recommends measures or prepares instructional materials to remedy conditions
noted. Participates in resource and economic base studies to develop information
that will guide program decisions.

Informs and advises the general public and special interest groups about
available rural credit assistance through news media, technical publications and
group meetings. Actively participates in working out mutually acceptable
procedures with agencies having joint responsibilities for rural development and
assistance activities, and shares in technical and financial planning for
development projects.

and/or municipal transactions or by servicing a commercial loan portfolio. There

administration, economics, accounting, insurance, engineering, mathematics,
banking and credit, law, real estate operations, statistics, or other field
related to the position, such as agriculture, agricultural economics, farm,
livestock or ranch management, or rural sociology.

                                 Jerusalem Post

                            October 19, 2010 Tuesday

The failure to secure home ownership

BYLINE:  SETH FRANTZMAN

SECTION: OPINION; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 973 words


A fascinating set of statistics were presented by Channel 2's Oren Aharoni on
October 13. The report was titled "In Israel people work the hardest to buy a
house."

According to the data, it takes just 30 months of work for the average Swede to
buy a house. The American works 60 months, while the Israeli is burdened by 129
months.

The information is not based on how much a person might actually work and save
or whether he can secure a mortgage to finance a house, it is just raw math
calculated on a person working without spending any money and saving every penny
toward the home. Consider the American numbers: 60 months multiplied by an
average salary of $2,000 a month equals $120,000. That is the cost of a home in
the type of market where the average salary is $2,000 (i.e. Arizona). So the
numbers make sense.

What is happening here? Based on the math it seems that a person making NIS
5,000 a month can achieve his dream of buying a home for NIS 645,000 in 11
years. Of course he won't ever achieve his dream because when one factors in all
the expenses the person must pay out every month, including utility bills, rent
and taxes, he is left with a tiny sum to save toward buying a home. Even with
the possibility of obtaining a mortgage, which in reality is the only reason
average people in any country can ever purchase a home, the Israeli is not only
behind his peers in other countries but he faces an increasingly uphill battle
to obtain propertied independence.

Why is this the fate of Israelis? This was supposed to be a country of hope for
the world's Jews, a place they could call their own and put down roots. But when
it comes to home ownership, which is a large part of identifying with one's
landscape, the Jewish citizens have little hope of obtaining this essential
lifestyle.

One must write "Jewish" here because all things are not the same when it comes
to home ownership. The Arab community owns most of the fully private land (5
percent roughly) and home ownership is held in high esteem in Arab culture (one
oft-repeated ditty is "have a son, build a house, plant a tree"). The Arab
community suffers from perceived building restrictions and overcrowding, lack of
planning, infrastructure and other issues, but owning one's own property is not
one of the factors mentioned by Arab rights groups as an issue of
discrimination.

SO WHAT is it that has turned the Zionist dream of living in one's own land on
its head? One oft-repeated excuse for the lack of affordable housing and steep
prices is that there is a lack of land. Obviously relatively wealthy countries
with a high population density tend to have housing price problems. In the 1990s
the business world was abuzz with stories of the "100-year Japanese mortgage" or
what was called the "three generational loan."

In the society of the "salaryman" (the Japanese term for the lifetime employee
in a business suit) such exotic financial instruments, while not necessarily the
norm, shine a light on what befell Japanese urban society due to rising real
estate prices.

Home ownership was not only out of the grasp of the Japanese though. Under
communism in Russia newlyweds told nightmare stories of waiting years to get the
"right" to live in small dingy apartments. But Israel isn't Russia under the
stagnation of the Brezhnev years, nor is it crazily hi-tech urban Japan. Even in
the worst development towns or peripheral communities, home ownership remains a
tough call.

In Beersheba the statistics tell us that one must work full time for 58 months
and save every penny.

How is it possible that in the rural periphery, in the desert where there are
millions of empty dunams, that people cannot afford to buy a simple apartment,
let alone a house? The answer is partly salaries. Public salaries are abysmal.
Police are paid a paltry starting wage of NIS 4,400 a month. Private salaries
aren't any better except in some industries in Tel Aviv, and there they still
don't compensate for the ridiculous price of real estate (216 months of work to
purchase an apartment).

Some of those interviewed on Channel 2 pointed to a government solution. Dov
Henin, the Hadash MK, complained about lack of government support for more
housing. Another man voiced anger that the government sends people to army
reserve duty but "gives them no hope" afterward.

Government can't solve all our problems. Artificially low prices for apartments
or building more flats isn't the only answer. Some hidden problems affecting the
real estate market can be found elsewhere. One issue that doesn't always exist
in other countries is that the rural property market is very frozen. To put it
simply, Arabs and Jews are not able to relocate. No Jew can move to an Arab
neighborhood and in many cases can't even gain admittance to Jewish rural
communities, like kibbutzim and moshavim. Arabs also are generally unable to buy
homes anywhere but within their own communities.

This creates, for better or worse, a frozen market, one artificially structured
to allow only certain groups to live in certain places, the opposite of a free
and open real estate market. Obsession with planning - the resulting eyesores
can be seen in every development town and suburban or urban community - leads to
building plans being approved that have nothing to do with the private demand
for housing.

How else to explain the absolute scandal that is the Jerusalem housing market
where the statistics tell us one must work 151 months, in one of the poorest
cities in the country, to buy a property? Government regulation, the inability
of ethnic groups to mingle, the domination of the rural environment by communes
from another era and other factors have conspired to crush the dream of home
ownership.

The writer is a PhD researcher at Hebrew university and a fellow at the
Jerusalem Institute for Market Studies.

LOAD-DATE: February 22, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES: TERRA INCOGNITA. This was supposed to be a country of hope for the
world's Jews. But when it comes to buying a home, the Jewish citizens have
little hope of obtaining this essential lifestyle

GRAPHIC: Photo: A VIEW of the construction site of a luxury apartment building
near the beach in Tel Aviv. Israel has emerged as one of the hottest, and
unlikeliest, property markets in the world: Since real estate collapsed around
the world in 2008, few if any countries have seen house prices rise faster.
(Credit: AP)

                           The Sunday Times (London)

                               November 18, 2007

Between Rock and a hard place

BYLINE: Cally Law

SECTION: FEATURES; Home; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 1556 words


* House prices in the southwest are among the highest in Britain compared to
salaries. But local farmers are helping to bridge the affordability gap, says
Cally Law

There is little doubt that Rock, on the north Cornish coast, has been one of the
great property success stories of the past decade. Second-homers with City
bonuses have splurged up to £ 1m on nondescript bungalows with sea views, then
sat back and watched their investments rocket. For many of the locals, though,
it has been a disaster, as house prices have spun way beyond the reach of the
average salary.

Now, as in much of Britain, the market is uncertain and the big-money deals are
stalling -but the locals don't care. Thanks to a pioneering community-based
self-build scheme, and a farmer who has sold a plot of land on the edge of the
village at a fraction of the going rate, 12 families have the chance to buy a
first home of their own in one of the most expensive places in Britain. A
three-bed bungalow is priced at £ 84,000 -less than a third of the £ 350,000
they could fetch on the open market. The project is being seen as a potential
model for other communities elsewhere in the southwest and beyond.

The origins of the scheme go back four years, when the late Bill Dingle, a local
builder and parish councillor, realised the lads working for him, building homes
for others, would never be able to buy a place themselves. At his instigation,
the St Minver Community Land Trust was formed to provide the wherewithal for 12
locals to build their own homes at a price they could afford. Such trusts have
been around for decades, largely for the management of orchards and woodlands.
Now, though, they are being encouraged by the government as an efficient way of
delivering rural homes.

The first requirement was land. Retired farmer David Wills, 76, who is the
chairman of the trust, sold a 1.5-acre field for £ 120,000, or £ 10,000 a plot.
It lay just outside the development boundary of the village -although single
plots, closer to the centre, can fetch as much as £ 400,000 each. Wills says
that there wasn't much else he could do with his land, though a less charitable
person might have hung onto it in the hope of a boundary change.

Thanks to the involvement of the not-for-profit trust, North Cornwall district
council accepted Wills's field as a rural exception site. In other words,
despite its location, it is eligible for planning permission as long as all the
homes built on it are classed as affordable -and will continue to be so in
perpetuity.

The council provided the trust with an interest-free loan of £ 544,000, to be
repaid within 15 months. Fittingly, this money came from funds raised by
increased council-tax charges for second-homeowners, who now pay 90% rather than
50% of the usual rate. It will be repaid when the self-builders take out a
mortgage on their properties.

Competition to get on the scheme was fierce, with 45 applicants for the 12
places.

Candidates had to have strong local connections and be unable to afford to buy a
suitable home in the area - often because they couldn't obtain a mortgage.

The winners will be given the plots, with planning permission, roads and
services, foundations and a timber frame, up and ready to be filled in.

Once they have received mortgage approval, all they need to do is get together
and build the rest. A bit of blockwork, plasterboard, electrics and plumbing,
and, with a project manager on hand to lead the way, by Christmas next year, 24
lucky people and their children should be living in detached bungalows with
garages, gardens and driveways.

Should they ever want to sell, a prospective buyer must be approved by the
trust.

"The same constraints will apply in perpetuity, and we will buy back if
necessary," says Helen Richards, 63, a retired property negotiator, former
county councillor and company secretary of the trust.

Jemma Hoskins, 23, a holiday letting agent, is buying a three-bedroom plot with
Daniel Latham, 33, a painter and decorator. Her brother will help with her share
of the building -there's nothing in the rules to say buyers have to do the work
themselves -and she plans to live there for a long time. "Why would we want to
sell?" she says.

Tom O'Donnell, 28, a trainee building surveyor, is moving in with his wife,
Michelle, and their children, Jack, 4, and Amelie, 1. "We could maybe have
afforded a one-bed flat in nearby Wadebridge," he says, "so we feel very lucky
to be given this chance."

Rock is far from the only place in the southwest where property prices have
risen far out of line with earnings in recent years. "Cornwall has one of the
worst affordability gaps in Britain," says Alan Fox, community land trust
project manager at Cornwall Rural Housing Association. "And this gap -the
difference between household incomes and house prices -is exacerbated by
second-homeowners." The average income in north Cornwall, where the main
industry is tourism, is just £ 18,626 -against a national average of £ 23,580.

And research published last month by Hometrack reveals that 34% of young working
households in the southwest cannot afford to buy in the area where they live -
even more than in London, where the figure is 31.5%.

A similar land trust scheme is due to start next year at St Just in Roseland, a
village about 35 miles from Rock, on Cornwall's southern coast, where
second-homers have also pushed prices beyond the reach of locals. Six years ago,
Roland Michell, 40, a carpenter, banded together with a group of eight men in
the building trade. "Most of us were living with our parents or in rented
accommodation," he says, "and we thought that if we could find a farmer to sell
us a bit of land, we could build our own homes."

Finding the land was no problem: a local landowner was happy to sell the group
three-quarters of an acre on the edge of the village for £ 30,000, a site big
enough for eight plots. "He didn't mind losing a bit of land, because he knew it
was going to a good cause," Michell says.

Carrick district council bought it from the landowner, charging the self
builders just £ 1 a plot, and granted planning permission when it discovered the
land trust scheme. "It means we won't be able to sell on the open market,"
Michell says, "but it was the only way we were going to get the result we
needed, which was a place in the village we were born in, to bring up our
families."

The St Just self-builders will each raise a £ 95,000 mortgage for the cost of
building, although, like their counterparts in Rock, they will have to put in
several months' work themselves. Similar three-bedroom houses on the Roseland
peninsula sell on the open market for between £ 300,000 and £ 350,000.

The government hopes that, with the help of the surprisingly large number of
landowners who are willing to sell land for a fraction of its potential value,
more schemes can be rolled out nationwide. Two are already in place in Dorset.

In Buckland Newton, 10 homes are being built -some shared ownership, some for
rent -on an acre of land sold by a landowner for £ 5,000 a plot. The land was
deemed a rural-exception site and therefore given planning permission. "The
owner was very much swayed by helping the community," says Andy Lloyd, rural
housing enabler for West Dorset and Purbeck district councils. "Some landowners
may have failed to get planning permission, but want to get some value out of a
small piece of land; others are more altruistic."

The other scheme is in Worth Matravers, where more than half the houses are
second homes. Here, a local businessman, Bob Kenyon, snapped up a five-plot,
two-acre site, holding onto it until the trust was in a position to buy, then
selling it on at cost.

There are other extraordinary examples of personal generosity. In East
Portlemouth, near Salcombe, in Devon, more than 70% of properties are second
homes. Isobel Waterhouse, 71, who was born in the village, is giving away four
cottages, with a total value of £ 2m, to provide affordable rental housing for
young families.

"I'm doing it because I hope that other people will enjoy the places that I
have, and that young families can grow up in this magical place," she told one
interviewer.

When the village hall needed a new roof and a refurb last year, at a cost of £
50,000, a request for contributions was sent to the second-homers. "We were
overwhelmed," says Lindsey Lindley, chairman of the parish council. "We raised
the lot, and more."

Meanwhile, back in Rock, work is about to begin on the bungalows. If it goes
well, the trust has hopes of a second phase. Wills, for one, is confident: "The
community spirit is going to make it a lovely place to live." And affordable,
too.

                     The Press Democrat, Santa Rosa, Calif.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             August 18, 2014 Monday

EDITORIAL: A housing market on the upswing brings challenges

BYLINE: The Press Democrat, Santa Rosa, Calif.

SECTION: COMMENTARY

LENGTH: 550 words


Aug. 18--For those who held tight during the housing swoon, who made payments,
weren't caught with balloon mortgages and rode out the recession in
neighborhoods relatively unscathed by foreclosures, there is reward in the
latest news of recovery in California. The American dream of home ownership is
again an investment that pays off.

But with every new report of promising gains is the inevitable worrisome
asterisk. Rising prices mean more people shut out of the housing market. It
means low- and middle-wage workers struggle to find affordable rents, much less
a lender willing to accept a less-than-stellar credit rating and
less-than-average income as a new customer.

As Staff Writer Robert Digitale reported, the median sales price for homes in
Santa Rosa reached $508,500 in July, up 2.5 percent from June and 6.2 percent
from a year earlier. Sale prices in Santa Rosa have appreciated 50 percent over
the past five years, according to the Trulia online real estate site. The
average listing price for Santa Rosa homes on Trulia was $711,404 for the week
ending Aug. 6.

That keeps Santa Rosa above California averages, already high for the nation,
but not at the tip-top.

That glory -- or bane -- goes to other cities. Four of the five most expensive
housing markets are in California, according to the National Association of
Realtors. Topping the list: San Jose metro area, where the median existing
single-family home price was $899,500; followed by San Francisco's $769,600,
Anaheim-Santa Ana's $691,900 and San Diego's $504,200. The only non-California
area to make the top five was Honolulu in fourth place, at $678,500.

Economists projecting the future of California's economy predict better than
average results. They are just a bit blue about the lack of affordable housing,
which could tamp down expected economic growth.

Sonoma Valley homes are again becoming unreachable for many people, especially
for younger buyers. The college-debt strapped millennials are particularly
pinched.

Changes are needed. The federal government could make federal loan repayment
accessible in more fields where more workers are sought and the community
benefits from their endeavors. The medical field is a good start, for example.
It benefits many. However, we have more needs, and more young workers would
welcome the opportunity to live here, contribute in a helping professional and
work themselves out of life-crimping loans.

Locally, lenders of all stripes need to step up to broaden access to loans,
especially for working class petitioners.

Civic, business and government leaders can get ahead of this issue by joining
hands in creative ways to broaden access to home loans, and accepting denser
development in some areas. The housing issue intertwines with wages and the need
to attract workers for jobs of all sorts.

"You can't add jobs if there is no growth in the labor force because people are
leaving because they can't afford housing," Chris Thornberg, an economist with
Beacon Economics, has warned.

Our community must rise to the challenge of ensuring enough housing exists at
many price points to protect and expand the local economy.

(Santa Rosa, Calif.) at www.pressdemocrat.com Distributed by MCT Information
Services

                               The Financial Post

                     May 23, 1998 Saturday WEEKLY EDITIONS

MOVEABLE FEAST: Prefabricated homes run the gamut from Mexican villas to
custom-design cottages

BYLINE: Jessica Pegis, For The Financial Post

SECTION: SECTION 2, FP REVIEW; Pg. R4, Property

LENGTH: 1017 words


Keith Weinbender remembers the days when buyers of manufactured homes in some
rural areas of Western Canada couldn't even get a mortgage. People buying
joists, floors and walls from a factory and schlepping the stuff across the
countryside? Uh-uh.

That's all changed, says Weinbender, senior vice-president at Nelson Homes, a
division of Nelson Lumber Co. in Lloydminster, Alta. 'Back then, I guess the
lenders were scared of us because we were often far away and we were a system
they hadn't heard about. Now, when our homes go up for sale a second and third
time, the real estate ad will say say, 'Nelson home for sale' and the model
number will be included.'

His company has built 33,000 manufactured homes in Western Canada since the
launch of its homes division in 1959.

And that - from ignorant to magnificent - just about summarizes the history of
manufactured houses in Canada. Although factory-made homes still represent just
a small percentage of total housing sales, lots of people are learning to move
beyond the prefab stereotype.

Myth No. 1 is that prefabs are cheaper. Not necessarily, say those in the know.
They're just better because they're built in a controlled environment. And you
can't beat the speed: six to 10 weeks from purchase to finished product.

But try to get the lingo right before you go shopping. The term 'manufactured'
covers all bases but it usually refers to a structure that is assembled on site.
The factory precuts the joists, flooring and walls (with window openings already
in them), and ships the pieces (or panels) to you. The house is assembled at its
final destination.

A modular home, on the other hand (sometimes called a mobile home, not to be
confused with a 'trailer') is built at a factory in large sections (or modules),
then moved to its location. Panelized homes usually require a team, often
arranged by the manufacturer, to finish the wiring, plumbing and interior trim.
Modules are usually shipped with all the finishing touches, including paint,
wiring, and plumbing.

Quality Manufactured Homes in Kenilworth, Ont., builds modular homes for the
Ontario market. Sales and marketing manager Bill Wells admits prefab homes still
have the greatest appeal among rural buyers.

'We do about 140 to 150 homes per year, almost entirely in rural Ontario.
Farmers are very familiar with modular housing because it's ideal if you have a
nice lot and are looking for a custom home. People who have always lived in the
city and are moving to the country or are buying a cottage usually can't believe
what can be done. They're just blown away by the whole thing.'

Believe it. This year's Dream Home for the National Home Show, held in Toronto
April 3 to 12, was built and assembled by Quality. The Mexican-style villa
consisted of nine separate modules totalling 4,000 square feet and included a
floor plan designed around a central courtyard. Another contractor, arranged by
Quality, created the authentic tile roof. The house was shipped to an eager
buyer after 125,000 people had a chance to look at it.

'It's not the kind of thing we would build every day, but it did demonstrate
what is possible,' says Wells. The company assembled the house in six days and
took it apart in two. At $ 75 to $ 90 a square foot, it came in at more than $
300,000, the high end of the spectrum for manufactured homes.

The company's most popular model averages from four to five modules and costs
from $ 150,000 to $ 200,000, and that includes everything from foyer tiles to
furnace, plus garage. Each module measures about 15 ft. by 15 ft. by 60 ft. They
can be attached horizontally or vertically in an infinite variety of designs.

'The number of modules can vary from two - a little bungalow, which is what
people are thinking about when they think of a modular home - to four, five, or
even 10 modules,' says Wells. 'The largest home we ever built had 11 modules and
6,000 sq. ft.'

Panelized homes are also available in practically any size, from 800 sq. ft. to
5,000 sq. ft., and the sky's the limit in terms of design.

'We've become a very custom builder,' says Weinbender of his company. 'I say to
people that you can walk in any city in North America, pick any home you like
and we can probably build it exactly the same, and you wouldn't know the
difference. Right now, we're selling a home with a seven-car garage. We've built
homes as large as 7,000 sq. ft. Because we sell in Alberta, where there are
sprawling areas for ranches, we're being asked to build some very large homes.'

The company's most popular house is 1,300 sq. ft., priced at $ 45,000 to $
50,000. Some on-site work will be extra.

Another specialty manufactured home in demand right now is the traditional post
and beam house, not to be confused with the little log cabin, says David
McFarlane, president of Normerica, formerly Upper Canada Post & Beam, and one of
the leading manufacturers of post and beam structures worldwide.

From the outside, you can't tell these houses begin with precut pine posts,
rafters and joists. Inside, however, the aromatic wood gives away the secret.
McFarlane is sure his houses appreciate faster and better than many on the
market. Earlier this year, the company built a 4,000 sq. ft. home for the
vice-president of a major developer at Keystone, Colo. The executive paid US$
500,000 for materials and assembly, and now estimates his house is worth US$ 1.3
million.

'The person who buys our product is looking for a principal residence or a
chalet in one of the ex-urban areas. They're looking for something different and
they're usually professional people,' says McFarlane.

The company's best Canadian markets are 'the Banff area of Alberta, the interior
of British Columbia, Whistler, Muskoka and Georgian Bay, and Ottawa - all the
places you would expect to see us.'

The average price for a finished post and beam home is $ 100 to $ 125 a sq. ft.,
plus site servicing costs such as digging the foundation and installing wiring
and plumbing.

'It's an exceptionally custom product at an unexceptional price,' says
McFarlane.

                             March 8, 2014 Saturday

Oklahoma business briefs for March 8

SECTION:

LENGTH: 329 words



Oklahoma briefs

Three projects to receive funds

STILLWATER - Three Oklahoma projects have been selected to receive funding
awards from the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The awards are a part of a
nearly $16 million investment in rural telecommunications equipment, aimed at
expanding access to education, job creation, and improved health care in 25
states through USDA's Distance Learning and Telemedicine Loan and Grant program.
Among the recipients are the school districts of Arkoma, which will receive
$393,333, and McAlester Public School, which will receive $336,543 for their
distance learning projects.

The school districts will use their awards to link to neighboring schools,
universities, and other educational resources. The Board of Regents of the
University of Oklahoma was selected for a $500,000 telemedicine grant to be used
at the Health Sciences Center. The OU project will expand geriatric and
educational services through video teleconferencing to three partners: Choctaw
Nation clinical sites, Stillwell Community Hospital, and Variety Care clinical
sites in Fort Cobb, Grandfield, and Tipton. Digital equipment and software will
be purchased with the grant funds.Oklahoma joins egg lawsuitOklahoma has joined
a multistate lawsuit against a California law that requires egg producers to
comply with stricter standards to sell within the state. The 2008 California law
requires egg produces to provide larger housing enclosures for egg-laying hens
in order to sell eggs in the state. Missouri, Alabama, Kentucky, Iowa and
Nebraska are also part of the lawsuit. The lawsuit asks a federal court in
California to strike down the law as unconstitutional because it violates the
Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution, which bans states from passing laws
that regulate businesses and industries outside their borders. Oklahoma produced
741 million eggs in 2012, with a value of $90.5 million, according to the U.S.
Department of Agriculture.

                       The Janesville Gazette (Wisconsin)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              June 29, 2008 Sunday

Housing market ripe for first-time buyers

BYLINE: Stacy Vogel, The Janesville Gazette, Wis.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1181 words


Jun. 29--JANESVILLE -- The national housing market has been spewing bad news
about foreclosures, dropping prices and a glut of homes on the market.

But the bad news for the market could be good news for buyers, said Verna
Saladino, a real estate agent with Coldwell Banker Success in Janesville. That's
especially true for first-time homebuyers who don't have to worry about selling
their current homes.

"There's just great opportunities for a first-time homebuyer in the area,"
Saladino said. "There's great properties to choose from, and the interest rates
are still phenomenal."

The process for buying a home might seem daunting, but plenty of resources are
available for first-time buyers. Here are a few tips to get you started:

Q: How do I know if I'm ready to buy a home?

A: There are plenty of advantages to owning a home--it's a good investment and
helps you build equity, Saladino said.

But you have to examine your finances to see if you're ready, said Dave Sheedy,
state mortgage sales manager for M&I Bank. Your banker can examine your credit
history, income and savings to let you know if you can afford a house and, if
so, how much you can afford.

Though some programs allow you to buy a home with no money down, Sheedy
recommends having some savings for a down payment and closing costs, he said.

"We would always encourage a borrower to have money available for a down
payment, because in most instances that will help them get in a better-priced
mortgage," he said.

You also should be prepared to live in the home for at least five years to
recoup your costs when you sell it, Saladino said.

"You've got to give it time to appreciate," she said.

Q: What's the first step in buying a home?

A: The first step is to get pre-approved by a lender, Saladino said. Your lender
will tell you how what kind of loan you can afford so you know what kind of
houses at which you should look.

You also should find a real estate agent you like, Saladino said. She recommends
you work with one agent to find a house because that agent knows the area and
can keep you in mind when looking at new properties for sale, she said.

If you don't have a lender, a real estate agent can help you find one, she said.

Q: What kinds of resources are available for a first-time homebuyer?

A: Financial and educational resources abound for first-time homebuyers in the
area.

The city of Janesville offers free homebuyer workshops several times a year. The
classes bring in experts to teach buyers about loans, credit, home inspections
and the buying process.

"The homebuyers workshop is a great resource for people who are considering
(buying a house)," said Jennifer Petruzzello, Janesville Neighborhood Services
director.

Participants also can learn about special loan programs for first-time buyers.
For example, the Federal Housing Authority and the Wisconsin Housing and
Economic Development Authority both offer low-interest loans with little down
payment required.

The city of Janesville offers loans of up to $2,500 to income-eligible residents
for down payment and closing costs, Petruzzello said. The debt is forgiven over
a period of five years.

The city also offers home improvement loans for residents who meet certain
conditions, she said.

Plus, most banks have their own loan programs for first-time buyers, Saladino
said.

Q: What else should I consider in buying a home?

A: Homebuyers need to remember that owning a home isn't the same as renting,
Sheedy said. Homeowners are responsible for maintenance and have to fix anything
that goes wrong on the property.

As you think about your monthly mortgage, remember you also have to be able to
set money aside each month for property taxes, home maintenance and unexpected
problems.

"Everybody has life changes that occur as they go through life, and as you hit
the bump in the road, you don't want to be forced into not making your mortgage
payment because you blew a tire in your car," Sheedy said.

SHOULD I BUY A FORECLOSED HOME?

Some homebuyers focus on foreclosed homes because they think they'll get a great
deal, said Verna Saladino, a real estate agent with Coldwell Banker Success in
Janesville.

But while you might save some money, you probably won't get a basement bargain,
she said. Banks know how much homes are worth, and while they want to sell the
product quickly, they're not looking to lose a lot of money.

"If you get anywhere near where they feel the fair value is on it, they'll sell
it, but you're not going to steal it," she said.

People who buy foreclosed homes should be prepared for some extra wait and work,
Saladino said. Banks have their own timetables, and they don't have the urgency
to close the deal that some sellers might.

And the bank doesn't have the knowledge about the home that an owner would have.
When you buy a foreclosed home, you're basically buying it "as is."

That might mean accepting flaws, Saladino said. Sometimes, a homeowner who can't
pay his or mortgage gets discouraged and stops taking care of the home before a
foreclosure.

"There's no warranty, no guarantee to that," she said.

IF YOU GO

The next set of Janesville homebuyers workshops will meet from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m.
Tuesdays, Aug. 5, 12, 19 and 26. The fifth session is scheduled after you buy a
home. To register, call Janesville Neighborhood Services at (608) 755-3065 or
stop by the office at City Hall, 18 N. Jackson St.

HOMEBUYERS RESOURCES

Here are some resources if you're thinking about buying a home:

-- Janesville Neighborhood Services: (608) 755-3065 or www.ci.janesville.wi.us.
Offers first-time homebuyer workshops and down payment assistance.

-- Wisconsin Housing and Economic Development: 1-800-334-6873 or www.wheda.com.
Offers low-interest mortgages with little down payment.

-- Movin' Out: 1-877-861-6746 or www.movin-out.org. Provides down payment
assistance and housing rehabilitation loans to disabled households throughout
Wisconsin.

-- USDA Rural Development Program: 1-866-474-3600 or
www.rurdev.usda.gov/rbs/ezec. Offers extended-term mortgages and other
affordable financing options for purchase or repair of rural homes.

ARE YOU READY?

Here is a list of questions from the Federal Housing Administration to ask
yourself before buying your first home:

-- Do I have a steady, reliable source of verifiable income?

-- Have I been employed on a regular basis for the last two to three years?

-- Do I have a good record of paying my bills?

-- Do I have manageable long-term debts, such as car payments?

-- Do I have money for a down payment?

-- Do I have the ability to pay a mortgage and other living costs every month?

For more information, visit the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Web site, www.hud.gov/buying.

http://www.gazetteextra.com. Copyright (c) 2008, The Janesville Gazette, Wis.
