                          New Straits Times (Malaysia)

                           December 12, 2015 Saturday

`Pay BR1M every month'

SECTION: Pg. 6

LENGTH: 540 words


KUALA LUMPUR: ISSUES related to the increasing cost of living remain as the main
topic on the second day of debate with party delegates making a number of
suggestions for the party to address the problem.

Pahang Umno representative Datuk Shahaniza Shamsuddin said the government could
help the people face the high cost of living by providing RM500 monthly payment
under the 1Malaysia People's Aid (BR1M).

"It is more appropriate to pay BR1M on a monthly basis and it will only cost
RM6,000 annually for each recipient," said the Maran Umno division deputy chief
when debating a motion to support the president's policy speech yesterday.

 She urged the selection mechanism for BR1M recipients to be reviewed as it
should involve village heads and the Umno leadership at the branch level.

"When the selection was made by the Inland Revenue Board, some of the eligible
recipients did not get the aid," she said, adding that BR1M had helped the
low-income group since it was introduced.

 She said the government should help the young people own affordable homes since
many of them could not secure loans due to stringent terms and regulations set
by financial institutions.

"We must solve this problem as soon as possible if we want the young people to
vote for us," she said.

Shahaniza also hoped the goverment would help solve the problems faced by
teachers especially the heavy workload and the posting that separated them from
their spouse.

Perak Puteri Umno chief Salbiah Mohamed said the government should review the
1Malaysia People's Housing Programme (PR1MA) and ensure that its core business
was not only for profit but to increase the number of house owners annually.

 She said the younger generation were unable to own a house, including so-called
affordable homes, as they were saddled with debts including study loans after
graduation.

"Despite the many 'Mampu Milik' (affordable) housing projects, the younger
generation can only 'mampu tengok' (afford to look) at these houses," she said.

Salbiah hoped Umno and the government would introduce more programmes to help
the young generate income to supplement their salary. She also advised local
councils not to disturb those operating roadside stalls since they also had to
earn a living.

Kedah Umno delegate Datuk Othman Aziz said the Rubber Production Incentive
should include a living allowance to alleviate the burden faced by rubber
tappers, whose income depended on weather conditions.

"It is hoped that the government could conduct a study to consider giving rubber
tappers other incentives, such as allowances for six months in a year. An
allowance of between RM300 and RM600 may improve the scheme," he said, adding
that rubber tappers were badly affected during the rainy season.

Othman, who is Muda Agricultural Development Authority chairman, said projects
such as the multi-million ringgit Rubber City project in Padang Terap would help
spur development in rural areas.

He said the project on a 647ha site in Kuala Nerang was expected to have a gross
development value of RM11.2 billion and create 20,000 job opportunities.

Othman said the 2016 Budget tabled by the government was comprehensive as it
provided allocations for farmers, fishermen and subsidies for certain crops.

                           The Sunday Times (London)

                                    Ireland

Nama vows to build 30,000 homes

BYLINE: Stephen O'Brien

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 298 words


NAMA is promising to build more than 30,000 homes in Dublin and the commuter
belt before winding up operations as the state's bad bank.

The programme involves completing 3,000 new houses and apartments by the end of
2016, and securing planning permission for 3,500 more units after that.

Nama says it has found potential for another 25,000 homes in Dublin, Wicklow,
Kildare, Meath and Louth, but this would require investment in heavy
infrastructure.

The bad bank says it has entered agreements with partners such as Dublin city
council to build two new road and pedestrian bridges across the Liffey to
facilitate housing development in the docklands.

It is also working with Irish Water to identify supply needs in lands zoned for
housing across the commuter belt.

Nama is due to have repaid all of its debt to the Irish banks - AIB/EBS, Bank of
Ireland, Permanent TSB and the Central Bank - by 2018. As part of its wind-down,
it has been asked by the government to help complete the development of Dublin's
docklands and address the housing shortage.

"Nama has already paid down between 55% and 60% of its (EURO)32bn debt to the
Irish banks and will reach the 80% target next year," a spokesman said. "The
agency looks beyond individual developments. If the addition of a bridge or a
water supply makes development more feasible, it will take an overarching view
of the area and work with Irish Water or the local authorities to provide
funding for the necessary infrastructure."

Since 2014, Nama has funded the construction of 1,667 new housing units across
39 sites in Dublin, often working with developers whose bad loans are on the
agency's books.

Construction is under way on 1,600 units across 40 sites to be delivered by the
end of 2016, and planning approval is in place for 1,400 more.

                             National Mortgage News

                                 June 27, 1994

Joint Effort Will Generate $ 10MM Of Below-Market-Rate Financing

SECTION: AFFORDABLE HOUSING; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 664 words

DATELINE: SEATTLE


A joint effort by the State of Washington and the Federal Home Loan Bank of
Seattle will generate $ 10 million in below-market-rate financing for the
development of affordable housing for low- and moderate-income people.

The effort began with the state's purchase of a $ 10 million fixed-rate bond
issued by the Federal Home Loan Bank System.

The proceeds of the bond sale will be used by the FHLB of Seattle to finance $
10 million in below-market-rate loans made by the bank under its Community
Investment Program to member financial institutions.

They, in turn, will use the money to finance affordable housing and economic
development initiatives of non-profit and for-profit developers in their
communities.

The announcement was made by State of Washington Treasurer Dan Grimm and FHLBS
President James R. Faulstich at the William B. Phillips Apartments, an historic
landmark building and one of the developments that will be supported with
funding from the transaction.

"Targeting state investment dollars in this way," said Treasurer Grimm, yields
two benefits for the state.

The state acquires a safe investment that will yield an attractive return and
the investment directly serves citizens and neighborhoods by creating
much-needed affordable housing in communities throughout Washington.

Partnerships between a Federal Home Loan Bank and state government have been
formed in only three other states -- California, Illinois and Oklahoma.

The $ 10 million bond carries a fixed interest rate of 6.82%.  Direct placement
of the bond with the state saves commission costs normally associated with a
bond sale.  The cost savings will allow the FHLBS to further reduce the interest
rate on the loans it makes to its customer financial institutions.

Mr. Faulstich estimated the collaboration between the bank and the state will
finance housing for 500 families and individuals.

Both non-profit and for-profit developers will use the funding to construct,
renovate or acquire multifamily housing.  Economic development initiatives that
benefit low-income households or neighborhoods are also eligible for the
funding.

More than half, or $ 5.7 million of the $ 10 million, has been requested to date
by financial institutions in western Washington and committed for five
multifamily projects, including the Phillips Apartments.

Washington Mutual, A Federal Savings Bank, has requested $ 162,000 to make a
permanent mortgage loan to Historic Seattle Preservation and Development
Authority for the property.

Constructed in 1902 on First Hill, a few blocks northwest of Seattle University,
the Phillips Apartments were renovated to create 11 units of affordable housing,
including one fully handicapped accessible unit.

Anchor Mutual Savings Bank, Aberdeen, requested $ 1.3 million to support
construction of Alder House, a 35-unit assisted living facility under
development by Willapa Independent Senior Housing Inc. in South Bend.

Anchor Mutual Savings also is using $ 725,000 to support construction of the
60-unit Lincoln Commons Apartments in Hoquiam on the Olympic Peninsula -- a
rural area studies have identified as in dire need of affordable rental housing.

The building will provide affordable housing for families and individuals
earning 60% of area median income.

Viking Community Bank is using $ 500,000 to finance the mortgage on the
Wallingford Building -- a mixed-use property of small businesses and eight
affordable housing units in Seattle, owned by private investors.

First Mutual Savings Bank, Bellevue, is using $ 3 million to finance acquisition
of 17 multifamily rental properties by private investors.

Located throughout the Puget Sound area, the apartments provide a total of 186
units of housing for very low income people.

The FHLBS' Community Investment Program has, since its launch in 1989, advanced
more than $ 460 million in loans that financed 10,677 units of housing in nine
states, including 6,460 in Washington state.

                         Sunday Herald Sun (Australia)

                             October 3, 2010 Sunday
                               1 - FIRST Edition

Homes are shrinking

BYLINE: Graeme Hammond

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 40

LENGTH: 286  words


ANN DOUGLAS

Characterless homes ruining area

THE spread of tiny housing blocks through Doreen is destroying the semi-rural
character of the suburb, says Ann Douglas.

Mrs Douglas and her husband bought the last available block on Brookwood Ave and
moved into their new home last November. It was a trouble-plagued construction,
after builders discovered neither water nor power had been provided for the
site, forcing them to rely on neighbours, and they also had to wait five months
for a phone line.

But they are delighted with their home, built on a quarter-acre site that the
Laurimar estate's previous developers Drapac had intended to be standard
throughout the area.

Not that it stayed that way. When Delfin bought Laurimar in 2006, it introduced
a range of block sizes, with many as small as 312sq m, marketed as ``town
cottage'', ``villa'' and ``patio'' blocks.

``People buying in this area thought Laurimar would be country style blocks,''
Mrs Douglas said.

``The idea was you'd look out the windows and see trees and feel relaxed. Now
the area is filling up with characterless houses crammed together. Australia is
all about open spaces. Why would you live 40km from the city and live like
that?''

She said the absence of eaves to shade properties proved ``smart houses'' were
not so smart and tiny paved courtyards meant it was impractical for owners to
keep pets.

``The council has let us down,'' she said. ``The traffic is absolutely
horrendous and now they're trying to squeeze even more people in.''

In a statement this week Delfin Lend Lease said: ``Our smaller lots are focused
around the town centre and have been really important in providing housing for
smaller households such as couples and grandparents.''

                       Sarasota Herald-Tribune (Florida)

                           December 1, 2004 Wednesday
                                MANATEE EDITION

Farmworker group to open site in DeSoto to help storm victims

BYLINE: By SELINA ROMAN selina.roman@heraldtribune.com

SECTION: B SECTION; Pg. BM1

LENGTH: 410 words

DATELINE: ARCADIA


A South Florida organization known for getting farmworkers better jobs and homes
will open a permanent office in DeSoto County this week to help victims of
Hurricane Charley.

Centro Campesino, located in Florida City south of Miami, has experience dealing
with the aftermath of a hurricane. The agency worked with families after
Hurricane Andrew destroyed much of South Florida in 1992.

Now the agency is serving farmworker families in Hardee and DeSoto counties,
many of whom lost their homes and livelihoods to Hurricane Charley. While the
agency has worked in those counties before, this is its first settlement in West
Florida. The office will be located at 15 E. Oak St. in Arcadia.

Steve Mainster, Centro's executive director, said he wanted his staff to have a
permanent presence in the area and represent farmworkers as communities rebuild.

"We intend to be there for the duration and be a part of the community,"
Mainster said.

Hurricane Charley took an unexpected turn Aug. 13, with its eye traveling up
U.S. 17 into DeSoto. The storm destroyed citrus crops and farmworkers' already
dilapidated homes and trailers.

Farmworkers, many of them undocumented, were among the hardest hit. Most don't
qualify for government aid such as housing and loans.

While Centro's primary objective is hurricane repair, the agency will eventually
offer other services such as worker advocacy, job placement and affordable
housing assistance, Mainster said.

He added that a long-term goal is to get families out of mobile homes "so we
don't go through this pain again, so they don't have to go through the pain of
seeing their home hurt and destroyed again."

For years, Centro staff members have been driving more than four hours from
South Florida to DeSoto and Hardee counties to help families repair homes.

Sister Ann DeNicolo, program coordinator for Catholic Charities, said the
permanent office is needed because the long travel time often delayed projects.

"Sometimes it'd be months before they could get out here," DeNicolo said.

The United Way of Sarasota recently gave Centro Campesino a $10,000 grant toward
hiring two part-time outreach workers.

Alex Young, president of the United Way of Sarasota County, said he is eager to
have Centro in a community where "outreach is very tough" due to the rural
nature of the region and the diverse backgrounds of the residents. "It's a plus
to have them there," he said.

For more information about Centro Campesino, call (305) 245-7738.

                               Peterborough Today

                           November 6, 2014 Thursday

Speaker's Corner: Providing homes and jobs for ex-military

BYLINE: Mary Herdman

LENGTH: 643  words


The column that shouts about views and issues concerning Peterborough from a
variety of perspectives. This week's writer is Mary Herdman of UKIP...

Today there are over 20,000 ex-British soldiers, airmen and sailors who have
risked their lives fighting for Britain who are now sleeping rough and homeless
on our streets.

These men and women need our help and UKIP would provide shelter and housing for
every single one of them.

Not only would we provide them with homes but as a nation we have a duty to help
veterans readjust to civilian life, to find a job and get on the housing ladder,
as well as providing top quality healthcare.

Under UKIP, housing would be a top priority issue for all our ex- service men
and women and those returning from active service.

UKIP will also guarantee a job in the police force, prison service or border
force, to those who have served in the military. This will ensure that we not
only look after our servicemen but we secure our borders, get more police on the
streets and have safer prisons.

It is estimated that we need at least 200,000 new homes every year of which 43%,
according to Nick Boles, the government minister for planning, is due to
immigration.   The Conservatives, Labour and the Liberals all have an open door
immigration policy which has led to over 4 million people settling in the UK in
the last decade.  It is impossible to have an open door' immigration policy
without thinking about the consequences to our green belt and prime agricultural
land.

Six thousand new homes are planned each month for the countryside.  More than a
million homes are presently in the planning process to be located on green belt
and green spaces.   Some of this land allocated for housing is Fenland grade 1
agricultural land, the rich fertile soil surrounding Peterborough feeds the
nation and it is this land that is of prime concern.   Also, all these new
properties will need roads, infrastructure and services, further blighting our
Fenland landscape.

You may ask how on earth would UKIP solve this problem created by previous
governments?  Well first of all we would start by incentivising back into the
market the 700,000 homes shamefully lying empty in our country when 700,000
fellow Brits are homeless and sleeping rough.  Housing priority would be given
to our ex-servicemen first and then secondly to citizens whose parents were born
in Britain.

Under UKIP and in certain circumstances, it would be right to relax planning
regulations in strategic zones to make it easier to convert disused offices and
commercial spaces into homes.

The CPRE, Campaign to Protect Rural England estimate that 1.5 million homes can
be developed on brownfield land.  Civitas believe it to be as much as 2.5
million homes.  The centerpiece of UKIP's housing policy would be to therefore
instigate the most far reaching brownfield land revolution ever and provide
decontamination assessment grants, and low interest loans for decontamination
and land remediation.

We would issue Brownfield Bonds with the aim of raising £5bn to fuel our
brownfield revitalization programme.  Paving the way for more affordable
housing, more home ownership by investing in our country's most derelict and
underused land, and not by turning landscapes into concrete jungles.

Under UKIP we would eliminate stamp duty from all properties developed on
Brownfield and remove VAT from all Brownfield conversion costs.

Through grassroots planning referendums we will give the people and their
communities the power to shape the towns and cities they live in rather than
bureaucrats and big business.

Once these houses have been built on our brown field sites, it seems only right
to me that we make sure that troops, airmen and sailors returning to civilian
life go to the front of the queue, especially considering what they have risked
in defence of our nation.

                              The Washington Post

                    February 4, 1985, Monday, Final Edition

The Federal Budget;
Federal Aid Programs Marked for Ax;
State and Local Governments, Businesses, Farmers and Cities Would See Cuts

BYLINE: By Eric Pianin, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A5

LENGTH: 1073 words


A lot of the federal alphabet soup would disappear if Congress were to go along
with President Reagan's proposed new fiscal 1986 budget.

UDAG, EDA, SBA, REA, FmHA, and ARC are a few of the governmental acronyms --
cherished by big-city mayors, farmers, urban dwellers, commuters and businessmen
-- that would die in the administration's deficit-slashing efforts.

Some of these programs, which affect mainly the middle class, have been the
subject of administration assaults before, with little success.

These programs are among those slated for the ax:

* The $574 million subsidy for Amtrak, the national passenger train system.
Amtrak failed its original goal of profitability, the administration argues, and
the average $35 per-passenger subsidy is too much.

* The Urban Development Action Grant (UDAG) program, a popular holdover from the
Carter administration that provides start-up funds for commercial construction.
By gutting UDAG, the administration said it would save $2 billion over the next
three years.

* The Job Corps, a federal job-training program that the administration argues
is not effective or cost efficient. If the program continues, the administration
said, it would cost $15,200 to train each of 40,500 enrollees.

* The Small Business Administration, which provides credit and low-interest
loans to 21,500 businesses. The government should be more of a cheerleader for
small business than a "Daddy Warbucks," the administration argues. Besides, the
budget proposal said, plenty of private-sector loan money is available.

* General Revenue Sharing, which spreads nearly $4.6 billion a year in federal
largess among 39,281 local governments. The administration argues that revenue
sharing no longer can be justified while state and local governments have
surpluses and the federal government is swimming in a sea of red ink.

* The Appalachian Regional Commission and the Economic Development
Administration. These resilient agencies, designed to stimulate economic
development, have survived earlier budget assaults. The administration said it
wants to get rid of them as part of a government-wide effort to eliminate local
development subsidies.

* Most of the subsidized loan and grant programs of the Farmers Home
Administration, a mainstay of farmers and businessmen in rural America, that
financed more than $10 billion of water and sewer projects and community
facilities in the past decade. In the future, rural areas would receive
assistance through a block grant program of the Department of Housing and Urban
Development (HUD).

* The Export-Import Bank's direct loan program, which has aided many U.S.
corporations that do business overseas. The administration wants the bank to
boost its program of loan guarantees and quit making direct loans. This is in
line with the Reagan policy of placing greater reliance on private-sector
financing.

* Air carrier subsidies, established in 1978 to provide financial assistance to
communities as they adjusted to the impact of airline deregulation. The
government has spent $460 million in subsidies. "To provide further subsidies to
cities currently receiving them would turn a temporary transitional program into
a permanent entitlement," the administration contends.

* Health professional training subsidies, first granted in the early 1960s in
response to a serious shortage of doctors, nurses and other health specialists.
Today, the administration argues, there is a glut of trained medical experts and
the subsidy no longer is needed.

Reagan's budget proposes many other cuts or freezes that stop just short of
killing programs. The Urban Mass Transit Assistance program, for instance, would
be slashed next year by $768 million, with additional cuts planned that would
bring the total to $4.2 billion within three years.

"Federal support for a local function like mass transit is unjustified," the
budget document says. "It is unfair to the many taxpayers who pay for it and get
nothing in return, and its availability reduces local incentives to make sound
economic choices."

Reagan wants to squeeze the Power Marketing Administrations, a group of
government-financed businesses that sells hydroelectric power generated at 123
federally operated dams by cutting outlays by $1.5 billion and forcing the
hydroelectric operations to catch up on their loan repayments, even if that
means boosting electrical rates. The PMA sells 6 to 8 percent of all electricity
generated in the United States.

The president also wants to phase out the Rural Electrification Administration
(REA) low-interest loan program over the next five years. Since 1936, more than
$61 billion in federal assistance has been provided to rural electric utilities
and telephone systems.

Federal soil and water conservation cost-sharing programs also would be
eliminated.

A $384 million Maritime Administration subsidy for U.S. shipbuilders would be
eliminated. Profit-making publications and companies as well as national
political committees would lose federal subsidy for their postal rates.

The administration would declare a moratorium on U.S. oil stockpiling in the
Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The SPR, designed as a defense against oil-supply
interruptions, is expected to contain about 489 million barrels by 1986.

The president seeks to phase out federal sewage-treatment grants to state and
local governments by 1990. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) would
receive $2.4 billion in grants next year -- the same amount it has received
since 1982. Future funds would have to be used only to complete existing
projects.

The administration also wants to do away with grants for energy conservation and
for weatherizing school buildings, hospitals and the homes of low-income
families within five years.

The government will spend about $191 million on weatherproofing projects in
1986. The administration proposes to cover those costs with funds recovered from
petroleum companies that violated the old oil price-control program.

Other programs facing elimination under the budget proposal include the Legal
Services Corporation and the work-incentive program.

One of the few proposed budget increases is a substantial one in funds for the
"Superfund," which assists states in cleaning up waste dumps.

The administration also pledged to introduce legislation that would greatly
expand the national effort to clean up abandoned waste sites.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             The New Zealand Herald

                            October 9, 2010 Saturday

Bold plans for new centres fail to get off ground

SECTION: BUSINESS; General

LENGTH: 1326 words


The grass grows long on the city's fringes as visions of new town centres
evaporate, quietly and almost without a mention.

As Super City polls close today, Auckland's spread has been contained more by
the end of the boom-bust real estate cycle than any centralised planning
attempt.

Gone are millions of dollars, borrowed from the public and banks, to fund plans
which were a product of the 2000s real estate rise. The land was to become
entire new suburban areas for Auckland.

Ditched or downsized are grand plans for architectural wonders, tall towers of
apartment blocks, sprawling housing estates, shops linking to offices and new
suburban hubs at the end of rural railway lines.

One scheme for bare land at Albany sucked down about $100 million and people are
now asking exactly where that all went.

The closest they can get is writedowns in the value of land ($81 million), fees
to the developers, leasehold land rent payments - though those dried up during
the global financial crisis - and some repayments to bondholders.

Ex-Air Force waterfront land at Hobsonville has been carved into residential
lots and the first houses are about to hit the market in Housing NZ's
3000-residence scheme.

But plans for many other Auckland sites are defunct.

Patrick Fontein's Kensington Park is now in the hands of John Sax, who is
finishing a scaled-down version.

Nigel McKenna's vision for Flat Bush is in the hands of NBR Rich List family the
Todds.

Sax will build fewer houses at Orewa's master-planned Kensington Park, saying he
has applied for rezoning and envisages just 650 places, the lower-density plan
supported by Rodney District Council because it would provide for a
higher-quality project.

"We're reducing the density and putting in more green belts. That will mean more
amenities for the existing residents and more wetland areas too. I'm not
criticising Patrick because what he did was very good. We're just adding to what
is already a well-conceived process," Sax said.

But the BNZ is not satisfied and its bankruptcy application against Fontein will
be heard in the High Court at Auckland on November 8.

He's fighting the application, though his companies have gone under and by his
own admission owe $93.9 million.

He gave personal guarantees on at least $120 million and says he can earn
$200,000-plus annually as a property consultant, of which about $100,000 will go
to creditors.

The BNZ doesn't agree and claims he was "fiscally irresponsible".

Kensington Park's collapse was caused by his failure to fund infrastructure as
it was built and apply money according to loan agreements - it was not the
financial crisis which caused the downfall but his own actions, the bank
maintains.

Grand visions at Albany, Orewa, Waimauku, Clevedon and Manukau cost banks,
businesses and businesspeople dearly.

The public got stung too. Most costly to hundreds of retiree investors was the
now-ditched St Laurence/Symphony scheme for Albany. Kevin Podmore, chairman of
Albany City Property Investments (in liquidation) blames leasehold land for
Albany's demise.

"In hindsight, one of the problems with leasehold land is you have rental
obligations and if you don't pay the rent, you forgo the asset. We paid money
for a leasehold interest and got into a situation where we couldn't pay the
rent. The banks weren't willing to provide funds to pay rent, so the lessor took
the asset back."

Asked what lesson he learned, he quipped "be the lessor, not the lessee."

So did ACPI pay too much for the lease?

"In terms of the feasibility, it was okay. But unfortunately when you've got a
global financial crisis, money becomes so scarce.

"When we did all this, there was a market but things have changed. It's not like
there was a whole lot of money that went out of the company. There was a whole
lot of money that went to the asset that turned out to be worth zero," Podmore
admits.

He has bigger problems than ACPI, in the form of finance company St Laurence
which is in receivership owing 9000 investors about $245 million.

Rick Martin, who leaseholded freehold Albany land, is now selling the sites.

Progressive Enterprises has been one of the big buyers lately, taking a large
chunk and planning a big Countdown to break Foodstuffs' monopoly on the area
around Westfield Albany.

Gone also is Martin's vision for a European-style village with a train station
and 1375 units in neighbourhood clusters on a 464ha Waimauku block north-west of
Auckland.

He needed rural land rezoned to build an almost completely carless village. But
the Environment Court backed a council decision to ban rezoning of rural land
for the Waimauku Estate Village and Martin sold the land.

"I got knocked back in the Environment Court then appealed it, and got knocked
back again. I've still got the model of the property. I tried to sell it to
[neighbour and opponent] Barry [Hart] but no luck. I'm going to put it on Trade
Me under the heading 'field of broken dreams'! Reserve $100," Martin said.

"The funny thing was that the Margaret River Council, Western Australia, heard
about the project a few years ago, contacted me and said it was just what they
were trying to do over there.

"They then hired James Lundy, our urban designer, to help them with their
district plan. The Waimauku Estate concept can be done in Margaret River as of
right, so at least someone benefited out of it," Martin said.

At Flat Bush, Manukau City Council says the contract to develop a new town
centre has left Nigel McKenna's financially stricken Melview Group and now gone
to Todd Property, a subsidiary of Todd Corporation, the investment arm of the
country's wealthiest family.

Melview had the contract to design and develop a 17ha town centre with housing,
offices and cultural facilities but the council owns the land which Melview
wanted to start progressively buying after winning the contract in late 2007.

Mike Higgins, chief executive of Tomorrow's Manukau Properties, said his
organisation had concerns after the Melview Group's widely reported financial
issues and Todd Property Group had satisfied the organisation that they had the
staff and money to meet the obligations.

Auckland's borders remain rural, a sour sight for visionaries who wanted to
commercialise them. Many of the sites have been sold or the companies that
hatched the plans are subject to bankruptcy, liquidation or receivership
proceedings.

The wind still blows through the fields of dreams on Auckland's fringe.

Broken dreams

Flat Bush, South Auckland

* Developer: Nigel McKenna.

* Site: 17ha bare land on Ormiston Rd, Manukau.

* Dream: Homes for 40,000 people, new town centre.

* Reality: Undeveloped land, now in the hands of other developers.

* Losses: Unknown.

Albany City Property Investments

* Developers: St Laurence's Mike O'Sullivan and Kevin Podmore, Symphony's Colin
Reynolds with sons Adam and Damon, and Garry Looker and Gary Nolan.

* Site: 12ha of bare land opposite Westfield Albany

* Dream: $3.5 billion 30-level units, retirement village, offices.

* Reality: Bare, undeveloped land now gradually being sold as freehold titles.

* Losses: $96.1 million in year to March 31, 2009, liquidator says $76.2 million
owed.

Kensington Park, Orewa

* Developers: Patrick Fontein, Allan Clarke, Nicholas Topp, Wendy Norwood.

* Site: Puriri Ave off Centreway Rd, Orewa.

* Dream: $450 million, 750 apartments and houses, lake, shops, gym, pool.

* Reality: Partly finished, scaled back to 650 places by John Sax.

* Losses: Around $93 million, Fontein has $120 million in personal guarantees.

Waimauku Estate VIllage

* Developer: Rick Martin's Cornerstone Group.

* Site: 464ha farmland.

* Dream: 1375 units.

* Reality: Rejected by Environment Court, land sold to Malory Corp.

* Losses: Unknown.

Clevedon Canal Scheme

* Developer: Westminster Properties.

* Dream: Gold Coast-style gated 279 large houses with moorings on canal.

* Site: 5km from the rural community of Clevedon on Wairoa River.

* Reality: Strong local opposition, rejected by Environment Court.

* Losses: Unknown.

                       The Creston News Advertiser (Iowa)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             May 13, 2009 Wednesday

Iowana project advances, deadlines loom

BYLINE: Tyler Ellyson, The Creston News Advertiser, Iowa

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 885 words


May 13--Progress is being made toward renovating the Iowana Hotel into
low-income senior housing.

Funding remains an issue, but some milestones have been reached.

Late last year, a $1 million Section 515 Loan was secured through Rural
Development, and low-income-housing tax credits were awarded to the project by
the Iowa Finance Authority (IFA). Both of these funding sources are backed by
Midwest Disaster Relief Tax Credits.

Also, the State Historic Preservation Office accepted the Iowana's nomination to
the National Register of Historical Places in March. Vern Hanson, co-president
of MetroPlains LLC, which is in charge of development for this project, believes
this significantly enhances the ability to get federal historic tax credits.

"(These are) all pretty significant steps toward what we had needed to do in
order for us to prepare for the eventual renovation of the Iowana," he said.

Funding sources

Eight investors/syndicators have evaluated the Iowana project, with WNC,
Enterprise and Midwest Housing Equity Group expressing limited interest toward
investing in the low-income-housing tax credits that could fund the project.
Hanson said he expects investor commitments around the third or fourth quarter
of this year.

"That's pretty much consistent with what we're seeing across the board, no
matter where we're located," he said. "Once we find an investor with the
low-income-housing tax credits, the historic tax credit will automatically
follow."

Gov. Chet Culver recently signed a bill expanding the amount of money provided
for the preservation of historic properties through state tax credits from $20
million to $50 million per year. The problem is Iowa's historic tax credits are
awarded to projects by lottery and are not issued until the project is underway.
Federal historic tax credits are allocated by application, but can be withdrawn
if a project is not completed as originally specified.

Another option is the recently-passed American Reinvestment and Recovery Act.
This act also helps fund affordable rental housing through tax credit assistance
program (TCAP) funds and a buy-back provision (exchange credits) where IFA would
provide funds for returned low-income-housing tax credits.

According to Hanson, IFA should have more information on how they plan to
distribute this funding in the next 30 to 60 days. Using this act would
eliminate the need for an outside investor/syndicator and accelerate the
construction process. Projects using the exchange credits must be completed by
September 2012.

IFA has until June 4 to submit a request for funds from the federal government
and October to determine guidelines for the projects to be funded. Officials
from the city and MetroPlains are scheduled to discuss the Iowana project with
IFA on May 20.

"IFA is in the process of determining how they can, or want, to use these
resources," explained Hanson.

Problems

Hanson said there are some catches when using the American Reinvestment and
Recovery Act.

Midwest disaster relief tax credits aren't applicable under this act, but Hanson
said the state may be able to return these credits and replace them with
exchange funds.

"Not only is it very complicated, but the rules on how they would administer
that is not yet defined," he said.

Federal guidelines also require certain steps to be taken on projects over the
next two years for the project to be considered "real and ready."

"One of the biggest questions the states have in front of them is to determine
which of these projects are real and ready," said Hanson.

The low-income-housing tax and historic tax credit rates have also dropped, and
return on investment has doubled to about 15 percent. This could leave fewer
funds for projects and require secondary funding to fill the gap.

"For all practical purposes, there is insufficient funds in the tax credit
market to do anything with," said Hanson.

Stimulus package money is also being actively pursued.

Moving forward

Hanson said plans are through design development, but there are some steps that
need to be taken in the near future.

A phase one environmental site assessment and lead-based paint, asbestos and
hazardous materials tests must be completed by June 10. After the tests, the
city's cost to date for the project would be $63,760.50, and MetroPlains will
have spent $121,400.

"I think, at that point, the city would be done with expenses," Hanson said.

IFA requires 10 percent of the total project cost, or approximately $506,000, to
be spent by Sept. 30.

"What we've been trying to do is, rather than get into those really, really big
numbers, make sure we've got everything in place before anything else happens,"
said Hanson.

Despite the economical setbacks and fast-approaching deadlines, there is
optimism.

"I wish I could say we're ready to start construction. That's what we're hoping
for," said Hanson. "We're in it for the long run."

                  The Press-Republican (Plattsburgh, New York)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             July 14, 2011 Thursday

Federal flood relief pending; loan process stalled

BYLINE: Denise A. Raymo, The Press-Republican, Plattsburgh, N.Y.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 548 words


July 14--MALONE -- Businesses, homeowners and farmers with spring-flooding
damages may still be eligible for low-interest federal loans even if an earlier
denial of assistance sticks.

A variety of federal-relief programs could kick in if requests pending from Gov.
Andrew Cuomo are granted.

But flood victims may have to wait two more months to have their applications
reviewed.

DECISION APPEALED

The Federal Emergency Management Agency has OK'd assistance to upstate counties,
municipalities, fire departments and some nonprofit agencies, making them
eligible for federal public-assistance and hazard-mitigation funds to recover
from spring flooding.

But a state request for individual-recovery assistance through FEMA to help
tri-county businesses and property owners was denied because, a FEMA reply to
Gov. Andrew Cuomo said, the damage sustained wasn't severe enough.

Cuomo has appealed the decision, and U.S. Rep. Bill Owens has sent a letter of
support for the measure.

"It is vital that we explore every avenue of available federal assistance
available to upstate New York so that residents can rebuild their communities,"
he wrote.

Cuomo has also made an appeal to the U.S. Department of Agriculture for
low-interest loans to help farmers who suffered production and physical losses
due to flooding.

LOAN PROCESS HALTED

Farmers, farm cooperatives, small-business owners and private nonprofit agencies
might also be eligible for a second USDA program called the Economic Injury
Disaster Loans program.

But for now, little movement can be made because the pending appeal includes a
halt to applications for help through the Small Business Administration.

"One of the bad parts is that when (FEMA) denied (individual relief), it stopped
the SBA-loan process," said Ricky Provost, director of Franklin County Emergency
Services.

He said property-damage-assessment experts are due back this week to revisit
sites they looked at immediately following the storms and will also check out
other places they could not get to because floodwaters were still too high.

GRANTS LIMITED

That reassessment might bolster the region's case, because FEMA bases its
decision on the number of homes or sites destroyed.

But "we could go another 40 to 60 days" before a decision is made, Provost said,
which means property owners would have to tough it out even longer.

That wait and the weight of worry could be too much for some, such as hotel and
motel owners who may miss the entire tourist season because they have no money
to repair their rooms and amenities for safe occupancy, he said.

If the appeal is successful, individual assistance can include help finding and
funding housing, disaster-unemployment assistance, crisis counseling and other
assistance.

Even if the designation is awarded and individual property owners are eligible
to receive federal assistance, the maximum FEMA grant would be $35,000.

                            Middletown Journal, Ohio

                          February 8, 2006, Wednesday

Bush's budget proposal could cost Middletown, Ohio, programs, jobs

BYLINE: By Dave Greber

LENGTH: 524 words



Middletown stands to lose at least one program, one job or both if President
Bush's proposed cut to certain federal funds is approved later this year.

In his 2007 budget proposal, which was released Monday, Bush called for a
21-percent cut in the amount of money given to cities and counties across the
country in the form of community development block grants (CDBG).

The president is requesting to merge the CDBG funding system with other programs
that pay for the cleanup of brownfields, rural housing and economic development.
Critics of the plan are fearful that the $ 975 million cut could eventually lead
to the elimination of the CDBG program altogether.

Such a cut for Middletown -- still reeling from a 9 percent cut to CDBG funds
last year -- would mean at least one program or one job would be eliminated in
2007, city officials said.

"In a place like Middletown, the need is evident," said Angela Tucker, the
Planning Department's community development administrator. "There is no more fat
in this program, so if there is another cut, it's going to mean a program or a
job (next year)."

Since the budget doesn't go into effect until Oct. 1 each year, the budget is
expected to be adopted in September. Last year, Tucker said, Bush proposed a 100
percent cut to the CDBG program, but it was reduced to 9 percent.

In Middletown, CDBG money funds five major programs each year:

--Housing rehabilitation

--Housing code enforcement

--Public services (i.e. Butler County 2-1-1; the Middletown Health Center)

--Neighborhood revitalization

--Economic development loans.

In 2006, the Middletown's 30th year participating in the CDBG funding system,
the city received more than $ 680,000, and was forced to reduce the levels of
coverage for certain programs. If Bush's proposal -- dubbed Strengthening
America's Communities Initiative -- is approved, the city would receive $
544,092. According to city officials, more than $ 500,000 was spent on staff
costs, including salaries and other administrative fees in 2005.

The administration said the current programs are not efficient in some places
and present a plethora of funding sources that can be confusing for communities.

Although Middletown stands to be less effected than Hamilton or Butler County,
Tucker said, any reduction could be detrimental to new initiatives like those
that help subsidize the cost for local residents to renovate their homes.

"That's a huge bang for our buck, but it's so new it could be eliminated,"
Tucker said of the Property Enhancement Program, which is now five years
running. "It's a council favorite. But the city is in no position to absorb new
costs."


Reporter Jim Bebbington contributed to this story.

                        Cumberland Times-News (Maryland)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             April 10, 2016 Sunday

Water project closer to full funding

BYLINE: Heather B. Wolford, Cumberland Times-News, Md.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 425 words


April 10--CUMBERLAND -- A local water project is a step closer to being fully
funded after Allegany County commissioners signed documents to accept a federal
grant during a meeting last week.

The United States Department of Agriculture Rural Development grant is for the
$1.6 million Prince Albert and Sunnyside area water project.

The area consists of 70 homes southeast of Mount Savage with no access to public
water. Residents depend on wells or springs, however the county is working to
extend Frostburg's water source to the location.

"Some of these folks are having to get their water out of a stream behind their
house," said commission President Jake Shade. "It's crazy to think that some
people in our county don't have clean drinking water."

"They will have Frostburg water," said Paul Kahl, the county's director of
public works. "We are extending the line down to serve them."

The USDA awarded the project an $852,000 grant and a $102,000 loan for a total
of $954,000.

The county expects the remainder of the project funding to come from the
Maryland Department of the Environment and the Department of Housing and Urban
Development by mid-summer. Kahl said the funding offer from the USDA is a strong
indicator the project will be fully funded.

"Usually what happens is any time one of the federal funding agencies give us
money for a project, they work with the head of the funding agencies that they
know will get the remainder," said Kahl. "They (USDA) are not going to commit
money to a project they know won't go forward."

Representatives from the USDA are scheduled to visit the site on April 22,
formally announcing their commitment to the project at an Earth Day celebration
ceremony.

"USDA picks projects they like a lot, and they like this project," said Kahl.
"Some of the people in this area really have bad water."

The project will be 88 percent funded by grants, according to Kahl.

"Providing safe drinking water in Allegany County is one of the most important
things we do," said Kahl. "We have been able to work through our relationships
with the state and federal government to provide a funding package to make the
water affordable to our residents."

The county was able to bypass those still wanting to keep their wells, and
construction at the sites is expected to last until winter 2017, Kahl said.

Follow staff writer Heather Wolford on Twitter @heatherbwolford.

                             The New Zealand Herald

                           February 21, 2004 Saturday

What's eating pakeha: The beneficiaries of race-based funding

BYLINE: By RUTH BERRY

SECTION: NEWS; General

LENGTH: 899 words


National confirms it will swing the axe in the area of race-based funding but it
refused to give the Weekend Herald answers on most of the 10 programmes listed,
saying it has yet to develop its policy.

* Te Mangai Paho is a Crown entity established by National in 1993 to recognise
the Crown's broadcasting responsibilities regarding the Maori language and Maori
culture.

Essentially the Maori version of NZ On Air, TMP finances the production of
television programmes in the Maori language and about Maori in English. It also
funds some Maori-language CDs and the national network of Maori radio stations.
Its budget is just under $40 million.

* Special Housing Action Zones - bridging finance for papakainga. This Reducing
Inequality initiative, run by Te Puni Kokiri and Housing New Zealand, has a
four-year, $1.15 million budget.

It is designed for Maori communities occupying their papakainga (original home
base) or living on Maori land in multiple ownership, but is theoretically
available to other groups.

It provides two-year, interest-free loans to groups to build houses to sell on
to families. It is one of 11 programmes aimed to improve housing for low-income
people.

* Decile Funding for Schools. The present system, introduced by National in
1995, gives schools in under-privileged areas extra funding. The worst-off
schools are rated decile one and get an extra $682 a year a student. Decile 10
schools get none of this funding.

Six factors determine decile rating including: household income, household
crowding, parents' occupations, their educational qualifications, income support
payment and Maori and Pacific Island ethnicity. Independent research claims that
removing the ethnicity factor would result in little change to the funding
spread.

* TeachNZ Scholarships. These $10,000 scholarships are available to people from
rural areas wanting to teach in rural schools or to aspiring Maori or Pacific
teachers. About 500 were awarded last year.

National initiated the Pacific scholarships and Labour expanded the scheme. The
Government will next year fold the ethnic scholarships into a new "step-up"
programme for tertiary assistance, based on parental income only.

Other $10,000 scholarships for aspiring biology, chemistry, computing, English,
maths, physical education (PE), physics, and te reo Maori teachers will remain.

* Improving Responsiveness of Education to Maori. This is a Reducing Inequality
Ministry of Education initiative to shift teacher beliefs and practices to
improve the teaching of Maori. It is targeted at Maori students and has a $2.5
million budget. The pilot was extended after research showed programmes were
resulting in significant improvements in performance of Maori students.

* Maori Organisational Development Assistance programme. This is a Reducing
Inequality capacity-building initiative targeting Maori, with a $6 million,
four-year budget.

Run by the Community Employment Group (CEG), it aims to help existing Maori
organisations improve their ability to achieve employment and enterprise results
for their community. CEG, which works with communities to improve employment
opportunities, also has targeted Pacific people, women and youth programmes.

* Whanau Development Initiatives. This is another Reducing Inequality
capacity-building initiative run by the Social Development Ministry. It is
targeted to Maori with a $3 million budget, and was given another $1 million
last year.

Its aim is to strengthen communities and it ran at 12 sites last year. It has
been used to: hold marae-based course teaching traditional practices; establish
marae vegetable gardens with the aim of selling products to fund marae
developments; set up skill development programmes, including computer skills and
business start-up advice.

* Work Track Extension Programme to Maori and Pacific Islanders. This Reducing
Inequality Social Development Ministry initiative has developed a Work Track
Programme for Maori and Pacific people at risk of long-term unemployment.

It offers employment assistance including provision of offices with resources
and computers and has a $9 million, four-year budget.

* Community Education Initiatives to Reduce Family Violence and Child Abuse.

This Child Youth and Family Reducing Inequality initiative targets Maori and
Pacific Islanders and has a $10.3 million, four-year budget.

It finances Pacific and iwi and Maori providers for initiatives to reduce family
violence. Its activities include group and individual education programmes,
counselling, home-based support and programmes for youth at risk. Other
mainstream initiatives exist.

* Maori Smoking Reduction Initiative. This is a Reducing Inequality initiative
with a four-year, $20 million budget to specifically reduce Maori smoking.

Other funding exists for mainstream programmes. It involves the expansion of the
pre-existing Aukati Kai Paipa programme focused on Maori women to include
whanau-based programmes. It also pays for training new service providers and
expansion of the Quit/Me Mutu mass media campaign targeting Maori smokers.

                             National Mortgage News

                               September 21, 1992

AIDS Care Facility Construction Done

BYLINE: By GEORGIA STEELE, NMN Correspondent

SECTION: FARM AND RURAL MORTGAGES; Pg. 37

LENGTH: 324 words

DATELINE: SEATTLE


Bailey-Boushay House, the nation's first new construction of a long-term care
facility for AIDS patients, has opened here as a result of public/private
support.

The project, which took four years to complete, in a 35-bed residential care
facility for people dying at AIDS.

It also offers an adult center that assists 35 AIDS sufferers daily who are
still able to live at home but need daytime care.

It also provides physical, occupational, infusion and aerosol thereapies,
counseling services, an arts program, and a working greenhouse, and is designed
to handle nursing care for any other chronic disease whenever AIDS is conquered.

In addition to giving money, private lenders ran fund raisers and donated
political lobbying muscle and communications support services to the project.

The loan to purchase the five vacant lots at the site camWashington Mutual
Savings Bank and the Seattle Housing Authority.

Lobbyists from Seafirst Bank, Boeing and Weyerhaeuser broke a political logjam
in the Washington legislature to pass a bill allowing the project to receive a
higher rate of reimbursement from the state than ordinary nursing homes because
people with AIDS require more care.

Seafirst chairman Luke Helms headed a fundraising campaign.  When the Robert
Wood Johnson Foundation made a low interest, 3% loan of $ 1.5 million for
permanent financing of the project, it was guaranteed by Security Pacific Bank
for an additional 1%.

Lenders making corporate contributions to the project were Seafirst Bank, $
25,000; Security Pacific, $ 25,000; U.S. Bank, $ 10,000; First Interstate Bank,
$ 5,000; Pacific First Federal Savings Bank, $ 2,500; and Washington Mutual, $
2,000.

Government and plic funds for the project amounted to $ 3.52 million; corporate
and foundation contributions were $ 1.8 million; private financing came to $ 1.5
million; and individual contributions were $ 1 million for a total of $ 7.86
million.

                             984 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                  Burton Mail

                            February 13, 2009 Friday

Tenth of region's houses now empty

BYLINE: RICHARD CASTLE

LENGTH: 422 words


NEARLY a 10th of all houses in East Staffordshire are empty, new figures have
revealed.

But, under Government guidelines, East Staffordshire Borough Council is
committed to building a further 12,900 homes by 2026.

The borough council's 2008 stock condition survey says there are 3,248 houses
with no one living in them.

Out of these, 2,154 are for sale or rent, 627 are undergoing repairs or
'modernisation' and 437 are 'long term empty', 353 of which are in the rural
south of the borough.

Borough councillor Michael Rodgers, who represents the Burton ward, said he was
"staggered" by the Government's demands, which he thinks will "destroy the
countryside".

Councillor Rodgers said: "The Government seems to think, when the housing market
picks up, we'll have to rebuild on a massive scale.

"The plan to build 12,900 homes by 2026 will surely need to be very carefully
looked into.

"In my opinion, the number of homes prescribed has been grossly over-calculated.

"I might well be proved to be wrong but I just don't think there's the demand
and can't see there being in the near future.

"All that will happen is there'll be more and more houses being built on
greenfield sites and I think, once you go down that road, it's a slippery
slope."

Burton MP Janet Dean said she thought the empty houses, of which there are twice
as many as in 2005, were down to a temporarily poor housing market.

She said: "There's cross-party support for making East Staffordshire a growth
point.

"We know things are difficult at the moment in terms of getting mortgages and
keeping their jobs but we also know people want to live in East Staffordshire.

"The borough council accepted the 12,900 homes agreement and accepted East
Staffordshire should be a growth point.

"Trent and Dove is also working with the Government to buy up some of the empty
properties to make affordable housing.

"The Government is also taking steps to stop houses being repossessed and, with
interest rates now very low, people's mortgage repayments are falling."

A spokesman for homeless charity Shelter said: "It is shocking that so many
homes in East Staffordshire are lying empty and unused for years at a time, but
there are many reasons why councils can't use these homes to house homeless
people or people on housing waiting lists.

"More than 90 per cent of empty homes are privately owned, and some of them may
be used as second homes. Also, many homes are not fit to live in, are only empty
for short periods or will be in areas where people may not want to live."

                        Western Morning News (Plymouth)

                           September 19, 2006 Tuesday

Singing from same hymn sheet

SECTION: Pg. 4

LENGTH: 511 words


Regular readers  will be aware that Graeme Hicks, Cornwall county and Kerrier
district councillor, and I have not always seen eye to eye on matters concerning
my company's creation of new homes principally designed for local first-time
buyers. However, I was pleased to note one aspect of his letter (August 22) in
which we are evidently singing very much from the same hymn sheet.

I strongly support Coun Hicks when he says that "releasing some council-owned
land under the strictest conditions, and solely for affordable housing for
genuinely local people of proven need, should be urgently considered". This
concept is precisely what my company is putting into practice at Mabe, near
Penryn, and I would be truly delighted to work with Coun Hicks and his
colleagues in pursuing more such projects.

At Mabe, subject to the successful outcome of our current planning application,
we will provide the village's first exclusive affordable homes project with 12
one-bedroom apartments, on a site that previously won permission, now lapsed,
for local housing by another company utilising the Rural Exceptions Policy,
whereby housing for local people can be provided where normal open  market
housing would not normally be allowed.

Under our scheme, prospective purchasers are being identified in accordance with
conditions and procedures laid down by Kerrier District Council.  Applicants
must demonstrate that they would otherwise be unable to buy on the open market
and that they are first-time buyers.  Other criteria, also agreed with the
district council,  apply.

In an exhaustive public consultation, including a letter to all residents
inviting registration of interest, we established the level of need in Mabe.
The exact nature and scale of the proposed development has been influenced by
the response to this parish survey. This is an exercise we are keen to repeat
wherever and whenever possible, working hand in hand with the local authorities.

To help cement our links with local councillors, I have also written to the
Kerrier District Council chairman inviting her and all her fellow members to
visit our Vyvyan's Court development in Camborne to see for themselves our
flagship project and  meet the many happy occupiers who have already moved in.
Our "open book" policy is also illustrated via the website www.aheadstart4u. com
for a unique scheme that enables the purchase price for our flats to be reduced
below £60,000.

The site explains exactly how this is achieved, thus answering Coun Hicks' query
as to whether any additional loans are involved.  They are not.

Finally, I applaud Coun Hicks for his efforts, to which he refers in his letter,
to combat the shortcomings of some developers as regards the inadequacy of their
infrastructure contributions. My company regularly commits substantial
expenditure to infrastructure and off-site "community gain", but as a
long-experienced operator  I am well aware that by no means all other developers
come up to scratch in this respect.

David Worlledge

Managing Director Affordable Homes of  Cornwall Ltd Falmouth

LOAD-DATE: October 29, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                             987 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                                  The Express

                              June 1, 2007 Friday
                                U.K. 1st Edition

Good plot woos first-timers;
express property

BYLINE: By Maisha Frost

SECTION: FEATURES; 70

LENGTH: 735  words


AN imaginative project designed to bring low-cost, good-looking homes within the
budget of first-timers is winning interest from all quarters - including housing
associations and councils.

Over the past few weeks, developer Living Space 21 has received many enquiries
about its new-build studios scheme that encourages individuals and communities
to look at smaller or overlooked plots of land.

A primary draw has been affordability. The prices - from GBP 100,000 for a
freehold package, GBP 59,950 for a studio or GBP 19,950 for a self-build option
- make it easier for buyers to purchase outright.

The wood-frame apartments come with a choice of claddings and eco-features and a
10-year guarantee from the National House-Building Council. Each requires 40-50
square metres of land with access. "If someone has a plot and wants to sell, we
want to buy. We will pay GBP 40,000 or the current land value, " said Living
Space 21 director Ray Bedeman.

The apartments are aimed at people in rent traps who want to get on the property
ladder; parents with adult children still at home; cash-strapped key workers;
those looking for an economical live/work space; rural communities squeezed by
second home owners pushing up prices and councils keen to cut housing waiting
lists and improve the supply of affordable homes.

For sellers, there are significant attractions, too. "It could interest those
with large gardens who would welcome some extra spending money by freeing up
equity in their homes on better terms than current release schemes, " said Mr
Bedeman.

Two factors - land and design - have combined to make the radical concept
feasible. Available sites, however unpromising, can have their potential
transformed by ultra-adaptable constructions.

The Living Space 21 apartments feature pioneering building techniques that
enable them to be tailored to almost any location and leave the lightest
environmental footprint possible for the price.

"This is chameleon construction, our answer to a housing and land crisis that
has marginalised those with lesser means, " said Mr Bedeman, who is working with
one of the UK's leading eco-building experts, Green Party founder Professor
Michael Benfield. His company, Benfield ATT, is responsible for designing and
constructing the apartments.

"These are bespoke solutions that maximise land use and the interior space to
get best value for the occupants, " Professor Benfield said. And the studios,
which will qualify for mortgage financing, have further inbuilt advantages
destined, he believes, to become more apparent.

"Moving is becoming increasingly expensive when you take into account service
costs and stamp duty. These homes have a long-term component, they can be
extended, so if owners do not want to move they may not have to, " he added.

Under the proposed Home Information Packs, buildings will be subject to
ever-tighter environmental controls.

Those that already meet or exceed sustainable requirements should eventually see
that feed through to their value.

"The outlay to bring older homes up to contemporary standards will eventually be
reflected in market valuations, " said Professor Benfield. "Life cycle or
running costs do not figure at present in lending on property, but common sense
may eventually prevail and that will happen." For this reason, along with those
of well-being and good health, he has ensured that the Living Space 21 studios
tick as many eco and zero-carbon emission boxes as possible.

The timber frames will be sourced from sustainable European forests.

The slope of the roof can be angled to get the most from solar panels. Rainwater
capture and recycling are also fundamental parts of the design. Other features,
like smart meters that detail energy use and sun tubes that use highly-polished
surfaces to reflect natural light to dark areas, are also possible.

However, Professor Benfield did not hesitate when asked what design aspect of
the Living Space 21 he likes most. "The stilts, " he said. "They used to be very
popular in Britain centuries ago, then fell out of favour on a mere whim.

"You still see them overseas.

They are practical because they offer space that can be used or adapted in
future. If this project opens up minds to what stilts can offer, that would be
very satisfying."

Living Space 21: 0870 7444 983, www. livingspace21. com or e-mail:

inspire@livingspace21. com Benfield ATT: www. benfieldatt. co. uk

                          The Journal (Newcastle, UK)

                            April 18, 2015 Saturday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Valley homes for families

SECTION: HOME MAKER;FEATURES; Pg. 73

LENGTH: 413 words


THE spectacular Northumberland countryside, healthy lifestyle and easy
accessibility to Newcastle, Gateshead and Hexham mean that homes in the Tyne
Valley generally attract a great deal of interest. And brand new homes are very
popular.

So it is no wonder that developers Taylor Wimpey are seeing a high level of
enquiries about its development in the village of Corbridge which has yet to be
launched.

The Potteries will offer a range of luxury homes. Set across land on Cragside,
the development will consist of thre- bedroom bungalows and four and five
bedroom family homes.

The development will also includes a separate site which will include 18
affordable two and three-bedroom properties.

Karl Morton, sales and marketing director for Taylor Wimpey North East, said:
"We're very excited to soon launch this highly-anticipated development to house
buyers in the Northumberland area, especially as we've already had well over 200
people register their interest so far."

The Potteries is set in the rural idyllic setting, with fantastic views while
also incorporating fantastic green spaces and will also feature a landscaped
play area for children.

Karl continues: "While benefiting from its beautiful, green settings near
Corbridge village, housebuyers can also take advantage of our financial
incentives such as Help to Buy and Easymover, making it more affordable than
ever to move into a new home."

Homes will include the four-bedroom Cavendish, Sherbourne and President house
types, all with double garage. The interiors will all have a lounge, separate
dining room and study.

Through the Government-backed Help to Buy, aspiring home owners can get on to
the property ladder with just a 5% deposit, when purchasing properties worth up
to the value of £600,000.

Using Help to Buy they only have to source a 75% mortgage, the remaining 20%
coming in the form of a Government equity loan which is interest-free for five
years.

Meanwhile Taylor Wimpey's Easymover scheme alleviates the stress of selling,
with the builder liaising with estate agents and even covering the cost of their
fees.

The Potteries also includes a site located off Synclen Avenue which will include
18 affordable two and three bedroom properties.

Karl added: "For any interested buyers in the area, I would highly recommend
registering their interest online to be kept up-to-date with the development's
launch."

To register interest in The Potteries development, visit www.taylorwimpey.co.uk
or tel: 01434 405205.

LOAD-DATE: April 18, 2015

built in Corbridge - the Cavendish, above, the Sherborne, far left, and

Valley homes for families

SECTION: HOME MAKER;FEATURES; Pg. 73

                                  Korea Times

                            August 26, 2006 Saturday

Housing Price Correction Gaining Momentum

LENGTH: 519 words


By Yoon Ja-young

Apartment prices are continuing to fall in Kangnam, southern Seoul, indicating
that the real estate market has entered a corrective phase on higher property
taxes and other measures to curb home prices, according to real estate brokers
and government officials.

Buying also decreased, reflecting the difficulty in tapping housing loans at
banks, which have recently tightened their loan screening in line with
regulators' guidelines. People seeking to buy homes are also delaying their
purchases on expectations of further falls in prices, brokers said.

At the same time, the actual prices buyers paid were mostly lower than the
market price information posted on various real estate brokerage Web sites.
These prices, lower than those posted on the homepage of Kookmin Bank and other
Internet real estate information providers, are also expected to add further
downward pressure on prices in Seoul and surrounding satellite cities.

The Ministry of Construction and Transportation (MOCT) publicized on the its
homepage (www.moct.go.kr) the actual transaction price information on 2,896 out
of 237,000 housing contracts made in the first half of this year.

It showed that the average prices of apartments in Kangnam, Socho, and Songpa
District fell 14.4 percent to 19.27 million won per pyong (3.3 square meters) in
June, from 22.52 million won in March.

The average price of apartments in five newly constructed satellite cities -
Ilsan, Pundang, Sanbon, Pyongchon and Chungdong - fell even further, plunging
16.5 percent to 9.35 million won per pyong in June from 11.20 million won in
March.

"The data showed that apartment prices peaked in March," when the government
announced the latest anti-speculation steps on March. 30, a ministry official
said.

However, the apartment prices in northern Seoul and other rural cities moved
little, showing a bubble in apartment prices in expensive districts and
satellite cities.

The number of people buying apartments dropped, with the number of transactions
nationwide falling to 33,000 in June from 53,000 in March. Even fewer people
moved to buy apartments in Kangnam, with the number of apartment transactions in
July recording only 20 percent of March's figure.

Potential buyers are expecting prices to fall thanks to government
anti-speculation measures, and according to real estate analysts this
expectation has led to a plunge in prices.

"By announcing the actual transaction prices, we would be able to fix the
distortion in real estate prices, such as price fixing by homeowners," said
Construction and Transportation Minister Choo Byung-jik. Apartment owners often
colluded to fix apartment prices above a certain level, accelerating price hikes
and creating a bubble. As they pushed real estate agents to announce their
apartment prices higher than the actual transaction price, there was a
discrepancy between the two.

Choo added that the real transaction prices will be announced every quarter.
"Though the prices announced by real estate agents haven't fallen much, the
average actual transaction price hit a ceiling in March and began to fall from
April."

LOAD-DATE: August 27, 2006

                               The New York Times

                 July 7, 1981, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

ENVIRONMENTALISTS SEE GAIN FOR ISLANDS IN HOUSE BUDGET

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 729 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6


Environmentalists who for three years have been seeking more Federal protection
for the fragile barrier islands along the Atlantic Coast have gained some
unexpected support in the latest budget action by the House of Representatives.

In one section of the budget bill it passed before its current recess, the House
would forbid issuing any more Federal flood insurance for new housing or new
commercial construction on barrier islands.

In another, it would eliminate most of the funds for rural community
development, in the past a principal source of money for extending sewer and
water supply systems on the less developed barrier islands.

If these two sections survive the House-Senate conference, they will accomplish,
without further legislative battles, a part of what a controversial bill now
pending in Congress seeks to do.

300 Stretched Along Coasts

The more than 300 barrier islands stretching along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts
include such well known areas as Fire Island, Atlantic City, Nahant in
Massachusetts, Rehoboth Beach in Delaware, and the Outer Banks of North
Carolina, as well as Miami Beach and Padre Island in Texas.

Many of these islands are narrow strips of unstable sand with shorelines that
constantly shift under the force of storm-driven surf and ocean currents.

A recent study by the United States Geological Survey disclosed that in the last
30 years urban and built-up areas on barrier islands had increased by 140,000
acres, more than 150 percent. In the same period, their wetland areas, which
protect and sustain fish, shellfish and waterfowl, have decreased by almost
80,000 acres.

Much of the development in this period has been along the beachfronts below
elevations the storm-driven waves reach. Hundreds of beachfront homes have been
washed into the sea. The shoreline in front of hundreds of others has eroded
away, and many of them will also soon fall into the sea.

U.S. Financing for Builders

The environmentalists contend that without federally subsidized flood insurance
developers could not have borrowed money for the housing and commercial
structures that they have built along barrier island shorelines. Nor could
owners rebuild on the same flood-prone sites without this insurance.

These structures, the environmentalists argue, have interrupted the natural
movement of the barrier islands and threatened marine life in the bays and
marshes on their shore sides.

The flood insurance program is available for all flood-susceptible communities
that meet Federal zoning regulations and construction standards. The insurance
is required for federally related financing in flood hazard areas.

From 1978 through 1980 there was an operating deficit averaging $231 on each
Federal policy on barrier island property, which taxpayers financed. In 90
barrier island communities, claims amounting to more than $43 million were paid
in the last two years.

Means of Controlling Development

One means of controlling development, the environmentalists contend, would be to
deny federally subsidized flood insurance on new barrier island structures.
Another would be to take away Federal loans and grants for expansion of water
and electrical systems.

The House budget bill prohibits the sale of Federal flood insurance for any new
barrier island housing. It would also deny the insurance on houses and
commercial structures that were substantially rebuilt after a storm, and it
would cut more than $180 million from rural development funds for the fiscal
year 1982.

The same provisions are included in legislation introduced by Representative
Thomas B. Evans, Republican of Delaware, and Senator John Chaffee, Republican of
Rhode Island. The Evans-Chaffee measure would go further by prohibiting any
Federal financial assistance for construction or for community facilities on any
parts of barrier islands not already developed.

Supporters of the Evans-Chaffee bill are expecting opposition from Southern
Congressmen, many of whose constituents either own property on the more fragile
barrier islands or are building on them.

The Senate's budget bill does not include a denial of Federal flood insurance,
although it also provides deep cuts in community development loan funds.

The flood insurance ban could be lifted by the House-Senate budget conference if
the Senate members refuse to accept it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustrations: Map of U.S.A.
