                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                            August 29, 1999, Sunday

Tenants say apartment complexes mismanaged

BYLINE: AMYLIA WIMMER

SECTION: CITRUS TIMES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1054 words

DATELINE: CRYSTAL RIVER



A report is expected this week detailing the investigation into Jotar
Management, which oversees two complexes.

The manager at Atlantis Arms/Greenleaf Forest apartments was just finishing a
round of phone calls when Carla Hernandez stepped through the office door.

The manager needed to fill a vacancy, but calls to people on the waiting list
hadn't turned up any prospective tenants. Hernandez, who was fleeing a bad
relationship and had no job and no money, thought it was her lucky day.

Hernandez and her two young daughters needed a cheap place to live; the
federally subsidized complex needed a new tenant.

"When my girls and I moved in here, we had no place to go," said Hernandez, 45,
who now works at a day care center. "At that point I didn't care what I had to
do to put a roof over my kids' heads."

That was four years ago. Now Hernandez and her daughters are wondering whether
they will have that roof much longer.

Hernandez has joined a growing list of apartment residents, former complex
employees, law enforcement agencies and neighborhood watch group members who
question how Jotar Management, which manages the apartments for the owners, does
business.

Hernandez and her daughters live in Greenleaf Forest, one of two apartment
complexes built side by side 20 years ago using loans from the federal
government. Rural Development, an arm of the U.S. Department of Agriculture,
pays part or all of the rent for residents of the apartments who qualify for
help.

The agency pays a substantial portion of Hernandez' rent, leaving her to pay $
68 each month for a two-bedroom apartment.

This week, Rural Development is expected to release a report on its
investigation of Jotar, prompted by questions from former Jotar employees and
U.S. Rep. Karen Thurman, D-Dunnellon. That report will include some suggested
improvements but, says Louis Frost, acting state director of Rural Development,
"We didn't find any real smoking guns."

Some residents, frustrated with the management company and convinced that Rural
Development works too closely with Jotar, are wondering where they can turn
next. They say their apartments are in disrepair, Jotar keeps sloppy records,
and the company often tries to collect rent the tenants believe they have
already paid.

Hernandez is among the tenants accused of owing  rent. She said she has tried to
meet with Jotar to go over her rent receipts and has even offered to pay the $
461 the company says she owes - even though she believes she has already paid
it.

"When people are that afraid to let you know what you owe that they will not let
you see what's in your file, they have to be hiding something," Hernandez said.

Jotar, however, says it has tried to get Hernandez to pay her rent.

"She has been a difficult pay throughout her tenancy," said Tim Haines, an
attorney for Jotar. "They have met with her on numerous occasions, and
regardless, she pays late and tried to make partial payments, and they just
haven't been able to work with her."

Jotar filed an eviction notice against her, but as Hernandez waited at the
Citrus County Courthouse for her eviction hearing before County Judge Mark
Yerman on Aug. 20, she learned Jotar had dropped the eviction.

The management company will not say whether it still plans to evict her from the
complex. Hernandez fears the worst and believes Jotar is retaliating against her
for taking her complaints to Thurman's office.

"They don't like me because I just tell it like it is," Hernandez said.

Haines said Hernandez' accusation is groundless.

"We don't ever evict anybody because they complain about the condition of their
apartment," Haines said.

In court filings dealing with her eviction, Hernandez makes other claims against
Jotar that have surfaced before. Among other concerns, residents have said that
each time Jotar hires a new on-site manager to live and work in the complex,
that manager is directed to collect back rent from several residents.

In June, when notices were posted on the doors of residents who Jotar said owed
back rent, they were flooded with people who produced receipts proving they had
made those payments.

In court documents, Hernandez' attorney, John Fogarty of Withlacoochee Area
Legal Aid, says Hernandez has been habitually asked to prove she paid rent.

"Defendant repeatedly attempted to clarify that she does not (owe) any back
rent, and she has done so by showing her past payments to management, and
management has agreed with her," Fogarty wrote. "However, when management
changes, the past rent due resurfaces once again."

Hernandez also has complained because Jotar refused to make necessary repairs
around her apartment - ranging from a broken kitchen utensil drawer to faulty
shower facilities to a stained carpet she was told would be replaced years ago.

Thurman's office contacted Rural Development about Hernandez' concerns. But in a
procedure that frustrates Hernandez and other apartment residents, Rural
Development simply asked Jotar for its position and delivered the message to
Thurman.

"Why didn't they even talk to me?" Hernandez said. "Rural Development never even
asked me for my side."

Jotar began making headlines in the  fall after the Citrus County Sheriff's
Office targeted Atlantis Arms/Greenleaf Forest apartments as one of the county's
most troubled areas.

Frost said the most important concern expressed in Rural Development's report
deals with Jotar's failure to keep an experienced, full-time manager at the
apartments for more than a few months.

"There have been several management turnovers there at a fairly rapid pace,"
Frost said. "Jotar will be told to get a site manager that is experienced and
knows what they're doing, even if they have to pay a site manager some extra
money because of this complex having received a reputation of being a bad
complex to manage."

Tashia Hale, who operates Gainesville-based Jotar, said each time she hires a
new manager, she hopes he or she will stay for a long time. She also said that
Jotar tends to pay its managers more than other complexes do.

And because Jotar has dropped its eviction case against Hernandez, Hale refused
to answer questions about the company's dealings with the tenant.

"Actually, I have no need to respond to those things," she said.

facility, hasn't repaired problems such as a faulty kitchen drawer.

                              The Herald (Glasgow)

                                December 7, 1994

Welsh win rights to prime site East Kilbride a perfect start in Scotland, says
Redrow

SECTION: Pg. 11

LENGTH: 608 words


THE development rights for a 5.7-hectare site at Castleglen, East Kilbride, have
been awarded to a Welsh-based builder, Redrow Homes, the winner of an East
Kilbride Development Corporation design-and-build competition.

Castleglen is an attractive site three kilometres north-west of East Kilbride
town centre. The design guidelines insisted that the quality of the existing
environment, which includes a nearby castle mound, be retained in the design of
the housing development.

By offering the site at a fixed price of £32.2m, and by keeping guidelines to a
minimum, the competition aimed to give the housebuilding industry the
opportunity to come up with innovative ideas in residential layout and design.

A total of 107 design briefs were issued to interested builders following the
marketing of the competition in September. At the closing date, 14 submissions
were considered by the panel of judges.

Alan Bell, development manager at East Kilbride Development Corporation and a
panel member, said: "In the end it was Redrow's ability to integrate all aspects
of the design -- a blend of layout, house types and landscaping -- that stood
out.

"We were especially impressed with the unification of the urban and rural
environment where the landscaped setting, roads and dwellings blend
harmoniously, rather than simply appearing as separate and distinct elements
within a layout dictated by highways design."

The winning submission will provide 100 homes in a "Scottish style" of white
render with slate roof finishes, an unusual touch in an area dominated by red
-brick housing.

Redrow is one of the UK's major housebuilders, selling over 2000 houses last
year. The project marks its first development in Scotland, and construction work
on the site is scheduled to start early next year.

Steve Morgan, chairman of Redrow Group plc, said: "At the time of our flotation,
we announced our intention to launch a new regional operation in Scotland. East
Kilbride is a perfect start for what I am sure will become a very significant
region for the Redrow Group.

"We found the design competition an exciting and challenging formula and look
forward to putting our innovative designs into practice."

This is the second such competition run by the East Kilbride Corporation; a
competition was in June last year to develop the one remaining site at
Stewartfield, the largest private housing development in the west of Scotland.

Redrow celebrated its 20th anniversary this year, having grown from a one-man
business to a £185m-turnover organisation which provides employment for more
than 800 staff and 4000 sub-contractors.

The business was founded in 1974 by chairman Steve Morgan, then aged 21, with a
£5000 short-term loan from his father. In those early days the company operated
from the spare bedroom of Steve's bungalow in Rhyl, and concentrated on civil
engineering contracts.

During the early Eighties, Redrow began its diversification into housebuilding.
Acquisitions and organic growth both played a part in the company's development,
with the purchases of Whelmar Homes in 1987 and Costain Homes in 1993
representing significant milestones.

Redrow grew to become Britain's largest privately owned housebuilder prior to
its flotation on the London Stock Market in May 1994. The company recently
announced its first annual results as a plc, reporting profits of more than
£21m. More than 2000 houses were sold in the last financial year.

The company, which is also active in the commercial property, contracting and
interior design sectors, will seek a new base in Scotland.

                                  Burton Mail

                            February 9, 2004 Monday

Village post office plans thrown out

BYLINE: LAURIE COOMBS

LENGTH: 392 words


PLANS for a satellite post office in a South Derbyshire village have been thrown
out amid security fears.

Elderly residents in Kendrick's Close, Hartshorne, have hit out at Post Office
plans to house the part-time facility in the village's community hall, which is
situated behind their sheltered housing complex. Councillors refused the plans
during a meeting of South Derbyshire District Council's housing and community
services committee after a survey showed the majority of residents were strongly
against the proposals. In August, postmaster David Shadrack retired from the
village's Repton Road post office, but has since stayed on because a replacement
could not be found.

The Post Office proposed that a visiting sub-postmaster use Kendrick's Close two
mornings a week and provide a partial post office for residents who would have
difficulty getting to an alternative branch. The service would have been
provided from the communal lounge in the community hall and would have provided
pensions and allowances, postage stamps, utility bill paying, saving stamps,
National Savings Bank and personal banking. The Post Office was prepared to pay
rent to use the room and any profit from the arrangement would have been used to
provide equipment or social activities for Kendrick's Close residents as part of
the sheltered housing scheme. Bosses had previously suggested the satellite post
office be set up in Hartshorne Village Hall, but this was refused as it is
situated at the top of a steep hill and was not easily accessible to elderly
residents. Hartshorne's district councillor, Roy Bell, said: "These residents
are all elderly, and all 14 bungalows in the scheme are away from the road.
"They were concerned that, to access the community hall, people would have to
walk past their doors, which they felt was a security risk. "They have made
their decision and the Post Office is now endeavouring to find an alternative
site." Post Office spokesman Jane Beese said: "We are now looking at setting up
a part time post office in Dethick Hall, in Manchester Lane, as an extension of
the satellite services at Donisthorpe and Blackfordby. "This is in the early
stages and we will be consulting residents to ensure everyone is happy. "We aim
to maintain Post Office services in the area because we recognise how vital the
service is in rural areas."

LOAD-DATE: July 9, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        SUNDAY TELEGRAM (Massachusetts)

                               May 7, 2006 Sunday
                                 NORTH EDITION

Mobile home park gets support of Lunenburg voters

BYLINE: Lynne Klaft, CORRESPONDENT

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 766 words

DATELINE: LUNENBURG


After considerable time and discussion, town meeting voters yesterday voted
unanimously in favor of providing sewer and water lines to Meadow Woods Mobile
Home Park.

Both the Board of Selectmen and the Finance Committee had voted to approve
recommendation of Article 16, in which the town proposed to apply for federal
rural development grants and low-interest loans to install a sewer line and
water lines to the park at 1790 Massachusetts Ave.

Three hundred residents, visitors and consultants had crowded the Lunenburg High
School auditorium to begin the annual town meeting yesterday morning.

Newly elected Town Moderator Timothy W. Murphy began the meeting by asking
residents to "turn off your noisemakers - phones, beepers; no hissing, no booing
or hollering," to a round of applause.

With 57 warrant articles to discuss and vote, the meeting was recessed at 4:30
p.m. until 7 p.m. Monday at the high school. Fewer than half of the articles had
been resolved, many with votes so close that hand counts were demanded by
residents.

In discussion about the mobile home park, chief administrative and financial
officer Daniel M. Keyes said a federal loan for 40 years would carry a 4.5
percent interest rate and the grant will be 30 percent to 70 percent of the
estimated $4.1 million cost.

"There will be no betterment assessment to the town. This will be paid for by
the owners and residents of the park," he said.

Selectman David W. Rodgers estimated that park residents may have to pay $136
per month for the sewer and water service.

The mobile home park is in receivership. Sixty-six trailer homes and an
estimated 130 people were affected by the vote.

"Most of these people have nowhere to go and can't afford high rents," said
court-appointed lawyer Peter Delchinos. "If this measure is not passed, the park
will be condemned and the town will be responsible for relocating these people."

"We understand the high cost of living. We are also paying mortgages," said park
resident Lanny A. Bentley Sr. "If the vote is no, we will lose our homes and
still have to continue paying our mortgages. The judge will have no choice."

At this point, Mr. Bentley asked residents of the park to stand up. "These are
your friends and neighbors. Please vote so that we can still have our homes."

The mobile home park has a diverse cross-section of young and old, working and
retired, and disabled people among its residents.

David Connors, EarthTech engineer for the project, said a 200-foot mound would
have to be built on site to accommodate a septic system, and the six wells
serving the park provide very poor water quality and quantity.

George Emond, chairman of the Board of Health, informed town meeting that the
board has been involved in the case for more than three years. "The park has
been privately owned for 50 to 60 years, and is now inoperable through neglect."

According to Mr. Emond, the septic system for the park is on the verge of
failure and the state will not allow an on-site system to be installed. Water
pressure is very low and water must be supplemented on a regular basis.

The board filed suit in Massachusetts Housing Court; the owner has been found to
be in contempt and is being fined.

"Repayment of the funding will be decided by the judge," Mr. Emond said.

If the park owner decides to sell the property after the improvements have been
made, the residents have first right of refusal.

In addition to the unanimous vote to support the mobile home park improvements,
town meeting also approved an article unanimously providing an easement through
one of the park resident's lot.

Three capital expense articles were approved by two-thirds vote: $275,000 to
rehabilitate the Ritter building for town government use; $346,798 for equipment
and vehicles; and $50,000 for Department of Public Works renovations. The
measures also need a majority vote at the town election May 20.

Voters also unanimously approved $150,000 for state-mandated landfill
maintenance; seven consent articles; $32,079 in lease payments; $35,000 for a
playground; and demolition of the old public safety building.

Defeated articles included $225,000 for drainage improvements on Summer Street;
charter revisions; a bylaw to appoint a Sewer Commission; and $200,000 for Town
Hall renovations.

Articles still to be discussed include the operational budget for town
government, $26.8 million; $450,000 for an athletic field, $275,000 for a storm
water management plan; easements; two dog articles; a land swap; sale of town
property; zoning changes; elderly property tax abatements; and a study of
elected official stipends.

                          Kitsap Sun, Bremerton, Wash.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 5, 2010 Saturday

Former Owner of Stalled Woods View Development Files For Bankruptcy

BYLINE: Chris Henry, Kitsap Sun, Bremerton, Wash.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 899 words


Jun. 5--MANCHESTER -- Darlene Piper, South Kitsap attorney and real estate
entrepreneur who was a principal partner in the controversial Woods View
development, has filed for bankruptcy.

The property is now owned by Woods View II LLC, in which Piper had an interest
until 2008. It was to be sold at auction Friday by the lien holder, First
Citizens Bank & Trust of Tacoma. But the sale was rescheduled until July 9 due
to Piper's filing for bankruptcy May 6 in U.S. District Court in Tacoma, said
Terrence Donahue, attorney for First Citizens.

Court documents show Piper's net worth just shy of $1.3 million, but she owes
more than $18 million to creditors, including contractors on the partially
competed Woods View development at the corner of Woods and Farmer Dell roads.

Piper had an interest in other stalled developments, including the Quail Park
senior housing project in East Bremerton and Lundberg Landing in South Kitsap.
According to bankruptcy documents, a half dozen properties in which she has or
has had an interest are in foreclosure or have already been sold off.

Piper said her financial difficulties stem from a number of factors. A partner
filed for bankruptcy last year, and six of her commercial tenants closed
businesses, went bankrupt or otherwise breached their leases.

Two of the banks with which Piper had loans were taken over by the Federal
Deposit Insurance Corporation in 2009. First Citizens was formerly Venture Bank.
Federal-loss share agreements, which compensate the new bank for losses on loans
it assumes, serve as a disincentive to work with clients and resolve
foreclosures, Piper said.

Of all Piper's ventures, Woods View drew the most attention. Slated for 78 lots
on 12 acres, the project launched a widespread discussion of tiny "legacy lots"
that are located in many rural areas of Kitsap County.

The development, widely recognized as urban-scale development in a rural area,
was approved in March 2009 in Kitsap County Superior Court after a series of
appeals by the Beaver Creek Conservation Group.

The group raised many objections to the project, including a provision for a
large on-site sewage treatment system. Kitsap County subsequently issued a
moratorium on LOSS systems in rural areas, although the Woods View system is
vested. The LOSS ordinance, in a revised form, is set to be adopted into county
code June 14.

Delays caused by the neighbors' appeals were damaging but not fatal, Piper said.
Two homes were built and quickly sold.

"We had a builder lined up and numerous pre-sales for houses in the development
because they were competitively priced, $250,000 and less," she said.

But resistance to the project on the part of county officials ultimately led to
its undoing, Piper claims.

In December, Woods View II LLC filed suit against Kitsap County on Piper's
behalf, alleging county officials negligently delayed permitting for Woods View
and intentionally thwarted developers' efforts to get the LOSS system up and
running. Interference from the county caused one lender to back away, court
documents state.

Originally filed in Pierce County Superior Court, the case has been moved to
U.S. District Court in Tacoma. County officials have no comment on the lawsuit.

Piper's claim alleges former county administrator Cris Gears wrote to state
health and environmental officials discouraging them from approving the on-site
system, which in turn led to Karcher Creek Sewer District (now West Sound
Utility District) backing out as the municipal oversight agency.

Also named in the suit are Larry Keeton, the county's development director, and
deputy prosecuting attorney Shelly Kneip.

Dave Walden of John L. Scott Real Estate of Port Orchard, listing agent for
Woods View, said the LOSS issue has discouraged some potential buyers. Currently
there is a market for discounted plats among out-of-state companies able to bide
their time until the economy improves, Walden said. He showed the property
Friday, but the LOSS proved a sticking point.

According to Walden, another option for whoever ends up owning the property
would be to let it revert to a lesser density.

But Piper said a plan for managing the LOSS is in place and Woods View remains
viable. The state Department of Health approved contracts the developers had
signed with Aqua Test, a private company in Black Diamond, to operate the LOSS.
Another sewer district has agreed to serve as the third-party overseer, as
required by state law.

On the issue of legacy lots, Piper said, the county needs to clarify its code so
that property owners, developers and those who object to the lots can have
certainty of what's allowed and what isn't.

The county is developing new policies to do just that, Keeton said Wednesday.
Legacy lots and LOSS are associated in the public's mind, he said, because the
on-site sewer is one of the few options available for the small lots. But Keeton
said it made sense for the department of community development to address each
prickly issue separately.

http://www.kitsapsun.com. Copyright (c) 2010, Kitsap Sun, Bremerton, Wash.

                              The Herald (Glasgow)

                            December 21, 2007 Friday
                                 Final Edition

Property chief says financial market is a black hole

BYLINE: SIMON BAIN

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 39

LENGTH: 488 words


A LARGE star burns, explodes into a supernova and collapses into a dense mass of
increasing gravitational attraction. . . the financial market presently
resembles a black hole into which increasing quantities and categories of credit
are disappearing."

So says Douglas Lowe, chairman of AIM-listed property group Caledonian Trust, in
his annual economic dissertation to shareholders in the company's annual results
statement.

Lowe says banks stoked up the crisis by securitising highrisk loans, using
"effectively a financial philosopher's stone that transmutes low-grade credit
into investment grade loans".

He notes: "The Hudson Institute now estimates writeoffs in America will be
dollars-600bn-dollars-800bn (GBP302bnGBP402bn). It seems incredible that in 1998
it was considered a crisis when LTCM collapsed leaving total debts of. . . just
dollars-3bn."

On the bombed-out property market, he begins: "When force is applied to a pure
homogeneous quartz crystal, it, unlike an impure crystal, does not exhibit any
change or 'foreshock' as the force is increased until, without warning, it
shatters."

He goes on: "Bank investment has increased, more and more complex . . .
investment vehicles have been created, reasonable expectation of returns has
diminished progressively and depended more and more on increasing capital values
rather than rental growth, while financing costs rise, and . . . latterly taxi
drivers and student bar staff first asked advice on, and then gave advice on,
such investments."

He concludes that UK investment property "appears over-priced as rental growth
is likely to be limited, yields are likely to rise further and effective
interest rates will continue to be high".

Residential property would fall in price in the short term, but in the long term
prices would continue to rise.

"Neither current nor prospective economic conditions will detract from the
opportunity of uncovering specific situations from which substantial value can
be created by effecting planning change."

Caledonian now owns 15 rural development sites, most of them in Perthshire where
new planning policy on the conversion of steadings is already being implemented.
It also holds "four significant city centre sites, two small sites in the
Edinburgh area and 73 plots near Dunbar, " in addition to its investment
portfolio The group has reported a loss of GBP244,153 in the year to June 30,
2007, compared with a profit of GBP129,509 last year - though the second half
showed a profit of GBP154,431. Interest costs jumped by GBP464,587 to GBP508,093
due to significantly higher borrowings and slightly higher interest rates.

The trust's current year results would "continue to reflect the early stage of
the development cycle", as the first development site would not be completed
this year, Lowe said.

His analysis concludes: "I expect growth to be curtailed but a recession
narrowly avoided and damage to the UK economy to be limited."

                          Sunday Telegraph (Australia)

                            January 13, 2008 Sunday
                            Y - Money & You Edition

MONEY MATTERS

SECTION: FINANCE; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 788  words


How to help poor to help themselves

The credit crisis may be fouling billion-dollar takeover deals, but if you're a
poor African seamstress who needs a loan for a new sewing machine, you could not
ask for a better borrowing market to expand your business.

Anybody with as little as $US25 to spare ($A28.75) can now fund third-world
entrepreneurs and give them a much-needed helping hand, through a revolutionary
new Internet site.

The www.kiva.org site, a ``micro-financing'' website, matches individual lenders
with impoverished entrepreneurs in the developing world.

Steve Thomas, 50, a Chicago tax consultant, got started by lending $US50
($A57.50) to a man in Togo, who makes a living refurbishing used sneakers for
resale. The loan was repaid in full and Thomas has gone on to fund 83 more
ventures, from a cyber cafe in Ecuador to mushroom-growing in Moldova.

Micro-lending has been in use for decades. Muhammad Yunus shared the 2006 Nobel
Peace Prize with Grameen Bank, the lender he founded in the early 1980s to help
empower Bangladesh's rural poor. Several other institutions have developed since
then, but Kiva is the first to open direct micro-lending opportunities to the
general public with an online platform.

Kiva hit the publicity jackpot in September when Oprah Winfrey featured the
organisation on her daytime TV show, attracting a tidal wave of interest from
Middle America. Its 211,000 users have lent a total of $US18.7 million ($A21.51
million).

Demand was so high, on the day the episode aired, that every loan bid on the
site was met. Since then, Kiva has limited lenders to a $US25 portion of each
loan, the average of which is about $US600 ($A690.25). Even with the $US25 cap,
Kiva's lenders manage to fully fund each loan in 0.97 days, on average.

Aiesha Turman, 33, was web-surfing when she stumbled upon Kiva. Intrigued by the
organisation's name, which comes from the Swahili word for ``agreement'' or
``unity'','' the Brooklyn-based museum educator browsed through lender profiles.
She identified with a Tanzanian shopkeeper who shared the same first name and,
like Turman, was mother to one child.

The shopkeeper paid Turman back in full, consistent with 99.82 per cent of all
Kiva loans. Instead of reclaiming her $US25, she went on to fund new loans,
zeroing in on women with children.

``It's particularly harder for women, in general, to move up the ladder, but
especially in a developing nation,'' Turman said, adding that, by lending to
mothers, ``you're not just helping an individual, you're helping a community.''

Turman and Thomas say they don't mind not earning any interest on the loans they
make. The interest charged to the borrowers goes mostly toward the
administration of the loan, which can be expensive and time-consuming in areas
where infrastructure is barely developed.

The average interest rates charged by Kiva's field partners is 22 per cent,
though the rates range from 4 per cent to 50 per cent. Rates are determined by
the region and by the size of the local organisation and the services they offer
to borrowers. In some parts of Latin America, loan rates of 50 per cent are
still cheaper than borrowing from a local money lender, whose rates can top 100
per cent. Despite earning only an emotional return, lenders are snapping up loan
requests almost as fast as Kiva's partners can add new borrowers. For more
details, visit www.kiva.org

Quick fix for rate rises

ONE in three people looking to take a new mortgage soon will fix their interest
rate, according to a survey by the Mortgage and Finance Association of Australia
(MFAA) and BankWest.

The MFAA's Phil Naylor said: ``There is concern in the market about the prospect
of another rate rise in February and this may be fuelling a rush of people
locking-in their rates.

``Our survey has shown that the November rate rise was reasonably well tolerated
by borrowers, but that the pain is getting closer. According to our stats, about
39.3 per cent of people will be uncomfortable or very uncomfortable with another
0.25 per cent rate rise.''

Home units galore

A surge in building approvals -- effectively, the number of new properties being
built -- is fuelling fresh optimism about the housing market, which has been
underperforming for years.

More approvals will mean more supply in a year or so's time and that could help
ease Sydney's rental crisis and also slow house-price growth, which is being
squeezed up by lack of supply, despite high interest rates.

Commsec's Craig James said: ``The latest building figures result was boosted by
a massive increase in NSW apartment approvals. Investors may also be warming to
higher house prices and surging rents, starting to shift attention from the
sharemarket to the property market.''

                             National Mortgage News

                                February 1, 1999

Let Prosperity Reach Further

BYLINE: BY ROBERT E. RUBIN, Treasury Secretary; Mr. Rubin recently addressed the
Wall Street Project Conference, where he talked about ways the government is
promoting development in distressed areas.  His excerpted remarks are presented
as our Open Forum.

SECTION: OPEN FORUM; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 796 words


There is an enormous amount to do to promote growth and opportunity in America's
urban and rural economically distressed areas, places fraught with poverty and
economic duress.

I have long held the belief -- and more importantly, President Clinton deeply
believes -- that this country will fall far short of its full economic potential
for all Americans, unless our least well off have a real opportunity to join the
economic mainstream.

Providing this opportunity is not simply a social issue or a moral issue, but an
economic issue of great personal importance to each of us.

The foundation for a successful strategy of promoting growth in distressed areas
is strong economic growth, which in turn creates a tighter labor market, as we
have now, and thereby increases the availability of jobs and tends to increase
incomes at all levels.

Beyond economic growth, this Administration has focused on three key areas --
three areas that are mutually reinforcing -- to promote opportunity and growth
in the inner cities and other distressed areas: investing in people through
education and training; improving public safety, by putting 100,000 new police
on the streets, enacting tougher gun laws and other measures; and -- in an area
we are intensely focused on at Treasury -- expanding access to capital.  Let me
now focus on that third area for a few moments.

Despite the fact that financial markets in the United States are today the most
innovative, the broadest and deepest in the world, we still have a severe
shortage of financial institutions and credit to create housing and jobs in our
inner cities and distressed rural communities.

As a reflection of the importance we place on these issues, we have established,
for the first time in the history of the Treasury Department, an office
specializing in these issues, as well as on tax incentives for development in
distressed areas, the Office of Community Development Policy.  Through that
office we are focusing on three fundamental challenges going forward.

First, we must protect the Community Reinvestment Act, which expands access to
capital from mainstream financial institutions.  We have greatly improved CRA by
streamlining its regulations so that they focus on performance, not paperwork.
CRA has been an enormous success.  Over the last six years, according to
non-profit community groups, banks and thrifts have made commitments to provide
over $ 1 trillion in capital to low income communities.  Home Mortgage
Disclosure Act data shows that since 1993, home loans to African-Americans have
increased by 58 percent, to Hispanics by 62 percent, to Asians by 29 percent and
to low and moderate income borrowers by 38 percent, all well above the overall
market.

Second, we must strengthen the Community Development Financial Institutions
Fund, or CDFI Fund.  We will ask Congress this year for $ 125 million for the
CDFI Fund in the new budget to give this critical program the necessary
resources to continue its success.  Over the last several years we have
implemented President Clinton's vision of a CDFI fund, which gives funding to
small, community development organizations.

Third, we must build on our efforts to encourage economic growth in low income
communities through tax incentives for business investment.  Over the last
several years, we have enacted a number of incentives, from the so-called
brownfields tax incentive to spur the clean up and redevelopment of thousands of
abandoned, environmentally contaminated sites in under-served communities to two
rounds of Empowerment Zones.

We made the low income housing tax credit permanent, and we are now proposing to
expand it by 40 percent.

Building on these efforts, the President announced today (Jan. 15) a proposal
for a new tax incentive to spur the private sector to make equity investments to
help grow businesses in our nation's cities and rural communities.  This New
Markets Tax Credit could help foster $ 6 billion in new equity investment in
low-income communities over the next five years.  A community development
investment fund, if selected, would be able to offer potential investors a 6
percent tax credit for five years, cutting the investors' cost of capital by 25
percent.

This past year has been a year of significant crisis in the global economy, a
crisis that has affected hundreds of millions of people around the globe, in
nearly every country, including our own.  While we must be and have been
intensely focused on this crisis, because our own economic well being is
integrally related to the well being of the global economy, we must also remain
focused on being strong at home, and making sure the residents of our distressed
areas have a real opportunity to enter the economic mainstream.
